title: RealAIGI: An Innovative Dataset for Enhanced Detection of Real and AI-Generated Images
authors: Md Mahinur Alam, Kanita Jerin Tanha, Md Raihan Subhan, Taesoo Jun
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: The rapid advancement of generative neural networks has facilitated the creation of photorealistic images, raising concerns about the proliferation of misinformation. Detecting AI-generated fakes has become crucial, given their potential impact on public opinion and various sectors. This paper introduces RealAIGI, a novel dataset for real and AI-generated images, created using the advanced diffusion transformer model Sora. We demonstrate the applicability of this dataset through comprehensive evaluations, showing its effectiveness in AI-generated image detection. The dataset was tested using CNN and ViT models, achieving remarkable performance against benchmark datasets IEEE VIP Cup and DE-FAKE. Our results show that the dataset enhances detection accuracy and robustness, offering significant improvements over existing datasets.

title: Experimental Results on High-Intensity Magnetic Field Generation From a Capacitive Pulse Modulator
authors: M. G. AlYousef, P. Bahdanovich, S. AlDahmani, D. Leonenka, Y. Vasileuski, H. AlKetbi, Y. AlNuaimi, M. AlKaabi, F. Albarracin, M. AlMansoori, F. Vega, C. Kasmi
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The paper presents the development and experimental validation of a high-intensity pulsed magnetic field generation system utilizing a capacitor bank, a mechanical switch and a loop antenna. An RLC circuit model of the generator connected to the circuit model of the loop antenna was analyzed to estimate the magnetic field generated by the system [1]. These analytical results were verified by numerical simulation carried out in CST Studio Suite®.

title: Leveraging Deep Learning Methodology to Automate Knee Osteoarthritis Identification based on X-ray Images
authors: Munnangi Swapna, Mohammad Omar Sabri, Sugunakar Mamidala, Krishnamoorthi K, SNaveen Kumar, Chandi Priya K.G
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Knee osteoarthritis (KOA) is a leading cause of chronic disability worldwide, commonly diagnosed using radiographic imaging and evaluated using the Kellgren-Lawrence (KL) grading scale. X-rays would require manual interpretation, which is long, most likely to inter-observer variation, and could not be used in mass screening. The research provides a hypothesis that an automated model that relies on deep learning can be used to classify the severity of KOA and identify it with the use of X-ray images of the knees. A variety of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) paired with attention-enhanced modules (e.g., CBAM) is used, as well as architecture or variants including Transformer blocks and Capsule Networks. The model pipeline will entail the robust preprocessing methods-image normalization, histogram equalization, Gaussian noise, and rigorous data augmentation. The classification of the images is done on the KL scale (grades 0-4) and it is trained through cross-entropy loss and an adaptive optimizer such as Adam. The evaluation measures are accuracy, precision, recall and F1-score. Nevertheless, CNN+Transformer and CNN-CBAM models had the highest accuracy of 96.59% and 96.15%, which is better compared to the traditional architectures such as CNN-VGG16 and MobileNetV2 architectures. Grad-CAM was used to offer visual explanation, indicating pathological locations of joints, the demand of clinical trust. The models have been compared with the known traditional classifiers (SVM, Random Forest) over handcrafted features (HOG, LBP) and deep models performed better in all of the metrics. This paper proves that deep learning may contribute massively to diagnostic accuracy in KOA identification and unloading radiologists. In the future, the system to assess multi-joint osteoarthritis will be expanded, and real-time inference will be incorporated into clinical practice.

title: A Technical Survey on Uplink Capacity Enhancement in Direct-to-Cell (D2C) Systems: Toward Cooperative LEO Satellite Architectures
authors: Tae Hoon Yoon, Can Zheng, Fitsum Debebe Tilahun, Chung G. Kang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: Direct-to-Cell (D2C) connectivity via LEO satellite networks offers a promising path to extend mobile coverage to underserved regions. However, challenges such as limited link budgets, uplink interference, and beam management must be addressed. This paper surveys key technologies for uplink capacity enhancement, including regenerative payloads, interference mitigation, beamforming, and distributed antenna systems. It aims to guide future research and support scalable D2C network de-velopment in non-terrestrial systems.

title: Influence of Ferrite Dimensions on Gyromagnetic Nonlinear Transmission Lines
authors: F.S. Yamasaki, J.O. Rossi, J.J. Barroso, E. Schamiloglu, L.P. Silva Neto
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Gyromagnetic nonlinear transmission lines (GNLTLs) have attracted considerable attention in electrical engineering and applied physics due to their unique electromagnetic properties and applications. These structures are well-suited for generating radio frequency (RF) signals in systems such as radar, mobile defense platforms, and satellite communications. GNLTL operation is based on a coaxial configuration with ferrite cores magnetically saturated by the superposition of axial and azimuthal fields, resulting in RF oscillations at the output. This study utilizes a 60-cm gyromagnetic line to generate GHz-range RF signals with the axial magnetic bias supplied by a solenoid integrated into a custom test bench. A high-voltage pulse generator fed two GNLTLs built using two Amidon Ni-Zn ferrites of distinct size (models FB43-201 and FB43-101). The objective is to assess how variations in ferrite geometry (specifically inner and outer ferrite diameters) affect the transmission line's performance. Results indicate that ferrite dimensions significantly influence signal characteristics, underscoring the role of magnetic saturation in determining the efficiency of GNLTL. These findings support the optimization of GNLTL design for advanced RF applications.

title: A Monte Carlo Tree Search-Based Algorithm for Workflow Scheduling
authors: Bocong Zhao, Mingyuan Cai, Mengbing Zhou, Yang Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: We present an efficient algorithm for workflow scheduling, where the resource-request graph can be modeled as a directed acyclic graph (DAG) to enable parallel execution. Our algorithm employs Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS) to enhance resource utilization by fully leveraging the probability distribution of task execution times, rather than relying solely on a single execution time estimate. Building on this foundation, we introduce several targeted optimizations to traditional Monte Carlo Simulation (MCS) to overcome the limitations of static scheduling strategies when addressing the uncertainty of execution makespans. We developed a prototype system, named scDAG, which is a functionally extended and enhanced version of the CloudSim framework. Through implementation and experiments on scDAG, our algorithm demonstrates a superior approach to workflow scheduling. In addition, we analyze and compare the experimental data, revealing significant improvements. Our work ultimately achieves better performance by minimizing workflow scheduling time.

title: An Alternating Mode Strategy for Adaptive Sound Field Control and Acoustic Path Tracking
authors: Junqing Zhang, Jingli Xie, Dongyuan Shi, Wen Zhang, Jingdong Chen, Jacob Benesty
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Sound field control (SFC) aims to accurately reproduce a desired sound field within a specified region, which requires both adaptation to input signal characteristics and precise estimation of acoustic paths between loudspeakers and microphones. To meet these demands, two adaptive algorithms are proposed. The first is a signal-adaptive multichannel filteredx least-mean-square (MCFxLMS) filter designed to handle nonstationary input signals such as speech and music. The second is an acoustic path tracking algorithm that incorporates an input signal decorrelation strategy, enabling robust tracking of multichannel room impulse responses (RIRs) even under highly correlated excitation. Additionally, an alternating modeswitching mechanism is introduced to dynamically activate each algorithm based on predefined criteria. This approach can reduce computational complexity in large-scale multichannel systems while preserving sound field fidelity within the control region.

title: Hybrid LLM-Enhanced Intrusion Detection for Zero-Day Threats in IoT Networks
authors: Mohammad F Al-Hammouri, Yazan Otoum, Rasha Atwa, Amiya Nayak
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to intrusion detection by integrating traditional signature-based methods with the contextual understanding capabilities of the GPT-2 Large Language Model (LLM). As cyber threats become increasingly sophisticated, particularly in distributed, heterogeneous, and resource-constrained environments such as those enabled by the Internet of Things (IoT), the need for dynamic and adaptive Intrusion Detection Systems (IDSs) becomes increasingly urgent. While traditional methods remain effective for detecting known threats, they often fail to recognize new and evolving attack patterns. In contrast, GPT-2 excels at processing unstructured data and identifying complex semantic relationships, making it well-suited to uncovering subtle, zero-day attack vectors. We propose a hybrid IDS framework that merges the robustness of signature-based techniques with the adaptability of GPT-2-driven semantic analysis. Experimental evaluations on a representative intrusion dataset demonstrate that our model enhances detection accuracy by 6.3%, reduces false positives by 9.0%, and maintains near real-time responsiveness. These results affirm the potential of language model integration to build intelligent, scalable, and resilient cybersecurity defences suited for modern connected environments.

title: A Lighweight Distributed Security Protocol with Adaptative Key Management for Programmable Matter Based on Modular Robots
authors: Youssou Faye, Abdallah Makhoul, Serigne Mbacke Diene, Mohammed Ouzzif
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: Programmable matter can change its physical properties and, more likely, its shape, depending on internal or external action. Here, we approach programmable matter in the context of micro-robots, millimeter-sized mobile microcomputers that can move around each other, communicate, change color and hook onto other micro-robots to form different shapes. The current challenges are both hardware and software. The main research challenges are diverse and varied, and focus on self-configuration, clustering, synchronization time, decision-making, analysis of detected data and security. To date, very little work has been done in the field of security, and this does not take into account possible developments relating to the material itself, whose physical configuration underpins exchange and self-reconfiguration protocols. In this paper, we propose a solution that takes current security concerns into account, and which may be able to adapt to a future evolution of programmable matter based on modular robots. This solution is based on resource-saving cryptographic mechanisms to implement a robust authentication solution and a flexible key management mechanism coupled with a confidential data exchange of the structure formed.

title: An Efficient Transfer Learning Method Based on Adapter with Local Attributes for Speech Emotion Recognition
authors: Haoyu Song, Ian McLoughlin, Qing Gu, Nan Jiang, Yan Song
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Existing speech emotion recognition (SER) methods commonly suffer from the lack of high-quality large-scale corpus, partly due to the complex, psychological nature of emotion which makes accurate labeling difficult and time consuming. Recently, transfer learning based methods that exploit the encoders pretrained on large-scale speech corpus (e.g., Wav2Vec2.0 and HuBERT) have shown strong potential for downstream SER tasks. However, task-specific finetuning remains necessary for various conversational scenarios of different topics, speakers and languages to achieve satisfactory performance. It generally requires costly encoder retraining for individual SER tasks. To address this issue, we propose to train an adapter with local attributes for efficient transfer learning. Specifically, a weighted average pooling-Transformer (WAP-Transformer) is proposed as a lightweight backbone to enrich the frame-level representation. An adapter with teacher-student branches is exploited for task-agnostic transfer learning, where the student branch is jointly optimized via mask prediction and self-distillation objectives, and the teacher branch is obtained online from the student via exponential moving average (EMA). Meanwhile, local attributes are learned from the teacher branch via unsupervised clustering, which aims to act as a universal model that provides additional semantic-rich supervisions. A statistical attentive pooling (SAP) module is proposed to obtain utterance representation for finetuning. To evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed adapter with local attributes, extensive experiments have been conducted on IEMOCAP. Superior performance has been reported, compared to the previous state-of-the-art methods in similar settings.

title: Dementia Prediction From Speech Signal Using Optimized Prosodic Features
authors: Bagus Tris Atmaja, Sakriani Sakti
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Early detection of dementia, a general term for cognitive decline, is vital for enhancing patient care and management. Conventional clinical assessments and cognitive tests require expert clinicians and are time-consuming. Therefore, developing rapid and reliable in-house detection methods is highly desirable. Prior studies have identified speech-based early markers of dementia, motivating the application of machine learning for automated detection. This study investigates the effectiveness of optimized prosodic features, with a focus on pause-related metrics, for dementia classification. Experimental evaluation of 15 selected features shows that pause and formant features are the most discriminative, achieving improved classification performance over the original 45-feature set. These findings suggest that concise, targeted feature sets can enhance automated speech-based dementia detection.

title: Compact Function-Based Modeling of Storage Throughput for an Autonomous Distributed Storage System
authors: Atsushi Nunome, Hiroaki Hirata
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: We are developing an autonomous distributed storage system that efficiently utilizes networked storage resources with minimal management overhead. The system comprises heterogeneous storage nodes and autonomously reallocates data blocks based on their usage. In such environments, effective performance of the storage nodes must be considered when deciding data block migration. Accurate estimation of effective performance is essential for selecting appropriate destinations, but frequent data collection from many nodes incurs overhead and can degrade performance. This paper proposes a four-parameter sigmoid-based model to approximate effective throughput and an optimized eight-byte encoding scheme to reduce communication cost. Evaluation results show that the model closely fits actual throughput, with the encoding introducing only about 1.2% increase in residual sum of squares despite rounding.

title: Automated Feeding System for Laboratory Animals
authors: Feng Wang, Xueli Tian, Yuping Zhang, Xinru Li, Xuexia Ding, Zhanxiu Cai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: Laboratory animals are widely used, increasing the demand for the standardization and precision of their management. Traditional manual feeding methods are prone to time and operational errors, which lead to irregular feeding patterns for experimental animals, affecting the accuracy and reproducibility of experimental data. Therefore, designing an intelligent and efficient automatic feeder for experimental animals is significant. We designed software and hardware in this study. We developed the main program, the feeding control subprogram, the automatic leftover cleaning control subprogram, and the automatic water supply control subprogram. The hardware comprised the food supply control circuit, automatic leftover cleaning control circuit, and infrared sensing water supply circuit. The developed system employed Keil 5 for programming and Proteus 8.17 for simulation. Keil5 was used for code development and compilation, as well as program debugging, providing an integrated development environment. Proteus 8.17 was used for circuit design and simulation, building virtual hardware circuits. The developed feeding system operates precisely and conducts quantitative control, automatic operation, and remote interaction. The system effectively improves experimental efficiency and reduces errors caused by manual intervention.

title: Vehicle Damage Detection Using Fusion of Mixture of Experts
authors: Kamching Cheng, Yu Yong Poh, Lim Tong Ming
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: Manual vehicle damage inspection is a significant challenge in insurance claim processing due to processing delays, evaluator bias, and variability in judgment of assessors. While deep learning has advanced for general object detection, current models exhibit performance degradation when confronted with visually subtle, low-frequency, or small-scale damage types, especially under imbalanced training conditions. Therefore, we developed a scalable vehicle damage classification system based on the mixture of experts (MoE) architecture. Three model variants are introduced in the system: (1) RawMoE, which relies on raw RGB inputs; (2) ResMoE-50, incorporating pretrained ResNet-50 feature embeddings; and (3) CropResMoE-50, which integrates region-based cropping, scale-aware analysis, and focal loss for class imbalance mitigation. Evaluated on the Car Damage Detection dataset, the final model achieved 89.30% test accuracy and macro-average precision of 91.83%, demonstrating robust performance across categories and object sizes. The results highlight how expert specialization, adaptive loss weighting, and spatial preprocessing enable reliable and context-sensitive damage detection suitable for real-world insurance deployment.

title: Design, Manufacturing and Testing of a $115 \text{kV} / 54 ~\mathrm{A}$ Pulse Transformer Assembly for the Fair Plinac
authors: Max Collins, Sven Pütz
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: To generate the required antiproton beam intensity for the FAIR PANDA experiment, a dedicated proton LINAC (pLINAC) for the FAIR accelerator chain is being constructed. Klystron modulators are power converters within the high-power RF system of the pLINAC. Here, seven modulator systems with a nominal pulse power amplitude of 115 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{kV} / 54 ~\mathrm{A}$</tex>, an effective pulse width of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$360 \mu ~\mathrm{s}$</tex> and a pulse repetition rate of up to 5 Hz are required. These modulators are to be based on pulse transformers whose characteristics largely determine the modulator output pulse quality. This paper describes system considerations, modeling, design optimization, manufacturing and experimental validation of a high-voltage pulse transformer assembly matching the RF power requirements of the FAIR pLINAC.

title: Isolated DC-DC Converter with Active Clamping Circuit for Renewable Energy Systems
authors: Nabil A. Ahmed, Bader N. Alajmi, Ibrahim Abdelsalam, Mostafa I. Marei
publish: 2025 IEEE Industrial Electronics and Applications Conference (IEACon)
abstract: This paper presents a soft-switching isolated phase-shifted full-bridge DC-DC converter with an active clamping circuit, specifically designed for fuel cell power generation applications. The proposed converter incorporates an active clamping circuit on the primary side of the high-frequency transformer to mitigate voltage spikes and recover energy stored in the leakage inductor. The design offers several advantages, including a reduced component count, a straightforward circuit configuration, lower voltage stress, and a broad input voltage range. The soft-switching capability of the converter enables high switching frequencies while maintaining high power conversion efficiency. Detailed investigations are conducted in various operation modes and their corresponding equivalent circuits throughout the operating cycle. To validate the converter's performance, a downscaled 1.2 kW simulation and a 350 W experimental prototype were developed. The results demonstrate the converter's ability to achieve a wide output voltage gain while maintaining a stable output voltage across a wide range of low input voltages. The prototype achieved maximum power conversion efficiencies of 98% in simulation and 96.5% in experimental testing under full load conditions, attributed to the converter's ability to minimize switching losses at rated power.

title: Research on Ship Maintenance Optimization Based on Simulated Annealing Algorithm
authors: Li Cao, Yue Bao, Fangkun Zou
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: In formulating various levels of maintenance plans for ships, it is necessary to ensure that the final goals of total maintenance cost and period meet expectations, while the constraints of the maintenance process—including human resources, material resources, funds, technology, information, and time required for maintenance support—are mutually restrictive. To solve this non-deterministic polynomial problem, this paper uses the simulated annealing algorithm to solve for a relatively optimal target solution for the maintenance process model under certain convergence requirements, ensuring both meeting maintenance objectives and balancing various constraints.

title: A Multivariate Wiener Processes with Random Accelerated Effects for Degradation Modeling
authors: Xing Zhang, Hui Liu, Guangze Pan, Qingqing Zhai
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: The simultaneous degradation of interdependent performance characteristics (PCs) in industrial products, arising from shared operational environments and component coupling effects, necessitates advanced modeling approaches for reliability prognosis. This study develops a multivariate Wiener degradation model with inverse Gaussian (IG)-distributed random scaling factors and covariance structures to address this critical challenge. The unit-to-unit heterogeneity is captured by introducing a random scaling factor that follows the inverse Gaussian distribution, and cross-dimensional covariance structure is introduced to characterize the dependence between different PCs. Parameter estimation is achieved by an expectation maximization (EM) algorithm. The validity of the model is verified by Monte Carlo simulations. A real case study with comparative analysis demonstrates the practical advantages of the proposed multi-dependency model.

title: Algorithm-Architecture Co-Exploration of Systolic Arrays Using High-Level Synthesis
authors: Chu-Chun Yang, Gwo Giun Lee, Tsung-Ying Tsai, Jie-Ren Zheng, Yue-Cong Kuo, Wei-Chieh Lee, Ryan Karthik Pary
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This paper introduces an Architecture Compiler technique which jointly explores the algorithm and architecture co-design. This methodology facilitates a systematic mechanism by which design spaces are crossed or traversed from algorithmic functionality to potentially synthesizable microarchitecture designs having optimized placement and routing with low power, starting from high level synthesis. This will be demonstrated for parallel architecture designs for AI accelerators of general matrix multiplication (GEMM) with high demands in Generative AI on EDGE devices. In this paper, we explored the systolic array dataflow which includes weight, input, and output stationarity for parallel computing in CNN convolution. Different data granularities based on kernel sizes resulting in potentially different architectures will be explored at the high level. This algorithm/architecture co-design methodology will be exploring the potential design space solutions for all LeNet5, AlexNet, VGG16, and VGG19 CNN most suitable for the pre-defined specification quickly.

title: Efficient Adversarial Attack and Training on Learned Image Compression
authors: Jun Kurihara, Heming Sun
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: In recent years, Learned Image Compression (LIC) has drawn significant attention because of its powerful coding ability. However, similar to most neural network-based schemes, LIC is vulnerable to adversarial attacks. To mitigate the influence of adversarial attacks, adversarial training is usually adopted to finetune the network. This paper proposes efficient adversarial attack and training methods for LIC, by proposing three losses based on the original image, adversarial image, and reconstructed image. For the attack, we study the effects of three proposed losses on four qualities of classical factorized-prior and hyperprior models. For the adversarial training, all the proposed three losses are used in the finetuning for the three attack scenarios, respectively. We find that using the loss between the adversarial output and the original image achieves strong defense performance against various attacks, improving RD cost by up to 68.6%. Furthermore, we show that updating only the decoding during adversarial training along with reducing the number of iterations, can reduce the training time by up to 82.9% without compromising the defense performance.

title: Commissioning of the New Bipolar Solid-State Kicker Pulser Systems for the BESSY II Booster Injection and Extraction
authors: A. Kandratsyeu, L. M. Redondo, U. Sabaleuski, T. Atkinson, O. Dressler
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Two different types of solid-state Marx pulse generators were developed for the BESSY II accelerator facility. For the booster injection, an injection kicker pulser system based on a bipolar Marx topology with SiC MOSFETs technology, generating 320 ns pulses with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 8 \text{kV}$</tex> and 160 A was designed. Also, for the extraction kicker system a monopolar Marx topology applying SiC MOSFETs technology, generating 320 ns pulses with 15 kV and 600 A is being developed. Both designs have pulse output specifications of less than 3 ns rms rise time jitter, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 1 \%$</tex> flat-top deviation, and 80 ns rise and fall times in common. This paper discusses the results achieved.

title: Content-Aware Dominant Color Extraction and its Application to Mltiple-Key-Color Image Retrieval
authors: Mei Hashimoto, Michiharu Niimi
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel dominant color extraction method that incorporates salient region analysis to better reflect human visual impressions. Traditional dominant color extraction methods treat the entire image uniformly, often resulting in dominant colors that do not correspond to visually important regions. In this method, at first stage, images are classified into “landscape images” and “non-landscape images,” and then perform appropriate processing for each. For landscape images, dominant colors are extracted using conventional clustering over the entire image. For non-landscape images, we use saliency maps to detect regions of interest, and extract the most frequent color within these regions as the dominant color. Additionally, in order to evaluate the quality of dominant color, we construct color feature vectors based on predefined reference colors, enabling image retrieval tasks by multiple key-colors. Experimental results demonstrate that our method provides dominant colors that better match human perception, and improves the accuracy of image retrieval using color-based emotional representation. This approach shows promise for applications in affective computing, multimedia retrieval, and content recommendation.

title: Charge Accumulation Behavior of Threeelectrode Surface Dielectric Barrier Discharge Under Repetitive Nanosecond Pulses
authors: X. Zheng, H. Zheng, Z. Sun, Z. Zhao, J. Li
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Surface dielectric barrier discharges (SDBDs) driven by repetitive nanosecond pulses have shown significant potential in various applications, including flow control, energy conversion, icing mitigation, combustion, and ignition. Compared to traditional two-electrode SDBDs, the threeelectrode configuration has garnered more attention due to its higher deposited energy and distinct discharge modes, making it particularly promising for thermal-based applications such as flow control and ignition. The three-electrode SDBD under repetitive nanosecond pulses can operate in two discharge modes, i.e., streamer discharge and spark discharge, with transitions between them influenced by various parameters. Prior research has identified surface charge accumulation from previous pulses as a key factor in determining these mode transitions. However, the charge accumulation behavior in the three-electrode configuration remains insufficiently understood. In this work, the streamer dynamics and charge accumulation behavior of repetitively nanosecond-pulsed three-electrode SDBDs were investigated experimentally and numerically. The spatial and temporal evolutions of streamer morphology and electric field were obtained to analyze surface charge distribution. The results revealed that the final charge distribution was primarily determined by the secondary surface streamer developing within the primary streamer channel. Furthermore, simulation results provided insights into the charge transport mechanism within the streamer channel.

title: Synthesizing Vowel-Like Tones with Pitch Circularity
authors: Kaori Hashimoto, Takao Kawamura, Nobutaka Ono
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: In this paper, we present a method for synthesizing vowel-like tones that exhibit pitch circularity, an auditory illusion in which a cyclic sequence of tones appears to endlessly ascend or descend in pitch. Such illusions have traditionally been achieved using synthetic sinusoidal tones, such as the Shepard tone. However, the timbral characteristics of these tones and their relationship to speech have not yet been thoroughly investigated. Aiming at potential applications in music and auditory research, we attempt to synthesize sounds that simultaneously evoke vowel perception and pitch circularity. In our method, we construct a 12 -tone scale from a given vowel by varying its fundamental frequency (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F 0}$</tex>) while preserving its spectral envelope. To induce pitch circularity, we apply pitch-dependent attenuation to the odd harmonics relative to the even harmonics. Subjective listening experiments were conducted to evaluate the pitch perception and vowel identification accuracy of the synthesized tones. Using five Japanese vowels, “A,” “I,” “U,” “E,” “O,” the proposed method demonstrated stronger pitch circularity while maintaining high vowel identification accuracy (average F1-score: 99.7%). Audio demos of the proposed method are available online.

title: Optimizing I/O Performance of Global Atmospheric Spectral Model with XIOS
authors: Xinyu Chen, Jinhui Yang, Xiaoli Ren, Xiaoyong Li, Xiaoqun Cao, Jiarun Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Numerical weather prediction (NWP) models are pivotal for weather forecasting and climate research. As high performance computing (HPC) enters the exascale era, these models are advancing towards unprecedented high-resolution, generating explosive data volumes. In this case, Input/Output (I/O) operations have become a major performance bottleneck, hindering scalability and efficiency. In this paper, we focus on optimizing the I/O performance for the Yin-He Global Spectral Model (YHGSM). To alleviate these bottleneck, we implement a solution centered on a decoupled, asynchronous I/O paradigm. By integrating the XIOS framework, our method externalizes I/O tasks to dedicated server processes, which we enhance with a custom data transfer algorithm that strategically buffers data to maximize the overlap between computation and communication. The resulting integrated system is referred to as YHGSM-XIOS. The experimental results demonstrate substantial performance gains, showing that at a scale of 5,120 processes, the YHGSM-XIOS scheme reduces I/O overhead from 43.08 % to a mere 5.27 % and achieves an overall speedup of 2.31 times compared to the baseline system.

title: A High-Voltage High-Current Benchtop Test Stand for Solid-State Switch Testing at the SNS
authors: Austin Bullman, Yugang Tan
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Solid-state switches already replaced thyratrons in the SNS extraction kicker power supplies, offering improved efficiency and reliability. However, recent supply chain disruptions, combined with a self-firing issue, led us to explore alternative solutions. A vendor-developed MOS-Gated Thyristor switch was introduced but ultimately failed during testing. To investigate the failure and assess possible improvements, a benchtop test stand was constructed to evaluate the performance of a single stage board. This test stand features a Pulse Forming Network (PFN) that operates at 6 kV and 6 kA, with a repetition rate exceeding 60 Hz, simulating real operational conditions. By utilizing this setup, we seek to gain a better understanding of the failure mechanisms, refine the switch designs, and ultimately develop a more reliable alternative for the extraction kicker power supplies.

title: Preliminary Investigation of Grey-Box System Identification Framework for Unmanned Surface Vehicle
authors: Hyunjoon Cho, Dae-Hyeong Ji, Sunghyub Ko, Jong-Wu Hyeon
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: This study develops a grey-box system identification framework for unmanned surface vehicles (USVs), based on first-principle dynamic equations derived via the Newton-Euler approach. Given the characteristics of the USV selected as the identification target in this study, the dynamic equations are derived from first principles for a flat-bottom, low-speed vessel, with external disturbances modeled as input forces to enhance model fidelity. Under a series of reasonable assumptions, translational accelerations in the surge and sway directions, along with yaw angular acceleration, are decoupled and expressed as combinations of measurable variables and corresponding parameters. To support experimental implementation, a real-time variable measurement system is developed, along with a denoising technique to handle inherently noisy acceleration data. The feasibility of the proposed framework is verified through field experiments.

title: Dynamic Modeling of Six-Axis Robotic Arms Based on Broad Learning System: Experimental Validation and Performance Analysis
authors: Chun-Chieh Chan, Dimas Farhan Nugroho, Ya-Yun Hsiao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: A dynamic model of robotic arms is critical for improving control precision and efficiency. However, traditional models face challenges in nonlinear and high-dimensional modeling tasks and computational efficiency. To improve the models, we developed a dynamic modeling method for six-axis robotic arms based on a broad learning system (BLS), which integrates random vector functional-link neural networks. By leveraging enhanced layers and mapping layer designs, BLS improves modeling capabilities while reducing computational costs. The developed method in this study was evaluated using a six-axis industrial robotic arm, and the results demonstrated that BLS outperforms traditional least squares methods in key performance metrics, including maximum error, root-mean-square error, coefficient of determination, and computation time. These results highlight the efficiency and accuracy of BLS in nonlinear dynamic modeling. The method enables a novel solution for multi-degree-of-freedom robotic modeling, contributing to the development of smart manufacturing and human-robot collaboration applications.

title: Integrating Semantic Knowledge for Enhanced Weakly-Supervised Group Activity Recognition
authors: Muhammad Adi Nugroho, Jinyoung Park, Yeeun Seong, Changick Kim
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) have recently emerged as powerful tools for jointly modeling vision and language information, enhancing semantic representations. In this work, we introduce a method that utilizes high-level semantic knowledge of LVLM into the Weakly-Supervised Group Activity Recognition (WSGAR) task. Our Semantic Integrating Activity Recognition Network (SInAR-Net) enriches visual representations with language-based semantic information to construct complex spatio-temporal actor relationship. For efficient learning, we transfer the semantic knowledge via pre-extracted text features of contextual information generated through multiple prompt generations. Then, we construct multi-modal relationship between visual actor features and semantic text features using our semantic integration module. We ensure no drastic additional calculation cost by alleviating the use of LVLM in the inference stage, as our semantic integration module intrinsically learned the cross-modal semantic knowledge. Experiments on WSGAR benchmarks demonstrate competitive performance of our method, and ablation studies show the effectiveness of our novel semantic understanding components.

title: GWO-PowerGuard: An Adaptive Power Control Framework Using Grey Wolf Optimization for PU Protection in CR-WSNs
authors: G D Vignesh, Sudheesh S S, Subash K M, A M Balamurugan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Cognitive Radio Wireless Sensor Networks (CR-WSNs) present a promising solution to spectrum scarcity by enabling Secondary Users (SUs) to opportunistically access underutilized licensed bands without interfering with Primary Users (PUs). A dynamic optimization of SU transmission power to reduce PU interference and maximize network performance is also a serious challenge. The following paper, GWO-PowerGuard, an adaptive power control framework using the Grey Wolf Optimization (GWO) algorithm, to mitigate such problem, is proposed. The power control problem formulations follow the framework that models under the power control as a multi-objective optimization problem, in terms of SU throughput and PU interference. The usage of GWO allows searching the solution space efficiently and reaching the optimal power levels of each SU, dynamically adapting to the PU activity and to alterations in the network. Large-scale simulations were carried out at different SU densities, PU activity rates and channel conditions. The model suggested had the PU interference suppression of up to -95.4 dBm at low SU densities, and the values below -86.5 dBm at congested operations. It has surpassed Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Genetic Algorithm (GA) and Random Allocation with regards to SU throughput (up to 7.2 Mbps) and energy efficiency (up to 134.3 Kbps/mW). GWO-PowerGuard proved fast convergence rate of between 28-42 iterations, regardless of network scale. The outcomes indicate that the proposed framework is indeed effective to give an interference-aware, energy efficient and scalable solution to CR-WSNs.

title: Military Vehicle Alert System: An Integrated Approach Using Homomorphic Encryption and Federated Learning
authors: Kirankumar Manivannan, Kumaran K, Sreenidhi R, VasishPareekshith S S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: The paper proposes a method to enhance situational awareness for military vehicle operators through Augmented Intelligence of Things (AIoT), homomorphic encryption and federated learning. A sensor fusion technique is used that employs ultrasonic sensors in conjunction with RFID tags and readers to detect possible threats from nearby vehicles. The dual alert system provides alerts in both audio and visual formats. Where audio alerts use beeping sounds and visual alerts use color-coded visual alerts. Each military vehicle has its own unique RFID tag and a reader to detect incoming vehicles. The detected data includes each tag's ID and the timestamp of detection. Homomorphic encryption was used to protects sensitive data when processing and transmitting the data. Federated learning was used to enable many devices to collaboratively learn a shared prediction model without sharing their data. This multi-factor integrated system provides a significant enhancement to provide military safety operations in hostile environments.

title: Quantum Code-Assisted Entanglement Distillation Under Bit-Flip Noise
authors: Huidan Zheng, Gunsik Min, Yujin Kang, Youshin Chung, Hyelyn Kwak, Jun Heo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: This paper investigates entanglement distillation protocols assisted by quantum codes under bit-flip noise. Three protocols are compared: repetition code in correction and detection modes, and the [[4, 2, 2]] code in detection mode. We derive output fidelity and success probability for each, showing that the detection-based repetition code achieves the highest fidelity, while the [[4, 2, 2]] code provides better success rates. These results illustrate trade-offs between fidelity and yield, and highlight the potential of quantum codes in realistic noisy channels.

title: Optimizing Individual Protective Supplies: Merging Intelligent Equipment with Big Data for Safety
authors: Yuanyuan Song
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: According to the identified occupational risks, the effectiveness of conventional personal protective equipment (PPE) in complex environments was enhanced in this study. As traditional PPE does not sufficiently protect workers, intelligent equipment with sensors and big data is used to prevent hazards and improve compliance with safety measures. Through case studies of construction, healthcare, and manufacturing industries, the benefits of the intelligent PPE were verified in this study.

title: A Machine Learning-Based Agricultural Intelligence System for Crop and Fertilizer Recommendation with Price Trend Forecasting
authors: T. Manju, Shriman M S, Sivanesh Kannan S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Achieving sustainability and productivity in precision agriculture is reliant on the right crop selection. The results promote the use of a machine learning approach that can assist farmers in selecting crops based on environmental factors and soil nutrients. This system takes into account real data sources such as temperature, humidity, soil pH, precipitation, and levels of phosphorus, potassium, nitrogen, etc.; The data was utilized to train a Random Forest Classifier that can accurately predict suitable crops. Also, some of the systems suggests fertilizers by analyzing NPK levels and suggesting the appropriate combination of nutrients with standard fertilizer. Its module also presents the expected sale prices of these crops to help farmers make their decisions financially. Agricultural professionals, who are not knowledgeable in economics or farming, can benefit from this system's helpful guidance. Based on tests, it has been shown that the model can provide farmers with clear and accessible information to make informed decisions. It shows machine learning can increase the profits, improve planning efficiency and enhance farming knowledge.

title: Gradient Flow Bounds of Kullback-Leibler (KL)-Divergence in the Self-Attention Mechanism of Transformers
authors: Woo Yong Lee, Keunyoung Kim
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: The core of the Transformer technique lies in the structure called self-attention. This self-attention technique is a new mechanism that differentiates the Transformer from conventional neural network structures, and it has played a good role in the excellent practical performance. Existing studies interpret the operating principle of the transformer as a nonlinear transport equation that reflects the structure of the interacting particle system. Meanwhile, since the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence is defined with the entropy, it plays a important role in the information transmission fields. In existing studies, it has been elucidated that the optimal transportation problem (OTP) can be related to the variational problem of finding the optimal channel for the optimal rate distortion and information transmission. This paper applies these existing research results to the self-attention mechanism, and analyzes the upper and lower bounds of the gradient flow of the KL divergence, which is closely related to it. In addition, we examine the difference between the lower and upper gradient flow bounds of the change in Weighted mean Softmax according to the inverse temperature in self-attention through a simple toy example. The difference between the boundaries values of Weighted mean Softmax is relatively small, so this will be sufficient to examine only the upper bound. This result is expected to be of good help in understanding and interpreting the self-attention mechanism, which is the core scheme of Transformers.

title: Teaching System for Chinese Opera Features and Knowledge For Virtual Simulation
authors: Chen Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: A Chinese opera feature knowledge base was constructed to establish a teaching system based on virtual simulation. An action recognition algorithm was developed, too, based on the movement features of Chinese opera. The algorithm extracted the features of movements and decomposed the movement process into information on aspects such as gestures, body movements, and footwork. The outcomes were stored in a database via cloud computing with the cloud database’s data access mechanism for retrieval. Based on an understanding of students' abilities and preferences, the database was categorized. Virtual simulation technology was used to create a student-centered teaching environment, enabling students to be trained as actors in a virtual theater and perform various opera movements. The helps students learn, understand, and appreciate opera movements, enhancing their interest and enthusiasm. The teaching system also promotes the inheritance and development of Chinese opera and enables an exploration of new approaches to opera education.

title: A Pin-to-Liquid Discharge for the Hydroxylation and Dimerization of Aromatic Compounds
authors: V. Hahn, A. Mikolasch, M. Schmidt, J.E. Neuburger, J. von Langermann, M. Lalk, K.-D. Weltmann, T. von Woedtke, J. Kolb
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Different chemical methods can be employed for the hydroxylation or dimerization of aromatic compounds, but these procedures often require harsh conditions and environmentally harmful chemicals. [1]–[3] In contrast, non-thermal plasma offers unique advantages for the synthesis of organic compounds that may be used as starting point for the production of dyes or pharmaceuticals.

title: DCB: An Efficient Approach for Building Long-Range Dependencies in CNNs
authors: Tianxiang Lan, Mingyi He, Yuchao Dai
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Large-kernel convolution has garnered renewed attention in convolutional neural networks (CNNs) in recent years because of its ability to enhance model performance. However, the computational cost and the number of parameters caused by large-kernel convolution grow quadratically with kernel size, hindering its practical deployment. To address this challenge, we propose a novel cross-linear layer. Compared to standard large-kernel convolution, the cross-linear layer utilizes fewer parameters while efficiently creating feature connections in the spatial domain. In addition, we introduce a secondary propagation strategy to further enhance the cross-linear layer. This strategy can further extend connections among local features over a wide range, leading to the development of a Double Cross Block (DCB). The DCB combines the cross-linear layer and the secondary propagation strategy to efficiently construct local feature connections and significantly reduce computational cost. Furthermore, DCB improves network performance. We validate the effectiveness of the DCB module through extensive experiments on multiple datasets and demonstrate its applicability to state-of-the-art (SOTA) network models. The results indicate that the DCB can serve as an efficient alternative to large-kernel convolution layers with fewer parameters and lower computational complexity.

title: XGB-PRPr: A Novel XGBoost-Driven Parallel Randomized Preconditioner for CholeskyQR Algorithm
authors: Min Tian, Shui Nai, Xiaoming Wu, Jidong Huo, Yunhui Zeng, Wei Du
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: The randomized preconditioned CholeskyQR algorithm (rpCholeskyQR) is a state-of-the-art algorithm for tall-and-skinny, ill-conditioned matrices. However, its performance and numerical stability fundamentally depend on the design of the preconditioner, which involves both the sketching operator <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Omega$</tex> and the choice of the sampling factor <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$d$</tex>. In this work, to achieve better performance and adapt to the characteristics of the matrices, we propose a novel XGBoost-driven parallel randomized preconditioner for CholeskyQR Algorithm (XGBPRPr). Firstly, we introduce an XGBoost-driven machine learning model for optimal sampling factor. Secondly, we design a parallel hash-function-driven pseudo-random structured short-axis sparse operator (SSASOs) to enhance numerical stability. Finally, we employ a parallel computation and memory co-optimization strategy, called camco-SpMM, to enhance the performance of sparse matrix-matrix multiplication (SpMM) under the SSASOs structure. Experimental results show that our proposed method achieves up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.99 \times$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.23 \times$</tex> speedup compared with the standard QR factorization in the Intel Math Kernel Library (MKL) and the rpCholeskyQR algorithm, respectively, with errors remaining of the same order of magnitude.

title: Hybrid Clustering Algorithm and Linear Predictive Coding for Cross-Tier Security Integrated Wireless Body Area Network
authors: Dharani Buddha, Sk Himam Basha, Ghassan Samara, Vemuri Nitin, Jeyaprakash. N, Revathi V
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Wireless Body Area Networks (WBANs) are important in healthcare for monitoring patients in real-time, but challenges like low energy, high data costs, security risks, and network stability limit their use. This article introduces the Hybrid Clustering Algorithm and Linear Predictive Coding for Cross-Tier Security Integrated Wireless Body Area Network (HCLPCS) model to address these issues using hybrid clustering, lightweight data compression, and strong security measures. The HCLPCS model uses K-Means and K-Medoids clustering for efficient energy use and balanced node grouping, considering transmission distance and energy levels. To reduce data transmission, the Linear Predictive Coding Model (LPCM) predicts sensor readings, sending only the errors, which are compressed using RLE. This approach significantly decreases the amount of data sent, saving energy and reducing costs. The HCLPCS model includes a three-tier Cross-Tier Security Framework that ensures data integrity and confidentiality across sensor, gateway, and hospital network layers, featuring encryption, anomaly detection, and secure routing. Simulations conducted on the NS3 platform compared the HCLPCS model to existing protocols ECASS, LPRAK, and DATMS. Results showed that HCLPCS scales well, enhancing network lifespan and stability while keeping low delays and costs. It reduces energy usage by 30-50% and maintains low latency and high throughput in traffic. Overall, HCLPCS offers a scalable, secure, and energy-efficient solution for WBANs in healthcare.

title: Optimization of Load Frequency Control for a Multi-Area Power System Based On Bio-Inspired Metaheuristic Algorithms
authors: Hazlee Azil Illias, Lee Li Yang, Hazlie Mokhlis
publish: 2025 IEEE Industrial Electronics and Applications Conference (IEACon)
abstract: Load Frequency Control (LFC) is vital for maintaining stability in interconnected power grids by managing frequency variations and regulating power transfers. In this work, bio-inspired metaheuristic algorithms, Jellyfish Search Optimization (JSO) and Whale Optimization Algorithm (WOA) were employed to optimize the performance of LFC for two-area power system by tuning the PID controller parameters. The results demonstrate a significant LFC performance improvement compared to without using the optimization algorithms. JSO and WOA managed to reduce the settling time of the LFC response by more than 90% compared to the unoptimized system and more than 60% compared to Ziegler-Nichols tuning. The overshoot was reduced by 84.0% and the integral time absolute error (ITAE) was decreased by 98.1% compared to the unoptimized system. Thus, this demonstrates that JSO and WOA managed to improve the performance of LFC for two-area power system significantly by tuning the PID controller parameters.

title: Distributed Graph-Based Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search Index Construction via Task Parallelism
authors: Bingwen Wang, Xinyi Fu, Zhaokang Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Graph-based approximate nearest neighbor search (ANNS) algorithms have demonstrated superior performance in achieving high query throughput with high recall rates. The graph-based index construction is computationally intensive and time-consuming. The state-of-the-art parallel index construction algorithm ParlayDiskANN that produces the highest quality index utilizes multi-threading parallelism to reduce the construction time. However, the computational capacity of a single node limits its performance improvement. To address this challenge, we propose a distributed graph-based ANNS index construction algorithm DGANN that extends multithreaded index construction of ParlayDiskANN to the distributed environment via task parallelism. DGANN employs a broadcasting-based variant of the BSP framework. Each node maintains a copy of the complete graph index, builds the index in parallel via incremental adjacency list broadcasting, and generates the identical index structure to ParlayDiskANN. We introduce a conflict-free parallel buffer organization mechanism for the adjacency list broadcasting to reduce lock overhead during communication. The experimental evaluation on large-scale real-world datasets demonstrates that DGANN achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6.00 \times$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7.08 \times$</tex> speedup in index construction compared to ParlayDiskANN on eight nodes. The communication overhead of DGANN accounts for only 8.1 % of the total execution time, helping it gains near-linear data scalability and node scalability.

title: Computational Analysis of a Compact Physical Plasma Pulsed Power Rifle Design
authors: Ahmed M. Hala
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Non-lethal weapons are a class of arms that cripple adversaries without having necessarily a lethal effect. Technical challenges for hand held rifles for example included before a smaller gap that discharges power sparks at high voltage with a small current. This paper presents an analysis of a recent design of such weapons. A typical non-lethal rifle contains a sharp and coherent guiding light source such as a high power compact laser for example to break air, thereby creating an electrical path to subsequent delivery of pulsed power to targets. An additional ambient weather parameters measurement unit helps to fine tune the delivered electric jolts effectively.

title: A Diffusion Remote Microphone Technique for Distributed Active Noise Control
authors: Tianyou Li, Sipei Zhao, Haowen Li, Xiaofeng Zeng, Ruquan Sun, Jing Lu
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: The well-known Remote Microphone Technique (RMT) creates quiet zones at locations away from physical microphones, making it suitable for active noise control (ANC) in large-scale open environments. Conventional centralized RMT algorithms rely on a single processor for multi-point noise prediction and global control filter updates. However, the resulting high computational cost limits scalability in practical applications. Recently, distributed RMT approaches based on incremental strategies have been proposed, where each node in the acoustic device network performs local noise prediction and participates in global filter estimation, thereby distributing the computational load across the system. However, the serial communication mechanism inherent to incremental strategies increases vulnerability to link failures and leads to excessive communication latency, which may violate ANC causality constraints and degrade noise reduction performance. This paper proposes a distributed RMT scheme based on an augmented diffusion strategy. By leveraging neighborhood cooperation and parallel communication, the proposed method reduces computational complexity and significantly shortens communication latency. Simulation results and system complexity analyses demonstrate that it achieves consistent steady-state noise reduction performance with significantly lower computational and communication costs.

title: Model Prediction Direct Torque Control for Permanent Magnet Synchronous Generator Using Five-Level Vienna Rectifier
authors: Bryan Tan Xiao Yung, Yiauw Kah Haur, Yip Sook Yee, Thien Yee Von, Raymond Wong Jee Keen
publish: 2025 IEEE Industrial Electronics and Applications Conference (IEACon)
abstract: This project outlines the design and performance evaluation of a Permanent Magnet Synchronous Generator (PMSG) with a five-level Vienna rectifier (5L-VR) based on Model Predictive Direct Torque Control (MPDTC) strategy. The stator voltage model was created to facilitate a detailed analysis of how the 5L-VR switching vectors influence direct torque control performance. The proposed control strategy was validated using MATLAB/Simulink, proving that the tailored MPDTC manages precise torque and speed control across various reference speeds with small errors under low total harmonic distortion. These results confirm the proposed MPDTC strategy’s suitability under high- and low-speed scenario, enhancing PMSG performance in wind energy systems and offering valuable insights for real-world applications.

title: Bibliometric Analysis of Brain-Computer Interface Technology in China, United States, and Germany
authors: Huang Jin, Liu Xuan, Zhang Chi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: We conducted a comparative study on brain-computer interface (BCI) technology of China, the United States, and Germany based on bibliometric analysis. By retrieving articles on research topics on BCI from the Web of Science database, the differentiated development paths and scientific research innovation models were examined. Research scale, institutional distribution, and meso and micro-level research topics were compared between those countries. The United States maintained the technological leadership through accumulation and "government-industry-university-research"; Germany focused on specific disease research by non-profit organizations; and China demonstrated late-mover advantages through explosive growth in academic publications and interdisciplinary integration. While the countries focused I neuroscience research and medical applications, differences were observed in technology ethics, material innovation, and clinical applications. The results of this study provide a global perspective to enhance its competitiveness in BCI technology.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning based Resource Allocation in O-RAN
authors: Xin Yi Tan, Mau Luen Tham, Ying Loong Lee, Chee Onn Chow, Yi Jie Wong, Chuan-Hsian Pu
publish: 2025 IEEE Industrial Electronics and Applications Conference (IEACon)
abstract: The evolution of Radio Access Network (RAN) architecture towards 6th Generation (6G) network introduces Artificial Intelligence (AI)-driven automation and open, disaggregated design, enabling dynamic and intelligent resource optimization. In alignment with real-world telecom deployments by operators such as Vodafone, the O-RAN architecture is increasingly adopted in industrial-scale networks to enable AI-powered intelligent RAN control. Traditional resource allocation schemes typically rely on fixed algorithms to assign Physical Resource Blocks (PRBs) to multiple users, often targeting a single performance metric and lacking adaptability to real-time network conditions. This paper investigates two deep reinforcement learning (DRL)-based downlink PRB allocation algorithms, namely Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) and Twin Delayed Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (TD3), within a 5G Open RAN (O-RAN)-compliant simulation. The system integrates the Open5GS core network with a Software Radio Systems Radio Access Network (srsRAN) stack, configured as a disaggregated gNodeB (gNB) architecture consisting of an O-RAN Distributed Unit (O-DU) and O-RAN Radio Unit (O-RU). The control plane is managed by the Edge RAN Intelligent Controller (EdgeRIC), and a multi-objective reward function combining throughput and Jain’s fairness index is formulated to jointly optimize spectral efficiency and equitable resource distribution. The performance of both DRL algorithms is evaluated against traditional baselines in the O-RAN environment. Results show that TD3 demonstrates faster convergence and outperforms both PPO and rule-based methods in terms of fairness, while PPO achieves higher overall throughput.

title: Evaluating the Cost-Performance Trade-Offs of Cloud Repatriation
authors: Andrei Tablan, Florin Olariu
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: This study investigates the process and implications of repatriating a complex, full-stack e-commerce application from a cloud-based environment to an on-premises infrastructure. The application in question integrates multiple technologies, including an ASP.NET backend, a React-based frontend, and a Python-powered collaborative filtering recommendation module. Initially deployed on Microsoft Azure, the system was subsequently migrated to a local infrastructure to evaluate performance, cost efficiency, and operational control. The article presents a comparative cost analysis across three deployment models—cloud, on-premises, and hybrid—highlighting the trade-offs and decision-making factors involved in infrastructure repatriation.

title: Dynamic Magnetic Null Behavior in Planar Ion Diodes: Implications for Plasma and Particle Dynamics
authors: J. C. Foster, A. K. Tichy, S. B. Swanekamp, P. F. Ottinger
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Recent research has focused on an innovative planar ion diode [1] that aims to improve ion beam uniformity compared to traditional cylindrical diode designs [2], particularly for applications in material science. A power pulse of 1.6 MV and 800 kA peaking at 50 ns is used to drive a 2D particle-in-cell simulation of the diode. During this pulse, unexpected dynamic fluctuations were observed in the magnetic null region. These fluctuations are manifested as up-and-down variations in time where the electron beam current connects to the end of the anode. This behavior is surprising as it deviates from the symmetrical dynamics expected in planar diode configurations. Notably, these fluctuations are detected across various planar anode setups, including monolithic and dual anodes, as well as differing thicknesses, such as ultra-thin 100-micron anodes and significantly thicker 1600-micron anodes. Analysis indicates that the thinner anodes produce a broader ion energy spectrum than their thicker counterparts [1]. It is hypothesized that this peculiar fluctuating behavior may be linked to plasma instabilities, which may help explain the observed variations in ion energy distributions. This intriguing phenomenon raises questions about the underlying physics and highlights the complexity of plasma and particle dynamics in these high-energy-density environments. By deepening our understanding of these fluctuations, we can gain insights that could enhance the design and efficiency of diode systems for various applications. This presentation will explore these fluctuating behaviors and discuss their potential implications for advancing plasma and particle dynamics knowledge within pulsed power diodes.

title: Benchmark Comparison Data Fusion-Driven Support Resource Demand Modeling and Analysis Method
authors: Fan Yang, Zhiyu Jia, Jingjing He
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Maintenance support resource is the material basis of support system, and the adequacy directly affects the integrity of equipment readiness and efficiency. Based on similar theory, this study focuses on the analysis of equipment system support resource. Combining the concept and influence factors of spare part and support equipment demand, the composition of support resource benchmark comparison system (BCS) is summarized. A data model of support resource analysis based on knowledge graph (KG) is constructed based on benchmark comparison data. Comprehensive consideration the rule-based method, benchmark comparison data is used for spare part and support equipment demand analysis, and a data fusion-driven analysis method of spare part and support equipment demand is proposed. The method effectively utilizes the multi-source historical data of support resource and improves the accuracy and efficiency of support analysis.

title: A Study on Copyright Management in Generative AI Technology Environment
authors: Jung-Jae Lee, You-Kyung Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: The rapid development of major technologies such as the Internet of Things, artificial intelligence, big data, and blockchain, called the Fourth Industrial Revolution, is causing changes in service platforms and copyright ecosystems throughout the industry. Until now, various channels and application forms of copyright have emerged from the era of content ownership to the era of sharing. The content industry will grow as a new growth engine for future countries with high value-added industries, and the development of content distribution and protection systems is urgent to develop content that is competitive in the global market such as K-POP. In particular, the music industry among the content industries is an indicator of the creative economy, and industries with mechanisms by which composers or composers create, redistribute, and settle new added values as a source of creative ideas are being distributed. However, music created through Generative AI recently has been found to have many problems in the distribution and settlement of the domestic music industry. If the value-added creation of creative ideas in the music industry is not done properly, it will be difficult to sustain the market..

title: Innovative Training Approaches for HR and Finance Strategy in Small and Medium Enterprises
authors: P. Mathuraswamy, R. Santhi, D Fennala Agnes Iylin, T. Unnamalai
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Small and medium enterprises (SMEs) face many difficulties in terms of human resource and financial strategies with limited resources and expertise. The innovative training approach, which can be customized to suit the specific needs of SMEs, can alleviate this gap towards efficiency in operations and strategic alignment. The paper introduces a unified training framework to answer the problem at hand, utilizing a hybrid model combining the use of digital tools, scenario-based learning, and modular workshops. The approach aims to develop skills in financial planning, HR analytics, and decision-making as well as fostering cross-functional collaboration. By including real-world simulations with data-driven insights, the approach empowers employees to align HR and financial goals seamlessly. Results from pilot implementations in SMEs demonstrate improved workforce productivity, better financial decision-making, and a very significant reduction in training costs. This method provides scalable, adaptable solutions for SMEs addressing industry-specific challenges and equips them with sustainable growth preparations. The findings serve as a blueprint for the construction of resilient and innovative HR-finance strategies by SMEs.

title: Feedback-Guided Summarization Refinement for Small Language Models Using ModernBERT
authors: Geonwoo Hong, GilHan Choi, Gwangun Yu, Yonggang Kim
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: Small language models (SLMs) are gaining traction due to their efficiency and deployability on low-resource devices. Despite these advantages, SLMs often underperform compared to large language models (LLMs) in summarization tasks. In particular, they struggle to maintain coherence and ensure factual accuracy. In this paper, we introduce a feedback-guided frame-work for summarization. This framework improves summary quality without any fine-tuning of SLMs. To implement our method, we use ModernBERT, a bidirectional encoder designed for long-context inputs, which is fine-tuned to classify each article-summary pair into one of eight predefined feedback types. Next, the SLM uses the predicted feedback to perform a single, post-hoc refinement step. We evaluate this approach on the CNN/DailyMail news dataset and observe consistent improvements in both Recall-Oriented Understudy for Gisting Evaluation (ROUGE) and Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers Score (BERTScore). In several cases, our method outperforms LLMs, despite requiring only minimal computing resources. Our results show that the modular, feedback-guided approach can deliver high-quality summaries on lightweight systems with minimal resource consumption.

title: The Development of a Miniaturised Spectroscopic Reflectance System for Thin-Film Multilayer Thickness Measurements
authors: Néstor Eduardo Sánchez-Arriaga, Aruã Clayton Da Silva, Divya Tiwari, Windo Hutabarat, Adrian Leyland, Ashutosh Tiwari
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The in-process inspection of multilayer thin-film thickness across the width of a substrate is a requirement in roll-to-roll (R2R) manufacturing. However, the current inspection systems present limitations related to the nature of the techniques, in addition to the low scalability, modularity, high cost and complexity of implementation on the manufacturing floor. This work introduces the in-house development of a dimension-reduced and modular, single-sensor reflectometer instrument, enabling precise measurement of individual layers within multi-layer coated samples. This work includes the development of a new hardware design integrating a microprocessor, a light source, a logic converter and a spectrometer sensor; additionally, a unique software platform was developed to perform near real-time multilayer coating thickness measurements. Seven electrodeposited samples were created for testing and validation purposes. The results of more than one hundred and thirty measurements per sample show that the thickness of an Indium Tin Oxide (ITO) layer ranged between 125.48 to 138.82 ± 2.87 nm, achieving less than 7% error compared to vendor specifications (specification: 130 nm). Additionally, the thickness measurements from the sensor revealed a linear response of the Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):Poly sodium 4-styrene sulfonate (PEDOT:PSS) layer with increasing electrodeposition charge, resulting in thicknesses ranging from 201.47 to 506.03 ± 2.73 nm. The successful thickness single-point measurements lay the foundations for the development multi-sensor array to allow thickness measurements along the full width of coated substrates in R2R manufacturing.

title: Momentum-Enhanced Dual-Prototype Learning Framework for Robust Few-Shot Hyperspectral Image Classification
authors: Hanchi Liu, Jinrong He, Xiangqing Zhang, Zhaokui Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Prototypical network-based few-shot learning (FSL) has demonstrated promising performance for hyperspectral image (HSI) classification tasks under scarce sample conditions. However, existing prototype-based FSL methods suffer from data distribution variations among randomly sampled tasks, leading to unstable class prototype representations and weak cross-task generalization with limited samples. To address this issue, we propose a momentum-enhanced dual-prototype learning (MEDPL) framework for robust few-shot HSI classification. Firstly, a momentum-updated prototype mechanism constructs an iteratively optimized prototype memory bank. It obtains accumulated prototypes by exponentially decaying weighted fusion of historical and current prototypes, significantly suppressing noise from randomly sampled data and class center shifts caused by distribution bias. Simultaneously, a class-conditioned perturbation-augmentation strategy is introduced. It generates adaptive noise perturbations for support set features based on learnable covariance matrices to obtain enhanced prototypes, thereby improving the generalization representation capability of class prototypes across tasks. Secondly, a dual-prototype metric learning framework is designed, jointly utilizing accumulated prototypes and enhanced prototypes to synergistically enhance the model’s classification stability and cross-task generalization, thus significantly improving the robustness of few-shot classification. Experimental results demonstrate that MEDPL outperforms other few-shot hyperspectral image classification methods. Our source code is available at https://github.com/hejinrong/MEDPL.

title: Isolation Voltage Monitoring and Feedback Control System for High-Voltage Isolated Inverter as Floating Power Supply for Pulsed Power Generator
authors: A. Ono, K. Saito, K. Nagao, A. Mizukoshi, T. Sugai, A. Tokuchi, W. Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The pulsed power generators using semiconductor switches have many applications, and industrial applications require the pulsed power generator to be reliable, stable, compact, and low-cost. The semiconductor switches have many advantages over the gas switches which are conventional, however, they are distinctly inferior in power capability. Resulting in a typical solidstate pulsed power generator uses many semiconductor switching devices at the same time to reach the required operating voltage and/or current for specific applications. In the case of the use of semiconductor switches in series, these switches operate at different electrical potentials relative to the ground.

title: Comparative Study on Asymmetric Behavior of Start-Oscillation Current in Gyrotron with Structural Nonuniformity
authors: Z.-C. Liou, T.-F. Yang, C.-C. Chang, H.-Y. Yao, T.-H. Chang
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Gyrotron oscillators, based on the electron cyclotron maser (ECM), mainly rely on the interaction of electric field and weakly relativistic electrons that move helically and gyrate around a static magnetic field.
