This coherent beam-wave interaction leading to electron bunching in phase space either azimuthally or axially. In TM modes operations, the axial electric field (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{z}}$</tex>) may introduce bunching competition, potentially degrading output power. As a result, TM modes are traditionally considered unsuitable for gyrotron operation, and most analyses excludes TM modes from consideration. Recent theoretical studies on TM-mode gyrotrons have been devoted to studying the underlying mechanisms. Also, linear theory shows that the interaction of TM modes depends on the sign of the axial wavenumber (kz), unlike that of TE modes, and azimuthal bunching and axial bunching cooperate with each other when <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{kz}<0$</tex>, indicating that TM modes favor the backward-wave interaction. On the other hand, nonlinear analysis revealed that properly tapering structure can enhance the efficiency, but the impact on start-oscillation current still not be fully investigated. The study compares the tapered effect on TE and TM mode gyrotron under normalized cavity length and magnetic field and using axis-encircling electron beams due to comparable mode-coupling strengths. Through a comparative examination of downtaper and uptaper structures, we observed distinct differences in the starting current between TE and TM modes. The results indicate that TM mode are more favorable for backward interaction. This research provides new insights into optimizing gyrotron performance by tailoring the taper profile, which could improve efficiency and operational flexibility.

title: Development of an Image Correlation Routine for a Faraday Rotation Based Magnetic Field Imaging Diagnostic
authors: N. Dilworth, S. Bott-Suzuki, M.P. Valdivia, A. Truong, D. Camdzic
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Magnetic field structures are of interest in many high energy density plasmas, such as investigation of Magneto-Rayleigh-Taylor instabilities in z-pinches or magnetized plasma flows relevant to lab astrophysics. As linearly polarized light passes through a plasma, it undergoes a polarization rotation due to the Faraday effect depending on the path length, magnetic field strength, and electron density. This effect can be exploited in order to obtain 2D images of magnetic field distribution in a plasma given the electron density, which can be obtained through laser interferometry. The Faraday diagnostic system uses a two-detector scheme to eliminate the effects of plasma self-emission and other artifacts. To retrieve accurate magnetic field information, the two obtained polarograms must be correlated to each other. Overcoming differences in detector and optics positioning is important when resolving small spatial-scale magnetic field effects, such as those in shock regions occurring in magnetically accelerated flows. Multiple image correlation methods are employed in the reconstruction of magnetic fields, including a fourier-based phase correlation and homography computed from a corner detection algorithm run on images taken of a fiducial grid. Work towards developing an automated routine improving accuracy in magnetic field retrieval from polarograms is presented.

title: GLANet: Global-Local Adaptive Network for Efficient Rotated Object Detection
authors: Jie Xu, Liwei Deng, Tian Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Rotated object detection plays a crucial role in various visual perception tasks such as aerial photography, remote sensing imagery, and low-altitude unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) imagery. However, targets in both high-altitude remote sensing images and low-altitude UAV images often exhibit significant scale variations, diverse orientations, and dense spatial distributions, posing formidable challenges to detection algorithms in terms of accuracy and real-time performance. To address these issues, this paper proposes a Global-Local Adaptive Network for Efficient Rotated Object Detection (GLANet), designed to enhance detection precision and efficiency in complex scenarios. GLANet incorporates a lightweight backbone network, Revisiting Mobile CNN From ViT Perspective (RepViT), which balances inference efficiency with an improved capability to represent directional structural features of objects. During feature fusion, we introduce the Geometry-Enhanced Attention guided Rotated Feature Pyramid Network (GEAR-FPN), which jointly models global semantic context and local detailed features, thereby strengthening detection performance for small-scale and densely packed targets. In the detection head, we present a Dynamic Lightweight Geometric-Aware Head (DLGA-Head) alongside a Dynamic Lightweight Global Attention (Dynamic LWGA) mechanism to strengthen the representation of target orientation and boundary information. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated on both the DOTA and CODrone datasets. GLANet achieves an mAP of 78.12% on DOTA with competitive, near-state-of-the-art accuracy and significantly higher computational efficiency than other top-performing models. Specifically, it contains only 8.64M parameters and 35.69 GFLOPs, ensuring real-time inference while maintaining high precision. On the CODrone dataset, it further delivers improved detection performance while maintaining superior efficiency compared with existing approaches.

title: Axisymmetric Transformer in Glass IPD Technology and Its Application to Miniaturized On-Chip Bandpass Filters
authors: Bukun Xu, Yuhan Cao, Bo Yuan, Shichang Chen, Gaofeng Wang
publish: IEEE Electron Device Letters
abstract: In this letter, a miniaturized on-chip axisymmetric transformer with multi-transmission zeros (TZs) using glass-based integrated passive device (Glass IPD) technology is proposed. The proposed interwound winding transformer has two center taps. Four TZs are created by coupling capacitors and LC shunt resonators on three ports. The bandpass response is achieved by evolving the circuit structure. An on-chip prototype with a 3-dB fractional bandwidth (FBW) of 32.7% (4-4.5 GHz) is fabricated for verification purposes. In addition, a novel ultra-wideband bandpass filter (BPF) with a measured 3-dB FBW of 83.7% (4.5-9 GHz) is further designed by introducing a three-dimensional (3D) inductor, which provides a reliable solution for expanding the applications of on-chip transformer.

title: Collisional Pumping Effect on Ion Energy in the Sheath
authors: I. Seong, C. Cho, W. Jeong, M. Choi, B. Choi, M.E.H. Jami, S. Seo, I. Lee, W.-B. Woo, W. Park, J.-H. Jang, D.-K. Lee, S. Kim, S. You
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Collisions within the sheath are well known to have the effect of reducing ion energy at the electrode. For this reason, low-pressure conditions have been preferred in semiconductor processing to maintain ion directionality and preserve energy within the sheath. However, this study reports that collisions within the sheath can, in fact, lead to an increase in ion energy at the electrode. To demonstrate this, ion trajectory simulations were introduced, and the ion energy distribution and mean energy were examined as a function of pressure. Additionally, ion trajectories were analyzed to interpret the observed results. The findtings revealed that collisions within the sheath alter ion trajectories, causing relatively low-energy ions to transition into highenergy states. This study provides new insights into semiconductor processing, where low-pressure conditions have trajditionally been favored for ion energy preservation, and contributes to a deeper understanding of ion dynamics within the sheath.

title: Keeping it Trunky: Engineering Improvements for Enabling Long Term Interactive Enrichment for Elephants
authors: Arianna Mastali, Caden Prather, Charles Ramey, Kirby Miller, Nathan Elgart, Thad Starner, Melody Jackson
publish: Proceedings of the ACM 12th International Conference on Animal-Computer Interaction
abstract: Electronic systems for cognitive enrichment in zoos open avenues for monitoring to better understand how and when the animals are engaged. We present a pilot study of an automated elephant trunk detection system utilizing computer vision techniques such as background subtraction and region-based motion detection on a Google Pixel smartphone for real-time monitoring of enrichment use by four African elephants (Loxodonta africana) at Zoo Atlanta. Preliminary results show promise in using camera-based methods for trunk detection; however, more testing and refining of the algorithm is required to obtain an accurate and reliable method that could replace physical sensing methods.

title: Beam-Driven Plasma Wakefield Acceleration - State-of-the-art and Perspectives on Possible Future Applications
authors: G. Loisch, J. Wood
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Beam-driven plasma wakefield acceleration (PWFA) is considered one of the main candidate technologies to complement and even partially replace conventional accelerator technology due to the superior acceleration gradients it can support. Dedicated experimental facilities like FACET at SLAC, FLASHForward at DESY, AWAKE at CERN or SPARC at INFN Frascati have been built and operated in the last 20 years to investigate key aspects like achievable acceleration gradients, efficiency, repetition rates, and the possibility to preserve beam quality during acceleration. While no accelerator based on the PWFA concept has yet been built to serve actual user applications, the experimental results already allow to identify viable use cases for beam-driven plasma wakefield acceleration and to support conceptual designs of future accelerator facilities, as it is e.g. being done in the so-called HALHF study for a future linear collider. In this contribution the current status of beam driven plasma wakefield acceleration research is summarised and perspectives on possible future applications are given.

title: Experiment of Ultra-Fast Linear Transformer Driver Prototype Cavity
authors: Y. Zhao, J. H. Jiang, B. Wei, J. Wang, J. J. Kang, W. H. Han, L. J. Zhou, L. Chen, H. C. Li
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: A prototype cavity of linear transformer driver generator has been manufactured for flash X-ray radiography applications. The cavity includes 20 bricks representing two 10 nF capacitors and one high pressure gas spark switch. Two type switches, Three Electrode Field Distortion Switch and multi-gap gas switch were designed and tested individually. Experiments show that the inductance of the both is basically the same, but in terms of trigger synchronization, the multi-gap switch is significantly better than the three-electrode field distortion switch.

title: Ignition and Operation of Confined Atmospheric Plasmas Under Nanosecond Pulsed Power
authors: J. van Oorschot, M. Gendre, G. Pemen
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Plasma conditions and processes depend strongly on the applied voltage waveform. Common plasma power supplies have limited flexibility in this regard, which limits the versatility and efficiency of any plasma process.

title: Surface Flashover Across a Polyurethane Barrier Separating Oil and Water Dielectrics
authors: Z. Hargrove, D. Wetz, N. Jennings, A. Johnston, M. Burnette, A. Steiner
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: High-voltage pulsed power systems often rely on the interconnection of multiple transmission lines to deliver the required voltage, rise time, and pulse width, among other properties. These transmission lines may require multiple insulator media, and the separation of these differing dielectrics by a solid barrier causes permittivity mismatches and field enhancements along the interface. Understanding how the enhancements impact transmission line performance and its ability to resist catastrophic flashover events along the barrier surface is critical. We have designed and fabricated a small replica of the water-insulated intermediate storage capacitor from Sandia National Laboratory's Z facility to study dielectric surface flashover across a polyurethane barrier separating oil-insulated and water-insulated transmission line sections. Multiple transmission line designs, with and without windows, are fielded to facilitate observation of the surface flashover phenomena in the region of interest, while a roughly 600 kV Marx generator is used to drive the experiment. The motivation for the experiments, details of the experimental setup, and results obtained to date will be presented.

title: Advanced Magnetic Core Modeling for Pulsed Power Systems in LTSpice
authors: K. Kelp, D. Wright, K. Schriner, J. Dickens, J. Stephens, Z. C. Shaw, A. Neuber
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: A behavioral magnetic core modeling technique has been developed to accurately capture the behavior of nanocrystalline magnetic cores, as measured experimentally on the nanosecond to microsecond time scale. Although magnetic cores are crucial for many pulsed power systems, such as traditional pulse transformers and the more recent Linear Transformer Drivers (LTD), conventional SPICE models have struggled to accurately capture the behavior of magnetic cores under high-voltage pulses. The presented magnetic core model relies on only a few fixed parameters found through experimental validation to reproduce the dynamic behavior of nanocrystalline magnetic cores across magnetization rates ranging from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.5 \mathrm{T} / \mu \mathrm{s}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8 \mathrm{T} / \mu \mathrm{s}$</tex>.

title: AdvFMEA: Adversarial-Aware Failure Mode and Effects Analysis for Safety-Critical Monocular Depth Estimation in Autonomous Vehicles
authors: Mayur Anand Pandya, P C Siddalingaswamy, Sanjay Singh
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The reliability of monocular depth estimation is paramount for safe navigation in autonomous vehicles. However, these systems face critical safety vulnerabilities from physical adversarial attacks, such as road marking manipulations and object-blending perturbations. This work introduces an adversarial-aware Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (AdvFMEA) framework that quantifies these risks through an Adversarially Aware Risk Priority Number (AA-RPN) integrating factors such as attack persistence, depth-error severity, and adversarial impact. Benchmarking seven state-of-the-art models across CARLA simulations and the real-world KITTI dataset reveals that transformer architectures suffer from systemic depth spoofing. At the same time, lightweight CNNs exhibit higher safety-critical error rates. Our fail-operational approach includes an attack-agnostic FMEA methodology compliant with ISO 21448 (SOTIF), empirical validation of sim-to-real threat correlation, and deployable safety thresholds for resource-constrained systems.

title: Wideband, Beamsteerable Connected Slotted-Patch Antenna Array for On-Package Millimeter Wave Applications
authors: Md Rasheduzzaman Al-Amin, Elham Baladi, Mohammad S. Sharawi
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Antennas and Propagation
abstract: In this work, a long connected slot is cut out on a proximity-coupled patch antenna plane for the first time. The proposed connected slotted-patch antenna array (CSPAA) is designed, analyzed, fabricated, and measured for on-package millimeter-wave (mmWave) applications having wide beamsteering capabilities. Microstrip lines are used to excite the patch and the connected slot. The CSPAA is designed on a seven-layer vertical stack-up, making it suitable for on-package scenarios. The fabricated CSPAA has a measured bandwidth of 21.07% (centered at 28 GHz) and a measured realized gain of 9.51 dBi at broadside, yielding a total efficiency of 83%. The CSPAA demonstrates wide beamsteering capabilities up to ±390 with a compact form factor of 0.0881λ3 (1.52λ x 0.58λ x 0.1λ), where λ is the free-space wavelength at 28 GHz. A comprehensive comparison of the proposed CSPAA with the state-of-the-art shows that the proposed prototype has excellent bandwidth, gain, wide beamsteering capabilities, and a smaller form factor compared to previous solutions for mmWave on-package applications.

title: Community-Driven Contrastive Learning: Enhancing Global Representation in Graph Neural Networks
authors: Wenhao Zhou, Zhenhua Huang, Shaojie Wang, Junfeng Fang, Zhaohong Jia, Linyuan Lv, Xiaohui Xie
publish: IEEE Transactions on Artificial Intelligence
abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have demonstrated impressive performance across various graph-structured datasets and applications. However, their message-passing mechanisms primarily capture local information, limiting their ability to model long-range dependencies. While existing approaches enhance aggregation methods to incorporate local neighbor features, expanding the receptive field in globally aware GNNs increases model complexity, complicating the training of highcomplexity architectures. Community information, which uncovers the intrinsic graph structure, can address these limitations. To this end, we propose a Community-Aware Graph Neural Network (CAG) framework that leverages contrastive learning to enhance global feature extraction through community-aware modeling. To handle challenges such as heterogeneous community sizes and noise, CAG employs a Community Subgraph Explorer guided by Monte Carlo tree search, which identifies dense subgraphs as representative structures to mitigate noise. Extensive experiments show that CAG substantially improves GNN performance in node classification, outperforming backbone models with stateof-the-art accuracy gains (+4.09% by CAG (GCN) on CiteSeer) while maintaining acceptable computational overhead compared to backbone models. Our findings underscore the efficacy of community-aware frameworks in enhancing global information aggregation in traditional GNNs.

title: Development of 3D Textile Electrodes for Electrocardiography Measurement
authors: Sang-Ho Lee, In-Su Park, Han-Jeong Hwang
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Flexible dry electrodes are essential for wearable biosignal monitoring, but conventional textile-based designs often suffer from high impedance and unstable skin contact. In this study, a 3D-structured textile electrode was fabricated by embroidering conductive threads onto polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) substrates using a computerized embroidery technique. Compared to conventional flat textile electrodes, the proposed electrode exhibited an 80.6% lower impedance at 10 Hz and a 5.42 dB higher signal-to-noise ratio (SNR). During dynamic measurements, the proposed electrode maintained signal fidelity, achieving a Pearson correlation of 0.893 with reference <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{A g} / \mathbf{A g C l}$</tex> electrodes. These results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively improves signal quality and motion stability in dry electrodes for wearable electrocardiography (ECG) monitoring.

title: Product Failure Mode Recognition Method Based on Function and Physical Realization Process Decomposition
authors: Anqi Zhang, Jun Huang, Yao Zhu, Lei Zhang, Xinyun Zhang, Sikun Mi
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: The trend of multi task integration and generalization is a huge challenge to product reliability. At present, FMEA is commonly used to identify failure modes at various levels and take control measures accordingly to improve product reliability. However, in engineering practice, the preparation of failure mode and effect analysis tables relies more on the experience of designers and is highly subjective. Therefore, firstly, the framework for failure mode recognition method is constructed. Secondly, the steps of decomposing and identifying weak links are introduced from the aspects of designing functional and manufacturing physical realization, by using an improved risk fuzzy matrix and integrating expert evaluations of failure modes and the importance of each risk factor, the main failure modes of the product are quantitatively identified. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method was verified using a typical RF module as an example, and quality improvement suggestions were proposed, providing scientific input for designers to implement module quality improvement.

title: Vision-Based Quadrotor Tracking Control with Horizontal Field-of-View Constraint using Lyapunov-Barrier Function
authors: Javier Dustin Tambunan, Naufan Aurezan Mulyawan, Wilbert Ivander Nioman, Faqihza Mukhlish, Augie Widyotriatmo
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Instrumentation, Control, and Automation (ICA)
abstract: One of the recent developments in quadrotor research involves visual servoing in tracking mode using a camera. However, this approach faces a challenge arising from the horizontal field of view (FOV) limitation of the camera. In this paper, position and heading controllers based on Control Barrier Functions (CBFs) are proposed to ensure that the target subject remains within the FOV boundaries. The proposed control laws are validated through phase portraits and simulated in Simulink, supported by the PX4 package to create a high-fidelity quadrotor simulation model. The validation results show that the designed control laws successfully achieve the intended objectives and may exhibit global asymptotic stability. Furthermore, the simulation demonstrates consistent performance, with the quadrotor able to track the setpoint without violating the FOV boundaries. The results confirm that, within the FOV, the system consistently converges to the equilibrium point for various setpoint and FOV combinations.

title: Enhancing Medical Readiness with LLMs: A Low-Resource OTC Support Bot for Deployed Units
authors: James Paul Tan, Margrette Yebes, Michael Ralph Estrada, Paula Marielle Ababao, Gabriel Avelino Sampedro
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: In military and expeditionary (maritime) health care environments where isolation, safety, limited personnel, and resource constraints can threaten the delivery of frontline health care, access to timely and knowledgeable medical assistance can be extremely valuable. The purpose of this paper is to investigate the use of large language models (LLMs) in military and maritime health care environments by creating an AI-powered, Over-the-Counter (OTC) Medication Assistance Bot using the Mistral-7B model. The bot is intended to be deployed within tactical, or even shipboard systems, and it would empower autonomous, in-the-moment recommendations of medications for specific symptoms, while mitigating the risks associated with deploying personnel self-medicating through potential non-fundamental use errors. For this work, we employed Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) to fine-tune the system, and the bot was trained on a specific dataset derived from material on pharmacological sources, contextualized for medical practices in the Philippines. Based on evaluation the model achieved an average F1-score of 0.7296, which is above the 0.60-0.70 expected levels of performance for medical dialogue systems. The research shows promise for the model as it enhances combat and maritime healthcare readiness by providing consistent, low-bandwidth, and local medical assistance when connected medical supervision may not be immediately available.

title: Effective Speckle Noise Reduction Using Transformed Bayesian Likelihood with Wiener-Based and Sketch-Based Geometric Priors
authors: Ming-Hsun Mo, Pin-Wen Huang, Jian-Jiun Ding
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: An efficient filter for speckle noise reduction in Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) images is proposed. Traditional SAR despeckling techniques often suffer from the trade-offs between computational cost, edge preservation, and adaptability to complex scene structures. To address these limitations, the proposed method introduces three improvements: (1) A logdomain distance metric derived from a transformed Bayesian likelihood is proposed. It linearizes the multiplicative noise model and allows fast and stable patch similarity computation. (2) A Wiener-based prior estimation that leverages local statistics to provide a more accurate reflectance prior is adopted. It reduces the estimation bias and enhancing structure preservation. (3) A sketch-based anisotropic weighting mechanism that integrates geometric priors based on gradient orientation and edge strength is proposed. It enables edge-aware aggregation and superior texture retention. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed algorithm consistently outperforms existing approaches in terms of both the peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR) and the structural similarity index (SSIM), while also achieving substantial computational efficiency and improving the visual quality.

title: Conversation Context-Aware Direct Preference Optimization for Style-Controlled Speech Synthesis
authors: Atsushi Kojima, Yusuke Fujita, Hao Shi, Tomoya Mizumoto, Mengjie Zhao, Yui Sudo
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Conversational text-to-speech (TTS) generates context-appropriate expressive speech by modeling dialogue context, without requiring manual paralinguistic labels such as emotion or intent. However, acoustically similar emotions (e.g., happy vs. angry) often cause inappropriate renderings. To address this, we propose a preference-based optimization approach that reinforces the model toward selecting contextually appropriate emotional expressions. Specifically, we adopt direct preference optimization (DPO) in a unit-based TTS architecture, enabling fine-grained supervision of emotional expression by comparing discrete unit sequences for more and less suitable speech samples. Our method employs a text-to-unit model predicting discrete acoustic units from phonemes and context, followed by a unit-based HiFi-GAN vocoder. Training proceeds in two stages: first, the text-to-unit model is optimized with cross-entropy (CE) loss on ground-truth units; second, DPO is applied using unit pairs reflecting appropriate versus inappropriate emotions within the same context. Experiments on the STUDIES dataset show that preference-based optimization substantially improves emotion recognition accuracy (67.14 % with CE+DPO vs. 48.45 % with CE only). These results demonstrate that our approach enables fine-grained control of emotional expression and better captures subtle distinctions in conversational speech.

title: Dialect Identification Using Resource-Efficient Fine-Tuning Approaches
authors: Zirui Lin, Haris Gulzar, Monnika Roslianna Busto, Akiko Masaki, Takeharu Eda, Kazuhiro Nakadai
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Dialect Identification (DI) is a task to recognize different dialects within the same language from a speech signal. DI can help to improve the downstream speech related tasks even when speakers have a strong dialect. However, fine-tuning a speech model for tasks like DI is expensive in terms of computation cost and memory requirement. Recent studies have explored fine-tuning pre-trained speech models for tasks like DI using Parameter-Efficient Fine-Tuning (PEFT) methods, which offer parameter efficiency but limited improvement in memory efficiency and training speed. To address these challenges, we explore Memory-Efficient Fine-Tuning (MEFT) methods, originally proposed for language processing, and apply them to the generalpurpose pre-trained speech model. We then comprehensively analyze the GPU memory usage and fine-tuning speed based on various MEFT methods. As a case study, we fine-tune the Whisper model to identify six Mandarin subdialects from the KeSpeech dataset, reducing GPU memory usage by up to 73.25% and accelerating training speed by a factor of 2.1, while maintaining accuracy comparable to vanilla fine-tuning and PEFT methods.

title: DCCP: A Logical Respiratory Disease Classification Methodology based on Ultrasound Images using Deep Convolutional Classification Principle
authors: S. Vijay Shankar, Kolamala Sumathi, A V L Narayana Rao, Safeyah Tawil, Pacha Swathi, M. Dinesh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: The timely and accurate diagnosis of respiratory diseases such as COVID-19, Tuberculosis (TB), and Pneumonia remains a critical public health priority, especially in resource-constrained settings. The availability of ultrasound imaging, which is non-invasive, as a viable tool has been made possible by the portability, affordability and safety of the tools. The paper presents DCCP (Deep Convolutional Classification Principle) - a new model of multi-class classification of respiratory conditions based on ultrasound images. The model uses the Kaggle Dataset known as Lungs Disease Dataset (4 types) which includes more than 10,000 augmented images of five classes namely COVID-19, Bacterial Pneumonia, Viral Pneumonia, TB, and Normal. Pre-processing of the images consists of application of grayscale normalization, speckle noise removal along with artefact removal methods CLAHE and median filtering. Compact and effective CNN backbone EfficientNet-B0 is used to extract deep spatial features. It is concatenated with Convolutional Block Attention Modules (CBAM) and a multi-scale feature fusion to prioritise the pathological patterns (e.g, pleural irregularities and B-lines). The global average pooling followed by dense layers and softmax activation form the classification head of the model to give prognostic predictions in five classes. The model has been trained on Adam optimizer and Cross-entropy loss and shows an overall accuracy of 98.1%. The highest F1-score of 0.997 is achieved on dogs and highest F1-scores of all other classes improve to 0.92 and above. Its performance is confirmed by such evaluation measures as ROC-AUC, precision, recall, and confusion matrix. This paper shows the feasibility of DCCP to have a lightweight, interpretable, and deployable model that seeks to screen respiratory diseases at the point of care via lung ultrasound images in real-time.

title: Sentiment Prediction Using Multilingual Bidirectional Encoder Representations And Cross-Lingual Language Model Robustly Optimized Bert Approach From Transformers on Code-mixed Text
authors: Lee Seng Yuan, Lim Tong Ming
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: We investigated the linguistic phenomenon of Bahasa Rojak, a code-mixed language commonly used in Malaysia, and its implications for sentiment analysis. The challenges posed by the lack of standardized grammatical structures in Bahasa Rojak necessitate the development of specialized computational models. Therefore, we conducted the experiments using multilingual bidirectional encoder representations (mBERT) and a cross-lingual language model robustly optimized BERT approach from transformers (XLM-RoBERTa) on a Chinese-English dataset. A comparative performance analysis was performed, and the results showed that XLM-RoBERTa consistently outperformed other models for Chinese-English code-mixed text due to its superior multilingual tokenization and cross-lingual transfer learning capabilities, which allowed it to better understand mixed-language semantics. This result highlights the strengths and potential limitations of deep learning models for code-mixed sentiment analysis, emphasizing the need for further advancements in handling complex linguistic interactions for code-mixed sentences.

title: Detoxification of Poisoned Recognition Models by Fine-Tuning with Out-of-Distribution Samples
authors: Junsuke Takano, Kazuaki Nakamura
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: As machine learning models have advanced, the risk of attacks on such models has also increased. Typical examples include a poisoning attack (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{P A}$</tex>), which is an attack of injecting some “poisoned” samples into a training dataset of a target machine learning model to degrade its performance. In particular, PA using poisoned samples that seem clean for human eyes is called a clean-label poisoning attack (CLPA). A conventional approach for defending against PA and CLPA is to remove the poisoned samples from a dataset before training. However, this prophylactic defense approach is difficult to implement in federated learning (FL) environments because training samples dispersedly owned by multiple clients are not shared in a single place in FL. To address this problem, this paper proposes a novel therapeutic defense approach: a “detoxification” method for recovering the performance of a “poisoned” model that has suffered CLPA. To achieve detoxification, the proposed method fine-tunes only the network head of a poisoned model using a small set of labeled clean samples and a large set of unlabeled out-of-distribution (OOD) samples. Poisoned models tend to output uneven confidence scores near the ideal decision boundary, which is undesirable and therefore is calibrated by the proposed method using OOD samples with almost uniform soft labels. In the results of our experiments conducted on an object image recognition model, its recognition accuracy was recovered by up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1 1. 9 8} \%$</tex> compared to the original poisoned model. This demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: DistributedSGXDedup: A Distributed Key Server System Based on SGX for Reliable and Efficient Encrypted Deduplication
authors: Chengjian Liu, Longfei Yang, Feiping Wang, Yuanyuan Zeng, Lin Lin, Lixin Liang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Message-locked encryption is often employed in cloud storage systems to maintain both security and storage efficiency. A key server, operating within a trusted execution environment such as Intel SGX, can mitigate the risks of bruteforce attacks and compromise issues associated with the key server in a given storage system. However, due to the potential risk for single-point failure, the reliability of the key server cannot be guaranteed. Moreover, the key server may become a performance bottleneck for the entire system. To address these issues, we designed and implemented a distributed key server system named DistributedSGXDedup, which operates within a trusted execution environment based on SGX. The reliability of the system is enhanced as multiple key servers remain operational. Specifically, our comprehensive evaluation demonstrates that the performance of key generation increases with the number of key servers. We also present a security analysis that shows the security of DistributedSGXDedup is maintained by conducting key operations within trusted execution environments.

title: Beyond One-Shot Dubbing: Leveraging N-Best Translation and Prompted Paraphrasing with Synchrony-Aware Re-Ranking
authors: Jan Meyer Saragih, Faisal Mehmood, Sakriani Sakti
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Dubbing—translating and synchronizing spoken content across languages—requires not only semantic accuracy but also precise alignment with the timing and rhythm of the original speech. While recent work has explored paraphrasing with large language models (LLMs) for dubbing, most approaches rely on a single translation and a one-shot paraphrasing pass, limiting the space of alternatives and often resulting in suboptimal alignment. We propose a multi-candidate framework that leverages N-best machine translation outputs and in-context paraphrasing with LLMs to generate diverse candidates that preserve meaning while varying in structure and length. This expanded candidate space enables better exploration of alignment options without modifying the underlying MT or TTS systems. To select the best output, we introduce synchrony-aware reranking based on speech-only alignment metrics—specifically Speech Length Compliance and Speech Overlap—which quantify temporal alignment between the generated and reference speech without requiring video input or retraining. Experiments on German-to-English dubbing using the FLEURS dataset and the IWSLT 2024 Dubbing Challenge test set show that our approach improves temporal synchrony and perceived naturalness. These results highlight the value of combining translation diversity, incontext paraphrasing, and synchrony-based selection for highquality automatic dubbing.

title: Federated Learning-Optimized Financial Literacy AssessmentFramework for Urban Bangalore Investors
authors: S. Ayyappan, Micky Golani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: This research is an innovative study of the assessment of financial literacy of urban investors in Bangalore through Federated Learning (FL). The paper extends privacy-preserving analysis in the distributed data sources by use of the Federated Averaging (FedAvg) algorithm in the TensorFlow Federated (TFF) environment. The model suggested is decentralized learning enabling both financial and user devices to mutually train a global model without jeopardizing sensitive individual data. This is specifically important in the fiscal sector where secrecy of data is of great essence. The framework combines various behavioral and demographic data among the many nodes, and it generates an apt and scalable financial literacy profile of the urban investors. Model updates are aggregated in a secure manner using FedAvg guaranteeing efficiency both in terms of computation and communication. The vision is built to accommodate the changing patterns of the people and economic activity in Bangalore city eventually leading to improved financial empowerment and literacy. The findings indicate the impending possibility of federated learning to provide secure, scalable, and insightful financial literacy evaluations.

title: Development of Image Analysis Methods for Quantifying Wrinkles on The Face Due to Changes in Expression
authors: Vebi Nadhira, Rahmat Ilahi Siregar, Suprijanto
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Instrumentation, Control, and Automation (ICA)
abstract: The use of cosmetics as facial makeup to conceal black spots, skin discoloration, pores, and wrinkles has become increasingly popular among the general public and public figures. This trend has driven up demand for skincare products, particularly cosmetics, and research to measure their effectiveness. One area of research focuses on evaluating the wrinkle-concealing capabilities of cosmetic products. In this paper, we only focus on developing an algorithm to detect changes in dynamic wrinkles caused by facial expressions. Soon, this method can be used to assess the effectiveness of wrinkle concealment cosmetics across different facial expressions. In this study, a video capture configuration was designed to make dynamic wrinkles on facial images visible and significant. An algorithm was developed for segmenting and extracting facial wrinkle features to facilitate measuring the efficacy of skincare products. The method used includes comparing the Structure Tensor and the Sobel filter, with entropy used as wrinkle feature extraction. High entropy values indicate greater disorder, reflecting higher levels of secondary facial wrinkles. The results show that the Structure Tensor method has high sensitivity to variations in facial structure and orientation, while the Sobel method focuses more on edge detection but is less responsive to complex texture variations. Additionally, entropy values for the Structure Tensor method are significantly higher (0.6345 to 0.6877) compared to Sobel (0.0032 to 0.0398). Therefore, it can be concluded that the Structure Tensor method is more effective as a tool for measuring skin wrinkle levels due to its higher value variation in facial structure and orientation.

title: Virtual Reality Learning Environment: Gamified Medical Flashcards
authors: Alina Duca, Elena-Ecaterina Opaiţ, Maria-Ecaterina Olariu, Adrian Iftene
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: In a time when Artificial Intelligence (AI) based technologies are rapidly advancing, education is undergoing a significant transformation. Ensuring the creation of an appropriate learning environment is crucial for building a strong educational framework. In medical education, where knowledge of vast and complex information is essential, AI tools enhance engagement, retention, and understanding of core concepts. This article explores recent research and applications in the field, and proposes a Virtual Reality (VR) and AI-powered system that simplifies content creation by leveraging structured medical guidelines and expert-validated resources, ensuring the generation of up-to-date, high-quality questions that reflect real-world clinical scenarios.

title: Application and Optimization of Large Models Based on Prompt Tuning for Fact-Check-Worthiness Estimation
authors: Yinglong Yu, Hao Shen, Zhengyi Lyu, Qi He
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: In response to the growing problem of misinformation in the context of globalization and informatization, this paper proposes a classification method for fact-check-worthiness estimation based on prompt tuning. We construct a model for fact-check-worthiness estimation at the methodological level using prompt tuning. By applying designed prompt templates to large language models, we establish in-context learning and leverage prompt tuning technology to improve the accuracy of determining whether claims have fact-check-worthiness, particularly when dealing with limited or unlabeled data. Through extensive experiments on public datasets, we demonstrate that the proposed method surpasses or matches multiple baseline methods in the classification task of fact-check-worthiness estimation assessment, including classical pre-trained models such as BERT, as well as recent popular large models like GPT-3.5 and GPT-4. Experiments show that the prompt tuning-based method proposed in this study exhibits certain advantages in evaluation metrics such as F1 score and accuracy, thereby effectively validating its effectiveness and advancement in the task of fact-check-worthiness estimation.

title: Prediction Model of Return Rate in Cross-Border E-Commerce Based on K-Nearest Neighbor Algorithm
authors: Liping Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: With the rapid growth of cross-border e-commerce, the return rate has become a key factor for enterprises to reduce operating costs and improve customer satisfaction. The optimization of the return rate helps optimize inventory management and logistics arrangements and enables data support for enterprises to formulate effective marketing strategies. In this study, a prediction model of the return rate in cross-border e-commerce was constructed based on the K-nearest neighbor (KNN) algorithm. The historical transaction data of a cross-border e-commerce platform was collected and underwent data pre-processing and feature selection. The performance of the KNN model was optimized by adjusting the k value and distance measurement methods, and the prediction accuracy of the model was evaluated by using the cross-validation method. The experimental results showed that the optimized KNN model showed high accuracy and stability.

title: A Multi-Feature Fusion Model for State-of-Health Prediction in Lithium-Ion Batteries
authors: Sheng Xie, Yizhuo Zhao, Boming Chen, Yining Liu, Zhixuan Wang, Yunxia Chen
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Accurate prediction of the state of health (SOH) of lithium-ion batteries is crucial to ensure the safety and reliability of the system, but the existing prediction methods have some problems, such as difficult model application, lack of degradation mechanism characterization, insufficient information utilization, and difficult fusion training. Addressing this issue, this paper proposes a feature fusion machine learning model based on the CNN-LSTM-Attention-FC architecture. The model fuses Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) and low-frequency electrochemical noise (LF-ECN) features to achieve high-precision prediction of the battery SOH. The results demonstrate that the mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) of the fused feature model is 0.01376, which is over 70 % performance improvement over the single feature model. It verifies the effectiveness of the feature fusion strategy. Utilizing the CNN-LSTM-Attention-FC architecture for feature fusion effectively captures the hidden key features in the fused data, significantly improves the prediction capability of the fusion model, and provides a reliable technical solution for SOH prediction of lithium-ion batteries.

title: The Ionization Equilibrium and Electrical Conductivity of Dense Nonideal Plasmas
authors: Y. S. Seitkozhanov, Y. A. Tashkenbayev, E. O. Shalenov, K. N. Dzhumagulova
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Studying nonideal plasmas presents both challenges and opportunities for advancing our understanding of matter under extreme conditions. Recent advancements in experimental techniques [1] have significantly improved our ability to validate and refine theoretical models, underscoring the importance of detailed investigations into the thermodynamic, optical, and transport properties of these plasmas.

title: Vocal Onset Detection and Pitch Segmentation in Medieval Choral Music Guided by Original Notational Sources
authors: Samuel D. Bellows, Sarabeth S. Mullins, Brian F.G. Katz
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Accurate vocal onset detection is essential to many music information retrieval and music performance analysis tasks. While most algorithms and approaches perform favorably on contemporary popular instrumental music, precise vocal onset detection remains an elusive challenge, especially when expanded to include genres outside the typical applications. In particular, onset detection of medieval choral music faces further obstacles due to melismatic passages, variable expressing timing, fast-time and slow-time pitch variations, and an abstract notational system. To overcome these challenges, this work proposes a jumping dynamic time warping classifier to segment recorded audio frames to their respective plainchant neume. The approach uses an iterative maximum a posteriori pitch estimate to dynamically adjust neume pitch class from the initial scored values. The proposed algorithm shows significant improvements in vocal onset detection compared to standard and state-of-the-art audio-only and audio-alignment approaches.

title: Human-CLAP: Human-perception-based Contrastive Language-audio Pretraining
authors: Taisei Takano, Yuki Okamoto, Yusuke Kanamori, Yuki Saito, Ryotaro Nagase, Hiroshi Saruwatari
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Contrastive language-audio pretraining (CLAP) is widely used for audio generation and recognition tasks. For example, CLAPScore, which utilizes the similarity of CLAP embeddings, has been a major metric for the evaluation of the relevance between audio and text in text-to-audio. However, the relationship between CLAPScore and human subjective evaluation scores is still unclarified. We show that CLAPScore has a low correlation with human subjective evaluation scores. Additionally, we propose a human-perception-based CLAP called Human-CLAP by training a contrastive language-audio model using the subjective evaluation score. In our experiments, the results indicate that our Human-CLAP improved the Spearman's rank correlation coefficient (SRCC) between the CLAPScore and the subjective evaluation scores by more than 0.17 compared with the conventional CLAP.

title: Design of High-voltage Stator with Ring-type Air-core Armature for Direct Grid-connected HTS Synchronous Condenser
authors: Jiabo Shou, Chao Luo, Jien Ma, Pengcheng Huang, Yuang Zheng, Jie Chao, Youtong Fang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: The direct grid-connected high-temperature super conducting synchronous condenser (HTSSC) has high application potential in the new energy grid, based on its advantages of strong inertia support, high short-circuit capacity, high power density and fast response speed. Therefore, this paper explores the feasible technical solutions for direct grid-connected HTSSCs. By comparing the advantages and disadvantages of stators with different air-core armature structures in high-voltage applications, the stator with ring-type air-core armature is selected as the design basis. The insulation system and cooling system of the 35kV high-voltage stator are comprehensively designed. The insulation reliability and anticorona ability of the high-voltage stator are verified through electric field simulation. At the same time, the cooling effect of the air-cooling system on the armature winding and the stator core is verified through temperature field simulation. The results show that the special insulation system of the stator with ring-type air-core armature can achieve an armature current density of 3.5A/mm2, which is higher than that of the traditional synchronous condenser of the same power level. Therefore, the stator with ring-type air-core armature has the potential for high-voltage applications and can support the direct grid-connected operation of the HTSSC.

title: Enhancing Speech Quality in Scintillating Satellite Communications: A Rician Fading Modeling Approach
authors: Teh Kah Kuan, Sun Hanwu, Tran Huy Dat
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Ionospheric scintillation causes rapid signal fluctuations that degrade satellite voice communications. While radio wave propagation under scintillation is well studied, its impact on speech signals is less understood. This work introduces a speech modeling framework using variable K-factor Rician fading to simulate scintillation effects. We propose two enhancement methods: a lightweight RNN for real-time use and a score-driven diffusion model for high-fidelity restoration. Both are trained on augmented datasets generated by our proposed scintillated speech model and joint optimization framework. Compared to the Cornell scintillation toolkit, our approach yields consistently better speech quality. This work contributes a practical solution for enhancing speech quality in satellite aviation communications.

title: Directional Filtering of Sound Fields for Emphasizing Specific Directions of Arrival and Its Applications
authors: Ryo Murakami, Natsuki Ueno
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This paper proposes a directional filtering method for sound fields that enhances components arriving from a specified direction while preserving spatial acoustic information. The proposed directional filtering is formulated as a linear operator that applies directional weighting to a sound field based on the direction of arrival. Under a von Mises-Fisher-type weighting function, we derive a closed-form expression of the proposed directional filtering for sound fields represented as a superposition of spherical wave functions, which is one of the fundamental representations of sound fields. As an application, we also present a framework in which the proposed directional filtering is applied to sound fields estimated using microphone array measurements. Numerical experiments demonstrate that the proposed directional filtering can effectively enhance a specified directional component, even when the original sound field is not represented in an objectbased manner, including source position information.

title: Physics-Guided Modeling for Fault Detection in Analog Circuits Using ODE-GRU
authors: Chuhuan Zhang, Weiwei Hu, Jiahui Pan, Haoyan Wu, Ran Wang, Jingqi Wang, Yuwen Wang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Traditional diagnostic methods struggle with issues such as component aging, parameter drift, and inherent nonlinearities, while purely data-driven approaches-despite their ability to capture complex patterns-often suffer from poor interpretability and limited generalizability due to their “black-box” nature. The study proposes a physics-guided fault diagnosis method for analog circuits using an ODE-GRU model, which integrates the continuous dynamic description of ordinary differential equations (ODEs) with the temporal modeling capability of gated recurrent units (GRUs). A SallenKey circuit was simulated in LTspice, and representative timedomain fault data were generated via systematic fault injection and Monte Carlo analysis. The proposed method accurately captures dynamic anomalies caused by parameter drift in sensitive components, achieving a diagnostic accuracy of 90.44% a 17.55% improvement over conventional GRU models. The embedded physical constraints enhance interpretability and robustness, particularly under noise and nonlinear interference. Experimental results demonstrate that the ODE-GRU model effectively distinguishes between fault types, offering a reliable, data-efficient, and generalizable approach for circuit fault detection.

title: IoT Plant Monitoring and Pest Control
authors: Thirunavukkarasu J, Naveenkumar P, Akash A, Anish Karthick S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: This research describes an IoT-based smart plant monitoring and pest management solution aimed at boosting agriculture’s productivity and ecological footprint. A mesh of sensors captures critical variables: soil moisture, temperature, humidity, pH, and light intensity. Supplementary biosensors, combined with image recognition, identify pest presence and early signs of plant distress. Data from these sensors is relayed to a microcontroller that runs adaptive algorithms, activating the irrigation and pest control mechanisms whenever measurements exceed established limits. Farmers interact with the system through a dedicated mobile app, accessing real-time readings, adjusting thresholds, and controlling devices over a Wi-Fi link, thereby permitting remote supervision. Prior to analysis, readings undergo normalization and feature extraction, which refine the input for subsequent predictive tasks. Ensemble learning classifiers are then deployed to enhance the accuracy of pest forecasting and resource allocation decisions. Trials in farmers’ fields reveal notable reductions in irrigation volumes, diminished crop damage from insect infestations, and decreased reliance on manual labour. The outcome is a modular, resource-efficient, and intelligent framework that aligns with the principles of sustainable modern agriculture.

title: Rethinking Robust ASR Strategies: Can Textual in-Context Learning Improve Acoustic Robustness?
authors: Benita Angela Titalim, Faisal Mehmood, Sakriani Sakti
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Automatic speech recognition (ASR) systems have achieved high accuracy under clean conditions, yet their performance deteriorates in real-world environments with acoustic variability. Most existing robustness methods focus on the acoustic side-using enhancement techniques, noise-aware training, or specialized architectures-but often struggle to generalize across diverse conditions, especially when background noise includes non-target human speech. In this work, we focus on ASR robustness against a range of irrelevant inputs that commonly occur in daily life-namely, stationary noise, background music with vocals, and human utterances not belonging to the target speaker. Crucially, when noise takes the form of intelligible speech, it introduces linguistic interference that purely acoustic methods may fail to suppress. This motivates our investigation of a novel, language-level approach: leveraging textual in-context learning with large language models (LLMs) to guide ASR output through prompting. Experiment results demonstrate that this strategy enhances robustness without requiring retraining or front-end modification, providing a flexible and scalable alternative to conventional acoustic-centric methods.

title: Multimodal AI-Integrated Performance Monitoring System for Global Team Management
authors: Laxmi Sarat Chandra Nunnaguppala, K.S. Meenakshisundaram, Avinash Gupta Desetty, Abhishek Venkteshwar, Balaram Bora, Kareem Khudayer
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: The emerging tendency of geographically distributed teams has brought on the urgency of smart, dynamic performance monitoring systems. The Multimodal AI-Integrated Performance Monitoring System offered in this paper gives insights on the mode of prompt, data-driven information on the performance of employees working under different global teams by capitalizing on the empowered machine learning (ML) or data prediction expertise. The system combines various form of information (such as communication logs, task completion analytics, behavioral analytics, sentiment data) to comprehensively determine productivity, engagement and collaboration. The system provides high accuracy of multimodal data fusion and predictive performance points, using Transformer-based architectures, especially the OpenAI Whisper model to analyze a voice data and TabNet to interpret structured data. The important characteristics are anomaly detection of workflows, adaptive benchmarking, and feedback loops of continuous enhancement by intelligence. The platform powered by ML can be labeled as an important milestone of global HR technology that can help organizations to optimize teamwork, improve accountability, and enable big-data-informed decision-making.

title: Green Finance and Transformation Based on Big Data and Regression Model
authors: Ziyi Zhang, Hongzhen Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: We explored the mechanism and implementation effect of green finance and transformation on the manufacturing industry. For the "dual carbon" target, China National Petroleum Corporation has adopted the green transformation based on green loans, climate insurance, and carbon market participation. Using the panel data of Chinese A-share industrial manufacturing companies from 2010 to 2023, we constructed a green transformation index system and a dual fixed effect model to estimate the level of green finance using the entropy method. Using the system and the model, we calculated energy intensity and pollution emission degree. The results showed that green finance reduced the energy consumption intensity and the emission intensity of an enterprise and verified its positive role in promoting green transformation. Green finance enables the "environment-tech" by constraining emissions through environmental regulations and optimizing resource allocation to support technological innovation. Based on the results, policies were proposed. The results provide a theoretical basis and reference for improving the green finance mechanism and the sustainable development of the manufacturing industry.

title: An Automatically Optimized RFID Protocol for Freshness Preservation
authors: Changyu Huang, Weiping Zhu, Chao Ma, Runze Wu, Changjie Fan, Minmin Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) is critical for applications like freshness preservation in warehouses, where monitoring environmental data is essential. Existing protocols are inefficient for such requirements, and manual protocol design is resource-intensive. To address this, we propose an automated approach for composing and optimizing RFID protocols. We first introduce a generic RFID requirement description language (GRDL) to formally specify complex requirements and integrate the most similar existing protocols. Then, we introduce an automated performance optimization method for the composed protocols using communication merging, parameter tuning, intermediate parameter reuse and context-aware method adjustments. This method is generic and broadly applicable. For freshness preservation, our protocol outperforms the state-of-the-art protocol SEM by over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 1. 3 1 \%}$</tex>, and the further optimized version reduces the execution time by 58.56 % to 63.46 %.

title: Image Rearrangement for Fast on-Drone Tiny Object Detection
authors: Hyeonji Hong, Chanyoung Oh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: Although commercial networks such as LTE and 5G have seen significant improvements, they sometimes face challenges in providing reliable, low-latency links between high-altitude platforms, such as autonomous drones, and remote servers as they are primarily designed for terrestrial use. As a result, on-drone object detection becomes necessary, but the limited computational capacity of typical mission computers makes real-time inference infeasible. Moreover, the inference latency of state-of-the-art deep-learning detectors is determined solely by the input resolution, irrespective of scene content; this produces severe inefficiencies when targets occupy only a small portion of each drone-captured image frame. To address these challenges, this paper presents image-rearrangement techniques that automatically extract RoIs from each frame and re-tiles them into a compact, high-density layout so as to reduce overall computation. With our evaluation on a drone-captured image dataset, we achieve substantial speedups up to 4.86x while maintaining detection accuracy.

title: Poster: Multi-Source and Multi-Modal Fake News Detection via a Compositional Fusion Mechanism
authors: Chong Ma, Yongxin Yu, Ke Ji, Zhenxiang Chen, Kun Ma, Xiaofan Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a multi-source multi-modal CFM-FND. First, we focus on the collection, selection, and cleaning of multi-source heterogeneous data to construct a multisource, multi-modal dataset that includes reports from multiple perspectives. The dataset offers a comprehensive view of each event. Secondly, by utilizing the visual transformer instead of the traditional CNN as the visual feature extractor, we unify the processing of text and image inputs into a convolution-free process. At the same time, the text semantic perception module and the visual semantic perception module are designed to fuse news text and images from multiple sources. Fiimage inputs into anally, the bidirectional attention mechanism is used to enhance image-text correlation features, adjusting and optimizing the representation of one modality based on the content of the other. Experimental results and analysis demonstrate that the model we proposed can provide an effective solution for fake news detection in the era of big data.

title: Bidirectional LLC Converter with Wide Range Operation Based on Hybrid Modulation
authors: Xuewei Pan, Xulin Chen, Sinan Li, Can Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Industrial Electronics and Applications Conference (IEACon)
abstract: To achieve high efficiency operation under the constraint of bidirectional operation over wide output voltage for the electric vehicles charging station with V2G function, a hybrid regulation strategy is proposed for bidirectional LLC converter. In forward power transmission, LLC full bridge variable frequency, full bridge phase shift, half bridge variable frequency, and burst modulation techniques are combined to effectively improve the output voltage range of LLC converter. In case of reverse power transmission, a delayed boost modulation is proposed in addition to conventional variable frequency modulation. The smooth switching methods between multiple modulation techniques are proposed as well. The simulation model and experimental prototype have been built. The experiment results show that the proposed hybrid modulation strategy can effectively realize the wide range soft switching operation of the bidirectional LLC converter.

title: SoldierCare: Blockchain-Enabled IoMT Framework for Real-Time Health Monitoring and Cyberattack Detection in Tactical Environments
authors: Chigozie Athanasius Nnadiekwe, Collins Izuchukwu Okafor, Ikechi Saviour Igboanusi, Jae Min Lee, Dong-Seong Kim
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: SoldierCare is a real-time, blockchain-enabled Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) framework designed to enhance military personnel safety through integrated health monitoring and cyberattack detection. The system employs a hybrid Convolutional Neural Network-Long Short-Term Memory (CNN-LSTM) model trained on the WUSTL-EHMS-2020 dataset, combining physiological sensor data and network traffic to identify both health anomalies and malicious activities with high accuracy. A smart contract-enabled Ethereum blockchain ensures the integrity and traceability of alerts by immutably logging metadata, while detailed data is stored off-chain in IPFS to reduce on-chain overhead. The architecture supports edge deployment, enabling low-latency inference and autonomous operation in mission-critical environments. Experimental results demonstrate a detection accuracy of 98.6%, with efficient scaling and minimal false detections. Optimizations such as transaction batching enhance blockchain performance under increasing load. SoldierCare represents a secure, scalable solution that fuses AI, fog computing, and blockchain to provide resilient operational support in dynamic battlefield scenarios.

title: ZMDFS: A Zero-Migration Distributed File System for Data Centers
authors: Jinfeng Zhang, Shicheng Song, Jiang Zhou, Yanbiao Guo, Bo Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Data migration during cluster scaling is a critical challenge in distributed file systems, causing high I/O overhead and performance degradation. Typical data distribution algorithms, such as consistent hashing, can reduce data movement when new nodes are added. However, they still require relocating a substantial portion of data, which limits scalability and elasticity. This paper proposes ZMDFS, a novel distributed file system that leverages hashing-based method for data placement while achieving zero-migration during cluster expansion. To eliminate data movement, ZMDFS introduces a group-based partitioning strategy that divides existing and newly added nodes into independent, fixed-membership subclusters, ensuring data distribution stability and avoiding costly rebalancing. A multi-objective optimization approach is designed to intelligently select groups for data placement, based on the goals of data balancing, load balancing, and throughput maximization. After that, to place one data in the group, a list of node hash values is generated using Jenkins hashing, based on node IDs and the data path, while considering temporarily failed or offline nodes. During data distribution, ZMDFS prioritizes available nodes from the hash list, thereby avoiding data movement caused by temporary node failures or offline events within every group. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that ZMDFS reduces data migration and rebalancing time by over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{9 6 \%}$</tex> compared to GlusterFS, significantly enhancing scalability and system performance during dynamic cluster scaling.

title: Multi-Robotic Partial Disassembly Line Balancing Optimization Problem Considering Robotic Efficiency Difference
authors: Tianyang Fang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: To enhance the efficiency of remanufacturing waste electronic products, this study proposes a multi-robotic partial disassembly line to improve the disposal of excessive waste. The multi-robotic partial disassembly line represents a technological advancement over traditional manual disassembly lines. Line balancing optimization can enhance both the efficiency and stability of the disassembly process. To address the partial disassembly line balancing problem with multirobotic stations (PDLB-MRS), a mixed-integer programming model (MIPM) considering robotic efficiency differences is formulated to minimize cycle time, energy consumption, and hazard index while determining their global optimal values. Furthermore, an improved NSGA-II algorithm (INSGA-II) is developed to efficiently optimize the PDLB-MRS. Finally, MIPM and INSGA-II are applied to a real-world mixed disassembly case involving two types of computers. The comparative results obtained using GUROBI and INSGA-II validate the accuracy of the model and demonstrate the superior performance of the algorithm. Moreover, the derived Pareto solution set offers multiple decision-making options.

title: Model-Driven Development of Web Application Backend Using Node.js Framework
authors: Werayoot Kunphai, Twittie Senivongse
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Model-Driven Development (MDD) has emerged as a promising software engineering paradigm that uses models as the primary artifacts to support software development including web application development. This paper presents a novel application of the MDD principles for Node.JS backend development, focusing on both forward and reverse engineering processes. A UML Profile for Node.js, supporting both SQL and NoSQL databases, is introduced for building design models of web applications. Transformation engines are provided for model-to-code (M2C) and code-to-model (C2M) transformation. The proposed approach was evaluated through three case studies. The forward engineering results demonstrated high model-to-code transformation rates especially for Model (86.18-94.53%) and Route (70.73-90.52%), with consistent performance across SQL (MySQL) and NoSQL (MongoDB) implementations. The reverse engineering results showed 100% correctness in code-to-model transformation for different implementations of backend code. This approach significantly reduces development time for code development while maintaining system documentation through automated model generation, providing a practical solution for Node.JS backend development and maintenance.

title: Fostering Industry 5.0 through Engineering Innovation: A Framework for Enhancing Creativity, Problem-Solving, and Early-Stage Technical Competency in Future Engineers
authors: Wai Yie Leong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: The global engineering landscape transitions toward Industry 5.0, characterized by human-centric automation, hyper-customization, and sustainable co-creation. Therefore, it is needed to reconfigure educational paradigms to educate engineers to be equipped with advanced creativity, transdisciplinary problem-solving, and foundational technical acumen. In this study, a framework was developed, leveraging design-driven engineering innovation platforms, such as structured design fairs, to embed Industry 5.0 principles into undergraduate and early-career engineering curricula. Anchored in cyber-physical frameworks integration, digital twin modeling, and human-machine collaborative intelligence, the framework operationalizes experiential learning cycles to promote ideation, rapid prototyping, and frameworkic validation under real-world constraints. The framework is grounded in established engineering epistemologies, incorporating Bloom’s revised taxonomy for cognitive development, TRIZ-based methodologies for creative problem-solving, and ABET-aligned frameworks for assessing technical competencies. Empirical validation of the framework was conducted through multi-site intervention studies involving 320 engineering students. Metrics were used to assess computational thinking, embedded frameworks design, sustainability heuristics, and collaborative intelligence in pre- and post-intervention. The results indicated significant improvements in students’ abilities to decompose complex problems, demonstrate proficiency in digital fabrication, and apply frameworks engineering principles effectively. The results also presented the potential of innovation-driven educational interventions for advancing Industry 5.0 readiness. Such interventions help to solve the cognitive and technical divide between academic instruction and industrial application. The developed framework integrates ethical, innovative, and human-centric competencies into the curricula, enhancing educational outcomes to meet industrial demands.

title: Multi-Agent OSINT Architecture with Graph RAG Integration and Hierarchical Bloom-Filter Deduplication
authors: Gökhan Yurtalan, Serdar Arslan
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: Open Source Intelligence (OSINT) pipelines are required to analyze millions of heterogeneous data items, ranging from news articles to social media posts, under strict quality attributes such as functional correctness, latency, and resource efficiency. Building on our previous Quality Attribute Workshop (QAW), Attribute-Driven Design (ADD), and Architecture Trade-off Analysis Method (ATAM) studies, this paper introduces a fourth ADD iteration that reconsiders three architectural decisions previously identified as risk points in the earlier design. First, instead of a single “mega-agent,” a set of specialized micro-agents was employed for stance detection, named entity recognition, contradiction detection, ontology enrichment, and report generation. Second, a Retrieval-Augmented Generation with Graphs (GraphRAG) layer, which manages knowledge graph triples alongside vector embeddings, has been incorporated to eliminate separate graph and vector stores and to shorten the query path. Third, a probabilistic Bloom filter that performs URL refresh operations with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathcal{O}(1)$</tex> complexity and without generating false negatives has replaced key-value- based caches, resulting in a significant reduction in memory usage. A prototype evaluation was conducted using three datasets containing 1 million, 2 million, and 3 million URLs. The use of the Bloom filter increased the in-memory URL query speed by 10000% during runtime. The updated ATAM sessions confirmed that the previously identified risk and trade-off scenarios are no longer considered risks, thus validating that the proposed improvements significantly enhanced the system's functional suitability, performance, and resource utilization attributes. Updated ATAM sessions demonstrated that previously identified risk and tradeoff scenarios were no longer considered risks, confirming that the proposed improvements have significantly enhanced the system's functional suitability, performance, and resource utilization attributes.

title: Multimodal AI-Guided Resource Allocation System for Dynamic Cloud Data Workloads
authors: Anand Chauhan, Lakshya Sahai
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Growing dynamism and volatility of workloads in cloud environments have accompanied the exponentially strong increase in cloud based services and data-driven applications. An efficient allocation of the resources in the face of such variability is important to uphold the system performance and cost-effectiveness. The research introduces Multimodal AI-Guided Resource Allocation System aiming at realizing dynamic optimization of cloud resource management through deep reinforcement learning (DRL) coupled with real-time telemetry information. The system uses Apache Flink as a real-time stream processing application and includes all the data modalities (heterogeneous data types) such as CPU/memory usage, network I/O, and user demand patterns to support proactive and intelligent workload distribution. Use of AI will enable the smart system to learn the best allocation policies based on the feedback mechanism, which is adaptively scalable and better quality of service. This research would move the current state-of-the-art in AI-based cloud orchestration through the incorporation of multimodal data understanding into the use of real-time decisions.

title: TOI National Grader: A Support System for the Selection and Preparation of Thailand Informatics Olympiad Participants
authors: Jirayus Arbking, Watcharaphong Yookwan, Nilrat Kanyunthong, Kriengsak Panphotong, Sithipong Chimthai, Krisana Chinnasarn
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Thailand organizes annual national academic Olympiad competitions to enhance students’ capabilities and prepare them for international-level contests. In response to recent changes in the student selection process initiated by the Promotion of Academic Olympiad and Development of Science Education Foundation (POSN), a new system was required to accommodate the updated framework. This paper introduces the TOI-National Grader, a system designed to support the revised selection process and training camps.
