A key feature of the system is its ability to support all POSN training camps nationwide by integrating the CMS Grader platform with additional custom-developed components, enabling seamless coordination and functionality. This paper also discusses the technical challenges encountered during development and system deployment.

title: Plasma Technologies for Vertical Farming
authors: J. F. Kolb, T. M.C. Nishime, S. Bousselmi, M. Schmidt, U. Hoffmann, M. Timm, R. Rataj, M. Schneider, N. Wannicke, K.-D. Weltmann
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Greens, crops and fruits that are cultivated in vertical farming systems are increasingly contributing to the supply especially in highly urbanized societies. The method offers fast and many subsequent growth cycles that are independent from environmental factors. However, different challenges need to be addressed. Foremost important is a clean production that prevents the spread of pathogens. Ideally no synthetic agrochemicals, such as in particular plant protection agents but also fertilizers, are required. Economic constraints demand an efficient use of resources, i.e., by recirculating water. The decontamination and disinfection, especially of water, are predestined for plasma technologies. Without any other consumables but electrical power, plasma offers an environmentally benign, sustainable and controllable solution. In addition, plasma treated water can provide nitrogen as fertilizer and plasma treatments of seeds offer an alternative for seed hygiene and even the stimulation of germination and plant growth [1], [2]. Accordingly, we investigated plasma technologies in a vertical farming system of the 4th generation, which allows the complete environmental control of growth conditions for economically relevant conditions for 600 plants, i.e., Basil. Scale and scope are distinct advantages in comparison to so far mostly conducted laboratory experiments. A recirculating water system was integrated with the possibility to investigate different plasma treatment concepts concerning maintenance of system hygiene and to replace the need for additional nitrogen fertilizers. The results for a growth period of 4-6 weeks demonstrate the successful replacement of nitrogen fertilizers and efficient reduction of microbial loads and their associated impact on plant health. Different operating principles were considered with respect to economic constraints and advantages, such as water savings.

title: Design of a Compact 200-Kv MARX Generator for Pulsed Power Modulators
authors: Aaesha Al Ali, Umar Hashmi, Siarhei Ahafonau, Gideon Appiah, Fernando Albarracin, Felix Vega
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: This paper presents the design, modeling, and experimental validation of a compact five-stage Marx generator developed for pulsed-power modulator applications. The system delivers up to 200 kV output voltage and is capable of driving capacitive loads at high repetition rates. The complete generator is housed within a 5.35 L cylindrical enclosure weighing 9 kg, achieving one of the most compact implementations in its class. Circuit and electrostatic simulations were performed to evaluate the influence of parasitic elements and insulation performance, with results showing a strong correlation to experimental measurements. The generator was tested over 100,000 shots, demonstrating reliable operation and stable output under repetitive pulsing. Dielectric insulation is achieved using pressurized sulfur hexafluoride (SF6) in combination with a high-density polyethylene (HDPE) liner, ensuring high-voltage endurance and operational consistency. The generator produces 200 kV peak pulses with an 8 ns rise time and 15 ns duration, confirming its suitability for compact high-voltage pulsedpower applications.

title: Quantification Method of Operating Space Based on Convex Collision and Posture Comfort Analysis
authors: Qingtian Yang, Dong Zhou, Jinlong Zhao, Qidi Zhou, Zicheng Song, Yan Zhang, Yunbo Li
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Industry 5.0 highlights human - centric and capability - enhanced maintenance demands. In complex industrial equipment repair, confined spaces and dense obstacles pose significant challenges to operating space. Current methods have limitations like qualitative descriptions, collision constraint neglect, and difficulty in integrating ergonomics. This paper proposes a quantitative method combining convex hull collisions and posture comfort. Using the CoACD algorithm for efficient preprocessing of complex obstacle environments, it generates feasible operational domains considering upper - limb joint constraints and inverse kinematics. The GJK algorithm handles collision penalties, and the RULA scoring system manages posture penalties. A normalized operator then provides a quantitative evaluation of the operating space. The core innovation lies in the normalized comprehensive evaluation model, which first unifies the quantitative expression of operational entity reachability, obstacle avoidance, and comfort. Experimental validation shows that this method effectively analyzes operating space characteristics, offering a standardized quantitative assessment tool to support human computer collaborative decision - making, optimize maintenance task planning and facility layout, and enhance operators' health and efficiency.

title: Intelligent Fault Mode Extraction Method for New Energy Vehicles Based on Large Language Models
authors: Yuchen Hu, Siru Wang, Rui Shi, Yihai He
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of new energy vehicle (NEV) technology, traditional fault mode screening methods have become increasingly inadequate in addressing the complexities and rapid iterations of product design in the context of big data. Thus, a fault mode screening method based on large language models (LLMs) is proposed, which aiming to efficiently and accurately extract key fault patterns through automated analysis of after-sales service records. Leveraging the contextual understanding capabilities of LLMs, the method transforms unstructured fault descriptions into structured triadic knowledge representations. By integrating knowledge graph technology, a comprehensive knowledge network is constructed, encompassing fault modes, product components, fault causes, and repair solutions. Furthermore, this paper employs a fine-tuning approach based on Simple Contrastive Learning of Sentence Embeddings (SimCSE), which enhances the model's semantic understanding of texts in the NEV domain through contrastive learning, thereby further optimizing the accuracy of fault mode identification. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach exhibits high accuracy and robustness in handling complex fault descriptions, providing an intelligent solution for fault prediction and quality improvement in new energy vehicles.

title: Accelerating VVC Inter-Frame Coding: A Lightweight CNN for Fast QTMT Partitioning
authors: Jui-Chen Luo, Jiann-Jone Chen, Tien-Ying Kuo, Yi-Fan Wu, Kai-Jie Zhang
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: The H.266/Versatile Video Coding (VVC) standard offers <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 0 \%}-\mathbf{5 0 \%}$</tex> higher compression efficiency than its predecessor, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{H. 2 6 5} / \mathbf{H E V C}$</tex>, while maintaining comparable visual quality. However, this improvement comes at the cost of substantially higher computational complexity, posing challenges for real-time encoding. In particular, VVC's Quad-Tree plus Multi-type Tree (QTMT) block partitioning, high-precision motion compensation, and multi-directional prediction contribute to encoding times that are 8 to 10 times longer than those of HEVC. To address this issue, we propose a lightweight, adaptive information (LAI-CNN), a compact CNN-based model featuring a three-stage prediction scheme that integrates VVC inter-coding structure constraints to make fast and accurate QTMT partitioning decisions, thereby reducing redundant RDO operations while maintaining a compact model architecture. Experimental results under the VTM22.0 Random Access configuration show that LAI-CNN achieves a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 6. 3 5 \% - 4 9. 2 0 \%}$</tex> reduction in encoding time, with only a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 3 6 \% -}$</tex> 3.48% increase in Bjøntegaard Delta Bit Rate (BDBR). These results demonstrate that the proposed coding acceleration framework significantly reduces VVC encoding complexity, enabling practical deployment in real-time scenarios such as live streaming, interactive video services, and cloud-based processing.

title: Radiation Cooling Performance of Radiant Ceiling Air Conditioning System
authors: Xuan Yao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: Radiant cooling technology is widely applied in indoor air conditioning. Integrating radiant air conditioning systems with fresh air systems enables a clean indoor environment while ensuring energy efficiency and comfort. This method also significantly reduces energy consumption, improves thermal comfort, and enhances air quality. In this study, the radiant cooling performance of the radiant ceiling cooling system was evaluated. The experimental results showed an average indoor temperature of 22.6°C, and the temperature difference was less than 1.6°C and 1.4°C horizontally and vertically, indicating a uniform temperature distribution and enhanced comfort levels. The radiant ceiling cooling system provided a dehumidification capacity of 19.21 g/kg, demonstrating an effective dehumidification performance. The average temperature of the ceiling surface was 22.4°C, higher than the air’s dew point temperature, preventing condensation.

title: Quadratic Response Function of a Dense Plasma to Electromagnetic Field
authors: G. A. Pavlov
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Nonlinear phenomena in various media (crystals, graphene, various mixtures, composites, ionized gases, suspensions, etc.) related to the nonlinear interaction of electromagnetic waves are intensively studied. At the same time, nonlinear phenomena in dense charged systems (Coulomb systems and plasma) caused by a quadratic reaction to an electromagnetic field, for example, second harmonic generation (SHG), parametric radiation generation (PGR), have not been studied. To avoid this drawback, we investigate SHG and PGR in dense plasma. SHG and PGR can be implemented in laboratory conditions in the presence of stationary relatively strong magnetic fields. The calculated characteristics of these phenomena are determined by the quadratic response function (QRF) of a charged substance in a constant magnetic field to an electromagnetic field. Research shows that a consistent analytical calculation of exact formal expressions for QRF (obtained within the framework of the theory of nonlinear response) of non-ideal charged media is impossible. Computer modeling of exact expressions for QRF has not been carried out even for model non-ideal Coulomb systems. Therefore, it is recommended to use a model approach to determine these functions. We propose a variant of the model: using an explicit approximation for the response function with appropriate parameters based on the exact frequency moments of the QRF and the corresponding correlators. For this purpose, a quadratic fluctuation-dissipation theorem is formulated and the frequency moments of triple correlators and QRF to the electromagnetic field (EF) of dense charged media in a permanent magnetic field are calculated, which are the basis of the proposed model. In accordance with this model, the structure of QRF to an electromagnetic field of a non-ideal laboratory electron-ion hydrogen plasma in a constant magnetic field and the corresponding characteristics of SHG and PGR are investigated.

title: Geometric Impact of Volume Dielectric Barrier Discharge Electrodes on Biological Substrates: An Investigation via Electro-Optical Characterization
authors: Jonathan E. Thomas, Kristina S. Pattison, Darby M. Roberts, Jordan Simpson, Duncan Trosan, Brian C. Gilger, Katharina Stapelmann
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Cold atmospheric plasma (CAP) generated by volume dielectric barrier discharges (VDBDs) offers a non-thermal, antimicrobial treatment modality for biological tissues. This study investigates how different electrode geometries affect plasma behavior during treatment of various fungi strains and infected corneal tissue. Our results reveal geometry-dependent changes in dissipated power, and filament activity. The treatment of different biological substrates can also jointly affect plasma coupling parameters when serving as the counter electrode regardless of identical applied settings. These findings emphasize the need to tailor electrode design to specific biological substrates within plasma medicine applications.

title: Investigation of Polarization Effects in Wireless Communication Systems Considering Snow-Laden Surfaces in Extreme Environments
authors: Jinkyu Bang, Seungjae Baek, Jae Hee Kim
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: This study analyzes the effects of multilayer ground reflections on wireless communication between an Autonomous Mobile Robot (AMR) and a base station in extreme environments. Snow-covered ground is modeled as a three-layer medium, and the reflection behavior is examined under vertical and horizontal polarization conditions. Using the Friis equation at 2.4 GHz, the impact of reflection-induced interference on received power is evaluated. Results show that horizontal polarization experiences greater interference due to phase reversal, while vertical polarization provides more stable performance. The findings underscore the importance of selecting appropriate polarization for reliable LOS communication in snow-laden environments.

title: Comparative Studies on Hybrid Quantum Machine Learning
authors: Mădălina Spiridon, Lenuţa Alboaie
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: Quantum machine learning is an emerging Technology that is evolving rapidly and aims to translate classical machine learning models into a quantum context to be extended with the properties and applications of quantum mechanics. Despite the obvious advantage of being able to process large amounts of data in a short time, this integration between quantum and machine learning is not without challenges, especially when it comes to real datasets. In this paper, we aim to analyze the practical applicability of quantum machine learning approaches and to perform different experiments on generated and dedicated datasets that respect the quantum kernel training pattern, respectively, on real datasets, and to determine whether these can be processed to be suitable for quantum operations. To fully see the performance and potential advantage brought by the quantum component, a series of tests will be performed on both simulators and real hardware and it remains to be seen whether there is an improvement related to time complexity. Another goal based on the experiments carried out is to see on which types of datasets it is worth or justifiable to use quantum hardware at the expense of classical one. The novelty of this work lies in the use of a real-world dataset, and the experiments demonstrate that integrating quantum methods with classical processing yields higher accuracy compared to purely classical approaches.

title: Impact of Discipline Competitions on Undergraduate Education Quality in China: An Empirical Study Based on Linear Regression and Support Vector Regression
authors: Shengli Lai, Xiaobo Wang, Guoqiang Zeng, Fei Li, Chunhui Dong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: As China strives to build world-class universities, discipline competitions have been employed to foster innovative talents and have been given attention by higher education institutions. In this study, we explored the impact of discipline competitions on the quality of undergraduate education. Using competition data and related teaching indicators collected from multiple universities in China, the following hypothesis was tested: "The development of discipline competitions significantly improves students' continuous learning capabilities". Linear regression and support vector regression (SVR) models were employed to test the hypothesis. The results showed that the competitions play a vital role in developing students' capabilities and practical skills, although their influence on students' postgraduate admission rates is modest. The results can be used for educational reform and policy adjustments, advocating for the integration of discipline competitions into educational strategies.

title: Depth Control of Underwater Vehicles Based on Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference System Proportional–Integral–Derivative Control
authors: Xuesong Wang, Shukun Wu, Jie Xu, Yuan Tian
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: We addressed parametric uncertainties and external disturbances in marine environments by investigating operating conditions in the depth regulation of underwater vehicle control systems. 6-degree-of-freedom (DOF) dynamic equations were used to characterize underwater vehicle motion. In the Simulink simulation, proportional–integral–derivative (PID) controllers for depth control of underwater vehicles were implemented using adaptive neural fuzzy inference system (ANFIS), fuzzy logic, and traditional methods, and comparative analysis. Compared with other control methods, ANFIS-PID presented the shortest adjustment time and zero overshoot.

title: Sequence Modeling and Generative Model Driven Non-Rigid 3D Reconstruction
authors: Yuxin He, Hui Deng, Mingyi He, Yuchao Dai
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Non-rigid 3D reconstruction is a critical problem in the computer vision community. Although researchers have made significant progress in recent years, two key challenges remain: (1) ensuring temporal consistency in the reconstructed results, and (2) achieving accurate reconstruction under uncertainty in the input data. To address these challenges, we propose a novel framework that integrates a Temporal Convolutional Network (TCN) for modeling sequential dependencies and ensuring temporal consistency, alongside a diffusion-based module that generates pseudo-3D structures to provide teacher supervision. This diffusion-based supervision enhances spatial accuracy, particularly under weakly supervised conditions. Extensive experiments on the Human3.6M dataset show that our approach achieves superior reconstruction performance compared to existing baselines.

title: Enhancing Machine Learning Performance Through Quantile Binning for Resource Forecasting
authors: Jim Gregorie Ilejay, Paula Marielle Ababao, Gabriel Avelino Sampedro
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: Accurate resource yield prediction is critical for military logistics, planning, and operational readiness, yet remains challenging due to numerous influencing factors such as environmental conditions, resource quality, and logistical constraints. This study examines the effectiveness of quantile-based data binning on classical machine learning algorithms in predicting resource yields pertinent to military applications. Furthermore, the effectiveness of Backpropagation Artificial Neural Networks (BP-ANN) and Naive Bayes classifiers with regression models such as K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Linear Regression, and Multi-Layer Perceptron Regressors (MLPRegressor) are compared using a robust dataset representative of global resource metrics. The results indicate that binning continuous data into quartiles substantially enhances model accuracy, precision, recall, and computational efficiency. In particular, the binned data enables the BP-ANN to achieve an accuracy of approximately 90.4%, with regression models such as KNN and MLPRegressor outperforming this benchmark by attaining accuracies exceeding 93%. Additionally, binning drastically reduced hyperparameter tuning duration from around 149 minutes to less than 10 minutes, underscoring its computational efficiency advantage. Overall, this research demonstrates that quantile-based data binning is a valuable preprocessing technique that improves predictive accuracy, reduces computational cost, and enhances the reliability of classical machine learning models for military resource forecasting.

title: A Spark Batch Application Scheduling Method Based on Improved Bottom-Up Left-Justified and Genetic Algorithm
authors: Shuo Wang, Baiyou Qiao, Yuekai Zhang, Yuqi Huo, Donghong Han, Gang Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Existing Spark task scheduling methods primarily focus on intra-application task scheduling, often overlooking the scheduling of batch applications. This limitation can lead to prolonged execution times in batch processing scenarios. To address this issue, we propose a Spark Batch Application Scheduling Method (SBASM) that incorporates application execution time awareness, combining an Improved Bottom-Up Left-Justified (IBL) algorithm with a Genetic Algorithm (GA). In this method, the batch application scheduling problem is formulated as a two-dimensional bin-packing problem. Application execution times are predicted using a polynomial regression model trained on historical execution data. Based on these predictions, the IBL algorithm integrated with GA is employed to perform efficient scheduling. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed SBASM significantly reduces the execution time of batch applications and outperforms several existing Spark baseline models.

title: Optimizing Discovery Protocol for Enhanced Network Capacity and Mitigating Broadcast Storms in Software-Defined Networks
authors: Omar Masoud, Ibraheem Shayea, Bilal Saoud, Dina Satybaldina, Murat Kozhanov, Zhuldyz Sailaukyzy
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Software-Defined Networking (SDN) is an innovative approach designed to overcome the limitations of traditional networks. SDN separates the control plane from the data plane and creates a centralized controller with node switches. Communication between the controller and the switches is established using protocols like OpenFlow. This approach provides multiple advantages, like the ability to track the network traffic and facilitate network debugging. Furthermore, the implementation of discovery protocols within SDN aids in improving the network forwarding performance by providing the controller with essential network topology information, which serves as the foundation for improved routing and forwarding algorithms. This paper proposes enhancements to the discovery protocol to optimize network capacity. Additionally, a novel algorithm is introduced to address the challenge of broadcast storms-network events in which a broadcast packet creates a loop, consuming bandwidth and resources-in complex network topologies with closed paths. And to enhance network management and debugging, a visual application is developed to give an overview of the network topology.

title: Electrodeless Double-Headed Streamer Discharges from an Isolated Ionization Column in Atmospheric Conditions
authors: B. Disson, G. Sretenovic, V. Kovacevic, N. Bonifaci, C. Pichard, C. Cachoncinlle, A. Khacef, S. Iseni
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: This poster presents a groundbreaking experimental model that successfully reproduces the natural atmospheric phenomenon of double-headed streamers (DHS) in a laboratory setting at ground pressure. This is the first of its kind to replicate the inception of an electrodeless DHS, mirroring various observations made by the atmospheric electricity community [1]. By utilizing guided ionization waves from an Atmospheric Pressure Plasma Jet (APPJ) device, the experiment achieved excellent reproducibility and predictability in triggering DHS formation. The experimental approach effectively created conditions that align with several assumptions, such as maintaining an initial preionized column of free charges before breakdown [2]. This model closely matches numerous simulation results found in modeling literature [2], [3]. The positive and negative streamers were distinctly identified, showing simultaneous counter-propagation from the breakdown location. The high stability of the discharge allowed for advanced diagnostics, including time- and space-resolved optical emission spectroscopy. This enabled the first measurements of velocity growth, gas temperature, and electric field of a DHS. The electric field values confirmed the identification of positive and negative streamers. Notably, the electric field diagnostics revealed that a DHS can ignite under sub-breakdown conditions, highlighting the essential role of preionization in DHS formation. These findings support the theory proposed in [2]. While further research is needed to fully understand the underlying mechanisms, these results pave the way for deeper investigations into the early stages of sprite discharges and other poorly understood phenomena in atmospheric electricity using affordable laboratory-scale experiments.

title: Reliability Constraints and Response Surface Method
authors: Zehan Ye, Qinglin Chen, Jiayong Zhuo, Yingqiang Cai, Zhaoyi Zhu, Xiaowen Li, Miaojiao Peng, Kuan Fan, Yezhi Qin
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: This paper presents a lightweight design model for catamarans based on a multi-objective genetic algorithm. Finite element simulations were conducted on catamaran models with different laminate thicknesses, and reliability analysis of the model's transverse bending moment and torque was performed according to the relevant standards. Combined with the response surface design method, mathematical models were established regarding laminate thickness, the total weight of the catamaran, and the strength under various working conditions. Considering the conflicts between multiple objectives, a multi-objective genetic algorithm was used for optimization. The optimization results show that the catamaran optimized using the multi-objective genetic algorithm has reduced its weight by 23.46% compared to the original weight. Although there is a slight reduction in structural strength, the calculated beta is 5.26, reliability is 0.999987, which still meets the reliability requirements of the standard. This achieves an efficient balance between lightweight design and reliability, providing a robust pathway for ship structure lightweight design.

title: Multimodal Sentiment Analysis with Missing Modality: A Knowledge-Transfer Approach
authors: Weide Liu, Huijing Zhan
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis aims to identify the emotions expressed by individuals through visual, language, and acoustic cues. However, most existing research assume that all modalities are available during both training and testing, which makes their algorithms susceptible to the missing-modality scenarios. In this paper, we propose a novel knowledge-transfer network to translate between different modalities to reconstruct the missing audio features. Moreover, we develop a cross-modality attention mechanism to maximize the information extracted from the reconstructed and observed modalities for sentiment prediction. Extensive experiments on three publicly available datasets demonstrate significant improvements over baseline methods and achieve comparable results to the previous methods with complete multi-modality supervision.

title: Trusted Federated Learning-based Fraud Detection and Battery Life Prediction Using Deep Learning Models in an Internet-Based Environment
authors: Sudha G, B Venkata Prasanth, M.Senthil, Ahmad Abdelhafiz Ali Samhan, Sreekanth Sura, Asha V
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) is important for privacy-preserving model training across different devices, but it faces challenges such as data inconsistency, security risks, and performance issues. To address these, this study presents a new method called TFFDLI, which aims to enhance prediction accuracy, safety, and reliability, particularly for predicting battery life and detecting intrusions. TFFDLI combines RNN and 1D-CNN to effectively gather features from battery voltage-capacity data, allowing for accurate predictions while maintaining data privacy. A weighting aggregation technique in federated training ensures that valuable contributions from devices greatly influence the global model. It also incorporates secure model optimization to tackle typical vulnerabilities in FL, like poisoning attacks and free-riding. Experimental results show that TFFDLI surpasses other models in terms of performance, maintaining low loss and stable results across different configurations. The model displays a strong improvement in accuracy and precision; it offers a scalable and secure solution for intrusion detection and battery health predictions.

title: Unsupervised Spectrogram Enhancement Algorithm Based on Bi-LSTM
authors: Hanwen Zhang, Xiruo Su, Zhijuan Zhu, Bin Wu, Lingyun Ye
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Spectrogram enhancement algorithms are essential for the amplification of target tones within complex acoustic environments. Traditional methods, exemplified by the gradient-descent-based Least Mean Square (LMS) algorithm, suffer from a performance that is highly sensitive to the input signal-to-noise ratio (SNR). Conversely, contemporary deep learning techniques, while effective, are predominantly supervised, necessitating extensive labeled data for training, and are often characterized by computationally intensive network structures. This paper introduces an unsupervised spectrogram enhancement algorithm founded on a Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (Bi-LSTM) network to surmount these challenges. The proposed algorithm leverages a lightweight Bi-LSTM architecture to achieve exhaustive encoding of tonal features from temporal of the received signals. Experimental validation through simulations indicates that the proposed algorithm yields an SNR gain of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$12.58 \mathbf{d B}$</tex> when the input SNR is equivalent to the critical SNR of the LMS. Moreover, when evaluated with real-world data under the influence of high-energy narrowband noise, the proposed algorithm demonstrates a robust SNR gain of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8.58 \mathbf{d B}$</tex> and exhibits excellent real-time processing capabilities.

title: Performance Enhancement of Hybrid Dielectric Resonator Antenna Array Using Cylindrical and Conical Elements for 5.5 GHz Wireless Communication Systems
authors: Nandhakumar K, T P Ramachandran
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: This paper presents a high-performance dielectric resonator antenna (DRA) array that integrates cylindrical and conical elements to achieve enhanced radiation characteristics at 5.5 GHz forwireless communication systems. The proposed design evolves through three configurations: a single cylindrical DRA, a 1×2 array combining one cylindrical and one conical resonator, and a 1×4 array comprising two cylindrical and two conical DRAs. All configurations are implemented on a Rogers RT/Duroid 5880 substrate and excited using an asymmetrically branched 50 Ω microstrip power divider. The simulation is performed using HFSS software, demonstrate significant improvements across each stage, with the final 1×4 array configuration achieving a return loss of −65.09 dB, a VSWR of 1.0011, and a peak gain of 13 dBi, electric field, and magnetic field distributions confirm efficient excitation and radiation. while surface current and field distribution plots confirm efficient energy coupling and strong hybrid mode excitation. A detailed parametric study highlights the influence of microstrip power divider length, resonator radius and height. With its compact structure, high gain, and superior impedance characteristics, these results demonstrate that the proposed cylindrical conical DRA array offers a compact, low loss, and high efficiency solution for next generation sub 6 GHz wireless applications such as Wi-Fi, 5G,IoT networks. and point to point links requiring robust high gain performance and excellent impedance bandwidth.

title: Short-term Bitcoin Market Efficiency Prediction and Forecasting Volatility using Hybrid Deep Learning Techniques
authors: N Rupadevi, Kalyan Kumar G, K Radha, G. Durgadevi, Vishnu Prasad Parandhaman, J. Jayanthi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: The goal is to assess and predict Bitcoin market efficiency using a data-driven approach. The Short-term Bitcoin Market Efficiency Prediction and Forecasting Volatility using Hybrid Deep Learning Techniques (SBMEPF) model combines on-chain metrics, off-chain financial data, whale NetFlow data, and social media sentiment. Bloomberg provides minute-level financial information, including Blockchain.com shares transaction and mempool activity, and Twitter reveals behavioural mood data analysed using Google NLP and NLTK. The study uses SEM and OLS regression to find direct and indirect impacts of variables. It incorporates hypothesis testing and mediation analysis through the Sobel test, Delta method, and Monte Carlo simulations with 10,000 iterations. Market efficiency is assessed using variance ratios and return autocorrelations across various intraday intervals. EMD and VMD enhance prediction accuracy. The model predicts future market volatility using advanced deep learning methods like LSTM and CNN, along with a GAM. It outperforms simpler models based on validation metrics that align with real market data. Its effectiveness in forecasting complex market behaviors supports better decision-making in cryptocurrency markets.

title: Development of Pulsed Electric Field Resynthesis Method of ATP in Bonito Meat for Inhibition of Color Change at Long Term Storage at −18°C Freezing
authors: K. Saito, S. Kosugi, Y. Minamitani, R. Sawada
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: During long-term storage, butchering and transportation of bonito, the temperature must be kept below −50°C, because of causing a color change of the meat by that myoglobin converts to metmyoglobin by the decomposition of ATP, which is the material keeping fish freshness, over −50°C. This peculiarity brings in high equipment costs. If it is possible to resynthesis ATP also after death of the fish by fishing, it is thought that it will be possible to suppress decreasing ATP and keep the freshness of the fish. ATP synthesis is carried out by supplying energy from the membrane potential of biological membranes. Therefore, if the potential can be generated in the biological membrane even after the death of the fish, it may be possible to resynthesize ATP. For that, we consider using pulsed power technology. Pulsed electric field can apply the potential to the biological membrane depending on the applied pulse conditions without thermally affecting the target object. In this presentation, the resynthesis amount of ATP in bonito meat when a damping oscillation waveform is applied was investigated. As a result of the experiment, it was found that the pulse condition of 16 kHz of the damping oscillation frequency, 5 kV/cm of the electric field intensity, and 1400 shots of the number of applied pulses were better condition for ATP resynthesis. Furthermore, pieces of the meat of bonito were stored in a freezer set at −6°C after applying the pulsed high electric field. Then, the change in color of the meat of bonito and the rate of conversion from myoglobin to metmyoglobin for the elapsed time were investigated. As a result, it is found that application of the pulse high electric field can suppress the conversion myoglobin to metmyoglobin in the meat of bonito.

title: Experimental Investigation of a Relativistic Magnetron with Reducing Coaxial Section and Tilted Tuners
authors: Y. Delvert, A. Chauloux, J.-C. Diot, A. Catrain, J. Pothée, T. Delhoume, L. Dos Santos
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: A compact, efficient, and frequency-tunable magnetron (with TEM output) was numerically simulated in 2023. It achieves approximately 50 % efficiency over a wide frequency band (1.85-2.25 GHz, over 19%). The high-power microwave (HPM) tube compatible with the CLAIRE demonstrator was built to test the simulation, along with its 20 dB conical antenna.

title: Investigation of Transmission Line Effects on Nanosecond Pulsed Dielectric Barrier Discharge (NPDBD) Plasma
authors: J.Y. Park, Y.Y. Kim, S.U. Lee, K.-J. Chung
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Nanosecond Pulsed Dielectric Barrier Discharge (NPDBD) is a plasma discharge technique that applies high-voltage pulses on the nanosecond time scale. In this transient behavior, the characteristics of the applied pulses critically affect the discharge mechanism in the plasma load, thereby modifying the resulting voltage and current. This study explores how variations in transmission line properties influence the output. Key factors investigated include transmission line parameters-such as cable length, distance, and design-and their effects on characteristic impedance, stray capacitance, and stray inductance. Experimental results are complemented by simulation analyses using equivalent circuit models to quantify the impact of these factors on discharge voltage and current. The study focuses on determining the optimal operational conditions for maximizing power transmission efficiency, considering the plasma load.

title: Nanoseconds High Voltage Pulse Generators from Berkeley Nucleonics
authors: R. Foddis
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The PVX High Voltage Pulse Generators are optimized for high impedance capacitive loads and are well suited for driving extraction grids and deflection plates for electrostatic modulation of particle beams in time-of-flight mass spectrometers and accelerators, optical devices like Pockels cells and Q-switches, as well as certain low-current plasma applications. They are direct-coupled, air-cooled solid-state half-bridge (totem pole) design, and have over-current detection and shutdown circuitry.

title: Keynote 3 Personal Health Coaching Framework Using Digital Twin and On-Device AI
authors: Yeong-Tae Song
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: When a person comes down with a disease, it is important to get proper treatment at the right time to get it cured but due to various reasons, it may not be always possible. What is more important is to try not to be in such a situation by monitoring their own health and take necessary actions in a timely manner when any abnormal conditions occur. Clinical institutions such as hospitals are the places to get treatments but when it comes to maintaining personal health, they may not be the right place to be as health monitoring requires constant assessment and guidelines that may differ by person. With the advancement of health information technology, such personalized and constant guidance that can ensure health information privacy, security, and sharing may be feasible. In this talk, we propose a novel approach in personal health monitoring framework using digital twin and on-device AI. Digital twin is used to monitor, assess, and predict user’s personal health by using user’s most up-to-date and longitudinal health condition through clinical sensors and observed symptoms. On-Device AI is used to provide secure personalized health coaching capabilities as it does not consult external AI such as ChatGPT.

title: Experimental Study on Protein Denaturation Induced by Ultra-High Electric Field Pulses in Excess of 100 MV/m
authors: S. Katsuki, K. Tsurusaki, K. Endo, N. Yoshioka
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The electric field strength on the plasma membrane of a living cell exposed to a pulsed electric field (PEF) of sub-MV/m is automatically enhanced and exceeds <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \text{MV} / \mathrm{m}$</tex>. While electric fields of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \text{MV} / \mathrm{m}$</tex> are known to permeabilize phospholipid membranes, molecular dynamics (MD) simulations predict that they affect the function and structure of membrane proteins. There is growing interest in the effects of PEF on proteins, not only from a scientific perspective, but also in terms of its application to the physical control of protein function and structure, and the denaturation of proteins that occurs during the field sterilization of food products. However, it is not easy to identify PEF effects on proteins in living cells because other biological events such as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Ca}^{2+}$</tex> ion influx and subsequent biochemical reactions make it difficult to identify PEF effects on proteins. Previously, we experimentally demonstrated that electrical pulses with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20 \text{MV} / \mathrm{m}$</tex> or more denature urease proteins in aqueous solution. Furthermore, we reported that electrical pulses on the order of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \text{MV} / \mathrm{m}$</tex> disassembled transthyretin aggregates. Based on these studies, we have experimentally investigated the effects of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \text{MV} / \mathrm{m}$</tex> class electric fields on the hierarchical structures of proteins in this study. Two proteins, egg white ovalbumin (OVA) and bovine serum albumin (BSA), with similar molecular weights and different structures, exposed to 10 times of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$130 \text{MV} / \mathrm{m}$</tex>, sub-nanosecond pulses, 1 ns, were analyzed and compared in the respective hierarchical structures. Native-PAGE showed that PEFs with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.5 \text{MV} / \mathrm{m}$</tex> or more altered the tertiary structure of OVA but not of BSE. Native-PAGE showed that PEFs with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$50 \text{MV} / \mathrm{m}$</tex> or more altered the tertiary structure of OVA but not of BSE. Thiol group (TG) quntification indicates that the tertiary structure of OVA was loosen by the cleavage of the sole disulfide bond, whereas no significant change was observed in BSE. Circular dichroism (CD) analysis indicates significant changes in the secondary structure of neither OVA nor BSA. Throughout the experiment, pH and temperature remained unchanged. Hydrogen peroxide concentration was not changed significantly to affect the three-dimensional structure of proteins.

title: The Structural and Electrical Properties of the Yttrium Oxide Film in Mim Capacitors Using High-K Dielectric
authors: J.-C. Woo, J.-W. Lee, H.-M. Kwon
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: In MOSFETs the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SiO}_{2}$</tex> dielectrics would not satisfy the typical gate requirements because of the high direct tunneling leakage current. This issue has been found in high dielectric constant metal oxides which enable higher dielectric constant <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex>, compared to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SiO}_{2}(k=3.9)$</tex>. Although these materials have high dielectric constant, some of them fail one or more necessary criteria. Neither <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Al}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$</tex> nor <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{HfO}_{2}$</tex> do not provide sufficient advantages over the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SiO}_{2}$</tex> or <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Si}_{3} ~\mathrm{N}_{4}$</tex> dielectrics. Nevertheless, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{ZrO}_{2}, \text{HfO}_{2}, \text{TiO}_{2}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Ta}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{5}$</tex> were observed to react with Si substrate. Among the materials mentioned above, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{Y}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$</tex> is one of the most attractive ones combining such favorable properties as a high dielectric constant (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{k}=10 \sim 20$</tex>), a wide bandgap (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 \sim 7 \text{eV}$</tex>) as well as a close thermal expansion coefficient with Si that results in good thermal stability of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{Y}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3} / \text{Si}$</tex> structures. Therefore, the development of the structural and the electrical properties for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{Y}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$</tex> thin films is the key technology to adapt high-k materials to commercial industry.

title: Power Consumption and Aerodynamic Efficiency Enhancement Through Plasma Actuator Placement Optimization: A Numerical Study
authors: M. Burlett, M. Mobli
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: While active flow control using dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) plasma actuators is an effective approach for enhancing aerodynamic performance, plasma actuators' power consumptions need to be minimized to make them a viable active flow control mechanism, especially for battery-powered avionics. We propose optimizing the plasma actuator placement through parametric studies to achieve the most efficient flow control scheme possible by maximizing the flow control using flow interaction methods similar to the ones implemented in vortex generators installed on trucks. In this numerical study, we have developed a computational model in OpenFOAM that couples fluid flow with plasma discharge physics. This model accurately simulates the plasma discharge and the ionic wind generated by DBD actuators, the flow control characteristics of the DBD plasma actuator, and is validated against available experimental data in the literature, to ensure a robust representation of plasma-fluid interactions.

title: Construction and Analysis of Transfer Function of Steady-State 47 kA Fullcontrolled Solid-State Switch and SNU in Tokamak Fusion Device
authors: Q. Xu, Z. Song, H. Li
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: At the beginning stage of plasma discharge experiment in tokamak fusion device, switching network unit (SNU) in the power supply system of tokamak fusion device affects the generation of plasma and the process of plasma current establishment. Its reliable operation is related to the success of fusion experiment and has important research value. When conducting system simulation analysis on SNU, it is necessary to model the system circuit, and the degree of parameter conformity between the model and the real equipment is crucial for the authenticity and reliability of the system simulation and analysis. The SNU scheme based on full-controlled solid-state switch with a steady-state breaking capacity of 47 kA was designed, and the transfer function of the steady-state 47 kA full-controlled solid-state switch in the SNU scheme and the SNU was constructed on the basis of taking into account equipment parameters and structural characteristics. This paper provides a more reliable theoretical basis and research foundation for the modeling, simulation, analysis of SNU and power supply system, as well as the construction of digital tokamak.

title: Relativistic Correction of Theoretical Stark Broadening for Hydrogen/Deuterium Spectra and Machine Learning Analysis of Resulting Lineshapes
authors: A. D. McNaughton, E. Sanchez
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: A theoretical formulation for relativistically corrected Stark broadening of hydrogen/deuterium (H/D) emission spectra is developed, combining the semi-classical formalism of Derevianko and Oks (1994) with relativistic and screening corrections of Zenkhri et al. (2023). This formulation assumes an isotropic, unmagnetized, hydrogen plasma. It is numerically evaluated for a range of plasma parameters for the H/D Lyman, Balmer, and Paschen series. These relativistic Starkbroadened spectra are compared to (1) broadened spectra of the non-relativistic formulation, and to (2) theoretical Doppler broadening, given the same plasma parameters, to establish plasma parameter regimes wherein the relativistically-corrected Stark broadening is expected to be significant.

title: Electron Temperatures in High Power Impulse Magnetron Sputtering: The Role of the Target Material's Sputter Yield
authors: M. Rudolph, K. Barynova, D. Lundin, J.T. Gudmundsson
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Magnetron sputtering is a widely used process for thin-film deposition, employed in laboratory research and industry. It is based on a low-pressure plasma discharge in which ions of a working gas, typically argon, are created and accelerated toward a target containing the source material. Sputtering from the target releases target atoms into the gas phase that can condense on a substrate to form a thin film. High-power impulse magnetron sputtering (HiPIMS) achieves high discharge current densities by pulsing the discharge at a low duty cycle. This process generates a dense plasma region through which sputtered atoms pass with a high probability of becoming ionized. The resulting highly ionized flux of film-forming species enables for example the deposition of dense, crystalline and well-adhering thin films.

title:
Particle in Cell Monte Carlo Collision Simulations of Capacitive Cl
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    /Ar Discharges
authors: J. T. Gudmundsson, B. Mahdavipour
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Mixtures of reactive gases with rare gases in capacitively coupled discharges are frequently applied in etching and deposition processes in microelectronic device fabrication. The chlorine discharge and its mixtures are frequently applied in etching of semiconductors and metals. Here we explore capacitive <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Cl}_{2}/\text{Ar}$</tex> discharges driven by a sinusoidal rf current at 13.56 MHz in a 2.54 cm gap using one-dimensional particle-in-cell/Monte Carlo collisional (PIC/MCC) simulations. The chlorine discharge is highly electronengative and, by adding argon to the discharge, the electronegativity can be varied over a wide range. We will discuss how the electron power absorption mechanisms, the electronegativity, the electron energy distribution function, appearance of striations, and the composition of the discharge vary with the addition of argon to the discharge. We will in particular discuss the influence of the metastable argon on the discharge properties. Furthermore, the role of secondary electron emission from the electrodes will be explored.

title: High-Power Pulsed Power Generation Using GaN FETs
authors: K. Nagao, T. Sugai, A. Tokuchi, W. Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Pulsed power generators using power semiconductor switches promise these features, high repetition ratio, long lifetime, flexibility of output, and so on. These feathers are attractive, and the pulsed power generators using semiconductor switches have been developed significantly. Wide band gap semiconductors such as silicon carbide (SiC) and gallium nitride (GaN) have high voltage capability and fast switching speed. SiC power switching devices have been used in pulsed power supplies, also GaN power switching devices have been focused on the features; of higher voltage capability and faster turn-on switching speed than SiC devices but the over voltage at turn-off timing is one of the problems.

title: Quantifying Hall Conductivity of the Inner MITL on Z
authors: G. Vasey, N. Bennett, D. Welch, E. Watson
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Particle simulations are an effective tool for modeling the magnetically insulated transmission lines (MITL) on Sandia National Laboratories' Z machine. However, a fluid-like understanding is desirable for analyzing behavior and would aid in designing new geometries that mitigate current loss. Previous analysis of PIC simulations of the inner MITL suggests that the Hall current plays a significant role in time-dependent current loss. In this work we use Weak Sparse Identification of Nonlinear Dynamics (WSINDy), a data-driven model identification method, to quantify the Hall coefficient as a function of time and space in the inner MITL. The weak formulation of WSINDy allows us to perform this analysis without a smoothing or averaging step and work directly with fluid quantities calculated from the particle data. The Hall coefficient is learned for multiple inner MITL geometries and spatiotemporal regions of significance are identified. The end goal is a parameterization to represent how the geometry of the inner MITL relates to the Hall coefficient and the resulting current loss.

title: Fixed-time distributed cooperative control for the multi-tug towing of unactuated offshore platform with uncertainties and unknown disturbances
authors: Yulong Tuo, Shaolong Geng, Yuanhui Wang, Zhouhua Peng, Shasha Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Although a couple of robust cooperative controllers have been proposed to achieve the multi-tug towing of unactuated offshore platform with uncertainties and unknown disturbances, the convergence performance of towing control system is unsatisfactory. To surmount this challenge, this research aims to improve the convergence performance of multi-tug towing system based on fixed-time stability theory. Initially, a fixed-time extended state observer (FxESO) is designed to estimate the uncertainties and disturbances. Based on the FxESO, a fixed-time virtual controller is proposed to acquire desired drag force for the offshore platform to track the expected trajectory. Subsequently, the desired drag force is allocated to the desired towline tensions of tugs by the quadratic programming algorithm, and the corresponding desired towline length is calculated through the towline catenary model. Then, the desired position of each tug is obtained based on the desired towline length and the current position information of the platform and tug. Based on the desired positions of tugs, a fixed-time distributed cooperative controller is designed to achieve the multi-tug towing of offshore platform within the fixed time. Finally, simulations and comparisons have verified the progressiveness and effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: System-Level SEU Hardening of Wireless Receivers through Modulation Scheme Selection
authors: James H. Shin, Jeffrey W. Teng, Brett L. Ringel, Zachary R. Brumbach, Delwyn G. Sam, Justin P. Heimerl, Adrian Ildefonso, Trevor Crane, Ani Khachatrian, Dale McMorrow, John D. Cressler
publish: IEEE Transactions on Nuclear Science
abstract: Previous work suggests that optimization of a signal constellation could be used to reduce single-event upset (SEU) likelihood, but focuses on isolated circuit components, not systems. The present work extends the process of digital modulation scheme selection for SEU-resilience to a generalized procedure for a full radio frequency (RF) receiver. Two custom modulation schemes are optimized for Manhattan or Euclidean distance to minimize the system-level SEU impact of an single-event transient (SET) within individual circuits. Pulsed-laser single-event effect (SEE) testing is utilized to evaluate SEU-hardening of a SiGe wireless receiver operating on these custom modulation schemes. Basic receiver archetypes are used as test cases to determine the efficacy of system-level radiation hardening through modulation scheme selection. Results demonstrate that intentionally selecting modulation schemes based on known component sensitivity can reduce system-level SEU rates.

title: Uncertainty-Aware PCA Revisited
authors: Lukas Friesecke, Christian Braune, Christian Rössl, Holger Theisel
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is perhaps the most popular linear projection technique for dimensionality reduction. We consider PCA under the assumption that the high-dimensional data points are equipped with Gaussian uncertainty. Several approaches to such uncertainty-aware PCA have been developed recently in the visualization community. Since PCA is a discontinuous map, a small uncertainty in the data points can result in a huge uncertainty in the projected points. We show that the uncertainty of the data points also creates uncertainty in the eigenvectors of the covariance matrix that defines the PCA projection. We present a closed-form expression to quantify eigenvector uncertainty. Based on this, we propose a 3D glyph that supports the decision whether existing solutions for uncertainty-aware PCA are sufficient, or whether a more expensive sampling-based approach is required. We apply our approach to several test data sets.

title: Estimates of the Dynamic Structure Factor for the Uniform Electron Gas in the Warm Dense Matter Regime via Analytic Continuation of Quantum Monte Carlo Data
authors: T. Chuna, N. Barnfield, T. Dornheim, M. P. Friedlamder, T. Hoheisel
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) simulations are one of the few methods which can describe the structure of the plasma in Warm Dense Matter. However, the imaginary time correlation functions (ITCF) estimated by QMC simulation must be analytically continuated back to real time to extract dynamic information about the system. One of the most ubiquitous approaches to analytic continuation is the maximum entropy method (MEM). The MEM is typically used with Bryan's controversial algorithm [Rothkopf, “Bryan's Maximum Entropy Method” Data 5.3 (2020)]. We supply a dual Newton optimization algorithm to be used within the MEM that addresses known issues. We pay special attention to our uncertainty providing analytic bounds for the algorithm's error as well as numerical estimates of the uncertainty arising from both the ITCF and the regularization weight. We use the MEM to investigate authentic quantum Monte Carlo data for the uniform electron gas and further substantiate the roton-type feature in the dispersion relation, demonstrating that the all-purpose maximum entropy method can reliably estimate the DSF from QMC data. This establishes a path towards model-free estimates of the DSF in ion-electron systems.

title: Mapping the Unseen Ground: A Survey on Dense Mapping and Traversability Methods for Agricultural and Forestry Robots
authors: Iman Esfandiyar, Dominik Belter
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Autonomous navigation in unstructured agricultural and forestry environments demands high-fidelity, real-time 3D mapping to support safe and efficient motion planning. This survey systematically reviews dense mapping techniques, spanning grid-based, octree, surfel, mesh, and neural implicit representations, and evaluates their suitability for mobile robots operating under variable terrain and foliage cover. We begin by examining common sensor modalities (monocular/stereo cameras, RGB-D, LiDAR, mmWave radar) and their integration into mapping frameworks such as TSDF/ESDF, OctoMap, Voxblox/Nvblox, and NDT-OM. Next, we detail adaptations of these methods for agricultural and forestry applications. Finally, we address the emerging challenge of estimating solid ground beneath vegetation and constructing traversability maps through statistical models, proprioceptive–exteroceptive fusion, radar sensing, and self-supervised deep learning. By comparing state-of-the-art algorithms and datasets, we identify key trade-offs between memory efficiency, map fidelity, and real-time performance. We conclude with recommendations for integrating uncertainty-aware and active-perception strategies, and outline future directions toward scalable, cloud-based, multi-robot mapping for precision agriculture and forestry management.

title: Very-low-field MRI scanners: from the ideal to the real permanent magnet array
authors: U. Zanovello, A. Arduino, V. Basso, L. Zilberti, A. Sola, A. Agosto, L. Toso, O. Bottauscio
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Very-low-field MRIs are becoming increasingly popular due to their portability and adaptability to different environments. They are being successfully used for various clinical applications, leading to a paradigm shift in the way imaging care is typically performed. The development of low-cost MRI scanner prototypes began a few years ago, with some interesting and promising open-source projects emerging in both hardware and software design. Using permanent magnets (PMs) to generate the static magnetic field B0 can substantially reduce the manufacturing cost while achieving satisfactory homogeneity. This article aims to explore the reasons behind discrepancies between magnet design and prototype performance in terms of magnetic field homogeneity. Understanding the impact of the practical implementation of magnet design could inform the development of more tolerant designs in future, simplifying subsequent B0 shimming procedures or even making them unnecessary. This work also evidences the impact of using different numerical model approximations in the modelling phase, proving how they also impact the quality of the design outcomes.

title: Electro-Magnetic Decoupling Preconditioner for Eddy Current Problems with External Circuit Coupling
authors: S. Hiruma, T. Mifune, T. Matsuo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Magnetics
abstract: This paper proposes an efficient and scalable preconditioning strategy for eddy current problems involving coupled external circuits. The approach, named Electro-Magnetic Decoupling (EMD) preconditioner, decomposes the discrete system into vector and scalar potential components and applies tailored preconditioners to each. In particular, strong preconditioning is applied to the scalar component to address the spectral degradation induced by the discrete Laplacian. The method was evaluated on four eddy current models with varying frequencies, conductor topologies, and excitation types. Compared to the conventional incomplete Cholesky preconditioner, the EMD approach achieved up to 33 times fewer iteration counts and up to 28 times faster iterative solver time. Moreover, the method supports physics-level parallelization, allowing efficient treatment of independently excited conductor domains. The EMD framework is compatible with algebraic multigrid, domain decomposition, and direct solvers, offering flexibility and robustness for large-scale electromagnetic simulations.

title: Parental Behavioral Willingness Push-Pull-Mooring Mechanism:Research on the Adoption and Barriers of AIGC-Assisted Learning for Primary and Secondary School Students
authors: Zhilong An, Yingchao Wang
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Artificial Intelligence Generated Content (AIGC) demonstrates significant potential in the field of education, but its widespread adoption is largely constrained by the level of acceptance from students’ parents. Parents’ lack of awareness of AIGC, trust issues, and concerns about technological dependence are major obstacles. This study, based on the “Push-Pull-Mooring” (PPM) theoretical model, conducts a survey analysis of 394 parents of primary and secondary school students using structural equation modeling to explore the key factors influencing their behavioral intentions toward AIGC-assisted learning. The study finds that intelligent support and the convenience of learning resources, as pull factors, have a significant positive impact on behavioral intentions, while concerns about technological dependence serve as the primary mooring barrier. Additionally, push factors, such as traditional educational content, the lack of personalized support, and insufficient interactivity, were also verified. The research suggests that parents’ adoption decisions regarding AIGC are a complex process of weighing technological benefits and risks. To promote the sustainable development of AIGC in education, efforts should focus on enhancing technological awareness, updating educational concepts, and building systemic trust. This study provides a theoretical framework and empirical basis for understanding parental decision-making mechanisms.

title: A Comprehensive Review on the Application of Large Language Models (LLMs) in Power Systems
authors: Masoumeh Ghafari, Asal Sami, Hamed Rezapour, Sepideh Saravani Ghayour, Fanfan Lin, Kivanc Basaran, George Cristian Lazaroiu, Pierluigi Siano
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Nowadays, modern power systems are facing increasing complexity with the rapid growth of renewable energy sources (RESs), the expansion of small and distributed energy resources (DERs) and the evolution towards cyber-physical smart grids. These developments have made the need for intelligent and flexible systems to support the decision-making processes. Advanced large linguistic models (LLM), as a new generation of artificial intelligence (AI), can understand and process complex text data and have been proposed as an innovative solution in the energy industry. These technologies can create a fundamental transformation in power systems management and optimization. This paper analyzes in depth the application of LLM in power systems. The current research tracks the evolution of AI in this field from simple methods, based on basic rules, to more advanced technologies, such as deep learning and transformer models. Within the paper, the basic principles of transformer models are described, and three important capabilities of this technology are emphasized: the ability to interpret the results, the ability to expand for different applications, and the flexibility to face different conditions. The conducted analysis highlights how the new generation of AI can bring a fundamental transformation in the management of power systems.

title: Long-Term Stability of SiC MOSFETs for Inductive Adders
authors: Johannes Ruf, Thomas Kramer, Dimosthenis Peftitsis
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The design of an inductive adder system <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(40 \text{kV} / 2.6 \text{kA}$</tex> peak) for kicker magnets at CERN requires a long-term reliable operation. Today, Silicon Carbide (SiC) metal-oxide-semiconductor field-effect transistors (MOSFETs) are the most suitable power semiconductor devices in terms of switching performance, blocking voltage, and rated current capabilities for inductive adders. However, SiC MOSFETs may suffer from degradation of device parameters during switching operation, which could jeopardise the stable and reliable operation of the inductive adder circuit. This paper studies the long-term stability of two key MOSFET's parameters, namely threshold voltage and drain-source breakdown voltage, under practical operating conditions of inductive adders under development at CERN.

title: Introduction to the Special Section on MSST 2024
authors: Ming Zhao, Benjamin Reed
publish: ACM Transactions on Storage
abstract: The ACM Transactions on Storage (TOS) is pleased to present a special section featuring extended versions of articles originally presented at the 38th International Conference on Massive Storage Systems and Technology (MSST 2024). MSST continues its long tradition as a premier venue for both academic and industrial research in large-scale storage systems, data management, and emerging non-volatile memory technologies. The MSST 2024 conference once again demonstrated the breadth of innovation in the storage community, from flash storage, persistent memory to cloud and AI storage systems.

title: High-Fiving with the Machine: Synthesising Reactive Motion from Human Input with Interaction Contact Labels
authors: Oliver Hixon-Fisher, Jarek Francik, Dimitrios Makris
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 18th ACM SIGGRAPH Conference on Motion, Interaction, and Games
abstract: Human motion synthesis has advanced significantly in domains such as text-to-motion and gesture generation, yet synthesising realistic interaction motion between multiple characters remains relatively underexplored, particularly in dynamic and user-driven environments like virtual reality (VR). Existing approaches rely on constructing sequences across a set number of frames, inherently limiting their usability in real-time and open-ended applications such as virtual reality. In this work, we present a novel latent diffusion-based framework for real-time interaction motion synthesis. Unlike prior models that operate on fixed-length sequences, our system continuously adapts to user behaviour, generating contextually appropriate and temporally coherent response motions. We introduce Interaction Contact Labels, a generalisation of ground contact annotations, to capture physical interdependencies between interacting characters and integrate them into the training objective to improve realism. Our approach enables open-ended, responsive character interactions suitable for live applications in VR, AR, and robotics. Further to this, we demonstrate a real-time implementation of the proposed method, which utilises CycleGANs to combine webcam data with high-quality motion capture data, allowing for easy end-user set-up.

title: Adversarially Resilient Multi-Label Object Detection: An Ensemble of ViT, EfficientNetV2-L, and YOLO12 for Forensic Imagery
authors: Leila Rzayeva, Perizat Tazhibayeva, Yonghao Wang, Dauren Izdibay, Nursultan Nyssanov, Zhaksylyk Kozhakhmet
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Detecting prohibited objects in images requires models that combine high accuracy with resilience to adversarial perturbations. This study presents a comparative evaluation of three state-of-the-art architectures—Vision Transformer (ViT B16), EfficientNetV2-L, and YOLO12—and an ensemble of these models for multi-label detection of illicit content (weapons, drugs, nudity, violence, benign) in forensic imagery. A dataset of 13 556 images was split 60/20/20 into training, validation, and test sets. Each model was trained using binary cross-entropy (for classification heads) and YOLO loss (for detection heads) and evaluated on clean data and adversarial examples generated by FGSM (ϵ = 8/255) and PGD (α = 2/255, 10 iterations). On clean images, ViT B16 and EfficientNetV2-L achieved 93.5% and 92.8% accuracy, respectively, while YOLO12 reached 84.0%. Under PGD attack, accuracies dropped to 81.0%, 79.5%, and 68.0%. The averaging ensemble attained 95.2% clean accuracy, 85.5% adversarial accuracy, and 96.8% recall. Results demonstrate that architectural diversity and ensemble fusion significantly enhance both detection performance and adversarial robustness in security-critical applications.

title: A Magnetostatic 10-Moment Multi-Fluid Model for Low-Temperature Partially Magnetized Plasmas
authors: D. A. Kuldinow, Y. Yamashita, K. Hara
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Fluid moment models are an attractive option to model plasma devices because they can describe macroscopic device-scale phenomena of an ensemble of particles without need to track myriad particle trajectories. In plasma devices, non-equilibrium (non-Maxwellian) effects can arise due to coupling between plasma-wall interactions, interspecies collisions and instabilities. While kinetic models can describe arbitrary velocity distribution functions, such models are generally more computationally expensive than traditional fluid models. In this study, we develop and apply a 10moment multi-fluid model to capture non-equilibrium anisotropic effects in low-temperature magnetized plasmas. The model solves for the density, bulk velocity and a full pressure tensor. The equations are closed by an extension of the traditional equilibrium Braginskii-type heat flux, obtained using Chapman-Enskog expansion. The one-dimensional model is applied to the simplified geometry of the discharge plasma in a Hall-effect thruster. The results are compared to previous 5-moment fluid results and kinetic particle-in-cell Monte Carlo collision model.
