title: Distributed Cross-Timescale Spatio-Temporal Graph Neural Networks for Sea Surface Temperature Prediction
authors: Nuoqing Zhang, Xinyue Liang, Jie Nie, Pengfei Bie, Min Ye, Ning Song, Yiyun Guo, Zhiqiang Wei
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Ocean data has strong spatiotemporal correlations and is also characterized by multi-source, decentralized distribution, presenting significant challenges for distributed collaboration. To address these issues, in this paper, we propose DGLN, a distributed GCN-based prediction architecture that employs a decentralized training paradigm comprising local and distributed systems. The local system is designed to capture scale-specific features of marine data across different processors, while the distributed system learns and coordinates global cross-timescale features. The graph learning module in the distributed system integrates graph features from other processors without transmitting raw data, thereby ensuring local data security. To accelerate training and enhance model performance, a joint learning module is composed by cross-timescale computation with a new global weighted consensus algorithm, which is able to adaptively adjust the weights of different scales. Experimental results show that DGLN is able to improve the local prediction accuracy and capture cross-timescale features effectively while improving the training efficiency.

title: Advanced Semi-Supervised Hyperspectral Change Detection via Cross-Temporal Spectral Reconstruction
authors: Qinsen Liu, Bangyong Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Hyperspectral change detection (HSI-CD) serves as an advanced technique for monitoring surface changes by leveraging spectral differences between multi-temporal hyperspectral images. Ideally, the spectral differences between unchanged areas across multi-temporal images should be minimal. However, in practical applications, due to various factors such as imaging conditions and seasonal variations, spectral differences in unchanged areas can still be significant, which may lead to an increased likelihood of false alarms in CD. In this article, we propose a distinct reconstruction-guided approach for semi-supervised HSI-CD, termed CSR-Net, which can precisely distinguish the changed or unchanged areas with significant spectral differences. Specifically, CSR-Net encodes input HSI to reconstruct the corrected spectral sequences, mitigating errors caused by spectral differences in unchanged areas due to factors such as seasonal changes and variations in land cover characteristics. Subsequently, the reconstructed spectral sequences undergo change analysis to detect changes. Moreover, we propose an innovative semi-supervised HSI-CD loss, which weights the mean squared error loss based on binary CD results. This loss introduces a constraint that enables the model to learn spectral-temporal relationships from unlabeled data, thereby facilitating the reconstruction of corrected spectral sequences and reducing false alarms. Extensive experiments conducted on four benchmark HSI-CD datasets demonstrate that the proposed CSR-Net and loss function consistently outperform existing state-of-the-art methods, even with a very limited number of labeled samples.

title: Channel-Aware Multi-Domain Feature Extraction for Automatic Modulation Recognition in MIMO Systems
authors: Yunpeng Qu, Yazhou Sun, Bingyu Hui, Jintao Wang, Jian Wang
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: Automatic modulation recognition (AMR) is a key technology in non-cooperative communication systems, aiming to identify the modulation scheme from signals without prior information. Deep learning (DL)-based methods have gained wide attention due to their excellent performance, but research mainly focuses on single-input single-output (SISO) systems, with limited exploration for multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems. The confounding effects of multi-antenna channels can interfere with the statistical properties of MIMO signals, making identification particularly challenging. To overcome these limitations, we propose a Channel-Aware Multi-Domain feature extraction (CAMD) framework for AMR in MIMO systems. Our CAMD framework reconstructs the transmitted signal through an efficient channel compensation module and achieves a more robust representation capability against channel interference by extracting and integrating multi-domain features, including intra-antenna temporal correlations and inter-antenna channel correlations. We have verified our method on the widely-used dataset, MIMOSig-Ref, with complex mobile channel environments. Extensive experiments confirm the performance advantages of CAMD over previous state-of-the-art methods.

title: Uniform Dynamic Control for Nonlinear PV Power Systems via Small-Signal Modeling
authors: GaHyun Kim, Hee Hyun Yang, Kahyun Lee
publish: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion
abstract: This paper proposes a Uniform Dynamic Control (UDC) strategy to ensure consistent dynamic performance in nonlinear photovoltaic (PV) power systems. Conventional Static Gain Control (SGC), which applies fixed controller parameters, often results in bandwidth variation and unsee transient behavior due to the nonlinear voltage-power characteristics of PV arrays and their sensitivity to irradiance and load variations. These limitations become more critical in single-stage systems, where the lack of energy storage directly couples PV voltage to load dynamics. To address this, a small-signal model is developed to characterize the PV system's operating-point-dependent behavior and is extended to capture the coupled dynamics between PV voltage and load-side rotor speed in motor-driven applications. Based on this model, UDC adaptively tunes the controller gains to maintain uniform control bandwidth and consistent transient response across a wide range of conditions. Experimental validation confirms that the proposed UDC improves voltage regulation, enhances speed response uniformity, and reduces transient deviations, but also verifies that the developed small-signal model accurately captures the system's dynamic behavior.

title: Research on Pulse Modulation Characteristics of PFN and Optimization of its Multistage Superposition Process
authors: S. Liu, X. Qiu, H. Zhang, W. Yan, R. Li
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The PFN-Marx generator, characterized by its compact design that enables simultaneous voltage boosting and pulse forming, has emerged as a focal point of research globally. The pulse modulation characteristics of the PFN play a pivotal role in determining the quasi-square wave pulse output of the PFN-Marx generator. As the demand for more compact devices grows, the inter-stage electromagnetic coupling arising from PFN wave propagation during the superposition process of the PFN-Marx generator influences its quasi-square wave out characteristics. This paper delves into this issue in detail. Initially, the optimal PFN types are selected by design and simulation. The experiments are conducted to investigate the quasi-square wave out characteristics of the PFN under varying impedance conditions and the impact of different arrangement structures on the waveform. On this basis, a 3D model of a typical PFN-Marx generator is established for field-circuit co-simulation and to optimal its wave propagation. Finally, a 5-stage PFN-Marx generator is built for experimental verification. The optimized single-stage PFN outputs a good flat-top waveform with a leading edge of 12 ns and a pulse width of 60 ns on a 3.5Ω load. The 5-stage PFN-Marx generator, under conditions of a charging voltage of 50 kV and a load of 20Ω, outputs a quasi-square wave with a peak value of 120 kV, a pulse width of 60 ns and a leading edge of 15 ns.

title: Time-Resolved X-Ray Spectrometer for X-Ray Opacity Study Through Z-Pinch Dynamic Hohlraum Radiation
authors: D. Zhang, Q. Xu, J. Zhang, H. Cai, S. Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: A new time-resolved X-ray spectrometer is currently developed on China's 10-MA facility, which is used for Z-pinch dynamic hohlraum radiation-driven opacity experiments. The spectrometer utilizes a six-slits imaging system, generating six frames of soft X-ray spectral images on timeresolved gold-coated MCP detectors after the diffraction of a convex cylindrical KAP crystal. The gating time of the system is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 1.1 \text{ns}$</tex>, which greatly suppress the background noise generated from the Z-pinch high-energy radiation beyond the backlighting moment. We present the time-resolved and time-integrated absorption X-ray spectral of radiation heated <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Al}+\text{Fe}$</tex> mixed plasma. The spectral resolution in time-resolved system is much better. By comparing the experimental X-ray transmission with the calculated transmission of Al plasma, we suggest the radiative heated <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Al} / \text{Fe}$</tex> plasma achieves a temperature of approximately 112 eV and an ion density of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.1 \times 10^{21} \text{cm}^{-3}$</tex>.

title: Meeting Future Mobile Traffic Needs by Peak-Throughput Design of Next-Gen RAN
authors: Paolo Fiore, Ilario Filippini, Danilo De Donno
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Growing congestion in current mobile networks necessitates innovative solutions. This paper contributes a novel network planning approach for mmWave 5G networks in urban settings, focusing on Integrated Access and Backhaul (IAB) and the Smart Radio Environment (SRE). The mmWave traffic will be mainly made of short bursts to transfer large volumes of data and long idle periods where data are processed, necessitating changes in how mobile radio networks are designed. Our proposed optimization models integrate IAB with SRE technologies while leveraging the maximization of achievable peak throughput rather than conventional average throughput metrics. Results highlight the advantages of this approach during the network planning phase, providing insights into better accommodating the demands of mobile traffic without sacrificing the overall network capacity.

title: DiAReL: Reinforcement Learning With Disturbance Awareness for Robust Sim2Real Policy Transfer in Robot Control_supp1-3634677.mp4
authors: Mohammadhossein Malmir
publish: N/A
abstract: Delayed Markov decision processes (DMDPs) fulfill the Markov property by augmenting the state space of agents with a finite time window of recently committed actions. In reliance on these state augmentations, delay-resolved reinforcement learning (RL) algorithms train policies to learn optimal interactions with environments featuring observation or action delays. Although such methods can be directly trained on the real robots, due to sample inefficiency, limited resources, or safety constraints, a common approach is to transfer models trained in simulation to the physical robot. However, robotic simulations rely on approximated models of the physical systems, which hinders the sim2real transfer. In this work, we consider various uncertainties in modeling the robot or environment dynamics as unknown intrinsic disturbances applied to the system input. We introduce the disturbance-augmented Markov decision process (DAMDP) in delayed settings as a novel representation to incorporate disturbance estimation in training on-policy RL algorithms. The proposed method is validated across several metrics on learning robotic reaching and pushing tasks and compared with disturbance-unaware baselines. The results show that the disturbance-augmented models can achieve higher stabilization and robustness in the control response, which in turn improves the prospects of successful sim2real transfer.

title: 400 V/50 V Vertically Mounted LLC Module with Enhanced Hold-up Capability for Datacenters
authors: Pranav Raj Prakash, Qiang Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: The growing power demands of AI- and ML based datacenters drive the need for higher power density in AC–DC power supply units without increasing their physical footprint. In isolated DC–DC stages, LLC resonant converters are favored for their high efficiency; however, achieving the large gain required during hold-up events via frequency modulation necessitates modifications to the resonant tank parameters that compromise nominal efficiency, resulting in oversized bulk capacitance. Secondary-side rectifier (SR) phase-shifting control can eliminate the dependence on magnetizing inductance, but extended freewheeling intervals require an increase in switching frequency to limit peak and RMS currents, which in turn broadens the frequency range and increases switching losses. This work introduces a selective SR phase-shifting control leveraging matrix transformers to mitigate these challenges. The approach is experimentally validated on a vertically mounted 400 V/50 V LLC converter module, achieving 98.7% peak efficiency and a surface power density of 1320 W/in<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, while maintaining regulation over a 200–400 V input range. The proposed method enables a 33% reduction in bulk capacitance compared to frequency control, improving both volumetric power density and efficiency in high-performance power supply designs.

title: Time-Varying Signal Propagation at Sub-THz Frequencies Using a Vector Network Analyzer
authors: Mohanad Dawood AI-Dabbagh, David Ulm, David A. Humphreys, Thomas Kleine-Ostmann
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Vector network analyzers (VNAs) are primarily designed to measure time-invariant networks by capturing the complex voltage response at discrete frequency points within a sample window defined by the intermediate frequency bandwidth (IFBW). The interval between frequency steps is determined by factors such as the selected IFBW and the total number of frequency points, which will result in the overall measurement duration. This conventional approach presents challenges when measuring time-varying transmissions, as changes in the waveform must be considered throughout the entire measurement period. To address this challenge, we investigate methods to adapt signal acquisition for time-varying signals, evaluating the feasibility and limitations of using VNAs for this purpose. We analyze the sweep duration and evaluate a segmented sweep, conducting experimental verification to establish a measurement scenario. This scenario aims to improve our understanding of time-varying measurements and to apply it to other much more dynamic channel-sounding systems, enabling estimation of associated measurement uncertainties. We present the measurement setup, mathematical analysis to simulate the scenario, and time intervals obtained for each measured segment at varying velocities, considering the actual position at each frequency step.

title: Scalable Cell-Free Massive MIMO System: Joint Optimal Pilot and Access Point Assignment
authors: Mhammad B. Hmayed, Ali H. Bastami
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Cell-free massive MIMO (CF-mMIMO) is a promising topology for 6G wireless networks which can potentially improve the network capacity. Pilot contamination, network overloading and scalability are the main challenges in the design of CF-mMIMO systems. In this paper, we jointly optimize the pilot and access point (AP) assignment for a CF-mMIMO system with correlated fading channels, which effectively mitigates pilot contamination, improves spectral efficiency, and provides scalability. For this purpose, we introduce a simplified interference index based on the channel covariance matrices and formulate an optimization problem by considering the interference index as the objective function and the scalability and pilot reuse parameters as the constraints. To find the solution of this NP-hard problem, we utilize the relaxation technique, the block coordinate descent (BCD) approach and the interior point method (IPM), which leads to a polynomial-time pilot and AP assignment algorithm whose iteration complexity scales as O(max(K4.5, LK3.5)) with the number of users K and APs L. The simulation results demonstrate that the proposed scheme achieves higher spectral efficiency and maintains stable runtime performance in networks tested with up to 150 APs, confirming both its scalability and practical feasibility. The simulation results also show that the performance gain of the proposed scheme improves with increasing the network user density, which confirms its interference mitigation capability.

title: EMT-HEE: An Evolutionary Multi-Tasking Method for Hyperspectral Endmember Extraction_supp1-3634746.pdf
authors: Fan Cheng
publish: N/A
abstract: Endmember extraction (EE) plays an essential role in the unmixing of hyperspectral images, and many EE algorithms have been proposed. Among them, evolutionary algorithm (EA) based EE algorithms attract much attention due to the EA's powerful global search ability. However, hyperspectral EE problem itself is a constrained and sparse large-scale optimization problem, and it is difficult to search the optimal solutions efficiently. In this paper, to address this problem, we tackle this complex optimization problem from the view of evolutionary multi-tasking. Specifically, an evolutionary multi-tasking method for hyperspectral EE, termed EMT-HEE, is suggested, where two related tasks cooperate with each other to achieve endmembers with higher quality. In EMT-HEE, the original hyperspectral EE problem is regarded as the main task, whose aim is to obtain the final accurate endmembers. Meanwhile, an unconstrained task is constructed to assist the main task, and is used to explore the sparse large-scale search space thoroughly and avoid the local optima. To implement the evolutionary multi-tasking idea, two populations (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$MP$</tex-math></inline-formula> and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$AP$</tex-math></inline-formula>) are evolved for the two tasks, respectively. During the evolving, a learning based solution generation strategy is suggested for the main task, which can produce high-quality solutions. Besides, a global search strategy with dynamic ranges is developed for the assisting task, which generates the solutions with more diversity. To make full use of the advantage of each task, a pair of knowledge transferring strategy (including the “assisting-to-main repairing strategy” and the “main-to-assisting enhancing strategy”) is proposed, which improves the performance of each task greatly. The competitiveness of EMT-HEE is validated on different hyperspectral datasets, and EMT-HEE can extract more accurate endmembers than the state-of-the-art EE algorithms.

title: Privacy-Preserving On-Screen Activity Recognition via One-Shot Federated Learning
authors: Parayush Swami, Annu Priya, Balamurugan Palanisamy, Debangshu Roy, Vikas Hassija, GSS Chalapathi
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Preserving user privacy while monitoring on-screen activity is a growing challenge in remote and decentralized work environments. In this paper, we propose a novel one-shot federated learning (FL) framework that enables secure, low-overhead, and privacy-preserving on-screen activity recognition. Conventional FL methods require multiple communication rounds between clients and a central server. In contrast, our one-shot FL approach performs model aggregation in a single round, significantly reducing communication costs and latency, making it ideal for bandwidth-constrained and resource-limited environments. Using a custom dataset of 2,300 screenshots from common applications (e.g., Coursera, YouTube, Amazon), we train Deep Convolutional Neural Network (DCNN) models such as VGG16, VGG19, and InceptionResNetV2 locally on client devices. Sensitive visual data is never shared, and the screenshots are processed and discarded post-inference, ensuring strict data confidentiality. We further enhance privacy by integrating differential privacy mechanisms. To further improve learning effectiveness under different data distributions, we evaluate two aggregation techniques, FedAvg for IID and FedProx for non-IID settings. Experimental evaluations show that our approach achieves up to 99.1% classification accuracy (MobileNet) while reducing communication overhead by over 80% compared to traditional FL. This work highlights the effectiveness and scalability of one-shot FL for secure, real-time activity tracking in privacy-sensitive applications.

title: Design Fiction for Animal-Robot Interaction: In the New Era of Artificial Intelligence
authors: Haruka Kasuga, Masashi Takeshita, Yuichiro Kasuga
publish: Proceedings of the ACM 12th International Conference on Animal-Computer Interaction
abstract: This one-day workshop uses a design fiction approach to explore the multifaceted future of animal–robot interaction in our society. It envisions and critically discusses scenarios in which social robots could foster relationships between humans and companion animals or enhance animal welfare. Based on the curriculum vitae (CVs) submitted during the application process, we will group participants with specific target animals. Following keynote talks by researchers specializing in animal–robot interaction and artificial intelligence (AI) ethics related to animals, participants will discuss the future of animal–robot interaction, including its potential benefits and ethical concerns.

title: Using Community Notes to Enact Attitudinal Change towards Urban Wildlife
authors: Sam Gowland, Brittany Davidson, Dirk van der Linden
publish: Proceedings of the ACM 12th International Conference on Animal-Computer Interaction
abstract: Social media increasingly plays a dominant role in shaping public opinion and attitudes on various topics, including human-wildlife relations. While moderation efforts such as Community Notes on X (formerly Twitter) primarily serve as fact-checking tools to combat misinformation, this study investigates their potential as vehicles for attitudinal change. We examine whether attitudes towards wildlife species exhibiting natural behaviours in urban environments can be neutralised or shifted through a Community Note that provides additional behavioural context.

title: Extendible Skip Graph Based on Order Preserving Linear Hashing
authors: Ken Higuchi, Ryoji Kawamura
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: In this paper, the extendible Skip Graph based on order preserving linear hashing is proposed. In this system, data are divided by order preserving linear hashing and additional routing elements are stored and managed in Skip Graph. These additional routing elements can be used for detours and some detours can be forwarded in one hop. Then, the number of hops for query forwarding may be reduced. In this paper, the extendible Skip Graph is compared with the previous Skip Graph based on order preserving linear hashing by experiments.

title: Development and Tolerance Analysis of a Second Harmonic MW-Level Gyrotron Cavity
authors: L. Feuerstein, K. A. Avramidis, I. Chelis, S. Illy, Z. C. Ioannidis, J. Jelonnek, J. Jin, E. Katsara, D. Peponis, T. Rzesnicki, I. Tigelis, M. Thumm, J. Weggen, C. Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The need for high-power gyrotrons operating at frequencies above 200 GHz is increasing, driving interest in harmonic gyrotrons with MW-level output powers. By interacting with the second harmonic of the electron cyclotron frequency, gyrotrons can achieve double the output frequency compared to fundamental gyrotrons using the same magnet system. However, as the harmonic number increases, the coupling between the electron beam and the cavity modes becomes weaker. Also, strong competition from fundamental modes arises, making it essential to develop effective methods to suppress fundamental modes. To address this challenge, coaxial gyrotron cavities with specific impedance-corrugated inserts can be used [1,2].

title: A Bayesian Theory-Based Storage Life Assessment Method for Multi-Level Product
authors: Shengpeng Zhang, Hao Li, Shuo Huang, Jiaming Feng, Ruyuan Xu
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Addressing the challenges of life assessment under limited sample sizes in storage life tests for highreliability and long-life products, this study proposes a Bayesian theory-based equipment life assessment method. First, we use Bootstrap sampling principle to fit the prior distribution of the equipment's life distribution parameters. Second, the likelihood function derived from test data is constructed with Bayesian inference to obtain joint posterior distributions. Third, to maintain equipment reliability evaluation, the Gibbs sampling method is employed to obtain marginal posterior distributions of each parameter. Finally, two case studies are conducted to discuss the application of the proposed method. The results indicate that the proposed method provides more accurate reliability evaluation results in comparison with traditional methods. Additionally, the proposed method can not only handle zero-failure and zerodegradation accelerated data but also achieve the evaluation of product activation energy.

title: Research on Aerospace Quality Data Analysis and Application Based on Retrieval-Augmented Large Language Models
authors: Texian Zhang, Beina Du, Lina Dong
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Generative artificial intelligence technologies, such as Large Language Model (LLM), have developed rapidly and are now applied to numerous domains. However, in the aerospace quality domain, LLM's applications and implementation paths require further exploration. In this paper, we study vector knowledge retrieval and prompt optimization methods based on retrieval-augmented LLM. We propose a hybrid retrieval method that integrates semantic retrieval, keyword retrieval, and a reranking algorithm to understand user intent accurately. Aerospace practices demonstrate that LLM can assist quality managers in conducting quality problem mining and quality situation analysis, uncovering key elements and correlations of quality and reliability problems, thereby revealing common weak points in aerospace products.

title: Edge AI for Industrial Quality Control: Real-Time Package Defect Detection Using YOLOv11 on Jetson Nano
authors: Prashik S. Maghade, Shlok Naik, Shivi Koshti, Rutuja Navale, Akshay G. Bhosale, Harikrishnan R
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Quality assurance of products is crucial in con-temporary industrial packaging lines. Automated solutions are very useful considering that manual inspection tends to be time consuming, inaccurate, and uneconomical. New advances in computer vision and deep learning led to the possibility of accurate real-time detection of defects on low-cost hardware platforms. Edge AI for Industrial Quality Control discussed in this paper is a real-time system of edge-computing-based defect detection that aims to inspect damaged packages with the Jetson Nano and YOLOv11 model. A Multi-camera setup improves visibility and alleviate diminishing false negatives, and the lightweight installation can easily be extended to current conveyor systems. The difficulty of broken package detection is addressed through multi-camera framework and fine-tuned object detection, where the system is robust to various conditions and classifies packages as good/bad. Our validation on an experimental dataset of custom-made data material provided high detection rates and precision across inference speeds conducive to real-time inspection. The findings reveal the feasibility, cost-effectiveness, and scalability of the solution to quality control in industries, and the possibility of its application in automated packaging lines.

title: Speaker Localization in Classroom Environments Using GCC-PHAT Features and Mamba State Space Models with Ad-Hoc Microphone Arrays
authors: Rashed Iqbal, Christian Ritz, Jack Yang, Sarah Howard
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Accurately understanding classroom interactions is essential for assessing teaching quality and student engagement. This study presents a novel audio-only source localization (SSL) framework designed for locating speakers within classroom environments using two microphone arrays located at unknown locations in the room. The proposed method integrates Generalized Cross-Correlation with Phase Transform (GCCPHAT) for time difference of arrival (TDOA) feature extraction and the Mamba State Space Model (SSM) for sequence modelling to estimate speaker locations. A dataset of reverberant speech recordings corresponding to three simulated classroom environments of different size and reverberation levels containing a teacher and multiple students and recorded with two different microphone setups, including First Order Ambisonic (FOA) Bformat arrays and 6-channel circular arrays. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms conventional baselines in both Mean Angular Error (MAE) and Mean Distance Error (MDE).

title: Hybrid Aritificial Intelligence and Internet of Things-Driven Proctoring Framework for Secure, Scalable, and Ethical Examination Monitoring in Online and Offline Environments
authors: S. Gouri Kiran Kumar, Thirupathi Regula, Noura Yahya Al Hoqani, Madhusudhana Rao Battina, Aisha Nasser Al Salmi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: The rise of online education, driven by way of the COVID-19 pandemic, has emphasized the need for reliable and scalable remote exam proctoring systems to uphold educational integrity. Therefore, we examine key strategies and technologies applied in modern proctoring systems, including synthetic intelligence, gadget mastering, and the Internet of Things (IoT) integration. We reviewed gaze tracking, head-pose estimation, voice popularity, and multimodal biometrics for detecting and preventing dishonesty. Continuous person verification and hybrid techniques, which integrate automatic and manual monitoring, are highlighted to improve accuracy and performance. Challenges such as retaining device robustness towards pose and light variations, privacy issues, and accessibility for numerous customers were also analyzed. We examined the cost-effectiveness and user accessibility of various proctoring systems, taking into account the constraints faced by educational institutions worldwide. Emerging technologies, such as real-time image processing and cybersecurity applications, are promising for future development. Through an evaluation of existing systems and the identification of current limitations, the results of this study provide a basis to enhance remote proctoring frameworks, enhance fairness, and meet the growing demand for online education. The results assist researchers and developers in designing proctoring solutions that are effective, secure, and inclusive for remote assessments.

title: Distributed Training Networks
authors: Haobo Ma, Binshi Wang, Rongzhe Li, Yuheng Dang, Zhaojun Hao, Xing Pan
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: With the advancement of technologies such as artificial intelligence and big data analytics, distributed training plays a pivotal role in areas including model training and image processing. A distributed training network is a system where multiple computing devices are interconnected through a highperformance network architecture to collaboratively accomplish large-scale machine learning model training tasks. A failure in any single device can disrupt the entire business process, resulting in substantial losses. Currently, research on distributed training is still inadequate, and there is a lack of targeted models and methods for reliability assessment. Therefore, this paper analyzes the typical failure modes and failure mechanisms of distributed training networks from the connectivity layer, performance layer, and business layer. It proposes a multi-agent simulation-based reliability assessment method for distributed training networks and establishes a simulation test platform to conduct reliability simulation assessments centered around distributed training operations. This provides a reference for the study of distributed training network reliability analysis and supports the implementation of reliability design and enhancement efforts for distributed training networks.

title: Construction of the Chinese Knowledge Graph on Electronic Product Failure Mechanisms and Reliability
authors: Xin Yue, Chen Ying
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: With the rapid development of industrial informatization, electronic products have become increasingly complex and diverse in structure and function, leading to higher demands for reliability. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a method for constructing a knowledge graph centered on failure mechanisms and reliability of electronic products, aiming to support reliability analysis and lifetime prediction. The approach integrates both bottom-up and top-down strategies to build the schema layer, where multi-source knowledge is collected and ontologies are defined using the IDEF5 method. The data layer is then developed through entity recognition based on a Bi-LSTM-CRF model and relation extraction using a Bi-LSTM with attention mechanism. The extracted triples are stored and managed via Neo4j, and the knowledge graph is further enriched through qualitative analysis or quantitative simulation. Finally, the proposed method is applied to a power module to construct a knowledge graph of its failure physics and reliability, demonstrating the full development process and providing a foundation for intelligent fault diagnosis, prediction, maintenance, and support of electronic products.

title: Narrativity-Aware Video Summarization Based on Vision and Language Foundation Models
authors: Shumpei Saito, Hiroyuki Ueda, Yosuke Ito, Kazuyoshi Yoshii
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This paper presents a novel video summarization approach that prioritizes the narrative quality of the summarized video to enhance its enjoyment and appeal. While most video summarization studies focus on extracting salient scenes using lowlevel visual features, they often neglect the storytelling aspect to optimize numerical performance on standard benchmarks. To address this, we propose a multifaceted video summarization method that leverages vision and language foundation models to assess shot-level importance (e.g., 2-sec intervals) based on both visual salience and textual narrativity. Specifically, our method employs a vision-language model (VLM) to generate objective captions for individual shots. These shot-wise textual descriptions are then fed into a large language model (LLM) with a prompt designed to produce a semantically-coherent text summary with strong narrativity. The narrativity-aware text embeddings obtained by the LLM, combined with visual embeddings from a vision foundation model, are processed by a recurrent neural network (RNN) to predict importance scores. The LLM and RNN are jointly fine-tuned to align with existing benchmarks. Experiments on the SumMe benchmark demonstrated the effectiveness of our multifaceted approach, highlighting significant performance improvements and the potential of text-domain video summarization.

title: Robust Audio-Visual Speech Recognition in Noisy Clinical Environments
authors: Akshita Abrol, Ridwan Arefeen, Haotong Yu, Alexi George, Kelvin Zhenghao Li, Zhengkui Wang, Rong Tong
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Visual acuity (VA) testing is a foundational clinical procedure for assessing vision clarity. Traditionally, VA testing requires patients to read optotypes aloud from a distance, with an assistant present to record the responses. Speech-enabled automation has been explored, however these solutions are highly susceptible to performance degradation from ambient noise and speech crosstalk: a common challenge in real-world, multilane clinical environments. In this work, we introduce a novel multimodal pipeline system that combines audio and visual speech recognition to enable robust and accurate VA transcription even under noisy conditions. By integrating synchronized microphone and camera inputs, our architecture employs advanced noise and crosstalk detection, and utilizes a dynamic decision module to intelligently select between audio-based ASR and lip-reading outputs based on real-time environmental analysis. To further improve accuracy under crosstalk conditions, we introduce a lip-guided audio masking mechanism that suppresses non-target speech by detecting when the patient is actively speaking. This multimodal pipeline represents a significant advancement for automated vision screening, offering enhanced transcription accuracy and reliability where single modality systems fail. Preliminary results demonstrate that the addition of lip-reading achieves a 33% and 16% relative reduction in word error rate (WER) compared to the audio-only baseline on the three-speaker and two-speaker crosstalk visual acuity test sets, respectively.

title: AI-Based Recommender System for a Healthy Lifestyle
authors: Rania Slimen, Mariem Haoues, Bassem Bouaziz, Nadia Bouacida
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: Recommender system technology has significantly progressed in recent years. This progress has made the automatic assessment of a healthy lifestyle achievable, offering a convenient way to track daily food consumption and manage physical activity. In the pursuit of fostering a healthy lifestyle, this study adopts the hybrid filtering system technique, considered for its ability to produce personalized recommendations. This paper proposes a personalized Healthy Lifestyle Recommender System, emphasizing diet evaluation and delivering customized suggestions for both dietary choices and physical activities. The primary objective is to enhance users' quality of life by empowering them with tailored guidance.

title: Implementation of RAG-LLM Based AI Agents for Public Service Innovation: RAG System Architecture Analysis and A Cross-National Case Study
authors: Jeesun Ryu, Yoonseuk Woo, Kyeongghyun Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: The rapid adoption of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) integrated with Large Language Models (LLMs) is transforming public sector services by addressing the limitations of conventional AI, such as outdated knowledge, hallucination, and regulatory compliance challenges. This study investigates the transformative potential of Retrieval-Augmented Generation integrated with Large Language Models (RAG-LLM) in public service innovation through architectural analysis and cross-national case studies of Estonia, Singapore, and the European Union. By examining RAG-LLM implementations across legal, administrative, and multilingual domains, the research identifies critical success factors in governance models, interoperability frameworks, and data standardization.Key findings reveal that centralized architectures (Estonia’s Kratt ecosystem, Singapore’s AIBots) enable rapid scaling through unified standards, while federated models (EU’s cross-border system) balance sovereignty with collaboration. Hybrid retrieval strategies-combining keyword-based and semantic search-and domain-specific embeddings reduce hallucinations by up to 63%, ensuring compliance and accuracy in high-stakes scenarios. Operational efficiencies are significant: Estonia processes 1.2M monthly queries with 89% resolution rates, Singapore automates 40% more citizen inquiries, and the EU reduces permit processing from six weeks to three days. Citizen satisfaction rates (82–98%) correlate with transparency features (source citations, multilingual support) and inclusive design.The study underscores that RAG-LLM systems act as force multipliers for public sector innovation when supported by adaptive governance, continuous data quality management, and standardized evaluation metrics. Challenges persist in generalizability to less digitized contexts, ethical governance, and evolving regulatory landscapes. Policy recommendations emphasize interoperability frameworks, domain-tuned standardization, and human-AI collaboration to realize scalable, trustworthy, and citizen-centric services.

title: UTRo-NAST: Non-Autoregressive Speech Translation via Understanding, Translation, and Reordering
authors: Yu-Chen Kuan, Kuan-Yu Chen
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Non-autoregressive speech translation (NAR-ST) has attracted increasing attention due to its ability to deliver competitive translation quality with faster inference speed. However, further improving the performance of NAR-ST models remains a challenging and important research direction. To this end, we propose UTRo-NAST, a novel NAR-ST framework that decomposes speech translation into three consecutive subtasks: source speech understanding, word-level translation, and target-side word reordering. The model first encodes the source speech into high-level acoustic representations, which are then translated into a sequence of target words. Finally, the sequence is reordered to match the syntactic and grammatical structure of the target language. By modularizing the speech translation pipeline, UTRo-NAST enhances model interpretability, robustness, and overall performance. Experiments on the MuST-C benchmark across eight language pairs show that UTRo-NAST consistently outperforms existing NAR-ST models and achieves translation quality comparable to strong autoregressive baselines, while maintaining faster decoding speed. These results demonstrate the effectiveness and scalability of the proposed framework for practical speech translation.

title: Accuracy Improvement of Automatic Chord Recognition with Source Separation Preprocessing
authors: Ayumu Mitoma, Ken'ichi Furuya
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Automatic chord recognition is a fundamental research topic in music information retrieval (MIR) and has been applied to various tasks, including cover song retrieval and music key detection. In recent years, several methods based on deep learning have been proposed, enabling easier and more accurate recognition. In this study, we focused on the bi-directional Transformer for musical chord recognition (BTC), a chord recognition method based on Transformers, and evaluated its performance. The experimental results showed that the chord recognition accuracy for the triads was <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 5. 5 2 \%}$</tex>, which is insufficient for realworld music applications. To improve the recognition accuracy, we focus on the differences in volume between instruments within a song. We propose a method that emphasizes sounds from chord-relevant instruments by applying source separation as a preprocessing step. By amplifying the volume of pitched instruments, such as a piano and guitar, we confirmed that the proposed method successfully corrected more than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2, 0 0 0}$</tex> misrecognized chord frames and improved the overall recognition accuracy compared with the conventional method.

title: Implementation of Type-1 Fuzzy Logic based Temperature Controller for Heat Exchanger
authors: Mohd Ismail Yusof, Noor Azzah Abdul Manap, Mohd Aliff Afira Sani, Azavitra Zainal, Mohd Zulkhairi Mohd Zan, Narendra Kurnia Putra
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Instrumentation, Control, and Automation (ICA)
abstract: Temperature process is one of the common control unit in chemical production facilities and employs for heating and cooling of certain materials. Intelligent control system is widely being employ in this facilities to control temperature according to its set point given. Designing an appropriate temperature controller is an utmost priority for control engineers due to its nonlinearity and longer dead time. This paper present a solution to systematically design an intelligent temperature controller using type-1 fuzzy logic. Initially, the open-loop time domain data is obtained from the experiment setup allowing a set of mathematical model to represent the temperature system. Then, a type-1 fuzzy logic controller is applied to the model and compared. The performance of closed-loop response is statistically evaluated showed that satisfactory performance with shorter settling time and less overshoot percentage can be obtained for temperature model with first order dynamic system response.

title: Preliminary Investigation Towards a MEBT Pulse Modulator for LANSCE LAMP Project
authors: A. Chrysler, H. Gaus, H. Patel, J. Alvarez Prieto, J. Bradley, A. Braido, G. Dale
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: This work describes the development of a GaNFETbased pulse modulator for the LANSCE Modernization Project at Los Alamos National Laboratory. A development board shows 500 V pulses with 4.2 ns rise and 3.2 ns fall. The development board can create two successive pulses with a 1.1 ns gap making it suitable for generating necessary beam patterns.

title: NAT-Unet Model for Optic Disc and Optic Cup Segmentation from Fundus Images
authors: Xiaozhong Xue, Kano Mizuno, Weiwei Du
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Based on the location, contour, and size of the Optic Disc (OD) and Optic Cup (OC) in fundus images, several eye diseases can be diagnosed. For example, glaucoma is identified by the cup-to-disc ratio, while papilledema is characterized by optic disc swelling, an unclear contour, and disappearance of the optic cup. Therefore, OD and OC segmentation not only assists clinicians in diagnosing various eye diseases but also enables the development of automated diagnostic systems. Although numerous OD and OC segmentation methods have been proposed, segmentation remains challenging in cases where the contours of the OD or OC are unclear, as is often the case in certain eye diseases. To address this, this paper proposes a Neighborhood Attention Transformer (NAT)-UNet model for OD and OC segmentation from fundus images. The NAT architecture is designed to extract discriminative features capable of identifying unclear contours associated with pathological lesions. To evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed model, data from glaucomatous and healthy eyes were obtained from a publicly available database. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model can accurately segment the OD and OC in fundus images.

title: Framework for Cross-Country Assessment of Logistics Efficiency on Asia-Europe Trade Routes
authors: Alina Nikitina, Aiavrina Efimova, Sanaaia Okhlopkova, Solangel De la Rosa, Wooho Kang, KwangSup Shin
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: This study presents a data-driven framework for assessing logistics performance between countries along Asia-Europe trade routes using an output-oriented Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA) model. Using the World Bank’s Logistics Performance Index (LPI) as a dataset. The model assesses how well countries transform logistics-related inputs such as customs efficiency, infrastructure quality, and international shipments into desired outcomes, including logistics competency, tracking, and timeliness. The analysis shows significant variation in performance across regions. Some countries with limited resources achieve full efficiency, while others with high indicators were found to be ineffective. The results highlight the critical role of digital coordination, organizational transparency, and policy integration in achieving logistics efficiency.

title: Effectiveness Evaluation of Anti-UAV System Based on Transformer
authors: Ruyue Li, Xiaohong Wang, Lizhi Wang, Mengfei Yao, Yushan Teng, Minze Xu
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: In the field of anti-UAV system effectiveness evaluation, traditional methods are difficult to describe the core characteristics of the system, such as adaptability, evolution and emergence. This paper proposes an intelligent evaluation method using deep learning (Transformer). Firstly, an agent-based modeling and simulation (ABMS) framework is developed to generate 16,000 samples. Then, eight core indicators (such as radar detection distance, photoelectric monitoring accuracy, etc.) were selected by using the grey relational analysis method (GRA), and a three-layer evaluation system was constructed. The Transformer model is introduced to model the nonlinear relationship between multi-source parameters and predict the core indicators: strike success rate <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(Y_{1}\right)$</tex> and interception success rate <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(Y_{2}\right)$</tex>. The experimental results show that Transformer achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2}=0.9740$</tex> (hit) and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2}=0.9982$</tex> (intercept), and the root mean square error (RMSE) is 0.0528 and 0.089, respectively, which is significantly better than linear regression (RMSE: 0.177 / 0.154), SVM and XGBoost. The multi-head self-attention mechanism of the model effectively captures the non-linear characteristics of the anti-no scene. The limitations of this method include Transformer 's inexplicability and static scene assumptions. Future work will focus on interpretable technology and dynamic combat simulation for further exploration.

title: Intelligent Root Cause Analysis Approach for Quality Accidents Based on Knowledge Graph and Large Language Model
authors: Rui Shi, Wei Liu, Chao Guo, Yihai He
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: As the speed of product updates accelerates, the mismatch between manufacturing capabilities and user needs becomes more and more obvious. Insufficient manufacturing capabilities lead to product failures or a series of quality accidents. Frequent quality accidents will bring poor product experience to users and cause huge economic and reputation losses to manufacturers. In this context, the continuous maturity of artificial intelligence technology has made it possible to efficiently and intelligently identify the root causes of product quality accidents and failures. To find the root causes of quality accidents and reduce the consequences of frequent quality accidents, a root cause identification scheme for quality accidents based on knowledge graph (KG) and large language model (LLM) is proposed. First, the connotation of quality accidents is proposed, and the formation mechanism of quality accidents in the big data context is explained with product reliability as the core. Secondly, a novel root cause analysis method of quality accidents is established based on the KG and LLM. Finally, a steam turbine is taken as the illustrated example to verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: On the Use of Artificial Intelligent with Large Language Model as a Tool for Evaluating Quality of Hazard and Operability Study
authors: Darmawan Ahmad Mukharror, Henry Susilo, Zulfan Adi Putra
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Instrumentation, Control, and Automation (ICA)
abstract: This study explores the application of Large Language Models (LLMs) in evaluating the completeness of safeguard identification in Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) studies. Safeguard completeness is considered a key result indicator in assessing HAZOP study quality. The methodology involved configuring a general-purpose LLM, followed by an initial training phase using synthesized data sets comprising Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams (P&ID) and HAZOP worksheets. The LLM's performance was evaluated across multiple iterations (shots) using prompts constructed by four respondents with varying levels of experience in process safety. Accuracy was measured by comparing LLM output to expert-generated safeguard data, and was found to positively correlate with both respondent experience and number of prompt iterations (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.9964 in the training phase).

title: Source energy distribution in an acoustic medium with an immersed anisotropic laminate plates
authors: Olga A. Ermolenko, Evgeny V. Glushkov, Natalia V. Glushkova
publish: 2025 Days on Diffraction (DD)
abstract: The transfer of wave energy from a source to a fluid-loaded anisotropic laminate plate is considered. The study is conducted within a semi-analytical model that was presented at the previous DD conferences (Glushkov, Glushkova, Miakisheva, 2020, Days on Diffraction, Proceedings, 79–84; Ermolenko, Glushkov, Glushkova, 2024, Days on Diffraction, Proceedings, 25–30). The closed-form representation of the time-averaged wave energy transfer through a cylindrical surface is utilized to study the source energy distribution. The frequency and spatial dependencies for the energy of reflected, transmitted, and guided waves are numerically illustrated and discussed.

title: A More Accurate X-Ray Spectrum Reconstructing Method in Pulsed Gas Discharge Diagnosis
authors: S. Zhao, B. Huang, C. Zhang, T. Shao
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Runaway electrons are a fundamental aspect of the physics behind gas discharge driven by nanosecond voltage pulses.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[1]</sup> Investigating the runaway electron energy distribution and its formation mechanism is a key focus of both plasma application and plasma physics.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[2]</sup> Recently, under the scheme of ionization waves, a groundbreaking method has been developed to reconstruct the runaway electron energy distribution function (EEDF) using X-ray spectrum.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[3]</sup> This innovative approach offers new insights into the behavior of runaway electrons.

title: Monomial Matrix Relocation on the Loss Function Level-Set of Feedforward Neural Networks
authors: Ozgur Soysal, Arda Ozdemir, Yigit Yildirim, Orhan Arikan
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Gradient-based optimizers are crucial for the success of deep learning methods; however, such optimizers frequently suffer from slow convergence and can become trapped in suboptimal local minima or plateaus. To overcome this issue, we propose a novel optimization technique called Monomial Equivalence - Interleaved Training (ME-IT) to augment well-known optimizers. ME-IT periodically applies a monomial matrix transform-a computationally cheap, loss-preserving transformation that leverages the inherent symmetries of the network. This “re-locates” the model to a functionally identical but parametrically different location on the loss level-set, enabling the network to explore the loss surface and find favorable points for continued gradient descent. Experiments on the MNIST dataset demonstrate that ME-IT-applied models converge significantly faster and discover final solutions with lower loss and higher accuracy than their state-of-the-art counterparts. A test accuracy improvement of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 0.3 \%$</tex> is achieved on the MNIST dataset with respect to the model with Cosine Annealing with Warm Restarts, and a training speedup of around <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 \times$</tex> is reached for shorter training sessions. This work establishes that strategically leveraging network symmetries is a practical tool for improving and accelerating deep learning optimization.

title: Strong Eye Closure Detection in Children with Profound Intellectual and Multiple Disabilities Using Robust Temporal Difference Features
authors: Kaito Kosaki, Teppei Nakano, Mari Wakabayashi, Tomomi Sato, Tetsuji Ogawa
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: In this study, we propose a model for detecting strong eye closure from sequences of periocular images. This motion is characterized by a temporal pattern in which the eyelids gradually close over time. While Transformers are well suited for modeling such temporal patterns, they primarily capture global dependencies across an entire sequence and may overlook subtle local changes. In addition, slight misalignments caused by camera shake, subject movement, or environmental variations across frames can make these fine-grained patterns even more difficult to detect. To address these issues, we aim to extract and exploit fine-grained local temporal variations in the periocular region while maintaining robustness to environmental changes and misalignment. Specifically, the proposed approach combines detailed, semantically meaningful feature extraction using GC <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> SA-Net, fine-grained inter-frame difference extraction via a token-exchange-based difference evaluation (TEDE) module, and Transformer-based sequence modeling. This design complements the Transformer's strength in modeling long-range temporal context by enhancing its sensitivity to subtle local changes and improving robustness to environmental variation and frame misalignment. Experiments on care-scene video data of a child with profound intellectual and multiple disabilities, who expresses discomfort or pain through strong eye closure, demonstrate that incorporating TEDE-based difference information significantly improves detection accuracy for strong eye closure.

title: Robustness Analysis of Urban Bus-Subway Coupled Networks Based on Cascading Model
authors: Zhiyong Yin, Ziyang Jin, Junlong Zhu
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: The robustness performance of bus-metro coupled networks during cascade failure processes triggered by sudden incidents has become a research focus. This study proposes a station importance evaluation method based on grey correlational-entropy weight comprehensive weighting. A cascading process model integrating a nonlinear load-capacity model and real-time redistribution of idle capacity is developed. Additionally, a robustness evaluation system combining network structure and passenger transportation functionality is established. Simulation analysis is conducted using Xi'an urban area as a case study. The results show that the capacity control parameters and overload coefficient significantly affect the robustness of the bus-metro coupled network in Xi'an. In the cascading process model established in this paper, when the two capacity control parameters are 0.23 and 0.1, and the overload coefficient is 0.2, the coupled network has high economic efficiency and robustness. Research reveals that dynamic critical nodes have a significant impact on network robustness indicators, and targeted protection can effectively enhance network robustness. The research provides theoretical support for urban traffic reliability management and enhances the ability to respond to emergencies.

title: Voice Privacy Protection with Adversarial Examples Using Anchor Speaker Embedding
authors: Shunya Ishikawa, Yuki Katsumata, Toru Nakashika
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Voice cloning technology has advanced rapidly due to its capacity for flexible speech customization, with applications spanning media content production and chatbots. However, this technology also poses significant risks to voice privacy, such as fraud via cloned voices and unauthorized access to speaker authentication systems. Recent research efforts have focused on preventing such imitation using adversarial examples. When applied to speech, such examples, or adversarial speech, can cause voice cloning models to synthesize speech signals that differ from the target voice, thereby protecting audio privacy. A previous study demonstrated the effectiveness of adversarial speech, which is optimized based on a simple loss function with only the target speaker's embedding. In this study, we propose a novel adversarial speech generation method, incorporating an anchor speaker embedding into a loss function to enhance the protective performance from objective and subjective perspectives. We also propose a method that uses Adam to optimize the noise added to the original speech to generate adversarial speech. Experimental results indicate that the proposed method is superior to the conventional method in objective and subjective metrics.

title: A High-Quality and Low-Complexity Streamable Neural Speech Codec with Knowledge Distillation
authors: En-Wei Zhang, Hui-Peng Du, Xiao-Hang Jiang, Yang Ai, Zhen-Hua Ling
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: While many current neural speech codecs achieve impressive reconstructed speech quality, they often neglect latency and complexity considerations, limiting their practical deployment in downstream tasks such as real-time speech communication and efficient speech compression. In our previous work, we proposed StreamCodec, which enables streamable speech coding by leveraging model causalization and a scalar-vectorcombined quantization strategy, but its reconstructed quality and complexity still have room for improvement. Therefore, this paper proposes an improved iteration of StreamCodec, named StreamCodec2. The StreamCodec2 supports streamable and lightweight speech coding by adopting a fully causal architecture and reducing the convolutional channels. To compensate for the speech quality degradation caused by model causalization and pruning, we introduce a non-causal, high-complexity teacher codec to guide the training of StreamCodec2 through knowledge distillation. Experimental results demonstrate that our proposed StreamCodec2, trained with the knowledge distillation strategy, can achieve high-quality speech reconstruction while maintaining low latency (only 20 ms), low computational complexity (only 910 MFLOPs), and low model complexity (only 5.4 M parameters).

title: Principal Component Regularization in Iterative Inversion of DBIM for Ultrasound Tomography
authors: Nguyen Thi Thu, Tran Quang-Huy, Luong Thi Theu, Duc-Tan Tran
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: In this study, we propose an improved framework for ultrasound tomographic image reconstruction by incorporating principal component analysis (PCA) into the iterative process of the distorted Born iterative method (DBIM). While traditional DBIM is effective in solving inverse scattering problems, it often exhibits slow convergence and poor performance under noisy conditions due to the accumulation of high-variance noise components across iterations. To overcome this, we embed a PCA-based filtering step into each iteration, which adaptively retains the most informative components of the current reconstruction and suppresses noise-dominated directions. Numerical simulations under varying problem sizes, with a fixed number of measurements, demonstrate that the PCA-enhanced DBIM significantly reduces the normalized reconstruction error—achieving up to 36 % error reduction compared to standard DBIM—and exhibits faster convergence, particularly in underdetermined scenarios. These results confirm that PCA not only improves the stability and robustness of the inversion process but also serves as an effective spatial regularizer, making it a promising tool for enhancing the quality and efficiency of iterative acoustic imaging methods.

title: AUDIO MATE – A Multisensory Learning Aid for Visually Challenged
authors: G D Vignesh, M Silambarasan, A M Balamurugan, J D Wilson Arul Raj
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Visually challenged individuals often face difficulties in accessing printed text, making independent learning a challenge. The ‘Audio Mate’ aims to bridge this gap by developing an assistive device that converts printed text into both speech output and digital Braille feedback, enabling self-learning without a mentor. The system utilizes an ESP32 CAM to capture images of printed text when a push button is pressed. The captured image is then sent for processing, where Tesseract OCR extracts and separates individual characters. Each recognized character is then converted into speech output through a speaker, while simultaneously being represented in digital Braille format using a set of six servos arranged in a standard Braille cell (2×3 layout). This dual mode output enhances accessibility for individuals with different levels of Braille proficiency. This results in elimination of dependency on traditional Braille books and human assistance, offering an innovative solution for independent learning.

title: Multi-Layer Sparse Coding for Multi-Exposure Image Fusion
authors: Altan Acar, Mehmet Turkan
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: A common strategy in multi-exposure image fusion involves weight map extraction, which determines the contribution of each exposure to the final fused image. This paper proposes three novel weight map extraction methods. The first one is based on multi-layered sparse approximations of image patches. This weight map refines the fine details to their fullest extent, forming the foundation of the proposed algorithm. The other two supplementary maps complement the first by providing additional base level of details derived from luminance and color information, enhancing the refinement process to construct the final fusion maps. Experimental results demonstrate that the developed framework achieves competitive performance, ranking among the leading state-of-the-art multi-exposure image fusion techniques.

title: Proposal of a Random Encoding Layer Compatible with Arbitrary Message Lengths for Diffusetrace
authors: Ou Egami, Masaki Kawamura
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: We propose an improved model for DiffuseTrace, which is a watermarking method that uses latent diffusion models. First, DiffuseTrace encodes a message into a watermark. Then, it inputs the watermark into a variational autoencoder (VAE). The resulting latent space is then used to generate the stego-image. However, this method of encoding messages has one limitation: the length of the message is fixed, requiring VAE reconstruction whenever the length changes. To solve this problem, we propose a converter consisting of an encoder and a decoder based on random networks. Our method enables the handling of arbitrary message lengths without reconstructing the VAE. We evaluated the image quality of stego-images generated using this method, as well as the accuracy and robustness of the watermarks against attacks. The results confirmed that our method achieves higher accuracy and robustness against attacks while providing image quality comparable to that of DiffuseTrace. Furthermore, we found that our method can support message lengths up to 20 times longer than DiffuseTrace.

title: Data Augmentation-Driven Segmentation of Ovarian Tumor Ultrasound Images Using Vision Mamba
authors: Thanh-Phuc Dao, Huyen-Trang To, Hoang-Son Bui, Thi-Lan Le
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: In this study, we investigate the impact of ultrasound-specific augmentation techniques on the segmentation of ovarian tumors in ultrasound images. These augmentations are designed to simulate common imaging artifacts such as shadowing, speckle noise, and contrast degradation, thereby enhancing model robustness and generalization. We integrate these augmentations into a training pipeline based on Vision Mamba, a state-space model known for its ability to model long-range dependencies with high computational efficiency. Experiments on the OTU2D dataset show notable improvements in segmentation performance. Compared to CNN-based baselines such as U-Net, our approach achieves higher Dice and Jaccard scores while maintaining a lower computational cost, making it suitable for real-time clinical deployment.

title: Optimizing Reading Assessment in International English Language Testing System with Generative Artificial Intelligence: Automated Question and Answer Generation
authors: Teh Chong Shin, Goh Ching Pang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: As English proficiency becomes increasingly essential for academic and professional success, the International English Language Testing System (IELTS) plays a key role in evaluating language skills globally. However, creating high-quality IELTS questions is time-consuming and requires considerable human input, which introduces bias and limits its scalability. Therefore, we automate the generation of authentic IELTS reading and writing questions, along with grading and feedback, by using large language models (LLMs). Gemini 1.5 Flash was selected for its superior performance across five criteria: massive multitasking language understanding, domain knowledge, output speed, integration ease, and cost. The results of GPT-4o Mini and Llama 3.2 Vision 11B were compared. We used a fine-tuned nucleus sampling setting (top-p = 0.7) to ensure relevant and coherent question generation. To assess system effectiveness, metrics such as bilingual evaluation understudy and recall-oriented understudy for gisting evaluation were replaced with task-specific evaluation criteria, including JSON formatting accuracy, answer retrievability, question-answer relevance, output variability, and material relevance. The developed system achieved a 93% accuracy in JSON formatting, 97.75% answer retrievability, and a question-answer relevance score of 0.9875. Additionally, the low output variability (0.2934) underscores the system’s capacity to generate questions that are diverse and semantically coherent. These results suggest that AI-driven automation substantially reduces resource requirements while enhancing the consistency and accessibility of IELTS practice materials.

title: Development of General and Data-Driven Machine Learning System for Quality Prediction on Manufacturing Lines
authors: Wei-Hung Chen, Jun-Lin Lin, Nhu-Hang Ha, Ya-Ting Chang, Wei-Chih Kao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: A general-purpose, data-driven machine learning (ML) system was developed for quality prediction in manufacturing. The developed system addresses the inefficiencies and human errors of traditional quality control methods, which delay defect detection, product recalls, or legal risks. While Industry 4.0 technologies, particularly ML, enable predictive analytics and process optimization, existing solutions are scenario-specific, so they lack adaptability across diverse manufacturing settings. To overcome this limitation, we investigated the needs of three different manufacturing companies (A, B, and C) through interviews and identified system requirements such as integration of heterogeneous data, flexible model deployment, real-time monitoring, anomaly alerts, and compatibility with multiple platforms. The developed system was implemented in Python, featuring an extract, load, transform (ELT) pipeline using Apache Spark (PySpark) and Apache Airflow for large-scale data processing and automation. A lightweight web-based interface developed with Streamlit enables users to explore data, adjust parameters, and visualize results interactively. The system performs data integration, machine learning model deployment, real-time visualization, and quality analytics. Ultimately, the system supports data-driven decision-making, improves production efficiency, reduces defect rates, and strengthens competitiveness through a stable, accurate, and scalable architecture.

title: Intelligent Sleep/Awake Node Scheduling Protocol for Enhanced Routing Efficiency in Wireless Sensor Network Environment
authors: Lakshmi N, Sri Ranjani V, Subapreethi M, Suman M, Syed Afrith M, Vaishali S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) have emerged as critical components in modern intelligent systems, particularly in remote monitoring, smart agriculture, industrial automation, and environmental surveillance. Nonetheless, there is a fundamental problem when it comes to deploying them in practice: bounded energy supplies on sensor nodes, which has a devastating effect on network lifetime and throughput. In order to overcome this, we shall develop an Intelligent Sleep/Awake Node Scheduling Protocol (ISANSP), which will optimize energy consumption, improve routing efficiency and not to compromise the coverage or data integrity of the network. A fuzzy-based classification and priority of the nodes are also integrated into the protocol so that only few critical and intermediate nodes are activated after other redundant nodes are placed into the sleep mode effectively. It is combined with energy-conscientious and clustering (LEACH, HEED) and utilizes the sleep-aware multiple-hop local area network routing to enable symmetrical drain in energy. The performance of ISANSP is shown by simulation results on a 100m x 100m field using 150 nodes that show that the system clearly outperforms conventional protocols. In particular, the protocol has an average PDR of 96.76% as compared to LEACH and TDMA protocols, a network lifetime extension of 40.20%, and residual energy saving of 28.4%. Although average latency does increase slightly (to 130.66 ms), that sacrifice is quite worth the much more network robustness and energy efficiency it produced. On top of this, the active node number is always very large during the simulation which will guarantee continued network operation. Consequently, the ISANSP deployment of adaptive scheduling as the intelligence behind energy-aware routing and fault-tolerant approaches provides a potentially desirable means to overcome the next-generation energy-constrained WSN. Being modular in nature, the protocol can be scaled to a variety of application areas that involve long duration independent deployments.

title: Evaluating Machine Learning and Satellite Data for Improved Prediction of Net Ecosystem Productivity in Thailand's Rubber Plantations
authors: Pramet Kaewmesri, Kanjana Koedkurang, Chompunut Chayawat, Pakorn Petchprayoon, Siwapreeya Phuhatthakarn, Duangrat Satakhun
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: Thailand’s rubber plantations in more than 3.2 million ha, are economically significant and ecologically valuable as potential long-term carbon sinks. However, their contributions to carbon sequestration are currently omitted from the national Greenhouse Gas (GHG) inventory due to the absence of standardized net ecosystem productivity (NEP) estimation methods and robust field-based validation. This study aims to include it in NEP by integrating multi-source satellite data, including Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer vegetation indices, Global OCO-2-based Solar-Induced Chlorophyll Fluorescence, and TerraClimate meteorological parameters with machine learning techniques and estimating NEP across rubber-growing regions. The validation of models was performed on ground-truth using Eddy Covariance data obtained from CRRC and NST, representing plantations of different ages and canopy structures. Among the tested models, random forest achieved the best performance (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.913 in training and 0.715 in testing), accurately capturing biophysical and climatic interactions. The predicted NEP values were used to draw high-resolution carbon maps, publicly accessible via Check Carbon, a mobile application developed by the Geo-Informatics and Space Technology Development Agency. This tool allows farmers, researchers, and policymakers to evaluate spatial patterns of carbon sequestration across Thailand. The study of the results showed that well-managed rubber plantations are effective carbon sinks and highlight the importance of including such ecosystems in national carbon accounting frameworks and climate mitigation policies. This integration ensures digital innovation with sustainable carbon planning.

title: Improving Automatic Speech Recognition Model for Super-Elderly Voice Using Speech Synthesis Model
