authors: Ryota Uematsu, Chee Siang Leow, Norihide Kitaoka, Hiromitsu Nishizaki
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Although speech recognition technology has made remarkable progress, recognizing elderly speech remains challenging due to age-related acoustic characteristics and limited training data. This paper introduces a novel data augmentation framework that utilizes text-to-speech synthesis specifically optimized for elderly voices. Our approach employs Style-BertVITS2 to learn from a small elderly speech corpus and generate additional training data while preserving distinctive elderly voice characteristics. Experiments using the EARS corpus demonstrate that our method achieves a statistically significant improvement in recognition accuracy, reducing the Character Error Rate (CER) by 0.31 percentage points compared to conventional approaches.

title: DOA Estimation with Lightweight Network on LLM-Aided Simulated Acoustic Scenes
authors: Haowen Li, Zhengding Luo, Dongyuan Shi, Boxiang Wang, Junwei Ji, Ziyi Yang, Woon-Seng Gan
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Direction-of-Arrival (DOA) estimation is critical in spatial audio and acoustic signal processing, with wide-ranging applications in real-world. Most existing DOA models are trained on synthetic data by convolving clean speech with room impulse responses (RIRs), which limits their generalizability due to constrained acoustic diversity. In this paper, we revisit DOA estimation using a recently introduced dataset constructed with the assistance of large language models (LLMs), which provides more diverse spatial audio scenes. We benchmark several representative neural network-based DOA methods on this dataset and propose LightDOA, a lightweight DOA estimation model based on depthwise separable convolutions and a gated recurrent unit, specifically designed for mutil-channel input in varying environments. Experimental results show that LightDOA achieves satisfactory accuracy and robustness across various acoustic scenes while maintaining low computational complexity. This study highlights the potential of LLM-assisted synthetic datasets for advancing DOA research, and demonstrates LightDOA as an efficient solution for resource-constrained applications.

title: MixedG2P-T5: G2P-Free Speech Synthesis for Mixed-Script Texts Using Speech Self-Supervised Learning and Language Model
authors: Joonyong Park, Daisuke Saito, Nobuaki Minematsu
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This study presents a novel approach to voice synthesis that can substitute the traditional grapheme-to-phoneme (G2P) conversion by using a deep learning-based model that generates discrete tokens directly from speech. Utilizing a pretrained voice SSL model, we train a T5 encoder to produce pseudo-language labels from mixed-script texts (e.g., containing Kanji and Kana). This method eliminates the need for manual phonetic transcription, reducing costs and enhancing scalability, especially for large non-transcribed audio datasets. Our model matches the performance of conventional G2P-based text-tospeech systems and is capable of synthesizing speech that retains natural linguistic and paralinguistic features, such as accents and intonations.

title: Progress and Challenges in DNN-Based Objective Quality Assessment of Synthesized Speech
authors: Erica Cooper
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: The field of speech synthesis has advanced rapidly in recent years, and evaluation methodologies for synthesized speech have evolved as well. While listening tests are the gold standard for evaluating synthesized speech, they are costly and time-consuming, leading researchers to consider more automatic and objective metrics for evaluation. In this paper, we give an overview of machine learning based approaches to the prediction of quality of synthesized speech, with a focus on modern deep neural network (DNN) based approaches for MOS prediction, including supervised task-specific training, approaches making use of pretrained self-supervised speech models, unsupervised approaches, and more recent approaches making use of large language models. We will also discuss the current state of objective evaluation of synthesized speech including open research challenges and future directions.

title: A Deep Reinforcement Learning Approach to Roundabout Traffic Signal Control
authors: Cheng-Yu Chen, Daniil Buryakov, Valentinus Roby Hananto, Victor Kryssanov
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Urban traffic congestion is a significant challenge for modern cities, leading to increased travel times, energy consumption, and environmental pollution. While conventional traffic signal control methods, such as fixed-time or rule-based strategies, are still widely used, they often fail to adapt to complex traffic dynamics, especially in urban roundabouts. This study proposes a deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework for intelligent traffic signal control, specifically trained and tested in the Gongguan Roundabout in Taipei, Taiwan-an intersection with high traffic volumes and asymmetric geometry. A simulation setup is created using the SUMO software, and a Recurrent Proximal Policy Optimization (R-PPO) algorithm with LSTM memory is used to address partial observability and temporal dependencies in the traffic flow. Experiments conducted under different traffic conditions, including peak traffic hours, demand fluctuations, and incident disruptions, demonstrated that the proposed R-PPO framework significantly outperforms baseline strategies. These findings highlight the effectiveness of memoryenhanced DRL in achieving adaptive, stable, and fair traffic signal control in real-world roundabout scenarios.

title: AODV-inspired Routing with Next-Hop Caching and Path Selection for LoRa Mesh Networks
authors: Melissa Jia Ying Chong, Shoon Kit Lim, Kei Kheng Tan, Jing Huey Khor
publish: 2025 IEEE Industrial Electronics and Applications Conference (IEACon)
abstract: The high mobility of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) leads to constant changes in node positioning, which disrupts communication links and affects overall network stability. Therefore, routing protocols such as the conventional Ad hoc On-demand Distance Vector (AODV) have been widely utilised in mobile ad hoc networks to ensure reliable data delivery. However, AODV’s on-demand routing nature leads to repetitive distribution of routing packets to re-establish overwritten routes, which is especially detrimental for low-data-rate communication networks such as Long Range (LoRa). This paper introduces an AODV-inspired routing protocol that integrates a next-hop caching strategy alongside a multi-route memory mechanism, enhanced by weight-based route selection. A proof-of-concept implementation is conducted in a real-world mesh network consisting of five static LoRa nodes and a mobile LoRa node traversing the network. Experimental analysis demonstrates that the proposed protocol is functional and achieves reductions in average routing latency of 19µs and end-to-end latency of 796.44s compared to the standard AODV protocol. These reductions in latency are vital for enabling efficient data delivery in dynamic topology networks. All source code and additional materials are publicly available at https://github.com/mcjy99/multi-route-memory-aodv.

title: Efficient Shared-Memory Parallelization of Flux Calculation in Unstructured Mesh CFD
authors: Qingsong Wang, Haozhong Qiu, Chuanfu Xu, Yonggang Che
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Computational Fluid Dynamics(CFD) on unstructured meshes are widely used in many scientific and engineering applications. However, efficient shared-memory parallelization of unstructured mesh CFD is very challenging due to indirect memory accesses and data conflicts. In this paper, we first evaluate various shared-memory MIMD (Multiple Instruction Multiple Data) approaches for the flux calculation kernel in an industry-level unstructured CFD software. Then we present several SIMD (Single Instruction Single Data) implementations for existing MIMD approaches, and integrate SIMD with MIMD. We test our shared-memory MIMD+SIMD approaches on both x86 and ARM architectures. Experimental results show that our MIMD+SIMD approach delivers a maximum speedup of up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.57 \times$</tex>, compared to prior shared-memory MIMD approaches.

title: Artificial Intelligence Enabled Genomic Identification and Validation of Diagnostic Markers in Acinetobacter Baumannii
authors: Fion Khek Xin Yan, Sumitha Samuggam, Jaayaisree R. Kupusamy, Suresh V. Chinni, Vijayan Venugopal, Ivan Rolland Karakada
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: The rising cases of multidrug-resistant (MDR) Acinetobacter baumannii in clinical practice have heightened the concern of rapid and precise diagnostic instruments. This paper uses the concept of artificial intelligence (AI)-based bioinformatics methodology to detect and confirm a species-specific non-coding RNA marker, AbaR-11, to use stable PCR-based-detection to identify A. baumannii. A computational pipeline was built based on genome mining, sequence alignment (BLAST) and Rfam databases to screen 342 candidate ncRNAs. Prediction tools based on machine learning, including RNApredator, were used to predict functional targets which showed connections to virulence regulators (e.g., AraC family). The chosen marker was very specific with a high sensitivity and the detection limit was 1.4 x 10 -3 fg/muL. The paper is able to combine the fields of computational genomics, AI-directed target prediction and molecular validation to provide a strong, low-cost diagnostic assay. This AI-bioinformatics hybrid framework provides opportunities of biosensors and monitoring of pathogens in limited healthcare settings with resources.

title: A Dynamic Malware Detection Algorithm for Enhanced Security in Sandbox Environments
authors: S V RithikSarogan, Linda Joseph, M Sambath
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: The rapid development of malware, characterized by obfuscation, polymorphism, and sandbox evasion techniques, has seriously challenged traditional detection mechanisms. Although widely adopted for the dynamic analysis of malware, sandboxes often fail to detect sophisticated malware variants. DMDA is a new approach that overcomes these shortcomings by adaptive behavior analysis, heuristic detection, and machine learning techniques. DMDA follows a multi-layered architectural framework from which features are extracted using API calls, memory usage, and network activity within a sandboxed environment. It uses advanced feature extraction techniques in conjunction with Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE) to rank features relevant for classification. By integrating them into the Random Forest algorithm, Deep Neural Networks enhance the capability of the system in making the correct distinction between benign and malware activities. The effects of the different features on outcomes in detection can be understood by the application of XAI methodologies including LIME and SHAP. DMDA learns knowledge of new emerging malware variants through continuous learning processes and reinforcement learning to adaptively improve the efficiency in detection. The proposed algorithm showed 98.8% detection accuracy, reducing false positives without losing computational efficiency. In fact, this makes DMDA scalable and robust for real-time malware detection in a sandbox environment. The future work will include cloud integration and applications in IoT security. Underlined is the relevance of creative methodologies in detection, as threats keep on evolving with overall cybersecurity resilience.

title: Dual-Band Shared Aperture Reflectarray Antenna for LEO Swarm Communication Systems
authors: Salwa Salsabila, Bagas Satriyotomo, Dongho Lee, Seongmin Pyo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: This paper presents a reflectarray antenna featuring a reflection-type horn feed, designed to deliver enhanced radiation performance in both the Ku and Ka bands. The antenna employs a precisely engineered phase distribution across the reflectarray elements, enabling accurate control of beam direction and radiation pattern. Simulation results demonstrate realized gains of 16.88 dBi at Ku and 28.5 dBi at Ka band. The antenna exhibits excellent impedance matching, with a scattering parameter (S11) of-21.99 dB at 11.77 GHz and a bandwidth of 970 MHz (centered at 12 GHz). At 28 GHz, the antenna maintains low S11 values, indicating good impedance matching across a broad frequency range.

title: Universal Scaling of Cascade-Failure Lifetime in Complex Networks
authors: Yongxin Deng, Chenyang Bai, Linchao Lu, Yikun Yang, Zhikai Tang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Cascading failures can dismantle critical infrastructures long before individual components reach their design limits. Yet quantifying the lifetime of such cascades remains difficult because breakdown probability depends simultaneously on network scale, load statistics and external disturbances. Through large-scale Monte-Carlo simulations on two-dimensional lattices covering four orders of magnitude in size, we show that the reciprocal lifetime collapses onto a single master curve when plotted against a dimensionless amplification factor that combines network size with the redistributed load per failure. This scaling law holds for five qualitatively different initial-load distributions—uniform, lognormal, gamma, power-law and Gaussian—thus defining a distribution-independent indicator of network robustness. A mean-field cascade map provides an analytic explanation and yields a closed safety bound that prevents the cascade from ever crossing the site-percolation threshold. The bound also shows that uniform disturbances translate the entire master curve horizontally, enabling accelerated lifetime qualification of large networks via small surrogates. These findings convert numerical evidence into actionable design rules and demonstrate how a seemingly complex phenomenon reduces to two control parameters: the amplification factor and the disturbance margin, together guaranteeing immunity against complete lifetime collapse.

title: Analyzing the Combined Effects of Association Rules for Software Defect Prediction
authors: Catherine Francis Mangare, Hiroki Inayoshi, Akito Monden
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Association rule mining has been widely applied to identify conditions under which software modules are likely to be buggy or not buggy. These rules include both positive rules (e.g., "A⇒buggy") and negative rules (e.g., "B⇒not buggy"). Positive rules help pinpoint modules that require thorough testing due to a higher likelihood of defects, whereas negative rules help avoid unnecessary testing by identifying likely clean modules. However, a critical question arises when both positive and negative conditions co-occur: what happens in such cases ̶ does the module end up being buggy or not ("A&B⇒buggy or not buggy")? This study investigates the combined effects of positive and negative conditions to determine which set of conditions dominates in predicting software defects. We conduct experiments using defect datasets from versions 2.0 and 3.0 of the Eclipse Mylyn project, which are widely used benchmarks in software defect prediction research. Our results show that dominant conditions for buggy (or not-buggy) modules are primarily associated with process metrics such as added lines, deleted lines, and pre-release defects, while product metrics showed very limited influence.

title: Reference-Free Adversarial Sex Obfuscation in Speech
authors: Yangyang Qu, Michele Panariello, Massimiliano Todisco, Nicholas Evans
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Sex conversion in speech involves privacy risks from data collection and often leaves residual sex-specific cues in outputs, even when target speaker references are unavailable. We introduce RASO for Reference-free Adversarial Sex Obfuscation. Innovations include a sex-conditional adversarial learning framework to disentangle linguistic content from sex-related acoustic markers and explicit regularisation to align fundamental frequency distributions and formant trajectories with sex-neutral characteristics learned from sex-balanced training data. RASO preserves linguistic content and, even when assessed under a semi-informed attack model, it significantly outperforms a competing approach to sex obfuscation.

title: ORCA-LF: Adaptive Leader–Follower Formation and Distributed Obstacle Avoidance for Ground Robots
authors: Xianchang Wang, Jiashuo Guo, Chengcheng Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: In obstacle-rich environments, each agent in a Leader-Follower multi-agent robotic formation faces simultaneous constraints from collision avoidance and formation maintenance, often leading to conflicting requirements. To address this conflict, we introduce an adaptive weighting mechanism that integrates the Optimal Reciprocal Collision Avoidance (ORCA) algorithm with a Leader-Follower formation control model, termed ORCA-LF. This method effectively balances the safety of obstacle avoidance with the stability of formation control. Theoretical analysis demonstrates that in obstacle-free environments, the proposed method guarantees asymptotic convergence of formation errors, while in environments with obstacles, it ensures formation errors remain bounded. Simulation results verify that ORCA-LF, while maintaining distributed control characteristics, effectively balances the demands of collision avoidance safety and formation stability. It demonstrates robustness and practical applicability across various scenarios, including open spaces, dynamic obstacle regions, and narrow passages, thus providing a solid theoretical foundation and technical support for deploying ground-based multi-agent systems in real-world engineering applications.

title: Sales Forecasting Model for Overseas Warehouses of Cross-Border E-commerce Companies Based on Big Data Technology
authors: Liping Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: Based on big data technology, a sales forecasting model of overseas warehouses in cross-border e-commerce companies was developed in this study. Key forecasting techniques such as Modeltime workflow and long short-term memory (LSTM) were integrated as a classical statistical method and an advanced machine learning method, respectively. Modeltime enables an easy process in time series prediction and automated model fitting and selection. LSTM-based forecasting models, including autoregressive integrated moving average, exponential smoothing, and extreme gradient boosting, capture complex patterns and long-range dependencies for accurate predictions. The hybrid approach showed high accuracy and forecast capability. The hybrid model developed in the study enhanced inventory management efficiency and optimized supply chains through enhanced demand forecasting in dynamically changing cross-border e-commerce environments.

title: On Field Reversals in Capacitively Coupled Plasma Discharges Driven by Tailored Voltage Waveforms
authors: C. Feng, D.-Q. Wen, J.T. Gudmundsson, J.P. Verboncoeur, J. Schulze, Y.-N. Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Capacitively coupled plasma (CCP) discharges are widely applied for etching processes in the microelectronics industry. In recent work, using experimentally validated kinetic particle-in-cell Monte Carlo collisional simulations [1], [2], we reported the sheath electric field reversal in low pressure CCPs, driven by a radio-frequency voltage source, when the driving voltage amplitude is up to 1000 V [3]. Due to the symmetry in geometrically symmetric single-frequency driven CCPs, the field reversal appears within each sheath adjacent to each electrode. In this work, we demonstrate the presence of field reversals in CCPs driven by tailored voltage waveforms. For a CCP with one electrode grounded and another electrode powered by a peaked or valley-type waveforms composed of 13.56 MHz sinusoidal waveform and its harmonics, a strong reversed sheath field is found only in one sheath that has the prominent sheath collapse phase shift. However, when the capacitive discharge is driven by a high frequency (60 MHz) voltage source on one electrode and a very low frequency (0.6 MHz) composed peak-type waveform on another electrode, multiple strong field reversals are found when the sheath collapses near the low frequency source driven electrode, a few weak field reversals are observed near the high frequency source-driven electrode due to secondary electron emission. In addition, the effect of a reversed sheath field on the electron/ion energy distribution incident on the electrodes will also be discussed in detail.

title: An Automated Academic Book Scanner with Deep Learning Powered Math Expression Detection and Recognition
authors: S Thamaraiselvan, Vivek Venugopal, Susmitha Vekkot, Pramod K. Pisharady
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Mathematical expressions are hard to read, which makes it hard to digitize printed STEM material. Conventional OCR methods do not work well on contents which comprise of text along with mathematical expressions. This paper proposes an automated book scanning system comprising of Raspberry Pi, page gripper and flipper set up and a smartphone camera for capturing the content. Once the content is captured, a combination of text recognition, mathematical expression detection and recognition modules work in synergy to provide the final digitized content. The mathematical expression detection module consists of a customized RoIHeads version of Faster R-CNN. The proposed model performed with 95.71% precision, 91.77% recall, 93.74% F1-score, and 87.42% mean IOU on the publicly available IBEM dataset. Once the expressions are detected, they are recognised using the Vision Encoder-Decoder Model architecture and the subsequent latex version of the mathematical expression is generated. This model is trained on the Im2Latex dataset and provided a BLEU score of 86.44 % on the test set. We also demonstrated the utility of the proposed method in academic STEM book scanning with accurate recovery of mathematical expressions. Our system gives a cost effective solution which makes it possible to extract text and mathematical content from printed books in a method that is scalable and accurate. This opens the door to large-scale digital preservation and machine-readable academic archiving.

title: Fine-Tuned LLMs vs. Rule-Based NLP for UML Diagram Generation: An Educational Evaluation
authors: Reshma P Nair, M.G. Thushara, Vijayan Sugumaran
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The automatic generation of Unified Modeling Language (UML) diagrams from natural language requirements continues to be a difficult task in software engineering education and practice. Conventional rule-based Natural Language Processing (NLP) approaches often fail to handle semantic ambiguity and typically demand extensive manual adjustments. Recent developments in Large Language Models (LLMs) demonstrate stronger contextual reasoning abilities, but their capability to produce accurate and structured diagrams-particularly in instructional settings—has not been thoroughly examined. This work compares a traditional NLP pipeline with a fine-tuned Qwen2.5-Coder-7B-Instruct model using a dataset of 75 annotated specifications. The fine-tuned model attained a semantic fidelity of 94%, a G-Eval correctness score of 0.78, and reduced manual correction requirements by 78%. In contrast, the NLP pipeline achieved 67% fidelity and required a 52% correction effort. Statistical analysis using MANOVA and ANOVA confirmed that these differences across the student, NLP, and LLM groups were statistically significant (p < 0.001). Moreover, students working with LLM-generated diagrams reported a 30% decrease in effort and greater engagement during modeling tasks. The findings demonstrate that fine-tuned LLMs can substantially improve the precision and interpretability of automated UML diagram generation while supporting more interactive and effective learning in software engineering contexts.

title: A Robust and Portable All-Digital TRNG Circuit for Extending the Instruction Set Architecture of RISC-V Processors
authors: Luca Crocetti, Ettore Noccetti, Pietro Nannipieri, Stefano Di Matteo, Ivan Sarno, Sergio Saponara
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: All-digital True Random Number Generators (TRNGs) play a crucial role in enhancing hardware security by providing native entropy sources directly within the processor pipeline. Their integration into open architectures such as RISC-V enables the extension of the Instruction Set Architecture (ISA) with secure, hardware-level random number generation capabilities essential for cryptographic operations. This work presents the design and validation of an all-digital True Random Number Generator (TRNG) for seamless integration with RISC-V processors via a custom interface. The proposed circuit has been developed using SystemVerilog and leverages Fibonacci Galois Ring Oscillators (FiGaROs), which use jitter and metastability as entropy sources to ensure high quality randomness. The TRNG has been integrated with the VECtor processor (VEC) core of the European Processor ACcelerator (EPAC) chip through a custom Control and Status Register (CSR) interface, enabling its use as a secure entropy source within the RISC-V instruction set architecture for cryptographic applications. The validation campaign is based on the typical main statistical suites of reference organizations in the field of security and cryptography and demonstrates that our solution offers both high-security standards and independence from both the implementation technology and the operating frequency chosen for the TRNG circuit, reporting an entropy per bit (in terms of Shannon entropy) of 0.9999 in all test cases, while always passing the pass-fail criteria for randomness. In addition, our circuit offers the highest entropy rate for both Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) and Application Specific Integrated Circuit (ASIC) solutions, as well as an efficiency in terms of entropy rate per resource consumption that is approximately 96 to 257 times that of the other solutions in the case of ASIC implementation.

title: The MJOLNIR Dense Plasma Focus Neutron Radiography Platform
authors: S. Rocco, B. Shaw, C. Goyon, S. Jiang, C. Cooper, S. F. Chapman, O. Drury, A. Link, A. Youmans, J. Park, D. Max, E. Anaya, J. K. Walters, A. Schmidt
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The MJOLNIR (MegaJOuLe Neutron Imaging Radiography) dense plasma focus (DPF) at LLNL is a prototype source for performing neutron radiography of dynamic events. MJOLNIR's driver can store up to 2 MJ stored energy and produce currents up to 4.5 MA (so far commissioned to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>3$</tex> MA). The DPF consists of two coaxial electrodes, which generate a plasma sheath by ionizing deuterium gas. The sheath implodes on the axis in a z-pinch geometry. When the pinch breaks apart, it produces a beam of ions that impacts the “target”, a region of the sheath assembled on axis past the pinch. The “beam-target” interaction produces a neutron burst lasting on the order of tens of nanoseconds, which can be used for radiography. We characterize the DPF implosion with laser interferometry, visible self-emission imaging, photodiode detectors, activation detectors, neutron time-of-flight detectors, and neutron radiography. The high shot rate and large suite of diagnostics make MJOLNIR uniquely suited to serving as a user facility for materials testing, diagnostic and detector testing and development, and longer-time-scale laboratory astrophysics platforms. As a new member of ZNetUS, MJOLNIR is an ideal platform for scaling up universityscale experiments. This presentation will lay out the opportunities available at the MJOLNIR facility as a test bed and neutron source.

title: Application of Weakly Interpretable PCA-KNN Framework in Ecological Restoration Engineering Planning
authors: Yuwan Xue, Xiaoping Li, Hui Li, Qiangjun Yang, Yan Zhang, Taoli Yang, Hanwen Yu
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Ecological restoration increasingly requires decision-support frameworks that can integrate diverse remote sensing indicators while maintaining interpretability for practical planning. Existing approaches often emphasize ecosystem assessment but provide limited guidance for selecting specific restoration projects, due to indicator redundancy and opacity of black-box deep learning models. To bridge this gap, this study proposes a weakly interpretable machine learning framework that combines principal component analysis (PCA) with k-nearest neighbors (KNN), termed PCA-KNN, for ecological restoration engineering planning. PCA fuses multi-source ecological indicators into principal components while retaining transparent loadings linked to underlying ecological processes, and KNN provides sample-based classification with traceable decision logic. Together, this structure allows ecological indicators and engineering decisions to be explicitly connected, balancing predictive performance with practical interpretability. The framework is applied to the northern slope of the Qinling Mountains, China, an ecologically significant region facing soil erosion, vegetation degradation, land-use conflict, and wetland decline. Using 13 kinds of remote sensing-derived indicators and field-verified engineering labels, the method achieves 87.6% block-level accuracy and 66.8% pixel-level accuracy, effectively mapping four restoration engineering types and reducing the planning cycle by more than half. Results demonstrate that the proposed PCA-KNN framework translates remote sensing ecological indicators into actionable engineering decisions, offering an operational and scalable pathway for data-driven restoration planning. This work advances remote sensing-based ecological restoration from post-hoc evaluation toward transparent, engineering-oriented planning support.

title: Unsupervised Hybrid framework for ANomaly Detection (HAND)- applied to Screening Mammogram
authors: Zhemin Zhang, Bhavika Patel, Bhavik Patel, Imon Banerjee
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Out-of-distribution (OOD) detection is essential for improving the generalization of of AI models used in mammogram screening, as unknown distribution shifts in external datasets can degrade performance. Identifying OOD samples helps maintain strong model performance across internal external datasets. Given the challenge of limited prior knowledge about OOD samples in external datasets, unsupervised generative learning is a preferable solution which trains the model to discern the normal characteristics of in-distribution (ID) data. Generic hypothesis is that during inference, the model aims to reconstruct ID samples accurately, while OOD samples exhibit poorer reconstruction due to their divergence from normality. Inspired by the hybrid architectures combining CNNs and trans formers, we developed a novel backbone- HAND, for detecting OOD from large-scale digital screening mammogram studies. However, relying solely on reconstruction error is insufficient for reliable OOD detection, as it may not consistently distinguish between ID and OOD samples. To address this, we incorporated synthetic OOD samples and a parallel discriminator in the latent space to distinguish between ID and OOD samples. Additionally, we applied gradient reversal to the OOD reconstruction loss, effectively discouraging the model from accurately reconstructing OODinputs and reinforcing its ability to differentiate them from ID samples. An anomaly score is computed by weighting the reconstruction and discriminator loss. On internal RSNA mammogram held-out test and external Mayo clinic hand-curated dataset, the proposed HAND model outperformed encoder-based and GAN-based baselines, and interestingly, it also outperformed the hybrid CNN+transformer baselines. Therefore, the proposed HAND pipeline offers an automated efficient computational solution for domain-specific quality checks in external screening mammograms, yielding actionable insights without direct expo sure to the private medical imaging data.

title: WizardEvent: Empowering Event Reasoning by Hybrid Event-Aware Data Synthesizing_supp1-3634839.pdf
authors: Zhengwei Tao
publish: N/A
abstract: Event reasoning is to reason with events and certain inter-event relations. These cutting-edge techniques possess crucial and fundamental capabilities that underlie various applications. Large language models (LLMs) have made advances in event reasoning owing to their wealth of training. However, the LLMs commonly used today still do not consistently demonstrate proficiency in managing event reasoning as humans. This discrepancy arises from not explicitly modeling events and their relations and insufficient knowledge of event relations. In addition, the different reasoning paradigms of the LLMs are trained in an imbalanced way. In this paper, we propose WIZARDEVENT, to synthesize data from the unlabeled corpus with the proposed hybrid event-aware instruction tuning. Specifically, we first represent the events and their relation in a novel structure and then extract the knowledge from the raw text. Second, we introduce hybrid event reasoning paradigms with four reasoning formats. Lastly, we wrap our constructed WIZARDEVENT with the paradigms to create the instruction tuning dataset. We fine-tune the model with this enriched dataset, significantly improving the event reasoning. The performance of WIZARDEVENT is rigorously evaluated through extensive experiments. The results demonstrate that WIZARDEVENT substantially outperforms baselines, indicating the effectiveness of our approach.

title: Statistical Models of Battery Packs Considering Cell-to-Cell Variations for Degradation Characteristics and Reliability Analysis
authors: Long Chang, Zhonghao Fei, Weibin Wang, Chen Ma, Chenghui Zhang, Changlong Li, Zhihao Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: Quantifying and assessing the degradation characteristics and reliability of packs under cell-to-cell variations are essential for ensuring the safe and reliable operation of electric vehicles (EVs). Therefore, based on statistical theory and a thorough investigation of cell degradation mechanisms and models, the statistical degradation models of packs for any configurations are pioneeringly developed through theoretical derivation. These models consider cell-to-cell variations, apply to various lithium-ion battery types and operating conditions, and are verified through Monte Carlo simulation. Based on these models, the pack state-of-health (SOH) statistics can be quickly and accurately obtained to quantify their degradation characteristics. Furthermore, the pack reliability can be efficiently assessed by integrating these models with the universal generating function (UGF) method. The results demonstrate that both parallel and series configurations enhance the pack-level SOH consistency. The SOH consistency in parallel modules with four cells is improved by 50% over cell-to-cell. After 3,000 cycles, a 10°C temperature variation caused pack reliability to decrease from 0.9343 to 0 (the lower the reliability, the greater the probability of failure occurring in a batch of packs). Moreover, packs with cells firstly connected in parallel and then in series exhibit superior SOH statistical performance and reliability. It has significant applications in pack configuration optimization, cell screening, and echelon utilization of retired packs.

title: Effects of Hydrodynamic Motion on the Stopping Power and Energy Deposition of Alpha-Particles in ICF-Relevant Plasmas
authors: B. Du, P. L. Yao, S. P. Zhu
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The outflowing velocity of the expanding deuterium-tritium (DT) fuel can become significant after bangtime, approaching its local thermal velocity when the inertial confinement fusion (ICF) hotspot exceeds the ignition threshold. However, the impact of such fluid motion on alpha particle transport and the underlying physics has not been fully explored in previous studies. In our work, we deduce a novel analytical expression for the charged-particle stopping power in moving plasmas. Furthermore, Monte Carlo simulations indicate that incorporating the background fluid velocity into the modeling of alpha particle transport within hotspot plasmas results in more energy being directly transferred to the D and T ions, while the background electrons receive less energy from the alpha particles. These findings enhance the understanding of how the burning hotspot quenches after bangtime and enable more accurate predictions in the pursuit of high energy yields.

title: Copyright Protection of General Information via Simulation Task Supervision
authors: Chenxi Hu, Yangyi Hu, Huangxiang Li, Yifan Hu, Ning Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) exhibit exceptional linguistic capabilities, yet their ability to verbatim reproduce copyrighted data from high-quality training datasets raises concerns about improper exploitation via Artificial Intelligence (AI) data traceability. Such copyrighted data may include general information (e.g., historical knowledge, or common sense), necessitating that LLMs generate content preserving key information rather than exact replicas. Current unlearning methods, however, primarily aim to fully forget targeted knowledge or key information, potentially leading to hallucinations of general information. To address these challenges, we propose an unlearning method based on attention flattening in auto-regressive models, combined with simulation tasks for targeted information forgetting. During optimization, the model is trained only on real tasks while acquiring knowledge from simulation task learning to suppress the memorization of copyrighted data. In inference, we compare the sensitivity of attention heads between simulation and real tasks, identify those most relevant to copyrighted data, and perform attention head pruning to suppress the generation of such data. Experimental results show that our method achieves lower perplexity and BLEU scores while maintaining higher entity coverage scores compared to existing unlearning baselines in generation tasks on copyrighted general information.

title: Platform Operations with Corporate Social Responsibility: Sales Assistance and Channel Selection
authors: Shihao Huang, Yudi Zhang, Kaijing Guo, Jiazi Zhang, Xiaojun Wang, Chun-Hung Chiu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management
abstract: As corporate social responsibility (CSR) gains increasing prominence in e-commerce, platforms are increasingly providing sales assistance to support their suppliers, such as JD's consumer-to-manufacturer initiatives, which help suppliers reduce their direct selling cost. However, the interplay between such sales assistance and the platform's CSR commitments remains poorly understood. While assistance can lower suppliers' operational cost, it may also reduce their profits in reselling channels, complicating the overall welfare implications. To systematically examine this interplay, we develop a game-theoretic model in which a CSR-oriented platform decides whether and how to assist a supplier, who subsequently chooses a distribution channel. Our results show that sales assistance benefits both parties only when the assistance is highly efficient and the commission rate is moderate. Otherwise, even well-intentioned assistance can harm the supplier due to high commission fees. Moreover, even if a platform with a high CSR level (i.e., one that pays more attention to suppliers' profits in addition to its own) exerts more assistance effort, a high commission rate can squeeze more profit, making sales assistance harmful to the supplier. Therefore, our study not only enriches the existing literature on channel structures by combining CSR and sales assistance but also provides valuable managerial insights. Specifically, it highlights that simply providing sales assistance is insufficient as it is necessary to simultaneously reduce commission fees for platform managers to achieve mutually beneficial outcomes. Managerial relevance statement: This research provides crucial strategic guidance for engineering managers and policy makers navigating platform-driven supply chains. For engineering managers responsible for designing operational assistance systems, such as logistics optimization tools, supplier training modules, or data analytics platforms, our findings demonstrate that technical efficiency alone is insufficient. To create sustainable impact, these systems must be coupled with moderate commission structures and a nuanced understanding of channel selection dynamics. Specifically, managers should evaluate how assistance efficiency interacts with commission rates across different channel structures to avoid unintended consequences where platform support inadvertently diminishes supplier profitability. For policymakers and platform strategists, this study reveals that corporate social responsibility initiatives require careful calibration between operational support and financial pressures. Regulatory frameworks and platform governance models should encourage transparent pricing structures and balanced risk-sharing mechanisms. Wellintentioned assistance programs can inadvertently harm supplier viability when implementation overlooks these economic realities. Policy interventions could include establishing guidelines for fair commission practices or creating certification standards for effective supplier development programs. This paper also contributes to the following SDGs: SDG 8, SDG 9, SDG 12.

title: Electrode Corrosion in Sodium Chloride (NaCl) Electrolytes During PEF-Treatment
authors: R. Straessner, A. Heinzel, A. Weisenburger, R. Fetzer, G. Mueller, W. Frey
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The examination of electrodes of treatment chambers, used for pulsed electric field (PEF) processing of aqueous liquids, showed macroscopic surface damages after only a few hours of treatment. The electrodes consist of acid-resistant, austenitic Cr-Ni steel (AISI 316Ti / 1.4571). For all investigations rectangular monopolar <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$40 \text{kV} / \text{cm}$</tex> pulses with a pulse duration of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \mu ~\mathrm{s}$</tex> were applied, administering a specific energy <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$150 ~\text{kJ} / \mathrm{L}$</tex> to the processed electrolyte. Corrosion was observed after PEF processing of aqueous sodium chloride (NaCl) electrolytes at a concentration of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 0.77 ~\mathrm{g} \text{NaCl} / \mathrm{L} \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$</tex>. The electrodes were processed in treatment periods of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 ~\mathrm{h}-10 ~\mathrm{h}$</tex>, corresponding to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.16 \times 10^{4}-1.08 \times 10^{5}$</tex> pulses. The obtained electrode mass losses were in the range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 1.0 \text{mg} / \mathrm{h}$</tex> (anode) and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 0.19 \text{mg} / \mathrm{h}$</tex> (cathode). Besides sodium and chlorine, only nickel ions could be detected in the processed electrolytes in significant concentrations of up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.28 \text{mgNi} / \mathrm{L}$</tex> electrolyte. The remaining corrosion products are present as solid particles. Additionally, results from metallographic investigations of the electrode surface and composition of the erosion products are discussed.

title: Development of Inductive Storage Pulsed Power Generation Using GaN FETs and Pulse Shaping by Current Multiplication
authors: K. Nagao, R. Matsuzaki, T. Sugai, A. Tokuchi, W. Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Almost a pulsed power generator is used in the industrial field, the energy is stored in capacitors, and the output pulse is generated by time compression or voltage multiplication. For example, LTD and MARX are voltage superposition-type generators. The current multiplication pulsed power generator has high energy density and the output voltage depends on the changing rate of the inductor current. The fast switching of semiconductor switches is key to output power.

title: Open Ended Rectangular Waveguide Operating Below Cut-Off for Measurement of Microwaves with kV/m-Amplitudes
authors: A. Aliyali
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: An open-ended rectangular waveguide is designed as part of a measurement setup to measure electric fields with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{kV} / \mathrm{m}$</tex>-amplitudes at 2.5 GHz. At these amplitudes, attenuation of the electromagnetic wave is necessary to prevent damage to the measuring instruments. This is achieved by operating the waveguide antenna below its cut-off frequency where the electromagnetic wave becomes an evanescent mode and undergoes tunneling. The amplitude of the signal can be attenuated by an arbitrary amount by varying the waveguide's geometry. As the attenuation increases approximately exponentially with decreasing frequency below the cut-off, any deviations in the measured electromagnetic wave from 2.5 GHz can be easily accounted for. Although waveguides operating below cut-off have been used for a long time, to our knowledge, there is no complete description of them in the literature.

title:
Two-Dimensional Fluid Simulation of Pulse-Modulated Inductively Coupled Ar/O
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Discharge
authors: M. Jang, H. Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: In sub-10 nm etching processes, profile distortions such as notching, bowing, and micro-trenching, as well as aspect ratio-dependent etching (ARDE) issues, pose significant challenges. The formation of a passivation layer by radicals and the control of etching rates by ions are critical for addressing these challenges. To maintain process consistency and ensure efficient equipment operation, it is essential to effectively control charge accumulation on the substrate surface. In continuous wave (CW) electronegative plasmas, the energy of negative ions is significantly lower than the sheath potential, confining them within the plasma due to the electrostatic field and preventing them from reaching the substrate. In this study, we employed two-dimensional fluid simulations of Ar/O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> inductively coupled plasma (ICP) with pulse power modulation to investigate the plasma characteristics under the duty cycles and mole fractions. Compared to CW ICP, pulse power modulation resulted in a substantially higher flux of negative ions. Additionally, during the afterglow phase, the ambipolar field collapses, resulting in an increased flux of negative ions reaching the substrate. These results therefor provide valuable insights for optimizing etching process conditions in the sub-10 nm regime.

title: Avoiding the Contracted CO2 Plasma Regime at Atmospheric Pressure by Utilizing Microwave Power Modulation
authors: L. Silberer, P. von Kürten, S. Soldatov, G. Link, J. Jelonnek
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The gas temperature of the plasma is considered as dominant factor for efficient microwave assisted CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> conversion [W. Bongers, 2017]. The optimum temperature for thermal dissociation of CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> into CO in thermal dissociation driven CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> plasmas is approximately 3500 °K[R. Snoeckx, 2017]. For industrial application microwave plasmas operating at atmospheric pressure are of high interest as they require less complex equipment and offer more design options. According to literature CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> microwave plasmas exhibit two main regimes, the diffuse regime for pressures below 300 mbar and the contracted regime for pressures above 300 mbar [F. D'Isa, 2021]. In the contracted regime, a CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> microwave plasma has a gas temperature above 6000 °K in the centre of the plasma volume and below 1000 °C at the edges of the plasma inside the confined space [E. Carbone, 2021]. Thus, the temperature in the centre is too high for the desired CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> conversion into CO and leads to the production of C atoms and C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> molecules. While in the diffuse regime gas temperature is ranging from 1500 to 4000 °K and has a more homogeneous temperature distribution [N. den Harder, 2016].

title: Design of the Circular Electron Optical System for a 650 GHz TWT
authors: J. Duan, Z. Lu, Y. Zheng, Z. Wang, S. Wang, H. Gong, Y. Gong
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: This paper presents a design for a circular electron optical system in a 650 GHz circular beam folded waveguide traveling-wave tube. A single-anode electron gun design and a uniform magnetic field, were developed to achieve good electron beam quality. Under a 19.0-kV voltage and 30-mA beam current, a focused electron beam with a radius of 15 um and a radial compression ratio of 26.67 is generated at the beam waist position. Confined by a 0.6 T uniform magnetic field, the focused beam exhibits good beam stability over a longitudinal propagation distance of 30 mm, maintaining a consistent beam profile without the interception of electrons, ensuring favorable performance for 650 GHz TWT.

title: Modeling Anode-Initiated Vacuum Insulator Flashover
authors: M. Hopkins, W. Brooks, R. Clark, Z. Echo, R. Goeke, C. Moore, M. Mounho, A. Neuber, J. Stephens
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: High voltage systems usually have an insulator, or insulator stack, in the system to hold off large voltage differences at the interface to a vacuum section. In a pulsed power system this insulator stack must hold off a large voltage pulse for at least the beginning part of the pulse, as power is delivered to a downstream target. Often, the size of the insulator stack to achieve robust performance is a limiting factor in the facility size. It is extremely advantageous, and sometimes necessary, to achieve reductions in size while maintaining a robust performance.

title: Energy Harvesting Aided PASTAR-RIS-Empowered NOMA System in the Presence of Impulsive Noise
authors: Aman Sikri, Bassant Selim, Georges Kaddoum
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: Reconfigurable intelligent surfaces are considered as a promising emerging technology for beyond-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$5^{\text{th}}$</tex-math></inline-formula> Generation /<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$6^{\text{th}}$</tex-math></inline-formula> Generation wireless systems. Leveraging energy harvesting technology, this paper considers an energy constrained source node that harvests energy from a power source through passive reconfigurable intelligent surfaces. The harvested energy is then utilized to serve multiple downlink power domain non-orthogonal multiple access users with the aid of partitioned active simultaneous transmitting and reflecting reconfigurable intelligent surface. Partitioned active simultaneous transmitting and reflecting reconfigurable intelligent surface as well as power domain non-orthogonal multiple access users are assumed to be impaired by impulsive noise. Hardware impairments are also accounted for at the source node and the power domain non-orthogonal multiple access users. It is shown that the impact of impulsive noise is negligible for imperfect successive interference cancellation at the power domain non-orthogonal multiple access users. However, for perfect successive interference cancellation, impulsive noise at the partitioned active simultaneous transmitting and reflecting reconfigurable intelligent surface degrades performance more severely for the nearest user than the farthest.

title: PFF-Net: Patch Feature Fitting for Point Cloud Normal Estimation
authors: Qing Li, Huifang Feng, Kanle Shi, Yue Gao, Yi Fang, Yu-Shen Liu, Zhizhong Han
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Estimating the normal of a point requires constructing a local patch to provide center-surrounding context, but determining the appropriate neighborhood size is difficult when dealing with different data or geometries. Existing methods commonly employ various parameter-heavy strategies to extract a full feature description from the input patch. However, they still have difficulties in accurately and efficiently predicting normals for various point clouds. In this work, we present a new idea of feature extraction for robust normal estimation of point clouds. We use the fusion of multi-scale features from different neighborhood sizes to address the issue of selecting reasonable patch sizes for various data or geometries. We seek to model a patch feature fitting (PFF) based on multi-scale features to approximate the optimal geometric description for normal estimation and implement the approximation process via multi-scale feature aggregation and cross-scale feature compensation. The feature aggregation module progressively aggregates the patch features of different scales to the center of the patch and shrinks the patch size by removing points far from the center. It not only enables the network to precisely capture the structure characteristic in a wide range, but also describes highly detailed geometries. The feature compensation module ensures the reusability of features from earlier layers of large scales and reveals associated information in different patch sizes. Our approximation strategy based on aggregating the features of multiple scales enables the model to achieve scale adaptation of varying local patches and deliver the optimal feature description. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance on both synthetic and real-world datasets with fewer network parameters and running time.

title: Experimental Implementation of Optimized Current Waveforms for Electromagnetic Launch
authors: V. Andraud, P. Gapenne, Q. Hassler, M. Schneider
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: During a railgun launch with capacitive energy as a primary source, the energy is converted into kinetic energy, inductive energy and resistive losses in the system, the kinetic energy being the main value to optimize. The efficiency and the speed of this conversion process highly depends on the current waveform characteristics. The objective of this study is to determine the influence of the current waveform on this conversion process. A set of experiments were carried out at the French-German Research Institute ISL involving the railgun experimental facility NGL-60, featuring convex rails and a 60 mm caliber, aimed at comparing different pulse shaping strategies and evaluating their effect on the launch efficiency. To this end, different initial capacitive energies with masses ranging between grams and kilograms have been tested. The results are analyzed by evaluating the different evolutions of energy quantities during the conversion process. The corresponding findings allow to derive methods to optimize the current waveform with respect to the railgun facility characteristics.

title: Full-Wave Simulations of Helicon Waves for Plasma Wakefield Accelerators
authors: L. Herrera Quesada, A. Köhn-Seemann, N. Fahrenkamp, S. Knauer, P. Manz, G. Tovar
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: In fundamental particle physics experiments, the energy requirements of modern circular accelerators constitute a challenge. Linear plasma wakefield devices appear as a modern solution to produce particles of very high energies: electric fields can be significantly higher than in conventional linear particle accelerators. However, to achieve high electric fields, the plasma medium must have a large electron density to create strong gradients. Helicon plasma discharges are known to yield the highest electron plasma densities, allowing the system to acquire the necessary density magnitudes for accelerator purposes.

title: Applications of Machine Learning Algorithms in Plasma Catalysis: Data-Driven Experiments and Simulations
authors: D. Ahrens, S. Wilczek, C. Koch
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Power-to-X processes are crucial for sustainable chemical production but face the major challenge of high energy consumption. To efficiently capture and process greenhouse gases like CO2, advanced technologies are required to convert them in an energy-efficient manner. enaDyne adopts the innovative approach of non-thermal plasma catalysis, where molecules are excited using electrically generated cold plasma. This process enables the synthesis of green basic chemicals, such as ethylene or e-fuels, without significant energy losses, such as those caused by waste heat.

title: Remote Magneto-Mechanical Modulation of Viability of A375 Melanoma Cells by Microsecond Pulsed Magnetic Fields and Magnetic Nanoparticles with Different Sizes and Shapes
authors: Y. Mi, M. Zhang, C. Ma, W. Zheng, J. Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Mechanical interactions between cells and magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) remotely driven by magnetic fields are receiving increasing attention, especially in tumor treatment for advantage of non-invasive stimulation. This study explored the influences of size and shape of Fe<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf> nanoparticles driven by microsecond pulsed magnetic fields (PMFs) on viability of A375 melanoma cells. Cells were exposed to PMFs with average amplitude of 1.22 T, width of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$28 \mu \mathrm{s}$</tex>, and repetition rate of 1 Hz for 20 min. CCK-8 reagent was used to detect cell viability. The results showed that the killing rate of PMFs combined with rod-shaped MNPs (diameter of 20 nm, length of 100 nm) was 39.6% higher than that of PMFs alone, and at least 18.38% higher than that of PMFs combined with the other three sphere-shaped MNPs (diameter of 10nm, 40nm, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex>). Furthermore, this study discussed the mechanism of the experiment result. Feature parameters of MNPs should match parameters of PMFs. In detail, the volume of MNPs should match the critical volume of Brownian relaxation, the relaxation time of MNPs should match the pulse width of PMFs, and the shape of MNPs should match the intermittence of PMFs. The results of this study provide guidance for the selection of parameters of PMFs and MNPs in remote magnetomechanical modulation application.

title: Research on z-Pinch Plasma Stabilization Method and its Mechanism Using Dynamic Axial Magnetic Field
authors: Z. Jiang, J. Wu, Y. Lu, W. Wang, Z. Wang, H. Shi, X. Li
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Z-pinch is an efficient technique for generating intense pulsed soft X-rays and has demonstrated significant potential for nuclear fusion energy applications. However, magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) instabilities during the implosion process often degrade implosion quality and reduce radiation yield. This study investigates the dynamic evolution of pulsed axial magnetic fields in Zpinch and their critical role in stabilizing the implosion process. To achieve three-dimensional control over the axial magnetic field distribution, an optimized rotating return column model is developed, incorporating the interplay of electric, magnetic, and mechanical fields. High spatiotemporal resolution optical diagnostics capture the diffusion and freezing processes of the axial magnetic field. Plasma parameters diagnostics and magnetic shear analysis further reveal the underlying stabilization mechanisms.To address axial field non-uniformities, a comprehensive magnetization structure composed of a magnetic mirror and a rotating return column is proposed. This design mitigates the suppressive effect of the return current structure on axial field diffusion at the load ends, enhancing axial field strength while improving uniformity. Results indicate that, for a fixed load height, the additional inductance of the rotating return column is correlated with the number of turns. Increasing the number of turns enhances the axial field but also extends the current rise time. For single-wire loads, increasing the turns from 0.75 to 1.25 expands the implosion radius by 25 %, delays stagnation time by 13 %, and reduces instability amplitudes by up to 40 %. In wire array loads, optical diagnostics reveal that the axial field migrates with the ablation flow, compresses along the axis, and effectively suppresses axial non-uniformities and magneto-Rayleigh-Taylor (MRT) instabilities.These findings provide new insights into optimizing magnetic field control to enhance Z-pinch implosion stability.

title: Significance of Co-Occurring Biomarkers in Localization of Epileptic Seizure Onset Zone
authors: Nawara Mahmood Broti, Masaki Iwasaki, Yumie Ono
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Drug resistant epilepsy (DRE) affects millions of people globally and requires surgical removal of seizure onset zone (SOZ). SOZ localization largely depends on biomarkers such as interictal epileptic discharges (IEDs) and high frequency oscillations (HFOs), though often they are found in both SOZ and non-SOZ areas, causing limited specificity. This study investigates whether temporally co-occurring biomarkers offer better SOZ identification. We analyzed intracranial electrode recordings from 10 DRE patients, evaluating three co-occurrence features: HFO-IED, HFO-HFO, and IED-IED overlaps. Statistical and machine learning analyses confirmed that co-occurrence features have significant difference in distribution within SOZ and non-SOZ region. IED-IED overlap demonstrated robustness in machine learning based classification, achieving the highest accuracy (71.65%), sensitivity (74.08%) and F1 score (0.6727); outperforming both traditional and overlap biomarkers. HFO-IED overlap showed the highest classification specificity (78.81%). These findings highlight the added value of temporal cooccurrence patterns, in enhancing presurgical evaluations for epilepsy treatment.

title: Deep Learning-Based Intelligent Fault Diagnosis of Motor Under Information Missing Conditions: A Review
authors: Zhenpeng Teng, Fuhong Kuang, Peng Hou, Xiaojian Yi
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: The significance of intelligent fault diagnosis technology is increasing in ensuring the operational safety and reliability of high-precision equipment. In particular, the integrity of multi-sensor data flow is directly related to the real-time and accuracy of motor fault diagnosis. Deep learning techniques, represented by generative adversarial networks, provide a new path to solve this challenge by virtue of its powerful nonlinear modeling capability and end-to-end diagnostic properties. This paper systematically reviews advancements in deep learningdriven fault diagnosis for motors under information missing conditions over the past decade. A brief introduction to the motor system is given first to dissecting the typical types of failures and their corresponding root causes from the motor system level to the component level. Next, data reconstruction methods and hidden space inference strategies to reconstruct missing data are investigated. Further, deep learning methods for label-missing scenarios are reviewed, focusing on semi-supervised, weakly supervised, and self-supervised learning frameworks. Finally, focusing on information missing scenarios, this paper summarizes the core technical challenges facing this research area and provides potential avenues for future development.

title: Autonomous Remote Power Activation and Deactivation System
authors: Zheng Wan, Jiahao Mo, Jiajie Pan, Beitian Zheng, Chenyang Hong, Shiyu Gu, Haoze Chen, Baohua Tan, Zongming Tan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: In autonomous driving of electric vehicles, vehicle power management is critical to ensuring system stability, safety, and energy efficiency. Therefore, we developed a remote power control strategy based on the Infineon AURIX TC397 multi-core architecture, in conjunction with a 5G communication module and an intelligent power management integrated chip. The strategy was validated through logical control and testing across various application scenarios. The developed strategy excelled in response speed, reliability, and scalability as an effective solution for remote control in intelligent vehicles.

title: Poster: EMDns: Advancing Security and Privacy in Domain Name Resolution
authors: Pengfei Yue, Jie Ji, Qing Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: This paper presents EMDns, a domain name system based on Ethereum and MongoDB, addressing the centralization, security weaknesses, and privacy issues of the Domain Name System (DNS). EMDns enables automated and decentralized domain management to eliminate SPOF and authority dependence, while resolution is performed via local look-ups with hash comparison to protect privacy against deanonymization attacks. Experimental results show that EMDns maintains resolution efficiency while significantly enhancing security and privacy.

title: Electro-Optic Testing of Flashlamps for a Laser Amplification System
authors: Benedict A. Land, Matthew Woodyard
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The Orion Laser Facility requires the use of flashlamps for the purposes of laser beam amplification. Flashlamps are typically constructed from a glass enclosure brazed to metallic electrodes at either end and filled with a low-pressure gas. There are many reasons attributed to flash lamp failure and replacing failed lamps in an operational system is both timely and expensive, presented here is a non-invasive method through which faulty lamps can be identified and removed from circulation.

title: Unified Graphics Processing Unit Communication Infrastructure for Global Distributed Computing
authors: Nikheel Vishwas Savant
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: The exponential growth of artificial intelligence (AI), high-performance computing (HPC), and the widespread adoption of cloud-native architectures have brought unprecedented demands on scalable and efficient graphics processing unit (GPU) infrastructure. Despite rapid advancements in GPU hardware, the ecosystem remains fragmented across vendors, complicating efforts to deploy distributed GPU systems. This study aims to survey existing GPU communication models to identify their limitations and propose a unified GPU network fabric (UGNF) to enable plugand-play interoperability across geographically distributed server farms. Theoretical strategies were proposed for minimizing cost while achieving optimal performance, providing a foundation for scalable and vendor-agnostic GPU deployments.

title: Platform-Centric Agile Transformation: Bridging Business Modularity with Federated Data Governance
authors: Wei-Ji Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: Agile transformation at scale requires architectural strategies to balance modularity, coordination, and enterprise-wide consistency. This study aims to develop a platform-oriented framework that restructures agile development around business-aligned modular components and federated data governance. The framework decomposes software systems into independently managed business components, each tied to specific functional domains and capable of localized development and deployment. These components interact through a centralized internal platform that standardizes infrastructure, tooling, and delivery workflows, enabling consistent integration across distributed teams. To support data consistency and policy compliance across organizational boundaries, the framework adopts a federated governance model inspired by data mesh principles to delegate data ownership to domain teams while preserving interoperability and global oversight. Informed by architectural patterns observed in real-world platform engineering and distributed agile practices, the proposed framework offers a scalable approach for organizations seeking to modernize their agile capabilities while maintaining traceability, modularity, and operational coherence.

title: FPGA Implementation of Encoder based Data Comparator for Non Linear filters
authors: Vasanth K, Pala Samhitha, Gubbala Mounika, Neeraja B, Sri Gayatri D, Sushanth Babu M
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: A Data Comparator using encoder to attenuate nonlinear noise in image processing applications is proposed. The Proposed Architecture implements a full subtractor using an encoder that is part of the carry generation unit. The Proposed solution was compared with the alternate technique and was found to offer optimized logic complexity and increasing the operational efficiency. Performance results confirm significant gains in power consumption and area over traditional comparators, making our architecture a best choice for Nonlinear filters in FPGAs.

title: Knowledge Forest-based Adaptive Learning Path Recommendation for International Chinese Learners: Multidimensional Cognitive Modeling Approach
authors: Yue Fu, Liqing Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: An adaptive learning path recommendation system was developed in this study for international Chinese learners. The system was constructed based on a knowledge forest to provide personalized learning paths for learners. By utilizing theme facet trees and the hierarchical dependencies of knowledge topics, the developed system effectively organizes and manages international Chinese teaching knowledge. Combined with a multi-dimensional cognitive modeling approach, the system evaluates learners' cognitive levels and learning styles, adjusts learning paths, and avoids 'knowledge drift'. We integrated the deterministic inputs, noisy "and" gate model to assess cognitive levels and the Felder-Silverman learning style model to quantify learners' personalized preferences, thereby recommending the most suitable learning content. The system’s adjusted learning paths significantly improve learning efficiency and knowledge mastery, while reducing redundant learning time. The system provides effective technical support and a foundation for personalized and precise international Chinese learning.

title: Ts-Vad+: Modularized Target-Speaker Voice Activity Detection for Robust Speaker Diarization
authors: Tran The Anh, Azmat Adnan, Wu Yihao, Chng Eng Siong
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Target-speaker voice activity detection (TS-VAD) improves speaker diarization by modeling speaker activity using prior speaker embeddings. We present TS-VAD+, a modular and scalable extension of TS-VAD enhancing robustness and generalization across diverse acoustic and domain conditions. TS-VAD+ integrates a transformer-based architecture, replacing traditional BLSTM, and is modularized to adapt any largescale self-supervised speech representations or pretrained speaker encoders, improving embedding quality. To further strengthen diarization performance, TS-VAD+ is employed with two additional modules: a profile enhancement module employing a denoising model to suppress noise and embedding leakage, and a post-processing module refining speech activity boundaries via an external VAD. Our evaluation on the AliMeeting dataset and the cross-domain DIHARD-III benchmark shows TS-VAD+ outperforms conventional TS-VAD. Notably, our enhancements reduce DIHARD-III DER from 19.53 % to 17.97 %. Scalability analysis indicates optimal performance when limiting the maximum number of speakers to eight. The TS-VAD+ code is released, supporting community research on this modularized approach.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup><sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>The code is available at https://github.com/TonnyTran/TSVAD

title: Improving Traffic Analysis with Computer Vision: A Comparative Study of YOLO and Machine Learning Models for Traffic Density Estimation
authors: Tzu Li Tang, Guan Hin Chau, Choo Jun Tan, Ming-Yu Liao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: Insufficient coverage and latency in traffic monitoring systems present challenges in growing urbanization, which increases traffic congestion. Computer vision and machine learning enhance the performance and responsiveness of traffic monitoring systems. However, varying traffic conditions and adverse weather introduce complexities that hinder the accuracy and precision of traffic detection. Therefore, we analyzed road traffic data using computer vision techniques to improve the accuracy and efficiency of traffic analysis. We also evaluated the potential of computer vision and machine learning in optimizing traffic flow to enhance road safety and support infrastructure management. Based on the results, computer vision-based solutions were developed to mitigate peak-hour traffic congestion. We used a traffic condition image dataset comprising five categories of traffic density (empty, low, moderate, high, and traffic jam) to assess the performance of different deep learning models: YOLOv8l, YOLOv9c, YOLOv10n, Sequential, ResNet50, ResNet101, ResNet152, InceptionV3, VGG16, and VGG19. YOLOv10n demonstrated superior performance, offering rapid inference and high accuracy in vehicle detection. VGG16 also proved to be a viable model, exhibiting low latency, short processing times, and strong classification accuracy across traffic density categories. Despite achieving high prediction scores, the sequential and InceptionV3 models overestimated traffic density, indicating limitations in their generalization capabilities. The results provide a basis for future research and practical applications in intelligent traffic monitoring systems.

title: Flow-Guided Consistent Video Depth Estimation for Cross-Dataset Generalization
authors: Jaeseok Jang, Chang-Su Kim
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Consistent video depth estimation aims to predict temporally consistent depth maps for videos. Various techniques have been developed to utilize temporal correlations between frames; however, most of these techniques generalize poorly to unconstrained scenes. Some recent methods based on testtime training require an impractical amount of inference time. Other methods apply attention mechanisms to video features to accomplish temporal consistency, but they do not consider scene variations across frames. In this paper, we propose a novel algorithm called flow-guided consistent video depth estimator (FCVD), in which a spatial feature alignment process leverages optical flow to modulate scene variations. Zero-shot cross-dataset evaluation results demonstrate that the proposed FCVD algorithm outperforms existing techniques in terms of depth accuracy and temporal consistency.

title: Towards Safer Online Platforms: Explainable and Adversarial-Resistant Toxic Comment Detection
authors: Sujani Chandrashekar, Yang Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
