abstract: Toxic content on online platforms—such as hate speech, harassment, and discrimination—continues to threaten the safety and inclusivity of digital spaces. These harmful interactions negatively impact user experience and highlight the need for automated, reliable moderation tools. In this study, we present a robust and interpretable machine learning framework for toxic comment classification using a fine-tuned BERT model. To enhance transparency, we integrate SHAP-based explanations that highlight which words contribute to a classification. To improve robustness, we incorporate adversarial training with obfuscated toxic samples (e.g., misspellings or symbol substitutions) that mimic real-world evasion tactics. Additionally, we implement a rule-based filter to flag borderline cases—especially those involving ambiguous terms—for manual review, reducing false positives. A user-friendly Streamlit interface allows real-time interaction with the model, providing both predictions and visual explanations. Experiments on the Jigsaw Toxic Comment Classification datasets show that our approach outperforms standard baselines in accuracy, interpretability, and resilience to adversarial input.

title: Degradation Modeling of Compressive Mechanical Properties of Delamination-Defective Composites Considering Heteroscedastic Dispersion
authors: Qian Chen, Ling Wang, Han Wang, Xiaobing Ma, Kewei Ye, Yujie Liu
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Due to the limitations of composite manufacturing processes, the mechanical properties of composite materials are significantly affected by defects such as delamination and porosity. Current degradation analyses of composite materials under defect conditions are mostly based on average or minimum performance, neglecting dispersion analysis, which restricts the generalization ability of the models. This paper takes ZT7H/5428 carbon fiber composite materials as the research object and proposes a compressive performance degradation prediction model that considers the size and location of delamination defects. By combining the heteroscedastic characteristics of the degradation process, the quantitative analysis of the uncertainty in degradation is conducted. The proposed model has been well validated with experimental data, achieving prediction <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> of 0.917, Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) of 364.96, and a prediction interval coverage probability (PICP) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 7. 1 4 \%}$</tex> under 95% confidence. The proposed model provides guidance for the design, maintenance, and production process control of composite material structures.

title: MVDR Beamforming for Underdetermined Sound Source Separation using Iterative PSD Estimation in Beamspace
authors: Jin Xuan Teh, Yusuke Hioka
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: We present an iterative beamforming framework that combines minimum-variance distortionless response (MVDR) beamforming with power spectral density (PSD) estimation in beamspace. This framework leverages the sparsity of speech in the time-frequency (TF) domain to improve the performance of MVDR beamforming for underdetermined sound source separation. Initially, PSD of interferences are estimated in beamspace using multiple fixed beamformers. These estimates are used to compute MVDR weights for each TF bin, attenuating the dominant interferers in each bin. In each iteration, the enhanced spatial selectivity of the MVDR outputs refines the interference PSD estimates, which in turn improve the subsequent weight computations. This iterative process preserves the distortionless response of MVDR beamforming while eliminating the need for nonlinear post-filtering and its associated artefacts. Simulations and real-world experiments conducted across diverse acoustic environments demonstrate substantial improvements in signal-to-interference ratio (SIR) and short-time objective intelligibility (STOI) compared to conventional MVDR. Notably, under anechoic conditions, the proposed method approaches the SIR improvement of a time-frequency MVDR beamformer constructed with oracle source PSD.

title: Comparative Numerical Analysis of Inductively Coupled Plasma Systems Using the Global Model, COMSOL, and Particle-in-Cell Simulation
authors: S.J. Hwang, S.I. Choi, H.J. Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP) systems are widely employed in semiconductor manufacturing because they generate high-density plasmas. Various numerical simulation techniques are utilized to analyze and optimize plasma behavior, each offering distinct advantages and limitations. This study compares three simulation approaches: the Global Model, COMSOL Multi-physics, and the Particle-in-Cell (PIC) Monte Carlo Collision (MCC) method for ICP systems. The Global Model assumes a spatially uniform plasma and efficiently predicts averaged plasma parameters as functions of external control variables such as input power, pressure, and gas flow [1]. COMSOL Multi-physics, a fluid-based finite element method (FEM) solver, enables the self-consistent modeling of electromagnetic fields, fluid dynamics, and chemical reactions, providing insights into multi-physics interactions within ICP systems [2]. Based on the PIC-MCC method, the K-PIC code tracks individual particle motions, offering detailed microscopic insights into sheath formation, power transfer, and kinetic effects [3]. This study investigates key plasma parameters under various operating conditions, including electron density, electron energy distribution function (EEDF), power absorption efficiency, and plasma uniformity. The trade-offs between computational cost and the accuracy level provided by each model are assessed, leading to a strategic selection framework for determining the most suitable simulation methodology. The findings of this study provide valuable guidelines for designing and optimizing ICP systems.

title: On the Use of Reflectometry to Remotely Measure Impulse Current for Biomedical Applications
authors: L. Michard, M.Z. Rahman, E. Oshin, P. Leveque, D. Arnaud-Cormos, C. Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Measuring current is critical to safe and effective pulsed power applications for in vivo medicine such as electrochemotherapy, pulsed field ablation (PFA) or endoscopic pulsed plasma treatment. Monitoring current not only allows the correct dose to be delivered to the target, but it also serves as a diagnostic tool for assessing the treatment outcome by indirectly providing the target impedance. In vivo applications usually involve catheters or electrodes, whose transmission-line effect can no longer be neglected when the applied pulses are very short, e.g., below 50 ns. In this case, the current becomes position-dependent, further complexifying measurement tasks. With this work, we propose a remote current measurement method based on voltage reflectometry. By analyzing voltage reflections from an arbitrary complex load, it has been shown possible to accurately assess the total current flowing through the load with no additional devices between the generator and the load. This work was achieved using an optoelectronic pulse forming network (PFN) generator featuring two photoconductive semiconductor switches (PCSS) [1]. Due to its special topology, the generator was simultaneously utilized as a voltage reflectometer. The generated pulses had a duration ranging from 10 ns to 40 ns with an amplitude up to 15 kV. The feasibility of the method was demonstrated using a nanosecond atmospheric pressure plasma jet (ns-APPJ) system [2]. The ns-APPJ system provided a configurable complex load that allowed validating the method over a wide impedance range. Furthermore, the electrical effects of the ns- APPJ system were assessed by performing a SOL (Short, Open, Load) calibration. The SOL calibration allowed separating the current due to the plasma discharges from the total current measured at the input of the device.

title: Poster: Digital Twin-Assisted Closed Loop Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Lane Changing
authors: Chang Liu, Ammar Hawbani, Ammar Muthanna
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Autonomous Driving Systems (ADS) integrating functional modules(i.e., driving maneuvers or processes) such as lane keeping, lane changing, and object detection must exhibit real-time responsiveness and high reliability, particularly when encountering rare and challenging scenarios. Enhancing system generalization in complex, dynamic environments remains a key research challenge. To address this, we propose a novel Digital Twin-based Closed-Loop Feedback Overtaking Decision Optimization Framework specifically designed for the overtaking maneuver. This framework leverages a Digital Twin (DT) to perform continuous model optimization and refinement, providing updated decisionmaking models to a physical twin for real-time execution. To mitigate performance degradation due to large data volumes, the framework incorporates both macro- and micro-level overtaking adjustment mechanisms coupled with incremental learning. Furthermore, we introduce a Boltzmann strategy-enhanced Reinforcement Learning (RL) algorithm to improve the efficiency of lanechanging and overtaking strategies. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework effectively enhances overtaking decision-making efficiency and optimizes performance in complex traffic scenarios.

title: Transmission Lines of the Capacitor Cell of High Repetition Rate Discharges
authors: B. E. Fridman, Y. L. Kryukov, M. V. Medvedev, N. E. Nechaev, R. A. Serebrov, D. B. Stepanov
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Transmission lines with a length from 15 to 25 m are intended to connect capacitor cells of 6 kV, 36 kJ with load [1]. The lines shall transmit the packets of cell discharge current pulses with an amplitude up to 120 kA and with a repetition rate of 1 Hz during 20 minutes. The transmission line in the cell circuit serves as an inductor which limits discharge current, transforms the energy released at the discharge of capacitors into magnetic field energy and then, after the crowbar diodes of capacitor cell are switched on, transmits the magnetic field energy to load.

title: Low ESL and ESR Aluminum Electrolytic Capacitors for Pulsed Power Applications
authors: Jonas Wittmaack, Thomas Ebel
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: This paper presents a novel impregnation method for aluminum electrolytic capacitors (AECs) using conductive polymer PEDOT:PSS to reduce the equivalent series resistance (ESR) in pulsed power applications. The capacitors are based on a previously developed low equivalent series inductance (ESL) winding geometry, ensuring minimal inductive contribution during high-current pulses. By pre-soaking the separator before winding the element, uniform polymer distribution is achieved within large winding geometries. The resulting samples exhibit stable capacitance behavior compared to classical HV-electrolyte capacitors and a factor of ten ESR reduction at 100 kHz. The proposed process enables improved high-frequency performance and offers a promising route for low-loss AECs in future highpower, fast-pulse systems.

title: Evaluation Score Prediction for Japanese Songs Based on Melody Fitness to Lyrics
authors: Sosuke Nishimura, Eita Nakamura
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This study investigates a method for predicting listener evaluation scores of melodies in relation to lyrics, with the aim of improving the quality of songs generated by automatic music composition systems. To address the limitations of supervised learning approaches that rely on large-scale human evaluation data, we propose a model that represents the implicit evaluation process involved in music creation. This enables the estimation of melody fitness to lyrics using only training data of melodies with aligned lyrics. As a specific focus, we study Japanese songs, in which the correspondence between musical elements and lyrical features, such as accent patterns and word boundaries, has long been discussed. By employing deep generative models of melodies conditioned on lyrical features, we analyze the relevance of various lyrical attributes to melody fitness and evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed approach. Experimental results show that the proposed method can predict listener evaluation scores with high accuracy, achieving a correlation coefficient of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 6 5 3}$</tex> with human ratings.

title: A Study on Individualized Learning Support for High School Mathematics by an Interactive AI Tutor : Educational Potential and Challenges in the Age of Large Language Models
authors: Shota Kitabayashi, Toru Takagi, Yukihiro Shintani
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: This paper is a literature review to summarize the pedagogical potential and challenges of interactive AI tutors in high school mathematics and to identify issues for the next stage of empirical research. The results were compared and analyzed from the four perspectives of (1) learning objects, (2) support design, (3) forms of practice, and (4) learning outcome measures. As a result, the following research gaps were identified: (1) lack of validation for students with significant academic achievement polarization, (2) lack of Large Language Models (LLM) tutor practice in Japanese and high school mathematics, (3) delay in developing indices to measure deep conceptual understanding and metacognition, and (4) lack of demonstration of cooperative operation models between teachers and AI. In particular, the fact that the average score of Mathematics IA (Math IA) in the common test fluctuates ±20 points from year to year and has an amplitude 3 to 5 times that of other subjects supports the urgent need for AI-based individualized optimization support. Based on the above, we plan to introduce the Generative Pre-trained Transformer 4 (GPT-4)-based "Khanmigo-like AI tutor" into Japanese high school mathematics classes and conduct a practical study to verify its effectiveness in deepening understanding and motivating learning for different achievement levels. We hope that this research will serve as a basic reference for designing mathematics education and generating evidence in the age of LLMs.

title: Research on Flexible Practice Method for General Quality Characteristics Assurance of Airborne Systems
authors: Da Li, Qihang Jiang, Shengqi Guo
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Current airborne systems development faces significant challenges in managing General Quality Characteristics (GQC), including ambiguous objectives of reliability activities, fragmented requirement flows and information flows among reliability activities, and misalignment with functional design. These issues lead to labor-intensive efforts with limited effectiveness. To address this, we propose a Objectives-Driven Assurance Methodology for GQC engineering. Departing from current process-oriented paradigms, our approach prioritizes the systematic mitigation of risks inherent in achieving top-level GQC objective. The method establishes a multi-level GQC objectives decomposition structure, which enables the hierarchical decomposition of toplevel GQC objective into measurable, traceable requirements at the subsystem, equipment, software, and hardware levels. Combining this decomposition structure with a dedicated assurance framework and risk-informed verification methods ensures that objectives remain valid throughout the development lifecycle and that expectations are met with acceptable residual risk. This integrated methodology provides effective management of critical functions and components, delivering quantifiable, traceable GQC design outcomes. The proposed approach demonstrably enhances the efficiency and effectiveness of GQC design and analysis, offering a viable solution to the critical need for flexible, outcome-focused development paradigms in next-generation airborne systems.

title: Overlapped Coffee Beans Detection and Localization Using a Low-Cost 3D Monocular Point Cloud Clustering Method
authors: Isack Farady, Alifya Febriana, Chih-Yang Lin
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Coffee beans present significant challenges for automated analysis due to their small size, overlapping arrangements, and distinctive morphological features. Most existing approaches rely on <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 D$</tex> image classification, typically distinguishing beans as either good or defective, but they do not adequately address occlusion and overlap—critical issues in realworld processing. Furthermore, many current methods depend on costly equipment such as LiDAR and depth cameras, limiting their practical adoption in agricultural contexts. This study proposes a low-cost monocular image-based framework for overlapped coffee bean detection and 3D localization. The approach integrates: (1) instance segmentation neural networks with monocular depth estimation to generate Pseudo-LiDAR point clouds; (2) projecting each 2D bounding box into a 3D pyramidal region of interest and clustering the enclosed points to isolate beans, followed by fitting 3D bounding boxes; (3) automatic pseudo-label generation from clustered point clouds to reduce manual annotation; and (4) tone-mapping techniques to enhance color contrast and improve detection robustness under challenging lighting conditions.

title: AIREM: AI-based Residential Electricity Monitoring System for Non-intrusive Monitoring
authors: Keh Kok Yong, Tengku Nurulhuda T. A. R., Wai Kong Lee, Kh’ng Xin Yi, Nor Aziah Amirah N. M., Boon Yaik Ooi, Woan Lin Beh
publish: 2025 IEEE Industrial Electronics and Applications Conference (IEACon)
abstract: Non-intrusive load monitoring (NILM) is an important technique for energy management and conservation. Extensive research was performed along this direction to allow automatic residential energy monitoring in a non-intrusive manner. The key to a successful NILM system development is to have a robust event detector and lightweight disaggregator for classifying each type of appliances and their power consumption. In this paper, we present an AI-based non-intrusive monitoring system able to automatically detect events, classify the types of active appliances, and estimate energy consumption. A novel table-based disaggregation method is proposed to easily disaggregate the power consumed by a particular appliance from the total power consumption. An efficient and robust rise/fall algorithm is also proposed to detect the targeted appliances. The backend (cloud server) and frontend (mobile application) designed are also presented in this paper.

title: Peer-to-Peer Energy Trading in a Local Energy Market Using Quantum Reinforcement Learning
authors: Md Moniruzzaman, Ajmery Sultana, Georges Kaddoum
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Recent years have witnessed a significant transformation in the sources of energy and its distribution among consumers and prosumers. Renewable energy sources (RES) such as photovoltaic have become particularly popular. However, RES requires a new approach to manage energy demand and supply by leveraging distributed energy generation. In this context, a useful paradigm is a peer-to-peer (P2P) energy marketplace, which is a trading mechanism that actively involves consumers and prosumers in trading electricity using state-of-the-art information and communication technologies. Accordingly, we focus on optimizing total energy trading costs by using quantum reinforcement learning (QRL) to ensure that local generation is first consumed by energy consumers within a local community. This is followed by a proposal of blockchain-based energy trading systems to facilitate decentralized, secured, and privacy-protected trading platforms for the trading participants. To this end, we use three optimization techniques - linear optimization techniques, reinforcement learning, and QRL - and analyze their performance. Simulation results show that the agents learning using quantum computing converge faster than those of the other two optimization techniques.

title: LLMs-Integrated Automatic Hate Speech Recognition Using Controllable Text Generation Models
authors: Ryutaro Oshima, Yuya Hosoda, Youji Iiguni
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This paper proposes an automatic speech recognition (ASR) model for hate speech using large language models (LLMs). The proposed method integrates the encoder of the ASR model with the decoder of the LLMs, enabling simultaneous transcription and censorship tasks to prevent the exposure of harmful content. Instruction tuning of the LLM to mask hate-related words with specific tokens requires an annotated hate speech dataset, which is limited. We generate text samples using an LLM with the Chain-of-Thought (CoT) prompting technique guided by cultural context and examples and then convert them into speech samples using a text-to-speech (TTS) system. However, some of them contain non-hate speech samples with hate-related words, which degrades the censorship performance. This paper filters the samples which text classification models correctly label as hate content. By adjusting the threshold for the number of correct answer models, we can control the level of hate in the generated dataset, allowing us to train the LLMs through curriculum learning in a gradual manner. Experimental results show that the proposed method achieves a masking accuracy of 58.6% for hate-related words, surpassing previous baselines. We also confirm that the curriculum training contributes to the efficiency of both transcription and censorship tasks. This paper includes offensive or hateful contents but does not refer to any particular group or individual.

title: Studies of Target Acceleration by Underwater Electrical Explosion of Foils in Strip Line Configuration and Magnetic Field Diffusion
authors: R. Grikshtas, S. Efimov, D. Rakhmilevich, K. Cohen, Y. E. Krasik
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Underwater electrical explosion of foils is a particularly efficient method to deliver high energy toward the acceleration of targets. In this context, we present experimental results of Delrin and lithium fluoride (LiF) targets which were accelerated by underwater electrical explosion of thin <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\sim 10 \mu \mathrm{m})$</tex> copper and aluminum foils in a strip-line configurations. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{1}$</tex> In these experiments, a submicrosecond pulse generator <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{2}$</tex> with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 580$</tex> J stored energy, delivering <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 100 \text{kA}$</tex> current pulse with rise time of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 250 \text{ns}$</tex> to the strip line, was used to accelerate the targets to velocities of up to 400 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$</tex>. The velocities obtained by analyzing streak shadow images agree with measurements made by a Photonic Doppler Velocimetry. Additionally, experiments with LiF crystals showed fast foil expansion corresponding to the liquid-vapor phase transition in the foils. Time resolved measurements of the infra-red and visible light emission relate their appearance to the foil's melting and vaporization, respectively. Lastly, we present observation of magnetic diffusion in thick <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\sim 200 \mu \mathrm{m})$</tex> foil experiments, where a water perturbation appeared <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 120 \text{ns}$</tex> after the beginning of the discharge current.

title: Sentiment Classification on Malaysian Mixed-Language Text
authors: Lim Kun Zer, Lim Tong Ming
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: With the prevalence of mixed-language usage, language processing models must perform adequately on mixed-language text as well as single-language text. Although natural language processing tasks such as sentiment classification have been extensively studied, limited research has been conducted on mixed-language text, particularly in Malay. Therefore, we investigated the performance of two models, long short-term memory (LSTM) and cross-lingual language model- RoBERTa (XLM-R), in conducting sentiment analysis on two datasets: one comprising English-language Twitter posts and another consisting of Malay-English mixed-language text. We evaluated the predictive accuracy of both models on a newly constructed Malay-English mixed-language dataset. The English Twitter dataset was obtained from publicly available online sources, while the mixed-language dataset was independently collected and manually annotated with sentiment labels. Both datasets underwent preprocessing to ensure compatibility with the input requirements of the respective models. Model performance was evaluated through the comparative analysis of sentiment prediction accuracy across the two datasets. Results indicate that the LSTM model outperformed the XLM-R model on the English dataset, demonstrating reliable sentiment classification capabilities. However, both models exhibited diminished performance when applied to the Malay-English mixed-language dataset, highlighting the challenges posed by code-mixed text in sentiment analysis.

title: A Study of Japanese Mixed Emotional Speech Synthesis Based on an End-to-End Emotional Speech Synthesis Model
authors: Issei Sakata, Tetsuo Kosaka
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: In this study, we examined mixed emotion speech synthesis for Japanese using Emotional-VITS, an emotional speech synthesis model based on VITS, which is an end-to-end speech synthesis model. On the dataset of pretrained models, we compared models trained in two languages (Japanese and Chinese) and models trained only in Japanese. Regarding the quality of the synthesized speech, we confirmed that the model trained only in Japanese has higher naturalness than the model trained in Japanese and Chinese in both subjective and objective evaluation experiments, and that the input text is accurately synthesized. We also examined the emotional features used in speech synthesis and confirmed that the average of the emotional features of other speakers, other than the speaker to be synthesized, yields a higher emotion recognition rate than the average of the emotional features extracted from the target speech or the average of the emotional features of the speech of the speaker to be synthesized. Furthermore, it was found that even in mixed emotion speech synthesis, in which two types of emotions are mixed, the emotion recognized by the subject changes consistently depending on the mixing ratio, and it was found that emotions close to human sensation are possible.

title: Generative Adversarial Networks-Driven Synthetic Data System for Secure E-Commerce Analytics
authors: Karthika M, R. Saranya, Ahmed Kateb J. Al-Nussairi, Ali Ihsan Alanssari, NajlaaNsrulaah Faris, Loveleen Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: This research is an innovative paper on leaving a synthetic data generation framework in secure e-commerce analytics through Conditional Generative Adversarial Networks (cGANs). The system proposed solves an acute problem of protecting privacy of users and at the same time keep the usefulness of the transactional data in an analytical manner. The model, trained on the condition of particular attributes (product category, customer demographics, and purchase behavior) produces realistic, but anonymized datasets that have the statistical characteristics of the real e-commerce data. This synthetic data can be used as a privacy-preserving substitute of training and testing machine learning models within areas of customer segmentation, fraud detection, and recommendation systems. It is realized with the help of TensorFlow with Keras API that allowed developing and deploying efficient models. The outcomes of an experiment prove that the synthetic data is highly trusted to be near a real one both in terms of security and usability. The strategy is scalable and feasible to use in work with secure data-driven applications in the emerging e-commerce analytics.

title: Enhanced Contrastive Learning for Prediction in Medical Temporal Knowledge Graph
authors: Hongji Bai, Zhou Sun, ZhaoHui Bai, Yuhang Wang, Runshun Zhang, Xiaoping Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Driven by the rapid advancement of artificial intelligence in healthcare, Temporal Knowledge Graph (TKG), which represent dynamic relationships among medical entities over time, have emerged as a vital foundation for tasks such as disease progression forecasting and the Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) principle of "preventive treatment." However, most existing TKG reasoning methods rely heavily on historical interactions or recurring patterns, limiting their ability to accurately predict medical events with limited historical records. To address this limitation, we propose a model called ECLTKG (Enhanced Contrastive Learning for Temporal Knowledge Graph), which is an Enhanced Contrastive Learning framework designed to jointly model both historical and non-historical dependencies. The framework introduces an adaptive loss weighting strategy to improve training stability and integrates a progressive thresholding mechanism with a mask-based inference module to effectively prioritize critical candidate entities. These innovations collectively enhance the model’s generalization capability in sparse clinical environments. We validate ECLTKG on a self-constructed temporal dataset derived from real-world clinical records of gastritis patients. Experimental results demonstrate that ECLTKG consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines across multiple evaluation metrics, offering robust support for disease risk assessment and the practical implementation of preventive healthcare in TCM.

title: Cucumber Leaf Pests and Diseases Detection Using Deep Learning Architecture with YOLOv5s Target Tracking and Image Enhancement
authors: K. Malathi, K V J Bhargav, R Sravani, Hebatullah Awwad, T Vijetha, Vijilius Helena Raj
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Detect cucumber leaf diseases and pests early to increase agricultural output and reduce losses. This study presents Cucumber Leaf Pests and Diseases Detection Using Deep Learning Architecture with YOLOv5s Target Tracking and Image Enhancement (CLPDDA) model, a lightweight deep learning framework for real-time identification of common cucumber leaf problems. It uses the YOLOv5s architecture, which is tailored for mobile and edge devices, combining advanced data preprocessing, augmentation techniques, and a solid detection backbone. The focus is on two main threats to cucumber leaves: leaf miner flies and target spot disease. Data augmentation techniques are used to enhance visual diversity. The YOLOv5s architecture boosts feature extraction. Transfer learning was applied with four models, VGG16, ResNet50, ResNet101, and DenseNet201, to evaluate feature extraction capabilities. The CLPDDA model has with over 89% mean average precision and high classification accuracy. The model's small size and high accuracy make it ideal for real-time use in agriculture, identifying cucumber pests and diseases.

title: Reducing Financial Debt and Illiteracy in Canadian Populations Using Machine Learning Prediction Models
authors: Mariam Merza, Uchechukwu Obinwanne, Wenying Feng
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: In this paper, we conducted a study on Financial Recommender Systems using tailored prediction and recommendation models. As financial debt and illiteracy rise across Canada, especially among Generation Z, there is a growing need for intelligent and accessible financial guidance. To address this, we synthesize a realistic dataset of 100 simulated Canadian users, we model financial behaviour using demographics, savings, debt, and expense data. Our system integrates multiple components: Isolation Forest for anomaly detection, ARIMA and LSTM for expense forecasting and a rule-based recommendation system (RecSys) to generate personalized financial advice. These elements form a unified pipeline that identifies abnormal spending, forecasts future expenses and delivers risk-aligned recommendations. Experimental results show that our hybrid forecasting model effectively predicts future financial behaviour, while the recommendation engine generates user-specific plans with heuristic scoring for priority labelling. Although this paper uses synthetic data and a rule-based RecSys, it provides proof of concept for scalable, practical applications. Future work includes real-user testing, dynamic LLM integration with an API key, and full-stack deployment.

title: Auxiliary-Function-Based Decentralized Independent Vector Analysis for Distributed Microphone Arrays
authors: Kouei Yamaoka, Katsuhiro Morita, Norihiro Takamune, Hiroshi Saruwatari
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel blind source separation (BSS) method for distributed microphone arrays, namely, auxiliary-function-based decentralized independent vector analysis (IVA). Previously, a decentralized IVA algorithm based on the natural gradient method was proposed for image signals. Unlike conventional BSS approaches, which aggregate all observations at a central processing unit, the decentralized IVA utilizes signals only within small groups of nearby microphones, referred to as subarrays, and shares not the signals themselves, but their power information among subarrays. In this paper, we first formulate the optimization problem of decentralized IVA for audio signals captured by distributed microphone arrays. We then derive a decentralized IVA algorithm as a modified version of auxiliary-function-based IVA to improve the convergence speed and stability of the conventional decentralized IVA. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm converges faster and more stably than the natural gradient-based approach and achieves better performance than centralized IVA.

title: Implementation of Internet of Things Test Levels in Precision Aquaculture of Malaysia Fishing Farm
authors: Teik Boon Tan, Yiqi Tew, Tong-Ming Lim
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: Test levels comprising component, integration, system, and acceptance stages were implemented across four small and medium-sized aquaculture farms located in the Perak region of Malaysia. We evaluated a precision aquaculture solution capable of transmitting sensor data from the edge to the cloud, thereby enabling federated learning. The test was designed to ensure coverage across all levels, followed by component-level validation of individual sensors, such as temperature and ammonia sensors, to confirm their functional integrity. Testing for integration was conducted to verify the interoperability of sensors with other system components. System-level testing was performed to assess the end-to-end functionality of the entire solution, ensuring that all subsystems operated cohesively. Acceptance testing was performed on-site to validate the deployment and operational readiness of the solution under real-world conditions. Design considerations and methodologies applied at each test level, from component to acceptance, were presented in the context of Internet of Things (IoT) implementation. The study results serve as a reference to meet the requirements and operational environments of the participating aquaculture farms.

title: Artificial Intelligence to Improve Acceptance and Performance of Bored Piles in Water Management
authors: Chenjie Tao, Yi Wu, Ming Hu, Jun Shi, Xiaofeng Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: We developed an artificial intelligence (AI) model to increase the acceptance and performance of bored piles in water management. Soils are complex due to their structural interactions. Traditional systems find it challenging to manage the data outputs, interpret the information meaningfully, or deal with a large amount of input data. To solve this problem, AI algorithms, such as an adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system, an artificial neural network, and a support vector machine, are applied to estimate the bearing capacity of the pile. Although each model has shortcomings, the AI-based model improves data analysis and prediction outcomes to offer a possible solution. By adopting AI techniques, the engineering of bored piles in water management is enhanced for effective water management.

title: Lightweight Hybrid Deep Learning Model with Digital Twin for Industrial Energy Optimization
authors: Md Raihan Subhan, Md Mahinur Alam, Kanita Jerin Tanha, Taesoo Jun
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: This paper introduces Energy-Twin, an integrated system that combines Digital Twin (DT) technology with Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) to support energy prediction and optimization in industrial manufacturing environments. Using real-time data from the Gumi Industrial Complex, the system establishes a dynamic link between physical operations and their digital counterparts, enabling continuous monitoring and intelligent decision-making. At its core, the framework employs a hybrid deep learning architecture that integrates Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Gated Recurrent Units (GRU), and Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) layers. This architecture is specifically designed to capture both spatial and temporal dependencies in energy consumption data, improving the accuracy of predictive modeling. The DT component simulates alternative operational scenarios in real time, identifying configurations that reduce energy usage without compromising production efficiency. XAI techniques are embedded to make the system's recommendations transparent and interpretable, fostering trust and usability for operators. Evaluation results show that Energy-Twin achieves a high prediction accuracy of 99.55% with low computational overhead, making it well-suited for deployment in resource-constrained industrial environments. The proposed approach offers a practical pathway to energy-efficient and intelligent manufacturing under the Industry 5.0 framework.

title: Phonocardiogram Signal Analysis for Myocardial Infarction Level Prediction using Deep Learning Model
authors: Ira Puspasari, Tati L. R. Mengko, Agung W. Setiawan, Miftah Pramudyo, Nobuo Watanabe, Trio Adiono
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Myocardial infarction (MI) demands rapid and accurate diagnosis to prevent life-threatening outcomes. Standard tools such as electrocardiography (ECG) and troponin assays remain essential but have limitations in sensitivity and early detection. This study proposes a non-invasive approach using phonocardiogram (PCG) signals—brief cardiac acoustic recordings—to classify MI severity, guided by troponin test labels. PCG signals were captured via electronic stethoscope, transformed with Continuous Wavelet Transform (CWT) for feature extraction, and balanced with Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE). A VGG-16 convolutional neural network was then applied to classify MI severity into four levels: micro, small, medium, and large infarctions. During internal validation, the model achieved 86 % accuracy, with 100 % sensitivity and specificity, and an F1-score of 92%. External validation yielded an F1-score of 85%, confirming generalizability. These findings demonstrate the feasibility of integrating non-invasive acoustic signals with deep learning for scalable, cost-effective, and early MI stratification.

title: Asymptotics of solutions to the characteristic problem for the ultrahyperbolic equation along null geodesics
authors: Maxim N. Demchenko
publish: 2025 Days on Diffraction (DD)
abstract: We deal with the problem for the ultrahyperbolic equation in the Euclidean space with data on the characteristic hyperplane. The main subject of the paper is the asymptotic behavior of solutions at large distances from the initial hyperplane. Analogously to hyperbolic problems, the result is given in terms of asymptotics along null geodesics with respect to a metric relevant to the ultrahyperbolic equation.

title: Autonomous AI-based Cybersecurity Framework for Critical Infrastructure: Real-Time Threat Mitigation
authors: Jenifer Paulraj, Brindha Raghuraman, Nagarani Gopalakrishnan, Yazan Otoum
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Critical infrastructure systems, including energy grids, healthcare facilities, transportation networks, and water distribution systems, are pivotal to societal stability and economic resilience. However, the increasing interconnectivity of these systems exposes them to various cyber threats, including ransomware, Denial-of-Service (DoS) attacks, and Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs). This paper examines cybersecurity vulnerabilities in critical infrastructure, highlighting the threat landscape, attack vectors, and the role of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in mitigating these risks. We propose a hybrid AI-driven cybersecurity framework to enhance real-time vulnerability detection, threat modelling, and automated remediation. This study also addresses the complexities of adversarial AI, regulatory compliance, and integration. Our findings provide actionable insights to strengthen the security and resilience of critical infrastructure systems against emerging cyber threats.

title: Interpolating Speaker Identities in Embedding Space for Data Expansion
authors: Tianchi Liu, Ruijie Tao, Qiongqiong Wang, Yidi Jiang, Hardik B. Sailor, Ke Zhang, Jingru Lin, Haizhou Li
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: The success of deep learning-based speaker verification systems is largely attributed to access to large-scale and diverse speaker identity data. However, collecting data from more identities is expensive, challenging, and often limited by privacy concerns. To address this limitation, we propose INSIDE (Interpolating Speaker Identities in Embedding Space), a novel data expansion method that synthesizes new speaker identities by interpolating between existing speaker embeddings. Specifically, we select pairs of nearby speaker embeddings from a pretrained speaker embedding space and compute intermediate embeddings using spherical linear interpolation. These interpolated embeddings are then fed to a text-to-speech system to generate corresponding speech waveforms. The resulting data is combined with the original dataset to train downstream models. Experiments show that models trained with INSIDEexpanded data outperform those trained only on real data, achieving 3.06 % to 5.24 % relative improvements. While INSIDE is primarily designed for speaker verification, we also validate its effectiveness on gender classification, where it yields a 13.44 % relative improvement. Moreover, INSIDE is compatible with other augmentation techniques and can serve as a flexible, scalable addition to existing training pipelines.

title: A Psychological Strategy Annotation Method Using Multiple LLMs with a Chain of Thought Based on Deductive Reasoning
authors: Jinran Wang, Jiaming Luo, Shaomeng Yang, Yongjie Zhou, Xuefang Zhang, Rongfeng Su, Nan Yan, Lan Wang
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Using appropriate psychological counseling strategies is critical for improving the quality of large language modeldriven mental health dialogues, yet a single large language model (LLM) often produces unreliable results due to ambiguous strategy definitions and degradation of thought in reasoning. Multi-LLM voting-based strategy annotation methods are often hampered in their overall decision-making performance due to the low accuracy of some individual models. To address this, we propose a multi-LLM system with a deductive-reasoning chain of thought. We built a dataset that comprises psychologist-client dialogue segments, each annotated with nine strategies by four professional psychologists. The system uses three LLMs as experts to generate initial strategy candidates, and then an LLM as a judge applies deductive reasoning-aligning dialogue evidence with strategy definitions-to annotate the optimal strategy. Experiments show that this approach outperforms single models, voting, and conventional chain-of-thought methods in F1 score and accuracy. This work advances LLM-based psychological strategy annotation, offering a reliable tool for mental health dialogue systems.

title: Anomalous Sound Detection Using Time-Frequency Derivative of Instantaneous Phase Features
authors: Tran-Quang-Tuan Vo, Quoc-Huy Nguyen, Masashi Unoki
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Anomalous sound detection (ASD) plays a crucial role in predictive maintenance for industrial machines, enabling the monitoring of their health status through the analysis of sound signals. With the diversity of anomalous sounds in industrial environments and the scarcity of labeled data, unsupervised learning that leverages deep learning techniques demonstrates robust performance. However, the entire performance of the ASD detector depends significantly on the front end, which concentrates on feature extraction. While most ASD systems rely on amplitude information, there has been relatively little focus on phase information. This study proposes the use of the derivatives of instantaneous phase along time, frequency, and time-frequency, incorporating an Interpolation Deep Neural Network for ASD. The experimental procedures are conducted on the MIMII dataset, with the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (ROC AUC) serving as the evaluation metric. The experimental results on the MIMII dataset demonstrate that our proposed method achieves an improvement in AUC over other recently proposed unsupervised methods that utilize amplitude information in detecting anomalous sounds from industrial machines.

title: Multichannel Feedforward Active Noise Control System with Optical Laser Microphone in Reverberant Environments
authors: Maoto Mizutani, Kenta Iwai, Masato Nakayama, Takanobu Nishiura, Yoshiharu Soeta
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: A feedforward active noise control (ANC) system is affected by a constraint related to processing and sound propagation delay, known as the causality constraint. To address this problem, an ANC system incorporating an optical laser microphone has been proposed. The optical laser microphone captures the vibration velocity of the target noise at the speed of light, thereby relaxing the causality constraint. However, the acquired signal contains few components related to the reverberation characteristics of the room. As a result, the noise reduction performance of the system degrades in reverberant environments. To overcome this issue, we propose a multichannel feedforward active noise control system to improve the noise reduction performance in reverberant environments. The proposed system uses both an optical laser microphone and an airconducted microphone as reference microphones. The key feature of the system is the additional air-conducted microphone, which acquires the noise with the reverberant components. The system processes signals acquired by each microphone using each noise control filter, thereby both relaxing the causality constraint and accounting for the room's reflective characteristics. As a result of actual experiments, we confirmed that the proposed system improves the noise reduction performance.

title: Profit Model of Small and Medium-sized Enterprises Using Support Vector Machine Algorithm in Building Materials Industry
authors: Xiaoyu Yan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: The value chain of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) of the building materials industry was analyzed using a support vector machine (SVM) algorithm. The algorithm was trained to learn the data and then to establish the profit prediction model. The SVM model showed high accuracy in profit prediction through parameter optimization. The mean squared error decreased from 2000 to 1200 after optimization, the root mean square error decreased from 44.72 to 34.64, and R² increased from 0.65 to 0.80, showing significant performance. Compared with the traditional linear regression model, the prediction accuracy of the SVM model was improved by 25%.

title: Heterogeneous Graph Attention-Based Deep Reinforcement Learning for Latency-Optimal Digital Twin Placement in Edge Networks
authors: Rongjiang Zhu, Shubin Zhang, KaiKai Chi, Yuchen Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: With the continuous emergence of next-generation advanced Internet of Things (IoT) applications, there is an increasing demand for efficient methods to discover time-sensitive information, services, and resources. To address this challenge, digital twin (DT) technology hosted on edge servers has become a promising solution to enhance the capabilities of IoT devices with limited computational, storage, and energy resources. This study presents a novel approach that utilizes heterogeneous graph attention (HeteroGAT) network to model interactions between user equipments (UEs) and base stations (BSs) in wireless networks, aiming to minimize task transmission delays by strategically deploying digital twins for UEs. A deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework is introduced to iteratively learn optimal DT placement strategies through gradient-based optimization of a reward function. Furthermore, a convex optimization method based on Lagrangian multipliers is employed to achieve optimal uplink bandwidth allocation, while a DRL-based strategy is designed for power allocation under downlink non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) conditions. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed DRL-based algorithm can rapidly learn effective DT placement strategies and achieves superior performance compared to traditional heuristic and benchmark methods.

title: Volatile Compound Identification of Traditional Filipino Alcoholic Beverages Through Electronic Nose with KNN Algorithm
authors: Chris B. Domingo, Ealiezerr Andrei E. Ladia, John Paul T. Cruz
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: This study presents the development of an electronic nose (E-Nose) system for the identification and classification of volatile compounds in traditional Filipino alcoholic beverages—Basi, Bignay, Lambanog, and Tapuy. The system employs a gas sensor array (MQ3, MQ6, MQ8, MQ135, and MQ136) and utilizes the K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) algorithm with Principal Component Analysis (PCA) for classification and dimensionality reduction. The experimental process consists of three phases: absorption, data acquisition, and desorption. A total of 1,125 training samples and 125 testing samples were used, evenly distributed across all classes. The model achieved an accuracy of 94%, demonstrating its effectiveness in distinguishing between the beverages. This work supports efforts in quality control, standardization, and cultural preservation of cultural Filipino-made wine through a low-cost, sensor-based solution.

title: An Efficient Collision Avoidance and Navigation Path Planning with Local Motion Planning in Autonomous Robots Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: R Mahammad Rafi, A Vasu Babu, Hayel Khafajeh, CH Srivardhan Kumar, B Rajalakshmi, B G Sivakumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: In robotics, especially in unpredictable environments, navigating and avoiding obstacles is challenging. This article introduces the ECNPLA model, which combines reinforcement learning and deep neural networks for effective robot navigation. It uses a time-series data framework that merges real-time and historical sensor inputs to predict the best navigation actions, like stopping or turning. The model relies on the Markov Decision Process (MDP) for state representation and action planning, using methods such as Q-learning and Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) for continuous improvement in complex situations. It also incorporates hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) for efficient route planning. The local motion planning uses advanced modeling to determine speed and direction to avoid obstacles. ECNPLA is shown to be better than sensor-based pre-training as it makes proactive decisions and adapts to changing conditions. The model reduces navigation errors and enhances performance, making it a reliable option for complex autonomous navigation tasks.

title: Optimal Image Resolution for Crop Growth Stage Classification Using Drone Imagery
authors: Jonggeol Park, Souichiro Toyota, JiuYun Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: This study explores the optimal image resolution for detecting crop growth stages using drone imagery and AI. Drone flights were conducted over a 2,727 m2 field in Chiba Prefecture, capturing images at various altitudes. YOLOv8 was used to classify the growth stages of cabbage, broccoli, and peanuts. Results showed that early-stage crops required higher image resolution for accurate detection, especially for cabbage and peanuts. Broccoli was detectable at lower resolutions in early stages but became difficult to distinguish as it matured. The findings suggest that the ideal resolution varies by crop type and growth stage, and adjusting drone altitude accordingly can improve detection accuracy. Future work will address labeling quality and detection challenges for later growth stages.

title: A Traffic Assignment Model on Supernetworks Considering Demand Uncertainty
authors: Siyue Zhang, Yiyong Xiao, Xinhao Cui, Bo Li
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Modelling the traffic assignment problem (TAP) is essential to capture the travelers' behaviors and predict the flow distribution in transportation networks. This problem has been extensively studied on road and highway networks. However, when multiple modes of transportation, such as cars, trains, planes, or ships, are involved, finding the optimal flow distribution becomes more complex. Different modes of transportation rely on different networks. A supernetwork is a large network that encompasses multiple sub-networks. In this paper, we define the supernetwork and then formulate the traffic assignment problem on supernetworks (TAP-SN) considering demand uncertainty as a linear programming model. The proposed model is solved using the commercial optimization toolbox CPLEX, with promising results, thus confirming the efficiency and effectiveness of the approach.

title: Delay is Better: A Proactive Flowlet Generation Approach for RDMA Load Balancing
authors: Qingyu Shi, Fangxue Jiang, Chuang Li, Xiaocui Li, Wenzhi Cao, Limei Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Modern data center networks widely deploy Remote Direct Memory Access (RDMA) technology to meet the performance requirements of applications such as distributed AI training and high performance computing. However, due to the insufficient number of flowlets in RDMA network traffic, existing load balancing techniques struggle to leverage flowlets to improve network transmission performance. Although current solutions proactively insert additional wait time in consecutive packets at the sender to generate additional flowlets in RDMA networks, these additional flowlets may choose a suboptimal path at the host side or still transmit along the original path, resulting in increased transmission delay. Therefore, this paper introduces a proactive flowlet generation approach for load balancing (DBLB) in lossless data center networks (DCNs). DBLB, implemented at source switches, leverages programmable switches to acquire multipath status and proactively generate new flowlets through delaying a small portion of packets for a certain time, where before delaying packets, DBLB ensures the delayed flow can be rerouted to the better path and achieve improved performance. Thus, DBLB enables proactive, timely, and performance-guaranteed rerouting decisions. Experimental results demonstrate that DBLB outperforms state-of-the-art methods under various workloads from real world, reducing the average and tail flow completion time by up to 57 % and 79 %, respectively.

title: A New Dynamic Adaptive Prognostics Method Based on Comprehensive Model Evaluation Criterion for Remaining Useful Life Prediction of Bearings
authors: Yingcheng Niu, Chao Wang, Biao Wang, Yong Qin
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Dynamic adaptive prognostics method is attracting increasing attention in remaining useful life (RUL) prediction of bearings, owing to selecting different models for prediction, and more accurately capturing the degradation trend. However, existing research exhibits two shortcomings: 1) Existing research constructs model sets that are difficult to comprehensively describe the complex and varied degradation processes of bearings. 2) Existing model selection criteria primarily focus on minimizing fitting error, neglecting the capture of bearing degradation trends. To address the shortcomings mentioned above, a new dynamic adaptive prognostics method based on comprehensive model evaluation criterion (CMEC) is designed for RUL prediction of bearings. Firstly, a complete model set is constructed to comprehensively describe the complex and variable degradation process, and the dynamic selection of the model more accurately captures the changes in the process of bearing degradation. On this basis, CMEC is designed for dynamic model selection, taking into account fitting error, robustness and trendability. Finally, the uncertainty evaluation and RUL prediction results are obtained by the Kalman filter (KF). To validate the effectiveness of the proposed method, trend prediction was performed on doublerow tapered roller bearings. Experimental result identifies that the proposed method better describes the process of bearing degradation.

title: Machine Learning in Economic Data Analysis
authors: Sandhya Ch V L, Tapos Ranjan Biswas, V. Noorzia Nasreen, Santhosh Y, Naveen Nandal, Nikita Vikrant Chavan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: The paper offers a viable and visually explainable model of analyzing economic data with an incorporation of KNN Imputation, LASSO, and LightGBM to form an environment that is running in Python. KNN Imputation was useful in filling missing values, making a dataset complete and satisfactory to be used in the modeling process. LASSO feature selection reduced the size of the set of predictors, promoting the computational efficiency and diminishing the danger of overfitting by keeping exclusive economic measures. LightGBM achieves high levels of forecasting accuracy versus conventional econometric models and proved to be very effective in the processing of GDP and inflation forecasting tasks. SHAP integration allowed a clear understanding of the contribution of features to model predictions facilitating the detection of the most valuable features of economic interest in addition to aligning model predictions with the economic theory. Besides powerful preprocessing, which is particularly useful in economies where categorical data become available over time, and succinct feature selection, the presented methodology involves elite gradient boosting, which could provide reasonable accuracy, good insight into the data and efficiency, and hence useful to academic studies and policymaking purposes.

title: Neuropsychology of Attention and Emotion Based on EEG Signals Using Graph Convolutional Networks and Gated Recurrent Units
authors: Firda Rahmasari, Esmeralda Contessa Djamal, Melina Melina
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Instrumentation, Control, and Automation (ICA)
abstract: In the modern marketing era, understanding consumer behavior is key because purchasing decisions are greatly influenced by how consumers respond to the products or services offered. One of the latest approaches to understanding this behavior is neuromarketing, which analyzes the brain's response to marketing stimuli such as advertisements and products. Neuromarketing is rooted in neuropsychology, the science that studies the relationship between brain activity and human behavior. With the help of Electroencephalogram (EEG) technology, brain activity can be monitored in real-time to observe cognitive variables such as attention and emotion. This study develops an EEG-based emotion and attention analysis system using Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) to handle irregular signal data structures. The process begins with signal filtering using the wavelet method, followed by spatial feature extraction using GCN, and temporal feature extraction with Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU). The results of testing the GCN method showed an accuracy of 88.40%. In the initial stage, various weight correction techniques were compared using four optimization algorithms: Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD), Adam, and AdaMax. Adamax achieved the highest accuracy at 88.40%, outperforming Adam (86.85%) and SGD (86.08%). This indicates that Adamax is capable of producing better model generalization compared to the other two optimization techniques. With an accuracy of 88.40%, the system has proven effective in identifying consumer emotions and attention, and holds potential for application in neuromarketing to objectively measure subconscious responses.

title: Job Satisfaction and Mental Health in Teaching Hospitals: A Qualitative Study Based on Herzberg’s Motivation-Hygiene Theory
authors: Cheongha Yeum, Sunghee Baek
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: This study explores the relationship between job satisfaction and mental health among healthcare professionals in teaching hospitals, based on Herzberg’s Motivation-Hygiene Theory. Utilizing a qualitative phenomenological approach, the study examines how social support and psychosocial support systems influence this relationship.In-depth interviews and focus group discussions were conducted with 25 professionals, including physicians, nurses, and medical technicians.Data were analyzed using Colaizzi’s method. Findings reveal the duality of job satisfaction between fulfillment and burnout, the fragile yet resilient nature of mental health, and the systemic role of both formal and informal support mechanisms.The study offers insights for developing effective psychosocial support systems tailored to the complex environments of teaching hospitals.

title: An Evaluation of Supervised Virtual Microphone Estimators in Reverberant Sound Fields
authors: Kimihiro Hattori, Wen-Chin Huang, Kazuya Takeda, Tomoki Toda
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This paper evaluates the generalization performance of supervised virtual microphone estimation under reverberant environments. While the previous studies have shown that virtual microphone estimators trained in reverberant time conditions can operate effectively, detailed investigations on their performance have not been conducted from various perspectives. In this paper, we clarify the generalization capability of the estimator by examining both estimation performance and its impact on array signal processing under simulated environments with different reverberation times. Furthermore, we explored strategies to improve the estimator, including different model architectures and loss functions. Experimental results show that as the reverberation time increases, the estimation performance decreases and the enhancement performance by MVDR based on steering vectors degrades significantly. Furthermore, the results suggest that enhancement performance can be improved by properly designing the model architecture and loss function.

title: Resilient Multi-Task Deep Learning for EV Infrastructure Anomaly Detection and Mitigation
authors: Oluleke Babayomi, Dong-Seong Kim
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: Electric Vehicle (EV) charging infrastructure faces increasing cybersecurity threats that can compromise operational efficiency and stability. Existing techniques are limited by poor efficiency and limited mitigation solutions. Therefore, this paper addresses these challenges by a novel resilient multi-task deep learning framework that simultaneously predicts charging demand, detects cyber-attacks, and mitigates the impact of the attack to ensure trustworthy demand prediction. The proposed framework has three key components: LSTM autoencoder for anomaly detection, interpolation-based anomalous data mitigation to preserve temporal continuity, and multi-task learning via Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks. The framework is validated on a real charging station dataset augmented with realistic anomalies including distributed denial of service and spoofing attacks cyber-anomalies. Experimental results show that our multi-task learning approach achieves superior performance compared to single-task models, with 20% improvement in volume prediction accuracy and 28.3% faster training time. Also, the integrated cyber-attack mitigation method produced trust-worthy datasets that enhance prediction reliability with 8.3%, 4.8% and 4.4% improvements in MSE, MAE and R2 metrics. The proposed architecture enables enhanced EV infrastructure planning, management, cybersecurity, response and recovery from malicious threats.

title: Prediction of Lithium-Ion Battery Health Degradation across Operating Conditions Based on Gaussian Process Regression with Composite Kernel Function
authors: Boming Chen, Cong Wang, Jiawei Zheng, Yunxia Chen
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: To predict the state of health (SOH) degradation of lithium-ion batteries across operating conditions, this study proposes a novel Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) model with a composite kernel function. The model innovatively uses the area defined by the charging current curve as the input for prediction, which reduces the input dimensionality and model complexity compared with directly inputting the operating condition parameters. A weighted combination of the Squared Exponential (SE) kernel and the Matern <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3} / \mathbf{2}$</tex> (M32) kernel is employed to effectively capture the unique characteristics of the area, facilitating the construction of the nonlinear mapping between operating conditions and SOH degradation. Evaluated through leave-one-out cross-validation, the model achieves an overall mean absolute error (MAE) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 9 4 \%}$</tex>, enabling precise predictions of lithium-ion battery SOH degradation. Compared with direct operating condition inputs, the area-based approach simplifies the input parameters and the MAE for individual cells was reduced by nearly 1 % at most among all batteries. Furthermore, compared to single-kernel, the model with the composite kernel demonstrates an MAE reduction of up to 5 % at most for individual cells among all batteries, indicating a significant improvement. This study offers a feasible technical approach for predicting lithium-ion battery degradation across diverse operating conditions.

title: Generative Information Debiasing and Multi-Task Optimization for Fake News Detection
authors: Qingqing Li, Ke Ji, Yuan Gao, Yongxin Yu, Kun Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Most current fake news detection models rely on news content from a single perspective to judge authenticity, ignoring the important role of multi-view information of the news environment in which the news event is located in identifying fake news. At the same time, in the current multi-task model of joint stance analysis, since the tasks are artificially separated, the complementary information between tasks cannot be fully utilized, resulting in insufficient feature interaction between tasks. Therefore, We propose a fake news detection method based on generative information debiasing and multi-task optimization. First, we collect news reports from various perspectives for each event through multi-source platforms such as Weibo and NetEase News. Subsequently, we employ generative language models to reconstruct the multi-source news, generating supplementary text that integrates multiple perspectives. Secondly, the comment features are filtered through the partition filtering network, enabling each task to adaptively filter the key information within the shared features, thereby effectively promoting feature interaction between tasks. Experimental results demonstrate that, compared with existing popular methods, the detection model proposed in this study exhibits superior performance.

title: Waste Management System Using Deep Learning
authors: L. Sai Ramesh, Jerophin D R, Keshav S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Because of inefficient sorting and manual operations, waste management is a prominent issue in both environmental and operational terms. In this paper, an artificial intelligence (AI)-based waste management system based on deep learning with a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model is introduced that classifies waste automatically as non-bio-degradable or biodegradable. The accuracy of the model classification was 97%, which was better than that of conventional systems both in accuracy and speed. The system is software-based, completely scaleable, and provides real-time classification using uploaded images or live webcam feed. The system also possesses the feature of underwater classification of waste where video is processed frame by frame to detect and classify submerged waste objects. This feature broadens the application of the system to ocean and waterbody waste monitoring. The system also provides operational intelligence with inbuilt dashboards and provides cloud reporting using Google APIs. This research adds to sustainable waste management practices and enables innovative opportunities for smart city infrastructure and conservation.

title: Portable EEG Device with Real-Time Seizure Detection
authors: R. S. Roshni, A. Sabarivani, M. Kavyaalagi, Pushpa Narayan Sharma, V. S. Inbhavanan, Devanshi Srivastava
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: This study introduces a smart and caring seizure detection system designed to protect and support people living with epilepsy. It gently keeps a track of vital signs such as brain activity, body movement, and even changes in sweating using connected sensors powered by Internet of Things technology. With the help of Arduino and NodeMCU, the system processes this data and sends it to the ThingSpeak cloud, where everything can be monitored in real-time. If the system senses signs of a possible seizure, it immediately alerts caregivers or medical professionals, ensuring that help can reach the person right away. Beyond just alerts, it also stores the collected data for future analysis. This helps doctors identify patterns, make informed decisions, and offer better, more personalized care. Simple, portable, and dependable, this system acts like a quiet companion, always watching over the user and helping manage seizures with love and intelligence.

title: Optimizing JPEG Decoder for Bitstream-Corrupted Image Restoration
authors: Shumin Jiang, Hao Qin, Tianyi Liu, Yi Wang
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This paper proposes an image restoration method based on an optimized JPEG decoder, aiming to address the issue of image bitstream corruption. As a fundamental form of image signals, bitstreams are often damaged by various factors (e.g., wireless channel fading, medium aging, and noise interference), resulting in bit flips that severely degrade image quality. Existing image restoration methods mostly focus on the pixel domain, making it difficult to effectively address structural errors caused by bitstream corruption. To better address this challenge, we propose an optimized JPEG decoder that incorporates compressed sensing techniques to restore and reconstruct the image in the image block-level domain. Our approach can more effectively restore the structural damage of an image, rather than being limited to traditional pixel-level restoration. To evaluate the effectiveness of the method, we simulate bit flips on two sets of real images and construct a bitstream-corrupted image dataset that simulates real-world environments. Under different bit error rates (BER), our method (SCA-CS) outperforms the state-of-the-art (SCA) method in repairing image block colors and eliminating block shift problems.

title: Integrating Exploration into Case-Based Reasoning: A Strategy for Enhanced Knowledge Acquisition
authors: Fateh Boulmaiz, Patrick Reignier, Stephane Ploix
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: We introduce a method to enhance problem-solving capabilities in case-based reasoning recommender systems, addressing the limitations of existing techniques that rely solely on the system’s pre-existing knowledge. Our approach explores the solution space with the primary objective of uncovering new insights that enhance future system performance, rather than immediately identifying an optimal solution. To accelerate this knowledge discovery, the exploration is guided by a heuristic that strategically focuses on less-explored yet promising areas of the solution space, avoiding the inefficiencies of random search. The method was empirically evaluated in the context of energy consumption optimization in buildings. Experimental results demonstrate its potential to significantly enhance system performance.

title: Performance Evaluation of Decision Tree, Random Forest, and XGBoost for Predicting Cycle Life in MOF-Based Battery Electrodes
authors: C. Ramesh Kumar, R. Dilli Babu, A. Prasad, R. Nandhakumar, G B Santhi, Lavanya M
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: This work introduces a machine learning-based method that uses the Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), Random Forest (RF), and Decision Tree (DT) algorithms to forecast the cycle life of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). Each model was trained to estimate the cycle life based on key input parameters that were gathered from the trial data. The models were assessed and contrasted using performance indicators such as RMSE, MAE, and R2 Score. With the lowest RMSE (91.25) and MAE (36.85) and the highest R2 (80.73%), DT performed the best. When compared to DT, RF, and XGBoost produced larger error rates but moderate prediction accuracies. The models shed light on how electrolyte factors affect cycle life. The identification of dominant contributing elements was aided by feature significance analysis. This study shows how AI techniques can speed up the prediction of material performance. The results can help improve MOF-based energy systems' synthesis and operating conditions. All things considered, the DT model is suggested for accurate cycle life prediction in MOF material.

title: Quasi-Axisymmetric Stellarator at nT-Tao Ltd
authors: Itay Gissis, Yoav Shoshani, Nadav Snir, Yasha Nikulshin
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
