abstract: nT-Tao Ltd. is developing a compact-core fusion concept that targets fusion-relevant conditions in a toroidally confined D-T plasma at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$T \sim 10, \text{keV}, n \sim 10^{22}, \mathbf{m}^{-3}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\tau_{E} \sim 10$</tex>'s of ms. The confinement scheme employs quasisymmetric stellarator topology. The small chamber size enables direct inductive coupling from surrounding coils, providing the high input power required for plasma heating. The current prototype, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{C}-2 \mathrm{A}$</tex>, is a compact, quasi-axisymmetric stellarator, with major radius <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R=0.7 \mathbf{m}$</tex> and minor radius <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$a \sim 30$</tex> mm. Its magnetic field is generated by optimized toroidal and helical coil sets. Time-resolved diagnostics verified the designed magnetic topology. Plasma initiation is achieved via RF heating, with further heating supplied by pulsed-power and solid-state electronic generators. These first experiments demonstrate the feasibility of combining stellarator confinement with pulsed, highpower plasma heating in a compact device.

title: Multicycle Tests with Compressed Primary Input Sequences and an Extended Primary Input Scan Chain
authors: Irith Pomeranz
publish: ACM Transactions on Design Automation of Electronic Systems
abstract: Test data compression supports reductions in test data volume and test application time. The use of multicycle scan-based tests with several functional capture cycles between scan operations supports test compaction beyond that possible with single-cycle or two-cycle tests. Multicycle tests with constant primary input sequences are used for avoiding the need to synchronize the primary input sequence with the functional clock. However, this prevents the detection of delay faults in the output cone of the primary inputs. A different solution is to produce the primary input sequence of a multicycle test by the on-chip decompression logic in addition to the scan-in state. This approach is considered in this article. The key new contribution of the article is to extend the scan chain that drives the primary inputs, and add design-for-testability (DFT) logic, to ensure that the primary input sequences produced by the decompression logic are suitable for the application of multicycle tests. Experimental results for transition faults in benchmark circuits demonstrate significant fault coverage improvements and significant test compaction.

title: DRUMS: Drummer Reconstruction Using Midi Sequences
authors: Theodoros Kyriakou, Panayiotis Charalambous, Andreas Aristidou
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 18th ACM SIGGRAPH Conference on Motion, Interaction, and Games
abstract: We present a system for generating expressive, full-body drumming performances from MIDI input, combining rhythmic precision with lifelike motion. Unlike prior work that focuses on limited gestures or audio-driven models, our approach produces coordinated animations of the entire performer, including hands, torso, legs, and facial expressions, driven solely by symbolic MIDI. Our system integrates a Bi-directional LSTM to predict fine-grained 3D hand trajectories, using sticks parented to the hands and synchronized with MIDI events. It also includes a retrieval-based module that generates expressive upper-body and facial motion conditioned on musical phrasing, and a pedal enforcement component that procedurally animates the feet. Our method addresses the unique challenges of drumming, where rhythm is both heard and seen in dynamic, physically grounded motion. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first system to generate full-body drum performances from raw MIDI. Our approach enables new applications in virtual concerts, immersive training, game animation, and digital avatar performance.

title: A Multimodal Ant Colony Optimization Framework for Multi-Solution Traveling Salesman Problem
authors: Han-Yang Pan, Ming Li, Qiang Yang, Wei-Neng Chen, Ya-Hui Jia, Jian-Yu Li, Dan-Ting Duan, Dong Liu, Jun Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Evolutionary Computation
abstract: This paper devises a multimodal ant colony optimization (MACO) framework to solve multi-solution traveling salesman problems (MSTSPs), which aim to find multiple optimal routes in a single run. Specifically, a dynamic niching strategy is designed to partition the ant colony into exclusive niches based on the route similarity measured by the common edges between two routes. Subsequently, MACO maintains a pheromone matrix for each niche and lets the ants in each niche construct their routes independently based on the associated pheromone matrix. For effective pheromone update, this paper designs a niche and pheromone matrix association rule to match each newly partitioned niche with one pheromone matrix. To further improve optimization efficiency, this paper designs a dynamic critical edge strategy to dig out critical edges during the optimization. Then, these critical edges are cooperated with 2-opt to refine the route constructed by each ant. To preserve the found optimal routes, this paper devises an optimal route preservation strategy to store as many different high-quality routes as possible. Lastly, we instantiate MACO with four canonical ACOs, namely Ant System(AS), Elite AS(EAS), Rank-based AS(ASRank), and Max-Min AS(MMAS), and then conduct extensive experiments to compare them with six state-of-the-art algorithms on the only one MSTSP benchmark suite and the TSPLIB instances. The experimental results reveal that the four MACOs perform competitively with one latest algorithm, but significantly outperform the other five comparison algorithms. Further analysis discovers that ASRank is the most effective one among the four ACOs to cooperate with MACO in solving MSTSPs.

title: Capacitor Unit 50 kV, 30 kJ of Capacitive Energy Storage
authors: R. S. Enikeev, B. E. Fridman, A. V. Korkunov, K. S. Sapozhnikov, P. V. Tomashevich, A. V. Vasiliev, D. V. Bochkov, V. D. Bochkov, S. V. Korotkov
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: A capacitor unit is intended to operate in a large capacitive energy storage. The capacitor unit is connected to load through a cable line at least 20 m long. The rise time of the discharge current to its maximum value in short-circuit conditions shall not exceed <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 \mu \mathrm{s}$</tex>, and the time of voltage front at the cable line output in the no-load conditions is no more than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0,1 \mu \mathrm{s}$</tex>. The unit generates a current pulse at the positive or negative polarity of capacitor charge voltage. The unit involves two capacitors of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$50 \text{kV}, 12 \mu \mathrm{F}$</tex> and a discharge current switch - pseudo-spark gap (thyratron).

title: The Gas Production Characteristics and Mechanism of Mineral Transformer Oil Decomposition Under Spark Discharge in Liquid Phase
authors: H. Wang, Y. Xu, L. Dou, C. Zhang, T. Shao
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The gas production characteristics and the mechanism of mineral transformer oil is important for insulation monitoring of transformer and heavy oil high value conversion. However, the decomposition characteristics and mechanism of mineral transformer oil under repetitive pulse discharge in liquid phase are still unclear in terms of the gaseous production pathways. In this work, the decomposition process of mineral transformer oil under repetitively pulsed discharge are characterized by gas chromatography (GC) and optical emission spectroscopy (OES). Besides, the cracking mechanisms and gas production pathways are deduced by the molecular dynamics and plasma kinetics simulation. The GC experiments show that the proportion of H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> decreases and that of C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> increases with the increase of the repetition frequency and prolonged reaction time. The OES results show that the electron density of the discharge decreases with the increase of the repetition frequency. The simulation results agree with the experiments and identify a continuous dehydrogenation process involving H radical reactions with C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf> and C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> as the primary pathway for C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> production. Despite of lower injected energy per discharge, the accumulated effect of repetitive discharge in liquid phase is the main reason for the continuous dehydrogenation of the mineral transformer oil. The work provides the feasibility to control the C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> gas production proportion in the repetitive discharges.

title: Relaying Pulsed Magnetrons for Continuous Wave (CW) Operation in Fusion Plasma Heating
authors: J. Zhang, X. Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Nuclear fusion is considered as an ultimate solution to clean and sustainable energy sources due to its abundant fuel supply, high power output, and zero emissions. However, nuclear fusion requires extreme high temperatures, typically enabled by millimetre-wave (mm-wave) sources like gyrotrons, which generate 1 MW continuous wave (CW) power. Unfortunately, gyrotrons are bulky, complex, costly, and have a low production yield (only 15 units worldwide), hindering fusion's commercial viability. To address this issue, we propose using magnetrons as mm-wave sources for a high efficient alternative to gyrotrons. While CW operation is needed for plasma heating, high-power mm-wave magnetrons currently function only in a pulsed mode.

title: Flow Field Distribution in Corona and Spark Discharge Visualized by Schlieren Technique
authors: L. Li, M. Zhang, Y. Chen, X. Pei
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The schlieren technique is a common technique for visualizing gas flows, fundamentally based on the principle that the refractive index gradient in the flow field under investigation is directly proportional to the gas density of the flow field. In this research, the schlieren method was employed to conduct a detailed examination of the flow field characteristics of needle-to-needle electrode discharges, with a particular focus on the corona discharge and spark discharge patterns under both horizontal and inclined needle-to-needle electrode configurations. The experimental results demonstrate that the ionic wind induced by corona discharge can effectively guide the development of the spark channel. Under the horizontal needle electrode configuration, the ionic wind maintains a high degree of consistency between the spark channel trajectory and the ionic wind streamlines through the synergistic effects of momentum transfer and spatial charge redistribution; whereas under the inclined needle electrode configuration, the degree of channel coincidence is influenced by the curvature radius of the needle tip, with a smaller curvature radius enhancing the guiding effect of the ionic wind. This research highlights the intrinsic connection between corona discharge and spark discharge, confirming the pivotal role of ionic wind in influencing the morphology of discharge channels, and provides insights for future applications of plasma and electrostatic technologies.

title: The Temporal Evolution of the Voltage and Current on the Load of the SNU X-Pinch Device with the Optics-Based Diagnostics
authors: S. Choi, Y. Choi, S. Bong, K.-J. Chung, Y.S. Hwang, Y.-C. Ghim
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The X-pinch device generates a focused current pulse through thin metal wires arranged in a cross configuration, serving as the load. During the pulse, the wires are transformed into plasma, and subsequently form a local Z-pinch configuration at the crossing point due to the interaction between the flowing current and the self-induced magnetic field. The evolving plasma alters the impedance of the load, making the temporal measurement of voltage and current critical for understanding the transition of the pinch plasma. Recently, optics-based measurement systems, utilizing the Pockels effect for voltage and Faraday rotation for current, have been developed and integrated into an X-pinch device [Seongmin Choi, et al., Rev. Sci. Instrum. 95, 073531 (2024)]. These systems offer the significant advantage of positioning sensors close to the load, enabling measurements directly on the load. We present the measured temporal evolution of voltage and current on the load using the optics-based measurement system. Then, we discuss the results with a circuit model providing insights into the physical phenomena including the phase transition of the wires and the plasma expansion dynamics.

title: Cybersecurity Analysis and Detection of Advanced Cyber Threats
authors: John Junghwan Rhee
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: The frequency and sophistication of cybersecurity attacks targeting critical infrastructure, businesses, educational institutions, and government agencies continue to grow each year. Many of these attacks, such as ransomware and data breaches, are carefully orchestrated to remain stealthy and undetected over extended periods. These characteristics make detection and prevention particularly challenging, as malicious behavior is often obscured by legitimate system activity.In this talk, Dr. Rhee will present a series of research projects focused on system-wide monitoring, behavioral analysis, and advanced threat detection. His work explores data-driven methods that trace causal chains of complex attack behaviors, as well as approaches that leverage domain knowledge of operating systems to identify anomalous states indicative of cyber threats. The talk will conclude with an overview of new cybersecurity programs being developed at the University of Central Oklahoma, which aim to provide students with practical, hands-on experience and foundational skills in cybersecurity.

title: Updated Electrical Design of the Diagnostic Neutral Beam Injector in RFX-Mod2
authors: M. Barbisan, B. Laterza, L. Cinnirella, L. Marrelli, F. Molon, S. Peruzzo, E. Zampiva
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The Diagnostic Neutral Beam Injector of the RFX-mod2 experiment (Consorzio RFX, Padova) is expected to provide novel and significant information about the Reversed Field Pinch confinement of fusion plasmas. The injection of the hydrogen beam in the plasma will allow Charge Exchange Recombination Spectroscopy (CXRS) and Motional Stark Effect diagnostics (MSE) to measure several quantities: ion speed, ion temperature, impurity content, intensity and pitch of the magnetic field. The DNBI is of particular importance for allowing the determination of these quantities at the core of the plasma.

title: Performance of the Refurbished Saturn Radiation Source at Sandia National Laboratories
authors: M. Savage, B. Hutsel, B. Ulmen, P. Das, S. Feathers, M. Fromer, D. Lucero, A. Nash, R. Puckett, J. Tunell
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: We have completed a significant upgrade to the Saturn system at Sandia National Laboratories with the goal of improving the repeatability of radiation output, while reducing the time and labor required for each test. The Saturn system is a pulsed high-brightness source of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 1.5 \text{MeV}$</tex> endpoint X-rays used for testing the response of material, components, and systems to intense radiation pulses. The system nominally stores 5 MJ total and consists of thirty-six identical modules, each with a microsecond Marx generator and a water-insulated pulse compression system. Energy from the modules is combined in the water near the water-vacuum interface into three balanced power feeds. For a more uniform spatial distribution of the radiation and lower inductance, the three balanced feeds drive three electrically isolated coplanar and concentric annular pinch Bremsstrahlung diode loads. The peak total forward-going power from the pulseforming system is 25 TW. The peak total power dissipated in the load is 15 TW. Total load current at the time of peak load power is generally 9 MA. The upgrades to Saturn include redesigned magnetically insulated transmission lines, a redesigned water-vacuum interface with current and voltage monitors on the anode (ground) side of each of the six feeds, and replacement of the 3 MV pulse-charged, electrically triggered gas switches. The impedance of the Bremsstrahlung loads collapses with a time constant of order 20 ns. For that reason, minimizing the time spread between modules and maximizing electrical power is important for effective energy coupling to the load. We will show the changes to the system and describe process changes intended to improve the reproducibility of the radiation output.

title: Study on the Self-Breakdown Characteristics of Gas Switches with SiC-Modified Graphite Electrodes
authors: M. Zhang, H. Zhang, X. Qiu, R. Li, Y. Hua
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: As a key device of the pulsed power drive source, the operating characteristics of the high-power gas switch largely determine the application capability of the system. In this paper, a technique to enhance the breakdown stability of graphite electrodes by SiC modification is proposed. The SiC modified layer is generated on the surface of graphite substrate by vapor deposition, and the micro-morphology and construction quality of the modified layer are characterized by scanning electron microscope and energy spectrometer. A high-voltage pulse gas switch test platform was established. The breakdown characteristics of the modified graphite electrode gas switch under the action of millisecond pulse voltage and uniform electric field were investigated experimentally. The regular understanding of the breakdown voltage amplitude and dispersion of this switch is obtained. The results show that under the operating conditions of 0.15 MPa N2 and 5 mm electrode spacing, the graphite electrode switch has an average breakdown voltage of 33.69 kV with a relative standard deviation of 4.50%, and the SiC modified electrode switch has an average breakdown voltage of 36.62 kV with a relative standard deviation of 2.15%. Utilizing the advantage of dense and uniform coating of the modified layer, the electrode breakdown location is more concentrated, which improves the switch breakdown characteristics and reduces the breakdown voltage jitter. Meanwhile, the good mechanical properties of the modified layer also solved the problem of graphite electrode particle shedding and effectively reduced the erosion products.

title: An Improved Rotor Topology of High-Speed Synchronous Reluctance Motor for Torque Capability Enhancement
authors: Jian-Xin Shen, Wen-Jie Wan, Ze-Cheng Li, Xue-Fei Qin, Shun Cai, Yunchong Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications
abstract: This paper presents an improved rotor topology aiming at torque enhancement for high-speed synchronous reluctance motors (SynRMs). Conventional high-speed SynRM rotor requires both tangential and radial ribs for mechanical integrity. However, the ribs increase flux leakage and reduce rotor saliency, consequently deteriorate the torque density. Ribless designs with extra connecting structures have been proposed, which come with high manufacturing and assembly cost. In the proposed structure, symmetrical inner ribs are employed to maintain rotor robustness without the need for additional structures. Moreover, tangential ribs are cut off with the design of asymmetric rotor island tips to improve rotor saliency ratio and reduce torque ripple. Sensitivity analysis of design parameters is performed for staged optimization of the proposed machine. Analysis results demonstrate that the proposed rotor topology delivers higher torque compared to the conventional design while maintaining similar maximum rotor stress. Finally, static and load experiments are conducted, validating the superiority of the proposed rotor topology.

title: DINCoDE: A Data Interpolation Network with a Collaborative Dual Encoder for Reconstructing Missing Sea Surface Temperature Data
authors: Xin Yang, Donglin Fan, Wenhan Hu, Hongchang He, Bolin Fu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Sea surface temperature (SST) data derived from infrared satellites are frequently missing due to cloud cover. To address this challenge, we propose a novel interpolation model, the Data Interpolation Network with a Collaborative Dual Encoder (DINCoDE). The model adopts a hybrid dual-encoder architecture that integrates a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and a Transformer encoder, enabling the joint extraction of local and global spatiotemporal features. A composite loss function is employed to ensure both pixel-level accuracy and structural fidelity in the reconstructed data. Experimental results on the OSTIA SST dataset (N=6,575) demonstrate that DINCoDE outperforms the DINCAE and DINEOF models across all evaluation metrics (RMSE = 0.25°C, MAE = 0.16°C, R² = 0.99, SSIM = 0.99) and generates more physically realistic spatial gradient fields. Notably, the pre-trained model demonstrated robust performance when applied to the Advanced Himawari Imager (AHI) SST dataset (RMSE = 0.38°C, MAE = 0.27°C, R² = 0.99), highlighting its strong generalization ability and potential for operational deployment. Moreover, our analysis reveals that the intrinsic spatial complexity and variability of the SST field are key factors influencing reconstruction performance. DINCoDE offers a high-accuracy, robust, and generalizable method for reconstructing SST data gaps caused by cloud occlusion, providing a reliable solution for SST data reconstruction tasks in oceanographic applications.

title: Intelligent detection of turbulence dissipation rates from radar wind profiler by Machine Learning Algorithms
authors: Boming Liu, Jianping Guo, Xin Ma, Deli Meng, Zhe Tong, Yingying Ma, Wei Gong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: The accurate estimation of atmospheric turbulence dissipation rate (ε) is crucial for better characterizing the atmospheric physical processes and understanding the boundary layer structure. Nevertheless, the ε derived from the traditional spectral width method (SWM) tends to be overestimated using the radar wind profiler (RWP) measurements, due to the non-turbulent broadening effects. To tackle this challenge, here we propose a novel intelligent algorithm that combines SWM and Random Forest (SWM-RF) to estimate ε. The experimental data were synchronized observations from RWP and meteorological tower at the Boulder Atmospheric Observatory site from March to April 2015. Firstly, a systematic analysis was conducted on the overestimation of the SWM under different turbulence intensity, time, and height scenarios. The SWM-RF model is then constructed by introducing the difference function as a physical constraint and combining multiple observation parameters of RWP. The determination coefficient of the ε between sonic anemometers and SWM-RF reached 0.59, and the mean absolute error is 0.007 m² s⁻³. The comparison of results with sonic anemometers under different times and height indicates that SWM-RF model is superior to the SWM and is not affected by variations in height and time. Results shows that the overestimation of SWM is reduced under strong turbulence conditions, while the correction effect is poor in weak turbulence scenarios. Finally, the semi-diurnal cycles of ε for March and April in 2015 are analyzed. The accurate intelligent detection of ε profiles will lay a solid foundation for advancing the understanding of atmospheric physical processes and improving turbulence parameterization.

title: Enhancing Algorithm Comprehension for Visually Impaired Individuals with LLM-Based Programming Code Segmentation
authors: Naoki Takamatsu, Eiji Kamioka, Chanh Minh Tran, Phan Xuan Tan
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The concept of inclusive education increasingly focuses on providing appropriate support for diverse learners, including visually impaired individuals (VIs) who encounter notable difficulties in programming education. Unlike sighted learners who can visually grasp code structure at a glance, VIs depend on screen readers that present code linearly, hindering their ability to comprehend program flow and increasing cognitive load. This study proposes a method that leverages Large Language Model (LLM) to automatically segment the source code into semantically coherent sections along with their corresponding explanatory descriptions. These descriptions are embedded in a screen-reader-compatible block-based programming interface, designed to enhance non-visual code comprehension by providing structured, high-level guidance. An experimental study was conducted with 20 sighted participants blindfolded to simulate non-visual interaction. Participants completed programming tasks using two systems: one with LLM-generated segmentation and one without. The results demonstrate that the segmented system significantly improved task success rates and reduced completion times by over 50% in the most complex task. Additionally, subjective evaluations indicated enhanced usability and comprehension. These findings highlight the potential of LLM-based code segmentation to improve programming accessibility for VIs. Future work includes testing on complex codebases, adding contextual aids, enhancing segmentation flexibility, and conducting broader longitudinal evaluations.

title: An Efficient Lattice-based Verifiable Public-key Authenticated Encryption with Keyword Search Scheme
authors: Saba Karimani, Taraneh Eghlidos
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Searchable encryption enables efficient retrieval of encrypted data stored in cloud environments while preserving data confidentiality. Within this context, Public Key Encryption with Keyword Search (PEKS) allows data users to perform keyword-based searches using their public-private key pairs. However, traditional PEKS schemes remain vulnerable to Inside Keyword Guessing Attacks (IKGA), which led to the introduction of the Public-Key Authenticated Encryption with Keyword Search (PAEKS) paradigm to enhance resilience against insider threats. Despite this advancement, most existing PAEKS schemes rely on number-theoretic assumptions, such as the discrete logarithm problem, thereby becoming insecure in the presence of against quantum adversaries. Consequently, recent research has focused on developing quantum-resistant, lattice-based PAEKS schemes. Although schemes based on the Learning with Errors (LWE) problem provide strong post-quantum security, they often incur high computational and communication costs, limiting their practicality in large-scale cloud environments. To overcome these limitations, this work presents an efficient and verifiable PAEKS scheme based on the Middle-Product LWE (MP-LWE) problem, which preserves the underlying security guarantees while significantly improving performance. Formal security analysis demonstrates resistance against Chosen Keyword Attack (CKA) and IKGA in the random oracle (RO) model. Experimental results confirm that the proposed scheme achieves substantially lower computational and communication overheads compared to existing schemes, while maintaining robust post-quantum security.

title: Reinforced Dual-Flow Neural Network for Tabular Data Classification with Dynamical Transformer and Fuzzy Clustering
authors: Ce Gao, Sung-Kwun Oh, Hao Huang, Zunwei Fu, Witold Pedrycz, Jin Hee Yoon
publish: IEEE Transactions on Fuzzy Systems
abstract: A novel reinforced dual-flow neural network based on attention and a polynomial-based radial basis function network (DFBTP) is proposed to enhance classification performance on tabular data. DFBTP consists of two types of architectures such as advanced Transformer model based on Tabular Prior data Fitted Network (TabPFN) and SV-clustering driven radial basis function neural network (SV-PRBFNN). The conventional PRBFNN model may encounter local minima and noise issues during training, which negatively impacts its performance. Local minima result from initial parameter choices, and noise issues are inherent in the dataset. By introducing the Transformer model and the Whale Optimization Algorithm (WOA), these challenges can be mitigated. Within the dual-flow architecture, the attention flow is trained using Bayesian inference capabilities and structural causal models, and it uses the self-attention mechanism to capture global features. This approach mitigates the problem of local minima. SV-PRBFNN flow uses the fuzzy clustering algorithm based on support vectors to replace the original radial basis function for training. Fuzzy clustering based on support vectors can alleviate the negative impact of outliers on model performance and also reduce the number of fuzzy rules. During neural network hyperparameter optimization, WOA is used to identify the global optimal values for hyperparameters. In the experiments, DFBTP demonstrated its superiority in classification accuracy in comparative experiments on 18 datasets and 13 models, and also performed well on real-world datasets. The robust performance of DFBTP was further validated through statistical analysis of the experimental results.

title: NunChuck: A Two-Phase Chained BFT Protocol for Tolerating the Partitioning Attack
authors: Huimei Liao, Haixia Xu, Mingsheng Wang, Jinling Tang, Siyuan Leng, Chunying Peng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Popular chained Byzantine Fault Tolerant (BFT) consensus protocols adopt a pipelined paradigm to achieve efficiency. However, these protocols remain vulnerable to critical attacks, such as forking and partitioning. While the two-phase commit rule can prevent forking, it often requires complex or expensive view-change mechanisms. Moreover, our study confirms that partitioning attacks are feasible in many existing chained BFT protocols. This paper devised NunChuck, a fully two-phase chained BFT protocol that ensures linear authenticator complexity, optimistic responsiveness, and resilience to partitioning attacks. NunChuck employs a lightweight certificate-based view-change mechanism to maintain efficiency, and introduces a unified message structure that enables leaders to make progress even under partitioned network conditions. We formally prove its safety and liveness properties. Furthermore, we develop a prototype implementation in Golang and conduct extensive evaluations. The results demonstrate that NunChuck consistently outperforms HotStuff and FastHotStuff, particularly in adversarial environments, with simulated delay analysis further corroborating our experimental findings.

title: A Comparative Analysis of Topic Reduction Techniques for BERTopic
authors: Wannes Janssens, Matthias Bogaert, Dirk Van Den Poel
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: BERTopic is a state-of-the-art topic modeling framework that generates topics by clustering contextualized document embeddings. However, its default clustering algorithm, HDBSCAN, often generates an excessive number of topics, which hinders meaningful comparisons or applications in downstream tasks. While different topic reduction methods exist, literature lacks a comparison of these methods and their impact on the quality of the reduced topics. This study offers an in-depth exploration of (1) topic reduction methods for BERTopic, including existing approaches for direct or indirect reduction, and (2) novel techniques that leverage large language models (LLMs), either by using the LLM-generated topic labels to create topic embeddings or by directly prompting the model for identifying overlapping topics. A comparative study of these topic reduction methods is performed, evaluating their performance in terms of coherence and diversity across multiple social media and web datasets. Our findings indicate that indirect topic reduction (e.g., agglomerative clustering) yields more diverse topics, though sometimes at the cost of coherence, compared to direct topic reduction (increasing the minimum cluster size). LLM prompting outperforms agglomerative clustering in both coherence and diversity, though at a higher computational cost. Therefore, we recommend selecting a reduction method based on dataset characteristics, computational resources, and the desired balance between diversity and coherence.

title: Tensorized Non-Negative Multi-Attribute Subspace Clustering_supp1-3634722.pdf
authors: Guoxu Zhou
publish: N/A
abstract: Subspace clustering has been successful in unsupervised learning by revealing low-dimensional structures in high-dimensional data. However, most existing subspace clustering methods rely on a single self-expressive learning process and neglect the multi-attribute information inherent in real-world data. Moreover, traditional subspace clustering often fails to capture the spatial structure of the data, leading to a loss of important attribute information. To address these issues, we propose a novel approach called Tensorized Non-negative Multi-Attribute Subspace Clustering (TNMSC), which preserves both the spatial structure and the multi-attribute information of the original data. Specifically, TNMSC uses a multi-attribute learning framework to construct separate affinity representations for each attribute, while imposing non-negativity constraints to capture more interpretable and richer features. To further retain spatial information, we introduce a tensor decomposition-based representation that directly operates on the high-order (tensor) form of the data instead of flattened vectors, making our approach particularly advantageous for multidimensional image data. Finally, TNMSC explores consistent topological correlation across different attributes to learn a refined consensus affinity representation that integrates all attribute information. Extensive experiments on seven real-world datasets demonstrate that TNMSC outperforms state-of-the-art methods. For instance, on the COIL20 dataset, our method achieves a clustering accuracy of 83.71%, surpassing the second-best approach by a significant margin of 5.86%.

title: PF-eBPF: In-Kernel Packet-Flow Feature Inference for Real-Time Network Intrusion Detection
authors: Yuqi Zhang, Xuefei Chen, Chen Li, Bibo Tu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: With the emergence of serverless computing and AI training, public cloud platforms have experienced rapid development. Real-time intrusion detection, which allows for proactive defense before network functionality and performance are affected, has become an effective means of securing public cloud environments. eBPF mitigates the overhead associated with real-time network data capture, offering an efficient mechanism for offloading intrusion detection and prevention tasks. However, existing methods still require waiting for the completion of the current flow before initiating detection, rendering it impossible to classify all packets within that flow. This limitation becomes especially critical when dealing with long-lived flows or persistent connections, where existing eBPF-based real-time detection solutions fail to provide defense before the network is impacted. To achieve detection for all packets within network flows, we propose PF-eBPF-an in-kernel solution for fast realtime detection. PF-eBPF employs a classification model that combines both packet-level and flow-level features, while overcoming inherent constraints of eBPF programs including instruction and stack limitations in real-time scenarios. Our method performs packet-level feature inference and packetflow joint inference on the early packets of the flow, without the need to wait for the flow to complete. Evaluations demonstrate that our solution achieves rapid detection for all packets while maintaining model performance and memory overhead comparable to the current state-of-the-art eBPFbased solutions.

title: An Unsupervised TinyML Approach with Efficient Edge AI for Effective Stress and Sleep Monitoring
authors: M Sudha, P.Neelaveni, E Pooja, V Mangaiyarkarasi, Rowsonara Begum, J. Jayanthi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: The creation of embedded technologies for detecting stress and categorizing sleep stages has been prompted by the need for monitoring health in real time. The UTMESS model combines data from various sensors, deep learning, and AI to monitor health using affordable devices. It improves the representation of features for accurate modeling of physiological states by collecting data from inertial measurement units and heart rate variability to create 12-channel tensors. The proposed model uses transfer learning with MobileNetV2 for health classification and an LSTM autoencoder for the effective monitoring of stress and sleep process. It is optimized for embedded devices through pruning and feature engineering. When run on the ESP32S3 microcontroller, UTMESS achieves 98.5% accuracy in the simulation demonstration which effectively distinguishes stress levels according to the given data, aligns well with known sleep stages, uses low energy, and performs excellently.

title: A Comparative Analysis of Federated Learning Algorithms for Healthcare: Strengths, Limitations, and Practical Recommendations
authors: Sheikh Sharfuddin Mim, Doina Logofatu, Gabriel Guerrero-Contreras, Inmaculada Medina-Bulo
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: Federated learning (FL) offers a promising framework for collaboratively training machine learning models across distributed healthcare institutions without exposing sensitive patient data. This decentralized approach aligns well with privacy regulations such as HIPAA and GDPR and addresses challenges posed by siloed electronic health records (EHRs), medical imaging archives, and genomic data. Despite its growing relevance, FL remains difficult to deploy effectively in healthcare due to data heterogeneity, resource imbalance, and privacy constraints. This paper presents a comprehensive comparative analysis of five key FL algorithms—FedAvg, FedProx, SCAFFOLD, FedBN, and pFedMe—evaluated across structured data, imaging, and segmentation tasks using MIMIC-III, MedMNIST, and BraTS datasets. We assess these algorithms in terms of predictive performance, convergence speed, fairness, communication efficiency, and robustness under non-IID settings. Experiments simulate realistic healthcare conditions, including client dropouts, bandwidth constraints, and system variability. Our findings highlight that no single algorithm universally dominates across all tasks. Personalized and variance-reducing methods tend to perform better in diverse data settings, though at the cost of increased complexity. We discuss key trade-offs, scalability limitations, and ethical considerations—including alignment with emerging regulatory frameworks such as the EU AI Act and OECD AI Principles. This paper provides practical guidance for selecting appropriate FL strategies in privacy-sensitive healthcare applications.

title: Soft Sensing Model for Mixed Gas Flow Prediction Using a Backpropagation Neural Network
authors: Tong Le
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: As energy systems become increasingly digitized, the accurate prediction of natural gas flow at the wellhead is essential for ensuring production safety and improving operational efficiency. This study proposes a soft sensing method for predicting the flow rate of mixed gases by combining capacitive sensors with a backpropagation (BP) neural network. A synthetic dataset was generated by simulating methane–steam mixtures under varying temperature, pressure, and humidity conditions, with sensor capacitance values used as key input features. The neural network was employed to model the nonlinear relationship between the input parameters and the target flow rate, and its training process was optimized using the Levenberg–Marquardt algorithm. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model achieves extremely high prediction accuracy on both training and testing datasets, with a root mean square error (RMSE) as low as 1.6 × 10⁻⁵. The predicted values closely match the actual measurements, with a tightly centered and unbiased error distribution, indicating strong generalization and robustness. This approach provides an efficient, cost-effective, and scalable solution for online intelligent prediction of natural gas and other mixed gas flows, offering significant potential for practical engineering applications.

title: Machine Learning-Based Data Transfer Time Prediction in Distributed IoT Architectures
authors: Saúl Llosa-Ponce, Irvin Dongo, Ana Aguilera
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: The increasing demand for real-time data processing in Internet of Things (IoT) systems stems from the need for responsive and efficient services across a wide range of applications. A clear example is Human-Robot Interaction (HRI), where service robots-operating as advanced IoT nodes-face constraints in processing power and battery life. To address these limitations, many systems have adopted cloud platforms and remote processing services, enabling robots to offload computation and respond more effectively. However, this architecture introduces a significant challenge: data transfer time. High transfer latency can hinder interaction quality and degrade overall system performance. Although load-balancing strategies have been implemented to distribute tasks across servers, most do not consider the influence of transfer latency on decision-making. To fill this gap, this work proposes a machine learning-based model to predict data transfer time using features such as IP addresses, data size, geographic distance, date, and request time. Among the models tested, the Random Forest algorithm showed the best performance, achieving an R-squared value near 1.0 and the lowest errors in MSE (44.3188), MAE (1.9068), and RMSE (6.6572). A web-based application was developed to implement and validate the model in real time. This tool can be integrated into existing load-balancing systems, allowing them to consider predicted latency when distributing computational tasks. The proposed solution thus enhances resource management in HRI environments and contributes to more autonomous, adaptive, and latency-aware infrastructures across the broader IoT landscape.

title: ADMM-Based Duty Cycle Adjustment in Magnetic Wireless Power Transfer Systems
authors: Shunxin Liu, Hao Zhou, Xiang Cui, Xinyu Wang, Xiaoyan Wang, Zhi Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Wireless power transfer (WPT) systems that rely on magnetic resonant coupling (MRC) have advanced considerably in recent years, spurring the development of diverse optimization approaches to enhance charging performance. Nevertheless, existing approaches to performance optimization—such as system frequency regulation and TX current dispatching—focus exclusively on the transmitter (TX)-receiver (RX) level, failing to account for duty cycle (the ratio of time a power switch is on to the total switching period, a key parameter regulating power conversion in WPT systems) adjustment from a system-wide holistic perspective. While duty cycle adjustment exerts a significant impact on the attained power-delivered-to-load (PDL), the area remains underexplored in research. In our paper, we present a PDL maximization strategy based on duty cycle adjustment for single-input multipleoutput (SIMO) scenarios. We first formulate this optimization problem and then transform it into a standard consensus optimization problem, which is subsequently addressed using an algorithm based on the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM). A prototype of the presented approach is implemented, and substantial experiments are conducted to assess its performance. The experimental data confirm the effectiveness of our presented algorithm: In comparison with the cutting-edge distributed baseline, our system achieves an average 100.4% improvement in charging performance and maintains performance close to that of the centralized baseline.

title: Phoneme-Specific Challenges to Intelligibility in Hearing Impairment Under Noisy Condition
authors: Denawati Junia, Candy Olivia Mawalim
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Hearing impairment significantly reduces speech intelligibility, particularly in noisy acoustic environments, due to impaired auditory sensitivity and phoneme recognition. This study investigates whether speech intelligibility can be accurately predicted by integrating phoneme-level error patterns in noisy conditions. Using the Clarity prediction challenge dataset, phoneme-level errors were computed based on the international phonetic alphabet transcriptions and quantified by word error rate (WER). Our key findings reveal that high-frequency fricatives (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$/ \mathbf{f} /, / \mathbf{3} /$</tex>) and affricates (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$/ \mathbf{d} \mathbf{3} /$</tex>), along with voiced phonemes (/g/,/ɔ/), showed the highest average WER. This indicates their particular vulnerability to masking and the effects of highfrequency hearing loss. While higher SNR generally improves intelligibility, we observed a weak correlation (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\rho \approx 0.20$</tex>), underscoring the critical role of individual hearing loss profiles. To further our analysis, we used the five most challenging phonemes and SNR as features to predict speech intelligibility with Random Forest and XGBoost models. This approach yielded slightly better prediction performance compared to the Hearing Aid Speech Perception Index.

title: Generative AI-Enhanced Science Pedagogy System for Digital Literacy Enrichment
authors: Deepali Singh, Premlata, Lubeck Abrahamhuaman Ponce, SelviaArokiya Mary Amalanathan, Isha Das, Prasanta Kumar Parida
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Smart systems are required in enhancing scientific and digital literacy with regard to the fast-paced development of digital learning. The novel aspect of this study is given with a Generative AI-Enhanced Science Pedagogy System that incorporates complex ML and NL literacy methods and offers flexible and transparent learning. Methodology includes a combination of text normalization and bias elimination to achieve fairness and data quality and SHAP-based Top-K feature selection to have interpretable and efficient feature extraction. To provide high forecasting accuracy on learner progress predictions, it is using a LightGBM classifier and, to achieve personalized feedback and context-based content generation, Hugging Face Transformers are used. The system proves to be much more accurate, engaging and interpretable in comparison to traditional pedagogical models. Its potential to mitigate bias, stay scalable, and deepen digital literacy are supported by experimental evaluations of the positive effect of the interactive and accessible science learning. The framework, in general, provides a strong basis on the use of generative AI with regard to the next-generation digital pedagogy and the inclusive learning surroundings.

title: Dynamic Cloud-Edge Collaborative Task Scheduling for VR Video Services in MEC
authors: Siyu Zhang, Zongshuai Zhang, Wenhao Zou, Lin Tian, Qi Ge
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: This paper investigates the computational resource bottlenecks faced by Mobile Edge Computing (MEC) in Virtual Reality (VR) scenarios. By deploying computational resources at the network edge, MEC brings processing closer to end-user devices, thereby meeting the high bandwidth demands of VR and enhancing the interactive experience and real-time performance of latency-sensitive applications such as VR. However, due to the intensive computational demands of VR applications, including high-definition video encoding and decoding, as well as real-time scene rendering—most existing task scheduling algorithms are based on static assumptions regarding the fixed number of terminals and servers, making them inadequate for dynamic real-world environments where both terminal devices and server resources fluctuate. To address this issue in the context of VR video services, this paper proposes a scalable Dynamic Edge-Cloud Synergistic Task Scheduling (DECS) resource management algorithm. By designing a link-output-based Graph Neural Network (GNN), a scalable distributed scheduling framework is constructed to support flexible resource allocation among any number of edge nodes in an edge-cloud collaborative architecture. Simulation results demonstrate that, compared with traditional Multilayer Perceptron (MLP)-based random allocation algorithms, the proposed method exhibits significantly better scalability. Furthermore, in terms of task processing latency, the edge-cloud collaborative architecture reduces delays by 8.52% and 20.54% compared to pure edge computing and pure cloud computing architectures, respectively.

title: Optimizing a Three-Echelon Stochastic Inventory Policy for Shared Electric Bicycle Batteries Using Double Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Jingjing Wang, Dandan Song, Xin Yang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Multi-echelon spare part inventory problems, encompassing warehouses, depots and bases, have attracted more attention from material suppliers in recent years. Most existing research explored a simple single-echelon optimization problem by using intelligent optimization algorithms, ignoring the effect of a complicated multidimensional state space on the optimization problem. To overcome this challenge, this study addresses the multi-echelon inventory management of batteries in shared electric bicycles using double deep reinforcement learning. An optimization model is formulated, where the failure time, replacement time and charging time of batteries are uncertain and random variables. To solve the randomness of inventory management, the double deep reinforcement learning is used to obtain the optimal order policy and the number of charging piles. Finally, a real-world case study from the BRT line in Tianhe CBD, Guangzhou, demonstrates the effectiveness of the methods used in solving complicated highdimensional inventory problems.

title: Evaluation of Low-Resource and High-Efficiency Deep Learning Accelerator for Clinical Dental Diagnosis
authors: Yuan-Jin Lin, Yu-Jen Chang, Chin-Hao Liang, Sung-Tsun Wei, Jia-Hong Weng, Shih-Lun Chen, Wei-Chen Tu
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: With artificial intelligence technology's rapid advancement, integrating AI into dental diagnostics has become an irreversible trend. Deep learning models have been increasingly employed to analyze dental images. These AI-assisted techniques have proven to enhance diagnostic accuracy and clinical efficiency. However, deploying large-scale models in resource-constrained dental clinics remains challenging due to high computational and memory demands, potentially limiting real-time support and responsiveness. This has driven the need for lightweight AI accelerator solutions that maintain accuracy while reducing hardware costs. Thus, this study investigates the feasibility of deploying deep learning models in clinical dental applications by combining pruning and quantization strategies. Specifically, we implement a compressed version of AlexNet using W8A8 quantization and 50 % structured pruning and evaluate its performance on the ZCU104 hardware platform. Compared to the original floating-point model, the compressed version achieves a similar accuracy (86.13 % vs. 87.10 %) while reducing DSP, LUT, and BRAM usage by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9.5 \%, 77.3 \%$</tex>, and 26.5 %, respectively, with 56.43 ms lower inference latency. Furthermore, 10-fold crossvalidation across a PA dataset of 1220 images demonstrates an average accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$85.67 \% (\pm 0.46)$</tex>, with a 95 % confidence interval ranging from 85.34 % to 86.00 %. These results verify that our approach can retain model precision while significantly reducing resource overhead, highlighting its practical potential for AI-assisted diagnostics in real-world dental settings.

title: Detection of Automated Parkinson’s disease and Multi Level Feature Enhancement using Artificial Intelligence Techniques
authors: R Manasa, O Ranjit Kumar, Safeyah Tawil, CH Srivardhan Kumar, Harish.S.S, Anandhi R J
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Early diagnosis and ongoing symptom monitoring are vital for improving life quality in Parkinson's Disease (PD). This study presents a new diagnostic system called the Detection of Automated Parkinson’s Disease and Multi Level Feature Enhancement using Artificial Intelligence Techniques (DAPMLA) model, which aims to improve current methods' accuracy and efficiency. The model uses data from sensors and sketches, along with advanced machine learning techniques, to identify early signs of PD. It incorporates L1-Norm Support Vector Machines (SVM) for selecting important features and uses the Relief algorithm to evaluate feature importance. The dataset includes features from both frequency analysis and sketches, and it trains various algorithms such as CatBoost, XGBoost, Random Forests, AdaBoost, and SVM for classifying PD. The DAPMLA model shows impressive performance, achieving 100% accuracy with balanced data and outperforming existing models. It has a high AUC score of 0.96, indicating good sensitivity and specificity. The DAPMLA model also shows zero false positives and negatives, demonstrating its reliability. A frequency analysis feature helps distinguish important signals, aiding in the understanding of voice and movement indicators of PD. DAPMLA is modular and easy to implement in healthcare systems. Its lightweight nature makes it suitable for remote diagnostics and telemedicine, providing effective, cost-efficient, and noninvasive monitoring.

title: Machine Learning for Dynamic Pricing in Online Retail
authors: Tarun Kashni, Manjula Pattnaik, Rucha Tatkare, M.Dhanabal, Neeraj Chopra, Sanjit Kumar Dash
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: In online retail, dynamic pricing has come to play a critical part in competitive strategy. The study is based on the acceptance of this machine learning where a combination of three techniques is implemented (Min-Max Scaling, Causal Forests, Proximal Policy Optimization) to achieve the objective of real-time pricing. The methodology starts with data normalization of Min-Max Scaling because of its ability to increase convergence of the model and Causal Forests to discover most significant factors contributing to the demand and give proper interpretability by means of causal inference. PPO, which is a reinforcement learning algorithm, deployed through Ray RLlib with a PyTorch backend, forms the basis of the core pricing strategy, which prices products by altering in real-time due to market and customer behavior. The system was conducted on a simulated retail setting, where growth in revenue as well as profit margins was significant as seen with the traditional pricing system. Its results validate the flexibility, scalability and interpretability of using a combination of causal modeling and reinforcement learning to produce an intelligent pricing solution. The present research adds a solid framework helping to support real time data driven pricing in e-commerce.

title: Reverse Algorithm for Mechanical Properties of Thin-Film Material Based on CNN-LSTM Neural Network
authors: Zongpei Wu, Tingting Huang, Pu Jia
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: This study proposes a hybrid CNN-LSTM deep neural network for reversing constitutive parameters from nanoindentation load-penetration depth (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$P-h$</tex>) curves. A dataset comprising 125 numerically <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$P-h$</tex> curves with combinatorially sampled Johnson-Cook parameters (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{A}, \boldsymbol{B}, \boldsymbol{n}$</tex>) was generated via finite element (FE) simulations. Network architecture integrates CNN (2 layers) to extract local morphological features and LSTM (4 layers) to capture temporal dependencies, enabling spatiotemporal joint learning of indentation responses. Hyperparameter optimization was conducted in two stages: an initial determination of CNN/LSTM layers based on test-set mean absolute percentage error (MAPE), followed by Bayesian optimization iterations to finalize the optimal configuration. Comparative experiments demonstrate that the CNN-LSTM model significantly outperforms standalone counterparts, achieving a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 4 \%}$</tex> reduction in overall MAPE (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 4. 9 0 \%}$</tex>) compared to the CNN model (32.33 %) and a 24 % reduction compared to the LSTM model (19.47 %). Notably, consistent error reduction trends are observed across all individual parameter predictions. This approach substantially reduces reliance on iterative FE simulations, exhibiting strong generalizability and industrial applicability for rapid mechanical characterization.

title: Learning Joint Source-Channel Encoding in IRS-Assisted Multi-User Semantic Communications
authors: Haidong Wang, Songhan Zhao, Lanhua Li, Bo Gu, Jing Xu, Shimin Gong, Jiawen Kang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: In this paper, we investigate a joint source-channel encoding (JSCE) scheme in an intelligent reflecting surface (IRS)-assisted multi-user semantic communication system. Semantic encoding not only compresses redundant information, but also enhances information orthogonality in a semantic feature space. Meanwhile, the IRS can adjust the spatial orthogonality, enabling concurrent multi-user semantic communication in densely deployed wireless networks to improve spectrum efficiency. We aim to maximize the users' semantic throughput by jointly optimizing the users' scheduling, the IRS's passive beamforming, and the semantic encoding strategies. To tackle this non-convex problem, we propose an explainable deep neural network-driven deep reinforcement learning (XD-DRL) framework. Specifically, we employ a deep neural network (DNN) to serve as a joint source-channel semantic encoder, enabling transmitters to extract semantic features from raw images. By leveraging structural similarity, we assign some DNN weight coefficients as the IRS's phase shifts, allowing simultaneous optimization of IRS's passive beamforming and DNN training. Given the IRS's passive beamforming and semantic encoding strategies, user scheduling is optimized using the DRL method. Numerical results validate that our JSCE scheme achieves superior semantic throughput compared to the conventional schemes and efficiently reduces the semantic encoder's mode size in multi-user scenarios.

title: DL-Based Optical Fibre Fault Detection for Healthcare Telesurgery Communication System
authors: Khushi Shah, Lakshit Pathak, Akshita Abrol, Kanak Jain, Rajesh Gupta, Parishi Shah, Sudeep Tanwar, Umesh Bodkhe, Tong Rong
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Telesurgery is one of the fastest growing fields in healthcare where surgeons are able to perform operations remotely through controllers by using robots connected to a high-speed network. Optical fibers are heavily utilized in this process due to the fact that the bandwidth is high, the latency rates low, essentially supporting active real-time data transfer as well as control. However, faults with optical fibers can be problematic at times, causing delays which compromises on the precision and safety of surgeries. This paper presents a DLbased framework for detecting faults and enhancing optical fiber communication in telesurgery. We used deep learning (DL) models like Recurrent Neural Network (RNN), Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU), and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) to identify these faults from Optical Time-Domain Reflectometer (OTDR) traces. Our models are trained using optimizers like Adam, Nadam, and RMSprop. Among these, LSTM proves to be the most effective, achieving the highest accuracy in fault detection. We also integrated real-time fault detection along with monitoring delays in communication. This innovation ensures that surgical operations can proceed smoothly and accurately.

title: Research on Fault Diagnosis Method for Aero-Engine Rolling Bearings Based on Dynamic Fusion Attention Mechanism and Convnext
authors: Zhiqiang Cai, Hongwei Wang, Xuefei Qin, Wenjin Zhu, Shubin Si
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: As a critical component of aircraft engines, rolling bearings are subjected to complex alternating stresses and wear over time, making them prone to failure, which can affect engine performance and threaten flight safety. Therefore, timely and accurate bearing fault diagnosis is crucial for preventing accidents and extending engine life. However, existing deep learning-based diagnostic methods often perform poorly in practical applications. Hence, developing bearing fault diagnosis methods with high diagnostic accuracy is of great significance for enhancing engine reliability. This paper proposes the DFAMConvNeXt model, which deeply integrates a dynamic fusion attention mechanism with the high-performance, lightweight ConvNeXt architecture. The model significantly improves feature extraction capabilities under complex conditions by mining deep features from time-series data. Experiments conducted on aerospace application bearings and standardized bearing datasets demonstrate that the DFAM-ConvNeXt model exhibits excellent diagnostic performance in bearing fault diagnosis tasks, achieving a maximum accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 9. 7 5 \%}$</tex>.

title: Practice Teaching in Functional Medical Experiments Based on Big Data Model
authors: Nan Zhou, Xin Li, Dexiu Wang, Xin Wang, Xiaoxu Yang, Xiaoyun Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: To overcome the limitations in data collection, analysis, and feedback in medical function teaching, we constructed a teaching system based on a big data model. Through the standardization and integration of multi-source data, experimental results, operation behaviors, and environmental parameters were integrated in this study. The data were processed with machine learning algorithms to identify high-frequency error patterns and conduct parameter sensitivity analysis and virtual simulation prediction. The developed system enables personalized learning by adopting behavior analysis. Using operation time tracking, hierarchical resource, advanced and innovative learning packages, and dynamic task adaptation, the system provides multi-person and multi-faceted teaching intervention. Relying on the cloud platform, a cross-temporal and spatial collaboration architecture of the system supports real-time data synchronization across multiple campuses for virtual projects and the analysis of regional data elements. The nonlinear interaction of physiological signals, such as the heart rate and blood pressure, is analyzed by a deep learning algorithm, and the related pathological processes are simulated on a virtual experimental platform. The developed system significantly improves experimental design, the timeliness of teaching feedback, and students' ability amid the digital transformation of medical education.

title: Real-Time Animal Pose Estimation Using Computer Vision Techniques
authors: Md Roman Bhuiyan, Barbaros Yesilova, Anastasia Shadakh, Shrish Arunesh, Giulio Napolitano, Md Baharul Islam, Junaidi Abdullah
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: With applications in animal monitoring, veterinary diagnostics, behavioral analysis, and robotics, real-time estimation of animal posture is an area of increasing interest in computer vision. In this work, we propose a method based on deep learning approaches to assess animal positions in real time. Selected for their applicability in both home and agricultural settings, the study centres on four animal classes: chicken, dog, horse, and cow. An important output of this work is a bespoke dataset created especially for posture estimation activities, including annotated videos. Every video in the dataset records continuous movement under different lighting and environmental contexts and runs for fifteen seconds. Keypoints marking important body joints for all types of animals were added to the extracted frames. Using the YOLOv8n posture architecture - which provides a balanced trade-off between speed and accuracy - we performed posture estimation. Although YOLO models are usually optimized for object recognition, we fine-tuned YOLOv8n-Pose to predict both bounding boxes and body keypoints, therefore enabling the real-time identification of intricate postural information. Trained on an annotated dataset using supervised learning, the model was tested on another test set from the same distribution. The proposed model achieves a PosePR mAP at the IoU threshold 0.5 of 99.5% in all classes, according to the experimental data. The dog class showed lower precision and F1 scores; the dog and horse classes showed decreased recall. The model maintains strong performance in real-time even if interclass posture variability and occlusion in video frames present natural difficulties. The system handles video input at an average frame rate enough for monitoring systems to be live. This study emphasizes the need for custom data sets tailored to real-world activities and the viability of employing YOLOv8n-Pose for the estimation of animal posture based on key points. Future directions include growing the data set, increasing keypoint accuracy, and including temporal consistency across frames. The data set is available at this link https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1xci52bt9IxcYQrq36r2fQBaLvx3cSGHH#

title: DEG-Sum: Discourse-aware Event Graph Summarization for News Texts
authors: Qiyi Wei, Xin Zhang, Wen Qian Shang
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: News articles are inherently event-driven, with their semantic structure organized around the development and evolution of real-world events. Traditional summarization approaches often rely on sentence-level extraction, lacking awareness of event progression and discourse-level organization, which leads to fragmented and incoherent summaries. To address this, we propose a hybrid framework that integrates event chain construction with discourse structure modeling. The method captures temporal and causal links between events while incorporating rhetorical and framing strategies at the discourse level, enhancing both semantic completeness and coherence. We implement a neural architecture that jointly models event graphs and hierarchical discourse features. Experiments on benchmark news datasets show that our approach outperforms state-of-theart baselines in content coverage, logical flow, and informativeness. This study provides a new perspective on structured summarization by combining event semantics and discourse understanding in a unified model.

title: AI-Assisted Outcomes of Testicular Torsion: The Effect of Delayed vs Early Hospital Admission on Diagnosis and Salvageability
authors: Mohamed Arsath Shamsudeen, Muhammad Hazmi Bin Aulia Mohamed, Hameed Abdulla, Mohammed Aadhil
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Testicular torsion is an urology emergency, which involves urgent diagnosis and immediate surgery to ensure that it may avoid irreversible damage to the testicles, which may cause infertility, and psychological trauma. Although clinical inspection and Doppler ultrasonography are routine, novel models of Artificial Intelligence (AI) can be used to improve prompt diagnosis, risk classification, and salvageability forecasting. We are examining patients with testicular torsion in this case series who presented both when there was still a possible salvage time and those who presented after the salvage time. There is potential that AI-enhanced DSS systems will decrease diagnostic delays especially in the cases of atypical presentations and in resource-constrained environments. Our results outline the clinical appearance, diagnostic methods, surgery, and postoperative results of detorsion surgeries or orchiectomies. These advantages include the early suspicion, fast referral, and the future role of AI-enabled tools in simplifying the triage and surgical preparedness. In conjunction with AI-driven early symptom detection systems, even better testicular salvage rates and fertility outcomes can be achieved through public health education.

title: Knowledge Graph-driven Optimization of Software Engineering Course
authors: Donghua Zheng, Lina Dai, Lizhu Ye, Weirong Xiu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: We developed an optimization method based on knowledge graphs and applied it to the software engineering course. By reviewing traditional software engineering courses, we obtained the knowledge base to structure the knowledge graph. Computer technology was used for knowledge extraction and integration. The moth-flame optimization (MFO) algorithm was employed to optimize the course system iteratively and dynamically adjust the model. Through the iteration process, the algorithm accurately identified the connections between the textual contents of software engineering courses, and the knowledge of mathematical statistics was used to optimize course sequences. The experimental results showed that the developed model enhanced the efficiency of system design for software engineering courses and enables the formulation of efficient teaching solutions in a rapidly changing educational environment. With the development of knowledge graph technology, software engineering courses were optimized based on scientific data support.

title: Optimizing Mobile Learning through Green Software Practices
authors: Ellis Ting Sy Yow, See Kwee Teck, Aw Kien Sin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: Mobile learning has made education more flexible and accessible, but students from low-income B40 communities in Malaysia struggle with outdated mobile devices, which limit their ability to engage with digital learning tools. Green software engineering (GSE) promotes sustainable development by optimising software for energy and resource efficiency and offers a promising path toward making educational apps more compatible with low-end devices. We explored the potential of GSE to improve mobile learning for underserved communities by examining current mobile learning challenges, GSE techniques, and evaluation tools. Finally, research gaps were identified to propose directions for integrating GSE principles into educational app development to enhance accessibility, sustainability, and digital equity in education.

title: Effect of Social Support for Learning Motivation of Primary and Secondary School Students Using K-means Algorithm and Cluster Analysis
authors: Guoping Zhang, Xiuli Liu, Mei Yiu Leung, Huixia Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: The relationship between social support and learning motivation among students from various primary and secondary schools in Province F, China, was explored in this study. Data were collected using standardized questionnaires to assess perceived social support and motivational levels. To identify motivational profiles across different support conditions, the collected data were clustered using the K-means algorithm. The results revealed a significant positive correlation between social support and learning motivation. Specifically, students who reported high levels of social support exhibited stronger motivation, whereas those with lower levels of support showed reduced motivation. The results highlighted the influence of social support on academic engagement. Based on the results, implications for educational practice were determined. By adopting targeted support strategies, educators can foster motivation and enhance the academic outcomes of students across different educational contexts.

title: Development of HRV-Based Biomarkers for Predicting Blood Glucose Levels
authors: Ju-An Park, Jun-Seok Lee, Na-Ri Kim, Han-Jeong Hwang
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: The objective of this study was to develop electrocardiography (ECG)-based biomarkers for predicting blood glucose levels. Resting-state ECG signals were recorded from lead I for a six-minute period, and 21 heart rate variability (HRV) features were extracted. To identify potential biomarkers for non-invasive blood glucose monitoring, we performed correlation analyses between the 21 HRV features and blood glucose levels. Four HRV features demonstrated statistically significant correlations with blood glucose levels: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha 2$</tex>, PIP, and IALS showed negative correlations, while HF power was positively correlated. These results highlight the potential of ECG-based HRV features as non-invasive biomarkers for estimating blood glucose levels in daily life.

title: Finite Element Analysis of Solder Joint Fatigue Failure in SiP Under Random Vibration Loading
authors: Xiangwei Wu, Liang Mei, Jiaoying Huang, Mingzheng Li
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: To investigate the failure modes and failure life of the internal structure of System-in-Package (SiP) under random vibration environments, a specific model of RF SiP was selected as the research object. The random vibration was conducted by using SolidWorks software to establish a 3D simplified model and ANSYS Workbench finite element simulation software. Based on the GJB 150.16A standard, acceleration power spectral density was set by using a generic device selection spectrum, followed by modal and random vibration analyses. The equivalent stress, strain, and deformation cloud maps of various parts of the RF SiP was analyzed based on the simulation results. By applying CoffinManson's equation, Miner's rule, Steinberg's model, and the three-band method to the finite element analysis results, the fatigue life prediction was performed. This indicated a fatigue life of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4, 5 8 5}$</tex> cycles for the ball grid array (BGA) of the RF SiP. This study presents a finite element simulation methodology for assessing the vibration-induced fatigue life of RF SiP. The methodology provides reference data for predicting the operational lifetime of this specific SiP model, which apply to actual service conditions.

title: Adaptive Policy Optimization for Product Infant Failure Risk Control in Manufacturing Processes with Variable Demands
authors: Xiao Han, Yuqi Cai, Anqi Zhang, Yao Zhu, Yihai He, Rui Shi
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: In manufacturing stage, Product Infant Failure Risks (PIFR) are typically controlled via quality control and environmental stress screening approaches that respectively eliminate workpieces with detectable or undetectable defects. With the evolvingly dynamic production demands in context of flexible manufacturing, the Intended Usage Scenario (IUS) of products can be variable.
