Considering that defect types prone to be triggered into product infant failure vary across usage scenario, this paper proposes a PIFR policy optimization method that adapts to demand variation. The main contribution involves (1) establishing an Scenario and Defect Activation Mapping (SDAM) decomposition model that reasons about the correlations between product usage scenarios and prone-activation defect types, (2) leveraging association relation mining to extract SDAM weights from information associated with the correlations between usage environment and product failure, (3) evaluating PIFRs via SDAM based on IUS specified by production demands, and (4) developing a reinforcement learning algorithm to implement adaptive PIFR control in response to demand variability. The applicability and effectiveness of the proposed method have been verified via an industrial case of Gas Turbine Bearing Seat (GTBS) manufacturing process.

title: Effects of Music Training Experience on the Production of English Rhythm by Chinese Learners
authors: Chenyu Li, Ying Chen, Ruizhe Wang, Yujia Zhang
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Rhythm is a pivotal element of speech prosody, playing a crucial role in intelligibility and presenting considerable challenges for second language (L2) learners. Previous studies have demonstrated that Chinese learners of English as a foreign language (EFL) encounter difficulties in mastering the duration of vowels and consonants, as well as in adjusting pitch patterns when producing English rhythms. This study aims to explore the effect of music training on the production of English rhythm by Chinese EFL learners. The results, based on comparisons of various rhythmic parameters, show significant differences in VarcoV and VarcoC between the music and non-music groups among low-proficiency learners. This finding suggests that music training facilitates improving the English rhythm production among Chinese EFL learners.

title: MDD: A Mask Diffusion Detector to Protect Speaker Verification Systems from Adversarial Perturbations
authors: Yibo Bai, Sizhou Chen, Michele Panariello, Xiao-Lei Zhang, Massimiliano Todisco, Nicholas Evans
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Speaker verification systems are increasingly deployed in security-sensitive applications but remain highly vulnerable to adversarial perturbations. In this work, we propose the Mask Diffusion Detector (MDD), a novel adversarial detection and purification framework based on a text-conditioned masked diffusion model. During training, MDD applies partial masking to Mel-spectrograms and progressively adds noise through a forward diffusion process, simulating the degradation of clean speech features. A reverse process then reconstructs the clean representation conditioned on the input transcription. Unlike prior approaches, MDD does not require adversarial examples or large-scale pretraining. Experimental results show that MDD achieves strong adversarial detection performance and outperforms prior state-of-the-art methods, including both diffusionbased and neural codec-based approaches. Furthermore, MDD effectively purifies adversarially-manipulated speech, restoring speaker verification performance to levels close to those observed under clean conditions. These findings demonstrate the potential of diffusion-based masking strategies for secure and reliable speaker verification systems.

title: PQSR: A Speech Corpus of Polar Questions and Spontaneous Responses in Standard Chinese with Complex Intentions Annotated
authors: Yingyi Luo, Yue Huang, Qingke Sun, Shuwen Chen
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: To advance research of how communicative intentions are conveyed in conversations and how prosody plays a role, we created PQSR, a context-specific, intention-annotated speech corpus of polar-questions and responses in Standard Chinese. It consists of two subsets: Polar Question Production (PQP) with 103 native speakers posing polar questions in given contexts for information seeking or rhetorical expression, and Spontaneous Responses (SR) with 106 speakers' natural oral reactions to these questions. Data was collected using a combination of experimental and naturalistic designs, with participants recording themselves on their smartphones. Beyond phonetic annotations, we introduced a framework for classifying communicative intentions, focusing on the respondent's concerns regarding the questioner, along with a corresponding annotation system.

title: TopcDB: Two-Phase Compactable Lossy Compression for Timeseries Databases
authors: Zijian Jiang, Peiquan Jin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Timeseries data compression is a critical issue in timeseries databases. So far, many compression algorithms have been proposed, in which lossy compression algorithms generally achieve superior compression ratios compared to their lossless counterparts. However, existing lossy compression algorithms do not account for the storage characteristics of timeseries databases. This paper proposes a novel two-phase compatible lossy compression method named TopcDB for LSM-tree-based timeseries databases. TopcDB addresses two critical challenges in existing approaches: error accumulation during compaction and inefficient compression for small data chunks. It employs an adaptive two-phase compression architecture: Phase 1 utilizes quantization-based error-bounded compression for in-memory chunks. Phase 2 applies entropy encoding with level-aware chunk sizing for LSM-tree-based persistent storage. The novelty of TopcDB includes a merge-friendly Lorenzo predictor, linearscale quantization with mathematical error guarantees, and geometric chunk scaling aligned with compaction patterns. Experimental results show that TopcDB achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.1-8.3 \times$</tex> higher compression ratios than Prometheus while improving write throughput by 147%. Compared to state-of-the-art lossy compressors, TopcDB maintains 1.1-2.8 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\times$</tex> and 1.1-1.4 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\times$</tex> higher compression ratios for in-order and out-of-order data, respectively. Our proposal eliminates error propagation during compaction through phase-isolated compression strategies, making it particularly suitable for industrial timeseries workloads with strict precision requirements.

title: HIQA-DB: A Benchmark Dataset for Image Quality Assessment in Hospital Surveillance
authors: Yujin Han, Taewan Kim
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Despite the growing use of intelligent video analytics in healthcare environments, the impact of image quality on algorithmic performance remains underexplored. In particular, hospital surveillance footage often exhibits highly uniform backgrounds (white walls, beds, and patient clothing) which complicates person detection, pose estimation, fall detection, and self-harm monitoring under degraded visual conditions. To address this, we present a new Hospital Image Quality Assessment Database (HIQA-DB), which contains 150 original images captured from real hospital Closed Circuit Television (CCTV) footage. Each reference image has four types of synthetically distorted versions, resulting in a total of 750 images. Subjective quality ratings collected from human evaluators reveal that compression artifacts degrade perceived quality the most and correlate strongly with performance drops in downstream analytics models. HIQA-DB provides a valuable benchmark for understanding and mitigating the effects of image quality on intelligent video analytics in clinical settings, and will be publicly released soon to support further research.

title: FurCare: A Comprehensive Digital Solution for Pet Adoption, Tracking, and Community Engagement in the Philippines
authors: Roben A. Juanatas, Ralph Ibn Jheio M. Bugarin, Wilfredo M. Romero
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: The rapid growth of the pet population has created a pressing need for comprehensive digital solutions that address the diverse requirements of pet owners. FurCare integrates a variety of features, including pet adoption services, veterinary clinic locators, real-time updates for missing pets, a pet dating platform, and a QR code editor for pet tags. This paper discusses the development, implementation, and societal impact of FurCare, emphasizing its contributions to animal welfare, community building, and the promotion of responsible pet ownership. By addressing the unique challenges faced by pet owners in the Philippines, FurCare aligns with global sustainability goals, particularly the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

title: Understanding Depression and Suicide Through Words: Analyzing Reddit Posts with Topic Modelling
authors: Shayaree Subba, Muskan Girhotra, Md Zamilur Rahman
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: This research presents an approach for assessing depression and suicidal concerns using Natural Language Processing (NLP) and topic modelling on Reddit posts. We have applied algorithms such as LDA and LSA to two benchmark datasets, SDCNL and CSSRS, to uncover the semantic structures within the text. Our findings indicate that LDA outperformed LSA’s topic coherence in the SDCNL’s suicide-related task, by capturing more meaningful themes and achieving an optimal coherence score of 0.6633 with 7 topics. On the contrary, both models showed limited performance with the depression posts, due to the general and passive language. Both models demonstrated complementary strengths in CSSRS, LSA outperformed LDA on emotion-driven labels, such as Supportive and Attempt, whereas LDA successfully identified unique and instructive topics for labels like Indicator and Ideation. The coherence score was not the decisive factor in distinguishing the performance of LDA and LSA in this dataset. The results highlight the potential of topic modelling as a tool for mental health monitoring, offering unique patterns associated with depression and suicide risk.

title: Personalized Energy-Saving Behavior Promotion System Based on User Utterance Analysis and LLM
authors: Shun Hirai, Sinan Chen, Sachio Saiki, Masahide Nakamura
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: In recent years, climate change, particularly global warming, has become a major concern, with global average temperatures continuing to rise. In response, the Japanese government has declared its commitment to achieving a zero-carbon society where the difference between CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions and absorption becomes zero. While energy conservation is crucial for achieving this goal, this research specifically focuses on energy-saving behaviors in general households. Previous research has proposed methods to promote energy-saving behaviors through dialogue between systems and users. However, these methods have several issues: they can only provide predetermined responses, they use costly 3D models, and they cannot determine whether users are at home. Considering these issues, this research proposes EcoWiz, a system utilizing large language models and Live2D. Additionally, the system implements presence detection and periodic notifications using motion sensors and Pub/Sub architecture. Based on the proposed method, we implemented the system and verified its operation through case studies.

title: Efficient Query Filtering in Big Data Using Entropy-Based Learned Indexing
authors: Elias Dritsas, Maria Trigka, Phivos Mylonas
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: This study explores the use of neural networks as lightweight surrogates for guiding value localization over numeric attributes in analytical data systems. Instead of directly modeling key-position mappings, we frame the problem as a multi-class classification task over discretized bins, enabling approximate query support without explicit index structures. The model was trained in a self-supervised manner using pseudo-labels from data-driven binning schemes, requiring no manual annotation. Experiments on three real-world datasets show that our method achieves a classification accuracy above 94.7% for coarse binning <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(K=5)$</tex>, with consistent F1 scores and inference times under 0.6 milliseconds (ms), The approach remains robust under skewed distributions using entropy- or quantile-based binning and is well-suited to latency-sensitive tasks such as filtering or partition pruning. Although this study focuses on univariate attributes, the method is extensible to multivariate scenarios via Multilayer Perceptrons (MLPs) or attention-based models. Overall, neural surrogates offer a practical complement to traditional indexing for approximate or edge-driven analytical workloads.

title: Design and Progress of a Novel MHz Repetitive Induction Acceleration Cell
authors: Yi Liu, Ziping Huang, Yi Shen, Huang Zhang, Xiaobing Jing, Liansheng Xia
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The Repetitive Induction Acceleration Cell (RIAC) is a key component in induction synchrotrons and storage rings. Conventional induction accelerators using matched-cable power feeds suffer from high energy loss in shunt resistors, while direct high-voltage-wire connections introduce parasitic inductance causing waveform distortion. To overcome these limitations, we developed an integrated RIAC with a pulsed Switching Power Supply (SPS) embedded directly in the cavity. This design minimizes parasitic inductance to nH-scale through compact integration. The system employs modular MOSFET-based switching units where mechanical supports also serve as low-inductance current paths and water-cooled heatsinks. Through dual-H-bridge circuits operating in time-division multiplexing configurations, the system achieves effective MHz repetition rate while individual components switch at lower frequency. Experimental results confirm stable 2 kV pulse generation at hundreds of kHz repetition rates, demonstrating significant progress toward full MHz operation. This work provides the foundation for next-generation high-efficiency induction accelerators applicable to XFELs and ion beam therapy systems requiring MHz repetition capabilities.

title: $\text{DHO}_{2}$: Accelerating Distributed Hybrid Order Optimization via Model Parallelism and ADMM
authors: Shunxian Gu, Chaoqun You, Bangbang Ren, Deke Guo, Lailong Luo, Junxu Xia
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: The surging model and data size boost the development of distributed model training paradigm, which uses a first-order or second-order optimizer as the fundamental tool. FOSI (First-Order and Second-Order Integration), as a hybrid order optimizer, is regarded as a promising substitute due to its fast convergence speed. However, implementing FOSI distributedly will face two challenges: First, the calculation of the curvature information is restricted on a single GPU device, whose memory is unaffordable when the model becomes large and the dimensionality of the curvature information becomes high, hindering the scalability. Second, frequently updating the curvature information incurs high time consumption, which decreases the acceleration of distributed computing. To overcome these challenges, we propose a distributed hybrid order optimization framework, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{DHO}_{2}$</tex><sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup><sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>Our source code is available at: https://github.com/ShunxianGu/DHO2. It achieves distributed calculation of curvature information via model parallelism to balance the computation and memory cost for each GPU device. Then, it reduces the training time by utilizing the property of ADMM (Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers) on enhancing convergence and proposing an ADMMlike model update rule for the hybrid order optimization setting. Experimentally, our <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{DHO}_{2}$</tex> can achieve a sublinear time-to-solution and memory usage with the increase of the GPU number, enabling the scalability. Meanwhile, it achieves up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.4 \times \sim 2.0 \times$</tex> speedup in the total training time and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \% \sim 5 \%$</tex> improvement in the test accuracy, compared with other previous state-of-the-art distributed first- and second-order optimizer frameworks.

title: Design of Aesthetic Education Teaching System Using Large-Scale Multimodal Artificial Intelligence Model
authors: Chunying Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: We present the design of an aesthetic education teaching system based on a large-scale multimodal AI model. The system collects information from multiple art forms, including painting, music, dance and literature, through multimodal data acquisition techniques. Leveraging the deep analysis capabilities of the AI model, it extracts key features of aesthetic education and generates personalized teaching content tailored to individual learners. An immersive virtual aesthetic education environment is developed to assess students’ learning progress and aesthetic literacy, providing targeded guidance to enhance their abilities. Combined with adaptive teaching content optimization and a multidimensional evaluation framework, the system continuously improves teaching effectiveness, thereby empowering aesthetic education and increasing instructional efficiency.

title: Chess Game Outcome Prediction Using Machine Learning
authors: Noah Giacchetta, Uchechukwu Obinwanne, Wenying Feng
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: This paper explores the use of machine learning to predict the outcome of chess games using pre-game data. We trained a Random Forest Classifier on a cleaned dataset derived from the KingBase Chess Database to predict whether White or Black will win, without considering in-game moves. Our model achieved approximately 69% accuracy. Inspired by prior research from the Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT), which employed similar input features to predict match outcomes, this paper builds on these efforts by incorporating standardized Encyclopedia of Chess Opening strategies (ECO codes), rating differences, and training on a dataset with more diverse features.

title: A New Concept: Multi-switch Shared Driving
authors: Junfeng Rao, Hao Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The design of drive circuits is critical in all-solidstate pulsed power supplies, as it directly impacts the output performance, size, and cost of high-voltage pulse generation. This paper introduces, for the first time, a systematic concept of multi-switch shared driving, including three configurations: shared control signals, shared partial drive circuits, and shared entire drive circuits. Two specific implementations are proposed: a parallel configuration where <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{P}$</tex>-type and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{N}$</tex>-type switches share the entire drive circuit, and a reverse-series configuration where two N-type switches share the entire drive circuit. The principles underlying these configurations are thoroughly explained, and their feasibility is validated through experimental studies. Leveraging this concept, a compact, battery-powered square-wave Marx generator has been developed. The final prototype weighs only 0.314 kg and can generate high-voltage square-wave pulses with a peak voltage of 10 kV and adjustable pulse widths ranging from 150 ns to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 \mu ~\mathrm{s}$</tex>. This multi-switch shared driving approach demonstrates significant potential for reducing the size and cost of solid-state pulsed power supplies while maintaining high performance, particularly in systems requiring many switches.

title: Poster: Accuracy Aware Incentive Algorithm for Model Deployment and Task Offloading with Low Budget
authors: Zhibin Fang, Yalan Wu, Jiale Huang, Jigang Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: This paper focuses on investigating strategy for model deployment and task offloading for deep neural network (DNN) inference to improve quality of services with low budget in vehicular edge computing (VEC). Specifically, a problem is formulated with the objective of maximizing the total revenue in VEC under constraints of per vehicle utility guarantee, per task accuracy requirement, per task latency requirement, etc. To address the formulated problem, an accuracy aware incentive algorithm based on group swap strategy is proposed. The simulations are conducted based on three kinds of DNN inference tasks, three DNN models with different accuracy, and two kinds of CPUs. Simulation results show that the proposed algorithm outperforms the state-of-the-art method for all cases, in terms of total revenue.

title: Speech Emotion Recognition Via Entropy-Aware Score Selection
authors: ChenYi Chua, JunKai Wong, Chengxin Chen, Xiaoxiao Miao
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: In this paper, we propose multimodal framework for speech emotion recognition that leverages entropy-aware score selection to combine speech and textual predictions. The proposed method integrates a primary pipeline that consists of an acoustic model based on wav2vec2.0 and a secondary pipeline that consists of a sentiment analysis model using RoBERTaXLM, with transcriptions generated via Whisper-large-v3. We propose a late score fusion approach based on entropy and varentropy thresholds to overcome the confidence constraints of primary pipeline predictions. A sentiment mapping strategy translates three sentiment categories into four target emotion classes, enabling coherent integration of multimodal predictions. The results on the IEMOCAP and MSP-IMPROV datasets show that the proposed method offers a practical and reliable enhancement over traditional single-modality systems<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup><sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>Code can be found at https://github.com/ExpiredTapWater/Emotion-Recognition. This study is supported by Ministry of Education, Singapore, under its Academic Research Tier 1 (R-R13-A405-0005) and its SIT's Ignition grant (STEM) (R-IE3-A405-0005). Xiaoxiao Miao is the corresponding author and this work was conducted while she was at SIT..

title: Enhanced Thyroid Cancer Detection Using a Hybrid Model by Deep Learning Methods
authors: K.P. Sriram, Abirami. K, Giflin Godshia D.S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Early detection of thyroid cancer is the most critical factor to improve survival rates and optimize treatment protocols. Traditional diagnostic pipelines depend on invasive procedures and human analysis of clinical images and data, causing delays or errors. This work presents a novel hybrid deep learning architecture combining Support Vector Machine (SVM) with Vision Transformer (ViT) for enhancing early detection of thyroid cancer from medical images and structured data. ViT efficiently extracts high-level visual features from thyroid ultrasound images, while SVM is optimally capable of classifying weak malignancy patterns in such features. The system includes a preprocessing, feature extraction, training, and testing module, all fully incorporated into a mobile/web- based diagnostic tool. The hybrid model attains a diagnostic accuracy rate of 98%, which is better than that of conventional models. The novelty is in the integration of Vision Transformer with SVM for the detection of thyroid cancer—a new combination heretofore untested—enabling high-performance, non-invasive, and accessible early diagnostics by intelligent automation.

title: Impact of Different PCB Designs on the Switching Speed of GaN Transistors for Nanosecond Pulse Generation
authors: Mohsen Feizi, Bas Vermulst, Tom Huiskamp
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Gallium nitride high-electron-mobility transistors (GaN HEMTs) offer ultrafast switching capabilities due to their low parasitic components and reduced gate charge requirements. These properties make them well-suited for plasma generation applications, where faster switching operations enhance plasma yield efficiency. Notably, higher switching speeds can be achieved by using an optimized gate driver with high driving current capability and fast rise/fall times. The external and internal parasitics within the gate loop influence the current delivered to the gate, thus significantly impacting the switching speed of GaN transistors. This paper investigates the effects of parasitics associated with two different gate drivers, specifically monolithic Si-based and GaN-based voltage-source drivers, on the rise time of 650 V GaN transistors. For experimental verification, three versions of the monolithic Si-based driver and two versions of the voltage-source driver were constructed. The primary 650 V transistor was evaluated in pulsed operation with a resistive load, reaching pulse voltages and currents of up to 610 V and 107 A, respectively. Experimental results show that, with the monolithic Si-based gate driver, the current rise rate ranges from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$24.74 \text{kA}/\mu \mathrm{s}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$26.87 \text{kA}/\mu \mathrm{s}$</tex> across different designs. Similarly, the current rise rate for the two voltage-source gate driver versions, at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{V G D}=7 \mathrm{V}$</tex>, were <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$32.67 \text{kA}/\mu \mathrm{s}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$36.64 \text{kA}/\mu \mathrm{s}$</tex>, respectively. The differences in rise times are attributed to variations in PCB design, resulting in different parasitic loop inductances.

title: High-Sensitivity in Complementary Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor for Low-Light Amplification
authors: Xinjian Liu, Hengkun Li, Weiquan Liu, Xiaoqian Wang, Ying Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: We reviewed recent advancements in the high-sensitivity design of complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor (CMOS) image sensors (CIS), focusing on low-light amplification. CIS performance has been enhanced in poorly lit environments with elevated noise levels and trade-offs between resolution and pixel dimensions. Challenges related to photon-to-electron conversion, readout noise, and increasing architectural complexity due to sensor miniaturization were also examined to propose technical solutions. The state-of-the-art strategies developed so far include back-side illuminated (BSI) pixel structures, enlarged pixel designs, correlated double sampling (CDS), adaptive analog-to-digital converters (ADCs), and advanced anti-reflective coatings. The adaptability of CIS technologies in expressway traffic management systems is critical for effective vehicle detection and monitoring under fluctuating illumination and adverse weather conditions. Recent technological advancements lead to significant performance improvements, including quantum efficiency exceeding 90%, signal-to-noise ratio enhancements of 10 dB, and dynamic range expansion surpassing 75 dB. Nonetheless, an optimal balance among sensitivity, resolution, and cost remains a challenge in CIS development. Through the integration of novel semiconductor materials, machine learning–based noise suppression techniques, and advanced noise reduction algorithms are used to enhance sensor performance. The advancement in low-light imaging and next-generation CMOS sensor technologies has shown transformative progress in medical diagnostics, security surveillance, and consumer electronics.

title: Bibliometric Analysis on Additive Manufacturing
authors: Yutong Ci, Bei Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: We analyzed research papers on additive manufacturing to explore the research status and progress of additive manufacturing. Using a bibliometric method, we analyzed 51245 papers published from 1980 to 2024, and examined annual trends, major countries, major institutions, source journals, subject categories, emerging topics, and research hotspots. A rapid increase in additive manufacturing publications was observed, with China and the United States being the primary contributors. The United States Department of Energy excelled in publication volume. Over 60% of the papers are published in Q1 and Q2 quartile journals. Notably, the following emerging topics have garnered significant attention: "Additive manufacturing of ceramics: techniques, challenges, and applications", "Binder Jetting Additive Manufacturing: Materials, Processes, and Properties", and "Laser Powder Bed Fusion of Titanium Alloys for Biomedical Applications". The high-frequency keywords included mechanical properties, additive manufacturing, microstructure, 3D printing, behavior, fabrication, selective laser melting, heat-treatment, design, and laser.

title: Dependency-Aware Edge Caching for Web3D via DAG-Guided Reinforcement Learning
authors: Jiwang Liu, Zhenli He, Lin Zhang, Shaowen Yao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: The surge of immersive Web3D applications in next-generation networks imposes stringent requirements on edge caching systems, particularly regarding latency, storage efficiency, and responsiveness to dynamic user behaviors. A key challenge arises from the complex inter-dependencies among 3D content chunks, often represented as Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAGs), which conventional caching strategies fail to capture effectively. In this work, we propose a dependency-aware caching framework based on DAG-guided reinforcement learning. At its core is a policy optimization mechanism built upon Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO), which learns to make cache admission and replacement decisions by explicitly modeling chunklevel DAG dependencies. This enables the system to prioritize critical content while avoiding redundant transmissions and excessive fetch delays. To further improve learning efficiency and convergence, we introduce a compact DAG encoding scheme and a dependency-sensitive reward function that together guide the policy training. Extensive evaluations demonstrate that our method reduces average retrieval latency by up to 26.5%, increases cache hit ratio by 10.7%, and significantly enhances overall edge resource utilization.

title: Neural Network-Based MPPT for High-Efficiency DC Power Delivery to Remote Buildings
authors: Hussain Attia, Ali Al-Ataby, Saeed Alsuwaidi, Mohamad Harami
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: This paper proposes an intelligent direct current power delivery unit as an effective solution for buildings of 13 kW·h scattered far from the traditional alternating electricity grid. Supplying DC instead of AC electricity improves the performance of the power electronic system that is supplied by solar photovoltaic energy. By removing the inverter, filter, and converter and reducing the complexity of the controller that is used for systems connected to AC loads, the system specifications will improve in the following aspects: system efficiency, size, and overall cost. An intelligent maximum power point tracker is designed using a simple neural network algorithm to guarantee harvesting maximum solar energy as an equivalent DC electricity to store the electrical energy in a suitable battery bank. This study demonstrates an accurate calculation and a comparison for a real case study and proves a high priority to the proposed DC unit compared to AC unit in terms of system efficiency and cost. The collected simulation results using MATLAB/Simulink demonstrate an effective algorithm with a mean squared error of 4.3534 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−5</sup> at epoch 214. By considering a certain real case study of a 1 kW load, the efficiency of the proposed DC system solution is 99.8%, and is used to supply DC appliances compared to 87.22% of a traditional PV system used to supply AC appliance of the same load power.

title: Spectrum Sensing Algorithm Based on Deep Belief Network and Bidirectional Long Short-term Memory Network in Cognitive Internet of Things
authors: Shiqing Xu, Ling Pei
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: To solve problems, such as low sensing accuracy and weak anti-interference ability caused by the dynamic spectrum environment in the cognitive Internet of Things (IoT), we developed a collaborative spectrum sensing algorithm based on the deep belief network (DBN) and the bidirectional long short-term memory network (BiLSTM). Firstly, DBN is used to perform unsupervised hierarchical feature extraction on multidimensional spectrum signals, exploring the statistical characteristics and nonlinear correlations of the signals. Secondly, considering the periodic and fluctuating characteristics of mobile wireless signals, a time-series classification and sensing model was designed. The developed algorithm employs an improved long short-term memory (LSTM) neural network as the spectrum sensing classifier to determine the dynamic threshold being through offline training. Subsequently, online testing was employed to evlaluate the spectrum sensing results. The developed spectrum sensing algorithm (DBN-LSTM) was verified in two modulation schemes and five signal-to noise ratios (SNRs). The results demonstrated that, LeNet5, learning vector quantization, and Elman algorithm, and DBN-LSTM enhanced the sensing accuracy by approximately 45% with a higher time efficiency.

title: Elastic Additive Angular Margin Loss Integrated with Mixup for Anomalous Sound Detection
authors: Yihao Zhao, Yichen Yang, Xiao Zhang, Shoji Makino
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Unsupervised anomalous sound detection (ASD) aims to detect anomalous sounds by modeling only normal sounds. Conventional methods use classification-based selfsupervised neural network models to identify normal and abnormal sounds. Building on this idea, Additive Angular Margin Loss (ArcFace) is utilized to enhance intra-class compactness and inter-class discrepancy of normal classes. Furthermore, previous methods introduce mixup to ensure intra-class compactness and alleviate the overlap of normal and anomalous data distributions. However, the additive angular margin applies only to a single target logit but not to learning from interpolated labels and samples generated by mixup. Additionally, its fixed margin is unsuitable for data with inconsistent intra-class and inter-class variations. To solve these issues, we propose a training method applying an elastic angular margin loss to mixup data augmentation, namely Elastic-Margin-Mixup (EMM). The proposed EMM weights the margin penalty by the interpolation factor, enabling the ArcFace loss to adapt appropriately to interpolated samples. Moreover, it introduces proportional randomization across differently weighted margins to further help the model handle inconsistent variations both between and within classes. On the DCASE 2020 Challenge Task 2 dataset, experimental results demonstrate that our proposed EMM achieved an AUC of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 5. 0 3 \%}$</tex> and a pAUC of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 9. 9 5 \%}$</tex>, surpassing previous approaches integrating ArcFace and mixup for anomalous sound detection.

title: Exploration of Gearbox Multi-Step Remaining Useful Life Prediction based on LLM and PEFT
authors: Wenchao Zhan, Laifa Tao, Zhengduo Zhao, Zijian Huang, Zhixuan Lian
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Gearboxes are essential components in mechanical systems, and accurately predicting their remaining useful life (RUL) is vital for implementing effective predictive maintenance strategies. In particular, multi-step RUL prediction facilitates the early detection of potential failures, thereby significantly improving system reliability and operational safety. However, existing lightweight deep learning models often face challenges in multi-step RUL prediction, primarily due to limited training data and constrained representational capacity. Recent advances in large language models (LLM) have shown remarkable generalization abilities and expressive embedding power, suggesting a promising new direction for addressing these limitations. In this study, we propose an end-to-end framework for multi-step RUL prediction of gearboxes, which harnesses the representational strengths of LLMs. The framework integrates parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT) techniques to adapt LLMs effectively to time series forecasting tasks while maintaining computational efficiency. Experimental evaluations on a benchmark gearbox dataset demonstrate the superior performance and practical viability of the proposed approach.

title: Identifying Speaker Information in Feed-Forward Layers of Self-Supervised Speech Transformers
authors: Tzu-Quan Lin, Hsi-Chun Cheng, Hung-yi Lee, Hao Tang
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: In recent years, the impact of self-supervised speech Transformers has extended to speaker-related applications. However, little research has explored how these models encode speaker information. In this work, we address this gap by identifying neurons in the feed-forward layers that are correlated with speaker information. Specifically, we analyze neurons associated with k-means clusters of self-supervised features and i-vectors. Our analysis reveals that these clusters correspond to broad phonetic and gender classes, making them suitable for identifying neurons that represent speakers. By protecting these neurons during pruning, we can significantly preserve performance on speaker-related task, demonstrating their crucial role in encoding speaker information.

title: Resource Optimization of Satellite Aircraft Network Coverage Based on Double Deck Dynamic Game Theory
authors: Yuhe Yang, Yunhe Sun, Shenglin Geng, Kang Yang, Dongsheng Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: With the rapid development of satelliteassisted satellite networks, the imbalance in satelliteaircraft communication resource allocation has become a critical bottleneck constraining network service quality. Traditional static allocation schemes and single-layer optimization mechanisms struggle to meet the varying demands of dynamic network environments. In response to this challenge, this paper proposes a dual-layer dynamic game architecture for optimized resource allocation. This architecture includes an initial game layer dominated by aircraft nodes and a secondary game layer led by satellite platforms. By dynamically optimizing utility functions, incorporating historical behavior preference mechanisms, and employing adaptive decision-making strategies, the proposed method achieves cross-layer collaborative resource allocation. Simulation results demonstrate that this approach ensures network performance stability while achieving comprehensive performance improvements, including reduced energy consumption, enhanced resource utilization, and optimized load balancing.

title: Investigation of Appropriate Condition for Induction of Unfolded Protein Response of Endoplasmic Reticulum in EGFP-293A Cells by Application of Nanosecond Pulsed Electric Fields
authors: Kuma Minakata, Masahiro Hirata, Yoshimasa Hamada, Seiichi Oyadomari, Naoyuki Shimomura
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The endoplasmic reticulum (ER), involved in protein synthesis, becomes stressed under various stimuli, which may lead to diseases such as diabetes mellitus. The unfolded protein response (UPR), as an ER stress response, has been reported to be activated by nanosecond pulsed electric fields (nspEFs). However, the activation is weak or cell dependent. Strong UPR activation by nsPEFs could be useful for preventing or treating ER stress-related diseases. This study aimed to determine suitable nsPEF conditions for UPR activation. Using a Blumelein pulse-forming line (B-PFL), nsPEFs were applied to EGFP-293A cells, which express green fluorescent protein (GFP) upon UPR activation. The pulse width, voltage, and pulse number were varied. Cell viability was measured immediately and 24 hours after nsPEF exposure, and fluorescence intensity was analyzed. GFP fluorescence increased compared to untreated samples, with significant enhancement under some conditions, although cell viability was reduced in those cases. These results suggest that UPR activation and cell death occur under closely related conditions.

title: Blazed gratings: effect of antiblaze angle on diffraction efficiency at normal and grazing light incidence
authors: Leonid I. Goray
publish: 2025 Days on Diffraction (DD)
abstract: The effect of the antiblaze angle on the diffraction efficiency of a single-periodic grating with a triangular groove profile shape (blazed) irradiated with electromagnetic radiation is examined. Three general cases of diffraction are investigated: (1) resonant— at the normal or near-normal incidence of light; (2) short-wave—at the grazing incidence of light in classical diffraction; (3) short-wave—at the oblique incidence of light in conical diffraction. Efficiency computations have been performed by a PCGrate<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">TM</sup> code, based on boundary integral equations, and new features are observed both for cases of the perfect and for the finite conductivity of the grating material.

title: Development of a 500 kV Tesla-Transformer Based Pulsed Generator in Off-Resonance Mode
authors: Gideon Nimo Appiah, Aaesha Al Ali, Umar Hashmi, Hamad Deiban, Fernando Albarracin, Felix Vega
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: This work presents the design, analysis, and experimental validation of a 500 kV Tesla-transformer-based pulsed generator operating in an off-resonance mode. The pulsed generator employs an open ferromagnetic core to achieve near-unity resonance between the primary and secondary circuits for an optimum energy transfer to the load during the first quarter of the wave oscillation. The pulse-forming line of the generator is filled with transformer oil which enhances the dielectric insulation of the line during its microsecond charging time typical of the off-resonance mode of operation. The designed generator producing a 250 kV output voltage with a pulse duration of 10 ns when coupled to a 65Ω load is validated through simulation and experimentation.

title: Adaptive Self-Triggered Impulsive Fault-Tolerant Control for Multi-Player Constrained Systems
authors: Lu Liu, Ruizhuo Song, Lina Xia
publish: IEEE/CAA Journal of Automatica Sinica
abstract: Considering that actual systems are often constrained by multiple factors such as state limitation, actuator saturation and actuator failure at the same time, this paper provides an effective solution for non-affine multi-player systems, which can guarantee the required performance while saving communication cost. Initially, an auxiliary system is established to accommodate state limitations, following which the controller design is partitioned into two distinct segments, addressing different types of faults. Specifically, the discontinuous and continuous aspects of the controller are achieved by sliding-mode control (SMC) and adaptive critic design (ACD), respectively. During the implementation of ACD to solve the guaranteed value function incorporating the utility function designed for the asymmetric saturation of the control input, two adaptive schemes including adaptive event-triggered impulsive control (AETIC) and adaptive self-triggered impulsive control (ASTIC) are introduced successively. It is proved that the system maintains exponential stability rather than asymptotic stability and the state signals keep ultimately uniformly bounded (UUB). Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed control sequence is verified by simulation comparisons.

title: LLM4AV: Hybrid LSTM-RAG Framework for Fault-Tolerant Decision-Making in Simulated AV Corner Cases
authors: Raneem Khafagy, Esmot Ara Tuli, Jae Min Lee, Dong-Seong Kim
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) require robust fault-tolerant systems for safe mission-critical operation. This paper presents a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM)-based fault detector integrated with a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)-based Large Language Model (LLM) agent for AV decision-making. The LSTM model detects anomalies in LiDAR data, while the RAG-LLM agent proposes safe actions using contextual retrieval of traffic rules. Evaluated in the CARLA simulator, the system demonstrated effective fault detection and decision-making under simulated sensor faults and corner cases. Results show a fault detection precision of 0.92, recall of 0.87, and F1 score of 0.89. The RAG-LLM agent achieved a rule compliance rate of 94.7%, with the system maintaining an average safety margin of 3.95 meters. The results validate the framework's potential applicability in more complex, real-world AV environments.

title: Speech Enhancement Network with Windowed Cross Attention Using Noise-Reference Microphone
authors: Kota Suzuki, Yosuke Sugiura, Tetsuya Shimamura
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: In this study, we propose an enhancement to a multichannel speech enhancement network that leverages a noisereference microphone. Our primary contribution is the introduction of a Windowed Cross-Attention (WCA) mechanism, designed to more effectively fuse features from a primary microphone capturing mixed speech and a secondary microphone capturing environmental noise. This paper presents a comparative evaluation of our proposed method (WCA) against several baseline architectures: a standard multi-channel DEMUCS (DEMUCS-m), our prior noise-fusion architecture (DEMUCS-prop), and a deep non-linear filter (DNLF). Experiments conducted in a simulated acoustic space assess each method in terms of objective speech quality metrics, followed by detailed analysis and discussion.

title: The Liouville-Lanczos Method of Timedependent Density-Functional Theory for Modeling Plasma Xrts Spectrum Across a Wide Range of Frequencies and Momentum Transfer Values
authors: Z. Moldabekov
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: In X-ray Thomson scattering (XRTS) experiments, the dynamic structure factor (DSF) of electrons (convolved with a probing X-ray beam and instrument function) is measured [1]. Linear response time-dependent density functional theory (LR-TDDFT) is a key ab initio method for simulating the DSF [2]–[5]. However, its reliance on orbital representation presents a significant drawback: as wavenumber increases, the need for empty bands grows, making LR-TDDFT impractical for XRTS modeling across large energy scales. In this work [6], we consider an alternative approach that employs the Liouville-Lanczos (LL) method [7], [8] for simulating the DSF. This method does not require empty states and allows access to the DSF at large momentum transfer values and a broad frequency range. We compare the LL results with those from the standard LR-TDDFT for isochorically heated aluminum and warm dense hydrogen.

title: Machine Learning-Optimized Load Balancing Algorithm for Indian Data Centers
authors: Shaik Maheboob, N. Raghava Rao, Neha Bonsale, Rishabh Tomar, Sophia S, Nidal Al Nidal Al Said
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: This paper has tried to develop a machine learning-optimized load balancing algorithm that would apply specifically to an Indian data center with the expectation of improving performance, efficiency, and scalability. The method consists of Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning (MADRL) to address the decentralized decision-making problem, Federated LSTM Forecasting to produce quality and privacy-preserving workload forecasting and Digital Twin Simulation to simulate and test the system learning in a realistic virtual environment. The system is implemented based on the Ray RLlib framework that allows the intelligent distribution of tasks of geographically distributed data centers and works with local energy allocation and data privacy laws. The achieved result using the experimental assessment shows substantial benefits such as a decrease in response time, increase in CPU usage, low power consumption, and fewer SLA violations inclusive of the standard approaches Round Robin and Static Heuristics. The combination of federated learning will make sure that the data is localized, and the digital twin to facilitate low-risk, low-cost testing. The findings point towards the success of the proposed framework as an extendable and flexible approach towards new-age Indian data center systems.

title: Large Sparse Covariance Matrix Estimation via Dual Proximal Gradient Method
authors: Fengpei Li, Ziping Zhao
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Covariance matrix estimation in high dimensions is a central problem in data science, signal processing, and machine learning, yet it remains challenging due to the need to ensure both statistical accuracy and computational efficiency. In this paper, we revisit the positive definite covariance estimation framework of [1] and develop an efficient primal-dual algorithm that alternately updates primal and dual variables. We demonstrate that the proposed method can be interpreted equivalently as a proximal gradient scheme in the dual domain. The algorithm inherently preserves positive definiteness throughout the iterations and is provably globally linearly convergent. Numerical experiments establish the superiority of the proposed algorithm over state-of-the-art methods, highlighting its effectiveness for high-dimensional covariance estimation.

title: Adaptive Algorithms for Enhanced Night Vision in Highway Traffic Management
authors: Zheye Tian, Chong Feng, Zhonghua Wang, Liqin Fu, Ruoxu Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: By integrating night vision technology and adaptive algorithms, we increased highway traffic management, especially in low visibility conditions. The developed system facilitates real-time traffic monitoring. Image outputs from the previous systems are degraded by motion-induced blur, diminishing their practical effectiveness. To address this limitation, adaptive algorithms were developed in this study to adjust parameters of exposure, contrast, and resolution under ambient lighting and severe weather conditions to enhance image clarity. The developed algorithms enhance object detection and tracking capabilities in the YOLO and Faster R-CNN architectures and improve detection accuracy and robustness in diverse nighttime conditions. The deployment of the developed system reduces traffic accidents, improves roadway safety, and optimizes nighttime traffic flow. The system’s performance and scalability were validated through case studies. The developed system can be used in smart cities supporting intelligent and resilient urban mobility ecosystems.

title: Quantum Computing-Assisted Data Mining for Advanced Network Intrusion Detection
authors: N. Nithyalakshmi, A. Muthukumaravel
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Network intrusion detection systems (IDS) are one of the data-intensive applications that could be drastically changed by the advent of quantum computing. This research proposes an innovative framework for enhanced network intrusion detection called Quantum Computing-Assisted Data Mining (QCADM). The framework overcomes the shortcomings of traditional approaches to dealing with complicated, massive amounts of network traffic data by using algorithms supplemented with quantum bits for feature selection, grouping, and classification. To enhance computing efficiency and optimize anomaly detection, QCADM uses quantum versions of Support Vector Machines (qSVMs) and Principal Component Analysis (qPCA). This result of the NSL-KDD dataset indicates that the framework beats traditional methods: 40% faster with much lower false positive rates. According to research, quantum computing offers a scalable and economical approach to handle complicated cyber threats and, hence, intrusion detection systems can be improved. In the further efforts, the study will overcome the limitations of present quantum gear and move towards real-world deployment.

title: Review of Deepfake Detection Techniques and Challenges
authors: Nur Shidah Ahmad Sharawardi, Siaw-Hong Liew, Punitha Turumugon, Angkay Subramaniam
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: The proliferation of deepfake technology, powered by advanced generative models such as generative adversarial networks (GANs), presents challenges in digital media authenticity, public trust, and cybersecurity. We reviewed recent advancements in deepfake detection across multiple modalities, including image, video, and audio. Benchmark datasets, such as FaceForensics++, the deepfake detection challenge (DFDC), and Celeb-deepfake (Celeb-DF), have been used to develop diverse detection models. These models encompass approaches based on EfficientNet-driven transfer learning, convolutional neural network-long short-term memory (CNN-LSTM) hybrids for temporal feature extraction, graph-based neural architectures, and ensemble methods that integrate deep learning with handcrafted features. Although certain models report detection accuracies as high as 99.99% on specific datasets, many exhibit limited generalizability across different benchmarks, particularly when confronted with compression artifacts. Additionally, real-time deployment remains constrained by substantial computational demands. Emerging threats, including adversarial perturbations and diffusion-based synthetic media, necessitate the development of more resilient detection strategies. Proactive countermeasures such as blockchain-based timestamping, digital watermarking, and cryptographic hashing have been adopted to enhance media integrity. The results of the review underscore the need for lightweight, interpretable, and multimodal detection frameworks to generalize the models' applicability across diverse domains, thereby supporting reliable and scalable media verification in increasingly complex digital environments.ion.

title: A Computer Vision Pipeline to Augment Touchscreen Tasks for Chimpanzees
authors: William Lubetkin, Christopher Flynn Martin, Isabella Walker, Jake Peacock, Ryan J. Eller
publish: Proceedings of the ACM 12th International Conference on Animal-Computer Interaction
abstract: Touchscreen tasks have long been a valuable tool for examining primate cognition and are now also being used at zoos to enhance animal enrichment and guest experience. We introduce a fully automated pipeline for chimpanzee facial recognition that allows for individual identification during touchscreen task engagement. Our system incorporates a YOLOv8 bounding box detector and a fine-tuned ConvNeXt classifier to detect and assign identities to chimpanzees recorded via video streams captured by an embedded camera. We implement a confidence-weighted sliding window approach to mitigate classification errors from low quality input footage. Using these techniques, we were able to achieve a high confidence identification (>80% of video duration) despite noisy video and frequent low-confidence model classifications.  This work enhances research, enrichment, and conservation techniques applied to great apes.

title: What is An "Animal" Anyways?: From Essentialism to Social Construction Through Research on ACI
authors: Lena Ashooh, Rebecca Kleinberger
publish: Proceedings of the ACM 12th International Conference on Animal-Computer Interaction
abstract: New technologies can produce changes in concepts, such as how the concept of work changed with online interfaces, money changed with new currency technologies, and cancer changed with the introduction of microscope technology. Research on animal-computer interactions (ACI) has changed concepts like user, welfare, evaluation, and participatory design, as the design of technology with animals as users, participants, and beneficiaries has required new concepts. We propose that ACI research has the potential to transform an even more fundamental concept: what an “animal” is. We hypothesize that ACI researchers have often been operating with essentialist concepts of animal categories such as species, breeds, or even categories like dog, bird, ape, and wild animal, where those grouping have aimed to reflect “biological” or “natural” groups that are fixed and unchanging. Drawing from the social philosophers Sally Haslanger’s and Ian Hacking’s methods of analyzing socially constructed categories, we propose that the essentialist concept of animal categories could inhibit ACI research and produce technologies that reinforce the existence of such categories. In turn, research on animal-technology interactions, if conducted with a social constructionist conception, could disrupt conceptions of animal categories, revealing ways in which animal categories are produced by animals’ material and social conditions, including their technological realities, and could change with changing technologies, opening new doors for ACI research and beyond.

title: Comparison of Empire and GAZEL Simulations of Intense Electron Beam Transport Through Background Gas
authors: C. H. Moore, P. Grua, E. N. Rajbhandari, T. Dhote, N. Szalek, E. L. Rhoades, D. Hebert, M. Mazarakis, K. Cartwright
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: In this work, we compare Empire and GAZEL simulations of the RKA (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 500 \text{keV}, 3-30 \text{kA},<100 \text{ns}$</tex>) electron beam's propagation through a pressurized Ar gas cell. Empire is a general plasma code that can be run as a fully kinetic Particle-In-Cell (PIC) problem with Direct Simulation Monte Carlo (DSMC) collisions or as a hybrid problem with both fluid and PIC charged species. They collide with a background neutral fluid via fluid-fluid rate-based interactions and PIC-fluid Monte Carlo Collisions (MCC) that produce a charged fluid of low-energy secondary plasma. GAZEL is a hydrid code operating in axisymmetric geometry. In the version of the code that is used, primary and secondary electrons are described by a PIC model, while neutral atoms and ions are described via a fluid. For ionization of neutral atoms and ions, GAZEL utilizes a MCC procedure between computational electron particles and the heavy species fluid. Here we compare the beam dynamics across a range of gas cell pressures (0.01-1.0 mbar) for fully kinetic Empire and hybrid GAZEL simulations in detail. Additionally, we compare the simulated beam on target with experimental RKA results.

title: Design and Comparison of High-Voltage Capacitor Charging Topologies for Pulsed-Power Applications
authors: F. Haag, F. Albrecht, V. Brommer, O. Liebfried, K. F. Hoffmann
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: High power capacitors are irreplaceable components in pulse power generators which are needed for the generation of short (ns-ms) pulses of very high power (MW-TW). Typically, a high-voltage power converter is required to charge the capacitors up to several kilovolts. In order to achieve a high repetition rate, high power in the range of megawatts is necessary. A compact design is essential since the railgun system is supposed to be mobile. In addition, a high electrical efficiency is important to keep both, the cooling effort and the primary energy demand low. Literature research shows that resonant converters are perfectly suited for these requirements since they provide high efficiency and the option for a modular design. Due to their low (switching) losses, the switching frequency can be increased, which decreases the size of other complementary components and ultimately increases the power density. Given the intricate nature of resonant converters, developers are faced with various design choices.

title: Satellite Computing Network Construction: Optimal Computing Node Deployment in Multi-layer LEO Mega-constellations
authors: Xiao Jia, Di Zhou, Min Sheng, Yan Shi, Sijing Ji, Jiandong Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: Satellite computing networks leverage the placement of computing resources on low-Earth orbit (LEO) satellite communication network to bring computing power closer to users, enabling robust and scalable solutions for emerging applications such as Internet of thing, edge computing and real-time analysis. However, with the explosion of multi-layer LEO mega-constellations(MLMCs), how to use the least number of computing nodes to achieve computing power resource coverage? This paper proposes a computing node deployment algorithm for MLMCs to construct satellite computing network with the minimum number of computing node. Specifically, we analyze the existence conditions of optimal computing node deployment, and derive the expression of the relationship between the number of computing nodes needed on the LEO, the multi-layer satellite network structure and the number of accessible hops of computing nodes. The expression can determine the minimum number of computing nodes needed to be placed on the MLMCs to realize optimal computing node deployment under a certain number of accessible hops. Then, according to the limitation of optimal computing node deployment, a multi-layer satellite network computing node deployment algorithm is proposed to determine the position of the computing resource in MLMCs, which can form a stable computing structure in satellite network. Finally, through simulation, the influence of network scale and computing node deployment on the number of required computing nodes and the effectiveness of signaling delay is analyzed. The simulation results show that this method can achieve better delay with the least number of computing nodes, balance the number of computing nodes and delay, and meet the specific network requirements.

title: Movable Antenna Aided Multiuser Communications: Antenna Position Optimization Based on Statistical Channel Information
authors: Ge Yan, Lipeng Zhu, Rui Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: The movable antenna (MA) technology has attracted great attention recently due to its promising capability in improving wireless channel conditions by flexibly adjusting antenna positions. To reap maximal performance gains of MA systems, existing works mainly focus on MA position optimization to cater to the instantaneous channel state information (CSI). However, the resulting real-time antenna movement may face challenges in practical implementation due to the additional time overhead and energy consumption required, especially in fast time-varying channel scenarios. To address this issue, we propose in this paper a new approach to optimize the MA positions based on the users’ statistical CSI over a large timescale. In particular, we propose a general field response based statistical channel model to characterize the random channel variations caused by the local movement of users. Based on this model, a two-timescale optimization problem is formulated to maximize the ergodic sum rate of multiple users, where the precoding matrix and the positions of MAs at the base station (BS) are optimized based on the instantaneous and statistical CSI, respectively. To solve this non-convex optimization problem, a log-barrier penalized gradient ascent algorithm is developed to optimize the MA positions, where two methods are proposed to approximate the ergodic sum rate and its gradients with different complexities. Finally, we present simulation results to evaluate the performance of the proposed design and algorithms based on practical channels generated by ray-tracing. The results verify the performance advantages of MA systems compared to their fixed-position antenna (FPA) counterparts in terms of long-term rate improvement, especially for scenarios with more diverse channel power distributions in the angular domain.

title: Comparative Analysis of Physiological and Speech Signals for State Anxiety Detection in University Students in STEM
authors: Ayse Dogan, Richard B. Sowers, Manuel E. Hernandez
publish: IEEE Transactions on Affective Computing
abstract: Anxiety is a common mental health condition that can significantly impair daily functioning, especially for university students in STEM. State anxiety is a situational emotional response and is typically assessed through self-reported questionnaires and clinical interviews. These traditional methods only capture discrete snapshots of an individual's emotional state and rely heavily on retrospective reporting. To overcome the limitations of self-reporting, we use wearable and contactless sensors. We continuously monitor a set of physiological signals (electrodermal activity (EDA), blood volume pulse (BVP), heart rate variability (HRV), and skin temperature (TEMP)) along with a behavioral signal (Speech) to detect state anxiety in real-time. We evaluate the predictive capabilities of these signals concerning self-reported anxiety levels, as measured by the six-item State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI-6). Machine learning (ML) models are employed to classify participants into state anxiety risk groups based on two thresholds: clinical (STAI-6 score <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\gt $</tex-math></inline-formula> 15) and median-based (STAI-6 score <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\gt $</tex-math></inline-formula> median). Our results indicate that BVP outperforms other single modalities across classifiers, particularly when combined with TEMP, achieving true positive rates (TPRs) up to 0.90 under the median threshold. Additionally, speech features demonstrate competitive performance in certain conditions, while EDA, TEMP, and HRV exhibit greater variability. We believe that this study supports using wearables to monitor state anxiety.

title: Open-Set Domain Adaptive RF Fingerprint Identification Based on Prototype Calibration
authors: Zhen Hong, Jiahao Lin, Taotao Li, Jinhao Wan, Jie Su, Zhenyu Wen
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: As a fundamental security mechanism for wireless Internet of Things (IoT) devices, Radio Frequency Fingerprinting Identification (RFFI) faces significant challenges in open environments and cross-domain deployments. Among existing deep learning-based open-set recognition (OSR) methods, prototype-based approaches are widely adopted. However, these methods often suffer from prototype drift and feature misalignment between source and target domains due to channel effects, device load variations, and other factors. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a Prototype Calibration Domain Adaptation Framework guided by Pseudo-labeling and Domain-Adversarial Neural Networks (DANN), termed PCPD. The framework first leverages a prototype network to learn discriminative representations for each class in the source domain. Subsequently, it employs pseudo-label loss and a domain discriminator to dynamically calibrate domain-shifted prototype points, enhancing feature alignment across domains. Based on the calibrated prototypes, the method significantly improves OSR performance in cross-domain scenarios. Experimental results demonstrate that PCPD outperforms state-of-the-art algorithms, achieving an approximately 10.8% improvement in OSR accuracy under cross-domain conditions.

title: NRAG: A Knowledge-Enhanced LLM Framework for Interpretable Neurosurgical Disease Diagnosis in Outpatient and Emergency Settings
authors: Haoyu Tian, Yiming Liu, Xinyu Dai, Xin Dong, Jian Yu, Wei Wei, Boran Wang, Xuezhong Zhou
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in numerous domains, yet their clinical deployment faces critical barriers, particularly insufficient reasoning in complex scenarios and limited interpretability. These challenges are exacerbated in neurosurgical diagnosis for outpatient and emergency settings, where time-sensitive decision-making, fragmented data, and complex comorbidities render conventional free-text-based modeling approaches unreliable. To address the limitations of existing LLMs in medical auxiliary diagnosis, particularly in interpretability and predictive performance, this study proposed NRAG, an auxiliary diagnosis method that combines LLMs with knowledge graphs (KGs). It extracts symptom descriptions from clinical records and performs personalized retrieval of associated paths in KG, and supplements potential patient symptoms to optimize the diagnosis model. Comparative experiments involving multiple general-domain and medical-domain LLMs, along with case studies, were conducted to validate the NRAG's effectiveness. Experimental results demonstrate that integrating KG significantly improves diagnosis accuracy, achieving an F1-score of 0.8150. It also substantially improves model interpretability and performs excellently in expert evaluations. Ablation studies and comparative experiments with other general-domain and medical-domain LLMs confirm the superior performance of the proposed NRAG. NRAG effectively supplements missing symptom information and provides knowledge-path-based evidence for diagnosis results, while improving the precision and interpretability of intelligent diagnosis. Furthermore, this approach sets the foundation for intelligent diagnoses in neurosurgery while providing a methodological framework for the integration of in-depth clinical data mining with medical knowledge base resources.

title: Design of a 3D Switch Array with Fast Driver for Pulsed Power Generator
authors: H. Zhou, Y. Hao, Q. Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Pulsed power technology, with its emphasis on compactness, lightweight miniaturization and solid-state design, serves as the foundation for high-power microwave systems. While the application of semiconductor switches, such as Insulated Gate Bipolar Transistors (IGBTs), has accelerated the transition to more compact and solid-state systems, the redundant packaging originally designed for DC/AC operation limits further improvements in power density for pulsed power systems. This paper introduces a 3-D Switch Array (3DSA) module specifically designed for pulsed power technology based on IGBT bare dies. Through chip-on-chip 3D packaging, a large series-parallel switch array is distributed on both sides of a multilayer printed circuit board (PCB) substrate, significantly enhancing the power density. Additionally, the dual power loop structure of the 3DSA reduces parasitic inductance through decoupling, which plays a crucial role in achieving fast rise times in pulsed power systems. To synchronize the driving of the series-parallel switch array, a fast array driver circuit based on planar transformer isolation is designed, which, together with the switch array, forms the complete 3DSA module. Experimental results show that a 6-series, 6-parallel 3DSA module, operating at a 5.5 kV voltage and discharging at 3.3-ohm impedance, achieves a pulse current rise time of 39 ns (limited by the inductance of the discharge circuit), with a peak current of 1450 A. Compared to a discrete switch array, the peak volumetric power density and peak weight power density are increased by 7 times and 12 times, respectively. Finally, a prototype of the solid-state Blumlein generator is manufactured based on the 3DSA module. Under a 6.6-ohm resistive load, the generator achieved a quasi-square pulse with a current of 738 A, a voltage of 4974 V, a rise time of 24 ns and a pulse width of 130 ns.

title: The Optimized Design and Experimental Study of Metal Wire Explosion-Type DC Circuit Breaker in Magnetic Confinement Fusion System
authors: Z. Li, H. Li, J. Ye, X. Zhang, X. Bao, G. Gao
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Explosive-type DC circuit breakers (DCCBs) are widely used as backup protection switches in magnetic confinement fusion systems. Compared to traditional explosive-type DCCBs, pulse current-driven metal wire explosion-type DCCBs can generate plasma with higher energy density, producing strong shockwaves with advantages such as low cost and low pollution. This paper presents the design of the driving mechanism for the metal wire explosion-type DCCB and uses Ansys simulations to validate the rationality and reliability of the structure. A high-energy metal wire explosion experimental platform capable of storing hundreds of kilojoules was developed. The stability of the platform and the feasibility of the experimental setup were validated. By controlling external energy inputs and optimizing the metal wire material properties, the optimal correlation between the physical parameters of wires and the energy storage of the system was established. Experimental results confirmed the feasibility of the metal wire explosion-type DCCB in terms of shockwave intensity, interruption speed, and cost-effectiveness. The developed optimization formula significantly enhanced the shockwave energy produced by the metal wire explosion. The findings of this study provide a theoretical basis for the application of metal wire explosion-type DCCBs in magnetic confinement fusion devices and high-power DC switching applications.

title: Committees
