title: CAIFNet: Capturing Amplitude-Invariant Features for Remote Sensing Image Change Detection
authors: Zhihao Li, Yikun Liu, Minghao Liu, Wenkai Yan, Gongping Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Change detection (CD) is a critical task in remote sensing (RS) image analysis. Recent deep learning networks for CD focus on identifying changes after mining the features of bi-temporal images separately. However, light differences in bi-temporal images lead to the networks extracting different features from the identical objects, which may cause pseudo-changes. From the Fourier transform perspective, an image can be decomposed into amplitude and phase, where the amplitude contains most of the light information and the phase is relevant to structure information. Therefore, amplitude-invariant features of the identical objects in different light conditions are roughly the same, which are pivotal to identify real and fake changes between bi-temporal images. In this article, we propose a capturing amplitude-invariant features network (CAIFNet), which reduces dependence on amplitude and captures diverse amplitude-invariant features. Firstly, we build an amplitude pre-processing module (APM) to provide diverse processed images by randomly mixing the amplitudes of the input images with the amplitudes of the reference images and keeping the phases of the input images constant. Secondly, a quadruple-stream encoder is proposed to capture amplitude-invariant features. Specifically, it is forced to learn and capture amplitude-invariant local details and amplitude-invariant contextual semantics based on the diverse processed images under CD task-oriented constraint, both reciprocate each other to become more accurate by local attention guide strategy (LGS). Moreover, a difference enhancement module (DEM) is designed in the quadruple-stream encoder to enhance the difference features. Thirdly, a bi-stream decoder decodes the captured amplitude-invariant features in main and boundary difference perspectives, enhancing main body and boundary details of the objects in the change maps, respectively. Finally, a spatial embedded module (SEM) allows the main and boundary difference features to be embedded into each other, obtaining more complete change maps. On three remote sensing change detection (RSCD) datasets, CAIFNet achieves better transferability and results compared to state-of-the-art methods. The source code is available at https://github.com/yihui1230/CAIFNet.

title: Environment-adaptive navigation method for biorobots enhanced by the innate nature of insects_supp2-3636291.mp4
authors: Yao Li
publish: N/A
abstract: Biorobots involve embedding artificial components into a living insect to transform it into a controllable robot, which comes with the advantages of low energy consumption, quietness, and flexibility. However, no models have yet been developed to describe the randomness-filled motions of biorobots, and their unique biological properties are also underutilized. In this work, the locomotion responses of a biorobot to electrical stimuli were summarized. The constant-current signal was found to have a higher capacity for sustained stimuli than existing methods. The joint influence of wall and current factors on cockroach behavior was explored to establish an environment-adaptive control model describing their locomotion. This model was then used to propose an navigation method enhanced by the inherent nature of a biorobot. In an indoor scenario, the proposed method achieved a success rate of 78.6% with minimal runtime and stimulus number while the control group using conventional navigation methods achieved a success rate of 30%, with two or three times the runtime and stimulus number. Compared with other approaches, the proposed method facilitates high-precision and long-range navigation with a short navigation time and very low control costs.

title: Inrush Current Reduction of Three-Phase Transformers Using Optimal Energization Angle Control
authors: Jin-Sung Cho, Sung-Jun Park, Sang-Kil Lim
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: When a transformer is energized, the inrush current can reach several tens of times higher than the steady-state magnetizing current, which may cause maloperation of protective relays, voltage dips, and deterioration of power quality. The inrush current occurs when the applied voltage phase at the instant of energization does not coincide with the residual flux in the transformer core, resulting in excessive flux that drives the core into saturation. This paper proposes a method to reduce such inrush currents by controlling the optimal energization angle of three-phase transformers to minimize residual flux asymmetry. The proposed approach utilizes a phase-locked loop (PLL) to track the source voltage phase and applies the mathematically derived optimal energization angle to suppress the inrush current. The validity of the method was preliminarily verified through simulations and further confirmed experimentally under both no-load and load conditions. Based on the measured voltage and current waveforms, ϕ–i hysteresis loop analysis, harmonic spectrum, and total harmonic distortion (THD) evaluation were performed to compare the results quantitatively. The objective of this study is to clarify the mechanism of inrush current generation and to experimentally verify that inrush current can be effectively reduced through energization angle control by mitigating residual flux asymmetry.

OSDI is one of the flagship conferences in computer systems research, covering a broad range of topics including operating systems, distributed systems, and storage. title: Perceptions of Excessive Car Window Tinting Among Drivers in Kuala Lumpur: A Pilot Study with AI-Enhanced Analytical Perspectives
authors: Gauri Krishnaswamy, Hussain Zuhoor, Maisha Ibrahim
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Introduction: The popularity of excessive window tinting of cars is also increasing in metropolitan Malaysia because it reduces heat, has anti-glare effects and offers privacy. Nevertheless, its impact on road safety, especially, the loss of visibility in the low-light conditions and violation of regulatory limits, is still of concern. Despite Visible Light Transmission (VLT) rules in place in Malaysia, there still exists inconsistency in enforcement and perceived ideas of the same, which makes it a risk.Objective: The purpose of the present study was to investigate the perception of drivers on excessive window tinting in Kuala Lumpur concerning their awareness, perceived risk level, compliance behaviour, attitude to enforcement, and individual responsibility as well as the possible application of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in supporting data-driven road safety measures.Methods: A 6 section validated questionnaire was used to carry out a cross-sectional survey of 52 drivers. The analysis of data was performed using SPSS (descriptive statistics, one-way ANOVA, linear regression), and the study provides information on how AI-based modelling might be used to complement the traditional statistical methods by forecasting behavioural patterns and enhancing the monitoring of compliance.Findings: The respondents exhibited moderate knowledge of tinting regulations with many indicating that they had a neutral or limited knowledge. The excessive tinting was seen as a safety concern especially during low visibility. There were split compliance perception views with the majority of the people on the side that said there should be stricter compliance enforcement and personal responsibility.Conclusion: The research results indicate that policy efficacy and road safety might be improved with the help of focused public awareness, regular inspection, and AI-based analytics on compliance check-ups. The way in which AI-based perception analysis and predictive modelling can reinforce awareness campaigns, enforcement strategies, and regulatory compliance should be investigated in future research.

title: Directed Graph Dynamic Mode Decomposition for Nonlinear State-Space Modeling
authors: Hiromu Kanauchi, Ryuto Ito, Hiroyasu Yasuda, Masaaki Nagahara, Yuichi Tanaka, Shogo Muramatsu
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This paper proposes a directed graph filter bank for predicting river water level distributions using time-delay dynamic mode decomposition (tdDMD) and sparse modeling. The previously proposed sparse-coded time-delay graph dynamic mode decomposition (STG-DMD) derived time evolution equations from water level data on an undirected graph structure, achieving high-accuracy predictions by considering multiple location connections. However, because the connections were defined as undirected graphs, the river flow direction was not considered. Therefore, this paper aims to incorporate river flow direction using a directed graph structure. To verify the effectiveness of the proposed method, performance evaluation experiments were conducted using both artificial and real observation data. The reproducibility of the proposed method was evaluated using water level data generated by process-driven models. In the experiment, water level data were collected via web scraping from the Internet, and river water level distribution was predicted. The results of the performance evaluations demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms STG-DMD.

title: Multimodal AI-Enabled Learning Personalization System for Indian Education Reform
authors: Geetali Tilak, Dheeraj Singh, Debahuti Chakravorty, Jayashree Patole, Gayatri Kaple, Nilesh Anute
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: This paper envisages Multimodal AI-Enabled Learning Personalization System which is going to transform the education sector of India. The product incorporates various forms of data, such as text, video, and still images, to make the learning environment personalized to enhance the experience of students in the various schooling settings. The system accurately forecasts student engagement, learning outcomes with more than 85% thanks to Gradient Boosting Machine (GBM), an ensemble machine learning method. Due to the high performance of the deep learning framework TensorFlow, multimodal data integration and processing can be seamlessly achieved, and the technologies are suitable to perform multimodal data integration and processing in either high-resource or low-resource environments. This will go a long way in personalizing the education process because education is focused on the styles of learning and needs of a particular student to promote improved learning outcomes and participation. The capability to deploy the application on a mobile device, with the help of TensorFlow Lite, allows it to be accessible in remote and underdeveloped areas. The provided proposal solves the shortcomings of the classic approaches to education and preconditions the creation of adjustable, scaling learning models that will fit diverse educational environment that India.

title: Vibe Coding: A Multivocal Systematic Mapping Study
authors: Nicole Beaulieu, Sergiu Dascalu, Emily Hand
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Vibe coding is an emergent, intuitive, and expressive approach to software development and engineering. Though not yet formally defined, the concept blends AI-assisted tooling, human-AI co-creation, and developer-centered aesthetics and intuition. The concept is the focus of blogs, essays, and practitioner-generated content. Few scholarly publications directly address the concept, although many engage with its adjacent practices and conceptual foundations.This study synthesizes and maps the current state of literature, discussing vibe coding and related topics to identify themes, publication trends, and future research opportunities. Drawing on eight seed publications, which yielded a total of 54 screened publications, including 30 grey literature sources and 24 peer-reviewed articles, this multivocal systematic mapping study employs structured rationale codes, rigorous screening, and established guidance for incorporating practitioner literature.Our analysis identified four primary themes: tooling impact, developer experience, human-AI collaboration, and cultural and organizational support and change. We present a catalog of publications that advance the understanding of vibe coding, a mapping of emergent themes, and a foundation for future research and design considerations related to human-AI co-creative development.

title: Using Long Short-Term Memory, Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers, And Robustly Optimized Bert Approach in Identifying Personality Trait
authors: Wong Thin Lun, Lim Tong Ming
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: We explored deep learning models for predicting personality traits from text using the Big Five Personality Traits and Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI). We employed long short-term memory (LSTM), bidirectional encoder representations from transformers (BERT), and a robustly optimized BERT approach (RoBERTa) to analyze linguistic patterns for scalable and non-intrusive personality assessments in recruitment, education, and psychology. RoBERTa and BERT outperformed traditional models due to their self-attention mechanisms. They enhanced contextual understanding and effectively handled code-mixed text. Despite data imbalance and model generalization, the results of this study highlighted the potential of the models in personality analysis and the need for refinements for real-world applications.

title: Design and Implementation of Whyline4Java to Enhance Dynamic Debugging in Java Programming
authors: Tan Jun Wen, Glaret Shirley A-P Sinnappan, See Kwee Teck
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: To improve Java software engineering workflows, we introduced the Whyline4Java tool, an innovative interrogative debugging (ID) tool. The Whyline4Java tool, created as a plugin for the Eclipse Integrated Development Environment, allows developers to ask "why" and "why not" questions about program behavior to solve challenges in understanding and adapting complex codebases. Building on Amy J. Ko’s original Whyline for Java idea, the tool presents technological improvements with support for JDK 5 and higher, optimized memory usage, simplified installation, and a more understandable user interface. We integrated quantitative analysis (one-way analysis of variance and linear regression) with qualitative analysis (structured interviews and expert reviews). The tool significantly reduced debugging time, from 30.29% to 82.73% for five different debugging tasks. The tool can be a solution for Java developers as well as improvements in end-user software engineering (EUSE) which is useful for educators and researchers working on dynamic debugging methodologies.

title: The Purechain Blockchain Network: An Overview
authors: Dong-Seong Kim, Ikechi Saviour Igboanusi, George Chidera Akor
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive overview of the Purechain blockchain network, a novel architecture specif-ically engineered for enhanced efficiency, robust security, and optimized resource utilization within permissioned blockchain environments. We delve into its core design principles, detailing the synergistic combination of its primary architectural features that contribute to overall network stability and performance. The paper further analyzes key network performance characteristics, supported by evaluation insights, and contextualizes Purechain's applicability for demanding enterprise and Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) sectors. The aim is to provide an in-depth under-standing of the Purechain network's architecture, its operational advantages, and its potential impact on practical blockchain deployments.

title: IoT and Long-Range Antennas: Challenges, Solutions and Comparison in the Next Generation
authors: Jayson P. Rogelio, Don Lorenzo F. Dela Cruz, Juan Paolo C. Escasura, Marci Angelo Q. Lara, Kate Zyrll M. Plantilla, Von Jansen G. Comedia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: Central to the success of IoT systems are long-range antennas, which enable communication over vast distances, even in challenging environments. These antennas are essential for applications requiring reliable connectivity, low energy consumption, and accurate data transmission. However, as IoT technologies advance, challenges such as signal interference, energy efficiency, and deployment in remote areas must be addressed to realize their full potential. This study evaluates the performance of long-range antennas in three distinct IoT systems: remote environmental monitoring, smart metering for water, gas, and electricity, and smart building and facility management. These systems utilize different long-range communication technologies, including Sigfox, LoRaWAN, and NB-IoT, optimized for specific use cases. By analyzing these technologies, the research compares their effectiveness in terms of location coverage, energy efficiency, and signal transmission accuracy. This comparative analysis offers insights into the strengths and limitations of each technology, providing guidance for improving IoT deployments. Additionally, the study examines the challenges faced by IoT systems using long-range antennas and suggests potential solutions to enhance their performance. The findings contribute to the development of next-generation IoT technologies, emphasizing the importance of long-range antennas in fostering innovation, ensuring sustainable energy use, and maintaining reliable communication in diverse, demanding environments.

title: Thermodynamic Properties of Dense Hydrogen Plasma
authors: A. T. Nuraly, M. M. Seisembayeva, K. N. Dzhumagulova, E. O. Shalenov
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Researchers worldwide are increasingly interested in dense, non-ideal plasma, where structural interactions are crucial. This interest stems from both academic curiosity and technological applications. Dense plasma appears in nuclear explosions, supersonic object motion through planetary atmospheres, and pulsed thermonuclear fusion using laser, electron, ion, or explosive compression. This study explores the thermodynamics of dense hydrogen plasma, focusing on the Mott transition. Using the Saha equation with ionization potential depression, it examines free energy, internal energy, and pressure, emphasizing bound states with Coulomb screening effects, which have been thoroughly studied in several works [1]–[5].

title: A User-Guided and Local Motion-Adaptive Framework for Virtual Product Placement in Video
authors: Tianwen Zhang, Ju-Won Seo, Kang-Min Kim, Keunsoo Ko
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Virtual product placement (VPP) aims to seamlessly insert a product into a pre-recorded video. It is gaining attention as a flexible and scalable strategy for digital advertising, where user preferences and subjective choices should be considered. However, the conventional VPP methods adopt fully automatic insertion frameworks without user involvement, which limits their adaptability to subjective scenarios. To address this limitation, we proposed a user-guided and local motion-adaptive framework, called ULM-VPP, for video VPPs. Given a video and a virtual product, the proposed system obtains an initial target region for the product placement and nearby keypoints in the first frame for minimal user interaction. For each subsequent frame, both the target region and virtual product are realigned based on local motion inferred from the keypoints. Finally, the virtual product is inserted seamlessly into the updated region over all frames while maintaining temporal consistency. Experiments across various video sequences demonstrate that ULM-VPP produces geometrically stable and visually coherent results. The source code is available at https://github.com/halikes/ULM-VPP

title: LLM-Based Dysarthric Communication Aid with Text and Voice Output
authors: Meenakshi Malhotra, Giridhar S, Girisha G.S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Speech recognition technology still does not meet the needs of a majority of people who suffer from dysarthria. Existing systems provide transcripts that end up being broken and disjointed and grammatically flawed and unable to convey speaker intended meaning. Such systems regard transcription as the end of the conversation process rather than the beginning points for understanding. This paper comes up with a new assistive system that employs post-processing to build meaning in an intelligent way. The system's core works on FLAN-T5-Large that acts as a robust language model to reason about contextual information and semantic relations. The system works through three interdependent steps: the initial step utilizes a Whisper ASR model specifically trained on dysarthric speech to translate audio into raw text. The language model then applies this text to create meaningful fluent language that mirrors what the speaker wished to say. The last part of the system employs a Text-to-Speech synthesizer to transcribe the corrected text into natural and expressive speech output. The system converts disfluent input into comprehensible expression to enable people with dysarthria to communicate fluently.

title: Exploring ConvNeXt and Vision Transformers for Classifying Messier Objects in Astronomical Images
authors: Amirreza Rouhbakhshmeghrazi, Bo Li, Talha Munir Rana, Sheida Shadman, Shayan Nalbandian, Mohammad Reza Hassannezhad
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: The rapid advancement of deep learning has transformed astronomical image analysis, enabling the efficient processing and classification of vast datasets generated by modern telescopes. Traditional Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) have been pivotal in tasks such as celestial object classification; yet their limitations in capturing global context have spurred interest in Transformer-Based architectures. In this study, we explore the efficacy of ConvNeXt, a modern CNN enhanced with Transformer-Inspired features, and Vision Transformer variants (ViT, Swin Transformer, DeiT, BEiT) for classifying seven Messier objects from a curated dataset of astronomical images. We benchmark these models against conventional CNNs (ResNet-50, EfficientNet, MobileNet, Inception). Our results reveal that the Swin Transformer achieves the highest test accuracy (97.14%), followed closely by ConvNeXt (96.43%), while DeiT and BEiT excel in training (99.96%) but show reduced generalization. These findings suggest that Swin Transformer and ConvNeXt offer a superior balance between accuracy and scalability for astronomical tasks, highlighting the potential of hybrid architectures to address the challenges of large-scale celestial datasets and paving the way for future advancements in automated astronomical classification.

title: Task-Based Motion Planning Optimization for Digital Twin-Enhanced Robotic Systems
authors: Nguyen Quang Chien, The-Thinh Pham, Chi-Cuong Tran, Quang Huan Dong, Khang H. V. Nguyen, Hoang-Huy Tran, Tan Do-Duy, Tuan-Khanh Nguyen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: Efficient motion planning is essential for the effective operation of digital twin (DT) systems, especially in complex and dynamic environments. By selecting appropriate algorithms based on the specific task, the performance of robotic systems can be significantly enhanced. We introduced a motion planning optimization framework for digital twin systems and task-based algorithm selection to improve robotic performance across various environments. The proposed methodology is used to evaluate multiple motion planning algorithms by generating and analyzing robotic paths based on task-specific criteria, such as path length, smoothness, collision avoidance, energy efficiency, and execution time. These metrics were weighted according to the task’s requirements for the selection of algorithm for optimizing the trajectory in manufacturing and other industrial applications. The methodology enhances flexibility and efficiency, allowing robots to adapt to varying task demands and operational conditions effectively.

title: Virtual Electrode - Driven Graph and Contrastive Learning Framework for EEG Based Stress Detection
authors: Deeparani S, Sumathy G
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Optimal electrode selection is a critical challenge in EEG-based mental stress detection. This work proposes a novel framework combining virtual electrode generation, Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs), contrastive learning, and channel-wise attention to enhance spatial resolution, robustness, and adaptability across subjects. Virtual electrodes improve spatial detail through interpolation, while GCNs capture spatial correlations between real and synthetic electrodes. Contrastive learning enhances the discriminability of the features by making similar or closely related stress-level embeddings close and the dissimilar or far apart and data augmentation enhances the generalizing ability of the model when subjected to different conditions. The channel attention mechanism is used to dynamically emphasis or de-emphasize the electrode importance in order to minimize the noise effect. Through the thorough testing in DEAP and SWELL-KW datasets, the accuracy is excellent (95.21 percent), the generalization is good since the testing is done on subject-independent mode, and the system is robust to noisy and skewed data. Our method has been proposed as ready to be deployed in real-time, which is an excellent solution to robust and interpretable EEG-based stress detection.

title: Distributed Extended Object Tracking with Adaptive Networks
authors: Kaidi Yang, Wei Xia, Mengqing Zhou
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: In this work, we consider tracking an elliptical extended object with adaptive networks. We propose a distributed extended object tracking algorithm for adaptive networks based on the diffusion strategy. The simulation results validate the superior performance as well as the computational efficiency of the proposed DEOT algorithm for adaptive networks.

title: Pixel-Level Cryptographic Hashing for Image Authentication and Recovery
authors: Yu-Cheng Chang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: Ensuring image authenticity and integrity is challenging in digital security. Therefore, a novel pixel-level cryptographic hashing method was developed in this study for image authentication and recovery. By extracting and encrypting RGB pixel values, the process generates a unique cryptographic representation that serves as the image's digital fingerprint. The generated hash is stored in a structured format, allowing efficient verification and reconstruction. The method detects any modification to the image, even at a minor pixel level, through hash mismatches. Furthermore, the system enables image restoration using the stored pixel information, providing an additional layer of security. The effectiveness of the method was verified in maintaining image integrity while allowing secure verification and reconstruction. The developed method advances digital forensics, watermarking, and secure image transmission applications.

title: Innovative Voltage Detection and Grounding Solutions for Enhanced Safety in Transmission Line Maintenance
authors: Yu Jiang, Lin Wei, Dan Li, Ziming An, Xiaojie Yan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: We developed a method for detecting voltage and grounding systems for safe and reliable transmission line maintenance. Standard maintenance procedures pose risks to personnel by acquiring inefficient and unsafe working methods. Therefore, we studied how smart sensors and the Internet of Things applications are used to monitor real-time operations while analyzing data. The method ensures workplace safety and reduces maintenance spending and personnel errors. We examined how to use these technologies in the current infrastructure while discussing the importance of staff training and strong cybersecurity practices. The method can be used to effectively control transmission lines and protect the power grid from damage, enhancing its performance.

title: Rapid Changing Robotic Arm System Using Unmanned Vehicle and Fault Detection in Manufacturing Industry
authors: Anarga Paritrana Widhi, Zulfikar Firmanto, Rimba Harits Hartanto
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Instrumentation, Control, and Automation (ICA)
abstract: Recently, many industries have shifted from relying on manual labor to automation. Industrial robotics is one important form of automation, with the robotic arm being one of the most versatile, capable of performing a wide range of tasks. According to the International Federation of Robotics, in 2021 there was a 14% increase in the number of active industrial robots compared to 2016. Despite the benefits of automation, routine maintenance is still needed and breakdowns still occur, leading to costly downtime. For example, in the automotive industry, loss of production costs up to US$50,000/minute. To reduce loss due to downtime, we propose as the solution a robotic arm replacement system that uses unmanned vehicle and fault detection. The robotic arm has pre-aligned wiring which can be automatically attached and detached, it also has a centralized control system able to configure their functions automatically. The replacement system will run automatically using a fault detection system based on the built-in sensors of the robotic arm and computer vision. If a fault is detected, the production line will be adjusted and an unmanned vehicle will be sent to replace the faulty robotic arm. Other than that, the system can be used when routine maintenance is needed. Unmanned vehicle and fault detection sensors have been used for a long time in the industry. Integrating both with robotic arm can create a functional system that meets the expected output. Modern robotic arms often have built-in sensors that can detect anomalies, making fault detection easier.

title: How to Form Temporary Teams While Staffing is Tight? A Perspective on GRA
authors: Qilin Huang, Kangjin Wang, Haibin Zhu, Dongning Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Temporary teams help the industry chain enhance its ability to deal with seasonal fluctuations in demand or unexpected incidents. However, it also presents greater variability among the workers and imbalance between teams. Furthermore, an excessive worker transfer rate will seriously affect the stability of the team. Thus, the imbalance in the performance levels among teams will also impact the overall progress. How to form stable and balanced temporary teams (FSABTT) has become a critical issue in the establishment of temporary teams. Notably, the Environment - Classes, Agents, Roles, Groups, and Objects (E-CARGO) model, a mature and proven effective tool, demonstrates outstanding performance in the study of such social issues. By extending the Group Role Assignment (GRA) model, this paper formalizes the problem. In addition, by introducing dual-threshold control, we propose a new multi-criteria evaluation method, which includes the worker transfer rate and the team average level balance as key criteria. The Group Role Assignment (GRA) model is incrementally extended through a series of simulation experiments. The improved model effectively reduces the worker transfer rate and balances the team average performance of new and old teams with only minimal performance trade-offs. This will help decision-makers quickly form stable and balanced temporary teams.

title: Prompt-Based Vertebral Segmentation Using a Generative Ai Approach in OVCF Spinal Radiographs
authors: Po-Kai Su, Pei-Rong Jiang, Kai-Xuan Xu, Meng-Lei Su, Jiann-Her Lin, Hsin-Han Chiang, Hsiao-Chi Li
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Osteoporotic vertebral compression fractures (OVCFs) are prevalent among elderly patients, with X-ray imaging serving as the primary diagnostic tool. However, challenges such as organ obstruction and poor contrast after vertebroplasty procedures complicate vertebral segmentation in spinal X-rays. This research introduces an innovative generative AI framework for vertebral segmentation in spinal X-ray images, combining YOLO-based detection with prompt-driven segmentation inspired by the Segment Anything Model (SAM). The system generates bounding boxes around vertebrae as segmentation prompts and employs an interpolation strategy to address potentially missed compressed vertebrae. By incorporating domain-specific knowledge of vertebral anatomy via the interpolation strategy, the framework enables accurate delineation of vertebral structures in cases of compression fractures. The model achieves impressive performance metrics, including a Dice coefficient of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.9389 \pm 0.0026$</tex>, an IoU of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.8854 \pm 0.0045$</tex>, and a sensitivity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.9436 \pm 0.0062$</tex>. Validation was conducted using data from 305 patients and 813 spinal X-ray images sourced from Taipei Medical Hospital (2014-2024), with training based on 164 patients (531 images, 2014-2019) and validation on 141 patients (282 images, 2020-2024). This generative AI application effectively addresses clinical challenges in vertebral segmentation for OVCF patients, potentially enhancing the accuracy of diagnoses and treatment planning.

title: Phase-Only Tuning and Clustering for Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface and Its Application to Multiuser Uplink Communications
authors: Yinman Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: Wireless signal propagation in multiuser uplink communications can be enhanced through the deployment of a reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS). Phase-only tuning strategies for RIS span a spectrum of design complexities, ranging from ideal implementations with continuously adjustable phase shifts to more practical configurations limited to two or four discrete phase levels. The associated optimization problems are solved using convex formulations and standard convex solvers. Clustering techniques are introduced to discretize continuous phase-shift values into arbitrary groupings, enabling flexible trade-offs between the symbol error rate (SER) and hardware implementation complexity. The proposed strategies in this study are compared with benchmark methods in terms of signal power, channel vector orthogonality among users, and end-to-end SER across various system configurations. The effectiveness and practical advantages of the proposed RIS-based strategies in improving multiuser uplink communication performance are identified.

title: Retraining-Free Blockage Prediction for Millimeter-Wave Communications Based on Minor Components of Angular Power Profiles
authors: Xiaoqing Tong, Kohei Mitani, Kazunori Hayashi, Koji Yamamoto, Takuto Arai, Shuki Wai, Tatsuhiko Iwakuni, Daisei Uchida
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: The paper proposes a retraining-free blockage prediction scheme that exploits angular power profiles (APPs) enabling us to proactively control system parameters of millimeterwave (mmWave) communications systems. Specifically, we propose a feature extraction method using some minor components obtained by the principal component analysis (PCA) of the sample covariance matrix of APPs. Moreover, to cope with environmental changes without model retraining, we employ a vector database indexed by the feature vectors of the minor components as the machine learning model, and perform prediction of the obstacle positions and received signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) via a nearest-neighbor search of the database. Numerical experiments using measured APPs from an indoor mmWave communication environment demonstrate that the proposed method achieves prediction accuracy comparable to that of a supervised model using LightGBM, while the proposed approach does not require any retraining. Moreover, we confirm that prediction accuracy is preserved even when the database contains data from multiple environments with different obstacle velocities.

title: Ethical Challenges in AI-based Clinical Decision Support System
authors: Thi Thuy Tien Tran, Xiaofan Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Clinical decision support systems are AI-based systems utilizing AI methods to assist the decision making process. In recent years, the use of clinical support systems has grown in popularity. In addition to its significant benefits in improving healthcare efficiency, it also raises several ethical questions. In this research, three case studies of real AI applications in the medical field have been investigated. The first one is PainChek®, an AI pain assessment tool utilized in Australian residential care. It is helpful for people, especially those who are not able to speak, to express their pain levels, but issues such as transparency, security, and accuracy are raised. The second example is IDx-DR, an FDA-approved automated method for identifying retinopathy in diabetic patients. Even while it can lower costs, there are still some issues with data management transparency, possible risks, and consequences on human specialists. The last case study discusses a hospital’s deployment of an AI-assisted end-of-life system. Although the system can boost physicians’ confidence and lower treatment costs by improving resource allocation, its shortcomings include bias and trust. To address those challenges, a framework has been developed for tracking ethical dilemmas that arise when developing machine learning models for medical applications. The framework combines policy regulation with model implementation processes. This framework aims to help the AI-based clinical system become more transparent and responsible, enhancing the effectiveness of clinical treatment as well as minimizing ethical risks.

title: Neural Network-Assisted Joint DOA Estimation and Beamforming with First-Order Reflection Modeling
authors: Yichen Yang, Chao Pan, Qiang Gao, Jacob Benesty, Shoji Makino, Jingdong Chen
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Source signal extraction and direction-of-arrival (DOA) estimation are core tasks in microphone array signal processing. However, their performance degrades significantly in reverberant environments: DOA estimation struggles to distinguish the direct path from strong reflections, while source extraction fails to effectively exploit the spatial cues in early reflections. This paper proposes a novel formulation of the source array-manifold vector (AMV) as a linear combination of free-field AMVs corresponding to the direct path and the four first-order reflections from the surrounding walls. A neural network is developed to jointly estimate the DOA and the combination weights of these component AMVs. The resulting composite AMV is then used in a minimum variance distortionless response (MVDR) beamformer for enhanced source extraction. Additionally, we introduce a location-based training strategy that enables end-to-end learning to automatically identify the direct-path direction. Simulation results show that the proposed method significantly improves both speech quality and DOA estimation accuracy in reverberant environments.

title: Application of Surface Electromyography for Measuring Muscle Fatigue in Gliding Athletes
authors: Ghazi Satriando Humaid Junior, Rengganis Ridwan Heru Santoso, Nia Sri Ramania, Narendra Kurnia Putra
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Instrumentation, Control, and Automation (ICA)
abstract: Currently, the use of Surface Electromyography (sEMG) is common in the field of sport science, particularly for measuring muscle fatigue. Fatigue in the back and lower back muscles has consistently been the most common complaint among gliding athletes, yet its severity has never been validly measured. This study aims to measure muscle fatigue in gliding athletes using sEMG. The method of this study is pre-experimental where 2 subjects were required to follow the sEMG measurement protocol before and after performing the flight in glider simulator. The result of this study shows that 3 out of 4 trials showing decreasing trend in median frequency (MDF) after the flight, indicating the presence of muscle fatigue. The conclusion of this study is that sEMG has been proven to be effective in measuring muscle fatigue in gliding athletes.

title: Probabilistic Prediction for Multi-Equipment Systems Based on Bayesian Spatio-Temporal Graph Attention Network
authors: Yizhuo Cai, Yanting Li
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Accurate probabilistic forecasting for multiequipment systems is essential for ensuring system reliability, safety, and maintainability. This paper introduces the Bayesian Spatio-Temporal Graph Attention Network (BSTGAT), a novel probabilistic forecasting model designed to enhance prediction accuracy by capturing time-varying and uncertain spatio-temporal correlations among devices. BSTGAT constructs dynamic spatio-temporal graphs based on prior information and utilizes multi-head self-attention mechanisms within the Graph Attention Network (GAT) and Graph Temporal Convolutional Network (GTCN) to extract endogenous spatio-temporal dependencies. Additionally, a masked multi-head cross-attention mechanism is employed to incorporate exogenous variables, enabling comprehensive information transfer across multiple data sources. To further improve predictive performance, we propose a two-stage training strategy combined with a Monte Carlo simulation-based mixture density approach. Experimental results on real-world wind power systems demonstrate that BSTGAT outperforms existing methods in terms of accuracy and robustness, showcasing its potential to intelligent reliability and maintenance technologies for industrial applications.

title: Machine Learning-Enabled Noise and Vibration Reduction in Rail Transport
authors: Naveen Mukkapati, Nalluri Archana, K.P. Siva, Shailendra Kumar Bohidar, Siddharthan P, B. Uma Maheswari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: The higher demand for rail transport needs requires effective solutions to reduce railway noise and vibration levels because they affect train efficiency and environmental well-being. A machine learning system functions as the proposed method to minimize noise and vibration in rail transport. Analysis of Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) enables the research to forecast and maximize track surveillance and rail-vehicle interaction optimization for reducing noise and vibrations while trains run. The system uses in-service train data processing through machine learning methods to detect track defects alongside system faults while monitoring the causes of high noise and vibrations. The research proves machine learning helps reduce rail noise with cost-effective results through testing in different noise and operation scenarios. Intelligent noise and vibration management tactics presented in the paper bring sustainable benefits to rail infrastructure operations.

title: Graph Neural Networks-Based Trade Flow Prediction Framework for Global Economic Analysis
authors: M. Aniji, Boddu Laxman, Hussein Basim Furaiji, Ahmed Kateb J. Al-Nussairi, Ali Ihsan Alanssari, Najlaa Nsrulaah Faris
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: International trade flows are an important issue in terms of sound economic policymaking and analysis of the global marketplace that require one to accurately forecast it. In this paper, a new framework based on using Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) to model and forecast trade flows between countries is suggested. This approach starts with Trade Graph Temporal Batching that is placed on trade data dividing into dynamic graph ensembles to record changing economical interaction over time. To increase the effectiveness and expertise of the model, Graph-based Mutual Information Feature Selector (Graph-MIFS) is used to select the most influential node features and edge features. The central prediction layer is based on Edge-Weighted Graph Attention Network (EW-GAT) with Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) decoder providing an opportunity to effectively regress trade volumes with the focus on bilateral relations. The model was implemented with the use of PyTorch Geometric (PyG) in order to prove better accuracy and scalability over conventional baselines. The place in the frame of time-relation and economic dimensions marks another profound consideration of global trading analysis and strategic economic planning.

title: Robustness Evaluation Against Fine-Tuning in Associative Watermarking Method for CNN
authors: Keiichi Mori, Masaki Kawamura
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: We propose a zero-bit watermarking method to protect convolutional neural network (CNN) models. Deep learning models are valuable intellectual property, so protecting them is critical. Specifically, since CNNs are often reused through finetuning, it is essential to be able to robustly extract the watermark even after fine-tuning. However, conventional watermarking methods have faced challenges, such as potentially degrading the model's performance due to watermark embedding and being vulnerable to fine-tuning. In contrast, our proposed method is based on the Associative Watermarking Method (AWM). As a zero-bit watermarking approach, our AWM-based method associates a watermark with the CNN model without degrading its performance. Additionally, the error correction capability of AWM allows it to handle feature degradation. An important aspect of our method is selecting features extracted from the CNN model. We use the weights of the convolutional layers as features and convert them to binary before inputting them into the AWM. We confirmed that our method enables error-free extraction of watermarks from eight different CNN models under non-attack conditions. To demonstrate the robustness of our method, we evaluated its performance against fine-tuning. Our computer simulations showed that complete watermark extraction was possible even when models pre-trained on ImageNet were finetuned using the CIFAR-100 dataset. These results show that our method maintains its protective capabilities even when significant modifications are made, such as fine-tuning.

title: Robust Initialization Strategies for Hankel Structured Low-Rank Approximation via Variable Projection
authors: Natsuki Yoshino, Akira Tanaka
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: We address the problem of Hankel Structured LowRank Approximation (HSLRA) using the Variable Projection (VP) method, which has been explored in signal processing tasks such as denoising and spectral estimation. A notable issue in VPbased HSLRA is its sensitivity to initialization, particularly under noisy conditions. We identify a phenomenon termed singular value switching, where the singular vector associated with the smallest singular value may not best reflect the true signal structure due to noise-induced perturbations. To mitigate this, we propose two initialization strategies: (M1) selecting among multiple singular vectors based on VP objective evaluation, and (M2) incorporating random linear combinations of singular vectors to expand the candidate set. Numerical experiments on exponentially decaying sinusoidal signals demonstrate that the proposed methods enhance reconstruction accuracy and robustness compared to conventional VP initialization.

title: Continual Audio Deepfake Detection via Universal Adversarial Perturbation
authors: Wangjie Li, Lin Li, Qingyang Hong
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: The rapid advancement of speech synthesis and voice conversion technologies has raised significant security concerns in multimedia forensics. Although current detection models demonstrate impressive performance, they struggle to maintain effectiveness against constantly evolving deepfake attacks. Additionally, continually fine-tuning these models using historical training data incurs substantial computational and storage costs. To address these limitations, we propose a novel framework that incorporates Universal Adversarial Perturbation (UAP) into audio deepfake detection, enabling models to retain knowledge of historical spoofing distribution without direct access to past data. Our method integrates UAP seamlessly with pre-trained self-supervised audio models during fine-tuning. Extensive experiments validate the effectiveness of our approach, showcasing its potential as an efficient solution for continual learning in audio deepfake detection.

title: Reliable Field Prediction for Industrial Safety: a GPR-MRF-K Approach to Emergency Response and Risk Assessment
authors: Chenglong Hou, Jun Yang, YuHao Zha
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Accurate and efficient field prediction is crucial for real-time environmental monitoring and emergency response systems. Traditional spatiotemporal methods suffer from high computational complexity, while single time-series models inadequately capture spatial correlations. This paper presents GPR-MRF-K, a novel hybrid approach integrating Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) with Markov Random Field-enhanced Kriging (MRF-K) for rapid field prediction. GPR handles temporal dependencies and uncertainty quantification, while MRF-K enables efficient spatial interpolation through neighborhood structure optimization, reducing computational complexity from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{O}\left(\mathrm{N}^{3}\right)$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{O}\left(\mathrm{n}^{3}\right)$</tex>. Experimental validation using a 12 -sensor ammonia leakage model demonstrates that GPR-MRF-K achieves 67 % lower mean square error compared to LSTM-based methods and traditional Kriging, with an average prediction time of 37 seconds. The approach shows significant potential for environmental monitoring, industrial safety, and emergency response applications requiring both accuracy and real-time performance.

title:
Design of the S-Preso Tool for SF
                    <sub>6</sub>
                    Gas Refilling at ULTG Garut
authors: Akhmad Fauzi Ikhsan, Hasan Sopian, Helfy Susilawati, Ginaldi Ari Nogroho, Ayub Subandi, Rifki Nurpalah
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Instrumentation, Control, and Automation (ICA)
abstract: S-Preso (SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> Pressure Recycle Tools) is a tool designed to support the processes of evacuation, transfer, vacuuming, and refilling of sulfur hexafluoride (SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf>) gas in high-voltage equipment such as Circuit Breakers (CB). This tool was developed to address problems at the Transmission and Substation Service Unit (ULTG) Garut, where many low-pressure residual SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> gas cylinders were found to be unusable, along with gas leaks in equipment. With S-Preso, SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> gas can be transferred from the CB to an empty cylinder before repairs, and conversely, can be refilled after the equipment is repaired. The transfer process is controlled through a Weintek HMI interface, integrated with a Siemens LOGO! microcontroller-based control system, allowing efficient and safe operation of both the vacuum and pressure pumps. Test results show that S-Preso can perform vacuuming to a pressure of -1 Bar within 2 minutes, and transfer SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> gas between cylinders or between a cylinder and CB within 1–6 minutes depending on volume and pressure. Gas characteristic tests show that SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> purity remains preserved at an average value of 99.99%, and the H₂O content remains within the standard threshold of <3960 ppmv. The minor decrease in purity and increase in moisture content during the transfer process remain within the allowable tolerance, with a purity standard of >97%. Thus, the S-Preso tool has proven effective in maintaining SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> gas quality as well as supporting the efficiency and sustainability of high-voltage equipment maintenance processes.

title: Transformer-Based Object Detection in Unconstructed Environments: A ROS-Gazebo Simulation Framework
authors: Aysegul Ucar, Ali Tekeş, Mehmet Yorulmaz
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: This study introduces a transformer-based object detection framework at unstructured and cluttered environments using Robot Operating System 2 (ROS 2) and Gazebo simulation. We demonstrate robust object recognition capabilities Employing Detection with Transformers (DETR) architecture on a simulated DARPA-inspired environment using the Unitree Go2 quadruped robot by employing Detection with Transformers (DETR) architecture. The framework integrates a pretrained vision transformer model and clearly exhibits its object detection performance at unconstructed environments, comparing results with a YOLO-based baseline. Our experiments highlight the advantages of transformer models in spatial understanding and detection accuracy. The complete system is developed and tested within a ROS 2-Gazebo setup for transferring the developed model from simulation to real-world autonomous robotics applications. The results indicate that transformer-based models offer significant improvements in terms of generalization over convolution-based counterparts in unstructured, cluttered, and uncertain scenarios.

title: The Effect of Creative Self-Efficacy on Adaptive Performance of Childcare Teachers: The Dual Mediating Roles of Psychological Capital and Psychological Empowerment
authors: Heejin Cho, Jiyeun Kim, Soim Park, Jong-Woo Park
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: This study aims to examine the effect of childcare teachers’ creative self-efficacy on their adaptive performance, focusing on the dual mediating roles of psychological capital and psychological empowerment. Based on structural equation modeling, the results indicate that creative self-efficacy positively influences adaptive performance both directly and indirectly through psychological resources. This paper provides both theoretical and practical implications for improving the adaptability of childcare professionals.

title: Integrating Blockchain Technology for Secure and Private Biometric Identification in Cloud Computing Environment
authors: Malathy K, Savariya Agastin Raj S, Shakthi R, Sonica V, Sri Krishna V R, Sujith R P
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: In the ever-growing world of digitalization, securing and protecting the privacy of biometric information in cloud-based data sets have become central concerns. This work provides a secure representation of the blockchain technology and incorporation of sophisticated iris recognition technology to allow a method of a secure and non-repudiable biometric identification in the cloud condition. With the help of the MMU Iris Dataset, comprising 460 datasets of iris images of 46 individuals, the proposed system will deploy the utilisation of the pre-processing methods that may involve segmentation, normalisation, and denoising to improve the quality of the images. Discriminative and compact feature vectors are produced by applying deep learning techniques such as InceptionV3 and classical Log-Gabor filters on feature extraction. To maintain confidentiality and integrity, these vectors are encrypted with the AES256 and hashed with the SHA-256. The hash-coded templates are subsequently enrolled and published on a permissioned block chain network with smart contracts to receive identity verification, admittance restrictions and withdrawal. With homomorphic encryption, biometric templates may be securely matched, without decryption and without breaching an end-to-end privacy. The proposed model reached the recognition accuracy of iris definition of 97.8%, which was much better than the recognized models of recognition such as ResNet50 (95.7%) and VGG16 (94.1%). The system also has a low encryption latency and has a high blockchain throughput (1200 TPS) which is scalable to the real world. This framework exhibits a combination of the benefits of biometric authentication and decentralization of blockchain, thus meeting both of the criteria of cloudbased identity management data security and trustworthiness. The proposed model can, therefore, offer a trusted, transparent and privacy-wise solution to nextgen biometric systems.

title: LMAPOI: An LLMs-Driven Multi-Agent Framework for Next POI Recommendation
authors: Shendong Gao, Zhixuan Wang, Yuqi Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: With the development of mobile and positioning technologies, Location-Based Social Networks (LBSNs) have burgeoned. The Next Point-of-Interest (POI) recommendation aims to predict users' potential POI visits through their check-in trajectories. Traditional techniques have progressed but suffer limitations, such as high computational resource consumption and a lack of semantic understanding of check-in data. Prompt length limitations and insufficient logical reasoning also constrain related studies leveraging Large Language Models (LLMs). This paper proposes an LLMs-driven Multi-Agent algorithm generation framework for the next POI recommendation (LMAPOI) to address these issues. It utilizes different agents to mine features of movement patterns and individual preferences from raw data, respectively. Subsequently, the new features are aggregated to formulate a scoring function for POIs. Finally, we require LLMs to search for new options in terms of ideas and parameters to obtain a more accurate function. This approach prevents LLMs from directly processing massive data, deepens the model's semantic understanding of check-in behaviors and problem objectives, and employs a dual strategy to fully utilize the algorithms generated by LLMs, enabling dynamic adjustment of POI recommendations. Experiments on three real-world datasets demonstrate that the proposed framework outperforms multiple baseline methods, showcasing remarkable superiority.

title: MF-VGP: Multimodal Fusion-Based Vehicular Global Perception and Planning Method for Autonomous Driving
authors: Yunchong Guan, Yue Shen, Yuanhao Zhang, XueFeng Jin, Qian Wang, Heng Qi, Junying Jia, Zhengfeng Jia, Xiguang Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Autonomous driving is becoming a trend in modern transportation systems. In this paper, we focus on two challenges, i.e., environmental perception and dynamic path planning. In order to make use of heterogeneous sensors on the vehicle and make efficient path plan, this paper proposes the method named MF-VGP, short for Multimodal Fusion-based Vehicular Global perception and Planning. Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) framework is used to integrates multimodal sensors (vision, LiDAR, IMU) data. The layered Model Predictive Control (MPC) with quintic polynomial trajectory parameterization is employed for obstacle avoidance. The modified dynamic-weight Dijkstra algorithm that adaptively adjusts road costs using real-time traffic assessment (e.g., congestion, construction) is designed to make path plan. Extensive experiments show that the proposed MF-VGP performs better than existing methods in efficiency.

title: Evaluation of Cohen-Coon and Ziegler-Nichols PID Tuning in Sensorless Speed Control of Induction Motors
authors: Christian Vieri Halim, Katherin Indriawati
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Instrumentation, Control, and Automation (ICA)
abstract: The reliability of three-phase induction motors is impacted by the usage of speed sensors in the speed controller. Furthermore, a three-phase induction motor is a common driving engine in industry. For induction motors to operate at their peak efficiency, speed sensorless control is therefore required. A discrete disturbance observer is used in this work to provide input on the speed sensorless control. This method uses a discrete PI controller that is tuned using the Ziegler-Nichols and Cohen-Coon methods. The goal of this research is to compare the Ziegler Nichols and Cohen-Coon tuning methods for the speed sensorless control scheme with torque load variation utilising a discrete PI. For this investigation, an Alliance AY3A-90L4 induction motor was used in an experimental setting. The results show that the Cohen-Coon tuning method is better under parameter efficiency and robustness against disturbance and Ziegler-Nichols is better under parameter reliability.

title: An Integrated Active Noise Control and Crosstalk Cancellation System Designed Under a Generalized Model-Matching Framework
authors: Michael Anthony, Chih Yen Wang, Ching En Huang, You Siang Chen, Mingsian R. Bai
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: In this study, active noise control (ANC) and crosstalk cancellation (XTC) are formulated in a generalized modelmatching framework. A unified system that jointly cancels undesired noise and synthesizes a binaural audio effect using a loudspeaker array is proposed. To design the ANC controller, we explore two approaches: a model-based approach based on the underdetermined multichannel inverse filtering and a learningbased approach utilizing the fully-convolutional time-domain audio separation network (Conv-TasNet). For the XTC, the frequency-domain underdetermined multichannel inverse filtering (FUMIF) approach is employed for the design of the inverse filters. The outputs from both subsystems are then merged to cancel the primary noise while preserving a binaural effect for the listener. The results of the study confirm the efficacy of the proposed system, demonstrating satisfactory noise reduction and binaural audio effects in several objective metrics.

title: Explainable AI for Smart Education: A Case Study on Student Performance Prediction
authors: Ali Alnoman
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: This paper aims to achieve an interpretable and trustworthy student performance prediction in higher education using explainable artificial intelligence (XAI). Specifically, a case study is introduced in which an AI-based classifier is used to predict whether or not a student will achieve an ‘A’ grade (i.e., 90% or higher). To that, the XGBoost model and Shapley values are used to understand and assess the significance of each feature in the dataset. Afterwards, the Decision Tree model (which is inherently explainable) is used to further explore the importance of each feature in light of the Shapley values. Results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed model in quantifying the importance of the different dataset features, and the significance of these features on the decision accuracy. In particular, the most effective features in the dataset were shown to be the midterm grade followed by the high school grade, while the absence percentage showed lower importance on the prediction performance. Such explainable AI model can assist educators to efficiently utilize AI for student performance prediction by knowing which feature of the dataset is more effective on the model accuracy.

title: Performance Analysis of lightweight YOLOv12 Framework for Object Detection using Real Time Web Camera based Inputs
authors: Bhuvaneswari Balachander, Sarveswari. B, Shinija N. S, Sahaya Sowmiya. C, Rajeshwari. R
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Object detection plays a vital role in autonomous vehicles, surveillance systems, health care and many more. This paper demonstrates a performance analysis of the YOLOv12 object detection framework on web camera-based images derived from COCO dataset. The focus of this study is to access the model in a dynamic indoor scenario instead of using static datasets. Images from live web cameras are fed into the model to compute performance analysis. Metrics precision (85.75%), recall (85%), mAP@0.5 (mean Average Precision at IoU 0.5) = 85.375% and processing speed of 21-24 FPS indicate the efficiency of the model. The model is evaluated under multiple scenarios, which details the challenges faced by the model. These observations will support the deployment of YOLOv12 object detection framework in many applications and also help in improving the model.

title: AI-Assisted npcRNA Screening and PCR Validation for Species-Specific Detection of Klebsiella pneumoniae
authors: Jaayaisree R. Kupusamy, Sumitha Samuggam, Fion Khek Xin Yan, Suresh V. Chinni, Vijayan Venugopal, Ivan Rolland Karakada
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Klebsiella pneumoniae (K. pneumoniae) is a major human pathogen responsible for both community-acquired infections and opportunistic nosocomial infections. The rising prevalence of multidrug-resistant strains presents a serious public health challenge. Early and accurate identification of Klebsiella pneumoniae therefore is crucial for effective infection control and clinical management, especially in hospital settings. In this study, npcRNA screening was performed to identify a potential detection marker gene specific for K. pneumoniae. A total of 210 candidate sequences were analyzed, and KpnR101 was selected for primer design due to its high specificity and suitability for PCR-based detection. Species-specific primers were designed and tested for sensitivity and specificity using for K. pneumoniae and eight other bacterial species. PCR results revealed distinct melting temperatures of amplicons, allowing clear differentiation of K. pneumoniae from closely related species. Analytical sensitivity, evaluated through PCR and gel electrophoresis, showed that the minimal detectable DNA concentration was 2.80 × 10⁻<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> fg/μl. This npcRNA mediated and PCR-based method provides a practical diagnostic solution with high sensitivity and specificity, reducing the likelihood of false positives. The approach enables rapid and accurate detection of K. pneumoniae, supporting timely treatment decisions and effective infection control strategies.

title: Three-Dimensional Gradient-Based Tracking of Multiple Sound Sources
authors: Shaoheng Xu, Wei-Ting Lai, Yile Zhang, Jihui Zhang, Amy Bastine, Prasanga N. Samarasinghe, Thushara D. Abhayapala
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This paper presents a gradient-based algorithm for tracking multiple sound sources in three-dimensional (3-D) space under reverberant conditions. The proposed method, called 3-D Gradient-based Multiple-source Tracking (3D-GMT), operates directly in the continuous spatial domain and estimates source trajectories via a frequency-constrained loss function. Unlike conventional grid-based approaches that suffer from quantization errors and require post-processing filters, 3D-GMT jointly refines all source locations in parallel, implicitly smoothing trajectories and reducing cumulative error. Simulation experiments in reverberant environments demonstrate the robustness and accuracy of 3D-GMT under two representative motion scenarios: straightline paths and complex spiral trajectories. The results indicate potential for applying the method to sound source tracking in reverberant environments with smooth, moderate-speed motion.

title: Scheduling Optimization for Flexible Manufacturing Systems Based on Human Factor Resilience Evaluation
authors: Jinglu Wei, Chao Guo, Jingxuan Wang, Qinglin Zheng, Chuxin Peng, Wei Dai
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Manufacturing is a pillar industry of the national economy. With product iteration rates and customization demands increasing daily, Flexible Manufacturing Systems (FMS) have become the primary choice for many enterprises to cope with uncertain order requirements due to their strong adaptability and efficient, precise management capabilities. The formulation of FMS production plans directly determines the system's performance throughout the production process. However, existing research predominantly focuses on equipment and process levels, prioritizing efficiency and quality as optimization objectives, and passively addresses unexpected events during manufacturing through rescheduling methods. There is a lack of consideration for the synergistic relationship between human factors and system resilience, leading to improper allocation of worker workloads, constrained production capacity, and suboptimal operational statuses under disruptive scenarios. This paper addresses the FMS scheduling optimization problem by comprehensively integrating human factor constraints and system resilience modeling. We propose a multi-objective integrated optimization approach that proactively mitigates disturbances through rational workload allocation and process layout arrangements, thereby enhancing worker productivity.

title: The Impact of Road Traffic Congestion on 4G LTE V2V Communications Channel Resource Performance
authors: Kee Oon Tan, Azizul Rahman Mohd Shariff, Aun Hee Tneh, Guan Hin Chau
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: Road traffic congestion is a critical challenge in intelligent transportation systems (ITS), influencing road safety and the performance of vehicular communication networks. In 4G long-term evolution (LTE)-based vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) networks, the availability and efficiency of wireless channel resources are essential for transmitting safety-critical messages such as cooperative awareness messages (CAMs). We investigated the impact of road traffic congestion on 4G LTE V2V channel resource performance in a junction road environment using a simulation. For the simulation, we used the Veins framework, integrating simulation of urban mobility (SUMO), an objective modular network testbed in C++ (OMNeT++), simulation for LTE network (SimuLTE), and an internet networking framework (INET) to simulate real-world vehicular mobility and communication. The analysis was conducted using performance indicators such as throughput, packet delivery ratio (PDR), average travel time, average waiting time, and queueing time, under varying traffic densities and speeds. Results revealed that a higher vehicle density significantly affected throughput, showing a degradation of up to 28% when the number of vehicles increased from 75 to 250. Vehicles also require more time to reach their destinations and experience increased travel and waiting time, especially at lower speeds. For instance, all 250 vehicles arrived by 800 s at 20 km/h and 640 s at 110 km/h, with average travel times of 42.6 and 23.85 s, respectively. However, PDR and average queueing time remained stable across densities, indicating minimal sensitivity to congestion in those metrics. Overall, the results demonstrate that road traffic congestion degrades communication efficiency in 4G LTE V2V systems, particularly in terms of throughput and vehicular delays, underscoring the need for congestion-aware channel resource management in urban ITS deployments.

title: Geometric Lattices in Abstract Modeling: From Protein Structure Prediction to Universal Computational Representations
authors: Ioan Sima
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: Geometric lattices, particularly those used in modeling protein structures under the hydrophobic-polar (HP) model, offer a discrete structure with applications extending beyond computational biology. In this paper, we explore the conceptualization lattices such as constraint spaces, spatial encoding frameworks, and geometric abstractions. We propose a generalized perspective of the lattice as a universal tool for representing discrete configurations, with implications for combinatorial optimization, graph theory, symbolic artificial intelligence, and digital morphogenesis.

title: LogAL-Prefix: Parameter-Efficient Log Anomaly Detection Based on Active Learning and Prefix
authors: Shiming He, Yanling Wu, Ying Lei, Gan Wu, Kun Xie
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Logs continuously record both normal and anomalous system operational states, serving as critical data for system runtime monitoring. Log anomaly detection facilitates system debugging and root cause analysis for issues such as system failures, shutdown faults, null pointer exceptions, illegal argument exceptions, and class cast exceptions. Deep learning has been widely adopted in log anomaly detection to enhance detection accuracy. However, deep learning models require substantial labeled log data, which demands significant human effort and time investment. To address this labeling requirement, pretraining models like BERT have been introduced. However, pretraining models introduce new challenges. BERT requires finetuning of an enormous parameter set, resulting in substantial training overhead. Existing parameter-efficient strategies in log anomaly detection degrade the performance while introducing inference latency through increased model depth. Furthermore, the continuous expansion of system scale generates exponentially growing log data containing redundant log information. Current random sampling methods for training data selection fail to filter more valuable instances and exacerbate data redundancy. To address these challenges, we propose a Log Anomaly Detection based on Active Learning and Prefix (LogAL-Prefix). LogALPrefix eliminates manual prompt engineering by freezing pretraining model parameters during training and exclusively updating prefix parameters, thereby further reducing the parameter footprint of pre-training models. Additionally, LogALPrefix employs active learning strategies to select a minimal set of high-uncertainty samples to retrain the model. Experiments on the BGL dataset demonstrate that <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\log A L$</tex>-Prefix can further reduce the trainable parameters compared to LogBP-LoRA.

title: MAC Scheduling and Traffic Control Prioritization with Object Detection Using Artificial Intelligence in IoT-SDN based Smart Agriculture
authors: K. Malathi, T Sreenivasa Murthy, Maram Y. Al-Safarini, D Sameer Kumar, S Naveen Kumar, Vijilius Helena Raj
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: The integration of smart technologies in agriculture has led to the creation of intelligent systems that address issues like energy use and real-time monitoring. This article introduces the MAC Scheduling and Traffic Control Prioritization with Object Detection Using Artificial Intelligence in IoT-SDN based Smart Agriculture (MSTCOD) model, improving data routing in smart agriculture using IoT, SDN, advanced MAC scheduling, and AI for traffic classification. It features a system that sorts traffic into regular, emergency, and on-demand and uses a Q-learning algorithm for real-time routing adjustments. The SDN-IoT gateway enables secure device authentication and manages data flow rules. A multi-path MAC scheduling mechanism enhances throughput and resource distribution, lowering collisions and interference. The lightweight AI model is designed for low-resource IoT devices, balancing accuracy and performance. Various kernel-based architectures were developed to optimize feature extraction while preventing overfitting. Performance testing showed that MSTCOD with previous models in critical metrics like latency, packet loss, and throughput, making it suitable for applications requiring real-time feedback and monitoring.

title: Gesture Matters: Pedestrian Gesture Recognition for AVs Through Skeleton Pose Evaluation
authors: Alif Rizqullah Mahdi, Mahdi Rezaei, Natasha Merat
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Instrumentation, Control, and Automation (ICA)
