abstract: Gestures are a key component of non-verbal communication in traffic, often helping pedestrian-to-driver interactions when formal traffic rules may be insufficient. This problem becomes more apparent when autonomous vehicles (AVs) struggle to interpret such gestures. In this study, we present a gesture classification framework using 2D pose estimation applied to real-world video sequences from the WIVW dataset. We categorise gestures into four primary classes (Stop, Go, Thank & Greet, and No Gesture) and extract 76 static and dynamic features from normalised keypoints. Our analysis demonstrates that hand position and movement velocity are especially discriminative in distinguishing between gesture classes, achieving a classification accuracy score of 87%. These findings not only improve the perceptual capabilities of AV systems but also contribute to the broader understanding of pedestrian behaviour in traffic contexts.

title: Variance-Driven U-Net Training and Chroma-Scale-Based Multi-Exposure Image Fusion
authors: Chang-Woo Son, Young-Ho Go, Seung-Hwan Lee, Sung-Hak Lee
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: We propose a multi-exposure fusion framework that integrates variance-driven U-Net training which suppresses data imbalance and noise amplification. To further enhance visual fidelity, we introduce a chroma-map strategy that redistributes the ab channel chroma scale. Combining variance-driven learning with chroma-guided correction, the proposed method produces high-quality HDR synthesis with improved detail and faithful color reproduction while maintaining computational efficiency. Compared with Conv MSR, DSIFT_EF, DEM, and DBM, the results demonstrate improvements in preservation of detail.

title: Development of an Inductive Adder Branch Module with Fast Overcurrent Protection for the CERN KFA4 Kicker System
authors: Johannes Ruf, Thomas Kramer
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: For the KFA4 kicker system at CERN, an inductive adder is being developed to replace the existing thyratron-based pulse generator. This new system must deliver a 40 kV, 2.6 kA, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.1 \mu$</tex> s pulse into the kicker's 15.7Ω load. The primary pulse circuit features a fast overcurrent protection system for the 1.7 kV SiC-MOSFETs used. Standard differential current sensing can be limited by high di/dt transients, due to a common-mode voltage caused by parasitic inductances that may saturate the sensing comparator. To overcome this, a single-ended measurement concept was developed. This approach incorporates the parasitic inductance into the measurement path and uses a matched RC compensation network to counteract this effect. Initial measurements confirm the protection system achieves switch turn-off within 40 ns of an overcurrent event. This paper presents the circuit design, the overcurrent protection mechanism, and initial test results.

title: RAR: Remapping Algorithm of Racetrack Memory Based Main-Memory for Parallelism Improvement
authors: Xinghao Li, Muyun Pan, Shouzhen Gu, Jin Sun, Edwin Sha, Qingfeng Zhuge
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Racetrack Memory (RTM), as a promising next-generation memory technology, offers high storage density and low access latency. It is a potential alternative to DRAM in main-memory applications. However, the data access pattern of RTM differs from traditional memory. Its “shift before access” characteristic presents challenges for efficient memory management and rapid data access. This article proposes a novel address remapping algorithm for RTM to improve data access efficiency in these contexts. By analyzing memory access locality and computing weights based on trace patterns, our method distributes data across multiple banks to reduce access contention caused by sequential access within a single bank. In addition, we introduce a workload balancing mechanism to achieve wear leveling, which further optimizes overall parallelism and reduces performance bottlenecks in the RTM storage system. We evaluate the proposed algorithm on 15 real-world SPEC2006 benchmarks, which demonstrates that address remapping reduces the number of shifts by 10.9 % and the total bank energy by 10.1 %. Furthermore, our strategy leads to a 10.2 % reduction in the average latency of single trace. These results highlight the potential of RTM in main-memory applications where low energy consumption and high throughput are crucial. Additionally, they illustrate the effectiveness of our approach in optimizing RTM performance for real-world, latency-sensitive workloads.

title: Directional Hybrid Optimization of HRTFs for Low-Order Spherical Harmonics Binaural Rendering
authors: Rui Zhang, Yuxuan Ke, Qunping Ni, Ge Yao, Xiaodong Li, Chengshi Zheng
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Employing only low-order spherical harmonics for binaural reproduction results in significant spectral distortions. Although existing methods like Magnitude Least-Squares (MLS) can reduce overall errors by means of low-order representation of the head-related transfer functions (HRTFs), residual inaccuracies persist in contralateral regions. To address this limitation, we propose a directional hybrid optimization of HRTFs. This method partitions the space into contralateral, ipsilateral, and transition zones, and each zone is processed using least-squares, MLS, and their linear combination, respectively. Objective evaluation results using KU-100 HRTFs demonstrate that the proposed method achieves much higher performance across all objective metrics, suppressing rendering errors in contralateral source while improving spatial cue accuracy at lateral positions when compared with MLS. Subjective MUSHRA tests further confirm the superiority of the proposed method, with perceptual scores exceeding those of MLS by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 4 \%}$</tex> at order <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N=1$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 \%}$</tex> at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N=4$</tex>. The results of both subjective and objective experiments indicate that the proposed method effectively suppresses spectral distortions of HRTFs in the contralateral regions while preserving critical spatial information for immersive auditory experiences.

title: Output Performance of the 330 GHz CW Clinotron with a Modified Cavity
authors: Sergey Vlasenko, Yurii Kovshov, Sergiy Ponomarenko, Sergey Kishko, Aleksandr Likhachev, Anatoly Kirilenko, Sergiy Steshenko, Eduard Khutoryan, Oleksiy Kuleshov
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Experimental results of a 330 GHz CW clinotron with a modified cavity are presented. These results are compared with the cold-cavity simulation results that take into account mode reflection and conversion at both the collector and the output ends of the cavity. During the analysis of output characteristics of the clinotron, special attention was paid to the excitation of the high-order surface modes in the beam-wave interaction region, which significantly enhances the electronic frequency-tuning range. The efficiency of mode excitation and conversions was analyzed in the frequency range of 280- 335 GHz, while the width of both the oversized the interaction space and the output waveguide were designed to provide singlemode output radiation.

title: Snow Ablation Optimizer-Based MPPT for PV Systems Under Various Partial Shading Conditions
authors: Norazlan Hashim, Rahimi Baharom, Ahmad Farid Abidin, Khairul Safuan Muhammad, Wan Noraishah Wan Abdul Munim
publish: 2025 IEEE Industrial Electronics and Applications Conference (IEACon)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI)-based maximum power point tracking (MPPT) algorithms play a crucial role in enhancing the efficiency of photovoltaic (PV) systems under partial shading conditions (PSCs). With the increasing variety of AI algorithms available, selecting an effective MPPT solution remains a challenge. This paper proposes a Snow Ablation Optimizer (SAO)-based MPPT algorithm, a novel physics-inspired metaheuristic derived from the sublimation and melting behavior of snow and evaluates its performance under various PSC scenarios in MATLAB/Simulink. The proposed algorithm is compared against two established techniques– Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) and Grey Wolf Optimization (GWO)–using two key metrics: success rate (SR) in locating the global maximum power point (GMPP) and convergence speed (CS). The overall performance is assessed using a performance indicator (PI) score that balances both metrics. Results show that PSO achieves the highest PI score of 0.564, followed by GWO at 0.500, while SAO records 0.446. Although SAO ranks third, its potential for improvement remains significant, supporting the No Free Lunch Theorem, which implies that no single optimization algorithm performs best in all scenarios.

title: Heart Failure in the Obese Population: Overcoming Diagnostic Barriers with Artificial Intelligence-Driven Approaches
authors: Dhanu Rajendra Kumar, Mohamed Arsath Shamsudeen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Background: Obesity has become a rising threat in the globe when it comes to the heart failure especially heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). The problematic aspect of the HFpEF diagnosis among the obese individuals is the presence of the overlapping symptoms, which occur, and the traditional diagnostic measures also have lesser functionality. They are particularly sharp in the low-and-middle-income countries (LMICs), where the high-level diagnostics is not readily accessible. Newly developed Artificial Intelligence (AI) especially machine learning and deep learning are the answer to these barriers.Methods: The given literature review is a summary of six articles (20192024) which have been published in peer-reviewed journals following a specific database search. Articles that have reported on the gaps in the diagnosing of obese patients with HF or studies that have experimented with AI-based solutions to diagnose HF were included. Results analysis was used to explore the themes.Findings: Echocardiography, electrocardiography (ECG), and B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) are not sensitive in obese patients because of the anatomical and metabolic differences. The solutions of the AIs particularly the solutions used in the echocardiographic and ECG data had high diagnostic accuracy, failure to respond to the poor inputs, and the capability to detect the disease early. In addition, AI-based risk stratification and decision support systems were also prospective in the LMICs in which the diagnostic facilities are insufficient.Interpretation: The problem of heart failure diagnostics in obese populations can be resolved with the help of artificial intelligence since it represents a scalable and cost-effective method of handling the problem. Its incorporation into clinical pathways can decrease the underdiagnosis, advance equity, and achieve the maximum outcome. The future of the cardiovascular diagnostics and cardiovascular care could be made more affordable, more precise and fairer in the future with the help of the AI-enhanced and echocardiography analysis software integrated into the LMIC healthcare and primary care systems.

title: Evaluation Method of Luminance Lifetime of Foldable Organic Light-Emitting Diode Display Modules
authors: Zhiwei Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: With the rapid development of foldable organic light-emitting diode (OLED) display technology, reliability evaluation has become critical for large-scale applications. In this study, the luminance lifetime of foldable OLED modules was evaluated under normal temperature and relative humidity (25°C and 50% RH). A multi-stress accelerated evaluation model was developed by integrating the stretched exponential decay (SED) model and the Hallberg-Peck model. The model addresses the challenges of long testing cycles and unclear failure mechanisms occurring in traditional reliability tests. T95 luminance lifetime (time to 95% of initial luminance) of the module under normal conditions was estimated to be 7713 h, with an acceleration factor of 7.63 under 60°C and 90% RH, improving test efficiency by 86.8%. The model can be used for the quantitative evaluation of luminance reliability and product optimization.

title: Converting Printed Electrocardiography to Digital Signals: Challenges and Solutions
authors: Angkay A-P Subramaniam, Nur Faiza Binti Ali, Nur Shidah Binti A. Sharawardi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: Electrocardiography (ECG) measures heart electrical activity through electrodes attached to the skin surface as a non-invasive diagnostic tool. The large collection of historical ECGs stored in paper format creates major obstacles for digital analysis and extended data storage needs. Therefore, we developed an extensive evaluation method which transform paper-based ECGs into digital signals. The techniques encompass image acquisition, preprocessing, signal extraction, and reconstruction. We examined the obstacles of each process in the built-in method of machine learning and deep learning techniques. The results underline the necessity of standardized digitization pipelines because they guarantee both clinical and research accuracy and reliability.

title: A Safety Analysis and Risk Assessment Method for USV Formation Navigation Mission
authors: Kaixuan Wang, Jiayun Chu, Tingdi Zhao, Yuan Yuan
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: To address the challenges of complex maritime environments and tightly coupled control interactions in the maritime navigation mission of unmanned surface vehicle (USV) formation, this paper proposes a safety analysis and risk assessment method for USV formation navigation mission. A multi-view SysML-based model is constructed to structurally represent the maritime navigation mission profile from the perspectives of organizational structure, mission flow, and temporal logic. Based on the System-Theoretic Process Analysis (STPA) method, a multi-layer safety control architecture model is established to map control logic among functional modules, identify failure-inducing causal factors, and uncover unsafe control actions and potential systemic risk paths. Focusing on the high-risk scenario of high-speed navigation during the maritime operation, a set of risk factors and hazard membership functions are developed. It enables real-time risk quantification and graded assessment under complex and dynamic conditions.

title: Optimizing CNN-BPNN Architectures for High-Accuracy Diagnosis of Multi-Class Thyroid Disorders
authors: Sumathy G, Sreelekha Nedunuri, Subashree Guruchandar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Thyroid disease is prevalent throughout the world, and accurate diagnosis is crucial for treatment. In this study, we discuss a new approach to study thyroid diseases utilizing Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for image classification and Backpropagation Neural Networks (BPNNs) for classifying datasets. Our dataset of thyroid images includes images collected via ultrasound, MRI, and CT scans. Each image is associated with the relevant thyroid disease category including hyperthyroidism, hypothyroidism, thyroid nodules, etc. In addition, the data was comprised of non-image features that included patient demographics, symptoms, and medical history. For classifying the images, we reviewed an architecture based on CNNs, which can automatically learn important attributes of the thyroid images. The CNN model has been trained using a labeled image dataset taking advantage of the convolutional and pooling layers for feature extraction, followed by fully connected layers for classification. A BPNN architecture has been created to classify the dataset and assess the subject in relation to non-image attributes associated with a thyroid disease. The BPNN is trained using back propagation, and by doing so, it learns the underlying patterns and relationships between a wide range of features, and the associated disease categories. The predictions have been drawn together and presented as a single system to assess the thyroid disease. The overall predictions were compiled using ensemble learning methods from the CNN and BPNN models, and the subsequent predictions improved the overall classification accuracy. The ability of the described system was assessed using non-overlapping test datasets, using measures of accuracy, precision, recall, f1-score and area under the ROC curve (AUC). The system was also validated against the domain experts, to ensure clinical usefulness and reliability. The outcome demonstrated the potential of integrating CNN's and BPNN's for a comprehensive evaluation of thyroid disease, providing a promising approach for accurate and reliable diagnosis in clinical practice.

title: Modern Methods for Ensuring Data Integrity in Radio Channels
authors: Valery Zolotarev, Gennady Ovechkin, Dina Satybaldina, Zhuldyz Sailaukyzy, Murat Kozhanov
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: This paper investigates the effectiveness of multi-threshold decoding (MTD) in multichannel wireless communication systems, taking into account various factors such as multipath signal propagation and inter-symbol interference. Particular attention is given to data transmission reliability, where MTD is applied to enhance error resilience in high-speed and interference-prone communication. The study involves simulation of a data transmission system based on self-orthogonal codes and orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (OFDM). The focus is placed on a comparative performance analysis of MTD versus other error correction methods, such as LDPC and turbo codes, under various modulation schemes (QPSK, 8PSK, 16APSK). Evaluation was conducted using ITU-R Outdoor Channel A and SCM Urban Macro channel models, considering different noise levels, receiver speeds, and fading parameters. The results show that MTD not only provides high performance comparable to other methods but also significantly reduces computational complexity, which is critical for mobile devices with limited processing resources. These findings confirm the relevance of applying MTD in data transmission systems to improve reliability and robustness under challenging radio environments and interference-prone communication, where traditional methods require substantial computational costs.

title: Automated Optical Marker Exam Recognition using Cross-Linear Area Detection from Smartphone Camera
authors: Watcharaphong Yookwan, Athita Onuean, Sirapat Tansavetwong, Jirayus Arbking, Sirima Chinnasarn, Krisana Chinnasarn
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: This paper presents an automated system for evaluating optical marker-based multiple-choice answer sheets using images captured from smartphone cameras. The proposed approach addresses the challenges of document distortion, varying lighting conditions, and diverse sheet templates through a multi-stage pipeline. The system begins with image dewarping using homographic transformation to correct perspective distortions. Key structural components—such as Exam Number, Student ID, and Page Number—are localized using YOLOv8 object detection. The answer region is then identified and cropped for analysis. Template matching is employed to detect landmark points, enabling precise alignment of the answer grid. Optical Mark Recognition (OMR) is performed using a Cross-Linear Area (CLA) algorithm, which calculates the ratio of dark pixels within each marker region to determine marked responses. Detected answers are mapped to corresponding questions and exported in JSON format for downstream use. Experimental results demonstrate that the system is accurate, efficient, and robust to real-world imaging conditions, offering a practical solution for low-cost, mobile-based exam evaluation.

title: A Coupled Source Degradation-Informed Hybrid ML–RL Energy Management Framework for Fuel Cell Electric Vehicles
authors: Lakshmi Priya. G, C. Benin Pratap
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: This paper proposes the use of a coupled degradation-aware Hybrid Machine Learning Reimbursement Energy management framework of Fuel Cell Electric Vehicles (FCEVs) to optimize power allocation between the fuel cell and battery systems, taking into consideration component deterioration. The framework incorporates the ML prediction module which includes Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, and Gradient Boosted Decision Trees (GBDT), to predict short-term power demand degradation rates. These estimates are used by a dueling Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) reinforcement learning agent so that proactive and degradation awareness control choices are possible. Standard driving cycles (including UDDS, HWFET and NEDC) were used to evaluate performance as well as against various rule-based control, standalone ML or standalone RL comparison strategies. A prediction accuracy of 97.23% (90.57) was obtained in foreseeing demand and degradation measurement which led to considerable advantages in terms of operations: hydrogen consumption (12-18 % reduction), battery state-of-charge (SOC) stability (reduction up to 45%) and average degradation rate (reduction by 34 %). Compared to advanced standalone RL techniques, the fuel economy improvements varied between 8-17%. The combination of adaptive policy learning with predictive modeling enables the system to proactively consider the operating condition that gives rise to a high-stress state to adjust the power allocation thus extending the components lifetime that enhances efficiency. The minimalized computing burden (~7ms per decision) would ensure real time applicability of computations in embedded automotive control units.

title: Expressive Prompting: Improving Emotion Intensity and Speaker Consistency in Zero-Shot TTS
authors: Haoyu Wang, Chunyu Qiang, Tianrui Wang, Cheng Gong, Yu Jiang, Yuheng Lu, Chen Zhang, Longbiao Wang, Jianwu Dang
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Recent advancements in speech synthesis have enabled large language model (LLM)-based systems to perform zero-shot generation with controllable content, timbre, speaker identity, and emotion through input prompts. As a result, these models heavily rely on prompt design to guide the generation process. However, existing prompt selection methods often fail to ensure that prompts contain sufficiently stable speaker identity cues and appropriate emotional intensity indicators, which are crucial for expressive speech synthesis. To address this challenge, we propose a two-stage prompt selection strategy specifically designed for expressive speech synthesis. In the static stage (before synthesis), we first evaluate prompt candidates using pitch-based prosodic features, perceptual audio quality, and text-emotion coherence scores evaluated by an LLM. We further assess the candidates under a specific TTS model by measuring character error rate, speaker similarity, and emotional similarity between the synthesized and prompt speech. In the dynamic stage (during synthesis), we use a textual similarity model to select the prompt that is most aligned with the current input text. Experimental results demonstrate that our strategy effectively selects prompt to synthesize speech with both high-intensity emotional expression and robust speaker identity, leading to more expressive and stable zero-shot TTS performance. Audio samples and codes will be available at https://whyrrrrun.github.io/ExpPro.github.io/.

title: End-to-End Integration of Speech Emotion Recognition and Voice Activity Detection with a Self-Supervised Model for Noise Robustness
authors: Natsuo Yamashita, Masaaki Yamamoto, Yohei Kawaguchi
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Speech Emotion Recognition (SER) often operates on speech segments detected by a Voice Activity Detection (VAD) model in a cascade manner. However, VAD models may output flawed speech segments including noise-only or nonemotional segments, especially in noisy environments, resulting in performance degradation in subsequent SER models. To address this issue, we propose an end-to-end (E2E) method that integrates VAD and SER using Self-Supervised Learning (SSL) features. By jointly training both VAD and SER models with SSL features for a combined loss function, our approach enables the VAD module to capture emotional speech segments for SER, while making the SER model robust against the flawed VAD output. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate that our proposed method improves SER performance without optimizing the VAD threshold. Furthermore, we analyze our method under various conditions, such as different loss weights and noise levels.

title: Probabilistic Language-Aware Speech Recognition
authors: Jen-Tzung Chien, Willianto Sulaiman, Chung-Hsuan Wang
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Code-switching scheme aims to imitate how speakers alternately switch different languages during speech communication in a multilingual community. However, building an efficient code-switching speech recognition remains a challenging issue, primarily due to the language confusion, which degrades the recognition performance. To address this issue, a novel probabilistic language-aware speech recognition is developed through a parameter-efficient learning where the tunable adapters are configured in a frozen Whisper backbone. In particular, this study incorporates a language-aware calibrator at the prediction stage, introducing the language identity as an additional condition for next token prediction. By merging such a language awareness in conditional generation, the model's ability to distinguish between languages in a code-switching speech is significantly improved. The results on Chinese-English code-switching dataset using SEAME show a 4.9% relative improvement in mixed error rate by using the proposed method with only 5.1% fine-tuned parameters relative to a strong baseline with full fine-tuned parameters.

title: Advancing Speech Quality Assessment Through Scientific Challenges and Open-Source Activities
authors: Wen-Chin Huang
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Speech quality assessment (SQA) refers to the evaluation of speech quality, and developing an accurate automatic SQA method that reflects human perception has become increasingly important, in order to keep up with the generative AI boom. In recent years, SQA has progressed to a point that researchers started to faithfully use automatic SQA in research papers as a rigorous measurement of goodness for speech generation systems. We believe that the scientific challenges and open-source activities of late have stimulated the growth in this field. In this paper, we review recent challenges as well as open-source implementations and toolkits for SQA, and highlight the importance of maintaining such activities to facilitate the development of not only SQA itself but also generative AI for speech.

title: Performance Analysis of Active Noise Control Over a Spatial Region
authors: Jihui Aimee Zhang, Thushara D. Abhayapala, Naoki Murata, Prasanga N. Samarasinghe, Yu Maeno, Yuki Mitsufuji
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Active noise control (ANC) over region(s), or spatial ANC, extends the noise control from one or more points to the entire region(s). This paper proposes an evaluation method to predict the ‘noise reduction performance over the entire region’ (NRR) for any given spatial ANC system. This method formulates the acoustic potential energy of the residual signals over the region into spherical/cylindrical-harmonics coefficients (also named as ’wave-domain coefficients’), and further decomposes it into three components related to the coherence between reference signals at the reference microphones and primary signals over the region, filter coefficients, and an uncontrollable term due to physical and practical constraints. This analytical tool provides insight into the contribution of each component to the overall noise reduction performance over the entire region.

title: PALGAN: A Joint Optimization-Based Preprocessing method for Speech Restoration in Parametric Array Loudspeakers
authors: Wenyao Ma, Jun Yang
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: The parametric array loudspeaker (PAL) inherently introduces baseband distortions in directional sound applications due to the nonlinear process in air. Recently, a two-stage DNNbased framework has been used to generate preprocessed signals for distortion-free speech restoration, where a preprocessing network is cascaded with a frozen forward model that estimates the PAL system. However, the preprocessing network can exploit weaknesses in the fixed model, resulting in adversarial outputs. To address this, we propose a joint optimization strategy based on a PAL-driven generative adversarial network (PALGAN), which simultaneously learns the PAL process and the preprocessing module. A process discrimination mechanism is incorporated into the discriminator, enabling it to determine whether the input signal pair conform to the PAL process while acquiring a forward model. The generator uses a causal TF-GridNet to estimate the real and imaginary parts of the preprocessed signal via a time-frequency band-split mechanism. Simulated and real-world experiments demonstrate that the proposed method achieves competitive reconstruction performance when compared with existing methods across various objective metrics<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>For access to the source code and speech samples, please visit: https://github.com/MWY0615/PALGAN..

title: Semantic Communication-Enhanced Split Federated Learning for Vehicular Networks
authors: Lu Yu, Mingan Luan, Zheng Chang, Alain R. Ndjiongue
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Federated learning (FL) and split learning (SL) have emerged as promising paradigms for privacy-preserving model training in vehicular networks. However, their performance is often constrained by limited wireless resources and dynamic network conditions. To address these challenges, we propose SC-USFL, a semantic communication-enhanced U-shaped split federated learning framework designed for image classification tasks. The proposed SC-USFL integrates a task-oriented semantic communication module-comprising semantic and channel encoders/decoders-to efficiently compress and transmit taskrelevant features. Additionally, a network status monitoring (NSM) module dynamically adjusts compression rates based on real-time channel conditions, optimizing resource usage. The simulation results demonstrate that SC-USFL significantly reduces communication overhead while maintaining competitive accuracy.

title: An Experimental Comparison Between Volumetric and Surface Flashover Breakdown of $SF_{6}$ and $C_{4}F_{7}N$ Under Nanosecond Pulse Conditions
authors: Luke Silvestre, Jakob Matthies, Luke Boswell, Jacob Stephens, John Mankowski, James Dickens, Andrew Young, Andreas Neuber
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: This study examines the high-voltage nanosecond pulsed breakdown performance of C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf>F<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">7</inf>N compared to SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> in volumetric breakdown and surface flashover conditions. While SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> is extensively used in the pulsed power community, Novec 4710<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">TM</sup>, C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf>F<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">7</inf>N, is being considered as an alternative to SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> owing to its lower estimated global warming potential. A coaxial testing apparatus enables the measurement of single digit nanosecond fast breakdown events. Volumetric breakdown testing was performed across a 2.2 mm gap using hemispherical electrodes within a pressure range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$150 \text{kPa}-450 \text{kPa}$</tex>. Mixtures of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 0} \%$</tex> and 50% C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf>F<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">7</inf>N were tested with CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> and N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> as buffer gases, and the results are compared to pure SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> under the same conditions. Surface flashover testing involved placing a polycarbonate insert across the midplane of the spark gap electrodes.

title: Blockchain Interoperability: A Trade-off Between Scalability and Privacy-Preserving
authors: Zheng Hui Ng, Miss Laiha Mat Kiah
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: The development of decentralized ecosystems enables blockchain interoperability to be a transformative catalyst and siloed networks to effortlessly exchange information and assets. This is the key to unlocking a fully connected blockchain ecosystem network. However, privacy in interoperable blockchain systems must be secure. While protocols such as relaying, bridging, and atomic swapping enable communication between networks, decentralized ecosystems raise concerns as they introduce additional overhead and complexity that threaten the scalability and the ability to preserve the need for privacy. In this study, we identified important tradeoffs between interoperability and privacy, mitigating the risks of cross-chain data exposure with assumptions to secure, scalable, and privacy-preserving blockchain interoperability.

title: Quantum Mechanical Modelling of Laser-Gas Interactions for Next Generation Laser-Triggered Gas Switches
authors: T. Wong, M. Given, I. Timoshkin, S. MacGregor
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: In medium- to large-scale pulsed power drivers, the characteristics and coordination of switch components responsible for the delivery of stored energy to the electrical load greatly influences overall system performance. Many high-power pulsed applications favour laser-triggered gas switches for their repeatable trigger characteristics and ability to achieve a high degree of synchronism due to low jitter. Some studies have additionally suggested that a certain degree of per-switch controllability may be achieved through modification of the laser parameters alone, while other have begun to explore the characteristics and breakdown mechanisms of ultra-short-pulse (picosecond, femtosecond) laser triggering for enhanced switching performance. The interaction between lasers and gas is rich in fundamental physics, much of which remains poorly understood, particularly within the context of laser-triggered switches for pulsed power. This work presents preliminary results achieved from ab-initio modelling of laser-gas interactions conducted with the aim to estimate laser ionisation rates in various simple gases. A custom implementation of the split-operator spectral method to solve the Schrödinger equation for electronic wavefunctions under laser perturbations is presented, enabling calculations, from first-principles, of laser ionisation probabilities and rates as functions of various optical parameters of the laser pulse and working gas. This work builds towards an understanding of basic processes that underpin laser-induced plasmas, with an aim to eventually produce key data that may inform future modelling and developmental efforts of high-performance and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SF}_{6}$</tex>-free switches for advanced pulsed power and related applications.

title: Blockchain-Integrated Circular Economy Framework for Maritime ICT Energy Materials
authors: Paula Marielle Ababao, Ian B. Benitez, Gabriel Avelino Sampedro
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: This study proposes a Blockchain-Integrated Circular Economy Framework to improve lifecycle tracking and emissions reporting for maritime ICT and energy materials. The system combines Digital Product Passports, IoT telemetry, and smart contracts on a permissioned blockchain to record operational data and end-of-life events for batteries, photovoltaic modules, and navigation equipment. A parametric algorithm calculates emissions by combining production impacts, usage profiles, and recycling credits, while automated incentives promote material recovery. Synthetic data simulations illustrate the framework's ability to monitor degradation, quantify emissions, and enforce circularity incentives. Results indicate that production emissions dominate lifecycle impacts, highlighting the value of integrated tracking and verified recovery to support low-carbon maritime operations.

title: Extracting Multi-word Expressions from Text Using Deep Learning Models
authors: Tan Yu Jie, Lim Tong Ming
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: Multi-word expressions (MWEs) play a significant role in natural language processing (NLP), particularly in machine translation, sentiment analysis, and information retrieval. However, accurately detecting MWEs remains a challenge due to their semantic idiosyncrasies and syntactic variations. We investigated deep learning-based approaches for MWE detection, comparing different model architectures, including bidirectional encoder representations from transformers (BERT), bidirectional long short-term memory (BiLSTM), and hybrid models incorporating bidirectional gated recurrent unit (BiGRU) and global vectors for word representation (GloVe) embeddings. Various deep learning models were trained and evaluated using precision, recall, and F1-score to determine their effectiveness in identifying MWEs. The results demonstrated that transformer-based models, particularly BERT and its hybrid variants, outperformed traditional sequence-based models in capturing contextual dependencies and non-compositional meanings of MWEs. The results of the study contribute to the advancement of NLP by improving the accuracy and efficiency of MWE detection for enhancing real-world applications such as chatbot development, search engines, and automated translation systems.

title: A Method for Enhancing the Quality of Video/Image Data for AI Learning of Unstructured Data
authors: Seung Hee Kim, Dong Ju Ryu
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: This paper proposes a method to enhance the quality of video/image data for AI learning, focusing on unstructured data. Quality inspections and improvements at each stage of data construction—including acquisition, cleansing, labeling, and training—were conducted to reduce errors and improve data reliability. This approach secures high-quality datasets and enhances AI model perfo rmance.

title: MilChain-UAV: A Blockchain-Based UAV Network Traffic Control Framework for Military Operations
authors: Hope Leticia Nakayiza, Love Allen Chijioke Ahakonye, Dong-Seong Kim, Jae Min Lee
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: The growing deployment of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) in military operations necessitates a secure, scalable, and decentralized approach to airspace management. This paper introduces MilChain-UAV, a blockchain-based traffic control framework tailored for military UAV networks. Built on PureChain, a custom permissioned blockchain network, MilChain-UAV supports autonomous mission governance, real-time path validation, and decentralized collision avoidance. To optimize blockchain efficiency while ensuring auditability, telemetry data is stored off-chain using IPFS, with only the cryptographic hashes anchored on-chain. By replacing centralized controllers with a distributed ledger, the framework enhances resilience against jamming and spoofing while enabling dynamic routing and verifiable behavior logging. Experimentation results demonstrate MilChain- UA V's effectiveness in improving efficiency and scalability in critical military operations, providing a robust solution for autonomous and secure management of military UAV traffic.

title: Accelerated Convolutive Transfer Function-Based Multichannel NMF Using Iterative Source Steering
authors: Xuemai Xie, Xianrui Wang, Liyuan Zhang, Yichen Yang, Shoji Makino
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Among numerous blind source separation (BSS) methods, convolutive transfer function-based multichannel non-negative matrix factorization (CTF-MNMF) has demonstrated strong performance in highly reverberant environments by modeling multi-frame correlations of delayed source signals. However, its practical deployment is hindered by the high computational cost associated with the iterative projection (IP) update rule, which requires matrix inversion for each source. To address this issue, we propose an efficient variant of CTF-MNMF that integrates iterative source steering (ISS), a matrix inversion-free update rule for separation filters. Experimental results show that the proposed method achieves comparable or superior separation performance to the original CTF-MNMF, while significantly reducing the computational complexity.

title: Single-Switch Module, Rectangular High-Voltage Pulse Generator with Nanosecond Rise/Fall Times for Transient Plasma Applications
authors: Seyed Mohsen Mortazavi, Tom Huiskamp
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: High-voltage solid-state pulse generators are widely used for driving transient plasma reactors, where rectangular pulses with nanosecond rise and fall times are essential for efficient discharge control. Capacitive plasma loads present a major challenge: after turn-off, the low load current causes slow switch commutation and extended fall times. Conventional fall-time control in capacitive plasma loads typically relies on passive dummy loads, which accelerate switch turn-off but cause significant power losses, or an auxiliary high-voltage switch in a half-bridge configuration, which increases cost and system complexity. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes a compact single-switch module with an active dummy load and energy recovery. In this method, energy is stored in an inductor during the pulse and released after turn-off to charge an output capacitor, thereby reducing the fall time while recovering energy back into the circuit. By employing a high-voltage switch topology based on capacitive coupling and gate boosting, the rise time is significantly reduced. A 10 kV prototype demonstrates nanosecond-scale rise and fall times with substantially lower power dissipation compared to passive methods. The proposed approach combines efficiency, simplicity, and scalability, enabling precise high-repetition-rate plasma pulse generation with improved overall performance.

title: LLM-Driven Hypothesis Set Refinement for Enhanced ASR Post-Processing
authors: Chen-Han Wu, Kuan-Yu Chen
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: In high-performing automatic speech recognition (ASR) systems, post-processing plays a critical role alongside the ASR model itself. Recent studies increasingly utilize n-best hypothesis lists as inputs to post-processing models. While much of the existing research focuses on improving model architectures, we observe that the composition of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n$</tex>-best list itself can significantly impact post-processing outcomes. Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated strong performance across various speech-related tasks, often outperforming traditional methods. Although some studies have explored the use of LLMs for ASR post-processing, these efforts have primarily focused on selecting the hypothesis with the lowest error rate or directly correcting recognition errors. In this paper, we focus on the task of hypothesis set refinement (HSR)-selecting a high-quality subset of hypotheses from the original candidate list to better support downstream processing. We propose a novel LLM-based HSR method that leverages the semantic reasoning capabilities of LLMs to select a more informative, diverse, and error-tolerant hypothesis set. This refined set facilitates subsequent post-processing methods such as reranking and error correction. To validate our approach, we conduct experiments on two widely used ASR benchmarks: AISHELL-1 and LibriSpeech. Furthermore, we investigate the potential of LLMs to directly perform reranking and correction, demonstrating how LLMs can be effectively employed throughout the ASR post-processing pipeline to enhance overall system performance.

title: Natural Language Processing-Based Employee Feedback Analysis Framework for Engagement Enhancement
authors: Elsa Cherian, G. Bhuvaneswari, P.T. Vijaya Rajakumar, Hussein Basim Furaiji, Shawqi Najah, Jasim Ahmede Jasim
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: The present paper provides a sophisticated Natural Language Processing (NLP) framework on employee feedback analysis based on RoBERTa and BERTopic to increase employee engagement at the workplace. The technique is based on employing a RoBERTa-based model fine-tuned to interpret sentiment and emotion that is used to accurately determine the mood and the level of satisfaction of the employee. To identify significant themes in unstructured feedback, the framework utilizes BERTopic as an effective topic modeling algorithm that lets whoever identifies important topics without labeling them using contextual embedding and cluster patterns. In combination, the tools are used to convert unstructured, unfiltered feedback into practical information, identifying areas of employee concern, motivation, and areas of self-improvement. The processed outputs are graphically visualized to drive the HR leaders to present a clear, data-driven picture of the organization sentiment through intuitive dashboards. The streamlined and end-to end solution facilitates real time analysis and continuous monitoring, thus it can fit practices in the agile HR. The framework proposed describes a modular and effective method of establishing a more engaged, responsive, and high-performance working environment.

title: Semantic-Fast-SAM: Efficient Semantic Segmenter
authors: Byunghyun Kim
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: We propose Semantic-Fast-SAM (SFS), a semantic segmentation framework that combines the Fast Segment Anything model with a semantic labeling pipeline to achieve real-time performance without sacrificing accuracy. FastSAM is an efficient CNN-based re-implementation of the Segment Anything Model (SAM) that runs much faster than the original transformer-based SAM. Building upon FastSAM's rapid mask generation, we integrate a Semantic-Segment-Anything (SSA) labeling strategy to assign meaningful categories to each mask. The resulting SFS model produces high-quality semantic segmentation maps at a fraction of the computational cost and memory footprint of the original SAM-based approach. Experiments on Cityscapes and ADE20K benchmarks demonstrate that SFS matches the accuracy of prior SAM-based methods (mIoU <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 70.33$</tex> on Cityscapes, 48.01 on ADE20K) while achieving <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 20 \times$</tex> inference time than SSA. We also show that SFS effectively handles open-vocabulary segmentation by leveraging CLIP-based semantic heads, outperforming recent open-vocabulary models on broad class labeling. This work enables practical real-time semantic segmentation with the “segmentanything” capability, broadening the applicability of foundation segmentation models in robotics scenarios. The implementation is available at https://github.com/KBH00/Semantic-Fast-SAM.

title: Rolling Bearing Remaining Life Prediction Based on Multi-Feature Extraction and Transformer-BiTCN
authors: Mengxuan Zhai, Fuhong Kuang, Peng Hou, Xiaojian Yi
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: With the rapid development of high-end manufacturing and intelligent maintenance, predicting the Remaining Useful Life (RUL) of rolling bearings is crucial for enhancing equipment reliability and reducing maintenance costs. This paper proposes a prediction model based on multi-domain feature extraction and a hybrid Transformer-BiTCN architecture. The model combines the Transformer's multi-head attention for global temporal modeling with BiTCN's bidirectional convolutions for capturing local dependencies. A comprehensive feature selection strategy is also introduced to enhance feature relevance. Experimental results show that the proposed method achieves superior accuracy, stability, and cross-condition generalization compared to several mainstream deep learning models, demonstrating strong potential for engineering applications.

title: Multi-Modal Transformer-Guided Face Anti-Spoofing Using Depth and Texture Cues for Enhanced Biometric Authentication
authors: Poornima P, M. Tamilselvi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Biometric systems use face recognition to confirm and validate a person's identity. But most face authentication devices can be tricked by replay assaults, attacks using 3D masks, and other types of attacks. So, face anti-spoofing algorithms are becoming more important in these systems. Deep learning has recently come on the scene and done quite well on hard computer vision problems. This proposed model suggests a new Multi-Modal Transformer-Guided Face Anti-Spoofing (MTFAS) framework that uses depth and texture signals from RGB and auxiliary data streams to deal with these attacks and make biometric authentication more secure. A Vision Transformer (ViT) backbone with Cross-Modal Attention Fusion (CMAF) is at the heart of this technique. It lets the model accurately detect spoofing by capturing extremely fine spatial, context-specific, and modality-specific data. Many tests on benchmark data sets such as CASIA-FASD, Replay-Attack, and OULU-NPU show that MTFAS is better at finding both 2D and 3D attacks than the best approaches that are currently available. It is more generalizable and robust across datasets.

title: Intelligent Animal Footprint Identification and Classification Strategy based on Learning assisted Digital Image Processing
authors: S. Niranjana, Madala Soujanya, P Vicky Kumar, Safeyah Tawil, Rajkumar Bhookya, G. Karthikeyan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Accurate identification of animal species based on footprint images plays a crucial role in ecological monitoring, wildlife conservation, and biodiversity tracking. The manual identification of the footprint using traditional methods is time-consuming, and too subjective, and may be error-prone in difficult terrain or poor lighting environments. This study suggests a smart, learning aided digital picture processing method that classifies animal footprints, which is a combination of a hybrid and a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) with GradientBoosting approaches. The pipeline of the system consists of standardized preprocessing procedure (resizing, grayscale to color conversion, CLAHE, noise removal), morphological segmentation procedure (Otsu thresholding, Canny edge detection), and fine-tuned feature extraction (Histogram of Oriented Gradients, Zernike moments, and VGG16 deep features). The hybrid model involving CNN feature embeddings and Gradient Boosting classifiers is utilized to conduct classification allowing improving interpretability and generalization. Tests on the Roboflow Animal Footprints dataset show it performs better on a wide array of species, types of substrates, and noise levels. The hybrid model produced an overall classification accuracy of 95.62% which were better compared to existing standalone models along with the hybrid models, SVM (85.60%), CNN (92.48%), and other two hybrids CNN-SVM (93.05%). The framework also achieved good robustness across different substrates (accuracy range 86.3% to 95.1 %) and noise density (accuracy >83.6 % up to moderate noise). Such findings show the consistency and flexibility of the model in implementing the real environment ecological conditions. The system could be implemented in portable wildlife tracking device, mobile application, or distant sensing systems. This work offers a considerable step toward fully automated animal tracking with the least human interaction and maximum accuracy that will allow designing modern, scalable, and AI-enhanced conservation planning.

title: MapCVAE: Probabilistic Prediction of Diverse Pedestrian Behaviors on General Roads
authors: Konosuke Kobayashi, Satoru Fujita
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Accurate pedestrian trajectory prediction is crucial for autonomous vehicles, but capturing the diverse and uncertain nature of pedestrian movements remains a significant challenge. This paper introduces MapCVAE, a new model based on Conditional Variational Autoencoders (CVAE), which predicts multiple possible future paths. By integrating semantic map information, MapCVAE produces contextually appropriate trajectories and captures diverse intentions such as changing direction or stopping. Experiments show that MapCVAE significantly outperforms conventional deterministic models in predicting diverse pedestrian behaviors. This research makes self-driving cars safer because it helps them better understand where a person might walk next.

title: Modeling and Numerical Analysis of Wear of Aviation Self-Lubricating Bearings
authors: Shuo Wang, Liang Yan, Shichang Du, Shanshan Li, Xianmin Chen
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: The wear mechanism and operating condition of aviation self-lubricating bearings are important for the reliability and safety of aircraft. However, there are still relatively few studies on modeling and analysis based on the actual load characteristics of self-lubricating bearings. This paper focuses on the coupled variable load conditions that selflubricating bearings actually endure and conducts modeling and numerical simulation analysis of aviation self-lubricating bearings. First, a finite element model of the self-lubricating bearing was established based on the structure of the aviation self-lubricating bearing, and the effectiveness of the constructed finite element model was verified under pure radial load. Then, the contact stress of the self-lubricating lining was analyzed using the finite element model. Finally, the wear process of the self-lubricating bearing was simulated based on the statics of the self-lubricating bearing finite element model and the UMESHMOTION subroutine. This study can provide a certain theoretical basis for the prediction of wear amount and wear analysis of self-lubricating bearings in aviation.

title: LIF-Dip Probe Diagnostic for Pulsed Electron Plasma Source
authors: L. Orellana, W. An, A. Weisenburger, G. Müller
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: A modified Laser Induced Fluorescence Dip (LIF-Dip) diagnostic [1] is applied to study the time evolution of plasma parameters of a cathode plasma during the extraction of a pulsed electron beam by an external electrical field. Plasma parameters are estimated from measurements of the spatial electric field distribution around a small conductive probe submerged in the bulk of the cathode plasma. It is well known that the disturbance of the plasma due to the probe is screened out by the formation of a plasma sheath, a region of space charge imbalance which extends in Debye length scale towards the undisturbed plasma. The sheath's characteristics, plasma potential and spatial field distribution, are determined exclusively by the plasma parameters of the local unperturbed plasma. The plasma parameters are obtained by matching the measured electric field distribution to the field resulting from the numerical solution of the Poisson equation. The space charge density in the Poisson equation is described by the plasma parameters, which are varied in an iterative process until an optimal fit with the measurement is achieved. The measured cathode plasma parameters at different stages of the discharge and under different pulsed electron source regimes are presented.

title: Demonstration of Amplification in a Linear Format Crossed-Field Amplifier Using a Gated Field Emitter Injected Beam
authors: R. Bhattacharya, C. Segura Del Rio, J. West, M. Pearlman, W. Chern, R. Hay, A. Akinwande, A. Garner, J. Browning
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: High power crossed-field devices such as crossed-field amplifiers (CFA) are advantageous in terms of power density and efficiency. Disadvantages are low gain and relatively high noise. Improving gain and noise characteristics would make the CFA more appealing for a variety of applications. In this work, we demonstrated operation of a linear format CFA using a meander line slow wave circuit. Operating frequency is 561 MHz. The circuit is 138 mm long and 72.5 mm wide with endhats and a segmented (9 element) end collector. Circuit retardation is 21. The circuit to sole gap is 20 mm. An injected beam configuration using silicon gate field emitter arrays was used.

title: Time Series Forecasting Framework Using Explainable Deep Learning for Stock Price Prediction
authors: S. Ayyappan, Aashish A Gadgil, Rahul Gupta, Hussein Basim Furaiji, Shawqi Najah, Jasim Ahmede Jasim
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: The study introduces a time series forecasting structure of stock price prediction by establishing an all-inclusive base that incorporates explainable deep learning methods. The suggested model is a synthesis of Temporal Convolutional Networks (TCN), Bi-Directional Long Short-Term Memory (Bi-LSTM) and Transformer-based attention to successfully learn both localities and long-term dependencies in the financial time series data. In order to provide a uniformity in scaling features, MinMaxScaler was used as preprocessing normalization. The feature selection was implemented with the help of SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations), which has also allowed the vehicle to be provided with interpretability, i.e., to determine the indicators with the greatest impact that caused the predictions of the model. TensorFlow 2.x and Keras were used to develop and evaluate the model and SHAP was used to provide results explanation in real-time. Experimental findings yielded high prediction accuracy compared with traditional models, performing better as far as accuracy is concerned and increasing transparency. The framework can be viewed as a serious response to the boom of the strong-foreseeability and interpretable forecasting tools in the stock market area, and it is useful to financial analysts, investors, and AI practitioners in time series forecasting.

title: Explainable Customer Segmentation Utilizing SHapley Additive exPlanations and Artificial Intelligence-Profiled in Retail Analytics
authors: Yap Kar Wen, Yu Yong Poh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: We developed a customer segmentation system by integrating unsupervised learning with explainable artificial intelligence (AI) and natural language generation. Using a K-Prototypes clustering algorithm, customers are segmented based on mixed categorical and numerical data such as purchasing behaviour, product categories, and engagement frequency. Post-clustering and SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) values are applied to interpret the contribution of each feature toward cluster membership. The important features and their directions are then fed into a language model to generate descriptive, business-friendly narratives for each cluster to provide actionable insights. For decision-makers in companies, the developed system translates complex clustering results into data-driven profiles that are easier to understand. The framework is flexible enough to scale across different types of stores and industries. The system closes the gap between the mathematical sciences and the applicability of the arts and creates a better interpretable product that can lead to focused advertising strategies.

title: FPGA implementation of FSM based Trimmed Modified Trimean for Impulse Noise Removal
authors: P.Anuradha, Vasanth K, A.L.N.Sri Datta, Sai Krishna Kondoju, A.Vani, S Radha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: A novel architecture using FSM based trimmed modified Trimean for impulse noise removal is proposed. Nonlinear filters are significant in digital signal and image processing, particularly in applications requiring noise attenuation and edge preservation, where linear filtering techniques do not work. By using the Sequentially of FSMs, the paper discusses VLSI architecture that maximizes the performance of nonlinear filters in terms of speed, silicon area and power usage. The paper presents an FSM-based implementation of the trimmed modified Trimean with significant insight into its performance in applications of intricate filtering. With simulation and synthesis results, the paper shows how this architecture can be applied directly to real-time processing systems to meet a balance between computation efficiency and hardware resource usage. The design sorts nine image pixels at a throughput of 11.9 MHz with a critical path delay of 84 ns and power consumption of 7.77W on a Spartan-7 SP701 platform. The study contributes to VLSI design methodologies, providing practical solutions to the inclusion of high-performance nonlinear filters in modern electronic systems.

title: Advanced software development for modeling transmission/reflection spectra and non-destructive diagnostics of multilayer semiconductor structures
authors: Nikita A. Kostromin, Alexander S. Dashkov, Dmitrii A. Barykin, Leonid I. Goray
publish: 2025 Days on Diffraction (DD)
abstract: A non-destructive diagnostic technique for semiconductor multilayer structures is presented, based on fitting theoretical transmission and reflection spectra to experimental data. The method employs the Transfer Matrix Method for coherent layers and the Random Phase Method for mixed coherent-incoherent structures. Dielectric properties are modeled using the Drude model for free carrier contributions, supplemented with experimental refractive index data for substrates. The inverse problem solving utilizes three optimization algorithms: Nelder–Mead simplex, Bayesian optimization, and Genetic algorithm.

title: Reliability Modeling of Operational Amplifiers Considering Bidirectional Degradation of Input Offset Voltage
authors: Junpeng Gao, Zhiwei Zheng, Mingyang Wang, Cen Chen, Xuerong Ye, Guofu Zhai
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Operational amplifiers (op-amps) are essential components in modern electronic systems, and their long-term reliability is crucial for maintaining consistent performance. Among various performance metrics, input offset voltage (VOS) is particularly sensitive to aging and serves as a key indicator of reliability degradation. This degradation stems from time- and temperature-dependent threshold voltage mismatches in input CMOS transistors, driven by thermally activated mechanisms governed by the Arrhenius law. Consequently, VOS degradation can follow bidirectional trajectories, deviating from the typical monotonic aging behavior. Traditional unidirectional degradation models fail to capture this behavior, often leading to inaccurate and physically inconsistent reliability predictions. This paper proposes a novel reliability modeling framework for op-amps that explicitly accounts for bidirectional VOS degradation. It includes a detailed analysis of stress-induced degradation mechanisms, with transistor aging rates quantitatively modeled using the Arrhenius equation to reflect thermally accelerated failures. The model is validated through representative case studies, demonstrating its effectiveness in quantitatively evaluating the reliability of op-amps with bidirectional VOS degradation. The results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively captures the bidirectional degradation behavior of op-amps, offering accurate and physically grounded reliability predictions.

title: Toward Automated Pain Evaluation in Osteoarthritic Dogs Through Inertial Data and Machine Learning
authors: Yifan Wu, Jianxun Wang, B. Duncan X. Lascelles, Masataka Enomoto, Alper Bozkurt, David L. Roberts
publish: Proceedings of the ACM 12th International Conference on Animal-Computer Interaction
abstract: None

title: Highly Efficient Industry Scale Ozone Generation by Dielectric Barrier Discharge
authors: T. Lessle, K. Andre, M. Hochberg
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Ensuring a safe drinking water supply for an increasing population is one of the most challenging tasks of today. The rising pollution level in waste- and drinking water requires an efficient and sustainable disinfection and a treatment of organic and inorganic compounds by effective oxidation processes. As one of very few technologies injection of high concentrated, gaseous ozone/oxygen mixture into the water to be treated can be used to remove harmful germs as well as to treat micro pollutants. Large scale industrial ozone generators use dielectric barrier discharges (DBD) to convert molecular oxygen gas into an ozone/oxygen gas mixture using pulsed, high frequency and high voltage converters. This contribution gives an insight into the working principles of highly efficient industrial ozone generation systems, their main components and design.

title: Development of a 300kV Compact All Solid-State Linear Transformer Driver
authors: H. Zhou, Y. Hao, Q. Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The all-solid-state linear transformer driver (SSLTD) is considered one of the most promising technologies for high-power microwave drivers ◻ and SSLTD with compact design and light weight have become one of the key issues limiting its development and application. Research has shown that the brick, as the fundamental discharge unit of the LTD, greatly influences the system's weight and volume due to its power density. This paper proposes an ultra-compact brick based on a switch array and an all-solid-state pulse forming network. The main switch module is formed by packaging an array of series and parallel Insulated Gate Bipolar Transistor (IGBT) bare dies, offering high power density and low parasitic inductance. A pulse forming network, composed of multilayer ceramic capacitors and printed circuit board(PCB)-clad inductors, is integrated with the switch module on the same PCB to construct the ultra-compact brick. The brick is capable of delivering an output of 10 kV, with a 24 ns rise time and a 75 ns pulse width when matched with a 12Ω load. Additionally, a core reset circuit is designed to enhance the effective magnetic flux density of the nanocrystalline core, reducing the size of the magnetic core of SSLTD. The system also integrates a high-voltage charging power supply and synchronized driver circuitry for bricks. In the final test, a 30 -stage SSLTD was assembled, with four bricks connected in parallel per stage. The system successfully generated a 279 kV pulse output at a 90Ω impedance, with a rise time of 22.8 ns, a pulse width of 77 ns, and a repetition frequency capability of 100 Hz. The entire system measures <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$333 \text{mm}(\mathrm{W}) \times 333 \text{mm}(\mathrm{H}) \times 830 \text{mm}(\mathrm{L})$</tex> and weighs 200 kg.

title: Deep Neural Networks for Multivariate Granger-Causal Feature Extraction
authors: Abhinav Kumar, Aneesh Sreevallabh Chivukula, Manish Kumar
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Identifying causal drivers in multivariate time-series data is central to finance, climate science, and other domains where interactions are nonlinear, high-dimensional, and noisy. Standard Granger-causality tests, based on linear vector-autoregressive models and F-statistics, fail to capture such complexity and do not scale to modern data volumes.We introduce a unified deep-learning framework that (i) models nonlinear lag dependencies with neural networks trained under empirical-risk minimization, (ii) quantifies multivariate causal strength via a generalized-variance criterion, (iii) enhances interpretability through Bayesian-network feature selection, and wavelet-based multiscale analysis, and (iv) implements mean squared error and quantile-based loss function to uncover causal effects. Extensive experiments on S&P 500 and NIFTY 50 data demonstrate that the implemented techniques effectively uncover Granger-causal relationships, yielding significant improvements, up to 82%, in predictive performance for the multivariate feature-set. Successful implementation of a diverse range of techniques further confirms that the proposed causal detection framework provides a scalable, domain-agnostic approach to causal feature extraction.

title: Deep Q-Network Based Optimization of Model Predictive Control Motion Cueing Algorithm for Specific Scenario
authors: Yi Liang, Rongjun Fu, Lai Zhou
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Motion cueing algorithms (MCAs) enable realistic motion cues on limited-workspace platforms for flight training. In upset prevention and recovery training, conventional MCAs often fail to deliver critical sensory cues, which reduces pilot training performance. This study proposes a model predictive control-based MCA optimized using a deep Q-network. Motion cueing weights for specific scenarios are learned under platform constraints. As a result, the optimized MCAs improved overall perceptual tracking by at least 11.6% and increased the subjective ratings by at least 7.8%. These findings demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in enhancing motion realism and training efficiency under high-demand conditions.

title: Towards Cost-effective and Interpretable Sea Level Prediction: MEMS Sensors and Temporal Fusion Transformer
authors: Xueyu Ren, Jiawang Chen, Qixiao Zhou, Hai Zhu, Shang Sun, Yongqiang Ge, Chen Cao, Peng Zhou, Yulin Si, Yiyuan Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Accurate sea level prediction is crucial for coastal communities facing rising sea levels and increasing storm-surge threats. However, the black-box nature of existing predictive models limits their acceptance in operational decision-making contexts, creating an urgent need for transparent, cost-effective, and reliable forecasting solutions. Here, we propose a novel framework that combines Micro-Electro-Mechanical System (MEMS)-based ocean sensors with an interpretable machine learning approach to address this need. Utilizing two months of data collected from a MEMS accelerometer array on submarine cables, our approach integrates Variational Modal Decomposition (VMD) to isolate key temporal patterns from raw sensor measurement data, and Principal Component Analysis (PCA) to optimize feature selection. These refined features with meteorological and calendar information are fed into an interpretable machine learning model, Temporal Fusion Transformer (TFT), for sea level prediction. The TFT provides interpretable outputs, including the importance ranking of input variables and attention distribution of different time steps. Our hybrid VMD-PCA-TFT model achieved a root mean square error of 1.57 cm and a coefficient of determination (R²) of 0.98 compared to tide gauge records, outperforming existing models. These results demonstrate that MEMS-based ocean measurement systems can match the accuracy of traditional methods at a fraction of the cost. Moreover, the TFT’s interpretable analysis reveals that the VMD-PCA features accounted for more than 80% predictive power, provide transparent insights into prediction mechanisms. This dual advantage of cost-effectiveness and interoperability of our framework could potentially promote widespread deployment of ocean monitoring systems and advance prediction capabilities for climate change adaptation.

title:
Passively Q-switched and tunable continuous wave Ho:CaYAlO
                    <sub>4</sub>
                    Laser
authors: Zhaoyu Ma, Qianqian Hao, Huanli Wang, Yuwen He, Linjun Li
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Quantum Electronics
abstract: We report a passively Q-switched Ho:CaYAlO4 (Ho:CYA) laser for the first time. Under an absorbed pump power of 10.42 W, an average output power of 1.23 W at 2079 nm and a pulse width of 35.1 ns at 18.22 kHz were obtained by using Cr:ZnSe saturable absorber (SA). The single pulse energy, peak power, and slope efficiency were calculated to be 67.5 μJ, 1922.2 W, and 13.2%, respectively. The Ho:CYA laser exhibits good beam quality and power stability at maximum average output power, with a beam quality factor M2 of less than 1.2 and a root mean square stability of about 2.30%. Also, a tunable continuous wave Ho:CYA laser was obtained by inserting a birefringent filter in the resonant cavity. At an absorbed pump power of 6 W, the tunable ranges of wavelength were 2076-2174 nm. To our knowledge, this is the first report of direct generation of Ho:CYA pulsed laser by using a passive modulation device.

title: Adaptive Multi-Template Matching-Based Quality Evaluation of Terahertz Imaging of Polyethylene Pipe Defects
authors: Xinqian Li, Binghua Cao, Jinping Pan, Mengbao Fan, Fengshan Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Detecting defects in Polyethylene (PE) pipes is essential for safe gas transportation. Terahertz (THz) time-of-flight tomography method can characterize the sample’s internal structure and defect morphology, making it an ideal technique for PE pipe detection. However, tomography produces images contaminated by noise and artifacts resembling defects, resulting from the pipe’s geometry. Conventional detection algorithms often perform poorly under these conditions, leading to misinterpretations. To solve the challenge of detecting rotationally invariant defects in PE pipes, like circular holes, we propose a complete, physics-informed, and data-efficient framework for THz tomography image quality evaluation. First, the PE pipe THz tomography images are reconstructed using the time-of-flight method. Second, a physical information guided multi-template matching method is adopted to pre-screen defect images. Next, an asynchronous and independent whale optimization algorithm is employed to adaptively determine the optimal multi-template threshold combination. Finally, the optimal defect image is selected based on the composite image evaluation indicator. The experimental results show that the proposed method can select clear, well-defined, and low-noise defect tomography images, enhancing defect detection accuracy.

title: ClimateSOM: a Visual Analysis Workflow for Climate Ensemble Datasets_supp1-3634788.pdf
authors: Yuya Kawakami
publish: N/A
abstract: Ensemble datasets are ever more prevalent in various scientific domains. In climate science, ensemble datasets are used to capture variability in projections under plausible future conditions including greenhouse and aerosol emissions. Each ensemble model run produces projections that are fundamentally similar yet meaningfully distinct. Understanding this variability among ensemble model runs and analyzing its magnitude and patterns is a vital task for climate scientists.
