In this paper, we present ClimateSOM, a visual analysis workflow that leverages a self-organizing map (SOM) and Large Language Models (LLMs) to support interactive exploration and interpretation of climate ensemble datasets. The workflow abstracts climate ensemble model runs—spatiotemporal time series—into a distribution over a 2D space that captures the variability among the ensemble model runs using a SOM. LLMs are integrated to assist in sensemaking of this SOM-defined 2D space, the basis for the visual analysis tasks. In all, ClimateSOM enables users to explore the variability among ensemble model runs, identify patterns, compare and cluster the ensemble model runs. To demonstrate the utility of ClimateSOM, we apply the workflow to an ensemble dataset of precipitation projections over California and the Northwestern United States. Furthermore, we conduct a short evaluation of our LLM integration, and conduct an expert review of the visual workflow and the insights from the case studies with six domain experts to evaluate our approach and its utility.

title: A Robust Cardinalized Probability Hypothesis Density Filter for Acoustic SLAM
authors: Yuzhou Li, Zhe Chen, Fuliang Yin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Heavy-tailed noise in complex environments could seriously degrade the localization performance of Acoustic SLAM (ASLAM). To address this problem, a robust cardinalized probability hypothesis density filter for acoustic SLAM based on variational Bayesian algorithm and unscented Kalman filter (UK-RCPHD ASLAM) is proposed in this paper. Specifically, the direction of arrival (DoA) observations and the number of sound sources are modeled as a random finite set. Then, the bearing-only source states are estimated using the Gaussian mixture cardinalized probability hypothesis density (CPHD) filter, where the state update with nonlinear observations is completed by the unscented Kalman filter (UKF). Next, the CPHD posterior likelihood is approximated using variational Bayesian algorithm. Finally, the number and location of sound sources as well as the robot’s trajectory are jointly estimated based on the proposed UK-RCPHD ASLAM. The proposed method has good localization performance and strong robustness against non-Gaussian outliers. Additionally, it does not require complex data association process and can adapt to changes in the number of sound sources. Experimental results validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: HyShare: Hybrid Sample and Shading Reuse for Real-time Photorealistic Rendering
authors: Yubin Zhou, Xiyun Song, Zhiqiang lao, Yu Guo, Zongfang Lin, Heather Yu, Liang Peng
publish: IEEE Computer Graphics and Applications
abstract: Real-time path tracing is computationally expensive due to intensive path sampling and shading, especially under high frame rate and high resolution demands. We present HyShare, a hybrid reuse algorithm that integrates ReSTIR-style path sample reuse with adaptive shading reuse across spatial and temporal domains. Unlike prior methods that treat reuse in isolation, HyShare jointly optimizes both reuse types, addressing their interdependencies while maintaining image fidelity. To prevent artifacts caused by stale data and correlation, we introduce per-pixel validation and dynamic refresh mechanisms. Our system adaptively disables reuse in motion-sensitive regions using radiance and geometric change checks. Evaluated on complex dynamic scenes, HyShare outperforms state-of-the-art baselines-including ReSTIR DI, ReSTIR PT, and Area ReSTIR-improving rendering speed by  37.4% and boosting image quality (PSNR +1.8 dB, SSIM +0.17). These results demonstrate the effectiveness and generalizability of HyShare in advancing real-time photorealistic rendering.

title: High-Resolution Medical Image Generation with Leak-Prevention Mechanism using Quantum Transformer Learning
authors: Ahmad Khawaji, R. John Martin, D Daspin
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: A high-performance computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) system enhances diagnostic accuracy, enabling early detection and treatment. However, limited medical image datasets and low-quality augmentation methods hinder training, affecting CAD performance. Data augmentation increases training data but introduces augmentation leaks, where distortions in augmented images appear in generated outputs. Maintaining invertibility in augmentation can prevent leaks, but ensuring this across various generative adversarial networks (GANs) and datasets remains challenging. Additionally, existing high-resolution image generation models rely on complex deep neural networks, making optimization difficult and leading to issues like blurred lesion boundaries and poor detection of micro-leakage and micro-vessels. To address these challenges, we propose quantum transformer learning (QTL) for high-resolution medical image generation with prevention to mitigate augmentation leaks. The QTL generator enhances detail generation in high-resolution images while the prairie dog optimization (PDO) algorithm is combined with the activation function to accelerate the model convergence. Furthermore, an auxiliary multi-head neural network (AMH-NN) classifies the augmentation process during GAN training, guiding the model to avoid generating images with unintended distortions. The effectiveness of the proposed approach is evaluated using the knee osteoarthritis and medical MNIST datasets. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed model significantly reduces augmentation leaks and achieves superior image quality, attaining the lowest FID scores compared to state-of-the-art GAN models. The proposed QTL+AMH-NN model achieves 22.4% improvement in FID values for the Knee Osteoarthritis dataset and 18.6% enhancement for the Medical MNIST dataset compared to previous approaches. The most notable gain is observed in Breast-MRI (86.3%), demonstrating the model’s capability to generate high-quality medical images with minimal augmentation artifacts.

title: Feature Matching Via Self Adjusting Reliable Correspondence Set and Early Termination
authors: Kuo-Liang Chung, Jui-Che Chang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Feature matching is a fundamental task in remote sensing and 3D vision. In this paper, a new feature matching algorithm is proposed under the RANSAC interaction model in which the global RANSAC works on the initial correspondence set <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\bf {C}$</tex-math></inline-formula> and the local RANSAC works on the reliable local correspondence set which is initially constructed by removing outliers from <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\bf {C}$</tex-math></inline-formula>. To increase the matching accuracy, after each RANSAC interaction round, the proposed self adjusting strategy updates the local correspondence set adaptively by adding some potential correspondences from <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\bf {C}$</tex-math></inline-formula>, but removing some unreliable local correspondences. Combining the global and local confidence level conditions with our two early termination conditions, namely the local early termination condition and the global maximal RANSAC interaction round constraint, it can achieve the best compromise between matching accuracy and time for different inlier rate cases. Finally, we apply the weighted SVD-based method to estimate the global model solution. Based on 873 testing image pairs, comprehensive experimental results have justified the matching accuracy and execution time merits of our algorithm relative to the state-of-the-art methods.

title: Risk-Aware Joint Communication and Control Resource Allocation for Secure Vehicle Platoons
authors: Zhiwei Lin, Mingrui Zheng, Zebin Huang, Shuaiyu Zhou
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: Vehicle platoons require low-latency, reliable V2V/V2I links, yet authentication, edge processing and active attacks consume scarce resources and introduce delay and uncertainty; prior work mostly treats control, communication and security separately. In this letter, we close this gap with a risk-aware joint control–communication–security framework and a practical solver, the Distributionally Robust Primal–Dual Alternating (DR–PDA) algorithm, which couples LQR-based control updates with SCA-based convex surrogates and Wasserstein–CVaR robustness for integer resource allocation. Numerical results show DR–PDA achieves low total cost, reduced leakage and attack success, modest per-epoch runtime and a small optimality gap; ablations confirm the Wasserstein–CVaR correction is critical for tail safety, while removing modeled authentication delay lowers cost but markedly increases leakage, illustrating the latency–security trade-off.

title: Comparison Study Between Contour and Hatching Tool Path Strategies for Micromilling Fabrication of G-Band Interaction Structure
authors: S. Jain, P. Unadkat, V. Vishant, N.M. Ryskin, N. Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Research on vacuum electron device (VED)-based high-power terahertz (THz) source has attracted considerable attention worldwide due to its potential of high-power generation suitable for highresolution imaging, spectroscopy, and next-generation wireless communication systems. VED based sources such as backward wave oscillator (BWO) can be developed with a compact size and can deliver high power to be well-suited for on field applications. A VED based high-power source has three major components namely; an electron beam source, a interaction structure, and a spent beam collector. In this paper we have focused on the most pivotal component of the source i.e., interaction structure. At higher frequency range such as G-band, the size of the interaction structure becomes extremely small and any deviation in the dimensions can significantly degrade the performance of the source. This emphasises the requirement of precise control over the fabrication process. Along the same lines, this study presents a comparative investigation between two distinct tool path strategies - contour and hatching used during the micro-milling fabrication process. The studies present the effect of different tool paths on the dimensions and surface roughness of the developed interaction structure. The scanning electron microscope (SEM) characterization results accounts for dimensional deviation in the range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 20$</tex> microns and the average surface roughness as measured by ZETA 3D optical profilometer accounts for a relative difference of 200 nm between both the tool path strategies. The findings provide valuable insights into the optimization of micro-milling strategies for fabricating high-precision THz interaction structures. The study underscores the importance of selecting an appropriate tool path to enhance fabrication accuracy and surface quality, ultimately contributing to the advancement of high-power VED-based THz sources.

title: A Highly Versatile Experimental Testbed for SOS Diode Evaluation
authors: M. L. Rawson, B. Esser, H. Spencer, A. Neuber, J. Dickens, J. Stephens, J. Mankowski, J. Schrock, B. Hoff, S. Heidger
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Semiconductor opening switch (SOS) diodes along with inductive energy storage can be used to generate nanosecond high voltage pulses though the cutoff of high current densities on the order of 1-10 kA/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. The optimal operation of these diodes depends on a few key conditions, these include the charge deposited in the diode during forward pumping, as well as the peak current through the diode at reverse current cutoff.

title: Tailored Compositionally Complex Claddings for Enhanced Pulsed Power Performance
authors: L. E. Singer, A. Sarracino, K. DeZetter, M. J. Abere
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Thermal desorption of hydrogen from magnetically insulated transmission line (MITL) surfaces can lead to plasma formation and ultimately cause current loss in MA-scale accelerators. MITLs are traditionally comprised of austenitic stainless steel, which has relatively high hydrogen solubility and enhanced hydrogen diffusion along grain boundaries. While other conventional alloys may have superior hydrogen characteristics, their usage in transmission lines is limited by their ability to meet other critical criteria, such as achieving optimal time to melt.

title: Surface Deformation and Wave Stimulated by Self-Organized Pattern on a Liquid Anode of Atmospheric DC Glow Discharge
authors: Z. Yang, J. Foster
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The coherent, spatial-temporal dynamic structure observed in a liquid anode of atmospheric DC glow discharge was found to drive an intricate surface deformation and mechanical wave at the plasma-liquid interface. The surface topography shares the same geometry with the plasma pattern and it was assumed that the surface distortion enables an autocatalytic process where the uneven profile may seed the non-uniform distribution for space charge to form the self-organized pattern. To verify this assumption, the surface elevation map at the plasma-liquid interface was measured for the first time using the reflective laser speckle background-oriented schlieren technique. This work shows that the surface deformation is acted on by the Coulomb forces derived from nonuniform net-negative surface charge at the liquid anode. Various operating parameters affect the pattern and surface waves by changing the gas heating and charge relaxation time. In their temporal evolutions, the plasma pattern is fully established before the surface waves. Statistically, plasma pattern and surface wave both have constant phase velocity indicating a non-dispersive nature. These results suggest that the surface deformation does not participate in an autocatalytic process and the neutral gas mass flow boosted by thermal convection could lead to the development of patterns.

title: 4 MV 600kA Marx Generator Design with Closely Coupled Sub-Marx
authors: Y. Parker, D. Phipps, F. Ambrosini, M. Wong, J. Mamoody, P. Sincerny, P. Gordon, J. Calkins, S. Seiler
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: We have designed Marx Generators equipped with Closely Coupled Marxes (CCMs) for Nuclear Weapons Effects (NWE) simulators at the Defense Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA) West Coast Facility (WCF) operated by Fisica, Inc. (formerly L3Harris) in San Leandro, CA. By closely coupling sub-Marxes, the jitter between sub-Marxes within a single Marx tank becomes a small fraction of the pulse width and does not affect the total Marx output. The CCM design is optimized for a Marx generator of which output voltage exceeds 4 MV with sub-microsecond pulse widths. Various cases have been taken into consideration in the optimization studies and will be presented, e.g., Marx phase variations, negative and positive charging, and pre-fire. Experimental data was collected throughout implementation of multiple Fast Marx designs from single 10 stage Marxes up to four 20 stage CCMs. Circuit simulations using Castle (which is a hybrid modified nodal analysis and a transmission-line code), electro-static analysis using Quick Field and CST Studio Suite e-static solver were used for design studies. CST time domain solver, Particle In Cell (PIC), and Tracking solvers were also used for benchmarking against experimental results and design optimization studies. This presentation summarizes the design studies carried out to achieve a high voltage SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> free Marx generator with outputs greater than 4 MV and 600 kA.

title: Sub-Nanosecond Rise Time, Variable Pulse Length Blumlein-Generator for Electron Extraction in Thermionic Guns
authors: G. Loisch, M. Sack, E. Abo Ghaloun, O. Alabdullah Sharoot, R. Jonas, I. Peperkorn
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Thermionic guns are the workhorse electron sources of numerous pre-accelerators for synchrotron radiation sources in the world. At DESY in Hamburg, the thermionic gun of LINAC-II is serving user operation routinely since 10's of years. Modifications in the subsequent circular accumulator ring PIA and a possible complete bypass of this machine necessitate significantly shorter electron bunches from the linear accelerator than the current minimum length of ca. 10 ns. To facilitate this reduction, new extraction electronics based on a two-switch Blumlein-generator are being developed. Switching times of down to 0.7 ns have been achieved using GaN HEMTs as main switches for up to 600 V pulse voltages. Here, we present results of the generator operating with a test load and details on the implementation into the actual electron gun setup.

title: Simulation Study of KrCL Excimer Lamp Driven by Nanosecond-Pulsed Voltage
authors: S. Zhao, B. Huang, C. Ren, L. Dou, H. Wang, C. Zhang, T. Shao
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Ultraviolet (UV) irradiation is an important disinfection technology. UV light with a wavelength of 222 nm is very safe for the human body as it cannot penetrate the stratum corneum of the skin or the tear film layer on the eye surface. It also provides better inactivation effects on microorganisms compared with other ultraviolet wavelengths and thus offers an excellent disinfection effect with minimal human body damage. The discharge process in a chlorine-doped krypton (Kr/Cl) gas atmosphere can produce KrCl excimers, whose state transition emits ultraviolet light with a wavelength of 222 nm, making Kr/Cl gas discharge tubes ideal 222 nm UV light sources. Generally, nanosecond pulse discharge features high active particle density, and compared to AC or DC discharge, its energy conversion to molecular excited states is more efficient. However, the discharge evolution process of the Kr/Cl system driven by nanosecond voltage pulse is not yet fully understood. This research constructs a fluid model to simulate a 222 nm excimer lamp with a plate-plate structure. By applying nanosecond pulse voltage and varying the plate gap, voltage amplitude, and gas composition, we explore the reaction mechanism and factors influencing the average intensity of 222 nm ultraviolet light under nanosecond pulse, aiming to identify ultraviolet lamp design parameters with maximum radiation efficiency. This study helps quantitatively optimize KrCl UV lamp design, enhancing 222 nm radiation efficiency and its disinfection effectiveness.

title: Upgrade History and Twelve-Year Operational Statistics of Modulator-Klystron System for PLS-II 3-GeV Linac
authors: S.-D. Jang, H.-S. Kim, H. Kong, S.-J. Park
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: PLS-II 3-GeV Linac machine as the 3rd generation synchrotron injector is under an operation of 17 RF stations for the top-up operation. This machine requires highly stable RF sources to meet the beam stability requirements. A modulator-klystron (MK) system as RF sources is one of critical components for stable beam energy control since its RF power output affects the electron beam energy. Therefore, we increased and upgraded the MK system every year to support these RF requirements. In addition, we independently completed two klystron-modulator system, which will be used as a test station for a performance test of RF components for PLS-II RF Linac. One is Test Lab MK for a new developed klystron test, and another accelerator test facility (ATF) for a performance test of RF accelerating column, respectively. For last twelve-year approximately, we have experienced many troubles operating MK system, and improved a performance of them. In this paper we will share major maintenance experiences through troubleshooting activity, and discuss a detailed upgrade history and twelve-year operational statistics of modulator-klystron system for PLS-II 3-GeV electron Linac as well as the test laboratory facility.

title: Complex Power Quality Disturbance Classification Based on Fuzzy Transfer Field and Shallow Double-Path Neural Network
authors: Y. Luo
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Times disturbances of power quality in modern power systems tend to be complicated due to the diversification of electrical equipment and the complexity of equipment working conditions. Traditional classification methods are difficult to meet the classification requirement of complex power quality disturbances (PQDs). In this paper, a complex power quality disturbance classification method based on fuzzy transfer field and shallow double-path neural network is proposed. Fuzzy transfer field is a conversion scheme proposed to solve the confusion problem in the process of amplitude-dependent signal transformation in the existing mainstream dimension conversion methods. Fuzzy idea is used to blur the specific coordinates of signal points, and precisely encode the timing relationship and distribution of signal points, so that it can effectively encode the timing relationship and distribution information of signals. It can retain the features well in the process of downsampling; Shallow double path neural network is realized by referring to shallow residual network model and using double path neural network modular fast combination stack. Simulation and experiments show that the proposed method can effectively solve the confusion problem of dimension conversion schemes, and can achieve accurate and rapid identification of complex power quality disturbances with an accuracy of 98.13%.

title: Message from the General Chair
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Welcome to the 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)!

title: Deep Learning Programs Applied to Check the Anomaly in the Geometry of the 6G Antenna
authors: Jinwoo Bae, Sanghyun Yun, Woogon Kim, Jaewon Koh, Hongsik Park, Sungtek Kahng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: This paper talks about a measure to hinder people from wasting resources of developing the wireless communication system by applying deep learning approaches. As the array antenna is essential but costly to the 6G mobile communication device, no single flaw is not allowed in its manufacturing as well as design, which leads them to checking a flaw or some in its geometry. A measure is taken to comb through the pixels of the array antenna and will tell you attributes of the physical error interpreted by the deep learning algorithms. The electromagnetic characteristics will entail the information of the classes of the defects. An 8-by-8 array working for 28 GHz is taken an instance of and the corresponding far-field patterns will be presented with technical comments.

title: LEE: An Efficient Scheme of Legal Element Extraction based on Large Language Model
authors: Huaiyong Li, Wenjiang Liu, Zhao Qu, Yongping Xia, Heling Jiang, Hongfa Ding
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: In recent years, element extraction based on Large Language Models (LLMs) has attracted increasing attention. However, extracting structured elements from legal documents remains extremely challenging due to the presence of technical terminology, complex sentence structures, and implicit semantic logic. To address these challenges, this paper proposes the LEE, a novel LLM-based scheme with three stages for the efficient extraction of legal elements from structured legal documents. In LEE, we employ rule-based parsing (RBP) and context-prompting learning (CPL) to improve the effectiveness of element extraction. The proposed LEE is rigorously evaluated and compared with state-of-the-art schemes over real structured legal documents and public datasets. Experimental results show that LEE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art schemes in multiple metrics.

title: Vision-based Real-time Sign Spelling System for Cross-lingual Translation using Neural Models
authors: Yu-Cheng Chang, Yu-Cheng Lung, Yu-Xuan Lin, Shan-Xi Yang, Wei Chien
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: A vision-based real-time sign spelling system was designed to facilitate cross-lingual translation among multiple spoken languages. The system incorporates the Choose Phonetic System, which allows users to select their preferred spelling scheme (e.g., Zhuyin, Hanyu Pinyin, English alphabet, Malay phonetics), and the Choose Target Language feature, which enables dynamic translation into target languages such as Chinese, English, Vietnamese, and Malay. The developed system supports simultaneous multi-user interactions and letter-by-letter gesture recognition, allowing the interpretation of out-of-vocabulary words and proper nouns. A modular neural architecture of the model enables flexible, bidirectional mapping between sign gestures and spoken text. The system’s accuracy, efficiency, and responsiveness were validated, and the results highlighted its applicability to education, accessibility services, and cross-cultural communication platforms.

title: A Large Language Model-Based Question Answering System for Unmanned Ground Vehicles Maintenance Knowledge
authors: Weiwei Zhang, Chao Ji, Qixuan Huang, Laifa Tao
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: With the continuous advancement in the design sophistication of unmanned ground vehicles (UGVs), the exponentially increasing volume of maintenance documentation poses substantial challenges to the maintenance operations. Aiming at tackling the problems of low knowledge utilization and insufficient interactivity in the existing UGV maintenance processes, this study introduces a Large Language Model (LLM)-based Question Answering (QA) system specifically designed for UGV maintenance knowledge. The system utilizes the LLM as an interactive bridge between maintenance personnel and maintenance knowledge repositories, allowing users to engage with the knowledge base via a natural language interface. Through the application of LoRA (Low-Rank Adaptation) fine-tuning and the implementation of Reranker enhanced Retrieval-Augmented Generation (Re-RAG), the system significantly improves the LLM's proficiency in understanding and applying UGV maintenance knowledge. The efficacy of the proposed approach was verified using real-world QA datasets. Experimental results show that the method achieves excellent performance in statistical metrics, semantic similarity metrics, and accuracy metrics, confirming that the developed system can effectively enable UGV maintenance knowledge question answering.

title: Lossless Image Processing for OpenEXR Images with Flexible Functions
authors: Anna Yamaguchi, Shoko Imaizumi
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a reversible image processing method for high dynamic range (HDR) images, especially in OpenEXR format (hereafter, OpenEXR images). To our best knowledge, the proposed method is the first to aim to reversibly process HDR images. The proposed method has been designed accounting for the structure of OpenEXR images in order to ensure reversibility. Thus, we first convert the pixel values in floating-point format to signed integers and then carry out the respective processing in signed integer format. Additionally, restoration data, which is information necessary to restore the original form, is embedded into the image itself, resulting in derivation of the output image. Our method has achieved six types of image processing with full reversibility and flexible control of processing intensity. Experimental results demonstrate that each type of processing yields a significant effect, while the artifacts introduced by embedding restoration data remain visually negligible. These findings confirm the effectiveness and practicality of the proposed reversible HDR image processing method.

title: Adversarial Attacks and Defense for Secure Medical Reports Interpretation using ResNet
authors: S. Lavanya, S. Jothi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: The use of deep learning models in medical image interpretation has come with a growth in concern about their susceptibility to adversarial attacks. Residual Networks (ResNets) are very prone to perturbations that will mislead predictions without impacting the human-perceived content, even though they possess remarkable diagnostic accuracy. This approach is an adversarial defense system that is a hybrid of ResNet for training and input transformation and latent feature denoising to counter this problem. It was tested and validated on the MIMIC-CXR and NIH ChestX-ray14 datasets with a range of attack vectors, including FGSM, PGD, and DeepFool. The results of the experiment show an impressive boost in resilience over the baseline and current adversarial training techniques. Clean accuracy is above 96%, while the adversarial accuracies are above 89%. The steady CAM localization and consistent gradient alignment of the concept make it extremely intuitive. The proposed architecture offers a clinically sound, scalable, and strong alternative for the secure interpretation of medical reports.

title: A Preliminary Study on Sectional Voice Anonymization and Detection
authors: Shaoqi Tang, Zeyan Liu, Liping Chen, Kong Aik Lee, Tomoki Toda, Zhenhua Ling
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Facilitated by the speech generation framework that disentangles the speaker attribute from the original speech and represents it as an embedding vector, voice anonymization is accomplished by substituting the original speaker embedding vector with that of a pseudo-speaker. To date, voice anonymization techniques are required to anonymize a speech utterance to a single pseudo-speaker, leaving the methodology for anonymizing an utterance into multiple pseudo-speakers unexplored. To this end, this paper investigates a sectional voice anonymization method, which partitions the original utterance into sections and replaces the original speaker with distinct pseudo-speakers in each section. Subsequently, to align with the single pseudo-speaker requirement defined for anonymized speech, a detection algorithm is investigated to examine the presence of multiple pseudo-speakers in anonymized speech. Experimental results on the LibriSpeech dataset demonstrated that the sectional anonymization method was able to enhance voice privacy protection capability, and the presence of multiple pseudo-speakers in anonymized utterances can be detected. Audio samples can be found in https://voiceprivacy.github.io/sectional-voice-anonymization-and-detection/.

title: Designing a Teacher—Student Knowledge Distillation Framework for Accurate and Efficient Epilepsy Prediction on Edge Devices
authors: Salem Trabelsi, Salah Gontara, Khaled Ben Khalifa, Abdellatif Mtibaa
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: Epileptic seizure prediction is a critical challenge in clinical neuroscience, where early warnings can greatly improve patient safety and quality of life. Deep learning (DL) models have shown strong potential by automatically capturing spatiotemporal electroencephalogram (EEG) features, yet their large size and computational demands hinder deployment in real-time or resource-constrained settings. Traditional compression methods such as pruning and quantization reduce complexity but often degrade performance. In this study, we propose a teacher-student knowledge distillation (KD) framework, where a high-capacity 1D CNN-BiLSTM with attention teacher transfers its predictive power to a 1D CNN-BiGRU with attention lightweight student. The student reaches near-teacher accuracy (97% vs. 99%) while reducing parameters, compressing model size by 99%, and lowering inference latency by up to 69%. Unlike standard quantization methods, which trade either accuracy or compression, our KD approach achieves both extreme compactness with reliable accuracy and fast inference. These results highlight our framework as a practical solution for enabling real-time seizure prediction on Internet of Things (IoT) edge devices.

title: Artificial Intelligence for Circular Economy Transformation: System Design Insights from Emerging Applications
authors: Than'a Alsaoudi, Eman Ouda, Adolf Acquaye, Malik Khalfan
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive systematic literature review (SLR) investigating the role of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in advancing Circular Economy (CE) practices across diverse industries from 2015 to 2025. Starting with an initial dataset of 815 articles retrieved exclusively from the Scopus database, a systematic screening process based on predefined inclusion and exclusion criteria reduced the collection to 335 studies. Following a thorough quality evaluation and relevance assessment, a final sample of 49 articles was selected for analysis. The review encompasses a diverse range of application domains, including manufacturing, waste management, energy systems, and supply chains. It further identifies the targeted CE strategies enabled by these AI applications, such as resource optimization, waste reduction, product life extension, and emission mitigation. Building upon this synthesis, the study proposes a robust conceptual framework designed to facilitate the strategic integration of AI technologies within CE initiatives. Based on the analysis of the final sample of 49 papers, the proposed framework offers actionable design implications. It identifies critical innovation pathways to support the development of intelligent and sustainable CE solutions. By combining theoretical foundations with empirical evidence, this research advances AI-enabled sustainability and promotes the development of intelligent systems for sustainable circular transformation.

title: Artificial-Intelligence-based Smart Control System for Virtual Games
authors: Xuan Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: The advancement in computing power enables the development of intelligent control systems for virtual games. Artificial intelligence (AI) technology is widely used for network intelligent interconnection and virtual intelligence applications. Virtual games, with their demanding requirements for environment rendering, computational efficiency, and sophisticated intelligent control, pose challenges that traditional control strategies struggle to meet effectively, especially in complex scenarios. To address the challenges, an AI-based intelligent control system was developed for virtual games in this study. The developed system consists of modules for environment perception, behavior control, and AI decision-making. Intelligent algorithms were employed for the precise and adaptive adjustments of control parameters. The developed system was validated through the feedback results for intelligent control simulations.

title: Analysis and Characterization of Seeds Treated with Cold Atmospheric Plasma for Agricultural Applications
authors: Priti Pal, Udit Narayan Pal, Mahendra Singh, Minakshi Singh, Akhilesh Mishra, Hansa Sehgal, Mukul Joshi, Shivendra Maurya, Ram Prakash Lamba
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: With the rapid growth of the global population, the demand for food is increasing significantly. However, nearly 40 % of food production is lost due to fungal infections, posing a major challenge to food security. To address this issue, cold atmospheric plasma (CAP) technology is emerging as a promising, eco-friendly solution for agricultural and food processing applications. This study investigates the effects of CAP jet treatment on different types of seeds. A CAP jet system was designed and developed, along with its electrical and optical properties characterization. The characterization also includes power dissipation, dielectric capacitance, plasma plume temperature, and reactive species generation. Seed samples of wheat have been treated under different plasma exposure times. The seed treatment examinations have been carried out for direct CAP exposures to the seeds. The study analyzed the chemical and physical modifications of the seed surfaces at different operating conditions. Key parameters such as wettability, moisture content, morphological changes, microbial inactivation, and the presence of reactive species have been investigated. The results demonstrated an increase in seed wettability and moisture absorption, contributing to improved germination potential. Additionally, microbial inactivation has been significantly enhanced, suggesting that CAP treatment can help mitigate fungal contamination and improve seed health.

title: Efficient and Scalable Hybrid Parallelization of Unstructured Computational Fluid Dynamics with Geometric Multigrid
authors: Chuanfu Xu, Haozhong Qiu, Liang Deng, Jian Zhang, Xiang Gao, Jianbin Fang, Qingsong Wang, Yue Ding, Yue Wang, Zhimeng Han, Yonggang Che
publish: ACM Transactions on Architecture and Code Optimization
abstract: Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) on unstructured meshes are widely used to simulate complex flow problems. Geometric Multigrid (GMG) is an essential method to accelerate CFD simulations. However, achieving high efficiency and scalability for unstructured geometric multigrid CFD is very challenging, due to data conflicts or data dependencies at shared-memory level as well as communication bottlenecks at distributed-memory level. Traditional hybrid parallelization schemes, which typically employ domain decomposition for MPI at distributed-memory level and mesh coloring for OpenMP at shared-memory level, fail to scale on modern HPC architectures.

title: CSLXF: A Feature Fusion Framework for Social Media Depression Detection Combining Sentiment Lexicon and XLM-Roberta
authors: Jingdong Wang, Wenyan Zhao, Fanqi Meng, Guangqiang Qu, Jia Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Aiming at the problem that existing feature extraction methods are insufficient in dealing with unstandardized and implicit semantics-containing texts on social media, which leads to poor detection of social media depression, this paper innovatively proposes a feature fusion framework (CSLXF) combining the sentiment lexicon and the XLM-RoBERTa pre-trained model. First, explicit sentiment features are extracted using a sentiment lexicon, while deep semantic features in the text are extracted using the XLM-RoBERTa pre-trained model; second, the explicit and deep semantic features extracted by the above methods are dynamically fused using an adaptive gate mechanism to accurately capture explicit and implicit sentiment expressions in social media texts; and then, the localized semantic meaning of the non-canonical short texts is enhanced by feature shift enhancement. local semantic sensitivity to non-canonical short texts, and the two synergistically enhance the accuracy and robustness of depression detection. Subsequently, the above feature extraction methods are utilized to extract the features of user tweets and depressive symptom description texts respectively, and the multivariate time series of user's depressive symptoms are obtained by calculating the similarity of these two, which are finally inputted into the time series classification model for depression detection. The experimental results show that compared with the existing feature extraction methods, our method has better detection performance, and its Accuracy and F1-Score both reach 0.9, which significantly improves the effect of depression detection.

title: DRL-RAG: A Dynamic Reinforcement Learning-Driven RAG Method for Enhancing Language Model Capabilities
authors: Nianlong Zhang, Ronghua Ye, Jianmin Han
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) are inherently prone to hallucination, as the accuracy of generated text cannot be guaranteed solely by their internal knowledge. While Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) enhances LLMs by incorporating external knowledge, its effectiveness highly depends on the relevance of the retrieved documents. The inclusion of irrelevant content often leads to performance degradation. To address this limitation, we propose Dynamic Reinforcement Learning-Retrieval Augmented Generation (DRL-RAG), a novel framework designed to improve the robustness of text generation. DRL-RAG utilizes relevance scores from a cross-encoder as a reward signal within a reinforcement learning (RL) mechanism to optimize the quality of retrieved documents. Recognizing that retrieval from static corpora frequently produces sub-optimal results, our framework dynamically extends retrieval to large-scale web search when necessary. Additionally, a confidence assessment mechanism selectively filters model-generated content based on reliability. Extensive experiments on three benchmark datasets show that DRL-RAG significantly outperforms existing RAG-based methods.

title: Mitigating Data Imbalance in Automated Speaking Assessment
authors: Fong-Chun Tsai, Kuan-Tang Huang, Bi-Cheng Yan, Tien-Hong Lo, Berlin Chen
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Automated Speaking Assessment (ASA) plays a crucial role in evaluating second-language (L2) learners' proficiency. However, ASA models often suffer from class imbalance, leading to biased predictions. To address this, we introduce a novel objective for training ASA models, dubbed the Balancing Logit Variation (BLV) loss, which perturbs model predictions to improve feature representation for minority classes without modifying the dataset. Evaluations on the ICNALE benchmark dataset show that integrating the BLV loss into a celebrated textbased (BERT) model significantly enhances classification accuracy and fairness, making automated speech evaluation more robust for diverse learners.

title: RBDGuard: Accessible Early Detection of REM Sleep Behavior Disorder Using Single-Lead ECG and Unsupervised Deep Learning
authors: Brenna Ren
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 23rd International Conference on Software Engineering Research, Management and Applications (SERA)
abstract: REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD) is a significant predictor of neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson’s Disease, but its diagnosis currently requires resource-intensive polysomnography (PSG) studies, limiting widespread screening. This paper presents RBDGuard, a novel deep learning framework that enables RBD detection using only single-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) data by leveraging both unlabeled and labeled datasets through unsupervised pre-training with supervised fine-tuning. This approach capitalizes on the increasing accessibility of ECG monitoring through wearable devices to offer an easy and inexpensive early diagnostic tool for sleep disorders. RBDGuard’s architecture employs bidirectional LSTM layers for unsupervised pre-training followed by dense layers with dropout for supervised classification. RBDGuard utilized 377,622 unlabeled 30-second ECG segments from 9,174 subjects and 39,316 labeled 30-second ECG segments from 37 subjects (22 RBD, 15 control) across three public databases. Compared to the exclusively supervised model, RBDGuard achieved significant improvements in accuracy (from $80 \%$ to $97 \%$) and reduction in misclassification (a $75 \%$ decrease in false positives and 95% decrease in false negatives), reducing both missed diagnoses and unnecessary referrals. Extensive testing demonstrated that the model consistently maintained accuracies of $\mathbf{9 7 \% - 9 8 \%}$ across different pre-training datasets, outperforming the supervised-only approach and indicating its adaptability to different clinical settings. These promising results establish RBDGuard as an accurate, efficient alternative to traditional PSG studies, paving the way for widespread early detection of RBD using unsupervised learning with ECGs. This advancement enables cost-effective, accessible early diagnosis of neurodegenerative diseases, transforming medical care and improving millions of lives.

title: Effects of Load Positioning on Muscle Fatigue During Hiking: Electromyography and Lactate Response Analysis
authors: Muhammad Anugra Rizky Rambe, Hesty Susanti, Liana Nafisa Saftari, Salsabila Aurellia, Adinda Shal Sabillah Kuncahyo, Aydin Muhammad Hafizh
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Instrumentation, Control, and Automation (ICA)
abstract: Muscle fatigue remains a prevalent issue during hiking, particularly when carrying a loaded mountain backpack. Improper load distribution is a key contributing factor, especially affecting the lateral hamstrings (HA), which play a critical role in maintaining postural stability. This study investigates the impact of load placement on muscle fatigue, energy efficiency, and postural control using a quantitative experimental approach. Surface electromyography (sEMG) and blood lactate accumulation were employed as physiological indicators of fatigue. Muscle activity from the HA was recorded via sEMG, while blood lactate levels served as a complementary biomarker. sEMG signals were analyzed in both the time and frequency domains. Time-domain features, Mean Absolute Value (MAV), Root Mean Square (RMS), and Integrated EMG (iEMG), quantified muscle activation, while frequency-domain metrics, Median Frequency (MF), Mean Frequency (MnF), and Spectral Entropy (SEN), captured spectral changes associated with fatigue. ANOVA analysis in the frequency domain revealed p-values ranging from 0.06 to 0.12, with the most prominent trend observed for SEN (p = 0.0670). Although not statistically significant, post hoc analysis of both sEMG features and blood lactate data supported these trends, indicating potentially meaningful physiological responses to load placement. These preliminary results highlight the influence of backpack load configuration on muscle fatigue and underscore the need for further investigation with larger sample sizes to substantiate these findings and inform evidence-based hiking ergonomics.

title: Data Augmentation in Invalid User Detection Based on a Typing Speed of Individual Words
authors: Takumi Ito, Tomoya Kawakami
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: In this paper, the authors improve the accuracy of invalid user detection based on the keyboard typing (keystroke) speed as a user’s behavioral characteristic. In an information society, countermeasures against unauthorized access have become essential. However, the difficulty is directly linked to the strength of security to judge a user valid or invalid. This is a problem that makes access to information more complicated and reduces the user’s convenience. The proposed method focuses on the keyboard typing speed and enhances security without reducing convenience by detecting invalid users in the background. The authors compared user models learning with logistic regression, XGBoost, and CatBoost using keyboard typing data collected from 20 users. The experiment results showed that the accuracy is improved from the previous study to detect invalid user by training with XGBoost and CatBoost, along with data augmentation and feature selection.

title: Empowering IoT with Large Language Models: A Survey of Applications, Challenges, and Future Directions
authors: Ali Shahraeeni, Rupinder Kaur, Abbas Kochari, Farah Mohammadi, Arghavan Asad
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: The integration of Large Language Models (LLMs) with the Internet of Things (IoT) is reshaping intelligent systems, enabling advanced automation, cybersecurity, and natural user interaction in cyber-physical environments. This survey synthesizes recent advances in LLM-IoT integration, highlighting transformative applications, challenges, and emerging solutions. Key applications include intelligent automation, with AutoIoT achieving 94.1%–98.5% accuracy in zero-code orchestration; personalized healthcare, with LLM-HAS reducing false alarms by 8.147%; and cybersecurity via ChatIoT and BARTPredict, the latter with 98% intrusion detection accuracy. Challenges include computational constraints on edge devices, privacy risks in data handling, and hallucinations, with medical LLMs showing up to 15% error rates without fine-tuning. Solutions like federated learning, model compression (reducing memory usage by up to 50%), and hybrid frameworks such as LLMind improve efficiency and privacy. This survey offers a comparative analysis of these approaches, providing insights into their trade-offs. Future research should focus on multimodal LLMs, scalable edge deployments, and trustworthy systems powered by explainable AI. By addressing these issues, LLM-IoT ecosystems can evolve toward resilient, adaptive, and human-centric intelligent systems, enabling more generalizable AI in IoT-driven environments.

title: Sloshing in vertical cylinders with circular walls and porous, radial baffles: examples of explicit solutions
authors: Nikolay Kuznetsov, Oleg Motygin
publish: 2025 Days on Diffraction (DD)
abstract: Sloshing eigenvalues are studied for vertical cylindrical containers of constant (possibly infinite) depth having circular walls and radial baffles that extend throughout the depth. The fluid transmission across the baffles is described by Darcy’s law, and so the spectral problem is nonself-adjoint. Explicit solutions are obtained, whose crucial feature is that the corresponding pressure difference vanishes across the baffle. These real solutions coincide with those that describe sloshing in the presence of rigid baffles, thus, demonstrating that at certain frequencies the damping efficiency of porous baffles is the same as that of the rigid ones having the same configuration.

title: Entropy Regularization and Trade-off Strategies for Policy Gradient Agent Recommendation in Dhaka Stock Exchange Market
authors: Md. Nadim Sheikh, Rashedur M. Rahman
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: To improve the performance of policy gradient agents for stock recommendations on the Dhaka Stock Exchange, this work explores the use of entropy regularization of the advantage critic function instead of traditional reward shaping. Policy gradient methods, while demonstrably effective for optimizing sequential decision-making tasks, can exhibit instability and converge to suboptimal solutions. Entropy regularization offers a potential remedy by promoting exploration and discouraging premature convergence. This research explores the inherent trade-off between exploration and exploitation within the context of the DSE’s specific market dynamics. The objective is to develop and evaluate adaptive strategies that leverage entropy regularization to improve the robustness and profitability of policy gradient-based recommendations.

title: Optical Imaging of Pulsed Power Outputs for Diode Performance and Dose Variation Analysis
authors: G. Marshall, M. Johnston, T. Zarick
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Optical imaging techniques provide valuable insights into pulsed power outputs by enabling continuous observation of beam profiles over a large area. At Sandia National Laboratories, we utilized solid and gas phase scintillators to capture optical information and investigate the effects of machine configurations at two pulsed power facilities: HERMES-III [1] and SPHINX [2].

title: End-to-End Simultaneous Dysarthric Speech Reconstruction with Frame-Level Adaptor and Multiple Wait-k Knowledge Distillation
authors: Minghui Wu, Haitao Tang, Jiahuan Fan, Ruizhi Liao, Yanyong Zhang
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Dysarthric speech reconstruction (DSR) typically employs a cascaded system that combines automatic speech recognition (ASR) and sentence-level text-to-speech (TTS) to convert dysarthric speech into normally-prosodied speech. However, dysarthric individuals often speak more slowly, leading to excessively long response times in such systems, rendering them impractical in long-speech scenarios. Cascaded DSR systems based on streaming ASR and incremental TTS can help reduce latency. However, patients with differing dysarthria severity exhibit substantial pronunciation variability for the same text, resulting in poor robustness of ASR and limiting the intelligibility of reconstructed speech. In addition, incremental TTS suffers from poor prosodic feature prediction due to a limited receptive field. In this study, we propose an end-to-end simultaneous DSR system with two key innovations: 1) A frame-level adaptor module is introduced to bridge ASR and TTS. By employing explicitimplicit semantic information fusion and joint module training, it enhances the error tolerance of TTS to ASR outputs. 2) A multiple wait-k autoregressive TTS module is designed to mitigate prosodic degradation via multi-view knowledge distillation. Our system has an average response time of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 0 3}$</tex> seconds on Tesla A100, with an average real-time factor (RTF) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 7 1}$</tex>. On the UASpeech dataset, it attains a mean opinion score (MOS) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4. 6 7}$</tex> and demonstrates a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 4. 2 5 \%}$</tex> relative reduction in word error rate (WER) compared to the state-of-the-art. Our demo is available at: https://wflrz123.github.io/

title: Pedestrian Detection Based on Visible Guided Occlusion Handling
authors: Lien-Chieh Huang, Ching-Te Chiu, Yung-Cheng Su
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Accurate and timely pedestrian detection is crucial in autonomous driving systems. There are a few major challenges including detecting pedestrians of varying sizes and distances within an image, occluded pedestrians or mutual occlusion, and high computational complexity. We propose a Visible Guided Pedestrian Detection (VGPD), in which the visible guided auxiliary head is only used during training, provides more supervision to reduce the ambiguity caused by occlusion, and helps eliminate false positives. The visible guided label assignment ensures accurate positive samples for heavily occluded pedestrians and improves classification. We utilize re-parameterization module that merges multiple computational layers into a single one at the inference stage, to enhance feature representation and reduce complexity. In addition, Adaptive Spatial Feature Fusion (ASFF) and Path Aggregate Network (PAN) effectively fuse multiscale features. VGPD achieved state-of-the-art performance on CityPersons, reducing inference time by an average of 48%. Compared to our baseline, VGPD also reduced the log average miss rate (the lower the better) from 9.9 to 7.7.

title: Joint Separation and Tracking of Moving Sources with Distributed Microphone Arrays Based on Time-Varying Inertial Spatial Models
authors: Ryunosuke Nihei, Yoshiaki Bando, Aditya Arie Nugraha, Diego Di Carlo, Hiroyuki Ueda, Yosuke Ito, Kazuyoshi Yoshii
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This paper describes the first attempt at separation and tracking (3 D localization) of multiple moving sound sources using multiple microphone arrays fixed at known locations in an indoor environment. As for static sources, location-dependent priors have been incorporated on the time-invariant spatial covariance matrices (SCMs) of sources in the statistical framework of blind source separation based on multichannel nonnegative matrix factorization (MNMF), achieving the maximum likelihood estimation of source locations. One may thus make both the SCMs and their priors vary over time to deal with source movements. This naive extension, however, fails to localize sources when the sources are inactive, yielding non-smooth, non-continuous trajectory estimates. To solve this problem, we formulate a hierarchical probabilistic model for multichannel mixture signals that consists of inertial Markov models for source locations, location-aware moving-average models for source SCMs, and NMF-based lowrank models for the power spectral densities (PSDs) of sources. All the time-varying attributes of sources are jointly estimated under a maximum-a-posteriori (MAP) principle, and the source images are then estimated with a multichannel Wiener filter. The experiment using simulated data with two moving sources and four four-channel arrays showed that the proposed method achieved better separation and smoother localization.

title: Data-Driven Model Reduction for MIMO Wind Farm Systems via Right-Tangential Interpolation
authors: Azka Muji Burohman, Aulia Rahma Jumardi, Yul Yunazwin Nazaruddin
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Instrumentation, Control, and Automation (ICA)
abstract: This paper investigates a data-driven model reduction approach based on right-tangential interpolation for discrete-time multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems within the informativity framework. While the original formulation of informativity-based interpolation was developed for single-input single-output (SISO) systems, we extend it to the MIMO setting. Using only time-domain input–output data, we first establish a necessary and sufficient condition to ensure the data informativity for computing right-tangential moments. Once this condition is satisfied, the corresponding moments can be computed directly without requiring explicit identification of the full-order system. A reduced-order model (ROM) is then constructed by matching these moments along prescribed tangential directions. The effectiveness of the proposed method is demonstrated through its application to a high-dimensional wind farm system, showing significant model compression while preserving key dynamic characteristics.

title: Evaluating the Source Code Review Performance of LLM-based AI Chatbots
authors: Toya Kakimoto, Hiroki Inayoshi, Hidetake Uwano, Akito Monden
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Source code review plays a critical role in ensuring software quality by identifying bugs early in the development process. Although recent studies have explored the use of large language models (LLMs) for tasks such as vulnerability detection and automated code refinement, few studies have evaluated their performance against human reviewers during the review phase. In this study, we empirically evaluate the bug detection capabilities of several LLM-based AI chatbots using a benchmark C program containing 27 bugs, originally used in a prior human-based code review study. We tested AI chatbots including GPT-4o, Grok-3, and Claude 3.7 Sonnet, under varying conditions such as code granularity, specification document availability, and Chain-of-Thought (CoT) reasoning. Our results show that while chatbots achieve bug detection performance comparable to that of human reviewers, they do not yet surpass them. We further analyze how code granularity, specification availability, and CoT reasoning affect the performance, and discuss the challenges that need to be addressed for effective LLM-assisted code review automation.

title: Big Data Analytics to Balance Between Urban Food Supply and Demand
authors: Wei-Ling Hsu, Yuanyuan Lu, Lin Mou, Zuorong Dong, Hsin-Lung Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: Using big data and geographical information system technology, we quantitatively measured the food supply and demand of the Northern Guangdong Ecological Development Area in 2024. By employing Normalized Difference Vegetation Index data, we estimated supply and demand capacity with population data. The spatial distribution characteristics of food supply and demand were also revealed. The results indicate an imbalance between supply and demand, with natural and socioeconomic factors exerting significant influences. The results of this study provide a basis for optimizing territorial spatial layouts.

title: Efficient Dynamic VLSI Design with Error Detection and 8-Way Power Amplifier for Triple-Gate Vertical Power MOSFET
authors: Anumala Alekhya, Maram Y Al-Safarini, T Sunitha, K Veeranjaneyulu, Swathi B, R Deivanayaki
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: The Efficient Dynamic VLSI Design with Error Detection and 8-Way Power Amplifier for Triple-Gate Vertical Power MOSFET (EDVEPT) model, a new solution designed to improve power amplifier (PA) performance for radar and wireless communication applications. This model combines a highly efficient Triple Gate Vertical Power MOSFET made from SiGe materials with an 8-way balanced PA system. By using a wideband balanced PA setup with Lange couplers, the EDVEPT enhances signal stability, reduces insertion loss, and increases power output, particularly for FMCW radar in the W-band. It includes transformer-based push-pull PA stages, which improve output power and impedance matching. Simulation results show consistent performance, with insertion loss below 4 dB and output return loss above 8 dB under varying loads. It also features a probability-based error detection system and adaptive noise detection using infrared sensors. The EDVEPT's SiGe-based MOSFET provides superior performance over traditional Si-channel MOSFETs, achieving low ON-state resistance and high current drive.

title: Intelligent Perception Model for Detecting College Students' Psychological Abnormalities Based on Educational Big Data
authors: Meihe Shang, Yixin Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: We developed an intelligent perception model for the detection of psychological abnormalities of college students based on educational big data. We employed advanced data mining techniques to process large amounts of psychological data to identify early indicators of mental health problems. The model predicted potential psychological risks to classify students according to their psychological profiles based on the data classification and association rule mining. The model was built on a three-tier architecture, providing scalability and efficient data management. The evaluation metrics and algorithms were used to evaluate the model's prediction precision. The model informs mental health professionals of timely intervention for student wellbeing. With its incorporation into educational environments, this smart model optimizes student mental health monitoring, offering a proactive and systematic solution to respond to psychological anomalies.

title: Research on Electrical Fault Detection in Railway Relay Circuits based on SPICE
authors: Haoran Zou, Yang Yang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Aiming at the problem that it is difficult to simulate the electrical characteristics of complex rail relay circuits and to detect faults, a SPICE-based electrical characteristics simulation method is proposed. First, based on formal modeling of relay circuits, the circuit structure is analyzed to identify series-parallel relationships. Next, a circuit simplification strategy is designed to reduce the complexity of the relay circuit structure. Finally, the SPICE algorithm is used to enhance the node voltage method. The simplified circuit is then simulated and analyzed, and the simulation results are compared with the expected values to detect potential electrical faults. Taking the transmitter-receiver circuit as an example for experimental verification, the results show that this method improves the accuracy of calculations, making fault detection more precise. This demonstrates the method' <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$s$</tex> advantages in improving the accuracy of the electrical analysis of relay circuits and offers new ideas and methods for research and practice in this field.

title: A Smart Platform for Food Enthusiasts Driven by AI for Recipe Sharing and Discovery
authors: Elangovan T, Mukesh M, Jeevan M S, Satheesh P
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Food is the most important element of humanity and it attaches us to each other through diverse food experiences. As a result, the rise of recipe recommendation platforms has created the demand for more intelligent and context-aware systems that can offer personalized and precise results. In this paper we propose a new recipe recommending system which improves significant functionalities such as ingredient based search and recipe suggestions using BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers) and handle real-time user feedback. Whether adding the intended twist to a dish by only searching for certain ingredients helps to bring different semantic organization into traditional keyword-based search is a question that can be answered only through experience. It incorporates BERT's bidirectional capabilities to very closely consider the query against not only which ingredients, but which cooking methods were used to create a recipe. Moreover, thanks to a dynamic adaptability feature, the AI continuously incorporates user feedback, tailoring its suggestions even further based on personal preferences and dietary restrictions. We further investigate the incorporation of up-to-the-minute user input, allowing the model to adjust its predictions based on the feedback provided to it by the user in the form of ratings and comments. Compared to traditional models, our approach demonstrates significantly improved recommendation accuracy, user engagement, and overall satisfaction, as evidenced by our results. As large datasets with complex ingredient combinations become more ubiquitous, the scalability of the model and its capacity to handle complex recipes will be one of the most important features of modern recipe recommendation systems. Personalized recipe platforms are an emerging area in the recipe domain, and this research adds to this new area by taking a more contextual and interactive approach to recipe search and discovery.

title: DAHG: Heterogeneous Graph-Based Dual Attention for Emotion Recognition in Conversations
authors: Yao Fu, Junpeng Gong, Pengzhou Zhang, Zhanxin Yang, Juan Cao
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: In human-computer interaction, emotion recognition in conversations is paramount as it enables machines to understand speakers’ emotions better and respond appropriately. Although Graph Neural Networks have been widely used in emotion recognition to model contextual information, current research has not yet explored the full potential of heterogeneous multimodal data. Therefore, a heterogeneous graph is constructed based on speaker dependencies between utterances and connections between different modalities. This graph aims to capture the context of multimodal interactions. A dual attention mechanism is used to calculate the impact of various modalities on contextual information precisely. The features of the utterance are improved to distinguish confused emotions better. We evaluated the performance of our proposed model on two publicly available benchmark datasets (IEMOCAP and MELD). Extensive experiments have shown that our model outperforms the baseline models.

title: LogTRV: A Log Compression Framework Based on Template Parsing and Token Encoding
authors: Jigang Wen, Quan Feng, Mingkuan Wei, Shiming He, Kun Xie, Yuxiang Chen, Xiaoxiao Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: In large-scale distributed systems, log data grows rapidly and poses significant challenges to storage and transmission. Traditional general-purpose compression methods often fail to exploit the structural characteristics of logs, leading to suboptimal compression performance. Existing log parsingbased compression methods exhibit unstable performance in parameter mapping dictionaries and fail to account for nonnumerical data compression. To address the two problems, we proposes LogTRV, a log compression framework that integrates log parsing with multi-level encoding strategies. The framework first utilizes the TCMS parser to separate log templates and parameters. It then applies a series of data processing models, including timestamp delta encoding, token run-length encoding, and numeric variable-length encoding, to reduce redundancy. Finally, the processed data is compressed using a general-purpose algorithm (e.g., bzip2). Experiments on large-scale real-world log datasets demonstrate that LogTRV achieves significantly higher compression ratios than baseline methods such as gzip, bzip2, and Logzip, while maintaining competitive compression efficiency. The results also highlight the effectiveness of different parsing and encoding modules within LogTRV.

title: RoutingGuard: Hop-Count-based Route Protection
authors: Bocheng Liang, Fuliang Li, Qiang He, Qi Wang, Xingwei Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: The increasing demand for real-time network services imposes stricter requirements on service quality and fault recovery time. Routing protection techniques address failure scenarios through backup path provisioning to achieve rapid and high-quality recovery. However, existing methods fail to simultaneously ensure comprehensive fault scenario coverage and high-quality backup paths while suffering from storage overhead and computational delays caused by redundant paths. To resolve these challenges, we propose RoutingGuard, which aims to identify the minimal set of backup paths for protecting optimal routes. We further design a novel dual-stack data structure that significantly enhances execution efficiency and ensures computational accuracy through controlled path access sequencing. Experimental results demonstrate that RoutingGuard achieves the highest protection rate compared to existing approaches while maintaining top-tier convergence speed.

title: Cross-Version Evolution Detection for Dependency Structures of Operating System: A Graph Embedding-Based Approach
authors: Xinran Hong, Jun Ma, Jing Wang, Chuang Zhang, Yongtao Tang, Min Liu, Binrui Zeng, Hao Xu, Zhilong Liu, Jie Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: As the foundation of modern software ecosystems, a distribution of Operating System (OS) is usually composed of a certain number of software packages among which exist complex dependency relationships. The refactoring of package dependency structures is an important form of evolution between different distributions that has been key factor affecting the compatibility of OS. Existing studies primarily focus on static dependencies or specific software subsets, lacking systemlevel modeling and structural analysis of cross-version evolution of the OS. To address this gap, we propose a unified framework for system-level modeling and analysis based on graph embedding techniques, designed to characterize structural changes in OS package dependencies over time. Our method constructs a homogeneous dependency graph spanning multiple OS versions and applies the HOPE embedding algorithm to extract evolution features and detect changes in dependency structure. Using this framework, we identify a novel evolution pattern -intermediate-layer phenomena - where functional roles remain stable despite significant structural refactoring. We further classify these phenomena into two types: refactored intermediate layers, which optimize architecture by reorganizing dependency topologies, and transition intermediate layers, which preserve interface compatibility through proxy packages. We validate our approach on six Ubuntu LTS versions (14.04-24.04), achieving 85.5% accuracy in detecting refactored intermediate layers and successfully uncovering unmarked transition proxy packages. This work offers a new perspective and technical means for analyzing OS structural evolution and assessing compatibility risks.

title: Are Multimodal Foundation Models All That Is Needed for Emofake Detection?
authors: Mohd Mujtaba Akhtar, Girish, Orchid Chetia Phukan, Swarup Ranjan Behera, Pailla Balakrishna Reddy, Ananda Chandra Nayak, Sanjib Kumar Nayak, Arun Balaji Buduru
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: In this work, we investigate multimodal foundation models (MFMs) for EmoFake detection (EFD) and hypothesize that they will outperform audio foundation models (AFMs). MFMs due to their cross-modal pre-training, learns emotional patterns from multiple modalities, while AFMs rely only on audio. As such, MFMs can better recognize unnatural emotional shifts and inconsistencies in manipulated audio, making them more effective at distinguishing real from fake emotional expressions. To validate our hypothesis, we conduct a comprehensive comparative analysis of state-of-the-art (SOTA) MFMs (e.g. LanguageBind) alongside AFMs (e.g. WavLM). Our experiments confirm that MFMs surpass AFMs for EFD. Beyond individual foundation models (FMs) performance, we explore FMs fusion, motivated by findings in related research areas such synthetic speech detection and speech emotion recognition. To this end, we propose SCAR, a novel framework for effective fusion. SCAR introduces a nested cross-attention mechanism, where representations from FMs interact at two stages sequentially to refine information exchange. Additionally, a self-attention refinement module further enhances feature representations by reinforcing important cross-FM cues while suppressing noise. Through SCAR with synergistic fusion of MFMs, we achieve SOTA performance, surpassing both standalone FMs and conventional fusion approaches and previous works on EFD.

title: Patrol: Max-Min Passive-Active Hybrid in-Band Network Telemetry Method in SDN
authors: Yang Cao, Yunhe Cui, Hongfeng Gao, Chun Guo, Yi Chen, Guowei Shen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: With the growing scale and complexity of networks, the need for real-time and fine-grained network monitoring is becoming increasingly critical. In this work, we propose a new insight into current In-band Network Telemetry (INT) approaches, which collects as much telemetry metadata by maximal-coverage passive INT and achieves low-bandwidth overhead using minimal-cost active INT. We propose Patrol, a max-min passive-active hybrid INT method designed for efficient global network telemetry in Software-Defined Networking (SDN). Patrol designs a maximal-coverage passive INT strategy and a minimal-cost active INT strategy. Using these strategies, Patrol achieves full telemetry coverage and lowbandwidth network telemetry. Patrol has been implemented on the Open vSwitch (OVS) to evaluate its performance. Evaluation results show that Patrol achieves 100% network coverage while reducing about 80.00% average bandwidth overhead compared with the existing hybrid INT method.

title: Examination of Breast Cancer Histology Images with MobileNet and NASNet Models
authors: V. Rajinikanth
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: In women community, the Breast-Cancer (BC) causes a larger infection-rate and death-rate. When the BC is detected in its early phase, it can be completely treated with necessary clinical procedure. Early detection and confirmation of BC involves in various imaging procedures including histology data. Manual examination of histology images are quite complex and hence, this research proposed deep-learning (DL) based tool and to improve its outcome, image pre-processing is executed. The various phases of this DL-tool consist the following phases; image collection and size modification, features extraction with DL-model and implementing classification with SoftMax, identification of best DL-models for generating fused-features-vector (FFV) using 50% reduction and serial fusion, and performance verification using classification and 5-fold cross validation. This research demonstrated the performance with MobileNet-variants and NASNet-variants using 5000 images of benign/malignant class. The result of this work confirms that the FFV-based analysis provides >97%.

title: Compact Solid-State Marx Generator Design
authors: Evan Loftin, Andrew Chysler, Henry Gaus
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: This work discusses a 90 kV Solid-State Marx Generator under development at Los Alamos National Laboratory. The final Solid-State Marx Generator is anticipated to have approximately 90 stages, each stage contributing 1 kV to the transient pulse. This Marx Generator uses SiCFET devices to perform the switching. The circuit topology is designed to be a Positive Polarity Marx Generator.
