The Marx Generator will have a 100 Hz pulse rate with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 \mu$</tex> s flattop pulses. Simulations indicate sub microsecond rise times and fall times on the order of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0 ~ n s}$</tex>. The droop should not exceed 5%. This work includes simulations of the full system response. Initial circuit simulations include idealized triggering of the SiCFET switches. Simulations also analyze the effects of capacitor size on droop. The actual triggering system will consist of highspeed (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 3 1 0 ~ n m}$</tex>) fiber optics and an Arduino to control timing. The pulse from multiple stages is characterized and analyzed. The system is analyzed for voltage breakdown areas. The data is used for assessing potential methods for creating a larger system with as many as 90 stages.

title: Federated Learning-Enabled Privacy-Preserving Analytics Framework for Multi-Cloud Data Environments
authors: Lakshya Sahai, Anand Chauhan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Current progress in cloud computing necessitates the constant attention to the Security, Privacy, and Regulatory Compliance. The following paper is a systematic review of recent trends in the use of Federated Learning and Artificial Intelligence to enhance the security of the cloud and maintain user privacy in multi-cloud data models. Based on the findings in the framework of a systematic literature review including 30 studies released since 2020 and until 2024 following the PRISMA 2020 checklist, it is revealed that in case of critical sectors, when incorporated with data anonymization, normalization, and a filter-related approach, Federated Learning drops the risk of privacy invasion by 25% and 40% improves threat detection. Approximately 80 percent of the considered implementations show better privacy preservation, but such problems as communication overhead or latency persist, with 50 percent of studies showing this address. New alternatives like Federated Neural Networks , hybrid networks and cryptographic improvements are studied to the issues. The current paper presents the development of a scalable deployment plan that can be used to implement Federated Learning to support secure, real-time analytics in Industrial Internet Things of Things (IIoT), autonomous systems, and dynamic edge-based environments with the enhancement of privacy-preserving frameworks of robust cloud security.

title: Electrothermal Instabilities Observed by X-Ray Radiography of Underwater Sub-Microsecond Electrical Explosions of Aluminum, Silver and Molybdenum Wires
authors: R. Grikshtas, N. Asmedianov, O. Belozerov, S. Efimov, J. Strucka, Y. Yao, B. Lukic, A. Rack, S. N. Bland, Y. E. Krasik
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: We present measurements of the wavelength of electrothermal instabilities <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup> (ETI) formed during underwater electrical explosions of aluminum (Al), silver (Ag) and molybdenum (Mo) wires. Wires were exploded using a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 450 \text{ns}$</tex> risetime and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 120 \text{kA}$</tex> amplitude current pulses delivered by a pulse generator. Images of the exploding wires were captured by multi-frame synchrotron radiography at the ID19 beamline of the European Synchrotron Radiation Facility.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> Resolvable ETI was observed only in Al and Ag wires after the vaporization phase, while no such instabilities were detected in Mo wires. Fourier analysis revealed that the ETI wavelengths in Al and Ag wires were comparable within the spatial resolution error, despite their different minimal instability wavelengths, which were predicted to develop during the melting phase. These minimal wavelengths were calculated using the linear ETI development theory and the simulated wire temperature. The latter was calculated via one-dimensional hydrodynamical simulations, considering uniform current density across the wire cross-sectional area.

title: CRSPU: Exploit Commonality of Regular Sparsity to Support Various Convolutions on Systolic Arrays
authors: Jingkui Yang, Jianchao Yang, Mei Wen, Junzhong Shen, Yasong Cao, Minjin Tang, Renyu Yang, Xin Ju, Zhaoyun Chen, Yang Shi, Chunyuan Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Dilated convolution and transposed convolution are widely used in the inference or backpropagation of generative adaptive networks (GANs) and convolutional neural networks (CNNs). They introduce non-contributing zeros in structured sparsity patterns (called regular sparsity in this work) into the kernels or into the feature maps as an inherent pre-processing stage before executing standard convolution operations. Existing accelerator designs typically pre-populate tensors with explicit zero values and then perform sparse computing on the zeropopulated tensors, which incurs high control complexity and hardware overhead. To address this, we propose CRSPU, a systolic array-based accelerator exploiting regular sparsity without modifying its original data flow. We redesign the traditional im2col algorithm with two address-level optimizations—Public Dimension Compression (PDC) and Similar Sparsity Merging (SSM)—to eliminate unnecessary computations induced by non-contributing zeros. We implemented CRSPU in RTL and the experiments show that CRSPU achieves a peak throughput of 7736 GOPS, with area and PE efficiencies of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2046.56 \text{GOPS} / \text{mm}^{2}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$30.22 \text{GOPS} / \text{PE}$</tex>, respectively. Compared with the state-of-the-art GANPU accelerator, CRSPU improves CycleGAN training speed by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.36 \times$</tex>, achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7.09 \times$</tex> higher PE efficiency, and reduces on-chip bandwidth requirements by up to 54.63%. On average, it achieves 93.27% PE utilization across various GAN workloads, demonstrating strong efficiency and scalability.

title: A Regional Clustering Method Based on Propagation Similarity for Modeling Cumulative Interference from Large Numbers of Terminals
authors: Tatsuro Hidaka, Osamu Takyu, Kei Inage, Takeo Fujii, Kohei Yoshida, Masayuki Ariyoshi
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: To realize Beyond 5G networks, frequency sharing between terrestrial and satellite communication systems is essential. However, in urban environments, it is difficult to evaluate the cumulative interference from a large number of terrestrial wireless terminals to conventional satellite ground stations in real time, due to the massive number and mobility of terminals. This paper proposes an approach to reduce the computational cost of interference estimation by clustering terrestrial terminals. This enables significant reduction in the complexity of interference calculations. Furthermore, we propose a new clustering method based on the similarity of radio propagation characteristics. The method uses standardized RSSI values and terminal positions as features, and applies recursive clustering with dynamic deviation control to minimize propagation variation within clusters. Simulation using real-world terminal distribution data in an urban area demonstrates that the proposed method improves propagation similarity within clusters while maintaining coarser cluster partitioning compared to conventional methods. Validation of interference estimation accuracy using the proposed clustering method will be addressed in future work.

title: GIDC: A Gaussian Inflection-Based Framework for Automatic Density Peak Clustering
authors: Yue-qi Wang, Rui-dong Qi, Jian-tao Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Density-based clustering can discover clusters of arbitrary shapes without knowing the number in advance. Decision graph methods, combining local density and relative distance, give intuitive guidance but their <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\gamma$</tex>-curves often lack clear transitions, especially under noise or smooth densities, making automatic detection difficult. To solve this, we propose GIDC, which applies (1) a contrast-weighted filter to suppress noise and enhance center contrast, and (2) Gaussian fitting with second-derivative analysis to locate meaningful inflection points. This probabilistic framework improves detection stability, and experiments show GIDC achieves higher accuracy and robustness than state-of-the-art methods.

title: A Hybrid Attention Mechanism to Improve Tacotron 2 Performance for Indonesian Text-to-Speech Synthesis
authors: Angela Catherina, Bima Prihasto, Boby Mugi Pratama, Li-Wei Kang, Jia-Ching Wang
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This paper presents a speech synthesis system for the Indonesian language using the Tacotron 2 architecture and HiFi-GAN vocoder. While Tacotron 2 has demonstrated strong performance in high-resource languages, adapting it for Indonesian remains underexplored. To address this, we propose a hybrid attention mechanism that combines location-sensitive and content-based attention to improve alignment accuracy and convergence during training. The system is trained on a custom Indonesian audiobook dataset prepared in LJSpeech format. We compare several model variants, including versions with and without phoneme conversion, and evaluate them using both subjective and objective metrics. Speech quality is assessed through Mean Opinion Score (MOS) ratings, while model performance is evaluated via attention weight visualization. Results show that the proposed hybrid attention mechanism accelerates alignment learning and produces speech with improved naturalness and intelligibility, confirming its effectiveness for low-resource TTS in Indonesian.

title: Big Data University Digital Library Personalized Recommender Approach Based on Column-Row Singular Value Decomposition
authors: Shuang Wu, Yiqi Tew, Tong Ming Lim, Xiangfu Zhao, Thein Lai Wong, Hengxin Lei
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: In the construction of university libraries, digital libraries integrate online electronic resources and offline book resources to provide users with recommended book information services. However, with the increasing number of literature resources in the library system, effectively helping readers efficiently and accurately discover the required book information in the context of big data becomes difficult. Personalized recommendation systems for digital books face two challenges in big data environments: data sparsity and the difficulty of dynamically generating accurate recommendations for incremental users. To address these issues, we developed a personalized recommendation system based on column-row singular value decomposition (CUR-SVD) incremental matrix factorization. The method involves selecting a subset of columns from the original user-item interaction matrix to form a matrix C and a subset of rows to form a matrix R. SVD is then applied to construct the linking matrix U. In this system, C and R serve as feature matrices for users and books, respectively. Because C and R are derived directly from real data, the CUR-SVD incremental matrix factorization technique enables the transformation of high-dimensional matrices into lower-dimensional representations while preserving the sparsity inherent in the original dataset. This property is particularly advantageous for generating personalized recommendations for newly added users or items. Validation results using the Amazon book dataset demonstrated that the CUR-SVD method showed a recommendation accuracy exceeding 93%, outperforming traditional matrix decomposition techniques such as singular value decomposition and principal component analysis. These results indicate that the CUR-SVD system maintains high predictive performance and effectively retains the sparsity structure of the original data, making it well-suited for scalable and interpretable recommendation systems in digital library environments.

title: Study on the Mechanism of Resin Surface Wiggling Under Different Etching Gas Conditions
authors: K.S. Heo, H.-J. Cho, S. Oh, G.-H. Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: During etching on a thick substrate oxide layer with the application of conventional photoresist (PR), fence formation and by-product deposition were observed on the diffraction grating surface, prompting the use of UV resin. However, UV resin is susceptible to mechanical or chemical alterations in its surface due to the type and mixture ratio of etching gases, leading to the occurrence of a wiggling phenomenon. The wiggling effect can be attributed to factors such as non-uniform flux of etching gases, excessive plasma energy, prolonged etching times, and chemical reactions with the etching gases. Since samples exhibiting wiggling behavior display altered ashing characteristics, which can influence the overall process, identifying the precise causes of wiggling is critical for optimizing etching conditions.

title: High-Voltage Pulsed Power Generator for Beam Injection Systems
authors: A. Smirnov
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Beam injection systems in hadron colliders require kickers generating ±kV peak voltages into a 50Ω impedance, with peak currents of 1000 A and sub- 10 ns rise and fall times. This paper presents a novel high-voltage pulse power generator utilizing a dis-tributed pulser architecture. It combines gallium nitride (GaN) transistors in a Marx to-pology with an inductive adder, achieving nanosecond-scale switching speeds and high-power efficiency. Compared to other solutions such as based on MOSFETs or fast ionization dynistors, our development offers superior peak and average power performance, reduced system complexity, and enhanced reliability, marking a significant step forward in high-voltage pulse generation for accelerator applications.

title: Voltage Fluctuation and Airflow Disturbance in Repetitive Nanosecond Pulse Breakdown
authors: H. Guan, L. Hong, X. Zou
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Currently, most studies on voltage recovery after spark breakdown utilize the double-pulse method or focus on breakdowns at relatively low repetition frequencies (<10 kHz). However, investigating breakdown voltage at high repetition frequencies is of great significance for applications such as the repetitive operation of spark switches. In this study, the breakdown voltage of two electrodes in atmospheric air under repetitive nanosecond pulses was measured. Schlieren imaging was employed to observe the breakdown channels and airflow disturbance. Experimental results show that at low repetition frequencies (10 kHz), the breakdown voltage remains relatively stable. In contrast, at high repetition frequencies (20 kHz-100 kHz), the breakdown voltage increases after a few milliseconds and exhibits significant fluctuation. At 100 kHz, periodic fluctuation in the breakdown voltage was also observed. This behavior can be explained as follows: at low repetition frequencies, airflow disturbance is minimal and nearly axisymmetric, and breakdown channels consistently follow the axis between the two electrodes. In contrast, at high repetition frequencies, the higher the breakdown voltage, the longer the breakdown channels. Airflow disturbance becomes stronger and asymmetric, and breakdown no longer occurs along the axis but instead forms irregular, curved channels that tend to appear in regions with greater disturbance. These findings suggest that the fluctuation of breakdown voltage under repetitive pulses is caused by changes of breakdown channels resulting from airflow disturbance, rather than stochasticity.

title: Absolute Magnetic Field Measurement Using a Single Channel Magneto-Optically Biased Sensor
authors: I. Owens, B. Ulmen, C. Grabowski, K. Vigil, L. Lucero, D. Lamppa
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Magnetic fields and electrical current are amongst the most important operating parameters and essential to understanding the properties of the operation and radiation output of pulsed energy accelerators as well as other research platforms. However, accurately measuring these fields using conventional diagnostics is difficult due to the presence of electromagnetic interference and ionizing radiation in high energy test environments. We describe a direct absolute magnetooptical approach to measuring the magnetic field driven by long pulse width <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(>5 \text{ms})$</tex> and high electrical current <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\sim \text{kA})$</tex> inside the center of a solenoidal coil. Our approach uses a fiber coupled laser beam with terbium gallium garnet (TGG) and terbium scandium aluminum garnet (TSAG) crystals that are highly resistant to electromagnetic interference, allow for absolute measurement and do not require an external calibration. Here, we focus on device theory, operating parameters, results from an experiment on a high current solenoid, and comparison with a reference monitor calculation of the magnetic field.

title: Streamlining Characterization and Modelling of GaN HEMTs for Pulsed-Power Applications
authors: I. Vorotiahin, M. Hergt, M. Sack, M. Hiller, G. Müller
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Gallium-nitride-based high electron mobility transistors (HEMT) are an emergent class of electronic components which, owing to their typical output voltages in hundreds of volts and rise time down to nanoseconds, can be used as fast switching elements in pulsed-power circuits. With the improvements of the GaN HEMT technology, there is a constant need to characterize new devices and create predictive behavioral models. Building upon the existing methods of MESFET and HEMT modelling, an algorithm for GaN HEMT simulation was adapted to extract and reproduce the device's behavior in a wide range of operating points relevant to its subsequent usage as a pulsed-power switch, taking into account effects, such as self-heating, which significantly affect the function of transistors. The proposed algorithm attempts to reduce the number of measurements necessary to extract the crucial model parameters while retaining the model's functionality.

title: Keynote 1 : Cyber-Physical Event Business Systems
authors: Tokuro Matsuo
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Nowadays, a lot of types of communication system to make consensus among people are provided. We can utilize these kinds of systems, such as Social network system, e-mail, and instant messenger system, to make a decision and determination through online discussion. In the next decade, we can forecast a lot of types of consensus formation systems are provided and we may find new communication systems integrating between cyber and physical environment. In this talk, I introduce our conducted experiments using cyber-physical discussion environment in the panel discussion session in the conference. In the session, facilitator asks question to panelists about issues on the discussion and attendees can also do as well by their voice. Each attendee also can post and declare his/her opinions and suggestions through the online discussion system during the session. One or two facilitators facilitate the discussion in the online system as well as real discussion. We found out a lot of interesting results of attendees survey taken in before/after the experiments. I also introduce the environment to provide useful information for attendees by the digital signage system in the conference venue. This digital signage system is connected to the attendees location capture system and conference registration system. These integrations between cyber and physical environments and data enable to make better consensus formation between all sorts of people.

title: Compact Coaxial Variable Resistance Load with Integrated Voltage and Current Probes for Evaluation of High Voltage and Current Pulses with Fast Risetime
authors: R. E. Miller
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: IS4S has built and tested a compact coaxial geometry variable resistance load using a fixed geometry Copper Sulfate resistor. The resistance of the load can be chosen by setting the Copper Sulfate concentration. The load is designed for changing resistance without disassembling the load and with an integrated air bleed mechanism to remove all air bubbles out of the Copper Sulfate for consistent performance of the load resistance. A Prodyn FD-5 D-dot voltage probe and IS4S designed compensated Rogowski coil are integrated into the load for measurement. The instrumented load is designed for measuring pulses <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>500 \text{kV}$</tex> in peak voltage and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>10 \text{kA}$</tex> peak current with a risetime <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<5 \text{ns}$</tex>. The load is of a compact coaxial design and an impedance of 50 ohms is achievable including consideration of the load impedance separate from resistance of the Copper Sulfate.

title: New ARC Power Supply for the TCV Diagnostic Neutral Beam Injector
authors: D. Velasco de la Fuente, S. Delaley, J. Dubray, D. Fasel, A. Karpuchov, A. Listopad, L. Moreira, J. Orsinger, U. Siravo
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: A Diagnostic Neutral Beam Injector (DNBI) is operated on the TCV Tokamak since 2000. Over the years, the plasma source and the ion optical system have benefited from several upgrades, whereas the power supply system remained almost unchanged. DNBI operation is now compromised by the obsolescence of both the power components and the control infrastructure. To allow for a long-term reliable operation, a complete renew of the power supplies set is ongoing. It includes a high-speed current source rated <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$500 \mathrm{A} / 100 \mathrm{V} / 2 \mathrm{s}$</tex> for the arc-discharge plasma source and a High Voltage Modulator (HVM) rated at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$55 \text{kV} / 5 \mathrm{A} / 2 \mathrm{s}$</tex> (subject of a separate paper at this conference)

title: An Open-Source CubeSat Electrical Power Supply
authors: Stefan Damkjar, Junqi Zhu, Bruce F. Cockburn, Duncan G. Elliott
publish: IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Magazine
abstract: The reliability of the electrical power system (EPS) in satellites is a major determinant of mission success. In the case of cost-constrained CubeSat satellites, the available commercial EPS options are relatively expensive and limited in their capabilities. This article describes a feature-rich and fault-tolerant EPS for CubeSats that is being distributed under the open-source model, which is well-suited for supporting the modest budgets and diverse mission objectives of both academic as well as industrial satellite designers. Adoption of the open source model promotes further development of the initial design. The proposed EPS provides capabilities that match or surpass the features and fault-tolerance of the commercial EPS alternatives. It provides four independent channels that provide optimized power extraction from the solar panels using maximum power point tracking. The fault-tolerance capabilities of the EPS include the use of a dual-processor microcontroller with ECC memory and 18 power channels (plus 2 internal) with over-current sensing and automatic channel shut-down, with the ability to automatically adjust the current threshold over time to account for radiation-induced aging effects. The article details the capabilities and fault-tolerance features of the EPS, and then presents the results of detailed testing and characterization experiments on a completed implementation.

title: Dynamic Spectrum Access Based on Multiple Time-Scale Fusion Deep Echo State Network
authors: Xue Wang, Rui Xu, Bo Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: Dynamic Spectrum Access (DSA) has emerged as an essential technological strategy for addressing the issues of radio spectrum shortage and suboptimal spectrum utilization. Deep Q-Network (DQN), leveraging their inherent dynamic adaptability, have been extensively adopted for training DSA strategies in dynamic spectrum management systems. In order to enhance the shared user experience in DSA-enabled systems, this work improves the DQN with high flexibility and scalability to enable the learning of more efficient DSA policies, thereby elevating spectrum utilization efficiency. By integrating skip connections and locality analysis, we introduce a Multiple Time-Scale fusion Deep Echo State Network (MT-DESN) designed to strengthen multi-temporal feature extraction capabilities in time-series data. The MT-DESN is embedded within the DQN framework to holistically extract and fuse multi-scale temporal features, facilitating the training of high-performance DSA strategies. MT-DESN employs three independent reservoirs with tailored recurrent connections to model dependencies across diverse temporal scales in time-series data. Then, it aggregates multi-scale echo states, and generates optimized spectrum access decisions. Experimental validation demonstrates that the MT-DESN-based DSA approach achieves superior spectrum access success rates and reduces collision probabilities compared to conventional deep echo state network and classical DSA methodologies.

title: Multi-Block ADMM for Efficient Model Pruning and Link Scheduling in Decentralized Learning
authors: Xinghan Wang, Nan Li, Mengfan Zheng, Xinyu Huang, Haojun Yang, Tingting Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: In this paper, we develop a unified framework for joint model pruning and link scheduling in decentralized learning systems to improve model consistency and communication efficiency. The framework incorporates an adaptive pruning ratio with a targeted error-compensation mechanism to enable dynamic adjustment of model complexity and accelerate training processes. On the communication side, we design a distributed graph-based scheduler that optimizes multicast link establishment, which can significantly improve data sharing and computational efficiency. By leveraging a sub-modular optimization method, we convert data flows into a simplified minimum-cost maximum-flow problem. The theoretical analysis presents the convergence bound of the proposed optimization algorithm, which is also empirically validated through extensive experiments on datasets to demonstrate its effectiveness on training loss and model accuracy.

title: E-Net: Efficient E(3)-Equivariant Normal Estimation Network_supp1-3635145.pdf
authors: Hanxiao Wang
publish: N/A
abstract: Point cloud normal estimation is a fundamental task in 3D geometry processing, playing a crucial role in applications such as 3D reconstruction, object recognition, and surface analysis. While recent learning-based methods achieve notable advancements in normal prediction, they often overlook the critical aspect of equivariance. This oversight leads to inefficient learning of symmetric patterns inherent in geometric data. To address this issue, we propose E$^{3}$-Net, an innovative neural network architecture designed to inherently achieve equivariance for normal estimation. We introduce an efficient random frame method, which significantly reduces the training resources required for this task to just 1/8 of previous work, while simultaneously enhancing prediction accuracy. Furthermore, we design a Gaussian-weighted loss function and a receptive-aware inference strategy that effectively leverage the local properties of point clouds, ensuring more precise and reliable normal estimation. Our method demonstrates superior performance across both synthetic and real-world datasets, consistently outperforming current state-of-the-art techniques by a substantial margin. Specifically, we achieve a 4% improvement in RMSE on the PCPNet dataset, 2.67% on the SceneNN dataset, and 2.44% on the FamousShape dataset, highlighting the robustness and scalability of E$^{3}$-Net in diverse environments.

title: A Crowding Distance That Provably Solves the Difficulties of the NSGA-II in Many-Objective Optimization
authors: Weijie Zheng, Yan Gao, Benjamin Doerr
publish: IEEE Transactions on Evolutionary Computation
abstract: Recent mathematical runtime analyses have shown that the crowding distance used by the NSGA-II multi-objective optimizer does not well reflect how isolated, and hence worth keeping, solutions are. This has provably led to drastic difficulties when the number of objectives is three or more. Based on the insights of these works, we design a variant of the crowding distance, called truthful crowding distance, and analyze the resulting truthful NSGA-II with mathematical means. (i)We show that it solves the many-objective versions of the OMM, COCZ, LOTZ, and OJZJk problems in the same (polynomial) asymptotic runtimes as the NSGA-III and the SMS-EMOA, contrasting the exponential lower bounds for the classic NSGA-II. (ii) For the bi-objective versions of these problems, our NSGA-II maintains the good performance of the classic NSGA-II, but is successful already with population sizes smaller by a constant factor. (iii) For the bi-objective OMM problem, we observe a (minimally) better performance in approximating the Pareto front. These results indicate that our truthful crowding distance is an interesting alternative to the classic crowding distance.

title: Achieving Covert Communications in Ultra-Dense LEO Satellite Systems by Exploiting Interference and Directional Uncertainty
authors: Lei Zhang, Zhao Chen, Zhifan Ye, Chunxiao Jiang, Liuguo Yin
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: This paper investigates a multi-satellite cooperative covert satellite communication (SatCom) scheme, where a positive covert rate is achieved in ultra-dense low Earth orbit (LEO) satellite constellations by exploiting both interference and directional uncertainty. Specifically, interference arises from aggregate sidelobe leakage from other satellite transmissions, while directional uncertainty stems from the random selection of the transmitting satellite among multiple accessible ones. To this end, we first propose a LEO satellite network model and formulate the corresponding hypothesis testing problem for the cooperative covert SatCom scheme. The power distribution of the aggregate interference is quantified and approximated using stochastic geometry. Next, by analyzing the detection error probability and outage probability under the impact of aggregate interference, we derive an approximate covert capacity expression for the case of a single accessible satellite, which maintains a positive covert rate even as the slot length approaches infinity. Furthermore, by leveraging directional uncertainty through hiding the signal’s angle of arrival, we analyze the multi-satellite cooperative covert SatCom scheme, leading to a concise approximate expression that reveals significant covert capacity improvement. Numerical simulations are performed to verify the superiority of the proposed scheme, suggesting that a positive covert capacity can be achieved with interference uncertainty and significantly enhanced by directional uncertainty as the number of satellites increases.

title: A Novel X-Band High Power Relativistic Diffraction Output Magnetron
authors: J. G. Leopold, O. Belozerov, Y. Hadas, E. Magid, Y. P. Bliokh, A. Andreev, E. Schamiloglu, Y. E. Krasik
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: A novel design of an X-band (9.6 GHz) relativistic diffraction output magnetron (MDO) as an efficient high-power microwave (HPM) source is presented. The MDO design is based on results of Particle in Cell (PIC) simulations, and experiments using a Linear Induction Accelerator confirm its high efficiency. In addition to high efficiency, a variant of this design reveals that for magnetic fields below and close to the limit of complete magnetic insulation when HPM generation terminates, a periodic train of HPM pulses (pulsation) appears with power maxima above the value of the input power. This phenomenon is described, analyzed and explained. Moreover, this pulsation is observed in experiments too.

title: High-Repetition Pulse Power Generators Using Solid-State Ltd
authors: J. Wen, T. Sugai, A. Tokuchi, W. Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: SSLTD (Solid-State Linear Transformer Driver) is a typical method for pulse adding. Its advantages of stress distribution and modular structure are particularly evident in portable compact pulsed power generators. In pulsed power generators using LTD, resetting the magnetic core is essential. This study aims to evaluate the effects of DC reset on repetition rates and clarify its limitations. Furthermore, it seeks to establish an embedded pulse reset method to prevent magnetic core saturation during high repetitive operations.

title: Lightweight and Trustworthy Authentication and Data Transmission Schemes in the Industrial IoT
authors: Yebo Gu, Xiang Dai, Tao Shen, Hui Li
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: The industrial internet of things tightly integrates heterogeneous sensing and communication devices, but it remains difficult to obtain lightweight authentication while simultaneously protecting the post-authentication data plane. This paper addresses both gaps with a unified dual-security framework. First, we propose channel-assisted hyperelliptic curve cryptography , which binds channel state information to hyperelliptic-curve primitives to derive one-time key (OTK) for mutual authentication with low overhead. Second, we introduce an OTK-based non-orthogonal artificial noise mechanism that synthesizes artificial noise from the negotiated OTK and optimizes its power allocation to jam eavesdroppers while remaining transparent to legitimate receivers. Security and cost analyses highlight the robustness and efficiency of channel-assisted hyperelliptic curve cryptography; an NS-3 implementation confirms practicality. Simulations show that OTK-based non-orthogonal artificial noise increases secrecy capacity by 61.11% and 167.74% relative to traditional artificial noise and OTK-based non-orthogonal artificial noise, respectively. We integrate channel-assisted hyperelliptic curve cryptography with OTK-based non-orthogonal artificial noise. Together, they provide end-to-end protection for industrial internet of things authentication and communication.

title: Nonlinear Massive MIMO-RSMA with Multilinear GSVD Precoding: Signal Characterization and Receiver Design
authors: Oussama Ben Haj Belkacem, Rui Dinis
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: In this work, we present a novel precoder design for multiuser massive multiple input multiple output (MU-mMIMO) systems impaired by nonlinear effects at the transmitter. By exploiting the rate splitting multiple access (RSMA) technique for user messages, we develop an analytical precoding framework based on the multilinear generalized singular value (ML-GSVD) decompositions for two or more matrices. This framework provides a robust statistical characterization of transmitted signals and enables accurate performance evaluation of precoding techniques in the presence of nonlinearities. Moreover, we introduce an iterative GSVD distortion cancellation (GSVD-DC) receiver for scenarios with strong nonlinear effects. Numerical results demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves substantial improvements in bit error rate (BER) compared to conventional precoders, for both linear and nonlinear cases, with moderate complexity increase, and without relying on successive interference cancellation (SIC). This makes the GSVD-DC receiver a promising solution for efficient and robust communications in nonlinear environments.

title: The Peculiar Effect of Scanning Trajectory Pattern Density on MPI-Reconstructed Image Quality
authors: Ton Duc Do, Ayazhan Kubasheva, Ferdinand Molnár, Tri T. Pham
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Scanning trajectory is a key component of many point scanning systems, including light detection and ranging (LiDAR), laser scanning confocal microscopes (LSCM), and Micro Electro Mechanical System (MEMS) scanners. This study investigates how different scanning trajectories affect the quality of MPI-reconstructed images, with an emphasis on scanning parameters, particularly scanning duration, which includes both scanning repeat and scanning time. The impacts of sampling frequency, scanning repeat, and scanning time on the quality of MPI-reconstructed images were examined across a wide range of scanning trajectories and pattern densities. Peak Signal to Noise Ratio (PSNR), Structural Similarity Index Measure (SSIM), Normalized Root Mean Square Error (NRMSE), and Normalized Sum of Squared Errors (NSSE) were the four metrics used to assess the quality of MPI-reconstructed images. The optimal sampling frequency is 6×106 Hz or higher, as evidenced by the convergence of all four measures to the same values. At low scanning density (Np < 80), increasing scanning repeats or times does not improve image quality. However, increasing scanning repeats or scanning times would help enhance image quality when employing a high density scan with Np ≥ 80. This study illustrates the peculiar effect of different scanning trajectories on the quality of MPI-reconstructed images at low and high scanning densities. Our simulations reveal how trajectory density and scan time impact image quality and reconstruction accuracy, providing a foundation for how long to scan or how many repetitions to rescan the sample to improve image quality.

title: A Modulation Method of the Radiation Field in Hard X-Ray Source Based on Compton Scattering
authors: M. Zhang, Y. Du
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The hard X-ray produced by the bremsstrahlung from low-energy electrons has a large emit angle, which makes a low utilization ratio of the radiation field in hard X-ray source. A modulation method based on Compton scattering to increase the utilization ratio of the radiation field is presented in this paper. Escaped photons are scattered into the detection region partially to increase the utilization ratio of radiation field by a Compton scattering layer with specific materials and structures. In addition, the average energy of the photon is reduced. The progress of Compton scattering of photons in materials at different energy and incident angles is studied. The effects of the materials and structures of Compton scattering layer on the radiation intensity and photon energy of X-ray are simulated. A Compton scattering layer is designed for the hard X-ray source, the array of cylindrical virtual cathode reflex triode, and an experimental study has been carried out. The experimental results show that the utilization ratio of the radial field is increased by 12 % by the Compton scattering, and the result has a good agreement with the simulation result of 13.5 %, which is an effective method to enhance the intensity of the radiation field.

title: Real-time Hand Motion Synthesis for Playing a Virtual Guitar
authors: Ryan Canales, Sophie Jörg
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 18th ACM SIGGRAPH Conference on Motion, Interaction, and Games
abstract: Concerts and performances in virtual reality are becoming increasingly popular. Accurately visualizing the detailed hand motions of musicians playing instruments is challenging. In this work, we present a real-time motion synthesis method that generates the detailed fretting hand motion for playing guitar. Our approach first involves capturing and post-processing hand motion data from guitar performances to create a data set for training. The post-processing ensures that the fingertip positions are placed as accurately as possible regarding distance from the fretboard and location between the frets. We then train a neural network that learns to predict hand and finger poses based on guitar tabs and previous poses. We found that our method produces reasonably stable motion and evaluate our results using accuracy measures and visual evaluation.

title: Saturation of Yield in Dense Plasma Focus Due to Current Redirection Phenomenon
authors: D. Lowe, M. Blasco, R. E. Castro, E. C. Hagen, M. Lawrence, P. Winters, J. Doria, B. Harris, A. Ikehara

abstract: One type of pulsed power fusion source is the Dense Plasma Focus (DPF). The DPF is a compact and economical z-pinch fusion source in use throughout the world. They are capable of many pulses per day, require little maintenance, and allow study and development resources necessary for fusion neutron research. 1

title: Research on the Application of SGTO Power Devices as Replacements for Thyratrons in the CSNS/RCS Kicker Pulse Power Supply
authors: H. Li, X. Qi, M. Lin, W. Zhang, J. Li, G. Zhao, Y. Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The extraction system of the Rapid Cycling Synchrotron (RCS) at the China SpallationNeutron Source (CSNS) comprises 8 kicker pulse power systems. The working principle of thesystem is that the high-voltage charger first charges the Pulse Forming Network (PFN) to theoperating voltage, and then discharges it through triggering a high-voltage switch to the load,generating 25Hz repetition frequency, amplitude of 6660A, 264ns rise time (3%-97%) currentpulse. Presently, the high-voltage switch utilizedis a hydrogen thyratron switch, however, asoperational time increases, thyratrons may experience aging and unstable operation, Regularparameter adjustments are requiredto maintain low jitter and drift, which have a certain impacton the stable operation of the accelerator system and result in high maintenance costs. In thehigh-power repetition frequency pulse field, the use of high-performance solid-state switches toreplace traditional gas switches has become a research hotspot and development trend.Based onsolid-state thyristors as a direct replacement for thyratrons, this paper introduces the design ofSGTO chips to replace thyratrons, SGTO series drive, SGTO valve series structure, and some testresults of SGTO valves in the CSNS/RCS kicker pulse power supply, as well as follow-upexperimental plans.

title: Analysis of Microwave Heating and Plasma Behavior in Toroidal Slot Antenna
authors: S.-H. Jung, H.-J. Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Plasma-Enhanced Atomic Layer Deposition (PEALD) is a critical technique for achieving precise thin film deposition in semiconductor manufacturing. However, challenges such as substrate damage caused by high ion energies, particle contamination, and non-uniform thin film deposition hinder the reliability and quality of this process. To address these issues, this study analyzes the dual role of microwave sources in heating and plasma generation. Depending on the presence of discharge gases and pressure conditions, microwave sources can function as wafer heating or plasma discharge systems. Microwave heating enables volumetric heating by selectively interacting with materials that possess appropriate dielectric properties. Additionally, it can be utilized as a low-ion-energy microwave plasma source to minimize substrate damage, while providing a high-density and uniform plasma environment based on the modes formed through the antenna. A 2.45 GHz microwave was propagated in the TE10 mode within a waveguide and radiated into the chamber through a slot in a toroidal antenna. Comprehensive simulations and experimental evaluations were conducted to analyze the effects of key parameters, such as cavity geometry, pressure, and power input, on plasma properties and heating profiles.

title: Single Nanosecond Pulsed Discharge Formation by Using Matching Resistor and its Effect on Ozone Production
authors: K. Watanabe, H. Koyanagi, T. Namihira, D. Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Ozone is characterized by its strong oxidizing power and no toxic residue. It can be applied to a wide range of fields, including semiconductor cleaning, sterilization, bleaching, decolorization, and deodorization, and is attracting attention as a next-generation oxidant. There are various methods of generating ozone, of which the discharge method is the mainstream in the industrial field. The discharge method using a nanosecond pulse power reported by Namihira et al is one of the promising way to realize ideal ozonizer. Nanosecond pulsed discharge mainly consists of primary streamers and it leads to higher energy efficiency of ozone generation than barrier discharge. However, the ozone concentration produced by nanosecond pulsed power become saturated around <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$40 \text{gm}-3$</tex>, which is not enough to the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \text{gm}-3$</tex> required for industrial applications. It is considered that the saturation of ozone concentration was caused by higher frequency electrical ringing following nanosecond pulse voltage. In this paper, the time reduction of the ringing was done by connecting a resistor between the nanosecond pulse power supply and the discharge reactor. The ringing time was determined by voltage and current waveforms and also discharge observation. As the results, the resister between the generator and reactor suppressed the ringing time and the characteristics of ozone generation was improved.

title: Progress on 140 GHz Gyrotron Development: Advancing Towards 2-MW Operation
authors: D. Mondal, L. Feuerstein, K. Avramidis, R. Bertazzoni, E. Deliprimis, S. Illy, J. Jelonnek, T. Rzesnicki, A. Schmidt, S. Stanculovic, C. Wu, M. Thumm
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: This study presents the theoretical considerations made in frame of the development of a 2 MW conventional-cavity gyrotron, focusing on its engineering constraints and theoretical validation at the Karlsruhe Institute of Technology (KIT). The study includes initial analyses of a 140 GHz gyrotron for designed to deliver 2 MW output power in advanced electron cyclotron resonance heating (ECRH) systems for fusion devices. While this gyrotron is developed with a general applicability in mind, its specifications align with the potential upgrade of the ECRH system at the Wendelstein (W7-X) stellarator. This design aims for utilizing the existing infrastructure already operational for achieving 1.5 MW at W7-X. The present study includes mode selection, starting current, and time-dependent multi-mode calculations which are carried out to optimize gyrotron performance to achieve high output power considering kinetic electron energy of 88 keV, pitch factor of 1.3, electron beam radius of 10.1 mm with the approximation of 5 % velocity spread. The output power at the desired mode <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{TE}_{28,12}$</tex> in the RF interaction cavity is confirmed by timedependent multi-mode simulations with an interaction efficiency of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>32 \%$</tex>. Considering a conductivity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.05 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{S} / \mathrm{m}$</tex> for Glidcop, surface roughness of 200 nm, and a temperature of 200° C, an output power of 2.2 MW is attained within the ohmic wall-loading limit of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.2 \text{kW} / \text{cm}^{2}$</tex>. Further, with conductivity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.83 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{S} / \mathrm{m}$</tex> at surface roughness of 200 nm, and temperature of 250° C exceeded the ohmic wall-loading at an output power of 1.8 MW. By enhancing cavity cooling using advanced mini-channel cooling, which allows peak wall-loading of up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.5 \text{kW} / \text{cm}^{2}$</tex>, the potential to achieve output powers exceeding 2.4 MW at the end of the cavity becomes feasible. Additionally, optimizing the interaction cavity surface roughness can support higher conductivity, enabling high-output power with the existing Raschig Rings cooling system.

title: Electron Temperature and Density Measurements in Nanosecond Pulse Dielectric Barrier Discharge Using Optical Emission Spectroscopy
authors: Y.Y. Kim, J.Y. Chung, J.Y. Park, S.U. Lee, D.J. Ham, D.-W. Kim, J. Kim, K.-J. Chung
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Optical emission spectroscopy (OES) is utilized to measure the electron temperature and density of nitrogen plasmas generated by nanosecond pulse dielectric barrier discharges (NPDBD) at atmospheric pressure. It uses the emission spectra of nitrogen molecules, particularly the first positive system (FPS) and the second positive system (SPS), along with electron density and temperature inferred through a simplified collisional-radiative model. This model employs two continuity equations dependent on electron density and temperature, where the coefficients are determined using rotational temperature, vibrational temperature, and the intensity ratio of FPS to SPS. By solving these equations with spectroscopic data, the non-equilibrium plasma parameters are estimated for various applied voltage levels. In this paper, we present the details of OES data and plasma parameters depending on the operating conditions of the NPDBD system.

title: Development of a High-Current Solid State Linear Transformer Driver
authors: K. Schriner, D. Wright, K. Kelp, J. Dickens, J. Stephens, Z. Shaw, A. Neuber
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: This research presents the development of a printed circuit board high-current solid-state LTD, which utilizes thyristors as the primary switching mechanism targeting 30 kV switching voltage and currents exceeding 20 kA. Linear Transformer Drivers (LTDs) have emerged as a compelling solution for many applications that require fast, high-voltage pulse generation. While larger LTDs typically employ gas switches or spark gaps for pulse generation, significant developmental efforts have focused on solid-state alternatives to help enhance the reliability and control of these devices. Current solid-state implementations predominantly focus on utilizing MOSFETs as active switching devices. While these devices offer excellent switching speeds and voltage holdoff capabilities, they have their limitations when handling high-current applications. Thyristors provide an advantageous combination of high voltage holdoff and superior current handling capabilities, though this comes with inherent trade-offs in usually slower rise times and the inability to actively turn off the device.

title: High Repetition Rate Bipolar Marx Generator Using Magnetic Coupling Inductors
authors: T. Sugai, S. Uei, N. Yoshikawa, W. Jiang, A. Higashida, S. Tsuda
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: A CO2 Laser, excited by a bipolar pulsed power source, is utilized for fine processing of printed circuit boards (PCBs). Recently, due to the increasing demand for PCBs, faster processing speeds have been required. Consequently, the repetition rate of a bipolar Marx generator needs to be increased while maintaining the shape of the pulses. However, the resistors or inductors needed to isolate each stages of a Marx circuit impede charge current, resulting in increased charge time and a decreased repetition rate. To address this issue, we adopted a magnetic coupling inductor as an isolator in a full bridge type bipolar Marx circuit. This approach results in the inductance decrease of the magnetic coupling inductor during the charge mode because the magnetic flux is offset. On the other hand, the inductance during the discharge mode increases as the magnetic flux is mutually intensified. Thus, it is expected that fast capacitor charge is possible while maintaining the function of the isolator during the Marx output. To confirm that, an 8 stages full bridge bipolar Marx generator connecting the coupling inductors to each stage was tested. As the result, the charge speed was improved, and the maximum repetition rate with stable pulse output was 150 Hz. However, stray resistor such as the equivalent series resistance (ESR) of the capacitor still restricted the charge speed, and the magnetic coupling inductor we made ourselves is not optimal. Thus, we will continue to improve the charging speed with further investigation.

title: Plume Characterization and Longitudinal Study for a Novel Liquid-Fed Pulsed Magnetoplasmadynamic Thruster Operating with a Green Monopropellant
authors: L. Organski, N. Babusis, A. Shashurin
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Traditional pulsed plasma thrusters have a long heritage in spaceflight, with significant applications for low power operation, but with relatively low efficiency. Additionally, interest has grown significantly in the development of novel electric propulsion systems that can use conventional chemical propellants as fuel. A liquid-fed pulsed magnetoplasmadynamic (pulsed- MPD) thruster shows substantial promise as a low power, high efficiency propulsion system with compatibility for dual-mode operation, combining chemical and electric propulsion modes. A novel “green” monopropellant ASCENT (Advanced Spacecraft Energetic Non-Toxic), developed by the Air Force Research Laboratory, has been demonstrated in this system with a novel low energy ignitor and propellant feeding mechanism. In this work, measurements of total ion current in the exhaust plume, electron number density, electron temperature, ion exhaust velocity, cathode erosion, and mass bit were conducted in a long-duration testing of 100,000 discharge pulses characterized by typical discharge voltages and currents in the range 50–150 V and 5–10 kA, respectively. These measurements were used to produce estimates of thruster performance parameters including impulse bit, specific impulse, projected total impulse, mass utilization fraction, and total system efficiency. Additionally, an orbital mission to demonstrate the use of the ASCENT-propelled pulsed-MPD thruster on a CubeSat via an orbit-raising maneuver was developed. The mission was selected to be directly relevant for future customer use cases of dualmode systems. The development included the design, fabrication, and testing of CubeSat subsystems including Pulsed-MPD Propulsion Subsystem, Attitude Determination and Control Subsystem, Radio Communication, Electrical Power Subsystem, Command and Control Subsystem, and Satellite Software.

title: Wave Breaking Amplitude of High Frequency Plasma Wave in Presence of Relativistic Proton Beam
authors: M. Karmakar, G. S. Yadav
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The nonlinear characteristics of electrostatic plasma waves have been studied in the presence of a relativistic proton beam in a two component electron-ion plasma system. Such a beam driven plasma system supports high frequency electrostatic plasma modes the breaking phenomena of which are investigated elaborately. The set of nonlinear relativistic fluid equations are solved using Sagdeev Pseudo Potential technique which enable us to determine the maximum allowed value of the electric field amplitude of the high frequency plasma wave. This limiting value is the so called wave breaking amplitude of the relativistic plasma wave. The breaking amplitude is found to be a function of the beam density, relativistic Lorentz factor associated with phase velocity of the plasma wave as well as on the proton beam speed. Dermination of the breaking amplitude has its relevance in the field of plasma wake field accelerators in which beam plasma interactions are considered. The maximum energy that can be achieved in such accelerator is determined by this limiting amplitude. Apart from this, this investigation is important in the field of the space plasma research as well as in the laboratory context.

title: Recent Advances in Terahertz Sheet Beam Traveling-Wave Tubes
authors: Z. Duan, S. Jiang, Z. Lyu, J. Dong, P. Pan, J. Feng, Y. Gong
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Terahertz sheet beam traveling-wave tubes (TWTs) showcase such advantages of high power, wide bandwidth, high gain, and high efficiency, which attract more research interest. To achieve high output power, the slow-wave structures with low loss and high interaction impedance, as well as sheet beam electron-optical system (EOS) capable of high beam current, are investigated. A Tshaped staggered double-vane slow-wave structure (SDVSWS) and a novel I-shaped metamaterialinspired slow-wave structure (MSWS) are proposed. The SDVSWS features low loss and wide bandwidth. Its measured amplitude of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{S}_{21}$</tex> is better than −3.5 dB, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{S}_{11}$</tex> is less than −18.1 dB from 0.21 to 0.23 THz, with an attenuation constant below 0.78 dB/cm. CST simulations predict a saturated output power of 120 W at 0.22 THz, with a 3-dB bandwidth exceeding 50 GHz. The MSWS exhibits high interaction impedance due to the enhancement of local electric fields caused by metamaterial. The simulated average interaction impedance is over 5Ω within 0.210-0.226 THz. The maximum output power is predicted by CST PIC to be 400 W with a 3-dB bandwidth of 5.4 GHz. In addition, a large current density sheet beam electron gun employing scandate cathode is experimentally studied. Its measured beam current is 170 mA and beam current density is 425 A/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> at the beam waist position of z=9.3 mm (the cathode emission surface is located at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$z=0$</tex> mm). Recently, to focus on the generated sheet beam for long-distance transportation, a tunable periodic cusped magnetic focusing configuration has been designed and fabricated, and the measured peak <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$B z$</tex> value is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 0.37 \mathrm{T}$</tex>. Based on the sheet beam EOS, a sheet beam TWT employing SDVSWS has been assembled. Its output power experiment is underway. These research efforts have potential applications to deep space exploration, radar detection, imaging, and high-speed data communication.

title: Development of Resonant Converters for Rapid Capacitor Charging in Repetitive Pulsed Power Applications Using SiC Devices
authors: D. Kaushik, P. K. Yadav, J.T. Meledath
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Capacitor banks form the backbone of various pulsed power systems across various applications. The capacitors must be rapidly charged and discharged for repetitive pulsed power applications. Therefore, a capacitor-charging high-voltage power supply (CCPS) is inevitable to efficiently charge capacitors to high voltages for applications like plasma material processing, electromagnetic forming, particle accelerators, etc. The authors have developed a compact resonant converter topology that efficiently utilizes the parasitics of the high-voltage transformer and the secondary end rectifier. Initially, the authors analyzed various resonant converter topologies and compared their feasibility for pulsed power applications. The developed converter is based on an LCLC-resonant tank operating at 150 kHz using SiC devices. The high-frequency operation compacts the converter by significantly reducing the size of magnetic components. In addition, the primary switches operate under ZVS (zero-voltage switching) during the entire charging cycle. The resonant tank is designed to use the voltage-balancing network parameters in the secondary high-voltage rectifier, which reduces the final component count. The developed converter has inherent short-circuit and open-circuit protection for pulsed power applications. The converter can operate on a full ripple DC voltage, eliminating the need for a front-end bulky filter electrolytic capacitor in the AC rectifier. Finally, a controller based on Constant Current and Constant Power (CC-CP) mode, employing a variable frequency control technique, has been designed to control the charging rate of the capacitor banks. The designed converter also exhibits modularity to increase the voltage and current rating of the final applications. The developed system is capable of both single-shot and burst-mode operations. The authors have simulated the result in PLECS and have developed a 1 kW prototype. The results are experimentally verified and compared against the simulated results.

title: Lightweight Local–Global Dual-Path Feature Fusion Network for Infrared Small Target Image Super-Resolution and Enhancement
authors: Haoran Jia, Xin Wang, Songyue Yang, Tongtai Cao, Yue Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Infrared imaging is widely used in remote sensing and military target recognition due to its strong resistance to interference in complex environments. However, imaging mechanisms and hardware limitations cause infrared images to have low-resolution, sparse textures, and significant background noise, which severely restrict the detection of small targets such as low-altitude drones and weak thermal emitters. To overcome these limitations, we propose a lightweight Local–Global Dual-Path Feature Fusion Network (LDFF-Net) that enhances the resolution and quality of infrared images, providing high-quality inputs for subsequent detection tasks. The network includes a Small Target Feature Recognition Module (STFRM) composed of three key components. The Enhanced High Frequency Perception Module (EHFPM) strengthens high-frequency details of small targets while suppressing noise, enabling robust local feature extraction. The State-Space Model (SSM) captures long-range dependencies with linear complexity and models semantic relationships between targets and background to compensate for the limited receptive field of local features. The Adaptive Feature Fusion Unit (AFFU) combines local and global features adaptively to improve the saliency of small targets. During training, we introduce a realistic degradation process based on visible-light images to generate training samples that include complex degradation patterns and noise, which enhances the model’s robustness and generalization. Evaluation on the ARCHIVE and SIRST datasets demonstrates that LDFF-Net outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods across eight widely used full-reference and no-reference metrics, including PSNR, LPIPS, FID, and NIQE. This result confirms the model’s effectiveness in enhancing both the super-resolution and detection performance of infrared small target images. The code and pretrained model weights are publicly available at https://github.com/98Hao/LDFF-Net.

title: Infrared and Visible Light Image Fusion for Tidal Flats: New Challenges, Datasets and Large Benchmark
authors: Tianwei Ren, Zekai Zhang, Yuanjun Li, Ming Fang, Jinling Zhang, Yuanjiang Li
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Tidal flats, situated at the intersection of land and sea, are ecologically sensitive zones whose dynamic changes are critical for environmental conservation and disaster forecasting. The fusion of infrared and visible imagery enables the acquisition of multidimensional information, providing comprehensive observational support for tasks such as tidal geomorphological evolution and habitat identification. However, existing research predominantly focuses on urban and natural landscapes, and the lack of infrared-visible datasets tailored for tidal flat monitoring hampers the performance of fusion models in real world scenarios. To address this challenge, we construct the first geostationary satellite-based multimodal tidal flat image dataset, MTFRS, comprising 2,365 pairs of infrared and visible images from the Yellow River estuary. The dataset spans multiple seasons and tidal conditions, offering high geometric consistency and diverse scene annotations. In addition, we propose a novel fusion method, RSTFuse, which integrates CNN and ViT architectures to enhance inter-modal correlation and detail extraction, thereby improving fusion performance. Through evaluation of semantic segmentation algorithms on MTFRS, we established a benchmark. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that our RSTFuse method significantly enhances cross-modal feature complementarity in tidal flat scenarios during image fusion tasks, exhibits stronger robustness to seasonal variations, and outperforms mainstream methods in both visual performance and quantitative metrics.

title: Adaptive Microwave Photonic Interference Mitigation Technique for Dynamic RF Environment
authors: Suen Xin Chew, Nicole Daniel, Hongchao Chen, Linh Nguyen, Xiaoke Yi
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: We present a novel microwave photonic interference mitigation technique for dynamic radio frequency environment. Our approach leverages the known modulation properties of the signal of interest (SOI) to adaptively suppress interference. The system automatically optimizes performance using constellation feedback, achieving significant interference cancellation across a wide range of interference conditions, including intentional continuous-wave jamming signals and unintentional phase modulated interference. Experimental results demonstrate robust mitigation of both in-band and out-of-band interference, achieving over 20 dB suppression across diverse scenarios. Our technique effectively restores degraded constellations and maintains stable cancellation up to 42 dB rejection even as interference power increases progressively. These results mark a significant step toward fully photonic, adaptive interference mitigation for next-generation wireless and satellite communication networks.

title: Solving Optimal Power Flow on a Data-Budget: Feature Selection on Smart Meter Data
authors: Vassilis Kekatos, Ridley Annin, Manish K. Singh, Junjie Qin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems
abstract: How much data is needed to optimally schedule distributed energy resources (DERs)? Does the distribution system operator (DSO) have to know load demands at each bus of the feeder to solve an optimal power flow (OPF)? This work exploits redundancies in OPF's structure and data to minimize the communication of such a data deluge, and explores the trade-off between data compression and the grid's performance. We propose an OPF data distillation framework involving two steps: The DSO first collects OPF data in near-real-time from only a subset of nodes. It subsequently reconstructs the complete OPF data from the partial ones, and feeds them into the OPF solver. Selecting and reconstructing OPF data may be performed to maximize the fidelity of the reconstructed data or the associated OPF solutions. Under the first objective, OPF data distillation is posed as a sparsity-regularized convex problem. Under the second objective, it is posed as a sparsity-regularized bilevel program. Both problems are solved using proximal gradient algorithms. The second objective is superior in approximating OPF solutions at the expense of increased complexity. Numerical tests show that it enhances the fidelity and feasibility of the reconstructed OPF solutions, which can be approximated reasonably well even from partial data.

title: A Novel Magnetic Coupler for UAVs Wireless Charging and Bidirectional Communication
authors: Tianxu Feng, Liukang Tang, Peiyue Wang, Ke Shi, Jincheng Jiang, Jie Hou, Yuanshuang Fan
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: Simultaneous wireless power and data transfer (SWPDT) is a promising technology to enhance the operational intelligence of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). Conventional shared-channel SWPDT systems, which use the same channel for both forward and backward data transmission, often require complex filtering circuits to reduce crosstalk during bidirectional communication. To overcome this limitation, this article introduces a novel magnetic coupler with two independent data transmission channels tailored for UAV SWPDT applications. The proposed architecture employs separate channels for forward and backward data, inherently minimizing crosstalk during bidirectional communication. Power and data transmission still share the coupling channel through frequency division multiplexing (FDM), eliminating the need for additional communication coils. The magnetic coupler comprises two DD coils and two solenoid coils, offering a compact, conformal, and lightweight structure with low leakage magnetic interference. On the power side, a dual-transmitter–dual-receiver topology is implemented using bilateral LCC compensation networks. For data transmission, four series LC branches are utilized to inject and extract the forward and backward data carriers. Analytical models relating signal amplitude to circuit parameters are established, along with a systematic design method. An experimental prototype achieves an output power of 174 W with a DC-to-DC efficiency of 87.2%. The system demonstrates a data rate of 500 kb/s in both forward and backward directions, yielding a total bidirectional data rate of 1 Mb/s. The measured transmission delay is 1.5 μs with a bit error rate (BER) below 10⁻⁶.

title: A Novel Observation Scheme for Large Baseline Imaging Radar Altimeter Based on Spatio-Temporal Beam Separation
authors: Haifeng Kou, Bo Liu, Bing Li, Liu Liu, Xiaonan An, Jie Liu
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The Large Baseline Imaging Radar Altimeter (LB-IRA) effectively compensates for severe baseline decorrelation effects caused by kilometer-scale interferometric baselines through the introduction of carrier frequency shifts, thereby improving altimetric accuracy to the sub-centimeter level. However, this frequency-shift-based compensation strategy imposes stringent constraints on the system bandwidth (typically limited to ≤66.90 MHz), which restricts range resolution and multi-look capability, ultimately degrading overall altimetric performance. Based on the dual-transmit dual-receive, time-division interferometric architecture of LB-IRA, this paper proposes, for the first time to the best of our knowledge, the implementation of a Spatio-Temporal Beam Separation (STBS) observation scheme within a dual-satellite LB-IRA system, incorporating polarization diversity to achieve simultaneous spatial and temporal separation of transmitted signals. By fully exploiting the spatial separation of dual radar main lobes and the temporal alternation provided by the satellite formation, the proposed STBS scheme effectively removes the bandwidth limitation induced by carrier frequency shifts and enables flexible wide-band system design with a bandwidth expansion from ≤66.90 MHz to 300 MHz. Quantitative simulation results demonstrate that, owing to higher parameter design freedom and improved multi-look efficiency, the proposed scheme enhances the effective number of looks by approximately 436.2% and reduces the phase-induced altimetric error to 0.365 cm at a spatial resolution of 1 km, corresponding to an accuracy improvement of about 59% compared with the conventional observation mode. This study provides a theoretical foundation for the design of next-generation bistatic interferometric imaging radar altimeter systems and offers key technical support for high-resolution ocean dynamic environment retrieval tasks.

title: 90-Degree Achromatic Bend for Transport of an Intense Electron Beam with Nominal Energy Spread of 16-17 MeV
authors: A. F. Press, A. M. Brandes, J. M. Campos, M. Schulze, M. A. Jaworski
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The dual axis radiographic test facility (DARHT) consists of two electron accelerators oriented perpendicularly. Accelerated electrons collide with a high Z converter target producing X-rays through the bremsstrahlung process. The X-rays are used to image hydrodynamic experiments. The second accelerator (Axis-II) produces multiple pulses each 10s to 100s of nanoseconds long over a 1.6 microsecond period. Over this time the converter target heats and rapidly expands changing the X-ray production region. This beam-target interaction has rich multiscale physics including hydrodynamic expansion, beam-plasma instabilities and charged particle transport. However, diagnostic access to the region is limited due to radiation shielding. To facilitate beam-target physics studies, a 90-degree bending achromat has been designed to transport the Axis-II beam to a separate target area which is amenable to fielding diagnostics.

title: Reinforcement Learning-Based Dynamic Beam Hopping and Power Allocation for RSMA-Assisted Constrained-Input Satellite System
authors: Lu Dong, Huayu Zhao, Xin Yuan, Yuehao Qiu, Changyin Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: This paper investigates a dynamic beam hopping and power allocation problem in rate-splitting multiple access (RSMA) assisted multi-beam satellite system, in which beam services are allocated for terrestrial cells with non-uniform traffic demands and spectrum resource is full-frequency reused among beams for serving multiple ground terminals through RSMA technique. The objective is to jointly optimize beam hopping and power allocation strategy for maximizing the long-term sum rate while simultaneously satisfying delay fairness demand. However, the interference caused by full frequency reuse among beams limits the efficacy of RSMA, and the frequent beam patterns changes make instantaneous channel state information (CSI) detection a challenge. To address these challenges, this paper designs a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) based resource allocation framework for discrete-continuous action spaces. To alleviate explosion of action space, each beam is treated as a DRL agent, and a multi-agent deep reinforcement learning method is proposed to learn the beam scheduling policy. In addition, an action mapping mechanism is employed to further manage the DRL power allocation for satisfying the power input constraint arising from limited satellite power budget. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method can achieve the highest sum rate of the system while ensuring fairness among non-uniform traffic load cells compared with several baseline methods.

title: Hierarchical Optimization-Based DOA Estimation for Low-Elevation Target in MIMO Radar over Irregular Terrain
authors: Qi Liu, Rui Guo, Jiajia Wang, Ziheng Zhao, Shiyou Xu, Zengping Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Direction-of-arrival (DOA) estimation for low-elevation targets plays a significant role in MIMO radar applications. However, in realistic irregular terrain environments, conventional DOA estimation algorithms suffer from a substantial loss of accuracy due to severe multipath effects and the difficulty of accurately modeling such propagation phenomena. To address these challenges, a hierarchical optimization-based DOA estimation method is proposed for low-elevation targets. First, a multipath signal model adapted to irregular terrain is developed, where non-ideal path reflections induced by terrain variation are modeled as stochastic perturbations. Then, high-order singular value decomposition (HOSVD) is applied to extract the tensor signal subspace from the element space, which is subsequently projected onto a lower-dimensional beamspace for efficient processing. On this basis, a two-level hierarchical optimization framework is proposed. In the first stage, a sparse Bayesian learning (SBL) algorithm in the beamspace provides coarse estimates of the target elevation angle and multipath angle of arrival. These estimates are subsequently refined in the second stage through a joint optimization procedure that combines alternating iteration with the quasi-Newton Broyden– Fletcher–Goldfarb–Shanno (BFGS) method. Simulation and experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method exhibits excellent estimation accuracy and robustness under irregular terrain conditions, while maintaining relatively low computational complexity.
