title: Fast Formation of Hydrogen from Ammonia Carrier by Rotating Gliding Arc Plasma: A Promising Approach?
authors: O. Vu Quoc, M. Young Sun, A. Denra
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Fast formation of hydrogen <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{H}_{2})$</tex> from ammonia <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\text{NH}_{3})$</tex> carrier was investigated using rotating gliding arc plasma (rGAP), a promising green technology for direct <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{H}_{2}$</tex> production. Cracking <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{NH}_{3}$</tex> in rGAP to from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{H}_{2}$</tex> occurs immediately at low temperatures and atmospheric pressure when sufficient electrical power is applied. However, the process is strongly dependent on the key parameters, such as the input power, the initial <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{NH}_{3}$</tex> concentration, and the flow rate. Herein, the effect of key inputs on the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{NH}_{3}$</tex> cracking process was examined to determine the tendency and evaluate their effect size by using standardized coefficients of the linear models; the models are estimated and validated with the experimental data. As a result, the tendency and magnitude of the factor effect were visualized by floating bars of the standardized coefficients. This analysis revealed that initial <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{NH}_{3}$</tex> concentration is the most critical factor, followed by applied power and total flow rate, for a high rate of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{H}_{2}$</tex> production and less energy consumption. The energy efficiency of rGAP showed a significant increase in comparison with other atmospheric pressure plasma sources; however, it is still lower than that of the thermal process under similar levels of specific energy input. Overall, rGAP featured <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{NH}_{3}$</tex> conversion of up to 46.5 % and energy consumption for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{H}_{2}$</tex> production at a level of around <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.7 \text{MJ} / \text{mol} \mathrm{H}_{2}$</tex>. With quickly turning on/off the process by switching the plasma power supply, rGAP is a potential method for fast formation of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{H}_{2}$</tex> from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{NH}_{3}$</tex> carrier.

title: Adaptive Polarization Diversity and Directivity Mode Selection in RIS-Aided Systems
authors: Hamidreza Khaleghi, Thierry Lucidarme
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This paper proposes an adaptive architecture for Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface (RIS)-assisted wireless communication, enhancing system performance by dynamically switching between polarization diversity and directivity modes. The RIS is divided into spatially contiguous subnets, referred to as groups, each comprising two identical tiles that serve a user or group of users within a specific zone. Each tile within a group is independently configurable to reflect waves with right-hand circular polarization (RHCP) or left-hand circular polarization (LHCP), alongside independent phase control for fine-grained beamforming. A novel, intelligent mode selection algorithm first performs a Dynamic Strategy Preview to assess the overall interference environment, then uses a local correlation metric–termed Circular Basis Correlation (CBC)–for fine-grained, per-group decisions. The CBC is estimated from uplink pilot signals within a time division duplex (TDD) framework, enabling low-complexity mode selection. The architecture supports dynamic group reconfiguration based on channel conditions, improving signal robustness and energy capture for linearly polarized receivers. Simulations under two distinct Rician fading scenarios reveal a nuanced trade-off between signal power maximization and interference management. The proposed adaptive scheme intelligently navigates this trade-off, outperforming fixed configurations across different channel conditions and signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) regimes.

title: Battery Reconfiguration in BESS: A Benefit-Oriented Predictive Maintenance Optimization Framework Integrating Safety and Performance
authors: Mengzi Zhen, Zhen Chen, Zhaoxiang Chen, Ershun Pan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) are essential for advancing the transition to sustainable power systems, with lithium-ion batteries (LIB) widely adopted for their high efficiency and scalability. However, the electrochemical complexity of LIBs presents significant challenges in maintaining long-term safety and performance. This study introduces battery reconfiguration as an innovative system-level maintenance strategy within a benefit-oriented predictive maintenance (PdM) framework, aiming to improve both operational reliability and energy efficiency. A binary-state characterization model is proposed, where safety is inferred from internal resistance using a Hidden Markov Model (HMM), and performance is determined by capacity—together constraining the system’s energy output. To evaluate economic value, a comprehensive generation-side benefit model is developed, incorporating both peak shaving services and electricity market participation. The reconfiguration task is formulated as a large-scale combinatorial optimization problem (COP) and is efficiently solved using a tailored degradation-aware improved genetic algorithm (DA-IGA). Numerical experiments on a 10×20 BESS system demonstrate that the proposed strategy achieves a 14.73% increase in energy output, a 22.47% improvement in net benefit, and an 84.58% reduction in renewable energy curtailment compared to a non-reconfigured baseline.

title: Generative Model for 2.5D-Assisted Future Urban Remote Sensing Image Synthesis
authors: Yuhan Zhang, Jie Zhou, Weihang Peng, Xiaode Liu, Yuanpei Chen
publish: IEEE Signal Processing Letters
abstract: Generating realistic future urban remote sensing imagery is critical for visualizing potential urban changes and supporting related technical analysis within urban planning. Traditional 2D-assisted methods are inherently limited in synthesize vertical development and infrastructure evolution, as they rely on binary planning maps. To address these limitations, we propose a novel 2.5D-assisted future urban remote sensing image synthesis method, aimed at generating future urban layouts based on existing urban structures and 2.5D planning maps. Specifically, the 2.5D map is divided into construction and demolition components, which are then integrated with the existing layout images and the embedding of the corresponding text as conditions for our generative model. We further design two trainable cascaded gated attention layers that process these two conditions separately and embed them into the latent diffusion model (LDM). This approach allows our model to dynamically comprehend the planning design requirements for key areas, making adjustments to accommodate diverse demands. Compared to existing state-of-the-art (SoTA) methods, our approach effectively targets design requirements, enabling flexible modifications that involve new constructions and demolitions in relevant urban areas. Experimental results on the 3DCD dataset demonstrate that the images generated by our method retain high fidelity and exhibit strong consistency with the 2.5D planning map.

title: Spatially-Aware Adaptive Diffusion: Unifying Low-Resolution Image Fusion and Super-Resolution
authors: Jiajia Fu, Zhenni Yu, Haosheng Chen, Songlin Du, Changcai Yang, Lianghua He, Guobao Xiao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Low-resolution visible-infrared image fusion and super-resolution (LRVIF) are critical for enhancing image quality in low-resolution scenarios, yet limited information in the input images often constrains performance. To address these challenges, we propose SaDiff, a spatially-aware adaptive diffusion model that introduces diffusion processes into LRVIF for the first time, representing a major breakthrough in the field. Leveraging the generative capabilities of diffusion models, our approach unifies and enhances image fusion and super-resolution within a cohesive framework. A key component of SaDiff is the Spatial Residual Adaptation Block, which extends the diffusion process by dynamically adapting feature representations to spatial variations in the local regions of the input images. This module maximally preserves crucial information from the input images, such as texture details and contrast, while effectively suppressing noise, ensuring robust and context-aware feature refinement. Then we further propose Direct Diffusion Synthesis, a novel mechanism that utilizes noise predictions during diffusion to generate fused images, enabling joint training of the fusion and super-resolution networks. Additionally, a Cross-Feature Fusion Module integrates texture and contrast details, producing super-resolution fused images with improved clarity and structural integrity. Extensive experiments show that SaDiff achieves state-of-the-art performance, offering a robust and unified solution to infrared-visible image fusion and super-resolution. The code for the proposed method will be made available at https://github.com/guobaoxiao/SaDiff.

title: Gauge-Free Whittaker Potentials to Model Wave Propagation in Homogeneous Medium
authors: Thomas Reum
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This article deals with alternative scalar potential formulations where no side effect associated to gauging exists whose purpose is to enhance the variety of accessible methods for efficient calculations of electromagnetic (EM) wave fields. In previous investigations, it was shown that in the process of gauging ordinary electrodynamic potentials, an unintentionally changed phase velocity of certain potentials occurs in specific scenarios. Some workarounds for correction were provided there. This aspect in particular suggests as an overriding goal the desire to circumvent any kind of gauge fixing. To realize that, the unusual Whittaker potentials are utilized, which are closely related to the better known Hertz potentials. Besides reasonable propagation properties, they sometimes allow a promising reduction of equations and simplified boundary conditions. Several specifically defined frameworks based on different coordinate systems facilitate appropriate formulations. Proposed dual gauge transformations enable conversions among the two Whittaker potentials for electrodynamically coupled fields. Many detailed computational demonstrations of realistic radio frequency (RF) scenarios modeled with each Whittaker potential individually enable versatile use for practitioners. Although the idea to combine them already exists, an estimation is given to continue this endeavor. Moreover, broad applicability is emphasized by two static scenarios.

title: Environment-adaptive navigation method for biorobots enhanced by the innate nature of insects_supp3-3636291.mp4
authors: Yao Li
publish: N/A
abstract: Biorobots involve embedding artificial components into a living insect to transform it into a controllable robot, which comes with the advantages of low energy consumption, quietness, and flexibility. However, no models have yet been developed to describe the randomness-filled motions of biorobots, and their unique biological properties are also underutilized. In this work, the locomotion responses of a biorobot to electrical stimuli were summarized. The constant-current signal was found to have a higher capacity for sustained stimuli than existing methods. The joint influence of wall and current factors on cockroach behavior was explored to establish an environment-adaptive control model describing their locomotion. This model was then used to propose an navigation method enhanced by the inherent nature of a biorobot. In an indoor scenario, the proposed method achieved a success rate of 78.6% with minimal runtime and stimulus number while the control group using conventional navigation methods achieved a success rate of 30%, with two or three times the runtime and stimulus number. Compared with other approaches, the proposed method facilitates high-precision and long-range navigation with a short navigation time and very low control costs.

title: Feel to Aim: Haptic Assistance for Enhanced Targeting in Virtual Reality
authors: Jean Botev, Johannes Günter Herforth, Marnix Van den Wijngaert
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 18th ACM SIGGRAPH Conference on Motion, Interaction, and Games
abstract: Haptic technology has the potential to substantially support users in mastering complex activities and improving their performance. This paper presents a haptic assistance system for targeting in virtual reality (VR), designed to enhance accuracy and user confidence during aiming tasks by enabling users to sense proximity to and guiding their motion toward a target. To evaluate its effectiveness, we conducted a user study (N = 28) using a custom VR archery simulation, assessing both quantitative performance metrics and qualitative user feedback. With haptic guidance, participants achieved significantly higher targeting accuracy and reported increased spatial awareness, although some also noted a reduced sense of agency. These results suggest that, while haptic assistance offers clear benefits, careful design is essential to avoid overreliance or interference with user autonomy in contexts such as accessibility, gaming, and broader human-computer interaction.

title: Swing it On: Design of Responsive Acoustic Environments for Zoo-housed Colobus Monkeys
authors: David Habboosh, Mohamed El Nayal, Sean Guiru, Aamer Syed, Ilyena Hirskyj-Douglas, Sarah Woodruff, Rebecca Kleinberger
publish: Proceedings of the ACM 12th International Conference on Animal-Computer Interaction
abstract: Traditional zoo enrichment methods often lack flexible, non-food-based interactive elements that support animal autonomy, agency, and meaningful engagement. Enrichment that responds dynamically to animal behavior offers promising alternatives to support species-typical activities while giving animals meaningful choices in their experience. We present the design and evaluation protocol for an interactive acoustic enrichment system that transforms a familiar swing into an agency-based interface for zoo-housed black-and-white colobus monkeys (Colobus guereza). Our system maps swing amplitude to progressive soundscape layers—stream, insect, and bird sounds—allowing monkeys to control the complexity of their auditory environment through natural swinging behavior. Unlike passive enrichment, this approach gives animals direct control over their sensory experience, rewarding physical activity with increasingly rich acoustic feedback. The system offers dual audio outputs: an embedded speaker for direct animal enrichment and an external speaker for visitor education, with zookeepers controlling configuration through a mobile application. We propose a three-phase evaluation protocol comparing passive and interactive swing usage through sensor data, behavioral observations, and keeper assessments. This work contributes to Animal-Computer Interaction (ACI) research by illustrating how zoo infrastructure can be augmented into responsive interfaces, providing a methodological framework for developing species-specific, enrichment systems that give animals meaningful control over their environment.

title: A Novel High Power X-Band Diffraction Output Magnetron (MDO) Pulsating with Maximum Power Higher Than the Input Power
authors: J. G. Leopold, O. Belozerov, Y. Hadas, E. Magid, Y. P. Bliokh, A. Andreev, E. Schamiloglu, Y. E. Krasik
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: PIC simulations of a novel design of an X-band relativistic diffraction output magnetron reveal that at magnetic fields close to the limit where magnetic insulation stops high-power microwave (HPM) generation, the output power pulsates at power levels much higher than the input power. The frequency of the appearance of these pulses is much lower than the HPM frequency. This novel phenomenon is studied in detail and a possible explanation based on the axial oscillation of the accumulated electron charge is suggested. These oscillations occur due to the axial dynamics of electron flows in an MDO which form virtual cathodes where the radius of the outer anode conductors increases relative to the radii of the magnetron anode.

title: Reflection and Noise Separation from Polarized Images Via Joint Nonnegative Matrix Factorization and Plug-And-Play Denoising
authors: Maharu Oda, Ryo Matsuoka
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: We propose a robust method for separating reflections and noise in polarized images captured through glass surfaces and affected by mixed noise, including impulse and Gaussian components. The method formulates an optimization problem based on an observation matrix constructed from multiple polarization-angle images and employs non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) with regularization terms that enforce smoothness in transmission and reflection components and sparsity in noise. To solve this problem efficiently, we adopt an alternating optimization strategy combined with the plug-and-play alternating direction method of multipliers (PnP-ADMM) framework, enabling the integration of advanced denoising operators. Experiments demonstrate that the proposed method consistently outperforms conventional approaches in both quantitative and qualitative evaluations.

title: Leveraging Language Information for Target Language Extraction
authors: Mehmet Sinan Yıldırım, Ruijie Tao, Wupeng Wang, Junyi Ao, Haizhou Li
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Target Language Extraction aims to extract speech in a specific language from a mixture waveform that contains multiple speakers speaking different languages. The human auditory system is adept at performing this task with the knowledge of the particular language. However, the performance of the conventional extraction systems is limited by the lack of this prior knowledge. Speech pre-trained models, which capture rich linguistic and phonetic representations from large-scale in-the-wild corpora, can provide this missing language knowledge to these systems. In this work, we propose a novel end-to-end framework to leverage language knowledge from speech pre-trained models. This knowledge is used to guide the extraction model to better capture the target language characteristics, thereby improving extraction quality. To demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed approach, we construct the first publicly available multilingual dataset for Target Language Extraction. Experimental results show that our method achieves improvements of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 2 2} \mathbf{d B}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 1 2}$</tex> dB in SI-SNR for English and German extraction, respectively, from mixtures containing both languages.

title: X-Band Relativistic Magnetron with TE11 Mode Diffraction Output Simulation
authors: Frans Nyberg, Pablo Vallejos, Tomas Hurtig
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: High power microwave sources generate more than 100 MW of radiated power at frequencies between 1 and 100 GHz. The relativistic magnetron is a high power microwave source that is compact, has gigawatt microwave output and high beam-to-microwave efficiency from L - to C -band. A challenge for the relativistic magnetron is to operate at higher frequency regimes. The possible output power decreases at higher frequencies because electric field breakdown are reached at lower powers when the source is smaller. In addition, materials used for explosive electron emission are expected to degrade faster at higher frequencies, because high currents are emitted from smaller areas. To assess the possibilities for X-band operation, a six-cavity relativistic magnetron with a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pi$</tex> mode to TE11 mode diffraction output was simulated in MAGIC. To mitigate high electric fields and current densities, we lowered the operating conditions (voltage and axial magnetic field strength). For example, at 142 kV and 0.64 T, the relativistic magnetron outputs 54 MW at 8.15 GHz and 30% efficiency.

title: Evaluating Data Presentation Tools for Effective Communication
authors: Nikhil N. Sharma, Kaden Nesch, Sergiu Dascalu, Frederick C. Harris
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Accurately selecting the proper data presentation tool based on the type of data being used is one of the most essential steps toward developing a robust and effective data communication method. This selection’s contribution to an application can either become beneficial or a downright detriment. Our project tackled this problem via the use of The Things Stack, an open-source LoRaWAN network server that links sensor deployments and records their data. Users on our application encountered two different methods of data presentation: a tabular data export page and a dynamic data visualization page. Through a user study, participants completed tasks to evaluate each method’s effectiveness in identifying specific data points, determining monthly averages, and locating peak values. Upon completion, participants voiced their opinions on which presentation tool they preferred as well as which one was more effective in progressing through the user study. Our initial quantitative hypothesis on the user study results stated that the data export page would yield a lower completion time, higher accuracy, and a higher number of clicks. After reviewing the results, the data export page had a 7.68-second lower completion time, 6.67% lower accuracy, and 13.3 more clicks compared to the data visualization page. Our results only managed to satisfy two out of three of the initial claims we had made.

title: Quantum-Resistant Cryptography for Underwater Acoustic Channels Using CRYSTALS-Kyber and SPHINCS+
authors: Collins Izuchukwu Okafor, Love Allen Chijioke Ahakonye, Dong-Seong Kim, Jae Min Lee
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: Secure underwater communication is vital for maritime operations; however, acoustic channels pose significant challenges, including limited bandwidth, high latency, and complex propagation effects. With quantum computing threatening classical methods, there is a need for cryptographic schemes that can withstand quantum attacks. This study presents a quantum-resistant underwater communication system that integrates CRYSTALS-Kyber for key encapsulation, SPHINCS+ for digital signature authentication, and AES for efficient payload encryption. The proposed system is evaluated under realistic underwater channel simulations that account for propagation delay, multipath fading, and Doppler effects. Experimental benchmarks reveal that while post-quantum operations, such as CRYSTALS-Kyber key encapsulation (2.41-4.91ms) and SPHINCS+ signing (96.10ms) exhibit higher latencies compared to classical ECC/ECDSA methods, these latencies remain within acceptable limits given the substantial security advantages they offer. This approach bridges the gap between rigorous quantum-resistant security and practical underwater deployment, establishing a robust foundation for future enhancements in error correction and adaptive network strategies.

title: Pilot Safety Performance Evaluation Based on Quick Access Recorder Data
authors: Ziyao Li, Xing Pan, Chongfeng Li
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: With the development of science and technology, aviation safety continues to improve, but pilot behavior remains a key factor in flight safety. Civil aviation safety performance management, particularly performance evaluation, is essential for formulating effective safety measures. Key parameters from the Quick Access Recorder (QAR) that reflect or affect flight safety are selected based on flight dynamics and operation analysis. These parameters are then transformed into pilot safety performance indicators based on aviation industry standard documents, forming an evaluation index system. Finally, pilot safety performance evaluation and sensitivity analysis of key factors for improving safety performance were achieved through fuzzy Bayesian method. This study provides theoretical model and data-driven decision support for airlines to assess the overall flight safety level and conduct targeted pilot training.

title: Efficient Text Classification with Hybrid Retrieval and Generative Labeling
authors: Ahmet Tuğrul Bayrak, Fatma Nur Korkmaz, Mustafa Sertaç Türkel, İsmail Utku Sayan, Bekir Berker Türker
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: This study compares the performance of retrieval-based (Faiss) and generative (ChatGPT) text classification approaches across different text representations and dataset characteristics. Two different datasets are evaluated. The first dataset is small and imbalanced, and the second dataset is bigger and equally labelled. Three preprocessing methods (original text, root extraction, and NER-based filtering) are combined with three classification approaches; Faiss similarity, ChatGPT, and hybrid Faiss + ChatGPT approach with varying similarity thresholds. Experimental results demonstrate that ChatGPT alone achieves superior accuracy but has higher computational costs. The hybrid approach maintains comparable performance while reducing API calls by 9–23% when using a 0.95 similarity threshold. The results show that dataset properties strongly influence performance. Hybrid methods provide a good balance, especially for imbalanced datasets. The study provides practical insights for selecting text classification approaches based on dataset properties.

title: Diversity-Driven Edge Microservice Execution Path Generation
authors: Kaijun Jiang, Shuxu Zhao, Xiaolong Wang, Chaoneng Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: A diversity-driven evolutionary strategy for microservice path generation in mobile edge computing is proposed to address load imbalance and user experience degradation caused by high request concurrency, resource heterogeneity, and centralized path selection. First, a backtracking search with diversity constraints is designed to overcome redundancy in conventional path generation, where a path-difference metric and pruning mechanism efficiently produce a structurally diverse, low-redundancy candidate path set. Then, a two-tier game-theoretic framework models user strategy evolution through evolutionary dynamics, guiding the shift from isolated decisions to coordinated distributions and mitigating resource contention across edge nodes. Finally, a discrete particle swarm optimization algorithm with recent-past position updating enables localized server pricing, steering requests toward underutilized nodes to relieve hotspot congestion. Extensive simulations demonstrate that the proposed strategy significantly improves path diversity, load balancing, and latency compared with state-of-the-art methods.

title: YOLOv10-C2f-FENG: Efficient Anomaly Detection for Smart Care Monitoring
authors: Feng-Yu Xu, Jen-Chun Lee, Yu-Jen Pan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: With the increasing population of elderly people, the demand for efficient and real-time intelligent monitoring systems in long-term care facilities has become urgent. However, deploying multiple deep learning models (e.g., abnormal posture detection and face recognition) on resource-constrained devices results in excessive computational overhead, negatively impacting system performance and stability. Therefore, we enhanced a YOLOv10 algorithm, referred to as YOLOv10-C2f-FENG, which incorporates the C2f-Faster structure and exponential moving average (EMA) optimization into the backbone and neck networks. The model was trained on a self-constructed posture dataset containing 4,665 images, divided into 80% for training, 10% for validation, and 10% for testing. Experiments were conducted to compare the performance of the lightweight and medium versions of YOLOv8, YOLOv10, and their improved variants. Compared with the baseline YOLOv10 model, the developed lightweight model improved performance by 2.8, 3.8, 5, and 5% in precision, recall, mAP@50, and mAP@50:95 metrics, respectively. The medium-weight model showed improvements of 5.5, 3.6, 3.8, and 0.5% for the same metrics. Additionally, the YOLOv10-C2f-FENG model significantly reduced computational overhead, decreasing giga floating-point operations per second by 33.6%, parameters by 20.6%, and inference latency by 15.9%. The model significantly enhances detection performance while effectively reducing computational costs, laying a technical foundation for intelligent monitoring systems.

title: Evaluation of Auditory and Tactile Perception for Augmented Sound-Image Enhancement Using Pre-Virtual-Leading Hypersonic Signals
authors: Ryota Imanaka, Yuting Geng, Masato Nakayama, Takanobu Nishiura
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Recently, stereo audio technologies have been proposed to control sound-image localization based on binaural effects. Precedence effect, which occurs when sounds arrive from different directions with a slight time difference, allows listeners to perceive a sound-image in the direction of the first-arriving sound. Moreover, hypersonic effect suggests that inaudible highfrequency sounds influence the perception of audible sounds. Considering the potential of ultrasound in controlling soundimage localization, we have previously proposed a sound-image augmentation method with ultrasonic signals, named pre-virtualleading hypersonic signals. In this method, a sound-image is constructed using stereo technologies, while these signals enhance directional perception. These signals are designed based on the tactile perception of ultrasounds. This method has been demonstrated to be effective in limited conditions, though the sensory perception mechanism has not yet been fully clarified. This paper focuses on whether the signals are perceived auditorily or tactilely. We conducted evaluation experiments and demonstrated the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: 100× Monolingual Data Augmentation Using LLMs to Build a Parallel Corpus for Machine Translation
authors: Hitoshi Ito, Naoto Shirai, Kazutaka Kinugawa, Hideya Mino, Yoshihiko Kawai
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: The aim of this study is to address the generation of high-quality synthetic data for domain adaptation in news machine translation. Effective machine translation requires training data that includes domain-relevant characteristics such as topical focus and writing style. Large language models (LLMs) can generate both bilingual and monolingual data; however, producing diverse monolingual data that closely aligns with the target domain remains a challenge. In this work, we explore the feasibility of using LLMs to generate synthetic data by attempting to create 100 times parallel sentence pairs with the original monolingual sentences. We leverage domain-specific keywords and combine multiple LLMs in a generation pipeline. Experimental results on Thai-Japanese news translation confirmed that the synthetic data generated by the proposed method significantly improved the translation performance of general-purpose models. These results also revealed that the use of appropriate keywords and the strategic switching between multiple LLMs play a crucial role in outperforming conventional methods.

title: Ontology-Constrained OCR with Verified Abstention and Semantic Metrics
authors: Eya Ben Hmida, Sarra Abidi, Leila Ben Ayed
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: Traditional OCR systems optimize character-level accuracy but often produce semantically invalid outputs for structured documents. We propose an ontology-constrained OCR framework that integrates domain knowledge during beam search decoding while maintaining verified abstention capabilities for uncertain predictions. Our approach introduces Correct Semantic Rate (CSR) and Semantic Error Rate (SER) metrics that better reflect real-world deployment requirements than traditional character-level metrics. Experimental evaluation on financial and administrative documents demonstrates significant semantic improvements with 34% reduction in SER while maintaining comparable Character Error Rate (CER), with calibrated abstention achieving 85% coverage at 15% risk threshold.

title: OLASS: Online Lyapunov Optimization with Selective Scheduling in High-Load Edge Computing
authors: Yongmin Zhang, Xiaoxiao Rong, Yijia Tao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: The explosive growth of Internet of Things (IoT) devices urgently requires efficient edge computing solutions to support real-time applications, while <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 \mathrm{G} / 6 \mathrm{G}$</tex> technologies enable rapid data transmission to Edge Servers (ESs). However, inherent challenges persist in task scheduling due to task diversity and divergent computing capabilities of ESs. Existing research typically assumes sufficient computational resources, overlooking the critical scenario where ES resources may become inadequate under high-load conditions. To address this problem, we propose an online Lyapunov-based Ant Colony Local Search Optimization Scheduling Strategy (OLASS) for dynamic edge computing. Firstly, the long-term scheduling optimization problem has been transformed into single-time-slot subproblems using Lyapunov optimization theory. Subsequently, heterogeneous tasks are scheduled among ESs through a two-phase scheduling mechanism. Extensive simulations demonstrate that, compared with three baseline methods, OLASS exhibits effectiveness and robustness under high-load conditions.

title: MMoH: Efficient Training of Multimodal Large Language Models on Heterogeneous Clusters
authors: Jinshan Fan, Zhiquan Lai, Weijie Liu, Shengwei Li, Wei Wang, Yanqi Hao, Dongsheng Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Multimodal large language models (MLLMs) achieve strong performance across diverse AI applications but remain costly to train. With advancing hardware, heterogeneous clusters are increasingly used for MLLM training. However, existing methods often ignore MLLMs' hybrid-module structure and varying parameter states, leading to suboptimal performance. We propose MMoH, an efficient training approach for MLLMs on heterogeneous clusters. MMoH consists of a parallel strategy planner and an early-termination scheduler. The planner jointly considers model structure, device heterogeneity, and parameter states to select optimal parallel strategies. It first matches module requirements with device capabilities to identify feasible topologies. Then, using a hybrid-granularity abstraction, it divides the model into chunks and assigns pipeline stages accordingly. The scheduler further reduces overhead by eliminating redundant computation and communication. Experiments show that MMoH accelerates MLLM training on heterogeneous clusters by up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.77 \times$</tex> over state-of-the-art methods.

title: Voice Conversion Augmentation for Speaker Recognition on Defective Datasets
authors: Ruijie Tao, Zhan Shi, Yidi Jiang, Tianchi Liu, Haizhou Li
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Modern speaker recognition system relies on abundant and balanced datasets for classification training. However, diverse defective datasets, such as partially-labelled, small-scale, and imbalanced datasets, are common in real-world applications. Previous works usually studied specific solutions for each scenario from the algorithm perspective. However, the root cause of these problems lies in dataset imperfections. To address these challenges with a unified solution, we propose the Voice Conversion Augmentation (VCA) strategy to obtain pseudo speech from the training set. Furthermore, to guarantee generation quality, we designed the VCA-NN (nearest neighbours) strategy to select source speech from utterances that are close to the target speech in the representation space. Our experimental results on three created datasets demonstrated that VCA-NN effectively mitigates these dataset problems, which provides a new direction for handling the speaker recognition problems from the data aspect.

title: And Regional Selective Mixup
authors: Yu-Chen Lin, Yi-Jing Chen, Chih-Chang Yu, Hsu-Yung Cheng
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Current studies on micro-expression recognition still achieve limited performance, typically yielding less than 50% accuracy. Although utilizing recent powerful models, such as Mamba, improves performance, they usually require enormous data for training. Therefore, this study proposes a regional selective mixup (RSMix) strategy that relies on facial Action Unit (AU) information to augment the dataset. The proposed approach systematically fuses facial images from micro-expressiongenerating regions with corresponding expressionless regions to synthesize new micro-expression samples. RSMix ensures that salient features from micro-expression-generating regions are preserved within these synthetic samples, facilitating the model's capacity to focus on essential visual cues for distinguishing different micro-expressions. We applied the VideoMamba model as the backbone to test the efficiency of RSMix and other augmentation methods. Experimental results on the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\operatorname{CAS}(\text{ME})^{3}$</tex> dataset demonstrate that with RSMix, the VideoMamba-Ti model achieves an accuracy improvement of Unweighted F1-score (UF1) of 0.0138 and Unweighted average recall (UAR) of 0.0048 compared to baseline configurations without augmentation. When flip augmentation is combined with the RSMix, the VideoMambaS model achieves UF1 of 0.5040 and UAR of 0.4941, superior to the Mamba-based approach. These results prove that the RSMix approach effectively enhances data diversity, which also helps VideoMamba for the micro-expression recognition task.

title: Wave Direction Estimation Based on Local Gradient Techniques from Satellite Imagery for Coastal Dynamics Monitoring
authors: Woramet Simrum, Paweena Kanokhong, Chakapat Chokchaisiri, Somrudee Deepaisarn, Kittipisut Chansri, Chanyut Lisawat, Waranrach Viriyavit, Akkharawoot Takhom, Phutphalla Kong, Didin Agustian Permadi, Sharifah Hafizah Syed Ariffin, Surasak Boonkla, Kasorn Galajit, Jessada Karnjana
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This paper proposes a wave direction estimation method using high-resolution satellite image patches to support coastal dynamics analysis, providing greater insight into coastal erosion and make coastal management more effective. The method draws inspiration from local gradient techniques used in SAR-based wind retrieval but adapts them to optical imagery with a more straightforward implementation. Using Sobel filters, dominant wave crest orientations are extracted from each image patch. After noise removal via thresholding and median filtering, wave direction is computed from edge orientations using a double-angle trigonometric averaging approach. Experiments on Thailand's coastal imagery demonstrate that the method produces robust average wave direction estimates at patch scale, offering a scalable and approach to wave pattern analysis without additional instrument installation. The experimental results show a mean absolute error (MAE) of 6.9 degrees and a root mean square error (RMSE) of 8.3 degrees, indicating a high level of agreement between the estimated and reference wave directions. Furthermore, 89.5 percent of the predictions fall within plus or minus 15 degrees of the reference values. However, the accuracy of method depends on image quality and parameter tuning, highlighting the need for consistent preprocessing.

title: Few-Step Diffusion-Based Voice Conversion Using Consistency Trajectory Models
authors: Ryuichi Hatakeyama, Toru Nakashika, Takuya Takahashi
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: In this study, we propose a voice conversion method that replaces the decoder of DDPMVC with the consistency trajectory model (CTM), a form of diffusion model distillation. DDPMVC is a voice conversion (VC) framework that consists of an encoder that suppresses speaker information from the input speech through a forward diffusion process, and a decoder that generates the target speaker's mel-spectrogram via multi-step reverse diffusion. While this framework achieved high conversion accuracy, its major drawback is the long inference time due to the sequential nature of the sampling process. To address this issue, we introduce the CTM into the decoder of DDPMVC. CTM directly predicts the endpoint of diffusion inference and has demonstrated improved generation quality and faster sampling compared to conventional diffusion models. Experimental results show that the proposed method outperforms DDPMVC in voice conversion accuracy while reducing the sampling steps from thousands to just 10 steps.

title: Neural Speech Separation with Parallel Amplitude and Phase Spectrum Estimation
authors: Fei Liu, Yang Ai, Zhen-Hua Ling
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This paper proposes APSS, a novel neural speech separation model with parallel amplitude and phase spectrum estimation. Unlike most existing speech separation methods, the APSS distinguishes itself by explicitly estimating the phase spectrum for more complete and accurate separation. Specifically, APSS first extracts the amplitude and phase spectra from the mixed speech signal. Subsequently, the extracted amplitude and phase spectra are fused by a feature combiner into joint representations, which are then further processed by a deep processor with time-frequency Transformers to capture temporal and spectral dependencies. Finally, leveraging parallel amplitude and phase separators, the APSS estimates the respective spectra for each speaker from the resulting features, which are then combined via inverse short-time Fourier transform (iSTFT) to reconstruct the separated speech signals. Experimental results indicate that APSS surpasses both time-domain separation methods and implicit-phase-estimation-based time-frequency approaches. Also, APSS achieves stable and competitive results on multiple datasets, highlighting its strong generalization capability and practical applicability.

title: Perception Sensors-Based Fusion System and Method for Controlling Vehicle
authors: Ankush Balajirao Khansole, Priyanga S, Sayed Hasan Megdam, Obaidur Rahman Mohammed, Prasanta Kumar Parida
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Safe vehicle control under varying environmental conditions using autonomous driving needs real-time, reliable and accurate perception systems. This paper describes a Perception Sensors-Based Fusion System and Method to Control the Vehicle with a Hybrid Deep Sensor Fusion method employing Bayesian Uncertainty Modeling in Transformer-based structure. The multi-modal data that includes camera, LiDAR, radar, and inertial sensor is integrated in the proposed system to support better object detection, localization, and prediction of future trajectory. The model also includes Bayesian uncertainty, which ensures confidence-sensitive decision, and it practically favors on false positives considerably and offers robustness in high-dimensional traffic settings. It was implemented in PyTorch with PyTorch Lightning, and it can achieve real-time performance on the inference with a latency of 28 ms by using NVIDIA TensorRT to optimize. The comparison analysis indicates high performance results compared against CNN- and GNN-based baselines, producing a significant increase in detection accuracy, localizing precision, and the capability of operating under unfavorable weather. The outcomes verify the scalability and capability of the framework to next-generation autonomous vehicle control.

title: A Novel AI assisted integrated bioinformatics identification of hub genes associated with lupus nephritis progression
authors: Zhao Liang, Suresh V Chinni, Zhiming Tang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Background: Lupus Nephritis (LN) is one of the worst forms of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) with complicated pathophysiology and few modes of treatment. The potential of transformation involved in determining the molecular signatures and drug targets in LN is inherent in the artificial intelligence (AI) and bioinformatics combination.Methods: We compared transcriptomic data in the GEO database, GSE32591 and GSE81622 with AI-based bioinformatics pipelines to determine the DEGs). The selection of features and prioritization of genes were done through the network-based machine learning algorithm, which was applied to the protein-protein networks formed through the use of STRING and visualized in Cytoscape. Topological AI ranking techniques of cytoHubba were used to extract hub genes. The verification of the gene expression across tissue types was conducted using integrated transcriptomic atlases (Bgee, HPA) and drug and gene interactions had to be mapped to the DGIDB database using AI-assisted pitfalls.Results: The common set of DEGs (CDEGs) were made up of 78 datasets. The AI-based enrichment proved that the above genes were functionally important in regulating ribonuclease and the NOD-like receptor signaling. Multi-algorithmic centrality scoring evaluate the centrality scores EIF2AK2, IFIT1, IFIT3, MX1, OAS1, OAS2. Their spatial confirmation of the expression of kidney tissue RNA and proteomics was done. One of the possible treatments, which was produced as a result of AI-created drug repositioning, was the IL-3 blockade.Conclusion: This article has shown that the AI-enhanced bioinformatics is powerful to identify meaningful molecular pathways and therapeutic hints in LN. The precision nephrology and the future AI-based diagnostic models are based on the identified hub genes and the drug targets.

title: A Congestion-Aware Adaptive Packet Sampling Framework for High Flow Visibility
authors: Chundong Wang, Tianci Cheng, Xiaodong Dong, Jinze Du, Yuhan Tian
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Modern switches commonly employ fixed sampling rates, which often fail to capture congested flows due to their reduced packet rates, ultimately resulting in low flow visibility. However, many network management applications such as traffic engineering and security analysis require high flow visibility to identify congested bottleneck links or detect anomalies. Although some adaptive sampling methods have been proposed, they suffer from scalability issues for requiring per-flow real-time packet rates, which are extremely complicated, expensive and imprecise to track. In this paper, we present CAsample, a congestion-aware adaptive packet sampling framework based on Software-Defined Network (SDN) paradigm to solve the above issues. The key idea of CAsample is to adaptively update sampling strategies, indicating which switch should sample which flow at what sampling rate, by sensing per-flow congestion degree. Specifically, CAsample detects the per-flow congestion degree by estimating switch queue lengths and packet RTT. We then establish a relationship between flow rate and traffic congestion degree following the ideas of TCP Reno congestion control and Random Early Detection. Finally, to maximize the flow visibility, we formulate an optimization problem, then propose a corresponding low-complexity near-optimal solution. We compare CAsample with state-of-the-art methods in small-scale Mininet testbed and large-scale simulation experiments. The results demonstrate that CAsample achieves an average 21.5% improvement in flow visibility while reducing the network sampling load by 17.2%.

title: Registration of Infrared and Visible Images Using Style Transfer-Based Semantic Segmentation
authors: Si-Ting Lin, Chih-Hung Han, Chieh-Ling Lee, Po-Chyi Su, Feng-Tsun Chien, Min-Kuan Chang
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Infrared and visible image fusion combines complementary information from both modalities to produce a single image that enhances human perception and supports high-level tasks such as semantic segmentation and object detection. Most existing fusion methods assume perfectly aligned infrared and visible image pairs, an assumption that rarely holds in realworld scenarios due to spatial misalignment, frame drops, and differences in resolution or field of view. While recent approaches can handle minor misalignments under equal resolution, more robust alignment strategies are needed for significant discrepancies. Furthermore, current fusion datasets lack semantic and object annotations, limiting the development of task-driven models. To address these challenges, we propose a new method for constructing a fusion dataset enriched with semantic segmentation labels. We apply style transfer to existing annotated datasets to generate synthetic infrared-visible image pairs tailored to target applications. These images are used to retrain segmentation models, creating datasets with needed annotations. For spatial alignment, we estimate scaling and translation using logarithmic polar transformations and the Fourier Transform. To handle temporal misalignment, we integrate spatial alignment with mask matching to maximize object overlap between paired frames. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our method in aligning infrared and visible image pairs.

title: Vision Transformers-Based Product Recognition System for Automated Retail Inventory Management
authors: Khushbu Keshri, Princy Singh, Tasneef Nav, Hussein Basim Furaiji, Shawqi Najah, Jasim Ahmede Jasim
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: The increasing need to have optimization of the retail activities has called upon development of improved machine learning-based inventory management systems. The proposed product recognition framework can be used to automate retail inventory with the help of Vision Transformer (ViT) networks. As opposed to traditional convolutional neural networks (CNNs), Vision Transformers apply self-attention, enabling capture of global contextual scene features to deliver an increase in accuracy and generalizability in complex retail settings with diverse lighting, occlusion, product orientation. It applies the TensorFlow to train the system, that can operate in real-time based on the scale of recognition of different retail products based on shelf images. Comparative study with previous models based on CNN illustrates better performance in the parameters of precision, recall and inference time. The provided approach not only increases accuracy of inventory but also decreases the number of operations that need to be performed manually, optimizing the actions of retail, and facilitating replenishment of stock in advance.

title: Adaptive Event-Triggered Control of Time-Varying Nonlinear Systems: A Tight and Powerful Strategy
authors: Lei Chu, Yungang Liu
publish: IEEE/CAA Journal of Automatica Sinica
abstract: This paper considers adaptive event-triggered stabilization for a class of uncertain time-varying nonlinear systems. Remarkably, the systems contain intrinsic time-varying unknown parameters which are allowed to be non-differentiable and in turn can be fast-varying. Moreover, the systems admit unknown control directions. To counteract the different uncertainties, more than one compensation mechanism has to be incorporated. However, in the context of event-triggered control, ensuring the effectiveness of these compensation mechanisms under reduced execution necessitates delicate design and analysis. This paper proposes a tight and powerful strategy for adaptive event-triggered control (ETC) by integrating the state-of-the-art adaptive techniques. In particular, the strategy substantially mitigates the conservatism caused by repetitive inequality-based treatments of uncertainties. Specifically, by leveraging the congelation-of-variables method and tuning functions, the conservatism in the treatment of the fast-varying parameters is significantly reduced. With multiple Nussbaum functions employed to handle unknown control directions, a set of dynamic compensations is designed to counteract unknown amplitudes of control coefficients without relying on inequality-based treatments. Moreover, a dedicated dynamic compensation is introduced to deal with the control coefficient coupled with the execution error, based on which a relative-threshold event-triggering mechanism (ETM) is rigorously validated. It turns out that the adaptive event-triggered controller achieves the closed-loop convergence while guaranteeing a uniform lower bound for inter-execution times. Simulation results verify the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed strategy.

title: Quaternion-Based Modeling and Predefined-Time Tracking Control of a Fully Actuated Autonomous Underwater Vehicle
authors: Yiming Li, Xiao Wang, Jinglong Shi, Jian Liu, Changyin Sun
publish: IEEE/CAA Journal of Automatica Sinica
abstract: This paper investigates the modeling and the practical predefined-time (PdT) tracking control problems for a fully actuated disk-shaped autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) with six degrees of freedom. To overcome the gimbal lock problem inherent in Euler angle representation, unit quaternions are adopted to model the AUV, accounting for internal uncertainties and external disturbances. Then, an improved time-varying function is introduced, which serves as the basis for designing a non-singular sliding surface and sliding mode controller with PdT stability. This approach ensures that the tracking errors converge within a predefined time, independent of initial conditions and design parameters. Compared with traditional PdT controllers, the proposed method eliminates singularities, enhances the precision of convergence time estimation, and typically yields smaller, smoother initial control inputs, thus improving its potential for engineering applications. Numerical simulations validate the effectiveness and performance of the proposed controller.

title: Personalized Bone-Conduction Bandwidth Extension with Speaker Characteristics
authors: Pan Xu, Zhongyu Zhang, Zhonghua Fu
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: To address the challenges of high-frequency attenuation and speaker variability in bone-conducted (BC) speech, this paper proposes a personalized feature-integrated bandwidth extension (BWE) method. The proposed approach employs a dual-encoder architecture that extracts time-frequency representations from low-quality BC signals and personalized features from air-conducted (AC) reference speech. These features are fused via an attention mechanism and jointly optimized with a speaker classification task. Experiments on both simulated and real-world datasets demonstrate that the proposed method significantly outperforms existing baseline methods in terms of speech quality, spectral fidelity, and intelligibility. These results validate the effectiveness of the approach in complex acoustic environments and offer a novel direction for BC speech enhancement.

title: Market Forecasting Using LSTM-ARIMA Model with MACD Decomposition
authors: Teng-Chih Yu, Jian-Jiun Ding
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Market forecasting plays a critical role in economic signal processing. In this study, a model that applies the moving average convergence divergence (MACD) indicator together with learning-based architectures is proposed for market forecasting. First, we propose a novel MACD decomposition method to preprocess the data. By employing the proposed decomposition approach, the high- and low-frequency components are effectively separated. These components correspond to the short-term and the long-term information in the market, respectively. Then, two well-known models in economic forecasting, LSTM and ARIMA models, are employed to perform next-day predictions using only past closing prices. The proposed algorithm well integrates the merits of learning-based techniques and classical regression model. Despite of relatively less complexity, the proposed approach achieves promising performance and demonstrates adaptability across a variety of economic signals.

title: Dynamic Beam-Hopping in Multi-Beam LEO Networks Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Tae-Yoon Kim, Jaeyeol Lee, Jihong Park, Taehan Moon, Jae-Hyun Kim
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: Conventional beam-hopping (BH) methods are not well-suited for the complex nature of LEO satellite networks. In this paper, we define a channel model and signal model based on the 3GPP standard and propose an effective action selection BH deep Q-network (EABH-DQN) algorithm to optimize the BH scheduling of Earth-fixed multi-beam LEO satellites based on ground cell traffic demand. The EABH-DQN algorithm employs an effective action-selection strategy to address the challenges of executing BH across a large number of ground cells within the highly dynamic conditions of LEO satellite networks.

title: Optimization of Cultural Space in Traditional Villages Based on Space Syntax: A Case Study of Weitou Village
authors: Huilin Zheng, Qinghui Huang, Yinglu Huang, Yifei Yang, Yuan Yuan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: For Weitou Village in Jinjiang City, Fujian Province, China, we investigated optimization strategies for cultural spaces in traditional villages using space syntax methodology. An axial model of the village’s cultural space was constructed to analyze its spatial structure and examine the relationship between spatial configuration and villagers’ behavioral patterns. Weitou Village’s cultural spatial network is relatively fragmented and characterized by limited connectivity among spatial nodes. Furthermore, the villagers’ route choices are largely influenced by the functional attributes and social significance of specific spaces. Based on these results, we propose a "Conservation and Development Plan for Weitou Village" to enhance spatial coherence and usability.

title: IoT-Based Implantable AI Pill Development for Medicine Tracking
authors: S. Sujiya, Priyadharshini. V, Rakesh. S, Roshan Fazila M I
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Implantable medication adherence technologies are crucial in places where traditional approaches, such as pillboxes, smart bottles, or patient self-reporting, fail to provide optimal treatment outcomes. Traditional systems are incorrect, reliant on humans, have limited real-time monitoring capabilities, and cannot validate drug consumption or physiological effects. It presents an AI pill that can be implanted in the body, which uses built-in sensors and a wireless connection to check if a person has taken their medication and how their body is responding. Cloud-based machine learning models for personalized recommendations, anomaly detection, and real-time compliance detection in terms of anomaly detection, the proposed system outperforms the existing systems, achieving 92% accuracy, 93% recall, and 89% true positive rate. pH tracking is also more accurate, with a mean error of only 0.05 units. A possible paradigm changes in the usage of intelligent device-based systems to monitor digital adherence in practice is provided by the results presented here, which are consistent with the existing research on the proposed system's ability to operate accurately and as planned.

title: Beyond Traffic Mixing: Ingress Shared Buffer Management for RDMA Networks
authors: Yubing Li, Qingyun Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: The shared buffer is used to absorb bursts in data center networks. The shared buffer architecture of data centers with Remote Direct Memory Access (RDMA) differs from that of traditional data centers. Data centers with RDMA introduce ingress shared buffers to isolate lossless traffic. Ingress shared buffer management differs significantly from egress management, as it employs Priority-based Flow Control (PFC) with multiple thresholds to buffer packets and pause upstream devices to minimize packet loss. The widely used ingress shared buffer management method, DT, suffers from deep queue depth and limited burst absorption capability. We propose a novel ingress shared buffer management method called ISBM, which includes threshold flipping and periodic threshold updating mechanisms. To our knowledge, this is the first work to improve flow performance in data centers with RDMA by optimizing ingress shared buffer management. The evaluation results demonstrate that ISBM significantly reduces the number of pause frames and improves the flow completion time of short flows up to 35%.

title: Experiments on Coaxial and Rectangular Cavity Oscillators for X-band High-Power Microwave Generation With No Guiding Magnetic Field
authors: Michael Mounho, Braden Baird, James Dickens, Andreas Neuber, John Mankowski, Jacob Stephens
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Simulated and experimental results for X-band high-power microwave (HPM) sources using split-cavity oscillators (SCO) are reported. Coaxial and rectangular SCOs are driven by a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-500 \text{kV}, \sim 10 \text{kA}$</tex> electron beam using no guiding magnetic field in particle-in-cell (PIC) simulations and have achieved tens to hundreds of megawatts of average output microwave power at frequencies ranging from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 6 \text{GHz}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 12$</tex> GHz. This paper details the design, materials, and experimental results of the two tested SCO geometries.

title: Optimization of Superconducting Pulsed Transformer for High-Performance Inductive Pulsed Power Supplies
authors: Ayaz Ahmed, Zulkurnain Abdul-Malek
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: High load current pulses with high repetitive rates are critical for applications such as fusion research, rail guns, and similar fields. Superconducting pulsed transformers are used in inductive pulsed power supply to improve energy transfer efficiency and reduce resistive losses. Previously, a twowinding superconducting pulsed power transformer was used. However, it suffers from overvoltage spikes across the opening switch and limited load current. In this work, a three-winding pulsed transformer (TWPT) is proposed. It consists of two primary windings using superconducting material and a secondary copper winding. Four coil stacking designs were simulated using Ansys Maxwell and an optimized coil stacking design was obtained based on coupling performance, magnetic field distribution, and load current capacity. A prototype TWPT was then constructed using superconducting tape (rare-earth barium copper oxide (ReBCO) at room temperature), each primary with 160 turns. The corresponding transformer coupling coefficients (Kpip2, Kp1s, and Kp2s) obtained from simulations are 82.9%, 83.7%, and 83.7%, and from experiment 78.3%, 78.7%, and 77.5%, respectively, with an acceptable difference of about 4. 6% – 6. 2%. A superconducting pulsed power supply (SPPS) was then designed using Ansys Simplorer to determine optimum repetitive rate and output current capacity. Four thyristor switching sequence modes (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{M}_{1}-\mathrm{M}_{4}$</tex>) and 16 timing combinations (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{C}_{1}-\mathrm{C}_{16}$</tex>) were analysed. Simulation results with 100 A charging current indicate <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{M}_{4}-\mathrm{C}_{4}$</tex> gives an optimum repetitive rate of 25 Hz with an optimum peak output current of 6.27 kA, exceeding the previously reported output of 20 Hz and 4.95 kA by Lu et al. (2021). A small-scale prototype of the SPPS was developed based on the obtained optimum design with the TWPT maintained at 72 K. A peak load current of 140 A (compared to about 80 A, at room temperature) was achieved with 7.5 A charging current at a repetition rate of 25 Hz.

title: Fixed-Point Based IMU Pre-Integration for Accelerating ORB-SLAM 3
authors: Michael Akor, Heoncheol Lee
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: While most SLAM acceleration research targets feature extraction and backend optimization, the IMU pre-integration module in ORB-SLAM3 remains an overlooked performance bottleneck for real-time visual-inertial SLAM on embedded platforms. We present the first hardware-ready, fixed-point C++ kernel for this module, achieving strict algorithmic equivalence and seamless high-level synthesis integration. Experiments on EuRoC MAV and TUM VI datasets demonstrate up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8. 2\mathrm{x}$</tex> speedup on desktop and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5. 5\mathrm{x}$</tex> on ARM, with accuracy pre-served within MEMS IMU noise. Our results reveal a promising and previously neglected avenue for practical SLAM acceleration on constrained hardware.

title:
Predictive Analytics with CO
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Dehydration Time Series Data Using LGBM
authors: Marina Yusoff, Nurain Ibrahim, Jasni Mohamad Zain, Mohamad Taufik Mohd Sallehud-Din, Amiza Surmi, Yuzi Mahmud, Siti Kamaliah Kamarudin, Iylia Idris
publish: 2025 IEEE Industrial Electronics and Applications Conference (IEACon)
abstract: Precise prediction of CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> dehydration efficacy is essential for maintaining operational efficiency in industrial gas processing systems, especially in CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> dehydration units. This research presents a predictive analytics framework that utilizes the Light Gradient Boosting Machine algorithm to forecast CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> dehydration behavior using time series data. The model utilizes historical operational parameters to identify temporal dependencies and forecast essential adsorption-related characteristics. A systematic methodology was employed to determine the ideal lookback period, with 72 hours (3 days) identified as the optimal interval that effectively encompasses both short-term variations and long-term trends. The model's performance was assessed using Root Mean Squared Error and Mean Absolute Error, consistently attaining a "Very Good" acceptance level across the majority of features. Essential process variables, such as vessel pressures and adsorption-related parameters, exhibited minimal error rates, whereas temperature output variables displayed marginally greater variability yet remained within acceptable performance thresholds. This research demonstrates that LGBM offers a robust, scalable, and efficient solution for predictive analytics in CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> dehydration systems, thereby facilitating the advancement of data-driven decision-making and operational optimization in industrial environments.

title: Optimization of Resilient Tolerance Allocation Based on Dynamic Process Capability Index
authors: Jingxuan Wang, Jinglu Wei, Qinglin Zheng, Ruochong Zhao, Chao Guo, Wei Dai
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Tolerance allocation is a critical aspect of product design. It connects both design and manufacturing processes and bridge the gap between machine processing Accuracy and assembly reliability. Effective tolerance analysis technology and allocation models play a pivotal role in providing precise data to enhance product design efficiency, reduce costs, and elevate product quality. This study proposed a novel tolerance allocation model that formulates a mathematical framework by considering the structural significance of tolerance nodes, tolerance-cost model, resilience evaluation parameters based on dynamic process capability index, and quality loss cost function. Moreover, it accounts for machining tool degradation disturbances during the manufacturing process to imbue the tolerance allocation scheme with greater system resilience. The proposed model is exemplified through a case study on the assembly size chain of a specific engine, juxtaposed against two conventional tolerance allocation methods, namely the equal tolerance method and equal precision method. The findings reveal that the proposed tolerance allocation scheme in this study minimizes the overall cost effectively.

title: A Novel Method Based on Fused Physical Model and Adaptive Threshold for Landing Gear Buffer Strut Fault Detection and Prediction
authors: Siyu Yang, Xiao Wang, Tian Qiao, Pengchao Wang, Yujie Cheng
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Landing gear reliability is critical to aviation safety and operational efficiency. Traditional methods, such as periodic inspections and fixed-threshold fault detection, cannot perform real-time performance evaluation and early fault detection. In this paper, we propose a landing gear fault detection and fault prediction method based on fused physical model (FPM). By fusing the landing gear fault physical model, adaptive threshold and the data-driven method, we compare the fault physical model with the real operation data to quantify the landing gear operation state and input it into the prediction network as features. The prediction network adopts AE-LSTM (proposed), which can reduce the prediction error and provide more robust fault prediction results than traditional RNN and ARIMA, and enhance the fault prediction and health management capability of aerospace system equipment.

title: Plasma Formation Measurements Within a MITL on the 1 MA Mykonos Accelerator
authors: N. Hines, D. Lamppa, J. Schwarz, M. Gilmore
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Desorbed surface plasmas ranging between <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \mathrm{e} 15-1 \mathrm{e} 17 \text{cm}^{\wedge}-3$</tex> that form within the inner Magnetically Insulated Transmission Line (MITL) of pulsed power accelerators allow machine current to be shunted across the Anode-Cathode (A-K) gap and reduce the load driving efficiency [1]. Recently, for the Sandia National Laboratory (SNL) 1 MA Mykonos accelerator [2], a versatile parallel plate platform has been developed [3] which includes a MITL region having variable electric and magnetic field strengths that are comparable to that of the SNL Z machine's inner MITLs [4]. A collection of Second-Harmonic Orthogonally Polarized Dispersion Interferometer (SHOP-DI), Avalanche PhotoDiode (APD), and Streaked Visible Spectroscopy (SVS) measurements were made on both the Anode and Cathode surface plasmas providing valuable insight to pulsed power desorption physics and current loss mechanisms.

title: Investigating How Text and Motion Style Shape Directness In Embodied Conversational Agents
authors: Michael O'Mahony, Cathy Ennis, Robert Ross
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 18th ACM SIGGRAPH Conference on Motion, Interaction, and Games
abstract: Embodied Conversational Agents (ECAs) are becoming more widely used for various applications, notably in health. Some studies have demonstrated the effectiveness of delivering Motivational Interviews (MIs), a patient-centred behaviour change method, with ECAs. Despite showing promise, the effect of agent communication style on MI effectiveness remains underexplored. Directness has been shown to impact satisfaction and preference of dialogue systems, and effectiveness in some cases. However, outside of verbal style, how to control directness in ECAs to achieve these goals is not well understood. We designed an ECA to convey different levels of directness through language and Non-Verbal behaviours (NVBs), then evaluated the impact of language and NVB on directness with a perception study. The results showed that language influenced perceived directness, and that NVB contributed when aligned with indirect language. These findings suggest ways to shape conversational agents’ communication style to enhance their effectiveness.

title: DP-GS: Depth-prior & Perception-guided Gaussian Splatting for Sparse-view Novel View Synthesis
authors: Bowen Gao, Zhicheng Lu, Mingyi He, Yuchao Dai
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Sparse-view novel view synthesis (NVS) is crucial for practical applications such as AR/VR, robotics, and largescale scene reconstruction, where capturing dense multi-view images is often impractical. 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) offers explicit and efficient scene representations for real-time NVS. However, its performance significantly degrades under sparseview settings, resulting in incomplete geometry and severe texture artifacts. To overcome these limitations, we propose DP-GS (Depth-prior & Perception-guided Gaussian Splatting), a unified framework designed for sparse-view NVS. DP-GS integrates depth regularization derived from monocular depth estimation to improve geometric completeness. Moreover, we introduce a point-level dropout mechanism to suppress unreliable points, and integrate perceptual optimization guided by diffusion model to enhance texture fidelity and structural consistency. Extensive experiments on LLFF and Mip-NeRF360 datasets demonstrate that DP-GS consistently outperforms existing 3DGS methods under sparse view settings.

title: Big Data-Driven Risk Assessment Based on Regression Model in Logistics
authors: Caoyi Wang, Hongzhen Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: We investigated the impact of big data on risk reduction in logistics, leveraging digital technologies and risk management. Utilizing panel data from 118 Chinese A-share listed logistics firms from 2012 to 2023 and conducting a case analysis of Qingdao Port, China, the correlation between big data adoption and enterprise risk levels was analyzed. A regression model was constructed to identify indicators based on annual financial reports. The results demonstrated strong explanatory power of the regression model and validated that big data enhanced the capability of risk prediction, operational transparency, and decision-making. The findings suggest logistics enterprises must adopt data-driven technologies, integrate advanced technologies, and cultivate data literacy to enhance risk resilience.

title: Reinforcement Learning-Optimized Performance Evaluation Framework for Remote Workforce
authors: Elsa Cherian, Arunkumar A, Abdullah Abed Hussein, RouaidaKadhim A. Al-Hussein, U. Sreerekha, N R Gopal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: As the following paper suggests, a Reinforcement Learning-Optimized Performance Evaluation Framework is suggested to facilitate the management of the remote workforce.
