The framework combines Z-Score Normalization to clean the data that includes outliers, Principal Component Analysis to select the most important performance indicators, and Random Forest Classifier to make accurate predictions to divide the levels of employee productivity. Collecting real-time behavioral data using digital tools of collaboration, the system automatically reshapes the task distribution and balancing of workloads with the reinforcement learningagents. The implementation of the framework is a Python script with library support of scikit-learn performing preprocessing and classification, TensorFlow featuring deep reinforcement learning models and OpenAI Gym which operates a mechanism of simulating dynamic environments of decision-making. This is proved experimentally on the proposal system, as it produces higher accuracy rates in prediction, distribution of work, and the support of managers in acting with data-based decisions concerning remote teams. This is a scalable and smart solution to organizations that want to maximize the performance and also continue to be a very productive company in a flexible and distributed working environment.

title: A Review of Digital Twin Framework and Key Technology Applications for Electronic Equipment
authors: Dongqian Shao, Bowen Cui, Shaokang Fan, Yuxiang Lin, Yaohui Guo, Ying Chen
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: With the continuous development of digital twin theory and technology, it has shown wide application value in the field of complex equipment products. Electronic equipment is an important guarantee for the safe operation of aviation, aerospace, and civil equipment, with characteristics such as complex structure, long service life, harsh operating environment, and high requirements for quality and reliability. This article first introduces the concept of digital twin of electronic devices, analyzes the research status of common key technologies of digital twin and its application in electronic devices, dissects the main problems faced, and finally takes airborne electronic devices as the application scenario to provide the implementation framework of digital twin technology for electronic devices. It has reference significance for further improving the digitalization and intelligence level of airborne equipment and achieving high reliability and long life design of products.

title: Internet of Things and Artificial Intelligence-Enabled Framework for Real-Time Monitoring and Alert Systems for Sandstorms and Landslides in Arid Region
authors: Warda Al-Hoqani, Thirupathi Regula, S. Gouri Kiran Kumar, Sunitha Cheriyan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: In the coastal regions of the Middle East countries, there are sudden occurrences of Natural disasters, such as earthquakes, landslides, tsunamis, and cyclones, which result in substantial ecological damage and loss of life. With climate change accelerating, these disasters are increasingly unpredictable, particularly in vulnerable regions such as forests and deserts. Therefore, we developed a model that is scalable in remote regions of Oman and the rest of the Gulf Cooperation Council Regions for enhancing disaster resilience, optimizing resource allocation, and situational awareness of a situation. The model enables a long-term solution to improving disaster management infrastructure in climate-exposed areas since performance metrics such as accuracy, precision, F1-score, and false alarm rate ensure high reliability. The system enables real-time responsiveness through edge data processing, the detection of anomalies, and the prediction of high-risk environmental events. Following initial edge-level analysis, data is transmitted to cloud platforms for further processing. Upon identifying potential threats, the system disseminates geofenced, multilingual alerts to affected individuals and first responders via mobile applications, wearable technologies, and public dashboards. The developed Internet of Things (IoT)-enabled smart system enhances the management of sandstorms and landslides, particularly in vulnerable regions. The system also integrates automated alert mechanisms to deliver timely warnings through mobile devices. It leverages edge computing, IoT sensor networks, geographic information systems (GIS), and GPS, complemented by cloud-based machine learning algorithms such as random forest and gradient boosting for predictive modeling. The system incorporates accelerometers, soil moisture sensors, particulate matter (PM) sensors, and geophones to monitor environmental and geotechnical conditions. This multi-sensor architecture supports situational awareness and facilitates proactive disaster mitigation strategies.

title: Predicting Crop Yield Using XGBoost and Geospatial Data Fusion in Precision Agriculture
authors: K.Kalaiarasi K. Kalaiarasi, Rahul S G, V.Nivedita V. Nivedita, D.Baskaran D. Baskaran, S.Hema S. Hema, N.Abirami N. Abirami
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Precise crop yield forecasting is essential for precision agriculture, maximizing resource utilization, and boosting output. However, the outdated yield forecast techniques are not always applicable or accurate. Traditional models are less expandable and are unable to reflect the intricate non-linear relationships among soil factors, climate, and spatial variability because these frequently rely on incomplete sampling data and simple statistics. In the study, a system that combines meteorological, soil, and satellite imagery with Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) geographical data is proposed. The technique uses high-dimensional, multi-source input to improve prediction robustness and accuracy. The proposed system in the paper performs far better than the existing systems, according to experiments. With a mean absolute value of 500 kg/ha and a root mean square error of 650 kg/ha, the model's R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> is 0.89, and its performance holds steady when used for various crops or geographical areas. A significant advancement above conventional methods of agricultural output prediction, the fusion-driven machine learning (ML) system will enhance farming operations' sustainability, scalability, and decision-making.

title: AI-Driven Fatigue Prediction in Healthcare Professionals Using Wearable Sensor Data and Gradient-Boosted Machine Learning Models
authors: Goutham D, S. Saravanasankar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Healthcare professionals often experience work-induced fatigue due to prolonged shifts and high-pressure environments, which may compromise their well-being and patient care quality. This research presents a methodology for forecasting weariness on the job consuming physiological data gathered on or after wearable sensors and based on machine learning. Features were identified and processed to detect patterns indicative of stress and tiredness using the WESAD dataset, which incorporates multimodal biosignals such as electromagnetic activity (EMA), core body temperature (CBT), heart rate variability (HRV), and accelerometer data. Using annotated labels aligned with affective states, a Gradient Boosting framework including XGBoost, LightGBM, and CatBoost was evaluated to classify fatigue levels. To make the system more resilient and less noisy, a lot of feature engineering and signal preprocessing were used. The LightGBM classifier has the best AUC, precision, F1score, accuracy, and recall among the models that were assessed. These results show that it is possible to anticipate fatigue states in real time with non-invasive wearables and little extra computing power. The suggested system is the first step toward making adaptive workload and shift management systems operate in hospitals. Future enhancements will investigate dynamic scheduling and ergonomic optimization through real-time tiredness feedback. To make sure that AI is used responsibly in healthcare settings, ethical issues like data protection and model interpretability are talked about. This work serves as a foundation for AI-enhanced occupational health monitoring, facilitating proactive fatigue reduction techniques for healthcare providers.

title: Visualizing Data Intelligently: Integrating Natural Language for Deeper Insights
authors: Daniela Petrea, Cosmin Irimia, Adrian Iftene
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: Nowadays, nearly every field, from finance to scientific research, is generating massive amounts of data that can take many forms: tables showing financial results, measurements from lab experiments, or even logs tracking people's daily activities. Most of the time, data is stored in formats like CSV or JSON. Understanding data is often much harder than getting it. The tools designed to help with data analysis and visualization are usually built for experts. They often have complicated interfaces or require knowledge of technical languages, such as SQL. Moreover, being commercial applications, they entail licensing costs that can be high, especially for public institutions or educational projects. As a result, a lot of people who need to work with data can't easily access or use it. This paper introduces a tool that simplifies dealing with data, built especially for those without programming knowledge. All is designed to be in a single space: uploading a dataset, creating charts and asking questions about data in natural language to better understand what it shows. Moreover, the app runs on the user's own computer and in this way the data stays private and even internet connection is not required.

title: TRH-Scheduler: Topology-Aware Revenue-Driven Hierarchical Scheduler for Multi-Cluster SFC Orchestration
authors: Ji Li, Guiyan Liu, Songtao Guo, Longzhi Dai, Quanjun Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: With the advent of 6G, extreme services such as autonomous vehicles demand efficient network management to meet stringent quality of service requirements. Network function virtualization decouples services from hardware via service function chains (SFCs), which is composed of multiple virtual network functions. Ensuring reliable SFC scheduling while efficiently using resources remains a challenge in dynamic and resource-constrained multi-cluster networks. However, most existing methods neglect admission co-optimization during SFC resources allocation, compromising long-term system stability. In this paper, we propose TRH-Scheduler, a topology-aware revenue-driven hierarchical scheduler for multi-cluster SFC orchestration. Specifically, the TRH-Scheduler decouples spatiotemporal decision via a two-stage mechanism and employs hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) to successively complete the two stages, a queue agent for admission control, and a deployment agent for resource allocation. Furthermore, graph neural networks (GNNs) are leveraged to encode topological information, optimizing the awareness of HRL agents. Through extensive evaluation, the results demonstrate more than 4.36% improvement in average revenue and 11.84% improvement in acceptance rate over baseline methods.

title: iTRAP: Mitigating Thermal Throttling Penalties via Strategic GPU Cluster Scheduling
authors: Xuefeng Huang, Junyan Chen, Baokang Zhao, Wei Xiao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: The exponential growth of large-scale AI work-loads has made shared GPU clusters a cornerstone of modern computing infrastructure, where optimal GPU placement is critical to maximizing task execution efficiency. However, existing scheduling strategies often prioritize assigning tasks to the most powerful GPUs to minimize latency, frequently causing overheating, thermal throttling, and consequent performance degradation. To address this critical issue, we propose iTrap, a novel scheduler that proactively mitigates thermal throttling by integrating thermal awareness into GPU cluster management. iTrap identifies heat-intensive tasks and strategically places them on accelerator groups with superior thermal dissipation capabilities. It leverages task-specific temperature predictions to minimize throttling risks while balancing accelerator hardware performance and cross-GPU communication overhead, optimizing for both high performance and low inter-device communication costs. Evaluations on large-scale production traces from Microsoft demonstrate that iTrap outperforms PAL, the state-of-the-art scheduler, by reducing average task completion time by 23.6% and P99 completion time by 26.0%. The gains from iTrap further highlight the importance of thermal-aware scheduling in unlocking the full potential of GPU clusters for AI work-loads.

title: GNN-Aided Efficient Multipath Routing in Satellite Constellation Networks
authors: Gwangun Yu, Minjung Kwak, Siwoong Park, Yonggang Kim
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: This paper proposes a graph neural network (GNN) based framework to predict dynamic Inter Satellite Link (ISL) topology under Free Space Optical Communication (FSOC) constraints. The GNN model captures both local connectivity and global structural patterns in the satellite graph. The output of the GNN is used to construct a predicted adjacency matrix, over which routing paths are computed using Yen's k-shortest path algorithm.

title: CGNOS: A Deep Learning enabled Chronic Kidney Disease Detection based on Convolutional Gene Network Optimization Strategy
authors: Gurram Kalyani, Choppara Priyanka, Ahmad Abdelhafiz Ali Samhan, Prasad D, M Harshini, R. Kanchana
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) is a progressive and potentially fatal condition that necessitates early and accurate diagnosis to prevent end-stage renal failure. In this study, we propose CGNOS (Convolutional Gene Network Optimization Strategy), a novel deep learning-based framework for the automated detection of CKD. The model integrates structured clinical parameters with genomic biomarkers, forming a multi-dimensional input tensor modeled as a gene-feature interaction network. A convolutional neural network (CNN) combined with attention mechanisms is used to work with this hybrid structure to reveal prevailing patterns and correlations in patient data. An optimization module implemented using Genetic Algorithms (GNOS) is also added in order to dynamically choose the subset of informative features, maximizing the classification accuracy and computational speed. The CGNOS model is tested on CKD data set available at Kaggle, and compared with classical machine learning approaches including SVM, Random Forest, XGBoost, and simple CNNs. The peak accuracy of the proposed model reached 98.6% compared to the baseline models such as CNN (94.2%), Random Forest (93.1%), and SVM (91.5%). Further performance indicators that show the stability of CGNOS are the precision (98.1%), recall (99.0%), and F1-score (98.5%). Moreover, feature set size was also considerably minimized to 14 by the aid of the feature subset optimization without sacrificing the diagnostic performance that was originally 25. Such findings show that CGNOS can not only facilitate more accurate diagnoses but it can demonstrate enhanced interpretability and scalability toward real-world adoption in clinical practice. The combination of gene expression profiling and clinical characteristics provides a instrument in early screening of CKD and thus more direct and individual treatment techniques.

title: RL-Based Adaptive Scheduling for Full-Duplex Multi-Hop FSOC in Smart Semiconductor Manufacturing
authors: Siwoong Park, Ji-Soo Shin, Chan-Il Yeo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: We present a novel reinforcement learning (RL)-driven adaptive scheduling framework for full-duplex multi-hop free-space optical communication (FSOC) networks tailored to the operational complexities of smart semiconductor manufacturing. By directly integrating overhead hoist transport (OHT) mobility, burst traffic, and dynamic link constraints into a unified, parameterized model, our approach enables proactive, context-aware network optimization beyond conventional rule-based schemes. While large-scale simulations and experimental validation are left as future work, the proposed framework lays the groundwork for robust, large-capacity wireless connectivity under real-world industrial constraints, offering a strategic blueprint for practical deployment and further research. This work opens new directions for intelligent optical networking in advanced manufacturing, bridging the gap between theoretical design and practical implementation.

title: Comparative Analysis of Image Segmentation Methods for Porosity Evaluation of Wound Dressings Using Python and ImageJ
authors: Thaffira Auli Putri Prasetio, Laily Ade Oktaviana, Fathur Rahman, Rezicha Maulana Azazi, Dita Puspitasari
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Instrumentation, Control, and Automation (ICA)
abstract: Accurate porosity evaluation of wound dressings is essential for assessing their effectiveness in fluid absorption and tissue healing. This study presents a comparative analysis between three methods: manual analysis using ImageJ, instrumentation-based measurement via Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), and automatic segmentation with a Python implemented Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). Results show that CNN-based segmentation closely approximates porosity values obtained from ImageJ 18.6% and SEM 19.16%, demonstrating high reliability with a CNN result of 17.73%. While ImageJ and CNN use the same input derived from images generated by the SEM machine, ImageJ relies on subjective manual interpretation, whereas CNN provides a fully automated analysis pipeline. The findings highlight CNN’s capacity to process high-resolution SEM images efficiently while minimizing human bias. Notably, this study provides one of the first direct comparisons between CNN, ImageJ, and SEM for wound dressing evaluation, underscoring the potential of deep learning in biomedical material analysis. CNN-based approaches are promising for future wound dressing assessments, especially in resource-limited or high-throughput environments.

title: Re-Design of the Inductively Driven Transmission Line (IDTL) Current Diagnostic for the Z Pulsed Power Facility
authors: Stacie Hernandez, Katherine Chandler, Brian T. Hutsel, Carlos Aragon, Josh Leckbee, Matthew R. Gomez, Christopher A. Jennings, Edl Schamiloglu
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The inductively driven transmission line (IDTL) is a current monitor commonly fielded on the Z Pulsed Power Facility in recent years [1]. The IDTL passively couples to the magnetic field in the final power feed on the Z machine, redirecting a small amount of Z's magnetic energy along a secondary path to ground. A pair of oppositely oriented B-dot monitors measure the current in the secondary circuit enabling common mode noise cancellation. Experimental data show the IDTLs measure cleaner signals and are more robust than the conventional B-dot, which was previously used to measure the current in the final power feed on the Z Pulsed Power Facility. Recent simulations (modeled in COMSOL Multiphysics) and calibration measurements have identified a discrepancy in sensitivity of the two IDTL B-dot monitors of up to a factor of two [2]. This difference in sensitivity could be due to a difference in the environment that each Bdot loop in the monitor is sensing. As common mode rejection assumes that each B-dot loop in the monitor have the same input signal, rejecting a signal that is not common to both would be difficult to interpret. Moreover, the difference in B-dot loop measurement raises an uncertainty of which B-dot loop signal is correct, which results in low confidence in being able to measure the main current pulse. A re-design and its performance on the Z Pulsed Power Facility will be presented.

title: On the scattering of light by a spheroidal particle with a spherical core
authors: Victor G. Farafonov, Daria G. Turichina, Vladimir B. Il’in, Sergei I. Laznevoi
publish: 2025 Days on Diffraction (DD)
abstract: We solve the light scattering problem for a spheroidal particle with a spherical core by deriving the corresponding limit from the general solution for two-layer spheroids with non-confocal boundaries. No inherent peculiarities are found in analytical formulation, though numerical inaccuracies arise for large spheroidal particles when the core is nearly spherical. These errors are attributed to computational limitations rather than theoretical shortcomings.

title: An Accessible Path Search Method Based on Improved Fabrik for Maintenance Scenarios
authors: Zicheng Song, Dong Zhou, Yuchen Bai, Qingtian Yang, Qidi Zhou, Ziyue Guo
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Recently, maintainability is elevated to a critical status in design, driven by the complexity of product layouts. How to develop a rapid automated method for determining accessible paths in complex maintenance scenarios has become a current research focus. To solve the problem, this study proposes a path search method based on the improved forward and backward inverse kinematics (FABRIK) algorithm. By analyzing the limitations of the traditional FABRIK algorithm in terms of convergence and obstacle avoidance, an optimization mechanism incorporating a random rotation strategy is designed to effectively solve the problems of local optima and obstacle avoidance. At the same time, a 7 degree of freedom human arm kinematic model was constructed to constrain joint range of motion with ergonomic. The effectiveness of the algorithm was validated in a virtual environment, and the results showed that the method can plan accessible paths that conform to human motion characteristics in a 3D scene with obstacles. This method can provide effective solutions for the maintenance design of complex industrial equipment.

title: Analysis of the Steering Motor Current Characteristics in Micro-Electric Vehicles under Different Road Conditions
authors: Diky Zakaria, Diana Eka Putri, Taufik Ibnu Salim, Bambang Wahono
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Instrumentation, Control, and Automation (ICA)
abstract: Autonomous electric vehicles, such as Micro Electric Vehicles (MEVi), are expected to reduce dependence on fossil fuels and lower greenhouse gas emissions. However, the performance of the steering motor system, which is affected by external factors such as road surface type and load distribution, still requires further study. For this reason, this study collected data on the current of steering motor using an ACS758 sensor on two types of road surfaces (epoxy and concrete) and two load conditions (all wheels touching the surface and rear tire lifted). The purpose of this study is to analyze the effect of road surface conditions and load distribution on the characteristics of the electric current generated by the steering motor in MEVi. The results show that smoother road surfaces (epoxy) produce a more stable current distribution, while rougher surfaces (concrete) cause a wider current distribution. Machine learning algorithms, such as Decision Tree, Random Forest, Support Vector Machine (SVM), and K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), were used to classify the road surface type and steering position. SVM provided the best accuracy in road type classification with 79% accuracy. This study suggests adding other variables, such as voltage and power, to improve classification accuracy and maximize the performance of prediction models in autonomous electric vehicle steering systems.

title: DDC: Efficient Dynamic-Dictionary-Based Compression on Floating Time Series Data
authors: Keyue Yang, Dongping Wang, Shijie Li, Wenbin Zhai, Wenjing Wang, Ziyi Zheng, Jinan Wang, Liang Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Growing demand for large-scale time-series data storage has rendered floating-point time-series compression a key technology for better storage efficiency and performance. General-purpose compression rely on exact matching to build dictionaries, making them effective for repetitive data but unsuitable for time-series data with small fluctuations and gradual changes. While time-series-specialized compression leverage correlations between adjacent data points, they ignore long-term similarities and periodic patterns. To address these limitations, we propose an efficient Dynamic-Dictionary-Based Compression (DDC) algorithm for floating-point time-series data. DDC uses three matching strategies to capture both local patterns and global trends. It dynamically updates the dictionary and adapts its compression strategy during processing. Moreover, DDC reduces precision redundancy by adjusting mantissa bit lengths and separating floating-point components. We evaluate DDC against state-of-theart time-series-specific (Gorilla, Chimp, AFC, TSXor, FPC) and general-purpose (LZ4, LZW, Snappy) compression algorithms. Experimental results demonstrate that DDC achieves superior compression ratios and faster processing speeds, highlighting its effectiveness and practicality.

title: Intelligent Analysis System for University Students' Learning Status Monitoring Based on Data Mining
authors: Yunke Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: An intelligent analysis system of university students' learning status was constructed using data mining methods to promote personalized education. Integrating user profiling, data mining, deep neural network (DNN), and k-means algorithm, the system analyzes learning behaviors, academic performance, and engagement of students. It provides personalized learning resource recommendations based on the data, using machine learning techniques based on the constructed knowledge graph. Features were extracted to provide the recommendations through a storage mechanism and diagnosis learning. The developed system enhances student performance, resource optimization, and classroom management, which enables personalized education, data-driven practices, and improvements in pedagogy and learning outcomes.

title: Roller Heat Treatment Workshop Scheduling Using Reinforcement Learning
authors: Siyu Tong, Deng Guo, Siqi Qiu
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: The roller heat treatment process involves sending rollers into different-sized heating furnaces, with energy consumption varying by furnace size. Therefore, utilizing the furnaces by heating multiple rollers simultaneously in the same furnace can effectively reduce furnace usage frequency and lower energy consumption. Current research mainly focuses on batch scheduling rather than optimizing roller distribution. Moreover, existing studies predominantly use heuristic algorithms like Genetic Algorithms (GA) and Simulated Annealing (SA), which are unable to make sequential decisions. Field investigations indicate that most enterprises rely on laborintensive, inefficient manual scheduling for heat treatment. To address these challenges, this study proposes a novel approach based on Reinforcement Learning (RL) for roller heat treatment workshop scheduling. The optimization objective of the distribution scheduling is to minimize the total cost of the workshop while taking into account various loading strategies, including furnace width, stacking limits, and heating time. The total cost is the sum of inventory cost, energy consumption cost, and delay cost. This study constructs a mathematical model that frames the heat treatment process as a Markov Decision Process (MDP) and introduces the Q-learning algorithm to dynamically determine the optimal scheduling strategy for the workshop that meets the heat treatment constraints. Research shows our method efficiently optimizes roller heat treatment scheduling, enhancing the efficiency of production scheduling and reducing energy consumption.

title: Centralized Protection and Control (CPC): Smart Solutions for Digital Protection System
authors: Ir. Azwanizam B A Rahman, Ir. A Karim B A Rahman A, Ir. Ts. Fitriah Bt Shafe’i, Faizah Bt Othman, Ts. W Azura Bt Mohd Azhar, M Zulhilmie B Mat Kana
publish: 2025 IEEE Industrial Electronics and Applications Conference (IEACon)
abstract: As power electronics systems evolve in complexity and scale, there is a growing demand for intelligent protection architectures that align with the principles of digitalization and advanced control. Centralized Protection and Control (CPC) systems emerge as a transformative approach, replacing conventional relay-based schemes with software-defined, centralized platforms. This paper examines the role of CPC in modern power electronic environments, focusing on its integration with digital substation architectures and smart grid technologies and the proven case of its implementation in industry. Key benefits of CPC include reduced hardware footprint, enhanced system visibility, cyber-resilient architecture, and scalable automation. Challenges such as IEC 61850 interoperability, online calibration, and data-driven validation also addressed. The findings support CPC as a critical enabler for the next generation of digitalized power electronics systems, advancing both reliability and operational efficiency in future-ready substations. The paper written based on IEEE Paper on CPC and testing conducted on CPC units for its performance capability demonstrates CPC’s potential to replace existing relay technologies, paving the way for a more resilient and adaptive design towards industry shaping.

title: Attention-Based Adaptive Structured Patchout Spectrogram Transformer for Music Classification
authors: Yuan Liu, Lingqing Liu, Yichen Yang, Shoji Makino
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Music classification is a subfield of audio classification, which aims to understand and differentiate various types of music. Patchout faSt Spectrogram Transformer (PaSST) is an efficient transformer model for audio classification. Its core innovation is Patchout, a token-dropping mechanism. Patchout reduces computational demands and improves model generalization by shortening the input sequence. However, its random patch selection strategy may lead to the loss of crucial information. This loss hinders full feature learning, especially for structurally rich music. Therefore, we proposed a novel Attention-based Adaptive Structured Patchout (AASPatchout). It deterministically preserves the most informative patches by using the transformer's internal attention scores. Our AASPatchout requires no additional modules, instead directly utilizing the model's existing attention mechanism. We evaluated AASPatchout for two downstream tasks in music classification: polyphonic instrument recognition and music genre classification. The experimental results demonstrated that our proposed method outperformed the conventional random Patchout baseline.

title: Resonance effects at mode repulsion and zero group velocity frequencies as diagnostic signs in ultrasonic inspection of adhesive bonds in layered composites
authors: Evgeny V. Glushkov, Natalia V. Glushkova, Artem A. Eremin, Victoria A. Polezhaeva, Alexander A. Tatarkin
publish: 2025 Days on Diffraction (DD)
abstract: In this work, we analyze the possibilities of ultrasonic resonance-based express diagnostics of adhesive joints in layered materials. It is shown that degradation of bonding interface properties manifests itself as shifts of resonance peaks in the frequency response. Such shifts are predicted using a semi-analytical model for forced guided wave excitation and propagation. Numerical analysis confirms that the resonance peaks occur at the frequencies associated with mode repulsion and zero group velocity effects. Experimental measurements demonstrate good detectability of such resonance peaks.

title: Explainable Supervised Learning Based Turnover Prediction Framework for HR Retention Systems
authors: Sheena Noorajahan, Ravindra R Kaikini
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Turnover of employees is a major problem of organizations in terms of productivity, morale, and cost of operations. The proposed research briefly presents an Explainable Supervised Learning-Based Turnover Prediction Framework to HR Retention Systems in order to predict employee turnover by maintaining transparency in the model. It uses XGBoost, one of the most robust gradient boosting algorithms to classify and it incorporates SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) to explain the effect of each feature. The pipeline was constructed on Python by using Jupyter Notebook and scikit-learn to evaluate the model and imbalanced-learn to overcome the class imbalance by using the SMOTE-Tomek methods. Through experimental results, it is illustrated that the offered model performs better than conventional classifiers in terms of accuracy, precision, and recall. On top of that, the explainability level will also provide vital turnover causal factors, including overtime, job satisfaction, and tenure so that the HR could develop wise proactive decisions concerning retention. The framework provides an interpretable, scalable and ethically balanced service to organizations that would like to lower attrition levels and improve employee engagement.

title: Mode transformation near degeneracy points of the crossing type for the 2D Dirac equation
authors: Maria V. Perel
publish: 2025 Days on Diffraction (DD)
abstract: The 2D stationary Dirac equation with coefficients depending on one spatial coordinate x is studied in the semiclassical approximation. Two asymptotic solutions corresponding to particles moving in opposite directions are constructed. The solutions interact, i.e., scattering of the particles occurs if their momenta at some point x<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">*</inf> vanish. There are two possibilities, either the corresponding eigenfunctions degenerate or are linearly independent. Special functions arising in expansions near x<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">*</inf>, as well as the reflection and transmission coefficients, are presented.

title: Dimension 414 and Minimal Embedding Dimensions for Phonetic Feature Encoding in WavLM
authors: Narthana Sivalingam, Uthayasanker Thayasivam
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Self-supervised speech models like WavLM have advanced speech processing tasks, but the role of individual embedding dimensions from each transformer layer remains unclear. This work investigates how phonetic features, voicing, fricative, and nasality are encoded withinWavLM representations across layers. By combining Integrated Gradients with a hybrid elbow-point method, we identify sparse subsets of embedding dimensions that are sufficient to retain classification performance. Interestingly, one dimension Dimension 414 consistently emerges as the most influential across layers and features, suggesting that WavLM concentrates phonetic information into compact and functionally distinct dimensions. Supporting correlation analysis with handcrafted acoustic descriptors reveals that this dominant dimension aligns with interpretable speech properties. Our findings demonstrate that WavLM embeddings encode phonetic features in a sparse, structured, and explainable manner, offering new pathways for transparent and efficient speech model analysis.

title: 3D Data Optimization for Real-Time Applications Using glTF and Texture Compression
authors: Sungho Cho, Seunghyun Yoo, Jihyeon Lee, Yunhui Lee
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: This study presents a lightweight 3D model conversion methodology by transforming CityGML 3.0 datasets into glTF format. The proposed pipeline enables a 70 - 80% reduction in file size while preserving detailed architectural information. To address the network transmission bottlenecks and rendering load caused by high-resolution textures, we adopt advanced texture compression algorithms such as Adaptive Scalable Texture Compression(ASTC), DirectX Texture Compression(DXT), and PowerVR Texture Compression(PVRTC), based on usage environments. Among them, ASTC is particularly recommended due to its flexibility in block size and high visual fidelity under low bitrates. Furthermore, we integrate Draco for geometry compression to minimize the size of 3D mesh data. Through the combined use of ASTC and Draco, this approach achieves optimal performance in mobile, AR/VR, and BIM visualization environments. Our method contributes to improving real-time rendering performance while ensuring visual integrity and efficient data delivery. However, the pipeline may require additional configuration to support dynamic streaming or advanced semantic features beyond Level of Detail3(LOD3).

title: Multi-Dimensional Digital Twin Models with Dynamic Updating Scheme for Enhanced Wind Turbine O&M Decision-Making
authors: Ying Hu, Lin Ma, Yingjie Deng, Naichao Wang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Wind energy, as a critical renewable energy source in the global energy transition, requires efficient operation, reliability, and maintenance (O&M). While digital twin technology enables intelligent O&M of wind turbines by creating virtual replicas of physical systems, existing models predominantly remain static or rely on periodic updates, lacking real-time feedback capabilities regarding equipment performance degradation and maintenance-induced perturbations, thus limiting decision-making accuracy. To address this limitation, this paper proposes a digital twindriven O&M optimization method. Multi-dimensional digital twin models including a physics-based model, a data-driven model, and an O&M knowledge model are constructed. Considering the impacts of equipment degradation and maintenance activities on the physical entity, a dynamic model update scheme is proposed to ensure the consistency between the digital twin models and the state of the physical system. A case study on a 5 MW benchmark wind turbine demonstrates the effectiveness of the approach in enhancing the intelligence of wind turbine O&M decision-making, thereby supporting the practical application of digital twin technology in the wind power sector.

title: Artificial Intelligence and the Hay Method: A Study of Candidate Evaluation in Moroccan Companies
authors: Asmaa Benhmama, Brahim Sabiri
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: This study explores the role of Artificial Intelligence in enhancing the performance of recruiters when evaluating candidates using the Hay method in Moroccan Companies. An within-subject approach was used to compare recruiters' perceptions before and after the integration of Artificial intelligence. Data from 31 companies, analyzed through the Mann-Whitney U test, revealed significant differences across several dimensions, indicating that Artificial Intelligence improves the accuracy of technical assessments. However, no significant differences were found in dimensions related to interpersonal skills. These results underscore the complementary role of Artificial Intelligence in analytical areas while highlighting the continued importance of human judgment in relational and interpersonal domains.

title: A Fuzzy based Logical Clustering Network Formation to Enhance Overall Lifetime of the Wireless Sensor Network
authors: Ananda Babu Devarapalli, Khaled Alqawasmi, J Kaliappan, M. Gopila, D Rajeshwari, R.Suganthi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) are increasingly deployed in diverse environments for real-time monitoring, yet their performance is critically constrained by node energy depletion and inefficient clustering. We present a new Fuzzy-Based Logical Clustering Network Formation protocol that optimizes total WSN lifetime to fuzzy inference used to intelligently select Cluster Head (CH). The model has considered three crucial parameters of Residual Energy, Node Degree and Distance to Base Station (DBS) to calculate Cluster Head Suitability Score (CHSS) through Mamdani fuzzy logic. Segmentation based on logical zones guarantees a spatial fairness in CH distribution, and supports intra-cluster communication with: clock cycle based TDMA; aggregation of data transmitted. Numerical simulation proves that network life, energy consumption, and data integrity have been improved significantly. The proposed model significantly beats the typical communications such as LEACH, HEED, and EECDA in terms of the main metrics. The model achieves an accuracy of 94.7% in CH selection—validated against optimal energy conditions—and extends the first node death (FND) to 1290 rounds and last node death (LND) to 2240 rounds, compared to 780 and 1650 rounds in LEACH, respectively. The Packet Delivery Ratio (PDR) stays substantially about 90% to 1200 rounds and even higher than the state-of-art criteria. These performances validate the usefulness of fuzzy-based logical clustering approach to the extension of WSN life time, balanced consumption, and reliable data transmission. Our proposed solution can be promising in environmental surveillance, intelligent crop management, as well as surveillance in the battlefield due to their large-scale and energy-limited nature.

title: Reliability Evaluation Based ENEM Considering Cascading Failure and Adaptive Recovery for Intelligent Systems
authors: Jiao Li, Wensheng Peng, Zhaoyang Zeng, Yu Hao, Zekun Song, Ming Xu
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into critical aviation safety domains such as autonomous obstacle avoidance and landing, which brings new reliability challenges. Traditional methods struggle to effectively address deep learning risks, dynamic recovery strategies, and the spatiotemporal evolution of multi-source uncertainties. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes a CRQ (cascading failureautonomous recovery-risk quantification) methodology based on an Extended Network Evolution Model (ENEM). First, the cascading failure mechanisms and recovery strategies (e.g., parameter weight adjustment, redundancy switching) in typical CNN systems such as SAFETERM are analyzed, serving as the foundation for establishing a real-time game-theoretic model characterizing fault propagation and dynamic recovery. Subsequently, we evaluate system reliability through performance margin assessment under multi-source uncertainties, specifically addressing multi-factor coupled effects in cross-level fault propagation chains. Finally, rigorous validation of the proposed method's effectiveness and practicality is performed via an aviation accident investigation where improper sensor data fusion weighting was identified as the root cause. This methodology enables real-time, precise monitoring of intelligent systems' health status, thereby significantly enhancing aviation safety.

title: Filament-Triggered Gas-Filled Spark Gap Switch with In-Situ Plasma Diagnostics
authors: A. Mohanta, A. R. Baba, K. K. Kabotu, S. AlMarzooqi, S. AlMazrouei, G. Matras, G. N. Appiah, U. Hashmi, F. Vega
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Spark gap discharges have gained growing interest due to their utility in diverse high-voltage applications such as surge protection, power switching, and high-energy laser triggering. A major limitation of gas-filled spark gap switches is the inherent timing jitter largely due to the stochastic nature of discharge initiation, which affects their precision and repeatability. Laser triggering, by inducing pre-ionization in the gap through a focused laser pulse, is a promising approach to mitigate this issue. The laser-generated seed electrons facilitate avalanche and streamer formation, promoting faster breakdown and arc formation. Nevertheless, the inherent randomness in ionization dynamics remains a key factor in timing jitter, underscoring the need for deeper investigation.

title: Fusing Blocked Deep Features of Pre-Trained Models for Short-Duration Speaker Verification
authors: Zhijun Zhang, Wu Guo, Jie Zhang, Yu Guan
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: In this paper, we propose method to jointly use multi-layer features from pre-trained model (PTM) and handcrafted features for short-duration speaker verification. We evenly divide the Transformer layers of PTM into shallow and deep parts, each of which are processed separately. For the shallow part, we partition feature-map of each layer into several subblocks along channel dimension and calibrate them via learnable weights. The weighted features from both shallow and deep parts and the hand-crafted features are then fused using attentionbased fusion modules. Experimental results on the VoxCeleb datasets show the promising performance of the proposed method with an EER of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 9 8 4 \%}$</tex> given 3s-duration trails on VoxCeleb-O.

title: A Content Based E-Commerce Dataset Recommendation System Using BERT and Named Entity Recognition
authors: Ayomide E. Oduba, C.I. Ezeife, Mahreen Nasir
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Existing dataset recommendation (rec) systems including those named as ZhangRec23, WangRec22, and GDS19, face certain limitations, such as lack of focus on e-commerce datasets, inability to address complex queries, and reliance on inconsistent metadata (e.g., data structure of domain of products being recommended). This leads to incomplete or mismatched results returned by the system for complex query searches, such as "impact of seasonal sales on customer reviews for electronics". These traditional dataset rec systems rely on simple keyword matching, failing to interpret context-sensitive queries that researchers often need, and are unable to capture the dynamic trends in the e-commerce domain. This highlights the need for an advanced dataset rec system that improves metadata quality and integrates semantic understanding to recommend precise and relevant e-commerce datasets to researchers. This paper proposes an E-commerce Datasets Mining Rec System (EDMRec), an adaptation of ZhangRec23 approach. EDMRec combines content-based filtering, advanced metadata processing, and machine learning approach in a three-layered structure involving (i) Data Collection, (ii)Data Processing, and (iii) Query Processing. It utilizes Named Entity Recognition (NER) to complete metadata and uses TF-IDF with Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT) embeddings to capture both keyword relevance and semantic context, enhancing recommendation precision for complex queries. Experimental results show that EDMRec improves precision, recall, and F1 score by 15% over existing systems, consistently providing contextually accurate recommendations across 4,373 metadata entries from sources such as Kaggle and Google Dataset Search, making it well-suited for supporting data-driven insights in e-commerce.

title: Reasoning Visualization for Critical Care EEG Classification with Prototypical Part Networks
authors: Takuma Bingo, Hajime Yano, Taichiro Ashizaki, Kazuma Koda, Masaya Togo, Riki Matsumoto, Tetsuya Takiguchi
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Automatic interpretation of electroencephalograms (EEGs) in critical care settings requires not only accurate classification but also clear explanations for model decisions. Prototypical part networks (ProtoPNets) offer inherent interpretability by learning typical local patterns (prototypes) for each class and visualizing the basis of their decisions. In this study, we adapt ProtoPNets for critical care EEG analysis by computing similarity between class-specific prototypes and EEG segments across all time windows and electrodes. Experimental results demonstrate that our method improves classification performance, particularly for periodic discharges (PD) and rhythmic delta activity (RDA), which exhibit temporally periodic and spatially widespread patterns. The proposed model achieved the highest recall for the RDA class (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6 1. 1} \%$</tex>) and outperformed baselines in accuracy (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{+ 3. 6} \%$</tex>) and macro recall (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$+5.1 \%$</tex>) over EEGNet + BiGRU. Furthermore, the model provides visually interpretable evidence that aligns with clinically typical waveforms, indicating its potential for decision support in critical care environments.

title: A State-Dependent Model for Identification of Time-Varying Directed Graphs
authors: Yuzhe Li, Hangjing Zhang, H. Vicky Zhao
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Identifying dynamic directed graphs from graph signals has many applications in neuroscience and sociology. To identify graphs with time-varying weights, we propose a novel state-dependent model (SDM), integrating the linear time-varying sparse vector autoregressive model (SVAR) and nonlinear SVAR model. SDM models the time-varying property through feedback mechanisms that incorporate past graph signals, and extends the time-varying smoothness regularizer for model identification. We use the kernel method based on random Fourier features to formulate a convex optimization problem for identification, and propose an effective ADMM-based algorithm. Numerical results on synthetic datasets show that the proposed algorithm outperforms existing SVAR-based models, and demonstrate the importance of time-varying smoothness regularizer. Furthermore, experiments on US Senator ideology data showcase the model's interpretability, revealing state associations consistent with known political alignments.

title: Modified Blade Element Momentum Model Incorporating Wind Shear and Tower Shadow Effects
authors: Yueting Lin, Jianyong Chen, Ruifeng Zhao, Jinghui Song, Bangan Hu, Shiming Li, Chu Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: Accurate prediction of turbine power and blade loads under realistic inflow conditions is essential for assessing power generation capacity and quality. This study proposes a modified blade element–momentum (BEM) model that incorporates wind shear and tower-shadow models into the classical BEM framework. Using theoretical analysis supported by case studies, the modified model quantifies how wind shear and tower shadow cause time-varying fluctuations in axial force and power output at blade and rotor scales. Results indicate that wind shear and tower shadow reduce the axial load and power output of individual blades when they rotate toward the tower, reaching minimum values at the 180° azimuth position. For the rotor as a whole, three local minima in axial force and power output are observed during one revolution, occurring at azimuth angles of 60°, 180°, and 300°. The results highlight tower shadow as the dominant factor influencing these periodic fluctuations

title: Pure Chain-Integrated AI Framework for Health Risk Monitoring of Military Personnel
authors: Subroto Kumar Ghosh, Mohtasin Golam, Adnan Md Tayeb, Sium Bin Noor, Muhammad Sannan Khaliq, Jae-Min Lee, Dong-Seong Kim
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: Military personnel must remain in strong physical and mental health to carry out their duties. However, many chronic diseases like diabetes can develop silently over time. If detected early, the risk can often be managed with changes in routine, diet, or medication. Yet early detection relies on access to health data, and for military applications, that data is often sensitive and highly confidential. Most AI systems that predict health risks do not include strong privacy safeguards or consent control. This paper presents a secure health monitoring system designed specifically for military environments. The system combines AI with blockchain to ensure privacy, transparency, and individual control. It uses Pure Chain to manage access permissions through smart contracts. Military personnel must explicitly grant consent before their data is used for analysis. The health data, stored securely through IPFS, is only shared with the AI model after consent is confirmed. The AI model predicts health risks. Once a prediction is made, the result is sent securely to the respective personnel through a Flask-based backend. This way, the system maintains privacy while enabling timely health warnings. The model achieved 90.13% accuracy in cross-validation, 82.89% test accuracy, and an AUC of 0.90, showing strong potential for real-world deployment.

title: Solving the Networked Task Allocations Problem via Group Role Assignment in Industry Chains
authors: Kangjin Wang, Qilin Huang, Dongning Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: As industrial upgrading progresses, industrial chains have evolved from simple linear structures into intricate networks, making task assignment increasingly challenging. Concurrently, the intricate task architectures have heightened the complexity of personnel management, indirectly driving up corporate costs. In this context, identifying effective approaches to task assignment and grouping has emerged as a critical and daunting issue within such intricate task environments. The absence of adequate quantitative tools has impeded progress in computationally investigating the Networked Task Allocations Problem (NTAP) for industry chains, even though addressing it is critically needed. Notably, the Environment-Classes, Agents, Roles, Groups, and Objects (E-CARGO) model—a robust framework proven effective through maturity—has consistently shown efficacy in research concerning such social challenges. This article formalizes and explores the NTAP by leveraging the E-CARGO model and its sub-model Group Role Assignment (GRA). The weighted GRA prioritizes task allocation based on their priority level within the industrial network. To address task grouping challenges, we employ K-Means clustering to categorize tasks into clusters exhibiting typical topological characteristics. This approach not only boosts corporate cost efficiency and operational effectiveness but also strategically strengthens bottleneck tasks within the industrial chain, thus reducing the risk of single-point failures.

title: Assessing System Reliability Using Temporal Multilayer Complex Networks
authors: Yichen Huang, Xin Wang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: In today's business environment, accurately forecasting warranty reserves and managing spare parts inventory is essential. Effective failure modeling underpins warranty forecasting, yet dynamic modeling of complex products presents challenges due to interdependencies in component failures. This research explores system-level failure dynamics using a multilayer network approach. Traditional models often simplify systems into series or parallel configurations, neglecting cascading failures and seepage effects. Additionally, many studies rely on singlelayer networks, which inadequately capture short-term interdependencies in product degradation. Our objective is to develop a complex network framework with event-time adjustments. Using failure data from a taxi company, we create a temporal multilayer network where product components are nodes, and edges represent failure sequences. Inter-layer edges connect corresponding nodes across layers. By assigning weights to edges, we define an event-time multilayer network. Results show a strong correlation between component reliability and temporal claim frequency in inter-layer analysis, while intra-layer analysis reveals a powerlaw distribution characteristic of scale-free networks. Moreover, conditional reliability highlights the significance of components in relation to the overall system. The proposed supracentrality matrix offers a systematic framework to enhance maintenance and warranty decision-making in complex systems.

title: SMO Tuned PID Controlled DC Motor Speed Control through HMAC Authenticated CAN Controller
authors: P. Abirami, M. Pushpavalli, R. Harikrishnan, P. Sivagami, Gouri Morankar, Indhumathi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Nowadays, the automotive industries rely on the massive connections of ECUs to communicate among the advanced devices used in a vehicle. This integration of advanced technologies may result in the complexity of systems in the network. For decades, the Controller Area Network (CAN) has been the dominant protocol for communication among Electronic Control Units (ECUs) within vehicles. In this project, the CAN protocol is employed to regulate the speed of a DC motor, with both KVASER CAN interfaces and PCAN-USB used to send and monitor CAN messages. Also, a closed loop analysis of the speed control of DC motor is employed through a Spider Monkey Optimized PID controller for the steady control of the DC motor.Traditionally, automotive systems have relied on a security-through-obscurity model. However, this approach is increasingly vulnerable, as in-vehicle networks can be reverse-engineered and manipulated with even consumer-grade tools. To address on this drawback, the project integrates a Hash-Based Message Authentication Code (HMAC) mechanism into the CAN communication process to verify message integrity and authenticity. An experimental setup demonstrates motor speed control using authenticated CAN messages, and the results of this secure implementation are presented.

title:
Complementary Electrochromic Device with WO
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    and NiO Films and with Polyvinyl Butyral Polymer Electrolyte
authors: Ying-Chung Chen, Shih-Yuan Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: A complementary electrochromic device (CECD), consisting of WO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> and NiO films laminated with a polyvinyl butyral (PVB) gel polymer electrolyte (GPE) was fabricated in this study. The structure of the device included Glass/ITO/WO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>/GPE/NiO/ITO/Glass. The WO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> film, serving as the cathodic electrochromic layer, was sputter-deposited onto an indium tin oxide (ITO) glass substrate, while the NiO film, acting as the complementary anodic electrochromic layer, was sputter-deposited onto another ITO glass substrate. The PVB polymer electrolyte was used as the ionic conduction layer. The physical and optical properties of GPE were optimized at a LiClO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf> content of 6 wt.%, with a viscosity of 3,360 mPa•s, an ionic conductivity of 7.73 mS/cm, and an average visible transmittance of 89% at room temperature (RT). The fabricated CECD exhibited satisfactory reversibility and low power consumption when driven by a coloring/bleaching voltage of ±1.8 V, achieving a transmittance change (ΔT%) of 45.22%, an optical density change (ΔOD) of 0.53, and a coloration efficiency (η) of 72.6 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>/C at a wavelength (λ) of 550 nm, along with an excellent memory effect under power-off conditions. The results also demonstrated that PVB exhibited excellent electrochemical stability, preventing leakage and volatility issues while providing outstanding optical and physical properties, such as high light transmittance, strong adhesion, and impact resistance.

title: Research on Standardization of Measurement and Testing Process of Aviation Equipment Based on Motion Capture
authors: Chu Youbing, Cheng Sheng, Chen Mo, Yin Qifan, Wang Shiyuan
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: To enhance the operational standardization of metrology testing processes for aviation equipment and practical training for new employees, this paper proposes a method for standardizing the teaching of metrology testing processes and practical training for aviation equipment based on motion capture. This method uses inertial motion capture devices to capture the entire process of conducting a specific metrology testing activity according to standard operating procedures, obtaining posture data and action videos of a three-dimensional digital human model, thus forming a digital standard operation method for metrology testing activities of aviation equipment. By establishing a digital standard operation analysis system, it provides a basis for assessing the standardization and stability of ordinary employees' operations; it also offers visual teaching materials for new employee position training, guiding trainees to master key movement details during practical operations, thereby improving operational standards, work efficiency, and product quality.

title: Integrating Visual XAI and LLMs for Interpretable Medical Image Analysis
authors: Xin Hui Lor, Chern Hong Lim
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Despite the growing adoption of deep learning in medical imaging, the limited transparency of model predictions continues to hinder clinical trust and deployment. This work proposes a multimodal explainability framework for medical image captioning that integrates both visual and textual explanations to enhance transparency and interpretability. Using a convolutional neural network trained on the ChestMNIST dataset, our model achieves a binary classification accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 9 4 9 2}$</tex> across multiple thoracic conditions. We compare three visual XAI methods (SHAP, Saliency, and LIME) and four large language models (Gemini, Ollama, DeepSeek, and Skylark) to generate diagnosisinformed captions. Visual explanations highlight salient image regions influencing predictions, while large language models produce human-readable descriptions grounded in these visual cues. Our findings show that SHAP combined with DeepSeek offers the most balanced performance in terms of explanation fidelity and accessibility. Readability analysis indicates that the captions are suitable for a general audience with college-level proficiency, requiring no medical background. By bridging the gap between model decisions and user understanding, our approach improves the transparency and trustworthiness of AIdriven medical diagnosis systems.

title: A Pulse Generator Design to Feed a GNLTL for High Power RF Generation
authors: N. Charrel, A. Zhabin, A. Silvestre de Ferron, V. Gavrilenko, J.-C. Diot, A. Chauloux, A. Catrain, G. Ducrocq, L. Sousbielle, L. Pecastaing
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The present poster illustrates a pulse generator design based on a Marx generator associated with a pulse forming line (PFL). The objective is to feed a gyromagnetic nonlinear transmission line (GNLTL) with a square pulse of 30 kV, 2 ns rise time, around 10 ns width and 100 Hz of repetition rate. The Marx generator is composed of 8 stages that can be charged up to 15 kV and insulated with pressurized dry air up to 3.5 bar absolute. The pulse generated is about 70 kV amplitude with a 20 ns rise time onto a 50Ω impedance. This part has been simulated with circuit and 3D simulations and experimentally tested. The PFL design is based on an off-the-shelf coaxial cable connected to a dry air spark-gap switch pressurized up to 25 bar absolute that should give the desired pulse shape and rise time. As of now, the spark-gap design is simulated to ensure undisrupted impedance matches with transient simulations. Its study is ongoing and will be validated onto a 50Ω match impedance and then with a newly design GNLTL [1].

title: Overcoming Imperfect Detection Limitations: Deep Learning-Based Calibration Strategy for Rotating Interferometric Arrays
authors: Zhaohang Zhang, Chunzhe Wang, Zhen Huang, Yafeng Zhan
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: The calibration of rotating interferometers in real-world applications is critically challenged by complex, coupled systematic errors that render traditional model-based methods ineffective. While deep learning methods offer a powerful alternative, their practical application is hindered by the scarcity of labeled training data, the “black-box” nature of most networks, and their vulnerability to measurement noise. This paper presents a comprehensive strategy that addresses these limitations. We first develop a weakly-supervised labeling scheme that generates training data from non-cooperative sources, removing the reliance on dedicated emitters. Then we design a domain-knowledge-infused network to enhance the interpretability by explicitly modeling key physical quantities to learn their nonlinear couplings. Moreover, a novel inverse-solved feature is proposed to ensure robustness against measurement noise, which provides a denoised, temporally coherent input for the network. On field-collected data where model-based algorithms fail to converge, the proposed approach is shown to reduce positioning error by 34.48%, demonstrating its practical value.

title: Evaluating an AI-Enhanced Elective Program for Clinical Medical Students: Insights from Student Feedback on a Renal Dialysis Module
authors: Gauri Krishnaswamy, Anushani Sathiyaseelan, Anusia Rajan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Background: This paper assesses an AI-based enhanced renal dialysis elective course on clinical medical students by examining student feedback to lecture material, teaching format and the delivery of the program. Thematic text analysis using qualitative feedback and descriptive pattern recognition using quantitative data were incorporated into the evaluation process to enable a structured finding of strengths, weaknesses, and areas of curricular improvement using artificial intelligence (AI). Students identified benefits of interdisciplinary learning, technical learning and useful strategies of engagement. Nonetheless, they also reported such issues as lack of visual materials, excessive complexity of the material, and no chance to practice in real life.Purpose: The purpose of the assessment is to evaluate the effectiveness of a renal dialysis program consisting of an elective program with the help of AI-supported feedback analysis to determine the strengths and weaknesses of the educational program and the opportunities to improve the program.Procedure: It was a qualitative descriptive study, which included five fourth-year MBBS students. Open-ended forms, structured logbooks and supervisor evaluations were used to collect the data that were further processed by qualitative coding tools based on AI-driven thematic clustering and visualization.Findings: Lectures on haemodialysis, CKD screening, intradialytic complications, management of long-term complications, and cardiovascular risk factors seemed to be well-received. The analysis of the collected data with the help of AI was confirmed to have recurrent themes, such as the lack of visual aid, outdated references, as well as insufficient use of case-based methods. The suggestions were incorporation of simulations, betterment in multimedia teaching aids as well as fine tuning lecture pace.Conclusion: The results of the evaluation process with the integration of AI were more comprehensive and revealed the necessity to improve teaching aids, improve the design of lectures, and increase the correspondence between theory and practice. Such results indicate that AI can be useful in the assessment of medical curricula, including the creation of more interactive and centred clinical electives to students.

title: Tailoring Plasma Sources for Agriculture: Direct and Indirect Treatments
authors: T. M.C. Nishime, J. F. Kolb, S. Bousselmi, M. Schmidt, E. F. Hernandez, A. Adetunji, L. Colville, K.-D. Weltmann
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Plasma agriculture, an emerging interdisciplinary field, is gaining importance for its potential to revolutionize sustainable farming. By harnessing plasma, it can enhance seed germination, plant growth, and crop yield while reducing reliance on chemical fertilizers and pesticides<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>. Plasma treatments can also sterilize soil, disinfect seeds, and improve water use efficiency, addressing global challenges like food security, climate change, and environmental degradation<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>.

title: Visualization Platform for Employment Analysis of College Graduates
authors: Yuchen Li, Jie Zhang, Xiaojuan Zhang, Jia Luo, Jiaxin Yin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: We developed a visualization platform for employment analysis based on a secure shell framework. The developed platform addressed the problem of inconvenient access to employment resources for college graduates. The platform contained four modules: front-end user interaction, back-end business logic processing, data storage and query, and visualization display. The platform provided graduates with convenient and efficient employment services. The front-end of the platform provided the query function through Java server pages (JSP) and cascading style sheets (CSS), and a servlet for business logic processing. The back-end was connected to the database through Java Database Connectivity (JDBC) to realize data storage and querying. IDEA software was used for code writing. The platform integrated school, market, and student information through the network, providing a convenient communication channel between graduates and enterprises. The experimental results showed that the platform effectively improved the efficiency of obtaining employment information, optimized the distribution of employment resources, and provided intuitive and convenient employment services for college graduates.

title: Transferability of Adversarial Examples Across Speaker Embedding Models for Voice Privacy Protection
authors: Kotaro Nakamura, Takuya Takahashi, Toru Nakashika
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: The widespread use of speaker identification technology has raised concerns regarding personal information contained in voice data, particularly voice privacy. While the application of adversarial attacks is a potential protection measure for this issue, the extent to which their attack effectiveness is maintained across speaker embedding extractors with different architectures (a property known as transferability) is not yet well understood. In this study, we experimentally evaluated the transferability of adversarial audio generated using the I-FGSM method. The evaluation targeted three types of speaker embedding extractors with different architectures: X-vector, Titanet, MelStyleEncoder and ECAPA-TDNN. We evaluated attack effectiveness using identification accuracy and the Equal Error Rate, and assessed audio quality using PESQ, which predicts subjective listening quality, and SI-SDR, which measures signal fidelity. The experimental results showed that in black-box attacks, attacks from models like X-vector to ECAPA-TDNN exhibited high transferability, while an asymmetrical relationship was observed where the reverse direction had low transferability. Furthermore, a clear tradeoff between attack strength and audio quality was confirmed. These results indicate that adversarial audio can affect not only a single model but also other models, suggesting its effectiveness as a technology for voice privacy protection.

title: GCI Detection and Glottal Wave Estimation based on TV-CAR Speech Analysis
authors: Keiichi Funaki
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Accurate detection of Glottal Closure Instances (GCIs) is crucial for speech processing applications. The SEDREAMS method detects GCIs by identifying peaks in LPC residual within candidate intervals determined from mean-based signals. However, LPC analysis may not adequately separate glottal excitation from vocal tract characteristics, especially in low frequencies. This paper proposes replacing LPC residual signals with complex ones from Time-Varying Complex AR (TVCAR) analysis of analytic signals. TV-CAR provides improved low-frequency estimation by eliminating negative frequency components. Experiments on the CMU Arctic database demonstrate that TV-CAR-based SEDREAMS achieves better identification detection rates than conventional LPC-based methods, particularly for male speakers. This paper proposes a method to estimate the GCI using the TV-CAR method.

title: Detecting Defecation Premonition from the Acoustic Activity of Bowel Sounds
authors: Shota Miyagawa, Toshitaka Yamakawa, Masayuki Tanabe, Kazushi Ikeda
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This study investigates a method for detecting predefecatory signs from bowel sounds to help prevent fecal incontinence. We compared two analytical approaches: a macroanalysis of entire 8-second audio clips and a micro-analysis of individually detected bowel sound events. Using data collected from a single subject, multiple machine learning models were evaluated for their ability to classify audio as either belonging to a specific time window before defecation (ranging from 10 to 270 minutes) or to other times. The results consistently showed that the macro-analysis outperformed the micro-analysis in overall discriminative performance. A CNN-BiLSTM model achieved the highest performance in the macro-analysis, with a peak AUC of 0.76 for the 60-minute pre-defecation window. A subsequent statistical analysis revealed that this performance difference is attributable to a significant increase in the frequency and total duration of bowel sound events prior to defecation (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$p<0.001$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$r=0.378$</tex>). These findings indicate that the quantitative density of bowel sound events is a more dominant indicator for detecting defecation premonition than the qualitative acoustic characteristics of individual sounds. This suggests that focusing on event frequency analysis is a more promising direction for developing non-invasive prediction systems.

title: A Deep Reinforcement Learning Method with Enhanced Communication Mechanism for Spatial Crowdsourcing
authors: Gang Wang, Lu Yuan, Wang Lu, Lei Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Spatial crowdsourcing (SC) is a promising paradigm that employs human participants to complete data collection tasks. Unlike human participants, UAVs have high flexibility and controllability and can provide reliable support for emergency situations such as disasters and traffic congestion. We consider a UAV-assisted SC (USC) task with the goal of maximizing the amount of data collection, geographic fairness among points of interest, and minimizing UAV energy consumption. However, many existing studies have neglected the importance of communication between UAVs, resulting in unnecessary competition and difficulty in effectively perceiving global tasks. To this end, we propose a multi-agent deep reinforcement learning method with an efficient communication mechanism, named DRLMcs_ECA, which can enhance information interaction between UAVs and reduce communication overhead, thereby promoting collaboration between UAVs. Extensive simulation experiments show that DRLMcs_ECA outperforms the baseline method and improves overall energy efficiency while reducing communication overhead.

title: Interpretable Video-Text Alignment (VTA) for Cross-Modal Retrieval
authors: Tsung-Shan Yang, Yun-Cheng Wang, Chengwei Wei, Suya You, C.-C. Jay Kuo
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Aligning representations between the video and text domains is crucial in video-text retrieval. Most deep learning algorithms conceal this mechanism in a latent space through end-to-end optimization. In addition, the computational requirements for training and inference increase exponentially with the video length. To address interoperability and efficiency, we propose an interpretable video-text alignment (VTA) method in this work.
