Through keyframe selection and genre clustering, we reduce the number of trainable parameters to just 3% compared to CLIP [1] backbone training while maintaining constant time and space complexity during inference. Furthermore, our alignment method connects embedding spaces of different modalities. During the alignment process, the conditional probabilities for a given object or phrase are estimated and aggregated, providing probabilistic support for our predictions. Hence, the alignment method is fully transparent. Experimental results on the MSR-VTT dataset demonstrate that the proposed VTA method offers state-of-the-art performance. Moreover, our alignment method does not demand fine-tuning of the pre-trained encoder, thereby avoiding bias from small paired training datasets.

title: Cross-Modal Attention Guided Enhanced Fusion Network for RGB-T Tracking
authors: Jun Liu, Wei Ke, Shuai Wang, Da Yang, Hao Sheng
publish: IEEE Signal Processing Letters
abstract: Visual tracking that combines RGB and thermal infrared modalities (RGB-T) aims to utilize the useful information of each modality to achieve more robust object localization. Most existing tracking methods based on convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and Transformers emphasize integrating multi-modal features through cross-modal attention, but ignore the potential exploitability of complementary information learned by cross-modal attention for enhancing modal features. In this paper, we propose a novel hierarchical progressive fusion network based on cross-modal attention guided enhancement for RGB-T tracking. Specifically, the complementary information generated by cross-modal attention implicitly reflects the consistent regions of interest of important information between different modalities, which is used to enhance modal features in a targeted manner. In addition, a modal feature refinement module and a fusion module are designed based on dynamic routing to perform noise suppression and adaptive integration on the enhanced multi-modal features. Extensive experiments on GTOT, RGBT234, LasHeR and VTUAV show that our method has competitive performance compared with recent state-of-the-art methods.

title: Accelerating ML Inference via Opportunistic Pre-Loading on Serverless Clusters
authors: Yifan Sui, Hanfei Yu, Yitao Hu, Jianxun Li, Hao Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems
abstract: Serverless computing has emerged as a novel paradigm in cloud computing, characterized by its agile scalability, cost-effective pay-as-you-go billing, and user-friendly capabilities for Machine Learning (ML) inference tasks. Developers wrap their ML algorithms into serverless functions and run them in containers. However, the well-known cold-start problem significantly slows down the response time of functions. To address cold-starts, the technique of pre-warming, which proactively maintains containers in a warm state, has gained widespread adoption across both research and industry. Nevertheless, we observed that pre-warming does not address the distinct delays caused by the loading of ML artifacts. According to our analysis, in ML inference functions, the time required to load libraries and models significantly exceeds the time needed to warm containers. Thus, relying solely on pre-warming is insufficient for mitigating cold-starts. This paper presents Tyche, an opportunistic pre-loading approach designed to eliminate the latency associated with loading ML artifacts, enabling near-instant inference and minimizing function execution time. Tyche fully leverages the idle memory in warmed containers and GPUs to pre-load required libraries and models, striking an optimal balance between acceleration and resource efficiency. Additionally, Tyche is tailored for large-scale serverless platforms, incorporating cluster-wide scheduling and lightweight locality-aware load balancing to enhance performance. We design Tyche to be transparent to providers and compatible with existing pre-warming solutions. Experiments on OpenWhisk with real-world workloads show that Tyche reduces up to 93% loading latency and achieves up to 8× speedup compared to state-of-the-art pre-warming solutions. Compared with the state-of-the-art serverless pre-loading solution, Tyche also achieves up to 1.9× speedup.

title: Design of an X-Band Dual-Mode Relativistic Cherenkov Oscillator Operating at Low Guiding Magnetic Field
authors: Yueyue Huang, Fangchao Dang, Fuxiang Yang, Xingjun Ge, Peng Zhang, Rujin Deng, Xiaodong Hu
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This paper presents an X-band high-efficiency dual-mode relativistic Cherenkov oscillator (DM-RCO) operating at low guiding magnetic field. The device comprises a TM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">01</sub>-TM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">02</sub> mode converter, a trapezoidal slow wave structure (SWS), a collector, and an output waveguide. At the oscillation initiation stage, the electron beam interacts synchronously with fundamental forward wave of TM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">01</sub> in the SWS. Notably, the backward-propagating TM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">01</sub> mode is converted into the forward-propagating TM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">02</sub> mode via the upstream mode converter, establishing a hybrid TM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">01</sub>-TM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">02</sub> modal field distribution in the SWS. Due to the high coupling impedance of the zeroth space harmonic of TM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">02</sub> mode at the operating frequency, it can participate in asynchronous energy exchange with the electron beam. After the beam-wave interaction, the energy of some electrons decreases, thus, synchronous interactions between backward propagating TM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">01</sub>/TM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">02</sub> modes and low energy electron beam exist. Both modes participate in beam-wave energy exchange simultaneously, leading to enhanced efficiency. Particle-in-cell (PIC) simulations demonstrate that with a diode voltage of 782 kV, beam current of 10.5 kA, and a guiding magnetic field of only 0.5 T, the DM-RCO achieves a high-power output of 4.1 GW at an operating frequency of 9.47 GHz, with a conversion efficiency of 50%.

title: A Critical Review of Advanced Protection Devices in AC Microgrid
authors: Kayode Ebenezer Ojo, Akshay Kumar Saha, Viranjay M. Srivastava
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Protection is a crucial component of any power system that aims to deliver reliable, safe, and secure electricity of high quality and consistency. Creating a dependable protection system for an AC microgrid is challenging due to numerous practical considerations. In this work, several protection devices (PDs) in AC microgrids are systematically analyzed, with a focus on systems that employ electronically connected Distributed Energy Resources (DERs). This work employed several mathematical modeling equations to illustrate the challenges in microgrid protection associated with various operating modes. This study emphasizes the move toward intelligent and adaptive PDs, which offer enhanced fault isolation, real-time load balancing, fault detection, and system resilience. This research also underlines the usefulness of artificial intelligence (AI) in reducing the negative consequences of cyberattacks and cybersecurity challenges, especially those that jeopardize data integrity and confidentiality in microgrid PDs. Through an examination of pertinent standards and regulations, this paper explores how sophisticated communication and measurement methods might facilitate adaptive microgrid PDs that can update and modify relay settings automatically. The paper ends with several recommendations, highlighting the necessity of stronger cybersecurity measures and more reliable PDs to guarantee that the microgrid keeps playing a vital part in the shift to low-carbon energy.

title: Development and Initial Evaluation of 3D-Printed High Resolution Brain Phantom for PET
authors: Cynthia Lo, Ekaterina Shanina, Paul Gravel, Yifan Hu, Steven A. Lucero, Sean Martins, Tim Mulnix, Kathryn Fontaine, Seyed Faraz Nejati, Xishan Sun, Hongdi Li, Jinyi Qi, Simon R. Cherry, Richard E. Carson, Takuya Toyonaga
publish: IEEE Transactions on Radiation and Plasma Medical Sciences
abstract: Phantoms are essential for assessing PET system performance, but most existing brain phantoms do not provide the anatomical fidelity required for the next-generation high-resolution PET systems. To address this limitation, we developed HYDRA-OL (HYDrodynamically filled Realistic Anatomy of the Occipital Lobe) phantoms using high-resolution 3D printing based on the BigBrain atlas. In this study, two phantom types were created, HYDRA-OLG (gray matter only) and HYDRA-OLGW (gray and white matter), enabling contrast modulation between gray matter (GM) and white matter (WM). Precise anatomical fidelity and repositioning accuracy were confirmed via CT. A custom closed-loop filling apparatus ensured efficient and reproducible phantom preparation. Residual air in the phantom after 15 minutes was estimated to be less than 0.01% of the fillable space. To compare spatial resolution between scanners, the HYDRA-OLG phantom was imaged on four different PET systems (NeuroEXPLORER (NX), HRRT, Vision, and Focus220), with NX and Focus showing superior spatial resolution compared to the other two systems. To generate variable GM:WM contrast, list mode datasets obtained on the NX for both HYDRA-OLG and HYDRA-OLGW phantoms were down-sampled and merged to form one list mode data. Reconstructed images were successfully produced with GM:WM contrast ratio of 4:1, 2:1, and 4:3. Overall, the HYDRA phantom platform is a versatile tool for accurately representing human brain anatomy. It is likely to be more useful than previous phantoms for evaluating image resolution and optimizing reconstruction parameters for next-generation brain PET systems.

title: Construction of SubQUBOs by K-means Clustering of QUBO Variables
authors: Yuko Kamishima, Shuta Kikuchi, Shu Tanaka
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Ising machines are specialized solvers for combinatorial optimization problems (COPs), which are typically formulated as quadratic unconstrained binary optimization (QUBO) models. To enhance their performance, various methods have been proposed to construct subQUBOs by reducing the number of variables in the original QUBO. This study proposes a general subQUBO construction method applicable to a wide range of problems. The variables are clustered based on their interaction structure using the K-means clustering. A subQUBO is constructed from a randomly selected cluster and a pre-obtained tentative solution and then solved. This process of cluster selection and subQUBOs is performed iteratively. We evaluated the performance of the method on the quadratic assignment problem and compared it with two baselines: one that randomly reduces variables and another that directly solves the original QUBO without any variable reduction. Experimental evaluations demonstrated that the proposed method achieves high-accuracy solutions within the same computation time, particularly for large problem sizes.

title: S4DR-Net: Self-Supervised Spatial-Spectral Distance Reconstruction Network for Multispectral Point Cloud Classification
authors: Qingwang Wang, Jianling Kuang, Tao Shen, Yanfeng Gu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Multispectral LiDAR point clouds are valuable in remote sensing for their spatial-spectral consistency, yet their high acquisition and annotation costs pose significant challenges. To mitigate this, self-supervised learning has emerged as a promising solution, reducing reliance on annotated data while improving model generalization. However, existing self-supervised frameworks for point clouds often overlook the complexity of ground object distribution in large-scale remote sensing scenarios and fail to leverage the spectral information inherent in multispectral point clouds. In this paper, we introduce the Self-Supervised Spatial-Spectral Distance Reconstruction Network (S4DR-Net), a novel self-supervised pre-training network designed for multispectral point cloud classification. Serving as the key component of the network, the Spatial-Spectral Distance Prediction module (S-SDP) effectively addresses these limitations by reconstructing the distance relationships between voxel blocks in three-dimensional Euclidean as well as spectral spaces. By jointly considering spatial and spectral distances, S-SDP enables the network to learn a unified representation that captures the intrinsic spatial-spectral consistency of multispectral point clouds. This design allows S4DR-Net to generate low-dimensional feature representations in a self-supervised manner, without reliance on manual annotations. We conducted experiments and evaluated on two real-world multispectral point cloud datasets. The results demonstrate that S4DR-Net consistently outperforms existing self-supervised pre-training methods, achieving superior accuracy and generalization compared with current state-of-the-art approaches. The code will be released at https://github.com/KustTeamWQW/S4DR-Net.

title: High-Performance 406 nm Violet Laser Diode for Optical Wireless Communication
authors: Yang Kang, Feilin Xun, Muhammad Hunain Memon, Yuchen Du, Huabin Yu, Bohan Xiao, Zhen Yang, Yuanmin Luo, Jiangyong Zhang, Jinjian Zheng, Zhibai Zhong, Haiding Sun
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: Violet laser diodes (LDs) have emerged as one of the key light sources for optical wireless communication (OWC) systems requiring covert operation and quantum-secure links, but their performance remains limited by fundamental material and device-level challenges. Herein, we boost the electro-optical efficiency and device characteristics of 406 nm violet LDs via defect controlling of the GaN substrates on which the LDs are built. By increasing the V/III ratio precursor ratio from 20 to 40 during the material synthesis process, the GaN substrate crystalline quality is improved, reducing the dislocation density from 1.17×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup> cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-2</sup> to 5.54×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">5</sup> cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-2</sup>. Consequently, the violet LDs built on the substrate with reduced dislocation density exhibit a 49% reduction in threshold current density, decreasing from 4.14 kA/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> to 2.11 kA/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, and nearly doubled light output power from 0.39 W to 0.75 W at 7.5 kA/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> in comparison to the LD built on the substrate with higher dislocation density. Notably, the optimized violet LD also achieves a 106% increase of -3 dB modulation bandwidth from 1.6 to 3.3 GHz. Benefiting from the enhanced light output power and modulation bandwidth, the optimized violet LD achieves a maximum data transmission rate of 4.3 Gbit/s under operation of non-return-to-zero on–off keying modulation, representing a 43% improvement over 3.0 Gbit/s. This work marks a notable milestone in the advancement of high-performance GaN-based violet LDs for next-generation OWC systems.

title: Closely Coupled Fast Marx Design and Testing at DTRA West Coast Facility Quadeagle Simulator
authors: F. Ambrosini, D. Phipps, Y. Parker, R. Spielman, J. Mamoody, P. Sincerny, P. Gordon, J. Calkins, S. Seiler
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Quad-EAGLE (QE) is a new prompt-dose Nuclear Weapons Effects (NWE) Simulator that is currently under validation at the DTRA West Coast Facility in San Leandro, CA. QE will replace Double-EAGLE (DE), delivering twice the energy into a load at the same voltage and double the current, and providing customers with improved testing capabilities.

title: Robust GNSS/PDR Fusion Scheme with Probability Constraints
authors: Wei Liao, Junna Shang, Chundong Lu, Zhengtao Wu, Mingkun Su
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Aiming at the problem of insufficient robustness of factor graph models in multi-sensor integrated positioning, especially in GNSS and pedestrian dead reckoning (PDR) fusion scenarios, where existing methods suffer from significant positioning accuracy degradation due to abnormal sensor interference, cumulative error propagation, and dynamic environmental noise, and where current robustness improvement solutions mostly rely on manual experience or high-precision sensors while lacking systematic optimization frameworks, this paper proposes an adaptive fusion scheme based on cross-time-step constraints. By establishing an inertial sensor noise hard-truncation mechanism and a global historical state reverse-correction model, we propose a multi-step kinematic constraint framework based on state correlation, which enhances the consistency between sensor heterogeneous characteristics and the positioning model, suppresses the long-term impact of PDR cumulative errors on positioning, and reduces the interference of abnormal GNSS observations on system states.Simulation and field experiments show that the proposed scheme can effectively fuse low-cost smartphone sensor data in complex environments including urban canyons and signal-occluded areas, achieving highly robust integrated navigation and providing theoretical support for seamless positioning in dynamic interference scenarios.

title: Microwave Plasma Technology: A Versatile Tool for Chemical Conversion Processes
authors: A. Meindl, A. Hecimovic, C. K. Kiefer, C. L. Kranig, U. Fantz
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Microwave plasma reactors are introduced as a tool for the beneficial conversion of different molecules into other compounds of interest. Potential applications of this technology include for example the reduction of greenhouse gases, chemical energy storage, electrification of chemical processes, nitrogen fixation, and hydrogen production and storage. Microwave plasmas can cover a wide pressure range, making them tunable to the desired chemical conversion process, for which <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> splitting, methane pyrolysis and dry reforming of methane are used as examples. Besides changing the heavy particle temperature, the pressure also determines which mechanisms govern the conversion, ranging from electron-impact dissociation at low pressures to mostly thermal driven conversion at atmospheric pressure operation. Understanding the influence of different underlying parameters is crucial for the development and design of technological solutions that allow for an optimization of the achievable performances. Furthermore, aspects that need to be considered for potential industrial applications, such as process interfaces, gas separation steps, and possibilities for upscaling will be discussed. As a prominent example, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> splitting is addressed first, since it is currently the furthest in terms of technological development. On a more fundamental level, plasma-driven dry reforming of methane is presented. It enables a direct production of syngas, a mixture of CO and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{H}_{2}$</tex>, which serves as an important feedstock for example in the chemical industry. The utilization of pure Methane, pyrolized via the plasma process for the production of hydrogen and solid carbon, is touched upon as well.

title: Use of Pulsed Electric Field (PEF) Technology to Reduce the Bacterial Contamination in E-Coating Lines
authors: C. A. Gusbeth, W. Frey, P. Krolla, T. Schwarz, M. Sack, G. Müller
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: With the increasing application of environmentally friendly E-coating systems, water-based paints are being widely used. However, lower process temperatures and water recirculation promote microbial growth, leading to contamination in processing tanks and rinse water systems. Traditional disinfectants, such as biocides, face regulatory restrictions and risk bacterial resistance, necessitating alternative solutions. Pulsed Electric Field (PEF) treatment, which permeabilizes bacterial cell membranes through high electric field strengths, represents a sustainable method for microbial control in E-coating systems. However, paint deposition on electrodes and paint coagulation must be prevented during PEF treatment to maintain coating quality and system functionality. Calculations showed that this can be achieved using pulses in the range of few ns, while longer pulses promote paint deposition on electrodes. Electrodeposition on metallic substrates occurs through water electrolysis, where a pH increase at the cathode causes coating particles to become water-insoluble, leading to their attachment. Reducing the pulse duration below the induction time for OH<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-</sup> formation was ineffective, as even short pulses <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(<1 \mu \mathrm{s})$</tex> could not completely prevent deposition. High pulse repetition rates further promoted coating formation by continuously increasing pH levels. A more effective approach involved using bipolar pulses, where alternating anodic and cathodic interfaces neutralized OH<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-</sup> and H<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup> ions. Short bipolar pulses (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.75+0.75 \mu \mathrm{s}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1+1 \mu \mathrm{s}$</tex>) completely prevented deposition, whereas longer pulses <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(5 \mu \mathrm{s})$</tex> resulted in paint deposition. A solution was found by using a semiconductor-based pulse generator that ensured charge symmetry, preventing ion accumulation and coating formation. Experiments with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.5+1.5 \mu \mathrm{s}$</tex> bipolar pulses demonstrated long-term prevention, with no deposition after extended operation. This patented process was integrated into a pilot e-coating system. PEF treatment, using short bipolar pulses, offers an effective solution to bacterial contamination while maintaining coating quality, reducing freshwater consumption, and minimizing effluent generation in E-coating process.

title: Simulation Study of a Plasma-Assisted, Novel Truncated Conical Hollow Cathode
authors: P. B. Unadkat, S. Jain, N. Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: This paper presents a novel truncated conical hollow cathode (HC) for plasma discharge-driven electron beam sources, addressing the limitations of traditional hollow cathodes in single-gap configurations. The plasma-discharge in conventional HCs with inner cylindrical geometry results in single HCP when used in single-gap configuration. However, for the generation of high-energy electron beams using plasma-assisted electron beam sources, multiple HCPs with a HC capable sustaining the high-voltage breakdown for longer duration is desirable. The conventional multigap configurations introduce significant challenges in terms of design, fabrication, and integration, especially when dealing with millimeter-scale apertures. In this work, we present a HC with truncated conical inner geometry to mitigate these challenges and enable the formation of multiple HCPs in a single-gap configuration. This novel cathode design enhances the plasma discharge breakdown time and facilitates the generation of a high-energy electron beam in a single-gap configuration itself. It is a cold cathode, designed to generate cylindrical electron beam and utilizes a plasma-assisted Pseudo-spark (PS) discharge mechanism. Its geometry comprises a hollow cathode cavity with a truncated cone combined with a cylindrical extension. The apex of the cone is truncated at the front wall containing a single HC aperture, while the base of the cone extends into a cylindrical shape, matching the diameter of the conical base. The entire hollow cavity is enclosed by a solid metallic cylinder, with a diameter slightly larger diameter than that of the conical base. This ensures the external geometry remains consistent with conventional cylindrical hollow cathodes. A 3D particle-in-cell (PIC) simulation study of the proposed truncated conical HC was carried out using the software VSim Multiphysics. The truncated conical HC represents a significant advancement in PS discharge-driven electron beam technology, offering a simpler and more efficient approach to generating high-energy beams with multiple HCPs in a single-gap configuration.

title: Joint Design of Low Sidelobe Radar Waveform and Filter with Hardware Platform Verification
authors: Haoqian Rong, Shaojie Wang Zining Zhao Jiawei Zhang
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Radar waveform design is crucial for improving radar detection efficiency and accuracy. However, current theoretical research is disconnected from engineering practice, lacking verification in actual hardware systems. The paper first jointly designs radar waveforms and filters based on optimization theory to achieve range sidelobe suppression. Then, it constructs an arbitrary radar waveform transmitting/receiving platform using FPGA and high-speed AD modules, which can generate arbitrary waveforms, radiate them into space, receive target echo signals in an outdoor environment, and transmit them back to the host computer, thereby realizing real data verification of the waveform optimization algorithm. Corner reflectors are deployed as the targets to be measured in the real environment. The experimental results show that: each module of the hardware system functions as expected, with high accuracy in generating optimized waveforms and collecting signals; under the same bandwidth condition, the optimized waveforms have lower sidelobes compared to linear frequency modulation signals.

title: GDP-UAV: A Gaussian Differential Privacy-Empowered Multi-UAV Task Offloading in Low-Altitude Economy Networks
authors: Miao Du, Yinqiu Liu, Changyuan Zhao, Wen Tian, Huaifeng Shi, Zhu Han
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive Communications and Networking
abstract: The rapid growth of the Low-Altitude Economy (LAE) drives widespread deployment of multi-unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) systems for latency-sensitive applications. Collaborative task offloading to edge servers addresses computational limitations but exposes sensitive operational patterns to adversaries. Existing offloading strategies primarily optimize performance metrics such as latency and energy consumption while overlooking critical privacy concerns. To address this gap, we propose GDP-UAV, a novel privacy-preserving offloading framework based on differential privacy. Unlike traditional approaches, GDP-UAV mechanism injects dynamically calibrated Gaussian noise into both action selection and policy updates during offloading, effectively obfuscating decision patterns while maintaining learning stability. Specifically, we first formulate a privacy-constrained optimization problem to minimize noise-perturbed computational costs. Moreover, we establish formal differential privacy guarantees through bounded strategy sensitivity with detailed proven convergence and privacy under persistent noise. Extensive simulations validate the framework, demonstrating 11.6% lower privacy leakage and under 13.2% task completion overhead compared to non-private baselines across LAE scenarios.

title: Dynamic Scaling with Just-in-Time Snapshot in Distributed Stream Processing Systems
authors: Takdir, Salman Ahmed Shaikh, Akiyoshi Matono, Hiroyuki Kitagawa, Toshiyuki Amagasa
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Stream processing systems are typically long-running and likely experience varying workloads over time. The systems may need to process an excessive amount of data at any time. They must scale their capacity to meet low-latency requirements while still being resource-efficient. In distributed stream processing systems (DSPSs), scaling typically involves reconfiguring the physical topology of streaming jobs in the distributed computing environment. Current production-level DSPSs adopt a shared-nothing architecture to achieve scalability and reliability at a low cost, though this makes scaling stateful processing challenging. Most DSPSs employ a fixed partitioning scheme, which prevents altering the topology at runtime. As a result, scaling is performed by releasing the jobs and redeploying them with a modified topology. In fact, rescaling only some operators is sufficient to handle changes in workload. Several studies propose on-the-fly scaling by exchanging states between parallel instances of an operator. However, their custom state transfer mechanisms require substantial modifications to the existing DSPS architecture. We propose a dynamic scaling scheme that allows individual operators to scale at runtime with respect to the standard mechanisms provided by current DSPSs. We employ just-in-time snapshots for efficient state management of stateful processing. Compared to the job redeployment, the implemented approach in Apache Flink shows that scaling can be performed faster, with up to 80 percent for scale-out and two orders of magnitude for scale-in. The dynamic scaling scheme maintains stable performance during the rescaling phase.

title: Environment-adaptive navigation method for biorobots enhanced by the innate nature of insects_supp4-3636291.mp4
authors: Yao Li
publish: N/A
abstract: Biorobots involve embedding artificial components into a living insect to transform it into a controllable robot, which comes with the advantages of low energy consumption, quietness, and flexibility. However, no models have yet been developed to describe the randomness-filled motions of biorobots, and their unique biological properties are also underutilized. In this work, the locomotion responses of a biorobot to electrical stimuli were summarized. The constant-current signal was found to have a higher capacity for sustained stimuli than existing methods. The joint influence of wall and current factors on cockroach behavior was explored to establish an environment-adaptive control model describing their locomotion. This model was then used to propose an navigation method enhanced by the inherent nature of a biorobot. In an indoor scenario, the proposed method achieved a success rate of 78.6% with minimal runtime and stimulus number while the control group using conventional navigation methods achieved a success rate of 30%, with two or three times the runtime and stimulus number. Compared with other approaches, the proposed method facilitates high-precision and long-range navigation with a short navigation time and very low control costs.

title: Probabilistic semantic compression for zero-shot fault diagnosis
authors: Yifan Wu, Chuan Li, Min Xia
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Semantically bridging known and novel domains, Zero-Shot Fault Diagnosis (ZSFD) often faces two main challenges. First, deterministic semantic-fault associations fail to capture generalization. Second, automatically generated semantics are flat and redundant, impairing diagnostic inference. To address these issues, a Probabilistic Semantic Compression framework is proposed for ZSFD in this work. The approach extracts discriminative features through a contrastive projection head and constructs probabilistic semantics via a semantic projection head. The probabilistic semantics capture the uncertainty during the dynamic evolution of nonstationary fault patterns, replacing hard categorical assignments. A semantic compression module adaptively compresses the flat and redundant probabilistic semantics in a structure with both high interclass discriminability and interclass correlation. Features and semantics are mutually embedded in a shared latent space, where they are aligned based on their probabilistic distributions to enable the detection of novel faults. Extensive validation on three industrial datasets demonstrates strong generalization and effective transfer from bearings with artificially induced damage to those with naturally occurring faults.

title: RelMap: Reliable Spatiotemporal Sensor Data Visualization via Imputative Spatial Interpolation
authors: Juntong Chen, Huayuan Ye, He Zhu, Siwei Fu, Changbo Wang, Chenhui Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Accurate and reliable visualization of spatiotemporal sensor data such as environmental parameters and meteorological conditions is crucial for informed decision-making. Traditional spatial interpolation methods, however, often fall short of producing reliable interpolation results due to the limited and irregular sensor coverage. This paper introduces a novel spatial interpolation pipeline that achieves reliable interpolation results and produces a novel heatmap representation with uncertainty information encoded. We leverage imputation reference data from Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) to enhance visualization reliability and temporal resolution. By integrating Principal Neighborhood Aggregation (PNA) and Geographical Positional Encoding (GPE), our model effectively learns the spatiotemporal dependencies. Furthermore, we propose an extrinsic, static visualization technique for interpolation-based heatmaps that effectively communicates the uncertainties arising from various sources in the interpolated map. Through a set of use cases, extensive evaluations on real-world datasets, and user studies, we demonstrate our model's superior performance for data imputation, the improvements to the interpolant with reference data, and the effectiveness of our visualization design in communicating uncertainties.

title: Electro-Optic Probe for Real Time and Vectorial Analysis of Partial Discharges and Breakdown
authors: G. Gaborit, A. Zouaghi, C. Vollaire, L. Duvillaret
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The comprehensive analysis of the processes involved in discharges requires the understanding of the associated electric field behavior. We here demonstrate the potentialities of a pigtailed electro-optic (EO) probe to perform the experimental assessment of the transients associated to discharges in several configurations. The EO probe is entirely dielectric and millimeter sized, thus leading to very low invasive measurements and allowing near field analysis. Moreover, its frequency bandwidth exceeds several gigahertz and its measurement dynamics allows measurement from less than 1 V/m up to the breakdown field. All these properties make the EO probe suitable for real time characterization of discharges.

title: Exploring High Power Microwave / ElectromagneticVacuum Electronic Sources / Amplifiers from X- to Ka-Bands
authors: A.D. Andreev, A. M. Elfrgani, E. Schamiloglu
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The University of New Mexico (UNM) is at the forefront of academic research and development (R&D) activities in the High-Power Microwave (HPM) / Electromagnetic (HPEM) niche of the Vacuum Electronics technologies and applications. UNM performs analytical study, computer simulations, and laboratory experiments under an umbrella of several research projects exploring different kinds of electromagnetic radiators, ranging from 60 kHz to 220 GHz. One research project sponsored by the ONRDC, “High Power Electromagnetic Sources from X-Band to Kaband,” aims studying concepts of two HPM/HPEM sources, a relativistic <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$X$</tex>-band magnetron in collaboration with the Technion, Israel Institute of Technology and a relativistic <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$X$</tex>-band backwardwave oscillator (BWO). Another research project sponsored by AFOSR, “Exploration of Fundamental Limits to High Power Electromagnetic (HPEM) Amplification,” aims studying an HPM/HPEM amplifier - a relativistic <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$X$</tex>-band traveling-wave tube (TWT) in collaboration with the University of California, Irvine. Results of UNM's analytical and computational efforts implemented toward studying HPM/HPEM <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$X$</tex>-band radiators as well as results of experimental measurements of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$X$</tex>-band BWO operation are presented and discussed. The developing approaches toward studying computationally and experimentally some higher-frequencies <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$K u$</tex>-, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$K$</tex>-, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$K a$</tex> sources of interest for UNM and ONRDS, AFOSR research programs are outlined.

title: Production- and Transport-Limited Fluxes in Inductively Coupled Ion Sources for Neutral Beam Injectors
authors: M.S. Hossain, T. Regev, A. Mazzeo, K. J. Ammons, F. M. Laggner, M. A. Shah, K. M. Davda, S. C. Shannon, E. Kallenberg, J. T. Scoville, B. J. Crowley, A. M. Lietz
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Neutral beam injection (NBI) is the most powerful heating system at the DIII-D National Fusion Facility, using 8 injectors that deliver up to 20 MW of combined power. To enhance NBI performance, development efforts focus on optimizing radio-frequency (RF) inductively coupled plasma (ICP) positive ion sources to achieve high-density positive hydrogen ion beams. In RF ICP sources, this optimization involves balancing ion production and transport mechanisms. In a production-limited regime, ion flux is primarily constrained by ionization and dissociation rates; increasing RF power or improving electron heating directly enhances ion flux. Conversely, in a transport-limited regime, the efficiency of transport mechanisms, such as diffusion and convection, restricts ion flux. While increasing RF power still contributes to additional ion production, the transport bottleneck limits how much of that production translates into higher flux. Understanding the transition between these regimes is crucial for optimization.

title: X Band Pulse Amplifier Design for Radar Applications
authors: A. Eroglu, M. Tanvir
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Pulsed RF amplifiers are critical in radar, electronic warfare, and high-frequency communication systems, where precise, high-power signal amplification is required. Traditionally, vacuum tube technologies like traveling wave tubes (TWTs) and klystrons are commonly used, but they are bulky, inefficient, and require high voltages. The emergence of GaN-based amplifiers has advanced the field by offering higher power density, improved efficiency, and enhanced linearity, making them the preferred choice for modern radar and electronic warfare applications. Additionally, GaN amplifiers provide faster pulse response, sharper rise times, and better thermal performance, making them ideal for pulse-Doppler radar and SAR applications.

title: Simulations of Electrothermal Instabilities in Wires, Foils and Liners of Relevance to Magneto-Inertial Fusion
authors: J. Chittenden, J. Strucka, N. Chaturvedi, H. Biragnet, J. Lim, K. Sohn, S. Bland
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Magneto-inertial fusion (MIF) provides a promising route to fusion energy in which thermal conduction losses are mitigated through magnetisation of the electrons. Several approaches to MIF make use of imploding metallic liners driven by pulsed power generators to compresses the fusion fuel. One such approach is MagLIF which uses a beryllium liner to compress a magnetised deuterium fuel which is preheated with a laser and then imploded using 20MA currents on the ‘Z’ facility at Sandia National Laboratory.

title: Measurement and Simulation of Temperature Fields in Multistage Microwave Plasma for Nanomaterial Synthesis
authors: W. Ma, X. Bai, N. Luo, Z. Jie, G. Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Multistage microwave plasma demonstrates unique advantages in nanomaterial synthesis, including adjustable temperature gradients and stepwise reaction control. This study investigates the temperature characteristics of multistage nitrogen-sustained microwave plasma under varying power and gas flow conditions through an innovative measurement-simulation integrated approach. Given the significant temperature gradient spanning multiple orders of magnitude in multistage plasma systems, conventional single-point measurement techniques prove inadequate for comprehensive thermal characterization.

title: Controllable Synthesis of Core-Shell Nanomaterials in a Triple-Stage Microwave Plasma System: Hierarchical Regulation of Precursors and Gas Composition
authors: N. Luo, W. Ma, X. Bai, G. Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: This study develops a multi-stage microwave plasma strategy for one-step synthesis of core-shell nanoparticles, achieving carbon-encapsulated silicon (C@Si, core: 60-200 nm) from carbon black/micron Si (1-3 μ m) and iron oxide-coated iron (FeOx@Fe) from hematite micropowder (1-10 μ m). The multi-stage microwave plasma reactor enables control over core size (60-200 nm tunable) and shell composition through independent regulation of precursor feed rates (10-100 mL/min for Si/C, 10-35 mL/min for Fe<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>) and gas rates (9-15 L/min), plasma power at each stage (1500-3500 W, 2500-3500 W vaporization, 1500-2000 W oxidation and nucleation growth), and carrier gas composition (Ar/H2 mixtures and N2/O2 mixtures). Key advantages include: 1) Ultrarapid synthesis (<200 ms residence time) enabled by localized high-temperature zones (estimated 5000-6000 K) with steep thermal gradients; 2) Low byproduct formation; 3) One-step synthesis and small device size; 4)The control parameters are independent and the control method is simple. Core-shell structure nanomaterials exhibit excellent performance compared with ordinary structure nanomaterials, C@Si nanoparticles as negative electrode materials for lithium ion batteries exhibit excellent electrochemical performance, FeOx@Fe nanomaterials have high specific magnetic moment and high biocompatibility. The synthesis of core-shell nanomaterials using multistage microwave plasma in one step provides an innovative idea for the industrial synthesis of core-shell materials.

title: Electrostatic Analysis of Gamble-III's Novel Intermediate Storage CombinerBehaviors
authors: L. I. Welch, R. Allen, R. Cairns
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The aging Gamble-II generator at the Naval Research Laboratory, DC, is set to be replaced by the modernized Gamble-III facility. This upgrade aims to enhance reliability, reproducibility, and maintenance using best engineering practices. The new generator will maintain a similar peaking voltage and pulse width as its predecessor but will increase the current from 0.67 MA to 1.0 MA. Additionally, the Gamble-III generator will have a smaller footprint while delivering 50 % more power to an impedance-matched load.

title: Pulsed Plasma-Enabled One-Step $\text{CH}_{4} / \text{CO}_{2}$ Valorization to Platform Chemicals
authors: Y. Gao, L. Dou, Y. Xu, C. Zhang, T. Shao
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CH}_{4}$</tex> is the raw material of carbon-based value-added chemicals and hydrogen carrier. Given the status of high carbon emission by fossil fuels, renewable-energy driven in-situ methane utilization technology will be a vital force in the low-carbon transformation of the energy. However, traditional methane conversion highly relies on continuously external heating conditions, making it difficult to adapt to distributed intermittent electrical energy. In these undertakings, non thermal plasma (NTP) stands out as a prospective new solution for dealing with the difficulties of low-temperature C1 activation.

title: Modeling of High-Current Conductors
authors: C. L. Rousculp
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Metal foils have been used extensively as high-power opening switches. The configurations usually consist of an electrically thin (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\delta x<$</tex> classical-skin-depth) foil between dielectric insulating tampers. Both planar and cylindrical geometries are fielded with the latter reducing the effects of foil edges. The resistance of the foil fuse is governed by the simple equation for resistance (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}=\eta$</tex> length / area) where <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$h$</tex> the resistivity is a function of temperature and density. The general principle is to Joule heat the metal causing a 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> increase in resistivity but limiting it from reaching the plasma state where resistivity drops. Ideal, foils require a set amount of energy before they “burst.” One-dimensional modeling has shown that this is largely determined by the liquid-vapor curve of the equation of state table. Bulk motion of the foil due to magnetic pressure can increase the inductance of the circuit and thus reduce the peak current delivered downstream. Multidimensional effects are also investigated. First, the electrothermal instability leads to non-uniform current concentration perpendicular to the direction of flow and thus degraded switch performance. Second, dielectric tamping is commonly used to control switch operation. Different materials are investigated. Resolved calculations of inhomogeneous granular tamper materials are shown.

title: Surface Effects from Laser Irradiation of Anodes
authors: T. Rocha, C. Evans, W. Warner, S. Palko, S. Werdin-kennicott, M. Brito, S. Portillo
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The University of New Mexico is conducting an investigation into surface effects, specifically on reduction of desorption of neutrals from electrode materials after irradiation with laser light. Neutral desorption into the A-K gap of high energy electron devices poses serious deleterious effects due to neutralization of the incident beam and thus our work. These initial experiments generally use Aluminum as the electrode material and 900 nm as the laser wavelength. X-Ray Photon Spectroscopy as well as scanning electron microscope imaging was initially performed on small samples, followed by a more rigorous examination of spectroscopy diagnostics generated by anode plasma. Data from Anode-Cathode gap pulsed-power driven experiments will be shown and analyzed to determine elemental make up of the desorbed neutrals as well as from ablated material, providing insight to contents of the first several monolayers. These experiments will be conducted on Aluminum, Copper, and Titanium anodes all using a carbon nanotube based cathode.

title: Modeling a Current Divider for Controlling the Trajectory of a High-Intensity, Hollow Electron Beam
authors: S. B. Swanekamp, N. Gobs, J. C. Zier
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: This study presents designs for an inductive current divider, which can be used to control the trajectory of a high-intensity, hollow electron beam. Designs have been simulated using advanced particle-in-cell simulations that account for the complex interactions between charged particles and electromagnetic fields. By adjusting the inductances in each return current path of the current divider, we can steer the beam in any desired direction. Magnetic materials to change the inductances can make the device more compact. The study shows that different designs with similar inductance ratios achieve similar control over the beam, providing flexibility in experimental design.

title: Mass Balance and Scalability of Dry Reforming of Methane via Plasma Catalysis
authors: O. Kuschel, L.A. O. Hernandez, R.T. Nguyen-Smith, C. Koch
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The utilization of greenhouse gases such as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CH}_{4}$</tex> for syngas (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}+\mathrm{H}_{2}$</tex>) production is crucial for industrial applications and climate mitigation. Conventional thermal catalytic dry reforming of methane (DRM) is highly energy-intensive, leaving room for improvement through non-thermal plasma catalysis (NTPC) to mitigate its energy demands. NTPC enables gas conversion at lower operating temperatures and expands the range of possible reaction products, including oxygenates and higher hydrocarbons. However, for industrial viability, the scalability and mass balance of packed-bed plasma reactors in DRM require further investigation.

title: Verifying Safety of Safety-Critical Systems With Rare Events via Optimistic Optimization
authors: Tabea Henning-Günther, Daniel Grujic, Tino Werner, Lars Weber, Birte Neurohr, Eike Möhlmann
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Failures of safety-critical systems such as highly automated cars may result in loss of life, significant property damage, or environmental harm. Their trustworthiness and acceptance by society relies on safe operation, i.e., they have to be safer than their human-controlled counterparts, which is called the positive risk balance and which is a prerequisite for the operation in the EU. Hence, guaranteeing sufficient safety is a crucial task that requires rigorous examination. However, critical events such as severe accidents are assumed to occur with probabilities of order 10-6 or less. For this, automated simulation-based approaches for the purpose of statistical model checking contribute significantly to quantitative safety assessment. Common methods such as pure Monte Carlo simulation are inadequate to estimate the probability of these rare critical events due to excessively high simulation budget required. To overcome this, we provide a mathematical framework for combining an optimization algorithm, here from the family of optimistic optimization algorithms, with importance sampling in order to assess the safety of these systems quantitatively. Our methodology relies on a given criticality function that assesses each state of the underlying deterministic system regarding prescribed safety requirements. Applying the approach to a common test function and a simulated braking scenario using the software SILAB showcases that our method significantly reduces the required effort to quantify acceptable risk levels, compared to pure Monte Carlo simulation.

title: Design of an Induction Injector for Flash X-Rays Accelerators - EPURE Facility
authors: C. Vermare, B. Cassany, B. Cadilhon, C. Fourment, A. Goeury, W. Bohez
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The EPURE facility has three Flash X-rays sources; two are Linear Induction Accelerators. A new Induction Injector is under definition to replace, by 2031, one of the existing, Blumlein based injectors. This injector has a Push-Pull architecture. It will produce a 2.5 kA, 2.5 MeV, 80 ns electron beam. A critical performance is a +/− 1% flat, 80 ns long, plateau as required for the beam transport along the accelerator.

title: Attention-Enhanced Time-Frequency Deep Learning for Impact Localization on Composite Lamination Structures
authors: Siyuan Zhang, Wensong Jiang, Zai Luo, Li Yang, Siqi Feng, Jun Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: It is important to locate the impact source on composite lamination structures for the invisible damage caused by low-velocity impacts. However, desired signals of a low-velocity impact are easily overwhelmed by a strong noise in a 1-D time-domain with sparse sensor networks, reducing localization accuracy. To address this problem, a DenseNet-convolutional block attention module (CBAM) model is proposed based on image regression to realize high-precision impact localization on composite lamination structures. To reduce the interference of baseline drift and high-frequency noise components, the collected signals are reconstructed by a discrete wavelet. To highlight all the signal features in both the time and frequency domains, the reconstructed signals are transformed into a database of time-frequency spectrograms by using the short-time Fourier transform (STFT) and image augmentation methods. A 650 × 650 × 3 mm composite lamination structure is designed to validate the efficiency of our suggested method. The experiment results demonstrate that the model exhibits excellent global performance when CBAM focuses on spectrograms before the Dense-Block process. The maximum localization errors are 12.813mm for the DenseNet-CBAM model, 26.926mm for the traditional statistical method, and 13.963mm for ResNet-CBAM. The mean localization errors are 6.419mm for the DenseNet-CBAM model, 12.041mm for the traditional statistical method, and 7.873mm for ResNet-CBAM. In all, our suggested DenseNet-CBAM method is superior to traditional statistical methods and general deep learning methods.

title: Design of discrete state feedback current control for a drive system with a permanent magnet linear synchronous motor and LC filter in an application for small cargo transportation
authors: Andrzej Straś, Marek Michalczuk, Krzysztof Jackiewicz, Tomasz Bałkowiec, Thomas Schüning, Walter Neu
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The paper proposes a design procedure for a current control system of a permanent magnet linear synchronous machine for a small cargo transportation system. The drive system utilizes a long stator linear motor, and the vehicle is equipped with permanent magnets. Due to the possible high distance between the inverter and stator, the power circuit contains an LC filter. Therefore, the current controller must deal with a three-phase inductive–capacitive–inductive (LCL) circuit. Moreover, the stator of the machine is divided into segments. This leads to relatively fast changes in the induced voltage when the vehicle is passing through segment boundaries. Therefore, the current controller must deal with fast-changing disturbances. The state feedback control with gains selected using the linear-quadratic regulator approach is used to achieve high-quality system performance. Design and implementation include retuning of the controller gains for variable synchronous frequency. The control system is designed in the discrete domain concerning signal processing delay. The current control system with optimal gains is applied on the digital signal controller and verified experimentally on the test track.

title: RE-Mark: An Identity-Recovery Watermarking Method for Undoing Deepfake Face-Swap
authors: Tomasz Walczyna, Jacek M. Zurada, Zbigniew Piotrowski
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: In response to the growing threat of face‑swap deepfakes, we introduced RE‑Mark. This active zero-bit watermark embeds a compact neural identity signature directly within a facial image and later reconstructs the pre-swap appearance from a single image. The scheme employs a pair of symmetric, attention-enhanced U-Nets acting as an embedder and extractor. It is trained with a specific training pipeline that mixes five different face-swap engines with classical degradations such as noise and blur. This diversity forces the network to learn robust, high-level cues rather than brittle artifact patterns, yielding transparent watermarks that remain visually imperceptible at a peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR) of approximately 36 dB. Unlike previous active defenses that only flag manipulations, RE-Mark hides enough semantic redundancy to recover an authentic face without any external reference gallery, closing the gap between fragile detectors and robust—but non-restorative—watermarks. Therefore, the method equips platforms and investigators with a practical tool for both tamper verification and post‑factum identity restoration.

title: CP-Aware OFDM-Based OOK Signaling
authors: Badr Eddine Ouakouak, Salah Eddine Zegrar, Hüseyin Arslan
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: This letter addresses the challenge of cyclic prefix (CP) problem in orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM)-based on-off keying (OOK) generation for low-power Internet of Things (IoT) systems. We propose a CP-aware waveform design that generates the OOK signal over the entire CP-OFDM symbol duration, potentially breaking subcarrier orthogonality after passing through the channel if the CP is not matched. To enable such a mechanism, OOK has to be generated independently and a modification to the existing OFDM-based OOK generation block is needed. Additionally, a block-wise time shift can be applied to minimize CP mismatch. Analytical discussions and simulations confirm that the resulting interference on legacy subcarriers remains controlled, while OOK detection performance significantly improves, albeit with tradeoffs that should be carefully considered in practical deployments.

title: Design and Validation of a Grasping Force Measuring Vibrotactile Feedback Add-on for Laparoscopic Instruments
authors: Jan-Willem Klok, Yannick Smits, Roelf Postema, Asþor T. Steinþorsson, Jenny Dankelman, Tim Horeman
publish: IEEE Journal of Translational Engineering in Health and Medicine
abstract: Objective: Grasping force control is crucial for safe laparoscopic surgery. However, force feedback is limited as haptic information on grasping strength and tissue stiffness is mostly lost due to internal instrument backlash and friction. This increases tissue trauma risk as excessive grasping forces can lead to (postoperative) complications. This study aims to develop a grasping force feedback providing add-on for a laparoscopic grasper and to validate its impact on skills acquisition in basic laparoscopic skills training. Method: The ShaftFlex, a shaft-based grasping force measurement system providing feedback was designed as an add-on for standard reusable instruments. It consists of a compliant element deflecting proportionally to the applied grasping force, and a Hall sensor measuring that deflection. Influence on skills acquisition was evaluated in a comparative study where novices were divided into a Feedback and No feedback group, performing five training trials of a silicon torus transfer boxtrainer task. Afterwards, both groups performed a post-training task without feedback. Grasping force, time to completion and number of errors were measured. Results: There was a significant difference in mean grasping force between groups for all training trials and the post-training trial. In the Feedback group, there was no significant increase in grasping force when feedback was removed. Conclusions: The ShaftFlex working principle provided a feasible, sustainable method to measure grasping forces exerted by a laparoscopic grasper, enabling immediate haptic feedback. It potentially enhances objective skill assessment, providing feedback on training performance. In a clinical context, the ShaftFlex might be useful in surgery where delicate tissue is grasped.

title: Translational Evaluation of a Machine Learning Based Interactive Lab for Aphasia Rehabilitation in Post Stroke Patients
authors: Mukul Kumar, Rei-Zhe Wu, Shih-Ching Yeh, Eric Hsiao-Kuang Wu, Po-Yi Tsai
publish: IEEE Journal of Translational Engineering in Health and Medicine
abstract: Objective: To address the limitations of conventional aphasia therapy by developing and clinically evaluating a machine learning based interactive lab for personalized rehabilitation in post-stroke patients. Methods and procedures: A four week clinical trial was conducted with 27 aphasia patients, randomly assigned to an experimental group (n = 11) using the Language Interactive Lab and a control group (n = 16) receiving conventional therapy. Language performance was assessed using the Chinese Communicative Aphasia Test (CCAT). System interaction data were also used to train classifiers for aphasia severity and recovery tracking. Results: The experimental group showed statistically significant improvements in 7 out of 9 CCAT subtests (p < 0.05) and a highly significant total score increase (p < 0.001) compared to the control group. Machine learning classifiers achieved up to 91.7% accuracy in predicting aphasia severity and recovery progression. Conclusion: The proposed interactive lab integrates gamified therapy with real time, explainable machine learning assessment, demonstrates clinical efficacy in improving language outcomes, and offers a scalable framework for AI-driven, adaptive neurorehabilitation that has been clinically validated within a hospital setting and designed to align with Taiwan Food and Drug Administration (TFDA) software-as-a-medical-device (SaMD) regulatory principles for translational deployment in clinical environments and hospital investigational use guidelines. Clinical impact: The integration of gamified digital therapy with machine learning analytics supports personalized, data driven intervention for aphasia rehabilitation in both clinical and home settings, particularly in resource limited environments. Clinical and Translational Impact Statement: This study supports Clinical Research by demonstrating that AI-powered digital therapy significantly improves language outcomes in post-stroke aphasia patients and offers a pathway to scalable, at home neurorehabilitation.

title: Toward Reliable Wireless BMS: Robust Battery State Estimation Under Noise and Uncertainty
authors: F. Naseri, C. Barbu, A.C.S. Jensen, P. Setoodeh, J.A. Romero Baena, N. Hevele, E. Schaltz
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: Wireless Battery Management Systems (wBMSs) are emerging as a promising solution for electric vehicles, offering benefits such as reduced wiring complexity, improved modularity, and scalability. However, wireless communication introduces new challenges, including susceptibility to noise, electromagnetic interference, and data loss, which can compromise battery state estimation accuracy. Robust algorithmic methods are thus essential for ensuring reliability and functional safety. In this paper, we first present data transmission analysis in an experimental wBMS setup developed in the European project HELIOS. Second, we propose a robust parameter estimation algorithm that identifies battery model parameters and noise characteristics. Lastly, we develop a noise-tolerant Adaptive Extended Kalman Filter (AEKF) for state-of-charge estimation. The AEKF is optimized using a genetic algorithm and incorporates a Bernoulli-based packet loss detector with an online-identified model to reconstruct missing data. The proposed methods are validated using experimental data under varying noise and packet loss scenarios. Results show estimation errors under 1% at 30 dB SNR and a twofold reduction in estimation drift over 20 driving cycles. Real-time feasibility is demonstrated on a BMS, with reported metrics on memory and computation overhead.

title: Model-Free Thermometry from X-Ray Thomson Scattering Without Deconvolving the Source and Instrument Function
authors: T. Gawne, A. Baczewski, H. Bellenbaum, M. Böhme, O. Humphries, Z. Moldabekov, T. Preston, S. Schwalbe, J. Vorberger, A. Kononov, T. Dornheim
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: X-ray Thomson scattering (XRTS) is a powerful diagnostic technique for warm dense matter as it directly probes the dynamic structure factor (DSF) of a system. However, the measured spectrum is broadened by the source and instrument function (SIF) of the experiment, which needs to be removed in order to extract useful information. Since direct deconvolution is unstable to experimental noise and finite spectral ranges, the de-facto approach to interpreting XRTS spectra is to fit a model to the data, which includes the SIF broadening. However, this means the inferred conditions depend on the model used. More recently, it has been demonstrated that direct deconvolution can be performed by first performing a two-sided Laplace transform on the XRTS spectrum and SIF, and then dividing the two quantities [Dornheim et al., Nat. Comm. 137911 (2022)]. The resulting quantity - the imaginary time correlation function (ITCF) - is the two-sided Laplace transform of the DSF, which contains identical information to the DSF but in an unfamiliar form. For example, the temperature of the system is given directly by the minimum point of the ITCF, meaning this method in principle gives direct access to the system temperature. However, the SIF is challenging to accurately measure, and model forms of the SIF are often used instead, which reintroduces model-dependency in the inferred conditions. Here, we investigate an approach to avoid needing to measure or model the SIF entirely: Using the deconvolution theorem in the Laplace domain, we take the ratio of two Laplace transformed spectra. Provided the two SIFs are sufficiently similar, the SIF terms cancel, and the temperature can again be directly inferred from the minimum point of the raito. We use ray tracing simulations to validate the principle of the approach, and investigate its robustness to SIFs that do not exactly match.

title: Propagation of Intense Laser Pulses in Plasma with a Prepared Phase-Space Distribution
authors: J. Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: In an emerging type of particle accelerator, the laser wakefield accelerator, an intense laser pulse separates the charges by pushing electrons aside creating a wake, similar to that behind a boat on water; the plasma electrons re-converge a short distance behind the laser pulse [1]. Co-moving electrons can ‘surf’ this wake and be accelerated by its strong electric field. The achievable energy and other properties of the accelerated electron bunch depend on the amplitude of the laser pulse and its persistence. Laser wakefield accelerators (LWFAs) use the high-field resilience of plasmas to accelerate electrons to high energies in a compact space. Improving the properties of the resulting electron bunches requires stable acceleration over long lengths. We show, using particle-in-cell simulations, that a stable accelerating structure can be achieved using a pre-pulse to increase the electron density for the main pulse, which forms a co-moving deep plasma channel guiding it over a cm. Stable wakefields are also necessary for ion channel lasers to avoid longitudinal acceleration. The system is an interesting example of non-linear interaction between two laser pulses through the plasma. The prepared phase-space distribution of electrons has been analyzed for wakefield stability and further guiding of the laser pulse [2].

title: Polypyrrole-Metal Hybrid Film Formation Using Various Metal Substrates in Solution Plasma Process
authors: J.B. Nam, H.J. Jang, J.Y. Kim, H.-S. Tae, E.-Y. Jung
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Plasma process in the liquid is a method that utilized strong discharge generated by metal and metal electrodes. Conventionally, this method has been mostly used to create metals or carbon nanoparticles by eroding electrodes or carbonizing solutions from strong discharges. Since the report of a solution plasma device that can prevent carbonization and control oxidation and reduction based on DBD and streamer discharge, not only the synthesis of polymers nanoparticles even films has become possible. In the solution plasma process for polymer film, metal ions are dissolved from a metal substrate during the cycle where the substrate becomes the anode. Therefore, the metal component is doped into the deposited film. This method could be the easiest way to form various polymer-metal hybrid films. In this study, we conducted PPy films formation using a different metal of substrate (Fe, Cu, and Al). It was confirmed that the process worked and PPy films were formed regardless of the material of substrate. Consequently, we made PPy films which contain each different metal component using Al, Fe and Cu substrates in the same process. Detailed plasma properties and characteristics of PPy-metal hybrid films obtained by analysis of various experimental instruments will be discussed.

title: Multi-Objective Optimization of Electromagnetic Loading Device Based on NSGA-II Coupled Finite Element Analysis
authors: F. Wendi, Z. Jian, G. Rui, H. Yiyun
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: As a new type of electromagnetic projectile injection equipment, high speed electromagnetic loading experimental device is used in Tokamak rupture relief device. In this paper, a coupling finite element analysis method based on non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm (NSGA-II) is proposed to solve the multi-objective optimization problem of electromagnetic loading device. Based on the mathematical model of electromagnetic loading orbit-projectile launching process, the orthogonal matrix including projectile mass, orbit size, power supply capacitance, voltage, discharge timing and other parameters is established, and a fuzzy inference system is introduced to convert multiple optimization targets into a single target. The optimal combination of the structural factors of the electromagnetic loading device is obtained through optimization and selection analysis, and the system efficiency and influencing factors of the electromagnetic loading device are studied based on the coupled finite element analysis of the optimal solution.
