title: Image Charge Approximations for CNT-Fiber Emitters in a Molecular Dynamics Code
authors: Y. Zhou, Á. Valfells, K. Torfason, A. Manolescu
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations are a powerful tool for capturing the discrete particle effects involved in electron emission and propagation. They have proven effective in studying how electron emission from microstructures influences beam characteristics, including emittance, current density, and brightness [1], [2]. However, the high computational cost of MD simulations remains a significant challenge. The MD code, RUMDEED, incorporates the image-charge method to evaluate the electric field modified by space-charge effects near the cathode surface. This can be done in an exact manner for specific geometries. By using simplified parametric calculations, the image-charge model can be applied to a broader range of emitter shapes, reducing the computational load while maintaining accuracy in capturing key physical effects. We use machine learning to enable faster and approximate predictions of the electric field near a nonplanar emitter surface. Results for different geometries of CNT-fiber emitters will be presented.

title: Peransformer: Improving Low-informed Expressive Performance Rendering with Score-aware Discriminator
authors: Xian He, Wei Zeng, Ye Wang
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Highly-informed Expressive Performance Rendering (EPR) systems transform music scores with rich musical annotations into human-like expressive performance MIDI files. While these systems have achieved promising Results, the availability of detailed music scores is limited compared to MIDI files and are less flexible to work with using a digital audio workstation (DAW). Recent advancements in low-informed EPR systems offer a more accessible alternative by directly utilizing scorederived MIDI as input, but these systems often exhibit suboptimal performance. Meanwhile, existing works are evaluated with diverse automatic metrics and data formats, hindering direct objective comparisons between EPR systems. In this study, we introduce Peransformer, a transformer-based low-informed EPR system designed to bridge the gap between low-informed and highly-informed EPR systems. Our approach incorporates a score-aware discriminator that leverages the underlying scorederived MIDI files and is trained on a score-to-performance paired, note-to-note aligned MIDI dataset. Experimental Results demonstrate that Peransformer achieves state-of-the-art performance among low-informed systems, as validated by subjective evaluations. Furthermore, we extend existing automatic evaluation metrics for EPR systems and introduce generalized EPR metrics (GEM), enabling more direct, accurate, and reliable comparisons across EPR systems. The repository is available at https://github.com/Bigstool/peransformer.

title: Towards Faithful and Explainable Large Language Models: A Knowledge Graph-Guided Framework for Reasoning Enhancement and Hallucination Mitigation
authors: Chongwen Wang, Zhi Cao, Keqin Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: In recent years, Large Language Models (LLMs) have achieved remarkable performance across various natural language processing tasks. However, they still face significant challenges in complex reasoning scenarios, such as ambiguous inference paths and frequent hallucinations, which hinder their adoption in high-stakes domains like medicine, law, and education. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a novel unified framework that integrates Knowledge Graphs (KGs) to enhance the reasoning ability and factual consistency of LLMs. The framework is designed around two core objectives: reasoning enhancement and hallucination mitigation, and adopts a three-layer architecture to achieve these goals. Each layer is designed to interact through a structured semantic path, providing controllable reasoning guidance and factual grounding. Compared to traditional approaches like Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), the proposed method introduces explicit control over reasoning chains, thereby enhancing interpretability and output fidelity. This paper further analyzes current limitations in generalizability and engineering deployment, and identifies potential directions for future research, such as multimodal knowledge integration and prototype system development. The proposed framework offers a novel perspective on constructing trustworthy and controllable LLM-based systems, paving the way for their broader application in critical domains.

title: Deep Learning-based Binary Analysis for Vulnerability Detection in x86-64 Machine Code
authors: Mitchell Petingola
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: While much of the current research in deep learning-based vulnerability detection relies on disassembled binaries, this paper explores the feasibility of extracting features directly from raw x86-64 machine code. Although assembly language is more interpretable for humans, it requires more complex models to capture token-level context. In contrast, machine code may enable more efficient, lightweight models and preserve all information that might be lost in disassembly. This paper approaches the task of vulnerability detection through an exploratory study on two specific deep learning model architectures and aims to systematically evaluate their performance across three vulnerability types. The results demonstrate that graph-based models consistently outperform sequential models, emphasizing the importance of control flow relationships, and that machine code contains sufficient information for effective vulnerability discovery.

title: Exploring the Characteristics of the MZ Generation and Their Influence on Kidult
authors: Jin-Hee Lee, Jin-Hee Son
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: The global population aged 65 and older is expected to more than double—from 700 million in 2020 to approximately 1.5 billion by 2050. In response to this demographic shift, the silver industry is rapidly expanding. However, this growing market must also evolve its perception of older adults—seeing them not merely as dependent elderly individuals, but as young-at-heart, active consumers with diverse needs and preferences. Among the technologies most prominently integrated into the senior industry, artificial intelligence (AI) plays a central role in shaping modern marketing strategies. AI-based tools such as voice recognition systems and the Internet of Things (IoT) are increasingly being used to support seniors’ health, mobility, and everyday convenience. In particular, AI enhances the senior consumer experience in distribution and digital platforms, enabling greater comfort, autonomy, and access to a premium lifestyle. The growth of the silver industry and the advancement of AI-driven marketing are closely intertwined. As such, it is critical to develop strategic approaches for effectively applying AI marketing techniques to meet the evolving needs of the senior demographic. Therefore, this paper aims to explore the cognitive and behavioral characteristics of senior consumers, review the current status of senior-related industries across countries, and propose an innovative AI marketing model tailored to the transforming senior market.

title: A Study on the Impact of Supervisors’ Coaching Leadership on Organizational Performance — Focusing on the Job Attitudes of Contact Center Employees
authors: MiJeong Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Every organization faces the critical challenge of managing internal relationships and morale to drive performance. Particularly, employees at contact centers—who are at the forefront of customer interaction—play a pivotal role in shaping Organizational Performance. Their Job Attitudes significantly influence the overall quality of service and productivity. This study aims to empirically analyze the impact of supervisors’ Coaching Leadership on Job Attitudes of contact center employees and how such attitudes, in turn, influence Organizational Performance

title: Skin Spots Recognition Using You Only Look Once v11 Neural Network with Multicolor Spectroscopy
authors: Po-Yu Chuang, Chun-Jung Lin, Ya-Hsueh Chien, Po-Jui Lin, Ching-Ta Lu, Yuan-Yu Tsai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: In performing laser treatment for spot removal, doctors need to locate the spots to operate the laser equipment, which might cause eye injuries, a significant risk in clinical practice. Therefore, it is urgent to develop an intelligent method that automatically detects facial spots and estimate and recognize the skin spot type. We developed a method by using the images obtained from the You Only Look Once 9 (YOLO) version 11 neural network recognition multi-spectral detector and combining deep learning and multi-spectral image features to accurately recognize the types of spots, including freckles, dark spots, sun spots, age spots. The method carries out the spot recognition and the depth estimation of spots, and the recognition results are used for the treatment parameter setting and reducing the human judgment of spot type. The developed method provides a scientific basis for setting treatment parameters and reduce human errors in judgment, significantly benefiting medical aesthetics.

title: Conversational Storytelling Agent with Satellite Data: Adapting to User Profiles
authors: Faten EL OUTA, Amit Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: Although satellite programs like Copernicus now provide abundant Earth-observation (EO) data, non-specialists still struggle to access, process, and interpret it. This paper introduces a swarm-agent framework that closes this cognitive and technical gap. Plain-language questions are converted into structured workflows executed by specialized, modular agents that follow the four classic data-storytelling stages: clarifying the user's question, exploring the data, structuring the narrative, and presenting the results. The system then generates a concise story, supported by visuals and straightforward explanations. A proof of concept (POC) using Sentinel-5P data demonstrates how this approach can track pollutant levels in France's Centre-Val de Loire region. The POC shows how a data-storytelling-inspired swarm-agent architecture can make EO insights accessible, intelligible, and transparent to a broad audience in under 10seconds.

title: Beta Elliptic Modeling with Optimal Pixel Selection for Image Steganography Technique using Genetic and Type-2 Fuzzy Logic System
authors: Magesh Mani, Rajeesh Kumar N V, J. Usha, Suresh Govindasamy, V. Mangaiyarkarasi, R. Suganthi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: In today's digital environment, data must be transmitted securely and invisibly. Picture steganography is one way to conceal private data in images. This study introduces Beta Elliptic Modeling with Optimal Pixel Selection for Image Steganography Technique using Genetic and Type-2 Fuzzy Logic System (BEOIGT), a steganographic approach that blends biometric modeling, nature-inspired optimization, fuzzy inference, and genetic learning to improve security. Beta-Elliptic Modeling to examine the characteristics of handwritten signatures, which increases the correctness of data encoding. To locate the optimal pixels for data hiding while preserving image quality, it uses the BES algorithm, which is based on how bald eagles hunt. A genetic algorithm uses a fitness function based on PSNR to optimize essential parameters over several iterations. In addition to analyzing pixel similarity, the system only embeds data when pixels are very similar. BEOIGT's picture quality and resilience surpass that of current models, making it perfect for secure communications in delicate sectors such military transmissions and digital forensics.

title: From Emojis to Emotions: Abstractive Dialogue Summarization with Emotional Supervision Signals
authors: FuRui Wang, ZhenFang Zhu, HongLi Pei
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: The dialogues on the internet usually contain nontextual information including emojis and emotions. However, traditional dialogue summarization tasks primarily focus on textual information, overlooking the importance of non-text elements in conversations. To address this issue, this paper presents a model that utilizes emojis and emotional cues for dialogue summarization (EMOSum), which considers the semantic connections between emoji-induced emotions and dialogue texts to enrich the semantic information of online dialogues. Specifically, we built an emoji library based on the SAMSum dataset and established a mapping relationship between the emoji dataset and dialogues to better preserve the emotional information conveyed in online dialogue emojis. Moreover, we propose an emotion-aware mechanism that captures various emotional categories in emojis and dialogues to generate weak supervision signals, enhancing the model's ability to focus on the crucial emotional context within dialogues and thereby improving the relevance and precision of dialogue summarization. The experimental results on the SAMSum dataset show that EMOSum achieves improved performance, enhancing the emotional expressiveness of dialogue summaries.

title: An Attention-Based Denoising Framework for Personality Detection in Social Media Texts
authors: Lei Lin, Jizhao Zhu, Qirui Tang, Yihua Du
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: In social media networks, users produce a large amount of text content anytime, providing researchers with an invaluable approach to digging for personality-related information. Personality detection based on user-generated text is a method with broad application prospects, such as for constructing user portraits. The presence of significant noise in social media texts hinders personality detection. However, previous studies have not delved deeper into addressing this challenge. Inspired by the scanning reading technique, we propose an attention-based information extraction mechanism (AIEM) for long texts, which is applied to quickly locate valuable pieces of text, and fully integrate beneficial semantic information. Then, we provide a novel attention-based denoising framework (ADF) for personality detection tasks and achieve state-of-the-art performance on two commonly used datasets. Notably, we obtain an average accuracy improvement of 10.2% on the gold standard Twitter-Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (Twitter-MBTI) dataset. We made our code publicly available on GitHub<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup><sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>https://github.com/Once2gain/PersonalityDetection. We shed light on how AIEM works to magnify personality-related signals through a case study.

title: GDA: Multi-Parallel Intrusion Detection Framework with Group-Based Data Augmentation
authors: Xukui Li, Guang Cheng, Wei Chen, Xing Qiu, Zhen Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Due to the complex distribution, class imbalance and limited diversity of network data, existing intrusion detection schemes still face significant performance bottlenecks in fine-grained classification tasks. To address this issue, we propose a multi-parallel intrusion detection framework with Group-Based Data Augmentation (GDA). This framework constructs a heterogeneous detection model ensemble by implementing an adaptive grouping, which partitions similar data into clusters to capture the intricate distribution patterns of network behaviors. This framework establishes a one-to-one mapping between data groups and their dedicated detection models through a grouping-model binding mechanism, forming multi-parallel detection units. Each detection model utilizes Ensemble Autoencoders (Em-AE) for interpretable data augmentation, employs contrastive learning to optimize intra-class and inter-class sample distances, and utilizes a simple classifier for fine-grained classification. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets CIC-IDS-2017 (15-class), CIC-IoT-2023 (29-class), and CIC-IoMT-2024 (19-class) demonstrate that GDA achieves fine-grained classification accuracies of 95.57 %, 96.64 %, and 99.99 %, respectively. Compared to state-of-theart methods, GDA significantly improves intrusion detection in efficiency and accuracy.

title: Enhancing Spatial Reasoning in Multimodal Vision-Language Models via Depth-Aware Feature Integration
authors: Hiroo Tsuji
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Vision-language models such as Contrastive Language-Image Pre-training (CLIP) excel at aligning images and text, yet they still struggle to reason about spatial relationships within a scene. We present a lightweight extension to CLIP that injects a depth modality, fusing RGB and depth features while preserving the model’s pre-trained visual-textual knowledge. Trained and evaluated on dedicated spatial-reasoning benchmarks, our depth-enhanced architecture yields substantial accuracy gains over an RGB-only baseline and produces more human-like judgments of relative position and distance. These findings chart a clear path from 2-D image-language models toward true 3-D spatial understanding. Crucially, the compact design retains the rich semantics learned during CLIP’S large-scale pre-training, enabling markedly faster convergence while matching the final accuracy achieved by training from scratch.

title: Uninterrupted Internet Access: A Peer-to-Peer Alternative for Outage-Proof and Censorship-Resistant Communication
authors: Parita Paneri, M D Nashid Anjum, Syed Muhammad Danish, Wafi Danesh
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: The Internet has become a part and parcel of modern life, where many essential daily activities at the individual and communal level have been relegated. As such, local or national disruptions of Internet services cause severe distress in the national economy, society, and personal aspects. Henceforth, this paper identifies the Internet outage as a digital disaster. Broadly, Internet outage is caused by natural disasters, technical faults, or human-made reasons, with the last factor being the cause. Thus, Internet disruption has been identified as a cybersecurity threat in this paper which violates the resource availability of an authorized user. This paper surveys the alternatives for Internet outage resilience and proposes a hybrid solution considering both corporate and social perspectives. In addition, this paper proposes a social awareness framework aimed to prepare the individual to cope with Internet outage scenarios and minimizing the loss.

title: Uncertainty-Aware Cost-Effective Task Scheduling in Cloud Brokerage Architectures Under SLA Constraints
authors: Wenxuan Huang, Li Ma, Jin Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: This paper studies an important problem of scheduling user-submitted computation tasks in cloud brokerage environments, where task execution times exhibit stochastic uncertainty. Existing scheduling approaches typically assume deterministic task durations, leading to resource over-provisioning or service level agreement (SLA) violations under the impact of task duration variations. To bridge this gap, we formulate an uncertainty-aware scheduling model that minimizes the total monetary cost incurred by the cloud broker considering the penalties for overdue tasks and probabilistic success rate threshold. We introduce the concept of success rate (SR) to represent the fraction of successfully completed tasks, and further impose a lower-bound probability that the scheduling solution satisfies the SR specified in the SLA with varying task execution times. We further propose an improved estimation of distribution algorithm (IEDA), which is a population-based metaheuristic, to solve the resultant stochastic optimization problem. IEDA starts with an improved initialization strategy to generate a population of high-quality initial solutions. Then, IEDA incorporates an efficient sampling strategy that relies on an elite population and a probability sequence to evolve the population. To evaluate the quality of each candidate solution, we employ a greedy-based strategy to map each task to an appropriate computing resource under SLA constraints. Extensive experiments on an Amazon EC2-based cloud platform demonstrate the promising effectiveness and efficiency of our proposed IEDA in solving the uncertainty-affected scheduling problem.

title: Matrix representations of formal diffeomorphisms for applications in geometrical optics
authors: W. Pauls
publish: 2025 Days on Diffraction (DD)
abstract: A generalization of the ray transfer matrix formalism in geometrical optics is proposed, in which the ray tracing map describing light or charged particle propagation from the object to the image plane of an optical system is obtained as a composition of the ray tracing maps of its constituting subparts. Ray tracing maps, computable through power series expansions, are interpreted as formal diffeomorphisms. A representation of formal diffeomorphisms by means of infinite-dimensional matrices is constructed, in which composition of functions corresponds to a matrix product. Thus, the ray tracing map of the entire system can be calculated by matrix multiplication.

title: BurstDetector: An Accurate Low-Overhead Detection Algorithm for Burst Flows in Network Traffic
authors: Bing Xiong, Qida Xiao, Sijie Huang, Jijun Cao, Baokang Zhao, Keqin Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Burst flows in network traffic, are characterized by a sudden increase followed by a sudden decrease in packet frequency over a short period. Their instantaneous high-frequency characteristic easily induces network congestion, performance degradation, and potential cyberspace security risks. Therefore, it is necessary to accurately and promptly detect burst flows for various applications such as intrusion detection, traffic engineering, and network management. However, current work on burst-flow detection faces the issues of low precision and high memory overhead. To address these issues, this paper proposes an accurate low-overhead detection algorithm for burst flows in network traffic called BurstDetector. In the BurstDetector, we first design a low-overhead small-flow filter based on probabilistic data structures, to identify potential burst flows and filter out small flows. Then, we design burst-flow detection table to find out real burst flows and report their information including flow IDs and bursty periods. In particular, we propose a probabilistic replacement strategy based on bursty periods and flow frequencies to accommodate potential burst flows, for precise detection of burst flows. Finally, we theoretically derive the false positive error rate of the small-flow filter and the error bound of the burst-flow detection table in our proposed BurstDetector and conduct experimental evaluations on its performance with real network traffic traces. Experimental results indicate that the BurstDetector achieves the precision of over 95 %, the recall rate of more than 94 %, and the throughput of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{2 7. 8 1} \text{Mips}$</tex>, outperforming state-of-the-art algorithms.

title: Nitrogen Fixation in Air Plasma: Energy Cost and Chemical Kinetics
authors: X. Pei, Y. Li, Y. Luo, C. Man, S. Jiang, T. Zhang, J. Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Air plasma-based NOx production for nitrogen fixation has gained increasing attention due to its nearly cost-free raw materials, relatively safe synthesis process, and high gas conversion efficiency. Although research on air plasma synthesis of NOx dates back over a century, achieving lower energy costs and understanding the detailed chemical kinetics remain significant challenges. This study investigates the characteristics of several common air plasma sources for nitrogen fixation, including dielectric barrier discharge (DBD), DC glow discharge, nanosecond spark discharge, plasma jet, and propeller arc<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[1]–[7]</sup>. The results identify two key parameters controlling NOx production efficiency: the average electric field E and the average gas temperature T. Several strategies to reduce the energy cost of air plasma nitrogen fixation are proposed, such as lowering the dimensionless parameter <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\chi$</tex>, selecting appropriate electrode materials to reduce cathode-fall voltage, and coupling warm plasma with catalysts. Furthermore, laser-induced fluorescence (LIF) diagnostics were employed to study the kinetic processes of NO and NO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> formation in DC air plasma. The spatial distribution of NO was initially concentrated within the discharge channel and later evolved into a doughnut-shaped distribution outside the channel. This phenomenon suggests a potential correlation with the thermal decomposition of NO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>.

title: Vulnerability Analysis of IoT Protocols Based on CVE glossary and Penetration Testing Techniques
authors: Dina Satybaldina, Tolegen Aidynov, Fariza Tebueva, Saken Tleuberdin, Konstantin Malakhov, Gulsipat Abisheva
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: This article provides a comprehensive study of the vulnerabilities of Internet of Things (IoT) platforms and protocols using penetration testing methods. The work includes both analysis of publicly available vulnerability databases (in particular, the CVE database) and practical testing of IoT systems using the example of an air quality monitoring network using the LoRaWAN protocol and Wi-Fi (WPA2). An algorithm for the automatic collection and processing of vulnerability data has been implemented, and a web interface for interactive visualization and filtering of information has been developed. During the practical experiment, critical vulnerabilities were identified both in wireless networks (LoRaWAN, Wi-Fi WPA2) and in IoT devices themselves, such as using standard passwords, transmitting unencrypted data, and the possibility of Replay, Brute Force, and Deauthentication attacks. Based on the results of the analysis, recommendations have been formed to eliminate vulnerabilities and requirements for new device authentication schemes have been outlined. The obtained developments can be used by developers to improve the security of IoT systems.

title: Emittance Characterization of an Electron Source from a Velvet Cold Cathode
authors: C. Fourment, B. Cadilhon, B. Cassany, C. Vermare
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: LIA (Linear Induction Accelerator) Flash X-ray radiography uses electron beams produced by injectors, then accelerated and focused on high Z material targets [1]. Spot size of a focused beam strongly depends on its emittance, and so, depends on the emittance of the injector's beam. In the context of the development of an injector based on an IVA (Induction Voltage Adder) driving a cold cathode, we are conducting a study in order to characterize and understand the emittance associated with the extraction of a beam from the cathode surface, including in multi-pulse operation.

title: Efficient Generative Adversarial Networks for Color Document Image Enhancement and Binarization Using Multi-Scale Feature Extraction
authors: Rui-Yang Ju, KokSheik Wong, Jen-Shiun Chiang
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: The outcome of text recognition for degraded color documents is often unsatisfactory due to interference from various contaminants. To extract information more efficiently for text recognition, document image enhancement and binarization are often employed as preliminary steps in document analysis. Training independent generative adversarial networks (GANs) for each color channel can generate images where shadows and noise are effectively removed, which subsequently allows for efficient text information extraction. However, employing multiple GANs for different color channels requires long training and inference times. To reduce both the training and inference times of these preliminary steps, we propose an efficient method based on multi-scale feature extraction, which incorporates Haar wavelet transformation and normalization to process document images before submitting them to GANs for training. Experiment results show that our proposed method significantly reduces both the training and inference times while maintaining comparable performances when benchmarked against the state-of-the-art methods. In the best case scenario, a reduction of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 \%}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 6 \%}$</tex> are observed for training and inference times, respectively, while maintaining the model performance at 73.79 of Average-Score metric. The implementation of this work is available at https://github.com/RuiyangJu/Efficient_Document_Image_Binarization.

title: Cognitive Computing for Personalized Recommendation Systems in E-Commerce
authors: Geetha Manoharan, Mini Jain, Nivedita Pandey, Kawerinder Singh Sidhu, Rahul Joshi, Nikhil Polke
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Cognitive computing has become a paradigm-shifting concept in the improvement of personalized recommendation systems on the territory of the e-commerce sector. With cutting-edge deep learning (DL) technologies, in the form of the powerful Transformer frameworks, Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) and Variational Autoencoders (VAEs), it is now possible to capture user behavior, context, and preferences in a never-before-seen level of accuracy. Such models are more than conventional collaborative filtering with incorporation of real-time user interaction, semantics content interpretation, and multi-modal data integration. An outstanding instrument in this field is Amazon SageMaker, that enables the scope of scalable DL-driven recommendation engines by propelling model preparation, maximization and impression. By using them in conjunction with cognitive computing, it is possible to do adaptive learning, natural language understanding and emotion-aware personalization, essentially transforming user engagement and purchase intent in e-commerce platforms.

title: Equipment Maintainability Design Verification Based on RAG
authors: Senlin Zhu, Qingqing Song, Xingxin Li, Qingqing Hu, Ke Li
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: The maintenance design verification in the early stage of equipment development relies on the professional knowledge and experience accumulation of verification personnel, and the accuracy and efficiency of verification results are difficult to guarantee. Artificial intelligence technology provides new ideas for equipment maintenance design verification, but its accuracy and reliability in specific knowledge fields still need to be improved. To address this issue, this paper proposes a maintenance design verification based on Retrieval Enhanced Generative Technology (RAG). By constructing a professional domain knowledge base and utilizing the powerful generation function of Large Language Model (LLM), RAG is extended to access specific domain knowledge bases or authoritative knowledge bases, thereby improving the accuracy of retrieval in specific knowledge domains. Equipment maintenance design verification based on RAG can not only conduct a “census” of complex equipment, but also avoid manual verification omissions caused by time and experience limitations, effectively improving the quality and efficiency of maintenance verification.

title: Time-Intent Enhanced Sparse Sequence Recommendation
authors: Haolu Sun, Jinghua Zhu, Wei Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: The sequential recommendation, aimed at predicting the next item in a user's session based on historical interactions, is crucial for enhancing personalized recommendation systems. Existing neural network-based methods, such as recurrent and self-attentive architectures, predominantly focus on modeling user-centric sequential patterns, often overlooking item temporal dynamics and high-order connectivity between users and items. These limitations hinder their ability to effectively capture the intricate relationships that drive user behavior. To address these challenges, this study proposes a novel model. This model leverages a bipartite graph structure to encode both user-item interactions and high-order connectivity, integrating temporal, positional, and intent information. Using a position-augmented temporal graph convolution in combination with a self-attention-based aggregator, the method concurrently derives time-varying embeddings for users and items, which improves the capture of sequence dependencies and collaborative cues. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate the superior performance of the proposed model against state-of-the-art baselines, achieving a better balance between accuracy and computational efficiency, thereby making it highly applicable to real-time recommendation scenarios.

title: Making the Case for LLM-Generated Automated Program Repair Benchmarks
authors: Yasser Ebrahim
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Automated Program Repair (APR) has made significant strides in recent years, particularly with the integration of large language models (LLMs) and deep learning techniques. Yet despite this progress, one fundamental issue continues to hinder advancement: how we evaluate these systems. Many of today’s APR benchmarks suffer from serious limitations—including small dataset sizes, synthetic or unrealistic bug scenarios, overfitting risks, ambiguous evaluation criteria, and a narrow focus on certain programming languages.In this paper, we take a critical look at these challenges by identifying eight core limitations in widely used benchmarks. We then explore how LLM-generated benchmarks can help overcome these obstacles. Finally, we address some potential concerns about LLM-generated benchmarks and propose a quality assurance and validation framework.By combining the strengths of LLMs with thoughtful benchmark design, this work lays the foundation for more robust, diverse, and meaningful evaluation frameworks—paving the way for future breakthroughs in APR research.

title: Electrode Longevity on a Prototype Plasma Lens for Positron Matching
authors: N. Hamann, M. Formela, G. Loisch, G. Moortgat-Pick
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Future particle colliders rely on high current positron sources to meet the demands on collision events per time. As the positrons beams are highly divergent after their generation inside of solid targets, their low-loss delivery to the experiment is highly dependent on a so-called optical matching device at the positron source, which focuses the particles into the downstream accelerator sections. For the positron source of the International Linear Collider (ILC), an active plasma lens has been proposed as optical matching device. Such plasma lenses, where a current is driven through a discharge plasma to produce a symmetric focusing force for the positrons moving collinear with the plasma current, can provide focusing forces superior to conventional focusing devices. The prototype of an active plasma lens for positron focusing was developed and tested in a collaboration between the University of Hamburg and DESY. Initial experiments revealed plasma instabilities and substantial copper sputtering from the discharge electrodes. This contribution will discuss results of longevity tests conducted across different pressure ranges and electrode materials.

title: Data Mining–Based E-Commerce Sales Prediction Model
authors: Man Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: Effective sales prediction is essential for stock control, marketing strategies, and general business operations in e-commerce. In this study, an e-commerce sales prediction model was constructed based on machine learning, advanced tree ensembles, and deep learning. To develop the model, linear regression, support vector machines, random forests, XGBoost, and CNNs were compared. Then, the direct and non-direct influence factors and features in online purchase were identified to extract parameters. The categorical data were cleaned, imputed, normalized, and encoded. The identified features were pre-processed by using a 3D tensor and CNN for the model to learn hierarchical spatial-temporal patterns. Prediction accuracy was improved by using the CNN’s learned feature vector as input to the XGBoost regressor, resulting in a hybrid CNN-XG model. Lastly, the data acquisition, system integration, and performance were monitored over time.

title: Poster: An Amplitude-Phase Model for Shadow Fading
authors: Gan Luan, Shiyu Zhang, Zhenjia Chen, Chunyi Yue
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Shadowing occurs frequently in suburban as well urban wireless transmission environments and deteriorates signal strength and quality. The well known model for shadow fading is strictly an amplitude model and the lack of a model for the phase of shadow fading represents a gap in the wireless communication theory. Recalling that the lognormal model for the amplitude of shadow fading is physically based on obstacles in the radio transmission path and the central limit theorem for sums of random variables, a novel model for the phase distribution is proposed. The phase distribution model is based on a limit theorem for modulo sums of random variables. A persistence property of the uniform distribution in finite modulo sums is discussed.

title: An Optimized Key Distribution Protocol to Perform Secure Wireless Data Transmission in Heterogeneous WSN Environment
authors: G D Vignesh, Abla Suliman Hussein, OVSS Prasad, KMuralibabu, P Nishitha, S Purushotham
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Securing wireless communication in heterogeneous Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) remains a critical challenge due to the diversity of node capabilities and constrained resources. This paper introduces an Optimized Key Distribution Protocol (OKDP) designed to ensure secure, energy-efficient, and scalable data transmission in such heterogeneous environments. The methodology integrates node classification into high-capacity cluster heads and low-power sensing nodes, followed by identity-based lightweight authentication. A Firefly Optimization Algorithm is used over a matrix-based key pre-distribution approach, with minimum memory overhead and maximum key-sharing likelihood. Forward and backward secrecy is achieved by use of dynamic key establishment through elliptic curve Diffie-Hellman (ECDH) and hash-based rekeying. The protocol is also reinforced by the fact that a trust-aware intrusion detection module is in place isolating compromise nodes in real time. The proposed OKDP achieved an average key sharing probability of 94.18%, compromised node tolerance of 85.26%, energy consumption of 1.45 J, and an operational accuracy of 96.42% across various simulation scenarios. Its significantly higher performance in resilience, energy consumption, and communication overhead are confirmed by comparative results against well-known benchmark protocols (LEAP+, ECC-KPS, SPINS, etc.). The privacy-sensitive characteristics of the privacy-preserving data aggregation are secured through the adoption of the homomorphic encryption, which does not hinder the computational tractability. OKDP architecture is highly scalable and flexible and could therefore be well suited to the IoT present-day use cases such as smart farming, combat surveillance, and medical supervision. This paper, therefore, proposes a secure and effective protocol that is lightweight, less CPU intensive and optimized to support real-time secure transmission of data in WSNs composed of heterogeneous nodes.

title: Frequency-Enhanced Cross-Domain Self-Supervised Anomaly Detection
authors: Zhuohan Yu, Heng Wang, Zitong Qi, Yuanyuan Meng, Xiushuang Yi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: TSAD is of great significance in fields such as industrial monitoring, smart cities, and network security. In recent years, methods based on contrastive learning and domain adaptation have shown promising performance in cross-domain TSAD tasks. However, these approaches primarily rely on timedomain features, which limits their effectiveness in identifying frequency-sensitive anomalies, such as periodic anomalies or abrupt frequency changes. To address this, this paper introduces a frequency domain enhancement module, based on ShortTime Fourier Transform (STFT), into a cross-domain detection framework. This module's output is then fused with the original time-domain representation to enhance the model's ability to capture complex patterns. We conducted extensive experiments on benchmark datasets, including MSL and SMD. The results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms both baseline and mainstream approaches in key indicators such as F1score, Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic Curve (AUC), and Area Under the Precision-Recall Curve (AUPRC), thereby validating its robustness and effectiveness in complex scenarios.

title: Constructing an In-the-Wild Spoken Dialogue Dataset Based on Youtube Dialogue Videos
authors: Yuki Sato, Sanae Yamashita, Shinnosuke Takamichi, Ryuichiro Higashinaka
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: The development of a spoken dialogue system requires a large-scale spoken dialogue corpus. However, existing Japanese spoken dialogue corpora are limited in size. In this study, we propose a method for constructing a large-scale Japanese spoken dialogue dataset by collecting dialogue videos from YouTube. Since YouTube hosts videos across various genres, recording environments, and speakers, it provides diverse spoken dialogue data that can be utilized for developing spoken dialogue systems. The constructed dataset primarily consists of twospeaker dialogues but also includes many multi-party dialogues involving five or more participants. Additionally, it contains only a small amount of non-dialogue speech, making it suitable for the development of multi-party dialogue systems. Furthermore, since the dataset includes many relatively long dialogues, it is expected to be useful for long-duration dialogue applications.

title: Evaluation of the Effect of an Electromagnetic Aggression on Electronic Equipment - ESCAPADE 2 Project
authors: B. Lalle, Y. Delvert, J. Pothée, T. Delhoume, A. Chauloux, M. Majed, M. Salauze, L. Pecastaing
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: One of the aims of the Escapade 2 project is to compare the effects produced on electronic targets by two high-power pulsed sources: an Ultra Narrow Band (HPM) source developed by the ITOPP company, and an ultra-wideband (UWB) source developed by the SIAME laboratory. A first version of this UWB source was developed as part of the initial ESCAPADE project [1]. These two sources are based on very different technologies:

title: Application of IOT in Aquaponics System for Automatic Monitoring and Maintenance of Fish Ponds and Hydroponics
authors: Wineu Putri Setiana, Nazwa Nurazizah Zain, Firscha Aulia Ghassani Fikri, Rr. Nurrizka Puspa Wiranti, Nyoman Karna, Yulinda Eliskar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: Indonesia faces challenges in aquaculture and agriculture due to land limitations, water scarcity, and declining interest among the younger generation. Aquaponics offers an alternative by combining fish and plant cultivation in a closed, resource-efficient ecosystem. This study presents an IoT-based aquaponics system that monitors and controls pH, water level, temperature, and light intensity, and includes real-time plant monitoring and automated fish feeding via a mobile app. Experimental results show reliable sensor performance with 6.75%-13.60% error margins. The system effectively supported Brassica rapa var. chinensis growth, especially under semi-outdoor conditions. These findings highlight the system's potential for scalable smart farming in educational and commercial settings.

title: Poster: Maximizing Computation Rate via Joint Base Station Association, Task Offloading, and Resource Allocation in WP-MEC HetNets
authors: Xun Tong, Yingying An, Shubin Zhang, Kaikai Chi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: This paper studies a wireless-powered mobile edge computing (WP-MEC) system for energy-sustainable and lowlatency IoT services. We address the joint optimization of base station selection, binary offloading, bandwidth, and computational resource allocation under time-varying channels. The problem is formulated as a mixed-integer nonlinear program (MINLP). To solve it efficiently, we propose a decomposed framework: deep reinforcement learning optimizes discrete decisions (association and offloading), while convex optimization allocates continuous resources (bandwidth and computation). Simulation results show that our method significantly improves energy efficiency and computational performance over benchmarks, demonstrating its effectiveness for resource-constrained MEC systems.

title: ATBCC: Adaptive Trend-Based Congestion Control
authors: Jiaqing Dong, Xuejing Diao, Jinyao Yan, Haojun Huang, Hao Yin, Chen Tian
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: The emergence of applications such as online teaching and virtual laboratories in campus networks imposes extremely stringent requirements on network bandwidth, latency, and reliability. However, the congestion control algorithms widely adopted in current campus networks struggle to meet these demands. Campus network users are often concentrated, and their usage periods exhibit significant overlap. The greedy nature of TCP frequently leads to queue accumulation in buffers, resulting in frequent packet loss and retransmissions, which severely degrades the network experience. Given that modifying the protocol stack of terminal devices is often infeasible, this paper innovatively proposes an Adaptive Trend-Based Congestion Control (ATBCC) strategy. ATBCC performs congestion control at the access point router. It ingeniously adjusts the receive window field in the TCP header of ACK packets. This allows ATBCC to accurately calculate the target rate of each flow and proactively regulate the traffic rate in advance. Evaluations demonstrate that in wireless network scenarios, ATBCC significantly outperforms TCP CUBIC. Specifically, it shortens 95% of the queue length, reduces the average latency by 82.5%, and decreases the tail latency by 89.1%. In dynamic wireless link scenarios, ATBCC reduces the average latency and queue length by 40% and 60% respectively compared with Zhuge. ATBCC efficiently utilizes bandwidth while maintaining short queues, offering a novel solution for campus network congestion control.

title: Greenhouse Environment Monitoring System Based on STM32 and WiFi
authors: Suping Zhang, Jiajia Tian, Yefeng Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: We developed a monitoring system with sensors to collect and process the greenhouse environment data. The system controls the fan and LED light to adjust the greenhouse’s environmental conditions. The WiFi module was adopted to upload the environmental data to the cloud platform so that users could view the real-time environmental data of the greenhouse. The experimental result showed that the system monitored the greenhouse environment well and effectively regulated the environmental data.

title: Coexistence of Military and Commercial 5G Mobile Network
authors: Sangchul Oh, Nakwoon Sung, Heesang Chung, Kiwon Kim, Woocheol Kim, Heasook Park
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: The convergence of commercial 5G mobile networks and military mobile infrastructures presents both an opportunity and a challenge for national defense communication systems. The paper proposes architectural models that enable secure and efficient coexistence between these two domains. Three coexistence strategies are introduced: (1) dual-PLMN integration via multi-operator core network (MOCN), (2) RAN slicing under a shared PLMN using distinct single network slice selection assistance information (S-NSSAI) values, and (3) inter-PLMN federation employing security edge protection proxy (SEPP) interfaces. Each architecture for military network incorporates zero trust principles and software defined perimeter (SDP) to ensure data plane isolation and session-based access control. Performance evaluation confirms that although SDP introduces throughput degradation, it is essential for enforcing military-grade security policies. The proposed models support flexible deployment scenarios such as dual-use base stations and joint operations paving the way for secure 5G adaptation in defense environments.

title: Design and Implementation of Information Management System of Greenhouse
authors: Yan Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: A greenhouse information management system was developed based on the Internet of Things (IoT), wireless sensor networks, ZigBee communication, and big data analysis technology. The system monitors and controls the environmental parameters of a greenhouse to maintain the optimal conditions for plant growth and avoid wasting excess resources. The hardware of the system consists of sensors for data collection, a coordinator for data aggregation, and a microprocessor for data processing and command execution. The host computer’s control program is responsible for processing environmental data and the communication protocols of controllers based on ZigBee technology. The system was designed to enhance modularity and resource savings to build an effective solution. The system monitors and remotely controls the environmental conditions of the greenhouse in real-time and enhances the efficiency and sustainability of agriculture.

title: Using Image Recognition and Local Large Language Model-Driven Dialogue for Confirming Dynamic Intentions
authors: Sinan Chen, Masahide Nakamura, Kiyoshi Yasuda
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: Understanding human intention is critical in healthcare, where direct communication might be limited. We developed a dynamic intention recognition system for elderly care, integrating visual data and conversational interactions. Building upon in-home fixed-point cameras and lightweight image recognition systems, facial, skeletal, and hand features were detected to monitor behavior changes. Image-based analysis alone is often insufficient to fully grasp the intentions behind observed actions. Therefore, we developed a multimodal system that combines (1) image-derived contextual cues and (2) dialogue with an interactive agent, analyzed through locally executable large language models (LLMs). Specifically, we utilized locally deployable models such as Meta-Llama and Llama 3.1 within a web-based interface built on AnythingLLM, enabling real-time conversational intention estimation without compromising data privacy. The developed system performs image-based context extraction, conversational prompting with embedded intentions, and time-windowed log analysis using local LLMs for chronological intention estimation and confirmation. Five participants were recruited to compare their self-reported intentions with those inferred by the system using document similarity metrics. The results demonstrated the feasibility of the system and its real-time, privacy-conscious performance in elderly home care. The system contributes to the advancement of human-agent collaboration and lays a foundation for adaptive, intention-aware support systems.

title: A Validation Problem for Modeling Triggered Gas Switches Using the Particle-in-Cell Method
authors: M. Flynn, M. Hopkins, A. Steiner
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Designs of triggered gas switches with lower global warming potential alternatives to SF6 are of great interest to existing and future large-scale pulsed power facilities. Requirements for such switches include short runtimes (time from trigger to conduction), low jitter (variance of runtime), and high reliability against pre-fire (unintended spontaneous discharge). The particle-in-cell (PIC) method has previously been applied to study Z's SF6-insulated laser triggered gas switch [1]. PIC is being revisited for this regime of collisional gas physics as an aid to experiment for SF6-alternative switch designs.

title: A Hierarchical Attention Model for Local and Global Feature Integration in RCS Classification
authors: Yida Wu, Caiyun Wang, Jianing Wang, Xiaofei Li, Ying Nan
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Radar Cross Section (RCS) target recognition plays a vital role in radar automatic target recognition (RATR) systems. As a critical electromagnetic signature, RCS encodes unique target characteristics include geometric profiles, structural features, and material properties. However, the complex nonlinear relationship between RCS patterns and target attributes introduces significant challenges for accurate target identification. To address this, this paper proposes a hierarchical attention model for local and global feature integration, named LocalGlobal Efficient Channel Attention (LGECA), which enhances RCS feature representation through modeling both local-specific interactions and global contextual dependencies. Moreover, an improved multi-scale convolutional neural network is proposed as the backbone architecture, leveraging the LGECA module to establish new state-of-the-art performance in RCS classification. The comprehensive experimental results validate the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed module against conventional approaches.

title: On-Site Fluid Pressure Measurement Device for Vascular Flow Evaluation
authors: Fara Azzahra Dinata, Hadyan Fawwaz Anshori, Muhammad Salman Al Farisi, Muhammad Iqbal, Narendra Kurnia Putra
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Instrumentation, Control, and Automation (ICA)
abstract: Intravascular therapy is a minimally invasive procedure that treats vascular abnormalities and requires accurate hemodynamic assessment to ensure effective treatment. Monitoring intravascular pressure within blood vessels provides insight into flow dynamics and pathological conditions. Current devices, including pressure-sensing guidewires, rely on embedded MEMS sensors near the tip, introducing electronic components into the body, while other interventional tools, such as stents, either remain passive or measure only non-hemodynamic parameters. To address these limitations, we developed a catheter-based pressure measurement system that enables direct pressure acquisition without flow disruption or internal embedding electronics, providing a more accurate hemodynamic assessment. The system employs a Pitot tube catheter integrated with MEMS-based sensors to evaluate pressure profiles in a 3D-printed vessel model with 30Calibration of both the pressure sensor and the peristaltic pump ensured reliable data acquisition throughout the operating range. The system successfully captured the pressure distribution along the vessel, including a significant pressure drop of approximately 420 Pa across the stenotic region and partial recovery downstream. These results validate the feasibility of Pitot-based catheter probes for in situ flow evaluation and demonstrate their potential for future applications in experimental and computational hemodynamics.

title: Diff-BGC: A Diffusion Model-Based Framework for Network Traffic Imputation
authors: Jigang Wen, Qixue Lin, Xiaocan Li, Kun Xie, Yuxiang Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Accurate and complete network traffic data is essential for effective network monitoring, anomaly detection, and performance optimization. However, in real-world scenarios, network measurements are often incomplete due to measurement overhead, equipment limitations, and complex topologies. To address this challenge, we propose Diff-BGC, a novel imputation framework based on diffusion models tailored for network traffic data. Diff-BGC transforms the traffic matrix at each time step into a bipartite graph structure and reformulates the imputation task as the estimation of unobserved edges. It leverages both static and dynamic node features, as well as topological information, to construct expressive edge embeddings. A conditional diffusion training strategy is introduced to guide the model in learning meaningful representations from partially observed data, enabling it to perform robust conditional generation through a reverse denoising process, We evaluate the proposed framework on real-world dataset GÉANT. Experimental results demonstrate that Diff-BGC outperforms several methods under varying sampling ratios, achieving lower normalized mean absolute error (NMAE) and normalized root mean square error (NRMSE). Even when the sampling rate is only 2 %, the normalized mean absolute error (NMAE) generated by our method is only 0.67. The results confirm the effectiveness and adaptability of Diff-BGC in practical network traffic imputation tasks.

title: Advancing Surgical Anaesthesia through AI-Integrated Hypnotherapy: From Malaysia to the Global Landscape
authors: Gauri Krishnaswamy, Peh Kiam Heng, Nandan Kishur Kar, Anusia Rajan, Srayoshi Barua
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Introduction: A hypnotherapy is a procedure which have evolved out of a Greek word hypnos (meaning sleep) and has come to be a valid complementary procedure used in anaesthesia of patients undergoing surgery to bring about a benefit in the reduction of peri-operative anxiety, managing pain in the post-operative stage and enhancing recovery. Hypnotherapy has also continued to be evolved through addition of machine learning and virtual reality (VR) into the hypnotherapy treatment plans and more personalization and scaling of clinical practice with the advent of artificial intelligence (AI). Its clinics potential is old, as in the past, e.g. in 1829, Jules Cloquet conducted a mastectomy by hypnosis.Purpose: The systematic review will gauge the character of hypnotherapy, which is automated with AI technologies and applied to the surgical anaesthesia, particularly the adoption trends of the considered method in Malaysia and its application to other nations.Methodology: A very wide literature review was conducted in a number of peer-reviewed databases and the outcome of peri-operative anxiety, analgesic reduction, and recovery were analysed. The works, which proposed AI-enhanced approaches of delivery, such as virtual reality-generated hypnosis and monitoring of patient responses with the help of AI were also considered.Findings: The significant beneficial outcomes of hypnotherapy were demonstrated with the reduction of the level of anxiety, the reduction of the reliance on pharmacological analgesics, and the reduction of the recovery period. Hypnotherapeutic treatments on patients that were shown as potentially customized and standardized through AI-driven tools were predictive analytics of patient vulnerability and immersive VR hypnosis environment. However, there is the barrier of training in the form of infrastructural and cultural scepticism that prevents adoption- especially in Malaysia.Conclusion: Hypnotherapy using AI can result in colossal possibilities in improving the surgical anaesthesia practice. The additional training, development of AI-based protocols, and the improvement of the population awareness should be enlarged to synchronize the Malaysian healthcare policies with the improvements the world experiences in the digital and non-pharmacological anaesthetic care.

title: Optimizing RPC Performance via Dynamic Scheduling in Heterogeneous Multi-Path Environments
authors: Changsong Yang, Yuran Liu, Yong Ding, Hai Liang, Zhenyu Li, Chunhai Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: In distributed network measurement systems, clients frequently establish multiple parallel Remote Procedure Call channels with remote nodes. Given the pronounced heterogeneity in link characteristics—such as bandwidth, round-trip time, and packet loss rate—dynamically scheduling data streams across these paths is essential for maintaining system performance and stability. To address this challenge, we propose a refined multipath scheduling algorithm that incorporates round-trip time, packet loss rate, and bandwidth into a unified, multidimensional path scoring mechanism. Leveraging this scoring framework, the algorithm adaptively selects the most suitable channel for each transmission in real time. To validate the algorithm's performance, we construct a three-path heterogeneous network and compare the proposed method with several established scheduling strategies, including Round-Robin, Random Path Scheduling, Weighted Round-Robin, and Delay-Aware Packet Scheduling. Experimental results indicate that the proposed algorithm consistently delivers higher throughput under varying network conditions. Specifically, as the round-trip time of the primary path increases, the algorithm achieves a throughput improvement of 13.7% to 26.8% over Weighted Round-Robin. Similar gains are observed under elevated packet loss rates, underscoring the algorithm's enhanced adaptability, robustness, and overall effectiveness in heterogeneous environments.

title: Active Multi-Object Tracking for 3D Reconstruction with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
authors: Heng Li, Cheng Cai
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This study addresses the problem of active multi-object tracking in 3D environment, with a particular focus on application in 3D reconstruction. The objective is to achieve continuous tracking of multiple targets by dynamically controlling the poses of multiple cameras in real time. Unlike existing approaches, this work is conducted in a 3D environment populated with multiple cameras and targets, aiming to maximize the minimum 2-coverage (M2C) and the triangulation angle. Such multi-view coverage is crucial for enhancing the accuracy of 3D reconstruction. To this end, we propose a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework that decomposes the task into a two-level policy structure. A highlevel coordinator assigns targets to low-level executors with the goal of optimizing the M2C and the triangulation angle, while each low-level executor is responsible for tracking its assigned targets by minimizing the relative angle to them. Experimental results in a custom-built 3D simulation environment demonstrate that the proposed method substantially improves coverage efficiency compared to baseline approaches.

title: Poster:Cross-Neighborhood Feature Fusion Network for Point Cloud Classification and Segmentation
authors: Baoquan Zhang, Fanqi Meng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Most existing point cloud classification and segmentation methods employ single-scale neighbourhoods as network inputs, struggling to capture point-wise geometric variations within point cloud neighbourhoods, hindering efficient learning of point cloud geometric shapes and edge features. In this paper, we propose a Cross-Neighborhood Feature Fusion Network for 3D Point Cloud Classification and Segmentation, which is innovative in the following aspects: Extract multi-neighbourhood geometric semantic features through dynamic neighbourhood sampling; enhance point cloud geometric structure and edge features via dimensionality elevation, adaptive downsampling and inverse displacement coordinate correction. Meanwhile, aggregate local geometric semantic features through centre-of-gravity-driven feature curve analysis to resolve implicit spatial relationships between entities. Experimental results demonstrate the proposed network achieves favourable performance on the ModelNet40, ShapeNet, and S3DIS datasets.

title: A Sliding-Window Range–Bearing Scan STAP for Underwater Active Sonar Target Detection
authors: Weisi Hua, Yixin Yang, Yuxuan Chen, Xianghao Hou
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This paper presents a Sliding-Window Range-Bearing Scan STAP (SWRB-STAP) method for underwater active sonar target detection. First, the fast-time data are partitioned into fine-range cells, and at each cell a local covariance estimate is obtained via a guard/training sliding-window strategy to precisely suppress reverberation at different ranges. Next, narrowband STAP filtering is performed in parallel across all range cells and bearing angles to generate a two-dimensional range-bearing power map. Semi-physical/synthetic results demonstrate that SWRB-STAP can significantly suppress clutter and reliably detect weak targets in reverberant environments.

title: Design of Management Information System for International Continuing Education of Higher Vocational Colleges
authors: Lin Hao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: This study aims to develop a continuing education management information system (ICE-MIS) tailored to international continuing education in high vocational colleges. The system enhances administrative, academic, and financial processes and effectively manages international education programs. For system automation, the following management modules were included for (1) student management for grade inquiries, course scheduling, and student records, (2) course assignments and faculty coordination, (3) admissions and recruitment, and (4) payroll and faculty remuneration. The ICE-MIS streamlines operational workflows to maximize the impact of international education by enabling efficient data management and informed decision-making. With its modular design, the system ensures easy updates and maintenance and a seamless experience for students, faculty, and administrative staff.

title: Interactive Spatial Audio Rendering on Mobile Devices: A Two-Stage User Interface with Adaptive HRTF Selection and Real-Time Room Acoustics Simulation
authors: Shravan Raghunath, Kanishk AL, Sailesh S, Rishabh Gupta, Saurav Gupta, Ramesh R
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This paper presents an Android-based spatial audio rendering application that provides an immersive audio experience through a two-stage user interface. The first stage focuses on configuring room acoustics and selecting pre-stored HRTFs using a photo of user's face, while the second stage offers an interactive interface for placing sound sources and customizing the environment. The proposed Android application simplifies the process of rendering spatial audio signals with an average latency of 1.27 ms per 20 ms input frame. It maintains a low computational overhead (average CPU usage of 30.6 %), ensuring seamless customized spatial audio processing and rendering over mobile devices. The user interface is designed to be highly intuitive, as validated by subjective evaluations using Mean Opinion Score (MOS) ratings from 15 participants, who reported high user satisfaction and spatial realism (average MOS of 4.72 out of 5). The system supports dynamic listener movement and interactive control over sound source positioning, enhancing sound customization in different acoustic environments. Furthermore, the lightweight implementation with an app size of 104 MB makes it suitable for deployment on a wide range of Android devices, enabling accessible and realistic customization of spatial audio experiences for everyday users.

title: Interference Evaluation Between HAPS and UAVs Considering Overlapped Ground Service Coverage
authors: Hyunduk Kang, Ho-Kyung Son
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: We evaluate the interference between High-Altitude Platform Stations (HAPS) and Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs), considering their overlapped ground service coverage under various parameters, including the distance between HAPS and UAV, the radius of ground service coverage, the altitude, and the ground user density. Based on coexistence scenarios, we examine situations in which a neighboring UAV interferes with a HAPS, and vice versa-a neighboring HAPS interferes with a UAV. We also investigate the required keep-out distance, i.e., the separation distance between HAPS and UAV that ensures a target interference probability. Numerical results demonstrate how these parameters affect the interference probability, emphasizing the importance of careful deployment of both aerial platforms and the planning of their respective ground service coverages.

title: Design and Commission of Solid State Switch Driver in SLAC Subbooster Modulator
authors: Xupeng Chen, Jeffrey de Lamare
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The LINAC sub-booster modulator is a pulsed power supply to provide a 30kV pulse to drive a klystron in SLAC LINAC. It has used vacuum tetrode as pulse switch for more than 60 years. With the vacuum tetrode availability becoming less and its cost surging, a natural choice is to use solid state switch in this pulsed power modulator. To commission solid state switch in LINAC sub-booster modulator, a driver board is designed to drive a BEHLKE HTS-LC2 series MOSFET based switches. The design concept and some concerns in design will be presented. The driver board is universal for all HTS-LC2 series switches because they share the same driver signals and connections. After the driver is commissioned, two AI systems are introduced to design one core part of the driver, the results are presented here. During the commission of the driver board in the LINAC sub-booster modulators, some problems happened and were addressed.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning-Optimized Resource Allocation System for Agile Management
authors: Charu Bisaria, R. Srikanth, Ahmed Kateb J. Al-Nussairi, Ali Dawod Ali, Rouaida Kadhim A. Al-Hussein, Balasubramanian Durairaj
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: This paper proposes Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) optimizable Resource Allocation System focused on an agile management environment. Agile processes usually encounter variable task requirements and priorities as well as limited resources, which make effective allocation a difficult puzzle. We suggest a DRL framework that is using Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) algorithm to manage the dynamic allocations of the resources: the time, the budget, the task assignment of the developers. The authors view the agile process as the modeled system of a custom simulation environment where an agent learns the best policies by trial-and-error interaction. Sprint backlogs, team capacities, and task complexity determine the state, and velocity, resource utilization, and delivery efficiency determines the rewards, which are sprint velocity, resource utilization, and delivery efficiency. The experiments prove that the DRL approach is respondent to any shifts in the project conditions, as well as highly efficient in comparison with the static allocation strategies in terms of velocity and efficiency as well. The framework favours resource management in agile teams with an intelligent solution to scaling, making it the first step towards smarter inclusive project management in more voluminous and dynamic development environments.

title: Improving Operational Efficiency in Busan Port: A Predictive Approach to Truck Congestion
authors: Seong-Hyeon Jo, Ji-Yeon Kim, Ki-Hwan Kim, Young-Jin Kang, Seok Chan Jeong
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: This study aims to enhance the operational efficiency of port management and the stability of logistics flow by predicting vehicle traffic within the container terminal at Busan Port. The target variable for prediction is the number of inbound and outbound vehicles per time unit (inout_status), and high-frequency observational data collected at 5-minute intervals was used to analyze temporal patterns such as time of day, day of the week, and month, along with seasonal variations. A PyCaret-based AutoML framework was applied to compare multiple regression models, and a semi-automated structure was designed to predict future vehicle counts using real-time data. Through this approach, the study empirically demonstrates the feasibility of prediction-based decision-making for port operations.

title: HiSS: A Lightweight Non-Preemptive Approach for Efficient GPU Cluster Scheduling
authors: Yunhe Han, Bing Hu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: The rapid growth in deep learning (DL) model complexity has escalated computational demands, making efficient GPU cluster scheduling critical for managing resources and minimizing job queuing times. Traditional scheduling approaches, such as preemptive and optimization-based methods, often introduce significant overhead or require intrusive modifications, limiting their practicality in production environments. We propose the Hierarchical Simple Scheduler (HiSS), a lightweight, nonpreemptive scheduling framework that classifies DL jobs into four categories based on GPU demand and runtime, scheduling them hierarchically using tailored heuristics like Quasi-Shortest-Service-First (QSSF). By prioritizing small, short jobs and mitigating head-of-line blocking, HiSS achieves significant reductions in average Job Queuing Time (JQT). Additionally, we explore flexible scheduling policies within each category, allowing combinations of QSSF, Shortest-Job-First (SJF), and Tiny-JobFirst (TJF) strategies to adapt to diverse workloads. Evaluations on real-world traces from the Helios dataset demonstrate that HiSS outperforms baselines like SJF and QSSF, with flexible policy configurations yielding further improvements. HiSS offers a practical, low-overhead solution for production-grade GPU clusters, balancing efficiency and simplicity, making it easily deployable in production-grade GPU clusters.
