title: Parallel Animal-Centered Ethics
authors: Jake Peacock, Lisa Brey, Leigh Levinson
publish: Proceedings of the ACM 12th International Conference on Animal-Computer Interaction
abstract: Purpose-bred laboratory animals are underrepresented in the animal-computer interaction (ACI) literature. What the ACI community has published on research with such animals suggests that there are no examples of work utilizing animal-centered approaches. Globally, hundreds of millions of rats and mice are kept for scientific research, representing an overwhelming majority of vertebrate laboratory animals. Standard caging for rats prevents them from exhibiting some natural behaviors, including standing on their hind legs, gnawing to wear down their incisors, and living in social groups. Nonetheless, there is a significant body of laboratory animal welfare research that has been developed since the 1940s that is focused on the effects of enriched housing conditions on rats. An investigatory review of laboratory animal welfare literature reveals, a subset of recent scholarship (n=32) in this area takes interest in transitioning toward an animal-centered ethical framework. That work is happening independently of and parallel to the ACI community’s development of its own animal-centered ethics. In this literature review of laboratory animal science journals, half of the articles on rat (and/or mouse) welfare already used technologies that could be leveraged for ACI research. Slightly less than half (47%) of articles were considered to be ethically incompatible with ACI, at least partially. However, only 3 (9%) papers were identified representing work that were wholly incompatible. Of the remaining 53% of articles that were compatible with ACI, 4 (13%) were identified as functionally equivalent to ACI’s ethical framework, i.e., animal-centered. This finding stands in opposition to prior ACI work that suggested there were likely no examples of animal-centered research with laboratory animals. Clear opportunities for researchers in the ACI community to collaborate with laboratory animal scientists on research projects improving the well-being of rats and mice, and ultimately to all lab animals.

title: Generation of Runaway Electrons and Their Interaction with Discharge Plasma During Pulsed Gas Breakdown
authors: B. Huang, C. Ren, S. Zhao, Y. Gao, C. Qi, C. Zhang, T. Shao
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Runaway electrons (RAEs), overcoming friction drag and continuously accelerated by the external electric field, are universally observed in gas discharge phenomena both in nature and in the laboratory. This work investigates the generation of RAEs and their interaction with discharge plasma during pulsed gas breakdown. It is demonstrated that the micro-protrusion on the cathode and its electric field enhancement are critical to the initial acceleration of field emission electrons with low energy and dictate the flux of RAEs. Furthermore, the second electron acceleration process during breakdown initiation and potential lift-up due to plasma screening near the cathode determine the formation of anomalous energy RAEs, which have an energy higher than the potential difference between the cathode and anode. These RAEs, experiencing decreasing friction drag with energy, will maintain their energy during the ionization wave propagation formed as gas breakdown happens and induce pre-ionization ahead of the ionization wave front. A promoted density of seed electrons will improve the randomness of discharge channels and help to form a diffuse wide streamer with a diameter comparable to the discharge gap. This work illustrates the critical factors for forming RAEs and their effect on gas breakdown.

title: Experimental Results of the Uniform-Field Parallel-Plate Platform on Cornell's COBRA Generator
authors: C. Chavez, T. Mason, S. Lavine, R. Curry, A. Sarracino
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Magnetically insulated transmission lines (MITLs) are the final stage in coupling energy from pulsed power machines like the Z Machine to a target for many high energy density physics experiments. The extreme current densities and voltages in the Z Machine MITL give rise to significant challenges in its design, operation, and performance optimization. Effects such as field emission, explosive electron emission, and thermal desorption of contaminants can generate plasmas on electrode surfaces, which significantly affects machine performance. These environments are difficult to diagnose in situ due to limited diagnostic access in this region and the low frequency of shots per year. Therefore, a test platform, a Uniform-Field Parallel-Plate Platform (UFP3), has been developed to replicate the MITL current densities of multi-MJ pulsed power generators on university scale <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\square 100 \text{kJ})$</tex> drivers. The platform enables the generation of uniform, tunable fields while providing a direct line of sight through the electrode gap for enhanced diagnostic access. Here we present diagnostic results of the UFP3 fielded on the COBRA driver at Cornell University, including 12 -frame visible self-emission imaging, XUV imaging, avalanche photodiodes (APDs), gated visible spectroscopy (GVS), interferometry and shadowgraphy for kA pulses with a ns rise time. 12 -frame imaging and APD data show that the plasma self-emission consistently turns on at the same time for all experiments, proving the repeatability of this platform and its utility as a power flow platform to collect much more data than on Z alone.

title: DSRD Breakdown Voltage Against Snapping Time Tradeoff: Simulation and Analysis
authors: A. Usenko, S. Bellinger, A. Caruso, J. Eifler
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: At the previous pulsed power conference in Amsterdam, September 2024 our team reported optimized DSRD doping profile determined by simulation. One of new, unexpected and important conclusions was that for minimizing DSRD switching time, the DSRD must have zero base thickness. In other words, the best doping profile has only graded n-side doping and p-side doping that meet at p-n junction.

title: Design and Validation of a Power Divider for Multi-Channel GNLTL Synchronization
authors: N. Charrel, A. Zhabin, L. Pecastaing, A. Silvestre de Ferron, V. Gavrilenko, A. Chauloux, J.-C. Diot, L. Sousbielle, A. Catrain
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The gyromagnetic nonlinear transmission line (GNLTL) has garnered significant attention for its potential as a compact, solid-state source of high-power microwaves. Its RF power can be significantly increased by using an in-phase multi-channel configuration, whose effectiveness largely depends on the synchronization quality. To achieve high-fidelity synchronization of multiple GNLTLs, it is crucial to feed them with the same input signal.

title: Particle-Fluid Hybrid Simulation of Acceleration and Pinch Dynamics in Dense Plasma Focus
authors: Q. Sun, Y. Dong, W. Yang, H. Zhang, Q. Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Dense Plasma Focus (DPF) is a kind of high-efficiency plasma device with high energy density, which has important application potential in the fields of fusion energy, radiation source and material science. However, due to the coupling effects of complex multi-scale physical processes in DPF, it is difficult to achieve high-precision simulation of its entire physical process with a traditional single numerical model. In this paper, a particle-fluid hybrid model is established to study the dynamic process of dense plasma focus. In the hybrid simulation, the particle method is used to simulate kinetic ions, the fluid method is used to simulate electrons, and the Maxwell equation and FDTD (finite difference time domain) method are used to solve the electromagnetic field. Aiming at the time step advancement of hybrid simulation, the self-consistent explicit iteration of hybrid simulation is realized by using the prediction-correction method. Plasma acceleration, pinch and final focus formation are covered in the simulation, and the interaction of various physical effects such as electromagnetic field, fluid mechanics and particle dynamics are considered. On this basis, we compare the simulation results with the experimental data. The simulation results are in good agreement with the experimental data in terms of the spatialtemporal evolution of the plasma and the physical characteristics of the plasma focus region, which verifies the effectiveness and reliability of the hybrid simulation method.

title: Thermal Analysis and Design Optimization of DC Link for Long Pulse Operation in the BEST Tokamak
authors: Z. Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The BEST is a Tokamak fusion device for achieving D-T (deuterium-tritium) burning, where the DC Link serves as the critical electrical circuit for delivering current and voltage from the magnet power supply to the superconducting coil. This function is essential for controlling plasma shape, position, and providing ohmic heating. Long-pulse operation of Tokamak devices demands precise thermal management to ensure stable performance, making it vital to regulate the operating temperature of DC Link within a defined range. In this paper, the thermal equilibrium analysis of DC Link designed for a rated current of 55 kA is presented. Utilizing DC Link's low inductance and high insulation properties, the positive and negative conductors are assembled in insulating layers and metallic casing. The temperature distribution within the conductors and insulating materials under two cooling scenarios is analysed: without cooling water and with water cooling for long-pulse operation. Additionally, the impact of contact resistance on the temperature rise at the junctions of the multi-terminal busbar is calculated. The relationship between busbar length, conductor, metallic casing and insulating material temperatures, and flow velocity is analysed by the finite-element method. The maximum operating time of the DC busbars without cooling water is analysed to ensure the reliability of the DC Link system. This work provides critical insights into the thermal management of high-current DC Link systems for superconducting magnets in long-pulse Tokamak operations.

title: Hydrogen and Solid Carbon Production via Methanepyrolysis in a Rotating Gliding Arc Plasma Reactor
authors: Z. Ali, H. Song, U.N. T. Nguyen, H.C. Shim, S.M. Lee, M. Majeed, D.H. Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Plasma-induced methane pyrolysis is a promising hydrogen production method. However, few studies have focused the decomposition of pure methane as a discharge gas. Herein, a rotating gliding arc reactor was used for the conversion of methane (discharge gas and feedstock) into hydrogen and solid carbon. Methane conversion, gaseous product selectivity, and energy usage efficiency (specific energy requirement for hydrogen production (SER)) were investigated as functions of operating parameters, e.g., specific energy input (SEI), residence time, and reactor design. SEI was positively (almost linearly) correlated with methane conversion and hydrogen yield and negatively correlated with SER. Conversion and efficiency of energy usage increased when reactor designs providing higher thermal densities were used. With the increasing flow rate of methane at constant SEI, the reaction volume and, hence, the effective residence time of the gas inside the reaction zone increased, which resulted in methane conversion and hydrogen selectivity enhancement. The solid carbon featured four distinct domains, namely graphitic carbon, turbostratic carbon, multilayer graphene, and amorphous carbon, which indicated a nonuniform temperature distribution in the reaction zone. But it seems that graphitic carbon dominates amorhphous one. This study highlights the potential of rotating gliding arc plasma systems for efficient methane conversion into hydrogen and valuable solid carbon products.

title: Blockchain-aided Cooperative Market Offering for Distributed Renewable Energy Producers
authors: Yukai Wang, Qisheng Huang, Long Shi, Zhe Wang, Shaoyong Guo, Hao Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Distributed renewable energy (DRE) systems, such as so larpanels, wind turbines, and small-scale hydroelectric systems, are increasingly participating in electricity markets. The unpredictable nature of renewable energy imposes a significant impact on the strategic offering decisions of DRE producers in two-settlement electricity markets. Furthermore, small-scale DRE producers face challenges, such as minimum size threshold requirements, that prevent them from par ticipating in wholesale electricity markets. Driven by these issues, this work proposes a blockchain-aided coalitional game framework to enable the cooperative renewable offering strategies of distributed producers, wherein these producers are incentivized to form a grand coalition to participate in electricity markets and share real-time balancing risks. Moreover, it is verified that the grand coalition is optimal for maximizing the total profit of the producers, indicating the benefit of cooperation. It is challenging to obtain the core of the coalition due to the huge computational complexity. Nevertheless, a closed-form profit allocation mechanism is constructed and proved to be in the core of the coalition. This indicates that none of these producers has an incentive to leave the grand coalition. Furthermore, we design a smart contract to automate the coalition formation and profit allocation processes of DRE producers on the blockchain. Finally, numerical studies are conducted to validate the established theoretical results. Simulation results show that the proposed approach increases individual utility for all participants and improves the system's overall profit by up to 9.4% compared with the independent baseline.

title: Differential-Privacy-Preserving Distributed ADMM Using Load-Balanced Sparse Allreduce Communication
authors: Dongxia Wang, Yanli Lin, Xin Peng, Wenwu Xie, Jingxin Luo, Liang Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive Communications and Networking
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) enables efficient machine learning by connecting terminal devices to coordinate distributed model training. In typical scenarios, each device is treated as a computing node, training local models with its local data and updating the global model by exchanging parameters with neighbors. However, as the dataset scales grow, communication costs limit the scalability of distributed machine-learning algorithms. Moreover, parameters sharing increases the risk of privacy leakage. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a distributed alternating direction method of multipliers based on load balancing sparse allreduce (LBSA-ADMM). Unlike traditional distributed ADMM algorithms, LBSA-ADMM requires each node to compute and communicate only its associated features, drastically reducing overhead. More importantly, LBSA is tailored for performing allreduce on transmission parameters of all nodes. LBSA divides transmission parameters according to the weight of each feature, effectively balancing communication overhead across nodes. Furthermore, the paper proposes a differential privacy ADMM (DP-LBSA-ADMM) to enhance the security of LBSA-ADMM by injecting noise into penalty parameters. This algorithm dynamically adjusts penalty parameters to balance accuracy and privacy, with convergence guaranteed theoretically and empirically. Experimental results demonstrate that LBSA significantly reduces communication costs compared to state-of-the-art methods, DP-LBSA-ADMM achieves faster convergence than comparable ADMM algorithms.

title: High-Resolution Integrated Water Vapor Estimation Using the Gaussian Mixed Long Short-Term Memory Network: A Satellite-Based Inter-Comparison and Data-Fusion
authors: Lingke Wang, Duo Wang, Joseph Awange, Hansjörg Kutterer
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Water vapor, the most influential greenhouse gas, is central to Earth’s climate system, affecting the hydrological cycle, energy balance, and atmospheric dynamics. Integrated Water Vapor (IWV) is a key variable for understanding these processes. However, conventional IWV retrieval methods—such as ground-based sensors, satellite observations, and numerical weather models (NWM)—are often limited by spatial resolution, temporal continuity, and retrieval accuracy. To address these challenges, this study introduces a novel deep learning method GMLSTM-HIM, a High-resolution IWV estimation Model (HIM) based on a Gaussian Mixture Long Short-Term Memory (GMLSTM) framework. By integrating Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) and NWM inputs, including weighted mean temperature, GMLSTM-HIM utilizes a bidirectional LSTM structure and probabilistic output sequences to improve IWV estimation accuracy while quantifying uncertainty arising from spatial heterogeneity. Compared to ERA5 and VMF3, the model achieves average RMSE reductions of 68.44% and 36.15%, respectively. The model’s performance is further evaluated through inter-comparisons with MODIS and Fengyun satellite-derived IWV products, highlighting both the accuracy of GMLSTM-HIM and the complementary strengths of satellite observations. The results suggest that, of the satellite datasets examined in this case study, the MODIS 5 km product exhibits the highest consistency with the GMLSTM-HIM model estimates, outperforming the higher-resolution MODIS 1 km and FY-3D 1 km products in terms of product reliability (measured by root mean square error and correlation). A data fusion strategy is also proposed, combining model and satellite estimates to preserve fine-scale details and enhance robustness. Overall, GMLSTM-HIM provides a robust framework for high-resolution IWV retrieval, with significant potential to advance atmospheric studies, climate surveillance, and operational weather forecasting within the remote sensing community.

title: Tradeoff between Covertness and Transmission in NR V2X: Traditional and LLM-assisted Cases
authors: Qiang Fu, Mingkai Yu, Yongpeng Shi, Jiajia Liu, Nei Kato
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: Covert communication can reduce the security overhead of messages in New Radio (NR) Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) and provide a higher level of privacy assurance. However, it also introduces a tradeoff between covertness and transmission. In this paper, we explore the tradeoff between covertness and transmission in NR V2X communications and propose a covert scheme, Covert Semi-Persistent Scheduling (C-SPS). To elucidate this tradeoff in the traditional case, we derive the theoretical results based on stochastic geometry, which accounts for the fundamental processes of semi-persistent scheduling, including transport block re-selection and resource collision. Based on our derivation, the optimal setting of C-SPS is obtained to maximize the covertness of message delivery while satisfying the transmission requirements of NR V2X. More importantly, we assess the covert threat posed by intelligent adversaries equipped with the Large Language Model (LLM) capable of reasoning based on the tailored chain of thought. Finally, we evaluate the effectiveness of C-SPS in balancing the tradeoff under both traditional case and LLM-assisted case.

title: CoMPLe: Cross-Modal Hybrid Prompt Learning for End-to-End Multimodal Emotion Recognition
authors: Jue Feng, Zhengpeng Zhao, Lianmin Zhou, Yuanyuan Pu, Jiale Ye, Dan Xu, Jinjing Gu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Affective Computing
abstract: The quality of features directly affects the accuracy of Multimodal Emotion Recognition (MER). A key challenge in this context is the effective extraction of dynamically interactive multimodal features to enrich conversational emotion representations. However, existing approaches are often constrained by non-end-to-end architectures, overlooking the significance of feature extraction in MER. To address the problem of dynamic interaction in emotion feature extraction, this paper introduces an end-to-end network based on Cross-Modal Hybrid Prompt Learning (CoMPLe). The model takes raw video as input and leverages three prompt mechanisms to guide large-scale pre-trained encoders in extracting emotionally salient features with latent correlations. Specifically, we design a cross-modal soft prompt learning strategy to mine complementary information across modalities and dynamically adjust the cross-modal semantic space. To capture stage-dependent characteristics, deep feature prompts are incorporated to progressively learn intra-modal contextual representations. Furthermore, a label prompt mechanism is proposed to construct hard prompt templates from emotion labels. Finally, the highest cosine similarity is computed between each unimodal feature and the label prompt templates to activate factual knowledge relevant to emotion recognition. Experiments on three public datasets show that the end-to-end network proposed in this paper surpasses the existing State-Of-The-Art baselines.

title: Zadoff-Chu-Aided Backward-Compatible CP-OFDM IoT Transceiver
authors: Wafa Agli, Hamza Haif, Hüseyin Arslan
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: The emergence of the internet of things (IoT) has driven the demand for connectivity solutions that operate efficiently while remaining fully compatible with legacy orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM). This letter presents a novel transceiver architecture for IoT connectivity, designed within the framework of CP-OFDM systems. The proposed scheme embeds frequency-shifted Zadoff-Chu (ZC) sequences into a selected set of OFDM subcarriers. These subcarriers are integrated alongside conventional data symbols, ensuring full spectral compatibility and coexistence with legacy cellular systems. At the receiver, a correlation-based detection approach is employed for symbol recovery, eliminating the need for FFT-based demodulation. The proposed design is described, and its detection performance is evaluated against LoRa under various scenarios, demonstrating its effectiveness for resource-constrained IoT deployments.

title: Ortho-OPD: an Automatic Osteotomy Planes Design Model for Orthognathic Surgery Based on Deep Learning
authors: Yiming Wang, Xiangmin Li, Yang Yang, Mengjia Cheng, Xu Zhang, Jiahao Bao, Hongjun Qian, Xinyi Huang, Zhihan Wu, Suncheng Xiang, Yaofeng Wen, Hongbo Yu
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Orthognathic surgery is applied to restore esthetical facial profile and functional occlusion for patients with dentofacial deformity. Virtual surgical planning (VSP) is indispensable for precise and individualized treatment. Manually designing osteotomy planes is time-consuming and highly experience-dependent. This study aimed to develop and validate an automatic osteotomy plane design method based on deep learning. Methods: A deep learning model, Ortho-OPD (orthognathic osteotomy planes de signer), was proposed, consisting of a segmentation network and the random sample consensus (RANSAC) algorithm. The segmentation network was based on a convolutional neural network (CNN), orthognathic segmenting the craniomaxillofacial (CMF) CT data. Osteotomy planes were then defined by the RANSAC algorithm. Ortho-OPD was trained on 71 samples and tested on 31 cases. The performance was evaluated quantitatively and qualitatively. Results: Ortho-OPD functioned smoothly, and all cases were successfully performed. The 3D boundary-sensitive loss was employed to optimize precision. Evaluation metrics included accuracy and clinical efficiency. The mean dice similarity coefficient (DSC) was 0.920.032 in CMF seg mentation. Ortho-OPD showcased excellent productivity, taking an average of about 9 seconds to complete virtual bimaxillary osteotomy compared to manual work. The angular errors between the predicted planes and ground truth planes, plus the shortest distance from the neural tube or the adjacent apical points to predicted planes, were examined, indicating no significant difference and reliability for preserving vital anatomical structures. Overall, the automatic osteotomy plane design from raw CT data was realized using Ortho-OPD, composed of CNN and RANSAC, providing an efficient and ideal alternative in orthognathic osteotomy planning.

title: A Hybrid Framework for Scalable Data Quality: Comparing PySpark and AI-Powered Validation in Microsoft Fabric
authors: Dinesh Eswararaj, Vandana Kollati, Lakshmana Rao Koppada, Ram Sekhar Bodala, Ajay Babu Nellipudi
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The rapid growth of big data demands robust frameworks to ensure data quality in distributed platforms, as poor data quality undermines insights in domains like e-commerce and social media analytics. Traditional PySpark-based validation excels in syntactic checks (e.g., pattern violations) but struggles with semantic anomalies (e.g., sentiment drift, null detection). Large Language Models (LLMs) offer context-aware validation but face scalability and cost challenges. This study proposes an Adaptive Hybrid framework that integrates PySpark’s rule-based efficiency with AI-powered contextual validation in Microsoft Fabric’s Lakehouse environment to deliver high-performance data quality assessment. The framework uses a composite performance score (F = 0.4A + 0.4S − 0.2E) to quantify trade-offs in accuracy (A), scalability (S = 1/T), and development effort (E), ensuring reliable and efficient validation without runtime optimization. The weights reflect enterprise priorities for precision and throughput. Evaluated across four data quality scenarios null detection, pattern violations, semantic mismatches, and sentiment drift using real-world Twitter airline sentiment and Amazon product review datasets, the framework achieves high accuracy (~0.9), scalability (1.898 s for 5,000 rows in syntactic tasks), and low effort (E ≈ 0.3). PySpark dominates syntactic validation (F1-score = 0.791 for pattern violations), while AI and Hybrid methods significantly improve semantic recall (0.674 for mismatches). Unlike prior syntactic-only or text-classification frameworks, this approach bridges structured data quality gaps, offering a scalable, intelligent solution for modern analytics platforms.

title: High-Resolution Extended Finite Control Set Model Predictive Control for Three-Phase Two-Level Grid-Connected Converters
authors: Yonglei Zhang, Wei Jiang, Xibo Yuan, Sergio Busquets-Monge, Yan Li, Ruijie Zhu
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Finite control set model predictive control is an advanced control strategy for power converters. However, when applied to the control of grid-connected converters, it still faces several practical problems such as high current distortion, variable switching frequency and wide harmonic spectra. Although various improved MPC strategies have been proposed, how to solve the above problems of FCS-MPC only using the finite control set manner is still a challenge. In this article, a novel finite control set model predictive control for three-phase two-level grid-connected converters designated as high-resolution extended FCS-MPC (EFCS-MPC) have been proposed. By redefining the possible selectable switching options within a control cycle, the number of options within the control set of a three-phase two-level converter can be increased from 8 to millions, only limited by the capabilities of the selected digital controller (e.g. DSP or FPGA). The proposed method can not only reduce current distortion, and realize fixed switching frequency but also can keep the advantages of the FCS-MPC such as high dynamic response speed, simple and straightforward structures. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed high-resolution EFCS-MPC can significantly outperform the conventional FCS-MPC.

title: Terahertz demethylation for cancer therapy
authors: Hee Jun Shin, Hee-Jin Yang, Joo-Hiuk Son
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Quantum Electronics
abstract: Terahertz (THz) radiation has garnered attention in medical imaging owing to its non-ionizing characteristics. THz cancer imaging utilizes amplitude and/or phase changes resulting from variations in the cell structure and water content of cancerous tissues. To identify cancer-specific signals using THz radiation, DNA from various cancer cells was observed to exhibit a resonance feature at approximately 1.6 THz, which was attributed to DNA hypermethylation. DNA methylation is an epigenetic alteration that precedes genetic mutations during cancer development. Although pharmaceutical demethylation agents effectively reduce DNA methylation, they cause numerous side effects. We demonstrated that 1.6-THz radiation can effectively reduce the level of DNA methylation in cancer cells and tissues, as well as in extracted DNA. This review provides comprehensive details regarding the THz-mediated demethylation of cancerous DNA that may contribute to the development of cancer treatments using THz radiation.

title: Bi-Directional Coevolution for Multimodal Multiobjective Optimization With Local Pareto Sets
authors: Mengfan Li, Hu Peng, Zhanyan Cai, Dunlu Peng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Evolutionary Computation
abstract: Multimodal multiobjective optimization problems (MMOPs) feature multiple Pareto sets (PSs) corresponding to a single Pareto front (PF). While most multimodal multiobjective evolutionary algorithms (MMEAs) focus on locating multiple global PSs, they tend to overlook local PSs that provide valuable decision diversity despite exhibiting slightly inferior objective values. In this paper, a bi-directional coevolutionary algorithm, termed MMEA-BDC, is proposed for MMOPs with local PSs, which integrates tractive and diffusive search mechanisms to simultaneously discover both global and local PSs. Specifically, the tractive mechanism preserves the individuals with the best fitness, which tend to be located around global PSs, thereby guiding the search toward the global PF. Meanwhile, the diffusive mechanism evaluates individual fitness based on an improved local convergence indicator, allowing individuals near local PSs to be identified and preserved, thereby promoting convergence toward local PF. These individuals are further refined through a niche-driven filter to retain those contributing to decision space diversity. Additionally, a dual-space neighbor replacement strategy is designed to comprehensively consider the crowding degree of individuals in both decision and objective spaces, effectively balancing population diversity across the two spaces. Experimental results on several benchmark suites of MMOPs demonstrate that MMEA-BDC effectively discovers both global and local PSs and achieves superior competitiveness compared to seven state-of-the-art MMEAs.

title: Adaptive Cut-Off Frequency EMS Tuning Methodology Applied on a Long Range UAV Powered by a Hybrid Fuel-Cell System
authors: Thomas Pavot, Renaud Kiefer, Tedjani Mesbahi, Edouard Laroche
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Multi-source hybrid power systems combining fuel cells (FC), lithium-ion batteries, and supercapacitors (SC) are increasingly considered as viable alternatives to fossil-fuel propulsion for long-endurance unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), due to their improved energy efficiency, extended mission duration, and reduced environmental impact. For these systems, the energy management stratregy (EMS) must alocate the power demand in a way to maximize the life-time. This paper compares two strategies using a rule-based approach within the frequency domain. The first strategy is based on a fixed cut-off frequency to distribute load current across multiple sources. In contrast, the second strategy dynamically adapts the switching frequency according to the state of charge of the SC. A complete model of the hybrid energy system is developed, and a systematic tuning procedure for both control strategies is presented. Performance comparison on different flight cycles shows a significant reduction in FC current variations with the adaptive frequency strategy, thus limiting ageing. The results show that this approach requires low computing power, does not require additional equipment, but improves performance for all flight cycles.

title: Directed Energy Drilling Using High-Power Microwaves
authors: L. Zhang, R. Bamford, K. Ronald, I. Timoshkin, I. V. Konoplev, D. C. Speirs, A. J. MacLachlan, C. G. Whyte, T. Wong, S. MacGregor, B. Bingham, S. Eves
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The DIGGER (Drilling and Integrated GigaHertz-Generated Energy Resource) project explores the feasibility of adapting Directed Energy Drilling technologies, including plasma and microwave, for Lunar and Asteroid applications. This paper reviews the state-of-the-art microwave drilling techniques, identifies their space-use challenges, and reports on progress in microwave thermal co-simulations.

title: Data-Driven Prediction of Kerf Angle in AWJM of Hemp Fiber Composites Using Advanced ML Algorithms
authors: Lavanya M, R. Dilli Babu, G B Santhi, A. Prasad, R. Nandhakumar, C. Ramesh Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: In this study, three machine learning (ML) models, such as Support Vector Regression, Gradient Boosting Regression, and Artificial Neural Networks, are used for predicting the kerf angle in hemp fibre reinforced polymeric composites that are machined by an abrasive water jet. The R-squared, MAE, and RMSE metrics were used to assess the regression performance. With the lowest RMSE (0.3000), lowest MAE (0.1245), and greatest R-squared (69.56%) of all the models, ANN showed the best prediction accuracy. From this work, it was noticed that GBR trailed closely behind, surpassing SVR. Metrics like accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score were calculated for the classification analysis. ANN demonstrated strong classification performance by achieving the greatest overall accuracy (0.85) and perfect precision (. With balanced measures, GBR demonstrated excellent classification performance as well. In both classification and regression, SVR trailed. The outcomes demonstrate how well ANN models the behaviour of kerf angles. These results can be applied to sustainable composite material machining parameter optimization.

title: DOLPHIN: Diffusion Model-Based Approach for Coastal Sea Temperature Forecast Bias Correction
authors: Qixiu Li, Xiang Zhu, Junxing Zhu, Xiaoyong Li, Xiaoli Ren, Jingnan Wang, Ruiqing Qi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Accurate sea temperature forecasts are crucial for economic and other climate change estimates. However, due to bias, the accuracy of historical simulations and the reliability of future predictions are limited. Moreover, along the coast, such bias is particularly pronounced due to environmental complexity. Prior studies employed deterministic modeling approaches to address this problem. Yet, its bias correction efficacy gradually declines as time progresses, and for bias correction scenarios with varying lead times, the model training exhibits pronounced dependence on forecast products and temporal scale coupling, requiring substantial computational resources and costs. We propose a diffusion model-based approach that simulates natural stochastic processes through partial noise injection. Using an erosion operation to compute the coastal mask, which corrects sea surface temperature forecast biases in target regions. This model, trained solely on historical reanalysis data, effectively addresses the shortcomings of previous methods. Furthermore, we propose an adaptive denoising parameterization scheme targeting noise intensity and denoising steps, which achieves dynamic optimization of parameters. Extensive results from real-world dataset show the efficacy and superiority of our approach. Compared to previous models, our method reduces the RMSE of bias-corrected sea temperature forecasts by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 9. 3 2 \%}$</tex>, achieving state-of-the-art results.

title: FIMFS: A Fine-Grained in-Memory Secure Storage System for Distributed Confidential Containers
authors: Shicheng Song, Jinfeng Zhang, Jiang Zhou, Xiaoyan Gu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: The rise of confidential computing has enabled secure in-use data protection within containerized cloud environments. However, fine-grained data-at-rest security remains a critical challenge, especially in distributed computing scenarios where sensitive data spans across multiple confidential containers. We present FIMFS, a FUSE-based in-memory secure file system designed to provide container-level storage isolation and persistent data encryption on the host. By integrating with a trusted key management system (KMS), FIMFS enables automated per-container key provisioning and transparent data protection without host awareness. To further address the I/O performance bottlenecks typical of FUSE, FIMFS leverages the advantages of a tmpfs-backed in-memory layer for reads and writes, combined with an asynchronous mechanism for persisting data from containers to disks. We have implemented FIMFS on a SEV-enabled Kata container cluster and evaluated its performance under microbenchmarks and Hadoop workloads. Extensive experimental results show that FIMFS achieves strong security guarantees with a very small performance overhead, offering a practical and efficient solution for secure data storage in distributed confidential computing environments.

title: Foundation Models as Guardrails: LLM-and VLM-Based Approaches to Safety and Alignment
authors: Huy H. Nguyen, Pride Kavumba, Tomoya Kurosawa, Koki Wataoka
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: The growing deployment of large language models (LLMs) and vision-language models (VLMs) raises urgent concerns about safety and alignment. While alignment techniques such as supervised fine-tuning (SFT) and reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) improve model behavior, they are not sufficient to prevent harmful outputs. This paper reviews recent approaches that use foundation models themselves as guardrails systems that monitor or filter inputs and outputs for safety. We cover LLM-based moderation, neural classifiers, and multimodal safety filters, highlighting both academic advances and industry tools. We also discuss empirical evaluation methods such as red teaming and adversarial prompting. Finally, we outline open challenges in robustness, interpretability, and policy adaptation, pointing to key directions for building trustworthy guardrails for generative AI.

title: Innovative Computational Strategies for Early Alzheimer's Detection
authors: T.Kalpana, R.Thamilselvan, M.Pyingkodi, Pranitha P, Sakthivel R, Sam Anderson Y
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: The challenge of diagnosis for Alzheimer’s disease stems from its gradual onset and overlap of symptoms with other cognitive disorders, fostering delays in clinical identification and subsequent treatment. A deep learning-based classification model, built using multimodal data, could possibly address the diagnostic gap by integrating various types of information including brain imaging scans, genetic data, and data scores from cognitive tests. The attention-based neural network with cross-modal integration was able to derive useful information from MRI scans, gene expression data, and neuropsychological scores. The lack of interpretability and rigid data assumptions in conventional deep learning modelling has hindered the acceptance of such models for clinical use with real-world heterogeneous datasets. A transformer-inspired architecture with dynamic feature weighting was used in the network to allow the model to highlight the relevant biomarkers across modalities. Training and validation on the ADNI dataset exhibited top classification performance with very high accuracy, random forest empathy (sensitivity), and F1 across Alzheimer's disease states. Transfers from unimodal models exhibiting poor generalization were mitigated through external validation confirming the stability of the model even with unseen subjects. The integration of spatial, genetic, and behavioral streams permitted the network to capture some subtle clinically-important indicators of meaning in etiology and disease progression. The addition of explanation components in the form of attention heatmaps that provide clarity of which modalities were attending to specific areas of significance and the feature importance components of classification across all clinical cases (AD level).

title: Efficiency in Chat Application Encryption: A Comparative Review with Proposed Enhancements
authors: Jikesh Thapa, MD Nashid Anjum, Rashid Khokhar
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: The explosive growth of real-time messaging applications has coincided with a major shift in focus towards digital privacy due to clear and present threats such as mass government surveillance, hacking and extortion, cyberbullying, and so on. This has created a need for implementations that provide sufficient confidentiality while working effectively within modern mobile devices. End-to-end encryption protocols like Off-The-Record (OTR) and Signal, that most chat applications adapt, ensure privacy but impose additional computational demands on devices with limited but varied resources. This paper compares WhatsApp, Telegram, and Signal, analyzing their resource consumption patterns during encrypted message transmission. By measuring CPU usage, GPU usage, and memory footprint, we evaluate how these applications manage workload to balance security and efficiency using modern hardware. We propose an encryption optimization approach with CPU offloading that min-imizes resource utilization while retaining acceptable standards for confidentiality, crucial for applications operating in mobile hardware.

title: Simulation of Energy Consumption and Solar Generation for Urban Farming via PV Syst Software
authors: Siti Amely Jumaat, Ahmad Fateh Mohamad Nor, Suriana Salimin, Muhammad Nafis Ismail, Mohd Noor Abdullah, Shamsul Aizam Zulkifli
publish: 2025 IEEE Industrial Electronics and Applications Conference (IEACon)
abstract: The study focuses on urban farming is modern agricultural technology utilizing solar energy as the primary source through the Photovoltaic System (PVSyst) Software simulation. The main objective of this research is to obtain the Performance Ratio (PR), battery system efficiency and Solar Fraction (SF) of the system. Next, to predict the system generate electricity, and energy loss per year. The study was conducted at the Main Campus of Universiti Tun Hussein Onn Malaysia (UTHM), Parit Raja, Batu Pahat, Johor, Malaysia. The project uses a one (1) unit of a 405W, 37.85V, and 10.7A solar PV panel. Additionally, two (2) units of 12V 200Ah lead-acid batteries were used. The simulation results show that the system generates 1.3kWh/kWp/day or 520.20kWh/year, with an energy loss of 0.54kWh/kWp/day or 1.89kWh/year, which equates to a 0.9% PV loss due to irradiance levels. The battery efficiency loss is 13.6%. The PR value is 29.4%, and the SF is 99.3%.

title: Collie: Federated Query Processing via Reinforcement Learning
authors: Gansen Hu, Xujia Yao, Yang Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Modern distributed query engines have made significant progress in data processing, yet each engine exhibits different performance characteristics under varying workloads. While multi-engine integration solutions exist, they face challenges including manual integration complexity, and inflexible query routing rules. This paper presents a federated query engine framework that addresses these limitations through two key innovations. First, we introduce a query-driven lightweight integration method that enables easy engine integration without requiring deep modifications to existing systems. Second, we incorporate reinforcement learning techniques to automatically select the optimal query engine based on workload patterns and query characteristics. Our approach uses incremental learning to adapt to changing workloads in real-time. Experimental results demonstrate that our framework effectively selects the most suitable engine for different query types, leading to upto <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2. 1 5} \times$</tex> improved overall performance compared to single-engine solutions.

title: Unified OOD Detection and Generalization for Federated Learning with Data Heterogeneity
authors: Lu Liang, Xiaodong Fu, Lianyin Jia
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) has seen widespread adoption in privacy-sensitive domains. However, handling Out-of-Distribution (OOD) data, particularly in terms of detection and generalization, remains a significant challenge, as most existing methods address these issues separately. This separation often leads to the misclassification of OOD inputs and the rejection of generalizable samples. The challenge is further amplified in federated settings due to data heterogeneity and the need to ensure generalization across a diverse set of clients. Models are required not only to identify semantically shifted inputs but also to avoid misclassifying unseen classes from other clients as OOD, all while maintaining both intra-client and inter-client generalization. To tackle these challenges, FedGSV is proposed as a novel detection method driven by a federated global leading singular vector. FedGSV integrates self-supervised pretraining with local attention-based feature enhancement. Specifically, it employs self-supervised contrastive learning during the pretraining phase to learn feature representations with strong generalization capabilities. During the fine-tuning phase, it introduces a Partial Class Activation Attention (PCAA) module to enhance the stability of local features. During inference, FedGSV constructs a Global Singular Vector (GSV) by aggregating dominant singular vectors from all clients, enabling efficient and reliable OOD detection. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that FedGSV consistently improves OOD detection performance across a variety of datasets and heterogeneous environments, while also achieving strong generalization. These findings suggest that FedGSV provides a promising and robust solution for practical federated scenarios involving OOD detection and OOD generalization.

title: Audio Data Analysis and Music Genre Classification with Various Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Arda Deniz, Bilal Saoud, Ibraheem Shayea, Shambulov Ulykbek, Abilkair Imanberdi, Fuad Abdulgaleel Abdoh Ghaleb
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Music genre classification presents several challenges, including high-dimensional audio data, overlapping genre characteristics, and subjective labeling. Although machine learning has shown promise in addressing these challenges, many studies either focus on a narrow range of models or lack comparative performance insights. In this study, we perform a comprehensive evaluation of ten machine learning algorithms for music genre classification using the widely adopted GTZAN dataset. The models include Naïve Bayes, Support Vector Machines, K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Random Forest, Neural Networks, and Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), among others. Our results demonstrate that XGBoost achieved the highest accuracy at 90.09%, outperforming Random Forest (81.42%) and KNN (80.58%) by a significant margin. Feature importance analysis highlights that percussive, harmonic, and spectral features contribute most substantially to genre discrimination. Notably, XGBoost’s superior performance suggests its ability to effectively capture non-linear patterns in musical features, offering a strong alternative to traditional classifiers. This work contributes a broad comparative analysis and emphasizes the effectiveness of ensemble-based approaches in music genre classification, providing valuable insights for future research and practical applications in music information retrieval.

title: Extended Dissipative Observer-Based Plug-and-Play Control for Large-Scale Interconnected Systems
authors: Xiaohui Hu, Chen Peng, Hao Shen, Engang Tian
publish: IEEE/CAA Journal of Automatica Sinica
abstract: In this study, a novel observer-based scalable control scheme for large-scale systems (LSSs) with several interconnected subsystems is explored. Firstly, a scalable observer-based controller is designed to address complex situations where system states are difficult to measure directly. Secondly, unlike the limited cascade and ring topology connections in previous results, this study considers a universal arbitrary topology. Furthermore, it is noteworthy that the plug-and-play (PnP) capability of LSSs is guaranteed thanks to the proposed scalable scheme. Specifically, when subsystems are added or removed, only the controller gains of directly connected neighbors need updating, eliminating the need to redesign the entire system. Moreover, by choosing a Lyapunov-Krasovskii function with a quadratic matrix-valued polynomial, sufficient conditions are deduced to guarantee the global exponential stability with the desired extended dissipative performance for the resulting LSSs. Finally, the effectiveness of the employed scheme is verified by numerical and microgrid examples.

title: Semiconductor Thyratron Replacement for Extract Kicker Power Supplies
authors: Maliq Martin, Jonny Ranner, Li Ran, Richard McMahon
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Improvements in the capabilities of high voltage power electronics have continued to enable the replacement of thyratrons for niche applications. Increases in the supply cost associated with a decreasing market for high-power thyratrons have further pushed the case for replacement in operational power supplies. The research outlined will be on the development of a semiconductor solution to replace the thyratrons used in the existing Extract Kicker magnet power supplies at ISIS Neutron and Muon Source, STFC. The existing power supply consists of a 700 -stage pulse forming network (PFN) rated at 50 kV, producing 1 us pulses at repetition rates of 50 Hz.

title: The Effects of Preset Magnetic Field in Coaxial Type Plasma Erosion Opening Switch
authors: Shen Shou Max Chung, Shih-Chung Tuan
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Opening switch possesses certain advantages over closing switch in that magnetic field can store more energy than electric field in nature, thus in high power scenario, plasma erosion opening switch (PEOS) becomes an interesting choice. Previous efforts on PEOS mostly rely on a separate plasma source to inject plasma into switch volume to initiate the switch, but in coaxial type PEOS the plasma is generated within a coaxial transmission line, and the cathode built on top of a section of the center conductor provides the needed plasma. Previously we had studied the impedance of such PEOS under different applied voltage with a PIC code simulation, now we study the behavior of such PEOS under a preset magnetic field. The magnetic field should affect the flow of the electrons, and changes the properties of the PEOS, both in current and impedance.

title: Towards Ultra-Low Latency: Binarized Neural Network Architectures for in-Vehicle Network Intrusion Detection
authors: Huiyao Dong, Igor Kotenko
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: The Control Area Network (CAN) protocol is essential for in-vehicle communication, facilitating high-speed data exchange among Electronic Control Units (ECUs). However, its inherent design lacks robust security features, rendering vehicles susceptible to cyberattacks. While recent research has investigated machine learning and deep learning techniques to enhance network security, their practical applicability remains uncertain. This paper presents a lightweight intrusion detection technique based on Binarized Neural Networks (BNNs), which utilizes payload data, message IDs, and CAN message frequencies for effective intrusion detection. Additionally, we develop hybrid binary encoding techniques to integrate non-binary features, such as message IDs and frequencies. The proposed method, namely the BNN framework specifically optimized for in-vehicle intrusion detection combined with hybrid binary quantization techniques for non-payload attributes, demonstrates efficacy in both anomaly detection and multi-class network traffic classification. The system is well-suited for deployment on micro-controllers and Gateway ECUs, aligning with the real-time requirements of CAN bus safety applications.

title: Adaptive Brightness Adjustment Algorithm for Nighttime Inspection of Images
authors: Shukun Wu, Chunling Lang, Haifeng Qian, Deshinta Arrova Dewi, Youjun Zhou, Yuan Tian
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: With the increasing safety concerns, automated inspection is widely used. Images and videos are used to improve the efficiency and level of inspection. However, insufficient lighting at night makes it difficult to inspect images. Therefore, we develop an algorithm to enhance visual images in dim conditions through adaptive brightness adjustment and calculation in different lighting environments. The performance of the algorithm was verified in different scenes, lighting environments, and times.

title: DG-SED: Domain Generalization for Sound Event Detection with Heterogeneous Training Data
authors: Yang Xiao, Han Yin, Jisheng Bai, Rohan Kumar Das
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This work explores domain generalization (DG) for sound event detection (SED), advancing adaptability to real-world scenarios. Our approach employs a mean-teacher framework with domain generalization named DG-SED to integrate heterogeneous training data while preserving the SED model performance across the datasets. Specifically, we first apply mixstyle to the frequency dimension to adapt the mel-spectrograms from different domains. Next, we use the adaptive residual normalization method to generalize features across multiple domains by applying instance normalization in the frequency dimension. Lastly, we use the sound event bounding boxes method for post-processing. We evaluate the proposed approach DG-SED on the DCASE 2024 Challenge Task 4, measuring PSDS on the DESED dataset and macro-average pAUC on the MAESTRO dataset. The results indicate that the proposed DG-SED method improves both PSDS and macro-average pAUC compared to the baselines. The code will be released in due course.

title: Fusion-Based Arbitration Policy Switching Using Multi-Traffic Characteristics in Heterogeneous NoCs
authors: Juan Fang, Zekai Jin, Yuening Wang, Ziyi Teng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Resource contention in heterogeneous Networks-on-Chip (NoC) has become a critical factor restricting performance, while traditional arbitration policies lack effective awareness of traffic dynamics and showing limited adaptability to dynamic communication demands. This paper systematically analyzes the relationship between traffic characteristics and packet latency, and confirms the multifractality of traffic series. On this basis, we propose an Arbitration policy switching strategy based on Multi-traffic characteristics(MultiArb). MultiArb dynamically adjusts arbitration policies based on traffic temporal density and fluctuation characteristics to adapt to different traffic scenarios. Experimental results show that MultiArb reduces CPU packet latency by an average of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 4. 0 3 \%}$</tex> and improves CPU performance by 17.96 %, while keeping GPU performance and latency largely stable. Overall, system performance increases by 11.81 %, and average latency decreases by 1.48 %.

title: A Revolutionary Method for Accurate Vehicle Localization Leveraging Collaborative Map Matching and Responsive Base Stations
authors: G. Karthikeyan, Y Murali Krishna, Tumula Tirumala, Safeyah Tawil, P Yakaiah, P Gowthaman
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Accurate vehicle localization is a cornerstone for the safe and efficient operation of autonomous driving and intelligent transportation systems. Conventional GPS-aided localization experiences serious degradations of its accuracy when used in urban settings because of the multipath effect, signal blocking, and poor satellite sighting. This paper presents a ground breaking hybrid localization scheme that combines Collaborative Map Matching (CMM), Responsive Base Stations (RBS), and Vehicle-to-Vehicle (V2V) data sharing towards the improvement of localization accuracy and reliability in an enhanced way. The procedure consists of simultaneous use of real-time data input of GPS, inertial sensors, and onboard vehicle systems and their synchronization with the transformation into a local coordinate system. Also through strategically placed base stations one has the support of triangle signals (Time of Arrival (ToA) and Angle of Arrival (AoA) on the one hand, and to correlate the routes of vehicles using HD maps and environmental characteristics on the other (map matching). Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) can have an input of multiple sensors that are combined to provide the final result of position reading. Experimental testing on urban, suburban, and rural conditions demonstrates that the described system has an average localization accuracy of 0.42 meters, which is way better when compared to the standalone GPS (2.63 meters) and the traditional biased GPS (1.19 meters). The proposed system is also characterized by excellent map-matching accuracy (97.3%) and a confidence level of more than 95% in different contexts. By combining these three concepts, resilient end-to-end vehicle localization with the potential to enable autonomous navigation in a multi-sensor complex real-world environment becomes a reality.

title: Surface Roughness Classification Using Attention-Guided Convolutional Neural Networks on Real-Time Machining Sensor Data
authors: Rajendran Ashok Kumar, Dillibabu Venugopal, J. Lydia Pancy, Chidambaranathan Bibin, Raghavan Sheeja, Gopinath Soundararajan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Surface roughness classification is the most important measure in the pursuit of machining quality, but conventional offline measurements are not conducive to real-time monitoring. To address this issue, the paper presents an Attention-Guided Convolutional Neural Network (AG-CNN) for classifying levels of surface roughness from multivariate force signals (Fx, Fy, Fz). The model combines 1D convolutional layers with a temporal attention mechanism to concentrate on signal regions. The system is deployed with Python and TensorFlow, which allows effective preprocessing, training, and inference of the Models. To make use of the publicly released CNC Turning dataset, where force signals are normalized, segmented, and annotated as smooth, moderate, and rough classes in signals. The introduced AG-CNN achieves an accuracy of 85.3%, representing a 5.1% improvement over the baseline CNN. The findings verify that incorporating attention improves classification performance and provides a stable framework for real-time monitoring of surface quality in intelligent manufacturing systems.

title: Study on Signal Processing Techniques in Protecting Voice Personae Against Speech Synthesis Systems
authors: Nopparut Li, Candy Olivia Mawalim, Masashi Unoki
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Recent advancements in speech synthesis have enabled the generation of natural-sounding speech signals that can closely mimic specific speakers, raising serious concerns about the misuse of voice recordings for impersonation and fraud. Although researchers have extensively studied spoof speech detection, they can only implement these approaches once the spoofed content has been generated. We propose a method based on <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F_{0}$</tex> component elimination and compare it with conventional filtering and artificial reverberation for the impact on the quality of synthesized speech signals generated using the TorToiSe TTS model, as well as the perceptual quality of the modified speech signals. Results show that the proposed method is able to reduce the identifiability of synthesized speech signals with minimal impact on speech quality, offering a promising direction for voice personae protection against speech synthesis systems.

title: Advancing Strategic Game AI with YOLO and Large Language Models
authors: Andreea-Isabela Haiura, Cosmin Irimia, Adrian Iftene
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: The development of intelligent agents for video games essentially requires access to an accurate representation of the game's internal state. In environments that provide dedicated APIs or where direct memory manipulation, this requirement can be relatively easily met. However, many games, especially the older ones, have built-in security mechanisms that restrict access to external modifications of memory. This limitation represents a significant obstacle for researchers and developers who wish to explore the interaction between artificial intelligence and such gaming environments. Simultaneously, the availability of large language models (LLMs), such as GPT (Generative pre-trained transformer), opens up new opportunities in the direction of high-level strategic reasoning. These models are capable of interpreting structured input and generating complex decisions like human reasoning. In this paper, we will focus on extracting the game state using the YOLO algorithm, both for detecting and classifying objects such as units, buildings, and types of resources, as well as for recognizing the numbers necessary for extracting resource values (food, wood, gold). Once this state is obtained, the goal will be on comparing several LLMs in generating strategies for the game, using two distinct approaches: zero-shot and few-shot.

title: AIM-CF: Fast and Precise Counterfactual Explanations via Approximate Inverse Models
authors: Takafumi Nakanishi, Ponlawat Chophuk, Krisana Chinnasarn
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Counterfactual explanations (CFs) have become a key technique for validating the decisions of machine-learning models at the level of individual instances. However, conventional search-based algorithms incur (i) high computational cost owing to random or evolutionary exploration and (ii) inflated distances when many one-hot categorical features are present in tabular data. We introduce AIM-CF, a fast and precise CF generator that extends the Approximate Inverse Model Explanation (AIME) framework. AIM-CF consists of three deterministic stages: (1) minimal categorical flipping guided by the global feature importance derived from a representative prototype, (2) axis-wise bisection that shrinks each continuous variable to the decision boundary, and (3) micro-random refinement, which removes residual diagonal slack. The entire procedure requires only forward evaluations of the black-box model and no gradients. On the UCI Heart-Disease dataset, AIM-CF reduces the mean L2 distance from 0.92 (DiCE-Random) to 0.83 while cutting average generation time from 1.78 s to 0.10 s on a CPU—a 17-fold acceleration—and achieves a 100 % success rate versus 97 % for DiCE. These results demonstrate that AIM-CF surpasses the existing methods in terms of distance, speed, and robustness for tabular data containing both categorical and continuous attributes. We conclude by discussing how AIM-CF can be combined with other inverse-problem XAI techniques to provide actionable and explainable decision support in medical and financial applications.

title: Study of Plasma Electron Density Measurements Using a Planar Absorption Probe
authors: S. Lee, S. Kim, I. Park, G. Eom, B. Seo, M. Hur, W. Kang, S. You, D.-W. Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The electron density of plasma is an important measure of the characteristics of plasma, and many diagnostic tools have been designed and studied to measure the electron density [1]–[3]. Among them, the plasma absorption probe (PAP) can obtain the electron density of plasma by using the resonance of the wave oscillating on the surface of plasma. Theoretically, when a metal and a dielectric are in contact and exist in infinite space, resonance occurs at the surface wave resonance (SWR) frequency, which is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.707 \times$</tex> electron plasma frequency (Hz). The resonant frequency depends not only on the electron density of plasma, but also on the probe geometry and the sheath thickness [3]. These characteristics make the electron density measurement by PAP uncertain or impossible, which is a problem that needs to be solved in order to measure the electron density by PAP.

title: AI-Driven Integration of Multimodal Neuro Imaging for Vision Defect Detection and Classification
authors: Diana George, George Fernandez. I
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: The article leveraging artificial intelligence (AI) techniques applied to multimodal brain imaging data to predict and classify vision defects related to neurological and neuro-ophthalmic disorders. By leveraging different brain image modalities like magnetic resonance angiography (MRA), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), functional MRI (fMRI), and other diffusion images, the proposed framework aims to overcome key challenges in early detection, risk assessment, and differentiation of complex vision impairments. The proposed framework evolves through the recent advances in multimodal brain age prediction, neuro-visual rehabilitation, and neuro-ophthalmology diagnostics, synthesizing insights into an AI-driven model for precise vision defect classification. The results demonstrate the potential for enhanced diagnostic accuracy and individualized patient care, contributing to the development of robust neuroimaging biomarkers for neuro-visual health. By integrating explainable AI (XAI) for trusted medical interpretation made this model a unique approach for the vision prediction using multimodalities.

title: Cybersecurity Implications of AI-Driven Retail Personalization Engines
authors: Shanmugam Muthu, P. Deepalakshmi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: AI-powered retail personalization is transforming the customer experience by adapting to real-time behavior and providing actionable information. Traditional systems relying on static rule-based filters and simple segmentation have drawbacks, including limited flexibility and increased cybersecurity risks, including malicious attacks and data breaches. While inequality is a concern, the proposed system aims to address it. It includes privacy-preserving approaches like federated learning and homomorphic encryption, as well as sophisticated machine learning (ML) models like collaborative filtering, deep learning (DL), and reinforcement learning (RL). Real-time anomaly detection, adversarial training for robustness, hybrid recommendation algorithms with attention mechanisms, and secure data preparation. Early experimental results indicate promising improvements. Although the assault success rate remained around 15%, the model's precision, recall, and F1-score were 0.72, 0.68, and 0.70, respectively. Additionally, the user capacity increased to 10,000 within 90 ms of reaction time. It enhances consumer satisfaction and resilience to cyberthreats by improving personalization accuracy, security, and scalability.

title: Enhancing Inverter Synchronization: a Resilient Static Solution for Adverse Grid Environments
authors: Chang-Yi Chou, Mohammed Ansar Mohammed Manaz
publish: 2025 IEEE Industrial Electronics and Applications Conference (IEACon)
abstract: Accurate and robust synchronization is crucial for grid-connected power converters’ operation, particularly under dynamic or distorted grid conditions. Conventional methods such as the synchronous reference frame phase-locked loop (SRF-PLL) and dual second-order generalized integrator PLL (DSOGI-PLL) provide effective performance under nominal conditions but often encounter challenges during grid disturbances, such as phase jumps and frequency drops. This paper proposes a novel static synchronization (SS) method coupled with DSOGI, which we call the DSOGI-SS. The SS method generates synchronized sine and cosine signals through algebraic equations on instantaneous three-phase voltage measurements, avoiding the PLL and sine function generators. A detailed stability analysis is performed, and the frequency response characteristics of DSOGI-PLL and DSOGI-SS are compared. Furthermore, time-domain simulations under phase jump and frequency variation scenarios are conducted in the PLECS environment to validate the performance of the proposed method. The results indicate that DSOGI-SS exhibits improved high-frequency response characteristics and significantly faster synchronization during transient events, rendering it a promising solution for inverter control in modern power systems.

title: Custom Robot Arm-Based Trowel Direction Determination on Wall Corners using Deep Predictive Learning
authors: Huu Huy Thinh Nguyen, Ikumi Noborio, Weiwei Du, Xuan Bach Mai, Makoto Muramoto, Eunjong Choi
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: The robot arm is considered because the wrist joint is particularly effective for plastering tasks in construction. Moreover, the present study simulates expert plasterers’ actions to design a deep predictive learning model that captures the difference between the current action and the predicted action, including visual information. Deep predictive learning is implemented using a convolutional neural network (CNN) to extract features, with some positional data inserted into the CNN model after feature extraction. This study does not focus on controlling the robot arm itself, but rather on determining whether the trowel direction should change as the robot arm approaches a wall corner. The effectiveness of this approach was validated: as the custom robot arm nears a wall corner, the trowel direction adjusts accordingly.

title: Intelligent Training System Based on Text Mining for College English Writing
authors: Xiuqin Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: An intelligent training system for college English writing was developed based on text mining in this study. The system adopts text mining technologies and improves students' learning experience. Algorithms for text classification and transaction recommendation were also adopted in the developed system. Based on functional requirement analysis, a backend core module was developed for crawling along with an intelligent recommendation system.. The system provides categorized exercise texts for intelligent guidance. Students' writing trends are filtered and screened to recommend writing paths based on teaching expertise. The system provides n evidence-based mechanism that enhances academic writing. The system improves training outcomes in English writing.

title: Environment Independent Device-Free Gait Recognition Using Channel State Information
authors: Sheng Chen, Bangzhou Xin, Fei Yang, Aimin Pan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Wi-Fi signal multipath propagation presents a challenge as the signals reflected by the human body not only carry distinctive human features but are also distorted by the surrounding environment. To address this issue, we introduce EIGait, an advanced environment independent gait recognition system leveraging Wi-Fi Channel State Information (CSI). Unlike conventional Wi-Fi based gait recognition systems, EIGait aims to achieve high recognition accuracy while ensuring robustness against environmental changes. Specifically, EIGait extracts human gait features by fusing time-frequency features from spectrograms with temporal features related to phase changes, capturing more comprehensive and distinctive gait patterns. It then transforms these features from different environments into a uniform, environment independent feature space, ensuring consistent system performance across different environments. To demonstrate the effectiveness of EIGait, we implemented EIGait on commercial Wi-Fi devices and evaluated its performance across four distinct indoor environments. Experimental results demonstrate that EIGait outperforms existing gait recognition systems, consistently delivering superior performance even in challenging settings.

title: Optimization of Multi-Echelon Inventory Systems Using Stochastic Models
authors: Paras Shingadiya, Chetansinh Vaghela, Santanu Roy, Anitha Florence Vinola F, Debasri Dey, K. Aruna Kumari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Optimal inventory policies at multi-echelon supply chains are of essential concern when facing demand uncertainty, variable lead time and non-trivial interactions between distributions levels. The current study suggests the optimization framework in terms of stochastic models to optimize the decision-making process given uncertainty. The methodology includes decomposing time-series along with normalization as a preprocessing step on demand patterns, LASSO regression to identify the most representative features, and Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM) to carry out predictive modeling. Its implementation will be done with the use of Python tools such as PyTorch, OR-Tools, Ray RLlib, and Scikit-learn, which are used to implement Bayesian learning, optimization, reinforcement learning-based policy design and model integration, respectively. The experimental outcomes indicate substantial gains, including the minimization of the forecast error, minimization of the holding costs, a fractional occurrence of stock-outs, and the service levels augmentation as compared to conventional techniques. The results emphasize how hybrid stochastic/machine learning model offers scalable, accurate and resilient dynamic supply chain applications, offering a practical solution towards achieving real-time, dynamic inventory optimization in complex, multi-echelon networks.

title: Charging Dynamics of LiFePO₄ Batteries Using Concentrated Photovoltaic Arrays: A SIMULINK Approach
authors: Jose Deciga-Gusi, Firdaus Muhammad-Sukki, Roberto Ramírez-Íñiguez, Daria Freier Raine, Siti Hawa Abu-Bakar, Nurfadzilah Ahmad, Nurul Aini Bani
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: We simulated a low-concentration photovoltaic (LCPV) system for charging lithium iron phosphate (LiFePO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">₄</inf>) batteries. Initially, the short-circuit current I<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sc</inf> and open-circuit voltage Voc values obtained at a 0° tilt angle were used to determine the optimal series X<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</inf> and parallel X<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf> array configurations required to charge a small LiFePO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">₄</inf> battery, commonly used in portable solar charging applications. A detailed battery model and a constant current/constant voltage (CC/CV) charging circuit were developed using MATLAB Simulink to simulate realistic charging behaviour. A time constraint was applied to the CC/CV model to evaluate the time required for the concentrated array to reach specific states of charge (SoC), compared to a non-concentrated array. Additionally, the total charging time to reach full SoC (100%) was simulated. Key findings, performance comparisons, and potential sources of error are discussed, highlighting areas for improvement in future concentrator and LCPV system designs.

title: A-Guard: Extending Android Verified Boot to Enforce Application Integrity Against Repackaging Attacks
authors: Haohao Liu, Xuefei Chen, Juntong Yin, Tianle Ding, Da Zhang, Chen Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Repackaging attacks represent a critical vector for distributing mobile malware, wherein attackers modify legitimate Android applications and redistribute them with forged signatures. The open nature of Android's ecosystem allows execution of any signed application, regardless of signer authenticity. Existing defenses against repackaging, including detection and anti-repackaging techniques, often exhibit limited practicality, vulnerability to bypassing, and insufficient adaptability for offline environments.
