title: Efficient Satellite Hardware Architecture for Accelerating Satellite Computing Power Networks
authors: Junxiang Qin, Lingbin Zeng, Shan Huang, Zhixi Yang, Yonggang Wang, Jun Yang
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Low-orbit mega-constellations promote the arrival of the era of the Internet of Things (IoT) in 6G, and satellite computing power networks (SCPN) provide a resilient resource for services in IoT. Satellite resources are scarce due to volume and power constraints, forcing most tasks to be processed on the ground and hindering SCPNs practical application. To meet the elastic resource requirements of IoT, SCPN requires that each satellite node share its resources with others. However, the closedness of traditional satellite architecture cannot meet this requirement. Given that, this paper introduces a novel efficient satellite hardware architecture designed for accelerating SCPN named Efficient Satellite Hardware Architecture (ESHA), which is capable of fast and flexible satellite resource sharing. Through reorganizing the satellite system, ESHA enables the satellites to share resources among modules to aggregate resources for tasks in IoT. Besides, this paper presents a queuing network method to model and analyze ESHA and evaluate its performance. The experimental results show that, for the same type of parallel tasks, the speedup ratio of this architecture is 2.4 times higher than that of the traditional satellite architecture, the task completion time is reduced by 48%, and the utilization of satellite resources is effectively improved.

title: IWF-NET: A Synergistic Multi-Stage Network for Progressive Underwater Image Refinement
authors: Chunshu Peng, Jinxue Sui, Zuoxun Wang, Chi Zhang, Yongshuai Nie
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Due to the unique optical properties of under-water environments and the presence of suspended particles, underwater images often suffer from issues such as brightness imbalance, color distortion, and scattering blur. These challenges, compounded by environmental constraints, make image restoration and enhancement particularly difficult. To address these issues, this paper introduces IterWaveFold-NET (IWF NET), a synergistic multi-stage network designed for the progressive refinement of underwater images. Specifically, a joint pre optimization module is introduced to perform color correction and detail refinement, leveraging Residual Color Correction Blocks (RCCB) and Nonlinear Activation-Free Block (NAFB) to improve image clarity and suppress noise. A dual-domain attention-guided feature fusion paradigm based on DSAAB is employed to enhance texture detail recovery and contrast, effectively reinforcing critical feature representation. Furthermore, the integration of Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization and positive channel attention mechanisms improves feature extraction and fusion, preserving image edges and maintaining color balance. Experimental results on multiple underwater image datasets demonstrate that the proposed method significantly improves enhancement quality, validating its effectiveness in underwater image enhancement tasks.

title: A Pulsed Power Driven Antenna Array for Contactless PEF Treatment
authors: G. Pemen, J. Geeve, R. Serra, T. Huiskamp
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: In this paper, a study of an antenna array for contactless delivery of intense pulsed electric fields (PEF) is presented. Objective is to analyse if antenna arrays can be used effectively to improve flexibility of induced pulsed electric fields (PEFs), additionally allowing for high peak field magnitudes at picosecond rise times, while requiring comparatively low peak excitation voltages per array-element.

title: Novel Method for RF Pulsing Immunity Testing in High-Power Amplifiers
authors: A. Eroglu
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The design and performance evaluation of high-power RF amplifiers for semiconductor wafer processing applications are increasingly critical as advanced manufacturing techniques require higher precision and reliability. RF amplifiers are integral in driving processes such as plasma etching, deposition, and ion implantation, where stable and consistent RF power is essential for uniform wafer processing. During these processes, both CW mode and pulsing are often used simultaneously to achieve specific process characteristics. As a result, the RF amplifier's immunity to pulsing is a key factor in ensuring stable and optimal performance. Traditional evaluation methods typically focus on parameters such as output power, gain, and efficiency but often overlook the amplifier's response to RF pulsing conditions that are commonly encountered during semiconductor processing. While simple pulse injection techniques exist, they often fail to replicate the complex, real-world conditions under which amplifiers operate during plasma processes. This makes them less effective in testing amplifier immunity to RF pulsing, a crucial aspect for the reliability and performance of semiconductor processes.

title: Design of a Modulating-Anode Particle Accelerator for Space-Based Experiments
authors: C. D. Roper, Q. Marksteiner, J. W. Lewellen, G. D. Reeves
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: This research aims to enhance the performance of a mod-anode electron gun for future space-based experiments, specifically for Beam2PIE, an advanced particle accelerator designed to investigate beam-plasma interactions and their role in wave generation in space physics. Traditional electron guns rely on grids for beam modulation, but these components are susceptible to mechanical failure under the extreme conditions of space missions. The mod-anode approach, which introduces a secondary anode between the cathode and main anode, presents a robust alternative by enabling efficient beam modulation with reduced current and voltage requirements while improving mechanical durability.

title: Sleep and Mental Well-being: Non-Invasive Assessment System
authors: B. Padmavathi, G.K. Sathya Narayanan, A. Ashiq Rasool, B. Sanjana, L. Sathya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: This work provides an advanced and combined health monitoring structure that focuses on both sleep-related disorders and mental well-being through continuous and non-invasive observation. Making use of hardware of a Raspberry Pi 4, the system captures and checks real-time physiological and behavioral data using a combination of biomedical and environmental sensors. These parameters keeps track of vital signs, sleep posture and sound-related anomalies such as snoring or irregular breathing. The system is designed to keep an eye on different body signs to catch any health issues early. A easy to use web interface provides data visualization and easy access, making the system suitable for home-based health tracking. Designed to be cheap and easily accessible, this solution makes professional-level health check-up more available at home.

title: Discrete Particle Effects on Electron Emission
authors: A. Valfells, K. Torfason, A. Jonsson, A. Manolescu
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The electric field at the surface of a cathode has a strong effect on the rate of electron emission due to its effect on the surface barrier. The electric charge of emitted electrons will have an effect on the electric field on the cathode, and subsequently may have an effect on current density from the cathode. This space-charge effect is well known and manifests e.g. in spacecharge limited emission described by the Child-Langmuir law or in the equilibrium current for field emission [1]. It is also known that spatial variation on emission characteristics of the cathode can lead to spatial variations in the current density that can affect the beam characteristics of a device [2]. These effects may often be readily understood using a continuous model for electrical current. In this work we look at discrete particle effects on electron emission, and introduce a region of influence within which a single electron strongly effects the local surface electric field of the cathode to such a degree that it greatly influences emission. We present some simple analytic models for estimating granularity of electron emission and compare to simulations. We investigate what implications this granularity may have on beam quality parameters such as emittance and brightness, and on current that may be drawn from electron sources with nanoscale features.

title: Adversarial Learning for Duration Prediction in Indonesian Text-to-Speech: Modification to Stochastic and Deterministic Predictors
authors: Yoga Tiara Wiguna, Bima Prihasto, Boby Mugi Pratama, Chia-Hung Yeh, Jia-Ching Wang
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Text-to-Speech (TTS) technology has significantly progressed with deep learning, especially through models like Variational Autoencoder with Adversarial Learning for End-toEnd Text-to-Speech (VITS). However, improving audio quality particularly in duration diversity remains a challenge, especially for languages like Indonesian due to limited datasets and research. This study compares the performance of VITS using Stochastic Duration Predictor (SDP) and Deterministic Duration Predictor (DDP), while also exploring the impact of adversarial training on duration prediction. Evaluation employed subjective Mean Opinion Score (MOS) and objective Cosine Similarity using Resemblyzer. Two datasets were used: 343 formal audio samples and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2 5 0}$</tex> mixed (formal and informal) samples. The more diverse dataset achieved better results, with a cosine similarity of 0.91124 and a MOS of 4.54. Findings indicate that SDP produces more natural durations, and adversarial learning enhances audio quality through better duration modeling.

title: Adjoint Approach to Optimization of Traveling Wave Tube Amplifier Design
authors: A. N. Vlasov, D. Chernin, T. Antonsen, I. Chernyavskiy
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The design of a traveling wave tube amplifier (TWT) requires the specification of many parameters, including beam voltage and current, magnetic field profile, and circuit properties. Number of design parameters grows fast with increase performance requirements and consequent complexity of amplifiers. Gradient based optimization methods can substantially speed-up finding of optimal design in the case of many design parameters. However, success in application of gradient methods is determined by availability of algorithms for efficient calculations of multidimensional derivatives. The adjoin approach for efficient calculation of multi-dimensional derivatives of goal functions developed in [1] for folded waveguide TWTs and in [2] for helix TWTs was implemented in 1D large signal simulation codes CHRISTINE-Z [3] and CHRISTINE-Helix [4]. The modified codes are used in the steepest descent optimization algorithm to finds parameter values that minimize or maximize the desired figure of merit such as bandwidth, gain, or flatness of gain dependence versus frequency. Only three runs of the modified codes are needed to compute the partial derivatives of the output power and phase at a specified frequency with respect to an arbitrary number of parameters.

title: An analysis of the Trubnikov–Lamborn plasma dispersion relations: the Bernstein case
authors: Orchidea M. Lecian, Brunello B. Tirozzi
publish: 2025 Days on Diffraction (DD)
abstract: This work analyzes the linearized Trubnikov dispersion relations within the Lamborn formalism, focusing on the Bernstein model and Landau damping phenomena. We derive new analytical expressions for velocity conditions, electric field constraints, and distribution function perturbations. The linearized dispersion relation is reformulated as an explicit function of rest mass, with integrations evaluated analytically over the plasma frequency domain. The study employs linearization techniques for Debye-length waves within Gross’s simplified framework, providing novel insights into magnetized plasma wave propagation.

title: Crystal Classification Using CNN with Microscopy and Fluorescence UV Light Test
authors: Clark M. Felix, Marc E. Endaya, Meo Vincent C. Caya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: Over the years, quartz has been sought for its beauty and versatility, yet people often mischaracterize it from other types of crystals. This study classifies three types of quartz: Rose, Clear, and Citrine, implementing Mask R-CNN (Mask Region-based Convolutional Neural Network) to detect inclusions using a digital microscope with up to 1000x magnification. A Raspberry Pi 4 is used to process and analyze the captured images. Fluorescence UV light are utilized to highlight inclusions, while Microscopy will be used along with VGG-19 architecture serves as the second test to classify quartz based on extracted features. The system aims to enhance quartz classification accuracy, benefiting gemology, mineralogy, and the jewelry industry, while also laying a foundation for future machine learning-driven mineral identification studies.

title: Investigation of Head and Neck Cancer Margin Detection through Hyperspectral Imaging Using Deep Learning
authors: Dinesh Babu K, M Vennila, R S Vijayashanthi, T.Jayakumar, G Vijayakumari, B. Thiyaneswaran
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck is a serious cancer with low survival rates due to late diagnosis and limited assessment tools. To address these issues, the Investigation of Head and Neck Cancer Margin Detection Through Hyperspectral Imaging Using Deep Learning (HNCMD) model is introduced, which combines hyperspectral imaging (HSI), convolutional neural networks (CNN), and ensemble learning for better tumor detection and margin assessment. This model was developed using surgical samples from 102 patients, resulting in 293 samples of tumor, margin, and healthy tissue. It identifies four key genes that help in diagnosis and treatment. The model processes hyperspectral data using an optimized CNN architecture, enhancing prediction accuracy through ensemble methods. The HNCMD system provides a non-invasive way to assess tumor margins quickly, improving diagnostic accuracy and supporting surgical decisions, with promising results in performance and automation.

title: A Low Power Scheduling Algorithm for Segmented Frequency Scaling
authors: Luo Wendian, Dai Shengxin, Guo Bing
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: The goal of green computing is to reduce energy usage by integrating environmentally friendly designs, using lowenergy processors, and implementing efficient power management strategies, thus supporting environmental sustainability. The focus on low-power techniques has become a significant research area in real-time operating systems (RTOS). Among the strategies, Dynamic Voltage Frequency Scaling (DVFS) and Dynamic Power Management (DPM) are commonly employed to decrease power consumption. To optimize energy usage during task scheduling on single-core processors with discrete frequencies, we introduce a Low Power Scheduling Algorithm for Segmented Frequency Scaling (LPSAFS), tailored for the RTOS periodic task model. LPSAFS effectively reduces the number of frequency scaling operations by strategically allocating minimal slack time to each task. The experimental results reveal that LPSAFS significantly conserves energy while maintaining system reliability within acceptable limits. In scenarios with high utilization, LPSAFS can achieve energy savings of up to 46 %.

title: Segmentation and Evaluation of Water-Bodies from Satellite Images
authors: J. Barnabass Paul Glady, Jamal Zaidi, K. Vijayakumar, Uday Kumar Maurya, S. Prabha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Remote sensing and image-based assessment methodologies are frequently employed in satellite image-based water body detection to identify, delineate, and monitor lakes, rivers, and reservoirs for environmental management purposes. Effective monitoring of water bodies (WB) is essential for multiple reasons, and this study focused on the analysis of WB by deep-learning (DL) segmentation applied to pre-processed satellite imagery. The objective is to extract the WB-region from the image with enhanced precision for assessment and validation. Image enhancement with Otsu's function and the Butterfly Algorithm (OF+BA) is considered. This study analysed DL-segmentation technique's results on WB-region using pixel based comparison with mask-image. Investigation executed with 2000-training and 500-test images are analyse and this research offered superior Jaccard (>92%), Dice (>95%), and accuracy (>96%) metrics on the pre-processed image database.

title: Flexiconffed: Confidence-Based Aggregation for Federated Learning with Model Heterogeneity
authors: Qiufen Ni, Shangyuan Xie, Bingning Liu, Zhiqing Tang, Jianxiong Guo, Tian Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Federated learning (FL) enables collaborative model training across distributed edge devices without sharing raw data, but real-world FL deployments face two key challenges: architectural heterogeneity among client models and non-IID data distributions. Traditional FL aggregation methods, such as FedAvg, assume model uniformity, leading to aggregation failures and degraded accuracy in heterogeneous environments, while existing personalized FL strategies lack client reliability assessment and dynamic adaptation. To address these limitations, we propose FlexiConfFed, a confidence-based adaptive aggregation framework for heterogeneous FL. FlexiConfFed introduces a multidimensional client confidence score, combining normalized accuracy, update magnitude, and gradient stability, to dynamically weight each client's contribution in the aggregation process. The framework also identifies common model layers among diverse architectures and applies a set of hierarchical confidence-weighted aggregation strategies, supporting both robust knowledge fusion and personalized adaptation. Extensive experiments on datasets including CIFAR-10, CINIC-10, and Speech Commands demonstrate that FlexiConfFed achieves up to 3% higher accuracy, faster convergence, and enhanced robustness over existing baselines, confirming its value as a scalable and efficient solution for FL under real-world heterogeneity.

title: BAANI: A 296M-Parameter Neural Vocoder for End-To-End Punjabi Speech Synthesis
authors: Siddharth Kumar, Nisarg Trivedi, Ravindrakumar M. Purohit, Hemant A. Patil
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: In this work, we present BAANI, a neural vocoder comprising 296 million parameters, designed for end-to-end speech synthesis (SS) in the Punjabi language. Recognizing the unique phonetic and prosodic characteristics of a low-resource and underrepresented Punjabi language, BAANI aims to enhance the naturalness and intelligibility of synthesized speech. The proposed model is trained on an IndicTTS Punjabi corpus and evaluated using an NVIDIA GTX 1080 GPU and an Intel Core i7 12th Gen CPU-powered system. We conducted a comparative analysis (e.g., subjective, objective, and quantitative metrics) with several state-of-the-art neural vocoders to validate the effectiveness of BAANI. It achieved 4.18 on the Mean Opinion Score (MOS). On the other side, from five different objective measures, all measures surpass the current SOTA models. Furthermore, BAANI generates 22.05 kHz speech with real-time factors (RTF) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.2 \times$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.5 \times$</tex> on the NVIDIA GTX 1080 GPU and the Intel Core i7-12700 CPU, respectively, demonstrating its practical deployment potential. Notably, the vocoder effectively preserves high-frequency harmonics and pitch (i.e., <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F_{0}$</tex>) contours, aligning closely with the perceptual preferences of native Punjabi speakers.

title: Enhancement of IoT Device through Post Quantum Cryptographic Protocols and Lamport–Diffie One-Time Signature Scheme
authors: Ashokkumar K, Magesh Mani, V. Chinnammal, K.Sangeetha, Vishnu Prasad Parandhaman, B. Thiyaneswaran
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: The rapid growth of the IoT has led to more cyberattacks on low-power devices. This study presents the IPQCLD model, which uses advanced security measures for future IoT networks to address these issues. It applies data preprocessing methods like Min-Max normalization and LDA, quantum key distribution using the BB84 protocol, and post-quantum cryptography techniques such as Lamport-Diffie one-time signatures. These features enhance authentication, encryption, and attack detection. The Lamport-Diffie method blocks key reuse and authenticates messages, while the BB84 protocol helps detect eavesdropping for secure key exchange. LDA and Min-Max normalization simplify data management and ensure accurate detection. Simulation results show that IPQCLD significantly outperforms baseline models, achieving a precision of 0.95 and a recall rate of 0.90.

title: A flexible toolkit for real-time action recognition of virtual humans in XR/AR environments
authors: Hannes Fassold
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: Real-time action recognition for virtual humans in XR/AR scenes is essential for creating natural and interactive experiences, allowing avatars or holoported humans to respond dynamically to user movements and gestures. This technology enhances applications such as immersive gaming, virtual training simulations and remote collaboration by enabling realistic character interactions and intuitive control. It is also valuable in healthcare and rehabilitation, where motion tracking can be used for physical therapy exercises and progress monitoring. Recognizing the need for robust action recognition in XR environments, we therefore present a flexible toolkit for real-time action recognition of virtual humans in XR environments. Our toolkit is built using Unity due to its widespread adoption and adaptability in XR/AR application development. The action recognition component leverages cutting-edge deep learning models to ensure high accuracy and performance and runs the analysis on a dedicated processing PC in order to not disrupt the smoothness of the XR experience. Preliminary experiments and evaluations show that the toolkit is able to recognize a variety of actions (like raising the hand, waving the hand or jumping) in a robust way.

title: High-Voltage Sources with Faster Rise Times for Applications in Nonlinear Transmission Lines
authors: Lauro P. Silva Neto, Francisco E. D. D. F. Costa, José O. Rossi, Edl. Schamiloglu
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Nonlinear transmission lines (NLTLs) are under investigation as an alternative to Travelling Wave Tube Amplifiers (TWTAs) for producing high-power radiofrequency (RF) signals. NLTLs use passive components and provide a compact RF source; however, they require some conditions for operation. For example, capacitors must exhibit nonlinear behavior with voltage, and/or inductors must show nonlinearity with current. In addition to the nonlinear behavior of components, another critical parameter for this system is the line delay time, which depends on the number of sections, capacitance, and inductance. The primary challenge in generating RF signals using NLTLs is obtaining a fast rise-time pulse at the input. When the pulse rise time exceeds the line delay time, there is no RF generation. However, high-voltage (HV) sources with faster rise times of tens of ns are expensive. In this work, two schematic circuits as HV sources with fast rise times for NLTLs work as a solution. The first topology employs a driver (UCC37321) and an HV IGBT switch (IRG4PH40KD) to produce a negative pulse adjustable from 0 V to 1.2 kV (the maximum voltage supported by the IGBT), with a fall time on the order of 300 ns when using an NLTL as a load. The second circuit uses the same IGBT and driver. Still, it incorporates a high-speed optic coupler (model 6N137) to achieve galvanic insulation between the pulse generator and the power control (driver). This circuit improves the fall time to approximately 150 ns when using an NLTL as a load.

title: Investigation of the Effectiveness of O2 Plasma Pretreatment for the Decomposition of (Micro)Plastics in Water
authors: J. S. Diaz Alcala, J. Foster
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Plastic pollution is of global concern, with 57 million tons of waste produced yearly1. Microplastics pose an immediate danger. These particles serve as carriers of contaminants due to their internal composition (dyes, binders, etc.). Due to their small size <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(<5 \text{mm})$</tex>, microplastics have been found in water and soil, leaving humans, animals–particularly aquatic life, and vegetation to uptake the carried contaminants. It is evident that a solution to this plastics problem, particularly microplastics in water, is required. A proposed solution is the use of non-thermal air plasma for the treatment of microplastics in water. Plasma, in water, acts as an advanced oxidation process, leading to the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), such as OH radicals and O3. It is known that O2 plasma can decrease the contact angle of plastics, thus indicating an increase in hydrophilicity2. This allows the microplastics to disperse into the liquid phase, increasing contact with the ROS and, therefore, increasing the efficiency of the plasma treatment. To determine and quantify the effectiveness of O2 plasma pretreatment for microplastic degradation, pre-treated and control microplastics will be treated with air plasma and compared. The treated microplastic solutions will undergo GPC and ATR-FTIR analysis, to quantify average molecular weight changes and understand surface modifications to the microplastic surface. The gas and liquid phases will be analyzed using HPLC and GCMS to identify and quantify the formation of carbon products and quantify the effects of pre-treatment. The goal of this work is to quantify the effectiveness of O2 plasma pre-treatment on microplastic degradation.

title: Three-dimensional Analytical Modeling of Plate-type Superconducting Electrodynamic Suspension for Electromagnetic Launch Application
authors: Jinzhao Zhao, Guangtong Ma, Cheng Luo, Zhenhua Su, Libin Cui, Menglong Guo, Jun Luo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: Electrodynamic suspension (EDS) has a broad application prospect in high-speed magnetic levitation transportations due to its advantages such as strong self-stabilization ability and simple control. However, in high-speed application scenarios, flat-plate permanent magnet electric suspension has high magnetic drag force and requires a large weight of the installed permanent magnets. To ameliorate these problems, this paper addresses the plate-type superconducting EDS system with a higher lift-to-drag ratio. First, the structure and principles of the superconducting EDS system are presented. Second, a three-dimensional analytical model of the electromagnetic force considering the transverse end effect is established by the magnetic vector potential equation and the boundary conditions at the end of the conductor plate. Among them, the source magnetic field of the superconducting magnets array required by the boundary conditions is solved by the coil discretization idea. Then, the reliability of the proposed analytical model is verified by comparing the computational results of the analytical model with the finite element simulation results. Finally, based on the three-dimensional analytical model, the suspension stiffness characteristics of the superconducting EDS system and the influence of specific parameters on the system's suspension performance are analyzed.

title: LLMA4OpenMP: A Large Language Model Based Agent for Automatic OpenMP Parallelization
authors: Haoran Zhu, Weidong Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: In the field of parallel computing, efficiently leveraging multi-core processors is essential. OpenMP, despite its popularity, poses challenges due to data-sharing and synchronization issues, making manual parallelization both time-consuming and prone to errors. Traditional compiler-based automation tools could be constrained to the final development stages. Recent advancements in large language models offer new opportunities for automation, with models like HPC-Coder demonstrating potential through fine-tuning. However, fine-tuning alone does not fully address the complexities of code comprehension. We introduce a novel agent that dynamically orchestrates static analysis tools to analyze code dependency and leverages in-context learning to generate OpenMP directives. Then, we implement this approach into a user-friendly plugin, namely LLMA4OpenMP, for Neovim and VS Code, enabling one-click OpenMP parallelization. We test our approach on the sophisticated AutoParBench and obtain an accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 3. 1 \%}$</tex>, outperforming the state-of-the-art LLM-based method. The source code for testing is available on the following GitHub repository: https://github.com/LLMA4OpenMP/LLMA4OpenMP_VScode

title: Optimization Method of Image Acquisition and Augmented Reality Synthesis in Virtual and Real Fusion
authors: Caiying Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Computation, Big-Data and Engineering (ICCBE)
abstract: This article introduces a method for virtual-real fusion image acquisition and augmented reality (AR) optimization based on a limited number of cameras. With image acquisition constrained by hardware costs and camera deployment limitations, blind spots exist in a camera’s vision field. To address this issue, cameras were positioned at several key locations, and AR synthesis technology and the virtual optimization method were used to compensate for blind spots, thereby enhancing the virtual-real fusion effect. First, the feature point detection, depth information processing, and occlusion relationship optimization were completed using the deep learning algorithm. Second, the multi-frame fusion and dynamic real-time adjustment methods were used to ensure the accuracy of the virtual-real effect, thereby improving the visual perception quality. The developed method in this study reduced hardware cost and enhanced visual effectiveness vis-à-vis simple rendering, demonstrating its practical value and innovation.

title: Autoencoder-Driven Latent Representation Learning for Language-Agnostic Disordered Speech Classification Using a Universal Feature Set
authors: Puneet Bawa, Virender Kadyan, Shareef Babu Kalluri
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: The disordered speech affects communication in various ways and presents overlapping acoustic characteristics, which makes automated classification more challenging. The traditional classification models are often disorder-specific and rely on isolated feature sets, which limits their applicability in real-world multilingual contexts. This study proposes a language-agnostic and disorder-generalized classification framework using a hybrid autoencoder-based latent space fusion approach, combining Vanilla, Variational, and SMOTE-Augmented Autoencoders. The proposed methodology establishes a universal set of common features across languages, making it adaptable to diverse linguistic backgrounds. It enables the classification of multiple disorders - including Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), Dysarthria, Hyperkinetic Dysarthria, Parkinson's Disease (PD), and Vox Senilis, based on shared acoustic features extracted from multilingual and imbalanced datasets. The proposed framework is evaluated on a combination of a self-collected Code-Mixed Children - Autism Spectrum Disorder (CoMiC-ASD) dataset and publicly available datasets. The CoMiC-ASD dataset comprises 55 speakers, including Hindi-English code-mixed speech from 28 children with ASD (23 male, 5 female) and 27 Typically Developing (TD) children (13 male, 14 female). The proposed model achieves 96.96% - 99.49% accuracy across machine learning models, except for decision trees (88.34 %).

title: Pure Chain Enabled Access Control System for Fire Detection in Military Communications
authors: Sium Bin Noor, Adnan Md Tayeb, Subroto Kumar Ghosh, Mohtasin Golam, Jae-Min Lee, Dong-Seong Kim
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: Military fire detection requires both rapid identification of hazards and strict protection of sensitive images. This paper presents an integrated Pure Chain Enabled framework that unites real-time YOLOv11n fire detection, Advanced Encryption Standard with Galois Counter Mode (AES-GCM) encryption, decentralized off-chain storage, and blockChain Enabled access control. Upon detection, annotated frames are encrypted using AES-GCM. The ciphertext is stored in Interplanetary File System (IPFS), while only the resulting Content Identifier (CID) and base64 encoded symmetric key are recorded on a Pure Chain. Authorized personnel must be preregistered in the contract and a client-side barrier verifies contract deployment and prompts user confirmation before allowing decryption. Using Pure Chain's Proof of Authority and Association (PoA2) consensus, the system delivers confidential, tamper-proof alerts with subsecond consensus and minimal encryption overhead. Performance tests on a Pure Chain test network confirm real-time viability demonstrating low latency and robust auditability. This framework offers a scalable and secure solution for critical military alerting scenarios where data integrity, confidentiality, and rapid response are paramount.

title: Robust Superdirective Beamforming Using a Uniform Circular Array with Directional Microphones
authors: Weilong Huang, Longfei Felix Yan, Emanuël A.P. Habets
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Superdirective beamformers with uniform circular arrays are attractive in practical applications since they exhibit high directivity factors (DFs) and steering flexibility. High DF is desired for acoustic noise and reverberation suppression. However, this beamformer is very sensitive to array imperfections due to its low white noise gains (WNGs) at low frequencies of speech. Recently, a robust superdirective beamformer with a closed-form generalized sidelobe canceller (GSC) structure has been proposed to achieve a tradeoff between the WNG and the DF via a rank-reduced blocking matrix of the GSC. In this paper, we propose a method to boost the robust superdirective beamformer based on two improvements: Firstly, we extend the robust superdirective beamformer to uniform circular arrays and leverage directional microphones to enhance the performance of superdirective beamformers; Secondly, we propose to design the blocking matrix via a particular differential beamforming method, i.e., circular differential directional microphone arrays. A comparative study shows that the proposed method brings about a noticeable improvement in WNG at the low frequencies (15 to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20 \text{d B}$</tex> at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \text{k H z}$</tex>) over the existing method, meanwhile enhancing the DF and exhibiting a more frequency-invariant beampattern.

title: Guitar Tone Morphing by Diffusion-Based Model
authors: Kuan-Yu Chen, Kuan-Lin Chen, Yu-Chieh Yu, Jian-Jiun Ding
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: In Music Information Retrieval (MIR), modeling and transforming the tone of musical instruments, particularly electric guitars, has gained increasing attention due to the richness of the instrument tone and the flexibility of expression. Tone morphing enables smooth transitions between different guitar sounds, giving musicians greater freedom to explore new textures and personalize their performances. This study explores learningbased approaches for guitar tone morphing, beginning with LoRA fine-tuning to improve the model performance on limited data. Moreover, we introduce a simpler method, named spherical interpolation using Music2Latent. It yields significantly better results than the more complex fine-tuning approach. Experiments show that the proposed architecture generates smoother and more natural tone transitions, making it a practical and efficient tool for music production and real-time audio effects.

title: Reliability Modeling and Evaluation Method for Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Swarm of Leader-Follower
authors: Mingxi Cai, Jialing Lin, Jianfeng Yang, Chunyang Ji
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Reliability, Maintainability and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: In order to evaluate the reliability of UAV (unmanned aerial vehicle) swarm of leader-follower, a modeling method based on OODA (observe, orient, decide, act) loops is proposed to evaluate the mission success rate. Firstly, the reliability indicator system from single machine to swarm is proposed. Secondly, based on the theory of leader-follower UAV swarm and OODA theory, the swarm reliability modeling method is studied. Then, based on matrix theory and graph theory, swarm reliability evaluation method is studied. Finally, the proposed analysis method is verified by simulation to show the change of mission success rate with mission duration. The simulation results show that the proposed swarm mission reliability method is effective, suitable for leader-follower swarm, and has practical engineering significance.

title: NeuraVis: Retina Damage Detection Using Transfer Learning
authors: Adam Yassin Mohamed, Syed Mohammad Ali, Tariq Ribhi Yaseen, Abdul Wahab Basalirwa, Osman Abul, Ashraf Elnagar
publish: 2025 International Conference on INnovations in Intelligent SysTems and Applications (INISTA)
abstract: This study explores the application of transfer learning to accurately classify retinal diseases using Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) images. Utilizing a publicly available dataset from Kaggle, a pre-trained deep learning model is fine-tuned to identify three specific retinal conditions: Choroidal Neovascularization (CNV), Drusen, and Diabetic Macular Edema (DME), alongside healthy (Normal) retinas. The primary objective is to enhance diagnostic capabilities in medical imaging, thereby supporting healthcare professionals in the early detection and treatment of retinal disorders. Given that approximately 30 million OCT scans are performed annually, the manual analysis of these images presents a significant challenge in terms of time and accuracy. Furthermore, the scarcity of large, annotated medical imaging datasets necessitates efficient learning techniques. By employing transfer learning, this study introduces NeuraVis, which demonstrates that high-performance classification (99.28% with MedViT) is achievable with a relatively small dataset, making it a viable solution in data-constrained environments. The outcomes of this study underscore the potential of deep learning in clinical settings, offering a pathway toward automated, accurate, and scalable diagnostic tools that can reduce the workload of medical professionals and improve patient outcomes.

title: Explainable AI-Driven Anti-Chatbot Detection System for Secure Digital Communication
authors: Sunil Joshi, Naresh Kumar Reddy Panga, Milankumar Rana, Aldo Francis Augustine, Aravind Raghu, Anil Kumar Bayya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: The evolutionary development has led to questions of security and trust in the increasingly popular use of AI-backed chatbots in digital communication platforms, especially in the emergence of malicious and adversarial bots. In this research, the suggested Explainable AI-Driven Anti-Chatbot Detection System would be able to control both robustness in detection and comprehensibility. The text normalization step together with the emoji-to-text mapping step are integrated to deal with informal and multilingual content, which enhances feature consistency. To increase efficiency and retain transparency, a SHAP-based Top-K feature selection strategy is used to find the most influential predictors. LightGBM classifier is used to detect and is implemented in a scalable, reproducible manner with scikit-learn pipelines. Sensitivity (96.8), specificity (95.4), and recall (97.1) are high and there is a very low false positive rate of 3.1%. In addition, the explainable framework offers insights that can be acted upon in classification decisions making the system more robust to trusting users. The proposed system solves the shortcomings of current methods, therefore, proving to be a guarantee in real-time secure communication against the changing chatbots.

title: Improvement in Variance Estimation in Variable-Step-Size Shared-Error NLMS Algorithm for Acoustic Echo and Noise Canceller
authors: Kenta Iwai
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: In this paper, we investigate the variance estimation method used in the variable-step-size shared-error normalized least mean square algorithm for the acoustic echo and noise canceller. The variance of the shared-error signal is typically estimated using a recursive equation, as this signal is readily available. In contrast, the disturbances of the acoustic echo canceller and adaptive noise canceller cannot be directly extracted from the microphone input, which contains both the desired signal and disturbances. Consequently, their variances are approximated by subtracting the correlated components from the variance of the shared-error signal. However, owing to misadjusted cross-correlation vectors, the variable-step-size parameters often become inappropriate. To address this, the scaling method for the cross-correlation vectors within the variance estimation is modified in this paper. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method improves stability during and after the double-talk period. Nevertheless, the update of the adaptive digital filters is continued under the double-talk period, degrading the overall echo and noise reduction performance.

title: A Transaction Pruning Mechanism based on DAG-Lattice Structure in the Internet of Vehicles
authors: Xiaodong Zhang, Juanjuan Wang, Leixiao Li, Pengfei Yue, Jianxiong Wan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Parallel and Distributed Processing with Applications (ISPA)
abstract: Blockchain technology in the Internet of Vehicles (IoV) offers potential solutions to security challenges. However, the significant redundancy in blockchain storage makes its implementation in IoV environments difficult. While numerous studies have addressed blockchain storage scalability, none of these solutions are directly applicable to the IoV. To tackle this issue, the present paper proposes a transaction pruning mechanism based on the directed acyclic graph lattice structure within the IoV. This mechanism takes into account the impact of transaction pruning on system security, transaction timeliness, and network resource usage. Given the highly dynamic nature of IoV, the paper employs a random selection-based hyper-heuristic algorithm to optimize the transaction pruning strategy. Experimental results show that the proposed approach outperforms other optimization methods in terms of average target deviation, target variance, and success rate.

title: Intelligent Street Lighting with Automated Fault Detection and Dynamic Energy Management
authors: Jayarama Pradeep, Krishna Raju S, Maheswaran A S, Joshua Daniel S, Raghav Vyas
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Regular street lights on isolated roadways use too much electricity, cause light pollution, and are hard to change. A smart road lighting fixtures system is suggested to remedy this. It would make localized "bubbles" of light that follow cars and go back to dull levels when they are not moving. This dynamic control improves strength performance and keeps nighttime animals safe. The technology also has computerized fault detection built in, which helps find problems in real time and lowers any extra costs. An app keeps an eye on operational data to make sure that all parts are being watched. The solution encourages long-term safety and protection in regions with little traffic or that are sensitive to the environment.. [1].

title: Smart Workplace Management: Leveraging Cloud Computing for Operational Efficiency
authors: A. Arul Oli, J. Anand, Prabakaran Paranthaman, P. Viyayalakshmi, S. Kumaran
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Effective workplace management is essential for better operations, improved teamwork, and more efficient use of resources by today‘s businesses. A system for managing smart workplaces that uses predictive analytics and intelligent automation to overcome issues of scaling up, working together, and being adaptable in real time. The system proposed here is designed with multiple layers, using cloud resource management, task automation engines, and communication modules, and tested with CloudSim on real workplace operations data. The results reflect much better performance, showing that 85% of tasks are now automated, "resource utilization" went up by 46.5%, decision accuracy was improved by 41.9%, employee satisfaction is at 9.2/10, faster employee responses decreased by 44.4%, the time when tasks couldn't be processed went down by 66.7% and costs were reduced overall by 48%. These results demonstrate that the system effectively enhances daily tasks at the workplace. The final section highlights the system‘s ability to enhance an organization‘s performance and meet the requirements of a modern work environment, thereby shaping its future improvement.

title: TAPA-ICL: Taxonomy-Aware Prompt Augmentation for in-Context Learning in Music Understanding
authors: Jiahao Zhao, Yunjia Li, Kazuyoshi Yoshii
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: This paper presents TAPA-ICL, a novel in-context learning (ICL) framework for few/zero-shot symbolic music understanding task that generates human-readable analysis. Conventional ICL approaches mainly rely on the ability of large language models (LLMs) to infer patterns and tasks from contextual examples. However, while LLMs have shown basic capability of understanding symbolic music, how to enhance such capability via additional context still remains unexplored. To tackle this issue, we focus on the two major challenges as follows: (1) Sparsity of Score Input through taxonomy-aware prompt augmentation (TAPA) that distills label-to-feature profiles, reducing context length by over 10 times; and (2) Complexity of Musical Semantics Reasoning via structured chain-of-thought (CoT) prompts enforcing feature extraction, context-aware analysis, and decisionmaking. By combining TAPA strategy and the CoT reasoning prompts, our method enables effective few/zero-shot adaptation across emotion recognition, composer identification, and genre classification tasks. Experimental results show that our TAPAICL method significantly outperforms conventional few-shot ICL baselines (including those based on ultra-large and mixture of experts (MoE) models) on each downstream task and achieves slightly weaker performance to existing many-shot approaches.

title: Internal Threats to Deepfake Detectors: A Weight Tampering Scenario on MesoNet
authors: Seoah Myeong, Yonggang Kim
publish: 2025 International Conference on Mobile, Military, Maritime IT Convergence (ICMIC)
abstract: With the advancement of deepfake technologies, AI-based detection systems have emerged as essential tools for verifying content authenticity across various domains, including journalism, social media, and digital forensics. However, existing research has primarily focused on adversarial attacks that manipulate input data or model architectures, while threats involving direct manipulation of a model's internal parameters have received comparatively little attention. This study presents a weight tampering attack scenario that targets MesoNet [1], a lightweight convolutional neural network (CNN) designed for deepfake detection, by covertly modifying the weights of its internal Dense (fully connected) layers. Our experimental results demonstrate that, under conditions where the inputs remain visually indistinguishable (LPIPS = 0.0), the detection performance can degrade by up to 0.507, thereby disrupting the model's decision-making without altering the input image. In particular, dense layers adjacent to the final classification stage play a crucial role in interpreting high-level visual features such as texture, structure, and edges. Even minimal changes to the parameters in these layers can significantly distort the detection output, allowing visually normal images to evade detection or induce misclassification. Although demonstrated on Meso4, the proposed approach may be applicable to other CNN-based detectors with similar architectural traits. By empirically verifying the feasibility of silently undermining a detector's internal trust mechanism, this research highlights a structural vulnerability inherent in current deepfake detection systems. It further suggests that, to ensure the long-term robustness of AI-based detection systems, security design should move toward protecting and verifying internal parameters within tamper-resistant, isolated environments.

title: A Robust Proactive Communication Strategy for Distributed Active Noise Control Systems
authors: Junwei Ji, Dongyuan Shi, Zhengding Luo, Boxiang Wang, Ziyi Yang, Haowen Li, Woon-Seng Gan
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Distributed multichannel active noise control (DMCANC) systems assign the high computational load of conventional centralized algorithms across multiple processing nodes, leveraging inter-node communication to collaboratively suppress unwanted noise. However, communication overhead can undermine algorithmic stability and degrade overall performance. To address this challenge, we propose a robust communication framework that integrates adaptive-fixed-filter switching and the mixed-gradient combination strategy. In this approach, each node independently executes a single-channel filtered reference least mean square (FxLMS) algorithm while monitoring real-time noise reduction levels. When the current noise reduction performance degrades compared to the previous state, the node halts its adaptive algorithm, switches to a fixed filter, and simultaneously initiates a communication request. The exchanged information comprises the difference between the current control filter and the filter at the time of the last communication, equivalent to the accumulated gradient sum during non-communication intervals. Upon receiving neighboring cumulative gradients, the node employs a mixed-gradient combination method to update its control filter, subsequently reverting to the adaptive mode. This proactive communication strategy and adaptive-fixed switching mechanism ensure system robustness by mitigating instability risks caused by communication issues. Simulations demonstrate that the proposed method achieves noise reduction performance comparable to centralized algorithms while maintaining stability under communication constraints, highlighting its practical applicability in real-world distributed ANC scenarios.

title: Operation of the Collective Thomson Scattering Diagnostic in the OP2.2 Experimental Campaign of the Wendelstein7-X Stellarator
authors: S. Ponomarenko, D. Moseev, T. Stange, D. Straus, J. Jelonnek, L. Krier, H. P. Laqua, S. Marsen, M. Misko, S. K. Nielsen, R. Ragona, J. Rasmussen, M. Salewski, R. C. Wolf, J. Zimmermann
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: The collective Thomson scattering diagnostic (CTS) at the Wendelstein 7-X (W7-X) stellarator is designed for routine ion temperature measurements and quantifying the fast-ion velocity distribution function [1]. The diagnostic measures the spectrum of electromagnetic radiation from the probing gyrotron beam scattered by collective microscopic fluctuations in a plasma. Due to the presence of strong background electron cyclotron emission (ECE), detecting the weak spectral features of fast ions is challenging. To minimize background emission and enhance the sensitivity of the microwave receiver, the CTS diagnostic was upgraded to operate at a low-level ECE background between its second and third harmonics [1], [2]. Recent applications of the CTS diagnostic during experimental campaigns OP2.1 and OP2.2 at the W7-X stellarator confirmed reliable thermal ion measurements and showed the presence of fast ions during the operation of the neutral beam injection [3]. The fast ion detection results are currently under analysis. However, in certain plasma discharges, we observed signs of potential nonlinearities and saturation of the microwave receiver. This work focuses on identifying possible sources of the strong signals that interfere with the receiver operation and implementing countermeasures in its design. The operation of the probing gyrotron and its stray radiation, which can bypass front-end rejection filters in the radiometer, is analyzed. The updated radiometer is characterized in terms of linearity, dynamic range, and sensitivity. Test results are discussed and the limitations of the radiometer are defined.

title: ECG Arrhythmia Detection Using Complete Ensemble Empirical Mode Decomposition with Adaptive Noise (CEEMDAN)
authors: Grace Amelia, Annisa Humairani, Tito Waluyo Purboyo, Dziban Naufal
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Instrumentation, Control, and Automation (ICA)
abstract: Arrhythmia, a serious cardiac disorder, demands early and accurate detection to prevent severe outcomes. This study presents an automated arrhythmia classification framework combining Complete Ensemble Empirical Mode Decomposition with Adaptive Noise (CEEMDAN) and Support Vector Machine (SVM) classification. Two feature extraction strategies were evaluated: CEEMDAN alone and CEEMDAN preceded by Independent Component Analysis (ICA) for enhanced noise reduction and signal separation. Tested on the MIT-BIH Arrhythmia Database with five AAMI heartbeat classes, both methods achieved high accuracy, 98.10% for CEEMDAN alone and 98.04% for combining ICA and CEEMDAN, with precision, recall, and F1-scores above 96% across all classes, including difficult ventricular (V) and fusion beats (F). The proposed approach rivals state-of-the-art techniques, demonstrating the effectiveness of CEEMDAN and ICA in extracting meaningful signal components for reliable clinical arrhythmia detection.

title: Detection and Classification of Pneumonia from Chest X-rays Using Deep Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: P. Malathi, Kanith M, Kavi Priya. M, Keerthana. S M
publish: 2025 International Conference on Recent Innovation in Science Engineering and Technology (ICRISET)
abstract: Pneumonia is a widespread illness, especially in poor countries with minimal radiological evaluation. The difficulty of automatically identifying and classifying pneumonia from chest X-rays may be addressed by a deep CNN-based architecture. The method combines the preprocessing techniques like CLAHE and Sobel edge detection for the feature clarity, CNN feature extraction, and classification into bacterial, viral, and normal categories. To increase interpretability, Grad-CAM++ is used for visual explanation of model predictions. The dataset of chest X-rays used to train and test the model was formed from 5,863 labeled images of patients from a Kaggle-based chest X-ray dataset. Experimental evaluation achieves superior performance with 96.87% accuracy, 95.43% precision, 96.02% recall, and an F1-score of 95.72%, outperforming benchmark methods. The results prove the efficiency of the model and its ability to assist in early pneumonia diagnostics in the clinical and remote healthcare settings.

title: Sparse Echo Reconstruction of Micro-Motion Targets Under the Joint Constraints of Low-Rank and Periodic Consistency
authors: Mingming Jin, Jun Wang, Shaoming Wei, Peng Lei
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: In practical scenarios, affected by electronic countermeasures or multitasking requirements, radar echoes from the same micro-motion target inevitably exhibit sparsity. To solve this problem, this paper proposes a sparse echo reconstruction method for micro-motion targets based on joint constraints of low-rank property and periodic consistency, aiming to enhance reconstruction performance. First, the wideband sparse echo signal model under random missing sampling (RMS) for micro-motion targets is established; then, inspired by the concept of matrix completion (MC), the “periodic consistency” constraint is introduced into the objective function, constructing an optimization model for echo signal reconstruction based on the low-rank property. Meanwhile, the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) reconstructs echoes through alternate iterations and gradual optimization. Finally, simulation experiments validate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

title: Gender Differences in Muscle Endurance in Wall Climbing Activities: Analysis of Surface Electromyography (sEMG) Signals in Time Domain
authors: Latifa Majesta Saputra, Hesty Susanti, Muhammad Hablul Barri, Liana Nafisa Saftari, Salsabila Aurellia, Annisa Rayina Putri
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Instrumentation, Control, and Automation (ICA)
abstract: Wall climbing is a physically demanding sport that requires endurance and strength, particularly in the arms, shoulders, and core. It challenges the body’s ability to maintain strength and balance against gravity. Muscular endurance plays a crucial role in maintaining performance during prolonged climbing sessions, and climbers who engage in regular training experience muscle adaptations that enhance their endurance, strength, and overall performance. The Flexor Carpi Radialis (FCR) and Deltoideus (DEL) muscles, essential for wrist and arm movements, are key contributors to endurance in wall climbing. This study examines gender differences in muscle endurance and strength using surface electromyography (sEMG) to improve training, performance, and minimize injury risks. This study examined performance differences between males and females. Four participants (two males and two females, mean age 21.75 ± 2.63 years) climbed a 7A+ course while their muscle activity was analyzed using Mean Absolute Value (MAV) and Root Mean Square (RMS). The FCR and DEL muscles were evaluated for their role in wall climbing. Statistical analysis using ANOVA and Tukey’s HSD post-hoc test showed significant differences in muscle endurance between males and females, particularly in the RMS features of the DEL muscle (p = 0.004) and the Combined Muscle group (p = 0.029). These findings suggest that gender influences muscular endurance in wall climbing, with technique and experience also contributing to performance outcomes.

title: Depolymerization of Polylactic Acid Using Combined Spark Discharge Plasma and Ultrasound Technology in Aqueous Medium: A Novel Approach to Sustainable Polymer Recycling
authors: K. Hadian Rasnani, V. Brüser, R. Rataj, V. Hahn, T. de los Arcos, G. Grundmeier
publish: 2025 IEEE Pulsed Power &amp; Plasma Science (PPPS)
abstract: Polylactic acid (PLA) is one of the most widely produced bio-based and sustainable polymer used in food packaging, textiles, and medical applications. While PLA is biodegradable, its degradation under natural conditions can take months, necessitating methods to accelerate the process [1]. Ideally, a depolymerization method transforms PLA into its monomers or oligomers, facilitating a sustainable recycling.

title: Excitation of twisted waves by a circular phased array of loop antennas with the axes tangential to the array circumference in a magnetized plasma
authors: A.V. Kudrin, T.M. Zaboronkova, A.S. Zaitseva, N.V. Shchapina, N.V. Yurasova
publish: 2025 Days on Diffraction (DD)
abstract: Radiation from a circular phased array of loop antennas in a cold homogeneous magnetoplasma is studied in the case where the symmetry axis of the array is aligned with an external static magnetic field superimposed on the plasma, while the axes of loop antennas are oriented tangentially to the array circumference. The total power radiated from such a system and its partial powers going to different azimuthal field harmonics in the whistler frequency range are determined.

title: Recognizing and Recording Grasped Objects for Assisting Elderly at Home to Find Missing Items
authors: Toshinori Shindo, Takuya Nakata, Sinan Chen, Sachio Saiki, Kiyoshi Yasuda, Masahide Nakamura
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACIS 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD)
abstract: In Japan, the number of elderly people and dementia patients is on the rise. They often face the issue of forgetting where they placed their belongings. When they are unable to remember the location of an item, not only do they themselves have to search for it, but their family members and caregivers are also involved in the search, increasing the burden on everyone involved. Therefore, reducing this burden has become a significant challenge. To address this issue, this study proposes a "Grasped Object Recognition and Recording Service" that utilizes cameras installed in the room and image recognition technology to identify and record objects grasped by individuals. The implementation focused on the recognition and recording of the grasped objects. As a result, the system successfully achieved a practical level of accuracy in recognizing and recording the objects held by people in the room.

title: Honey Adulteration Detection via Robust Diffusion Classifier and Hyperspectral Imaging
authors: Weihao Tang, Guyang Zhang, Waleed Abdulla
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: Honey is the third-most adulterated food product in the world. Recently, AI-based hyperspectral detection has exhibited promising superiority in classifying pure and adulterated honey. However, the classification robustness of hyperspectral-based models has barely been assessed in existing studies, leading to the classification model being catastrophically “collapsed” under the attack of perturbations from honey adulteration. A trustworthy detective model is anticipated to classify the adulterated honey reliably, irrespective of perturbation attacks. In light of this, we propose a modeling strategy that views adulteration perturbations as variables. On top of that, accumulated negative log-likelihoods of conditional generative models are further wrapped with the Bayesian rule to certify the classification results, which improves classification robustness and accuracy of spectral detection models under attacks of adulteration perturbations. The results of empirical experiments imply that our proposed method successfully outperforms the state-of-the-art in applying hyperspectral techniques to classify the authenticity of honey. The precision score is still averagely over 85 % for classifying adulterated honey when adulteration concentrations are shifted, and the recall score is over 85 % when unobserved honey types attack. Consequently, our findings are eligible to serve as a potential way to improve the robustness and accuracy of hyperspectral detection models against food fraud.

title: Lyric-Aware Karaoke Background Video Selection Using Large Language Models and Moment Retrieval
authors: Tomoki Ariga, Jun Taniguchi, Yosuke Higuchi, Sayaka Toma, Kunihiro Abe, Rie Shigyo, Tetsuji Ogawa
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: We propose a method for constructing coherent background videos by automatically selecting and combining video segments that semantically align with a song's lyrics. Rather than simply visualizing the literal content of the lyrics, the selected segments aim to convey scenes and atmospheres inferred through a deeper interpretation of their meaning. In the proposed approach, a large language model is first used to interpret the lyrics in terms of multiple attributes, such as characters, season, time of day, weather, location, and mood. These interpretations then serve as queries for moment retrieval, enabling the extraction of relevant video segments. To further optimize the composition of segments assigned to each part of the song (e.g., verse, bridge, chorus), a re-ranking step based on a second round of moment retrieval is applied to the initial retrieval results, ensuring global consistency across the final background video. The effectiveness of the proposed automatic video selection method based on lyric interpretation is validated through a subjective evaluation experiment comparing the generated videos with those used in actual karaoke systems.

title: High-Resolution ISAR Imaging for High-Speed Targets Via Joint Intra-Pulse and Inter-Pulse Translational Motion Compensation
authors: Jiabao Wang, Shuai Shao, Jiaqi Wei
publish: 2025 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC)
abstract: High-resolution inverse synthetic aperture radar (ISAR) imaging technology is a key method for achieving situational awareness and precise recognition of high-speed moving targets. However, the high-speed movement of targets can cause intra-pulse and inter-pulse translational motion errors, resulting in severe defocusing of ISAR images. To address this issue, this paper proposes an algorithm for high-resolution ISAR imaging of highspeed targets via joint intra-pulse and inter-pulse translational motion compensation (JIPMC). This algorithm utilizes an improved matched filter to achieve precise pulse compression, effectively eliminating intra-pulse motion errors. Based on the homogeneity of intra-pulse and inter-pulse translational motion errors, this paper constructs an intra-pulse and inter-pulse translational motion error model. Combined with optimal parameter estimation, it achieves joint correction of intra-pulse and inter-pulse translational motion errors. The proposed algorithm avoids the cascaded processing of intra-pulse motion compensation (IPMC), envelope alignment, and initial phase correction, significantly reducing error propagation and improving the accuracy and robustness of motion compensation. For optimal parameter estimation, the proposed algorithm utilizes the artificial bee colony (ABC) algorithm to solve the optimization problem under the minimum entropy criterion. The ABC algorithm combines global search and local optimization capabilities, thereby effectively guaranteeing the global optimality of the solution. Experimental results validate the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed method for high-resolution ISAR imaging of high-speed targets.
